site_title: Hip new hangouts
summary: Two new establishments have opened in Singapore, redefining the dining and hotel experiences. Odette, a French fine-dining restaurant, offers a feminine ambience with 12 tables and a private room. Designed by Sacha Leong, the space features cracked marble flooring, curved vinyl panels, and a hanging installation of photographs of ingredients. Hotel Yan, a 69-room boutique hotel, boasts an industrial look with a reception desk made of concrete and bar stools from bicycle wheels. The hotel also features a bistro with bicycle wheel bar stools and a room with a utility stand. Meanwhile, YAN, a fine-dining Cantonese restaurant, has a glass-enclosed space with a semi-transparent oak screen and strategically scattered bronze strips, connecting diners with the art gallery location.

site_title: China mulls allowing individuals to invest more abroad
summary: China is considering relaxing its capital controls to allow individuals to invest more abroad, potentially unleashing a large influx of funds. The People's Bank of China is studying a policy to let "qualified" individuals invest in stocks, property, and financial products through the Shanghai Free Trade Zone. This move could be part of China's efforts to achieve complete capital account liberalization and strengthen its economy. The central bank announced the plan after a top-level Communist Party meeting, which discussed the country's development plans for the next five years.

site_title: China to start work on super-collider in 2020: report
summary: China plans to start construction on its world's largest super-collider in 2020, aiming to increase understanding of the Higgs boson, a fundamental building block of the universe. The facility, expected to generate seven times the energy of the LHC, will produce millions of Higgs bosons and surpass the current capacity of CERN's Large Hadron Collider. The project is part of China's efforts to become a world leader in basic scientific research, with the facility expected to be operational from 2025.

site_title: FOMC statement provides main focus for markets
summary: The US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) announced its readiness to start raising interest rates in December, sending markets into a frenzy. The Singapore Straits Times Index plummeted 2.3% over the week, with OCBC's stock dropping 4.6% after the bank's disappointing third-quarter earnings. UOB's shares surged 17% on a strong third-quarter net profit and special dividend announcement. Analysts now debate the likelihood of a December US rate hike, with the federal funds futures market's probability dropping to 48%.

site_title: GLP posts 27% jump in Q2 profit
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 27.4% jump in net profit for the second quarter to US$114 million, driven by growth in China, development gains in Japan, and entry into the US market. Revenue slipped 1.9% to US$189.3 million due to the sale of properties and yen weakening. The group's share of joint venture results increased 76.9% to US$34.3 million. GLP will start its largest Japanese development project, GLP Nagareyama, with a total investment cost of US$490 million.

site_title: Fancy getting a hot meal from a vending machine?
summary: Singapore is exploring ways for food and beverage businesses to reduce rental and labor costs by using vending machines to serve hot meals. The Food Services Productivity Plan, launched at a conference, aims to introduce new business models such as food vending machines in housing estates and "grab-and-go" food products sold through supermarkets. This move is expected to alleviate manpower pressures in the sector, where the workforce grew at 8.5% a year from 2004 to 2014, and alleviate rising costs for F&B businesses.

images.alt_text: A packed meal from a Chef In Box vending machine operated by JR Vending.

site_title: KL set to sell state-owned land
summary: The Malaysian government plans to sell its state-owned land to monetize assets and boost the economy. Two deals have been announced, with more expected, as the federal government still owns prime land around Kuala Lumpur and near planned MRT stations. This move is seen as a step to pump-prime the sluggish economy, and property consultants anticipate more disposals of state-owned lands in the future.

site_title: EU opens antitrust probe into Britain O2 deal
summary: The European Commission launched an antitrust probe into the proposed sale of O2, Britain's second-largest mobile operator, to a Hong Kong investment company, CK Hutchinson. The commission expressed concerns that the merger could lead to higher prices, less choice, and reduced innovation for UK customers. Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager will review the transaction by March 16, 2016, and may demand concessions to alleviate concerns. The probe follows similar EU concerns over reduced market competition, including a failed merger in Denmark last month.

site_title: Better late than never
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Janet Yellen is expected to signal a rate rise in December, contrary to her September postponement. The Fed has read the economic signals and ignored market noise, citing worrisome signs of irrational behavior and impatience among emerging market central banks. With macro signals flashing red, including employment numbers, GDP growth, and inflation, the Fed is set to end the nine-year period of no rate change. The decision is seen as a welcome correction after Yellen's previous hesitation.

site_title: S'pore market cap breaks 5-month slide with 6.3% pop in October
summary: Singapore's market capitalization broke a five-month slide in October with a 6.3% increase to S$881.8 billion. The gains were widespread, with larger stocks outperforming smaller ones, and all major industry classifications showing growth. The largest 20% of companies saw a 6.5% increase, while the smallest 20% gained 3.4%. However, analysts caution that the rally may be short-lived, citing concerns over corporate earnings, commodity prices, and non-performing loans.

site_title: US: Stocks end banner October on down note
summary: US stocks ended October on a down note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 92.26 points (0.52%) to 17,663.54. Despite a 8.5% gain for the month, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 10.05 (0.48%) and 20.53 (0.40%) respectively. Valeant Pharmaceuticals plummeted 15.9%, while ExxonMobil and Chevron rose after reporting lower earnings. Other stocks including Baidu, CVS Health, and LinkedIn also saw significant price movements.

site_title: Getting hot and steamy
summary: The Thermae Bath Spa in Bath, England, offers a unique experience with its rooftop thermal pool, steam rooms, and treatment rooms. The public can access the facilities through a two-hour spa session, priced between £32 and £35. A private session in the Cross Bath, a 18th-century site where natural spring water emerges unadulterated, costs £18-£20 per person or £125-£195 for exclusive use. The spa is owned by the YTL group and is conveniently located next to The Gainsborough Bath Spa.

images.alt_text: UNIQUE EXPERIENCE: (Right) The Cross Bath consists of a single pool where the natural spring water emerges unadulterated to the surface; (Left) Thermae Bath Spa's roof top pool.

site_title: Manufacturing, services firms turn bearish
summary: Manufacturing and services firms in Singapore have turned bearish about their short-term business prospects due to soft global economic conditions. A higher proportion of companies now expect a reduction in business activity over the next six months, with 26% of manufacturers and 21% of services firms foreseeing a worsening situation. The main concerns are the slowdown in China and weak oil and commodity prices, with the chemicals and electronics clusters being the most pessimistic. The overall sentiment is a significant deterioration from the positive net weighted balance seen a quarter earlier.

site_title: China manufacturing activity shrinks for third straight month: govt
summary: China's manufacturing sector activity shrank for the third consecutive month in October, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.8, down from the previous month. This signals a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy, contradicting policymakers' claims. The factory and workshop sector, crucial to China's economy, is experiencing a prolonged contraction.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. However, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2 with similar operating losses to H1. London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Dollar slips on poor US data
summary: The US dollar slipped to a 1.1003 against the Euro and 120.67 yen on Friday, following disappointing data on US income and consumption growth in September. Consumer income and spending rose only 0.1% last month, the slowest rate since January, bolstering the argument against a December Federal Reserve rate increase. Experts say this sluggish pace could be a weak point in economic growth in the fourth quarter, making a rate hike less likely.

site_title: Avoiding herd instinct amid uncertainty
summary: Investors can exploit short-term market volatility by focusing on the extremes of valuation and being patient. Avoiding herd-like behavior and overpaying for short-term certainty can harm long-term returns. Instead, look for undervalued stocks with strong fundamentals, such as improving trend fundamentals and balance sheet strength in Japan. The Japanese equity market offers opportunities for investors willing to avoid the herd and focus on value creation, driven by prospects for higher payouts and earnings growth, as well as structural changes in corporate behavior.

images.alt_text: TIME WILL TELL: History shows that investors willing to exploit shorter-term market anomalies by applying a disciplined long-term valuation approach will be more than compensated for their patience.

site_title: Global LNG glut pushing producers, importers into spot market
summary: Global liquefied natural gas (LNG) producers and importers are shifting to spot market trading due to a looming supply surplus, driven by new capacity in Australia and North America. The glut, combined with rising demand, is expected to pressure prices and establish a liquid commodity market. Major players disagree on the speed of market development, but consultancy Wood Mackenzie says prices will remain under pressure until the end of the decade. Japan is also adapting to the changing market by renewing only minimum long-term contracts and opting for mid-term and short-term purchases.

site_title: Hands down, it's hands-on
summary: Julio Portalatin, former president and CEO of Mercer, credits his management style, "management by walking around," to Tom Peters' book In Search of Excellence. He applied this style in his early roles, including as new business coordinator at Allstate Insurance, where he successfully implemented a 30-day policy clearance system and managed the transition of seven women being phased out due to computerization. By taking an interest in their lives and skills, he influenced them to retrain and stay with the company. This approach allowed him to build trust and collaborate with his team, ultimately leading to successful outcomes.

site_title: US$1b Quebec support for Bombardier jet project
summary: Bombardier, an aerospace manufacturer, will receive a US$1 billion bailout from the Canadian province of Quebec to help ease concerns about the company's cash situation. The bailout comes as the company struggles with its new commercial jet project, the CSeries airliners, which has been marred by delays, cost overruns, and a lack of orders. The project was intended to be a game-changer for the company, but its struggles have raised concerns about its future.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Bank lending in Singapore fell in September, driven by weaker business loans. Manufacturing firms turned pessimistic about their future prospects, while services firms became bearish about their short-term business prospects. The Singapore government plans to help food companies adopt digital solutions to boost productivity. Meanwhile, US shale oil cost savings are dwindling, and Singapore shares closed weaker for the week due to US interest rate concerns.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's hospitality sector saw strong international visitor arrivals in July and August, driven by a recovery in Chinese visitor numbers and the SG50 promotional campaign. This growth further boosted the sector.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse wants to expand China equity link to IPOs
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd plans to expand its equity link with China, allowing mainland investors to access initial public offerings of foreign companies. The move aims to increase liquidity in China and attract more Chinese funds. CEO Charles Li estimates that Chinese investors hold $22 trillion of investable assets. Similar links for bonds, commodities, and derivatives are also being considered. This expansion follows a successful Stock Connect program that started almost a year ago, and comes as China strengthens its economic ties with Europe and other countries.

site_title: Samsung seeks to supply tech to auto industry
summary: Samsung Electronics is expanding its presence in the auto industry, ramping up research and development for electric vehicles and components, with a focus on software, services, and components worth around $500 billion. The company has filed over 1,800 US patents related to electric vehicles and components since 2010, but has yet to land significant business. Analysts say Samsung needs a unified approach to build its supplier presence in the industry, and may consider acquiring established players to accelerate its entry.

site_title: BNP pleased with how WTA Finals is turning out
summary: BNP Paribas, the title sponsor of the WTA Finals, expressed satisfaction with the event's organization, citing a successful start with the 2015 tournament in Singapore. The bank, which has supported tennis since 1973, is proud to have hosted the event in Singapore since 2014, and the 2015 edition boasts a record US$7 million prize purse. The bank's We Are Tennis Fan Academy was also launched in Singapore, aiming to create a supportive atmosphere for players and fans.

images.alt_text: A PLACE FOR TENNIS SUPER-FANS: BNP Paribas' Sebastien Guyader (in suit) with members of the newly launched We Are Tennis Fan Academy at the OCBC Arena. The academy will recruit and train enthusiastic tennis fans who go for matches and support the players at tournaments sponsored by the bank.

site_title: SEC approves new crowdfunding rules
summary: US securities regulators approved new crowdfunding rules, allowing start-up companies to raise money from non-accredited investors online. The measure, part of the 2012 JOBS Act, relaxes federal regulations to spur small business growth. The SEC voted 3 to 1 in favor of the measure, which previously limited fundraising to accredited investors with a minimum net worth or income of $1 million or $200,000, respectively. The approval paves the way for mom-and-pop investors to invest in start-ups over the internet.

site_title: Three levels for Asean to fight haze: Masagos
summary: Singapore's Environment and Water Resources Minister Masagos Zulkifli has proposed three levels to combat the haze in South-east Asia: Asean, bilateral, and consumer levels. At the Asean level, he advocates for peatland management and extinguishing forest fires quickly. On a bilateral level, Singapore urges neighboring countries to work with Indonesia to address the haze. Consumers can also play a role by supporting environmentally conscious companies. The Asean environment ministers have expressed concern over the unprecedented severity of the haze and reaffirmed their commitment to addressing the issue.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Eurozone inflation exits negative territory in October
summary: Eurozone inflation rose to 0% in October, exiting negative territory, according to Eurostat statistics. This low inflation level has prompted European Central Bank president Mario Draghi to consider boosting its stimulus, including its bond-buying program. Eurozone unemployment dropped to 10.8% in September. These developments indicate the European Central Bank may soon increase its stimulus to support economic growth.

site_title: India asset sale target slips away on market swings
summary: India's asset sale target, set by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley at 695 billion rupees, has slipped away due to low commodity prices depressing valuations of state-run energy companies. After five months, the government has raised only about 20% of the target, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration may be forced to cut spending or defer infrastructure projects to meet the fiscal deficit goal. The government has made four asset sales so far, raising 127 billion rupees, and has a pipeline of over a dozen stocks to unload.

images.alt_text: WARINESS: The struggle to sell Indian state assets is one of PM Modi's biggest obstacles to reducing the fiscal deficit to an eight-year low.

site_title: Countries back roadmap towards 5G: UN
summary: The United Nations has approved a roadmap for developing 5G mobile networks, dubbed IMT-2020, which aims to harmonize the development of next-generation networks and deliver data speeds up to 1,000 times faster than current 4G systems. The plan, approved by radiocommunication experts from the UN's 193 member countries, is expected to pave the way for lightning-quick downloads and driverless cars, with a potential rollout in the 2020 timeframe. This could enable the transfer of data from Internet-connected devices at unprecedented speeds.

site_title: Credit Suisse says investigated by Swiss, US authorities over Fifa banking links
summary: Credit Suisse is under investigation by Swiss and US authorities over its banking links with Fifa officials accused of bribery and corruption. The investigation focuses on whether the bank waved through improper transactions or failed to observe anti-money laundering regulations. Credit Suisse is cooperating with the authorities and the probe is linked to the May 20, 2015 indictment of nine top Fifa officials and five businessmen. The scandal has led to pressure on Fifa to undergo deep reform and become more accountable and transparent.

site_title: China policy change seen having little baby-food impact
summary: China has eased its one-child policy, allowing couples to have two children, but this policy change is unlikely to significantly boost demand for baby food. Stock prices for baby-food makers like Danone SA and Mead Johnson Nutrition Co. surged after the announcement, but analysts predict little impact from the policy change. The change is expected to have a minimal effect on the industry, with some companies already experiencing growth due to other factors.

site_title: Oil industry slipping into the red
summary: The oil industry is experiencing a significant downturn, with top firms posting Q3 losses and a grim outlook for 2016. Seven of the top 20 European and North American oil and gas producers reported losses, including Royal Dutch Shell, Eni, and Occidental Petroleum Corp. Companies are cutting spending and jobs, and tapping debt markets to cover costs. Analysts expect Brent crude to average US$58.60 a barrel in 2016, below the US$78 required to cover spending and dividend payments.

site_title: Jubilee jewels
summary: Cartier is hosting its first-ever public exhibition of contemporary high jewelry in Singapore to commemorate the country's 50th anniversary. The exhibition, "Etourdissant Cartier," features 600 pieces, including 60 world premieres, showcasing the brand's 160-year history. The collection is on display at the Singapore Pinacotheque de Paris in Fort Canning Park until the end of the day, offering fans a unique opportunity to view the high-end jewels. This event marks a significant milestone for Cartier in Southeast Asia and Australia.

site_title: Luxury goods market heading for weakest growth since Lehman crash
summary: The global luxury goods market is expected to experience its weakest growth since the 2009 Lehman crash, with sales projected to rise only 1% to 253 billion euros in 2015. This decline is attributed to a combination of stock market turmoil, a strong US dollar, and a commodity price rout, which have curbed demand for high-end items like designer dresses and shoes.

site_title: Mizuno school may produce next S'pore pro
summary: The Mizuno Golf School Asia Headquarters has opened at the National Service Resort & Country Club in Singapore, offering programs for junior golfers, competitive players, and recreational golfers. According to USPGA Master Professional Joe Thiel, the school could produce the next Singaporean professional golfer in a shorter time frame compared to Japan, where four youngsters qualified for the Japan Women's and Men's Open after five years of Mizuno instruction. The school aims to develop life skills and character traits that will last a lifetime, with a focus on creating a long-term golfing learning environment in Asia.

images.alt_text: BUDDING PROS: Mr Tan teaching some of the junior players at the National Service Resort & Country Club. The school has been fitted with a performance lab which has a FlightScope Launch Monitor, V1 Pro Swing Analysis, and various training aids.

site_title: China mulls law to boost film industry
summary: China is reviewing a draft law to boost its film industry, aiming to expand cultural and commercial success globally. The law, which offers financing incentives and tax cuts, would ensure freedom to produce films and perfect film examination standards. China's box office is expected to overtake the US market by 2017, with locally made films accounting for 60% of total ticket sales this year. Critics argue that China's strict censorship regime hinders the global appeal of its films, but the new law aims to bridge gaps with foreign movies in technology, capital, talent, and content.

site_title: China potential for domestic demand big as ever: Li Keqiang
summary: China's domestic demand potential remains strong, despite economic slowdown, according to Premier Li Keqiang. Li stated China is an attractive destination for investment, with sectors like entertainment expanding rapidly. Retail sales have increased by over 10% this year, indicating a positive trend. However, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: India unveils plan to 'take flying to the masses'
summary: India's government unveiled a plan to make air travel affordable for millions by reducing airfares to 2,500 rupees per hour of flying on regional routes. The policy aims to revive ailing airports, build "no-frills" airports, and improve access to rural areas. The draft policy, submitted for review, seeks to overhaul rules dating back to the 1930s. India's under-penetrated domestic air travel market has only 70 million passengers out of 1.2 billion citizens. The plan is set to start in April 2016 and aims to "take flying to the masses."

images.alt_text: OUT OF REACH: Only 70 million of India's 1.2 billion citizens flew domestically in the year to March, making it one of the world's most under-penetrated markets.

site_title: Soaking in heritage
summary: The Gainsborough Bath Spa, a luxury hotel in the historic city of Bath, UK, has officially opened after a $100 million refurbishment of two derelict Grade II-listed buildings. The hotel features 99 rooms, a Roman-inspired spa, and public spaces designed by award-winning Champalimaud Design. Guests can access the hotel's thermal waters, which have been bubbling out of the ground for over 2,000 years, and enjoy a range of treatments and amenities, including a Michelin-starred restaurant and a chic cocktail bar. The hotel's opening marks a significant addition to YTL Hotels' luxury properties and showcases the city's rich heritage and natural beauty.

site_title: Indonesia's parliament approves 2016 budget, deficit at 2.15% of GDP
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved the 2016 state budget with a deficit of 273.2 trillion rupiah (2.15% of GDP). The budget allocates 2,095.7 trillion rupiah for spending, with 20% for education and 5% for health. The government's revenue target is set at 1,822.5 trillion rupiah, assuming 5.3% GDP growth. The approved deficit is smaller than the central bank's estimate for 2015 budget deficit.

site_title: Oxley's The Peak project in Phnom Penh sees sales of over 50% for Phase 1
summary: Oxley Holdings' The Peak project in Phnom Penh has achieved sales of over 50% for Phase 1, comprising 507 residential units in Tower 1. The project, a 55-storey mixed-use development, was launched in September and October 2015, with buyers guaranteed a 12% net rental return over two years. Construction is expected to start in early 2016 and completion in 2020, with a total of 1,014 units across two residential towers and commercial spaces. The sales progress is attributed to strong demand from buyers in Cambodia and Singapore.

site_title: SGX raps Advance SCT and two directors for rule breaches
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded Advance SCT and two directors, Weng Hua Yu and Peter Choo, for breaching listing rules by failing to disclose material information on transactions and seeking shareholder approval. The breaches include a delayed disclosure of an arbitration claim and a payment of S$1.6 million to a company owned by the directors. SGX has reported the rule breaches to the authorities and has warned that SGX-listed firms should consult the bourse before appointing the directors.

site_title: Far-flung eats
summary: Three unique restaurants in Singapore offer out-of-the-way dining experiences. Soek Seng 1954 Bicycle Cafe at Seletar Aerospace features a runway view and 20 restored bicycles, while Kontiki at Marina Bay offers a nautical theme and a quiet escape from the city. Smith Marine Restaurant on Pulau Ubin is accessible only by boat and offers a modern kelong experience with fresh seafood. Each restaurant aims to provide a unique and memorable dining experience, catering to those seeking an escape from the crowds and stress of city life.

site_title: Roxy posts 7% rise in Q3 net profit
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 7% increase in third quarter net profit to S$13.25 million, driven by higher revenue from property development and property investment. Revenue rose 31% to S$87.65 million, despite a decline in hotel ownership revenue.

site_title: Some Chinese take to social media - and some head for the bedroom
summary: China's "one-child" policy is being relaxed to a "two-child" policy, allowing all married couples to have up to two children. The decision sparked a discussion on Chinese social media, with some people announcing plans to conceive a second child immediately and others expressing reluctance due to the high cost of raising children. The change is expected to have significant implications for China's demographics and economy.

site_title: Forest fires make Indonesia world's biggest polluter
summary: Indonesia's forest fires have made the country the world's biggest polluter, surpassing China in daily carbon dioxide emissions on 14 days in the past two months. The fires, caused by deforestation for paper and palm oil plantations, have generated headlines and disrupted flights, threatening human health. With emissions exceeding those of the US on 47 days, Indonesia's total daily carbon dioxide emissions now rank among the worst globally, contributing to a climate catastrophe. The country has pledged to cut emissions by 29% by 2030, but experts warn that current efforts are insufficient to address the issue.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of wildfires bruning in Ogan Komering Ilir, South Sumatra, Indonesia, on Oct 20, 2015.

site_title: Europe: Stocks firm at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets rose in opening deals on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.16% to 6,406.10 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also advanced, with the DAX up 0.39% and the CAC up 0.19%. The FTSE 100 is expected to finish the week near its opening value, following a dip on Thursday due to speculation about a potential US interest rate hike.

site_title: America set to crack down on drones near airports
summary: The US is developing a system to track and potentially take control of rogue drones near airports, addressing concerns of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) about the growing threat of unmanned aerial vehicles. CACI International, a defence contractor, is working on the system, which could use technology developed for the military to locate operators and commandeer drones. The FAA has partnered with CACI to study the technology, which could be deployed at major US airports, and requires recreational drone owners to register their vehicles, with more regulations expected.

site_title: China mulls letting stock insurance fund apply for c.bank loans
summary: China is considering allowing the Securities Investor Protection Fund to apply for central bank loans in case of emergency. The draft amendments, announced by the China Securities Regulatory Commission, would provide the fund with more financial flexibility. The move comes after Beijing allowed securities institutions to use central bank borrowings to support share prices in June. The fund was established in 2005 to rescue brokerages and protect individual investors. This development aims to enhance the fund's ability to respond to market volatility and stabilize the stock market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Industries appoints Nicky Tan Ng Kuang as an independent director, effective November 1, 2015. Meanwhile, Soilbuild Construction Group reported a 24% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$3.07 million, despite a 26% increase in revenue to S$78.20 million. OKP Holdings and Creative Technology also released financial updates, with OKP Holdings seeing a 7.5% year-on-year decline in revenue and Creative Technology posting a US$13.93 million loss. Keppel T&T officially opened its Almere Data Centre 2 in Europe, and Top Global reported a 262% increase in revenue to S$48.05 million.

site_title: StanChart mulls raising at least US$4 billion
summary: Standard Chartered is considering raising at least $4 billion through a share sale to address a funding gap, amid pressure from regulators to bolster capital reserves. The bank, which has lost 25% of its value this year, may need up to $8 billion to meet the requirements. CEO Bill Winters has discussed the option with bankers, but no final decision has been made. The bank's stock fell 3.8% in London and 2.7% in Hong Kong trading on Friday, following a two-year slide in profit and shares.

images.alt_text: SLIDING PROFIT: The bank has felt the brunt of a turmoil sparked by plunging commodity prices and concern that China's economy is slowing more than expected.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end slightly lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed slightly lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 1.27 points to 1,665.71. A total of 2.12 billion lots valued at RM2.04 billion were traded, with 451 gainers outnumbering 396 losers.

site_title: NOL's Q3 net loss quadruples to US$96m
summary: NOL, a Singapore-based shipping company, reported a net loss of US$96 million in the third quarter, quadrupling from the same period last year, due to continued headwinds in its container shipping business. Revenue declined 29% and average freight rates plummeted 21% due to overcapacity. Despite this, the company achieved cost savings of US$80 million, taking its total year-to-date cost savings to US$335 million. The company's balance sheet has strengthened, and its share price remained flat at 99.5 cents.

site_title: Chevron to lay off 6-7,000 as oil price plunge hits
summary: US oil giant Chevron plans to cut 6,000-7,000 jobs, approximately 10% of its workforce, due to sharply lower oil prices. The company also announced it will pursue further asset sales, expecting to raise $5-10 billion by 2017. Chevron will reduce capital expenditures by 25% next year to $28 billion and anticipate further spending reductions in 2017 and 2018. The company reported a 63.6% fall in earnings to $2.04 billion in the quarter to September 30.

site_title: Sitting out China's summer rout pays off
summary: China's top-performing hedge funds gained an average 70% during the June-August period, outperforming nearly 1,300 other funds that were wiped out. The funds, led by Ze Quan Investment and Sunrise Investment, capitalized on brief upswings prompted by government intervention in July, including measures to ease panic and prop up stocks. This strategy allowed them to avoid the 30% decline in the Shanghai Composite Index during the same period. The funds' success was largely due to their ability to time the market, with some making strategic purchases on upswings and others sitting out the market before the June selloff.

images.alt_text: FRENZIED MARKET: The mid-June market crash spurred a US$5 trillion selloff. Almost 1,300 hedge funds were liquidated this year as at end-August and only 303 of 2,193 stock funds recorded gains during the June-August period.

site_title: Australia to review vehicle emissions testing after Volkswagen scandal
summary: Australia will review its vehicle emissions testing standards after the Volkswagen scandal highlighted the country's relatively lax regulations. The government will set up a working group to reduce harmful emissions and increase fuel efficiency in cars sold in Australia. The move comes after reports revealed Australia's standards were lower than in other developed nations, partly due to cost-cutting measures for the local car manufacturing industry, which will cease production in 2017. The review aims to align Australia's standards with international best practices.

images.alt_text: Australia will review its standards and testing procedures for vehicle emissions, the government said on Saturday, after media reports said the recent scandal involving Volkswagen cars highlighted the country's relatively lax standards.

site_title: Heart racing concepts
summary: The 44th Tokyo Motor Show 2015 showcased a range of concept cars, including Mazda's RX-Vision sports coupe, Nissan's IDS electric concept, and Mitsubishi's eX Concept compact SUV. Toyota displayed the C-HR Concept, a compact hybrid crossover, and the new Prius hybrid. Honda revealed the FCV, a fuel cell-powered car, while Porsche unveiled the 911 Carrera 4 and 4S. The show also featured world premieres from European manufacturers, including the Mini Convertible.

site_title: SME OUTLOOK 2016
summary: The SME Outlook 2016 event will provide insights on how to operate confidently in 2016, focusing on economic and business conditions. Experts Jimmy Koh, Ho Meng Kit, and David Toh will share their views on the US and Euro developments, China's stabilisation, and Asia's hotspots. The discussion will cover how businesses can respond to the economic outlook, including scenarios for expansion or contraction, and how to manage risk and prepare for growth. The event will take place on November 27 at the Fullerton Hotel in Singapore, with a cost of S$20 and limited seats available.

site_title: NOL reports Q3 net loss of US$96m on weak freight market
summary: Neptune Orient Lines Ltd (NOL) reported a Q3 net loss of US$96 million due to weak freight rates, with revenue falling 28% to US$1.2 billion. The company attributed the decline to the absence of the traditional third-quarter peak season in Europe and North America. NOL's President and CEO, Ng Yat Chung, stated that severe freight rates erosion occurred in major trade lanes.

site_title: UN staff fired over child porn, death threats
summary: Four UN employees have been fired for storing child pornography on their computers and sharing the images via email. Another staff member was fired for transporting marijuana in a UN vehicle and a third for death threats against a UN mission head. The incidents were part of 60 cases of misconduct or possible crimes reported by the UN's 40,000 staff between June 2014 and July this year. The UN's management has taken swift action against the perpetrators, with the firings being the first reported cases of such severity.

site_title: Spirit of Japan
summary: Shochu, a traditional Japanese spirit, is gaining global popularity, no longer being Japan's best-kept secret. Its consumption is now comparable to sake domestically, with Tokyo bars specializing in the spirit since 2006. Shochu has been produced since the 16th century in Japan's southern-most island of Kyushu, and its global appeal continues to grow.

site_title: India eyes bankruptcy reform to ease decades of gridlock
summary: India is set to reform its outdated bankruptcy system, aiming to modernize a process that has taken years and cost investors billions. A group of advisors has recommended sweeping changes, including imposing deadlines and establishing a network of insolvency professionals to tackle delays. The proposed changes would reduce the time taken to resolve insolvency cases from years to 180 days, and scrap the current Official Liquidator system. The reforms aim to professionalize the process, speed up the process, and ease the burden on investors and taxpayers.

site_title: Local Indian restaurants tie up to boost productivity
summary: Singapore's 22 local Indian restaurants have formed two consortia to boost productivity through new tech, food processing centers, and skills training. The consortia, divided into vegetarian and non-vegetarian, will establish separate Central Processing Units by Q1 2016. This move aims to create a more efficient and skilled workforce, addressing the tight labor market.

site_title: TPP to play key role in helping Japan meet GDP target: Nikkei
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to boost economic growth by nearly a quarter to 600 trillion yen, driven in part by the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade deal. The draft suggests TPP will boost growth rate to around 2% from below 1%, with increased exports and infrastructure work contributing to the growth. The plan also includes raising the minimum wage and cutting corporate taxes, expected to add 60 trillion yen to consumer spending annually. However, some experts question the realism of the target, citing levels of growth not seen in the past two decades.

site_title: China's richest man confirms Wanda has ties to Xi's family
summary: China's richest man, Wang Jianlin, has confirmed that his company, Wanda Group, has ties to President Xi Jinping's family. Wang Jianlin stated that his business partner, Deng Jiagui, a brother-in-law of Xi Jinping, bought shares in Wanda's commercial property subsidiary in 2000. The shares were sold at a low price point two months before Wanda's initial public offering, resulting in a missed opportunity for a significant return. This incident highlights the close relationship between Wanda and Xi's family, sparking speculation about the role of government connections in Wanda's success.

site_title: China naval chief warns US of conflict risk in South China Sea
summary: China's naval chief, Admiral Wu Shengli, warned US Admiral John Richardson that encounters between their forces could lead to conflict in the South China Sea, citing a recent US destroyer's close approach to Beijing's artificial islands. The US had sailed within 12 nautical miles of the disputed Spratly Islands chain, prompting Chinese authorities to monitor and warn the vessel. Wu expressed concern that the US' actions could spark conflict, but US officials said the two navies would maintain a dialogue and continue scheduled visits.

site_title: China's ICBC Q3 profit up 0.5%, soured loans rise
summary: China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) reported a 0.5% net profit increase for the third quarter of 2015, reaching 72.74 billion yuan. Soured debt rose, but the result aligned with analysts' 0.43% profit growth estimate.

images.alt_text: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Ltd (ICBC), China's biggest lender by assets, reported on Friday a net profit rise of 0.5 per cent for the third quarter of 2015, as soured debt increased.

site_title: Airbus Group Q3 core profit rises 12%, hikes jet output
summary: Airbus Group reported a 12% increase in third-quarter operating profit to €921 million, driven by a 6% growth in revenue to €14.072 billion. The company confirmed its annual targets and plans to increase A320 jetliner production to 60 planes per month from 2019. Airbus also launched a €1 billion share buyback and reiterated plans to break even on the A380 superjumbo this year. The company's industrial ramp-up of the A350 mid-sized wide-body jet is progressing, but remains challenging.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down
summary: Hong Kong shares closed down on Friday, falling 0.8% to 22,640.04, due to declines in energy and technology stocks. This marks a 2.6% decline for the week and an 8.1% gain for the month. Total trading volume was 1.6 billion shares.

site_title: Bank lending in first contraction since April
summary: Bank lending in Singapore contracted by 0.8% in September, marking the first month-on-month decline since April, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Loans through the domestic banking unit (DBU) fell to S$608 billion, down from S$609.6 billion in August. This decline may signal wavering business confidence, although the MAS has not commented on the implications of the contraction.

site_title: Japan firms more keen to invest in Asean than China
summary: Japan firms are increasingly investing in Southeast Asia, with $10 billion in investments in the region in the first half of 2015, surpassing China's $4.8 billion. Japanese companies are drawn to the region's better political relationships, growth potential, and proximity. This trend is expected to continue, with 75% of Japanese firms planning to expand in Southeast Asia, compared to 56.5% in China. Japan's record cash reserves are fueling these investments, which are seen as a way to offset anaemic domestic growth.

site_title: Nokia signs deals worth 910m euros with China Mobile
summary: Finnish telecoms group Nokia announced deals worth 910m euros (approximately $1.4 billion) with China Mobile, a world's largest mobile operator. The contract includes rolling out a wireless network, providing infrastructure, maintenance, and software solutions.

site_title: Senate passes budget deal to avert US default
summary: The US Senate passed a bipartisan, two-year budget deal that boosts federal spending by $80 billion, reduces a government shutdown threat, and raises the debt ceiling through the end of Barack Obama's presidency. The measure provides fiscal breathing room for lawmakers until the 2016 presidential election. The bill was negotiated in secret between House Speaker John Boehner and the White House and now awaits Obama's signature.

site_title: China's richest man says firm had ties to Xi's family
summary: China's richest man, Wang Jianlin, confirmed that his firm, Wanda Group, had ties to President Xi Jinping's family through his brother-in-law, Deng Jiagui. Deng's investment company bought shares in Wanda's commercial property subsidiary in 2009, selling them at a low price point before the company's initial public offering in 2014. Wang stated that this incident demonstrates Xi's strict management of family affairs, playing down speculation about the link between his success and government ties. The incident is part of a broader anti-corruption drive targeting prominent officials and low-level officials.

site_title: OKP Holdings reports rise in Q3 profit
summary: OKP Holdings reported a 255% increase in Q3 net profit to S$997,000, driven by a 13.5% increase in earnings per share to 0.32 Singapore cents. Revenue declined 7.5% to S$24.21 million due to lower maintenance segment revenue. Despite this, the company's earnings per share growth indicates a positive outlook.

site_title: Britain's The Sun to take down online paywall
summary: Britain's The Sun newspaper will remove its online paywall starting November 30, just two years after introducing it. The paywall will remain in place for content such as the Club Dream Team fantasy football game and The Sun Classic app. The move is seen as a bid to compete with rivals like MailOnline, which has around 200 million monthly unique browsers. The Sun had 1,108,861 unique browsers in September, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulation figures. This change marks a shift in the newspaper's digital strategy.

site_title: BoJ cuts growth, inflation view as Japan economy stalls
summary: The Bank of Japan (BoJ) cut its economic growth outlook to 1.2% for the fiscal year to March 2016, down from 1.7%, and pushed back its inflation target to 2% in six months, half a year later than expected. Despite holding off on fresh easing, the central bank's chief, Haruhiko Kuroda, left the door open for more stimulus, citing a "no limit" to policy options. The move highlights Japan's struggling economy, which is facing slowing growth in China and a shaky global economy, as well as weak inflation and consumer spending.

site_title: China's top banks book slowest Q3 profit growth in 3 years as bad loans rise
summary: China's top five banks reported their slowest third-quarter profit growth in 3 years due to the sluggish economy and rising bad loans. Interest rate cuts have squeezed commercial banks' net interest margins, while borrowers struggle to repay loans, leading to a rise in non-performing loans and impairment losses. As a result, banks are setting aside more capital, with impairment losses increasing by up to 62.65% in the first nine months of the year. This trend is expected to continue as China's economy slows, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks score strong monthly gain
summary: European stock markets closed the month with strong gains, with London rising 5%, Paris nearly 10%, and Frankfurt over 12%. The gains were driven by optimism despite China's economic slowdown and expectations of a delayed US interest rate hike. Investors cashed in gains after a bumper month for equities, and market sentiment was influenced by US-EU trade talks and company results.

site_title: September consumer spending up 0.1%
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.1% in September, its smallest gain in 8 months, and personal income also increased marginally. This data suggests domestic demand may be cooling, potentially countering the Federal Reserve's plans to raise interest rates in December. The weak inflationary pressures, as measured by the personal consumption expenditures price index, also argue against a rate hike. Despite this, the US economy's growth rate remained steady at 1.5% in the third quarter, driven by a 3.2% annual pace of consumer spending.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks lifted as China scraps one-child policy
summary: Shanghai stocks rose 0.60% on Friday after China scrapped its one-child policy, boosting children-related firms. The Shanghai Composite Index ended at 3,407.70, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.04%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.79% despite the positive news. The move is seen as a positive economic signal, but the global market retreated due to concerns over US-EU trade talks and global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Children-related firms helped Shanghai equities end on a high Friday after Beijing scrapped its long-standing "one-child" policy, but Hong Kong slipped in line with a global retreat.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker for the week on US interest rate concerns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 2.3% to 2,998.35, with a 70-point drop, amid US Federal Reserve interest rate concerns. The Fed hinted at possible rate hikes in December, causing sellers to emerge. Low trading volume and elevated banking sector activity led to a low dollar turnover of $1.1 billion. Banks such as OCBC reported disappointing third-quarter figures, contributing to the market downturn.

site_title: China to free capital account in Shanghai FTZ
summary: China will liberalize its capital account in the Shanghai free trade zone, allowing firms to trade derivatives and futures, and increase foreign and private investment in financial services sectors. This move is part of the central bank's efforts to experiment with financial reforms in the area. Other planned reforms include allowing firms to trade derivatives and futures in the zone and increasing foreign and private investment in some financial services sectors. The liberalization aims to promote financial innovation and deepen integration with the global economy.

site_title: Creative Technology's losses widen in Q1
summary: Creative Technology reported wider losses in Q1, increasing from $9.83 million to $13.93 million. Sales declined 7% to $22.51 million due to uncertain market conditions. Loss per share rose to $0.20 from $0.14 previously. The company also warned that H2 revenue may be below target, with an operating loss similar to the first half.

site_title: Top Global chalks up higher profit in Q3
summary: Top Global reported a 266% increase in net profit to S$984,000 in Q3, driven by a 431% rise in revenue to S$48.05 million, largely due to increased property development revenue. Earnings per share rose to 0.003 Singapore cents.

site_title: Swiss central bank posts US$34.28b loss for 9 months
summary: Switzerland's central bank, the Swiss National Bank (SNB), reported a 9-month loss of 33.9 billion Swiss francs (US$34.28 billion) due to the removal of the franc-euro cap in January. The bank has intervened in foreign exchange markets to weaken the franc, resulting in significant losses. This has raised concerns about the bank's ability to maintain its regular payout policy, potentially impacting its shareholders, including the federal government and cantons.

site_title: Building collapse kills 17 in central China: reports
summary: A residential building under renovation in Henan province, central China, collapsed on Friday, killing 17 construction workers and injuring 23 others. The building, a 1990s-era two-storey structure, was being renovated to add more levels. The collapse raises concerns over poor regulation and corruption in the booming Chinese economy. This incident is the latest in a series of construction accidents, including a 2011 incident in northeastern China that killed 12 workers.

site_title: SGX raps Advance SCT for rule breaches
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded Advance SCT for breaching several listing rules, including failure to promptly disclose material information and seeking shareholder approval. The company's chairman and CEO, Weng Hua Yu, and non-executive director Peter Choo, were also reprimanded. SGX has reported the rule breaches to authorities and served a 42.8 million yuan arbitration claim against Advance SCT and Mr. Weng. The exchange noted that the company paid S$1.6 million to a company owned by Mr. Weng, exceeding the shares' market value.

site_title: RBS warns conduct charges may be higher-than-expected
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland reported a third-quarter operating loss of 134 million pounds due to restructuring and misconduct costs, down from a profit of 1.1 billion pounds the previous year. The bank warned that future costs related to litigation and past misconduct could be substantially higher than expected, with 4.5 billion pounds already set aside to cover regulatory and legal actions.

site_title: Some major changes in golf rules in 2016 edition
summary: The 2016 edition of the Rules of Golf introduces changes aimed at making the rules more accessible and easier to understand for amateur golfers. Chairman David Bonsall of the Rules of Golf Committee believes that players only need to know a few key rules, but the current layout of the book can be difficult to navigate. The committee is working to simplify the rules and make them more intuitive, with the goal of having a "working knowledge" of the rules among all golfers.

images.alt_text: MR BONSALL: He is involved in a project to make golf rules much more easy to understand and more accessible to players.

site_title: UIC's Q3 net profit up 9% to S$65.28m
summary: United Industrial Corporation (UIC) posted a 9% increase in its Q3 net profit to S$65.28 million, driven by higher trading property sales. Revenue rose 6% to S$189.35 million. Earnings per share increased to 4.6 cents, and the net asset value per share stood at S$4.19.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Chevron, AB Inbev buoy Wall St on earnings beats
summary: Chevron and AB Inbev, two major companies, boosted Wall Street on Friday as they beat earnings forecasts. Chevron's core earnings per share exceeded analyst expectations despite a 63.6% decline in earnings due to the oil price crash. AB Inbev's operating profit rose 9.6% to $4.4 billion, and the company is poised to take over rival SAB Miller in a mega-merger. These positive earnings reports contributed to gains in the Dow Jones Industrial index, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rising slightly.

site_title: ExxonMobil earnings plunge 47.5% to US$4.2b
summary: ExxonMobil reported a 47.5% drop in third-quarter earnings to $4.2 billion, largely due to lower oil and gas prices affecting its exploration and production business. Profits from the upstream division decreased to $1.4 billion from $5.1 billion in the same period last year.

site_title: China Sept services trade deficit US$22.7b: FX regulator
summary: China's trade deficit in services narrowed to US$22.7 billion in September, down from US$22.8 billion in August. The January to September period saw a services trade deficit of US$158.2 billion, primarily due to a US$20 billion difference in tourist spending. China had a US$54.4 billion surplus on trade of goods in September.

site_title: IAG Q3 profit beats forecasts, upgrades 2015 guidance
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways, reported a 34% jump in quarterly operating profit to 1.205 billion euros, beating forecasts. The company upgraded its annual profit guidance due to lower fuel costs. IAG's operating profit for 2015 is now forecast to be between 2.25 billion euros and 2.3 billion euros, up from a previous forecast of over 2.2 billion euros. This increase is attributed to lower fuel costs.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for H2. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: WTA Finals bathroom partner Roca glad for raised profile
summary: Roca, a bathroom industry leader, has been named an official bathroom partner for the WTA Finals in Singapore. The company has been fitted with its products in the VIP hospitality pavilion and has a booth at the fan zone. Managing Director Josep Delicado expressed pride in the association, citing increased exposure to new and existing clients. This marks Roca's first major sports sponsorship in Singapore and builds on its existing sports sponsorship efforts, including previous partnerships with Barcelona and the Catalonia International Paddle Tennis tournament.

site_title: Indonesia's Indofood posts biggest 9-mth profit decline in decade on forex hit
summary: Indonesia's PT Indofood Sukses Makmur Tbk, the world's largest instant noodle maker, reported a 45% decline in 9-month profits to 1.68 trillion rupiah (S$172.3 million), the largest decline in a decade. The decline was attributed to a weak rupiah, which increased financing costs for foreign currency-denominated debt. The company's net profit margin dropped to 3.5% from 6.6%. Indofood CEO Anthoni Salim cited macroeconomic conditions and weak crude palm oil prices as contributing factors.

site_title: South Korea: Shares edge down, won slightly up on US growth data
summary: South Korean shares and the won were little changed on Friday, as investors awaited US monetary policy clues. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed down 0.2% at 2,029.47 points. The won was up 0.2% against the dollar, its biggest monthly gain since 2011. This comes after the US growth data, which may impact global economic outlook.

site_title: Credit Suisse in US, Swiss probe over Fifa
summary: US and Swiss authorities are investigating Credit Suisse's relationships with FIFA officials named in a US criminal indictment, marking the first global bank to disclose involvement in the corruption probe. Authorities are looking into whether financial institutions allowed suspicious transactions or failed to observe anti-money laundering laws. Credit Suisse is cooperating with the authorities, amid a broader scandal that has led to the suspension of FIFA president Sepp Blatter and European soccer chief Michel Platini. The probe is part of a larger investigation into corruption within FIFA.

site_title: AirAsia founder began buyout talks as share fall put loans at risk: sources
summary: AirAsia founder Tony Fernandes has begun buyout talks with bankers to take the airline private after a decline in its stock price put $200 million in loans at risk. The loans, taken by Fernandes and his business partner to finance private ventures, were collateralized by their 19% indirect holding in AirAsia. Fernandes and his partner may sell their stake to pay off the loans, with the airline exploring a management-led buyout and potentially selling a stake in its leasing subsidiary to Chinese companies.

images.alt_text: AirAsia founder Tony Fernandes began talks with bankers to take Asia's No 1 budget airline private after a plunge in its stock price put US$200 million worth of loans borrowed against AirAsia's shares at risk, people familiar with the situation told Reuters.

site_title: China's oil giants lose almost all profits amid crude crash
summary: China's top energy producer, PetroChina Co, and its largest oil refiner, Sinopec, reported their worst quarterly profits on record due to a 92% drop in earnings. PetroChina's net income plummeted 81% to 5.2 billion yuan, while Sinopec's net income fell 92% to 1.64 billion yuan. The decline in crude prices, which has dropped over 40% in the past year, has put these companies under tremendous pressure. Analysts predict the companies must find ways to cut costs and improve efficiency to remain competitive.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall for a 5th day, end 4% higher in October
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Friday, marking a fifth consecutive day of decline, as miners fell due to concerns over China and US demand growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended the week down 2%, its largest drop since Sept 21-25, but had a 4.33% monthly gain. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also fell 0.28%.

site_title: Asia: Shares edge up, Nikkei gyrates as BOJ holds steady
summary: Asian shares rose on Friday, poised for their biggest monthly gain since January 2012, despite weekly losses due to US interest rate concerns. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) held policy steady, as expected, but investors still await potential future easing measures. Japan's Nikkei index rebounded, while the yen rose after the decision. US indexes posted losses but were on track for their best monthly performance in four years, with the possibility of a Fed interest rate hike in December still looming.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.78% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.78% higher on Friday, rebounding after the Bank of Japan announced it would stand pat on fresh monetary stimulus, clearing market uncertainty. The Nikkei 225 index rose 147.39 points to 19,083.10, while the Topix index gained 0.72% to 1,558.20.

site_title: Six children among 15 killed in Philippine market fire
summary: Fifteen people, including six children, died in a market fire in the southern Philippines on Saturday. The fire, caused by faulty electrical wiring, broke out before dawn at a padlocked building where vendors and their families slept overnight to protect their merchandise.

site_title: Response to new housing grant 'most encouraging'
summary: More than one in five resale flat buyers in Singapore have applied for the Proximity Housing Grant (PHG) since its introduction on August 24, with nearly half of those eligible families previously ineligible. The scheme, which provides a one-time grant of S$20,000 for eligible families and S$10,000 for singles, has been met with an "encouraging" response. The increased income ceilings for the scheme have made more buyers eligible, with one in 10 first-timer families and singles now eligible for the grant.

site_title: Credit Suisse booked US$283m Q3 litigation provisions
summary: Credit Suisse has booked $283 million in Q3 litigation provisions due to suspected corruption inquiries from authorities regarding its banking relationships with FIFA. The Swiss bank is cooperating with the probes and has made significant overhaul plans, including raising 6 billion francs, slimming down its investment bank, and cutting jobs. This is the bank's biggest overhaul in almost a decade.

site_title: Indonesia eyes up to US$1.46b in loans to fund projects in early 2016: official
summary: Indonesia is seeking loans of up to $1.46 billion to fund infrastructure projects in early 2016. Finance Ministry official Scenaider Siahaan mentioned that the loans could be raised through local or global borrowing, with the possibility of global borrowing. The government aims to start many projects by early next year, despite only spending 28% of this year's planned capital expenditure.

site_title: Germany's Merkel says expects China's growth to weaken a bit
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel expects China's economic growth to slow somewhat, but maintain constant growth, she said during a visit to Hefei. Merkel attributed this to growing domestic demand in cities, which drives consumption and growth. This prediction comes after the head of the DIHK Chambers of Commerce stated German shipments to China would fall by 2% this year due to trade exposure.

site_title: UOB's Q3 profit dips on higher costs
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a net profit of S$858 million for the third quarter, down 1% from the previous year due to higher staff and branding costs. Despite this, total income rose 5.8% to S$2.1 billion, driven by strong core income and one-off gains from the sale of investment securities. The bank also announced a 20 cents per share one-off 80th anniversary dividend and targets mid-single-digit loan growth in 2015.

site_title: Muguruza, Kvitova reach WTA Finals semis
summary: The WTA Finals semi-finals have been confirmed, with Garbine Muguruza and Petra Kvitova advancing to the final four. Muguruza defeated Kvitova 6-4, 4-6, 7-5 in a two-hour and 33-minute marathon match. Maria Sharapova and Agnieszka Radwanska will face off in the other semi-final on Saturday, with the winners meeting in the final on Sunday.

site_title: Standard Chartered said to weigh raising at least US$4b to address funding gap
summary: Standard Chartered is considering raising at least $4 billion in capital to address a potential funding gap, as British regulators scrutinize lenders with emerging market exposure. The bank's CEO Bill Winters is under pressure to reverse a two-year profit decline. Standard Chartered may need up to $8 billion to address the gap, and a final decision on raising capital has not been made. The bank's shares have fallen 25% this year and 2.7% on Friday, following a two-year slide in profit and shares.

site_title: Singapore services sector turns bearish on six-month outlook
summary: Singapore's services sector has turned bearish on its six-month outlook, with 21% of firms expecting a reduction in business activities and 15% anticipating a favorable business outlook. This translates to a negative net weighted balance of 6%, down from 2% a quarter ago. The industries that are less optimistic include real estate, wholesale trade, and transport & storage services. In contrast, accommodation, food & beverage services and retail trade are more optimistic about their business conditions.

site_title: Taiwan announces stimulus steps to boost consumption after poor GDP data
summary: Taiwan's government announced a stimulus package to boost domestic consumption after the island's economy contracted for the first time in six years in the third quarter. The package is estimated to add T$15.4 billion (US$480 million) to GDP, but details on the timeframe were not provided. This move comes amid concerns over the country's export-driven economy.

site_title: Bank lending in Singapore falls in September: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore declined 0.8% in September from August, marking the first contraction since April, according to MAS data. Business loans fell 1.6% to S$367 billion, while consumer lending grew 0.2% to S$241 billion. Year-over-year growth in bank lending was 0.6%, weaker than the 1.5% gain in August.

images.alt_text: BANK lending in Singapore fell in September from the previous month, dragged down by weaker business loans, preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) showed on Friday.

site_title: AB InBev upbeat on revenues due to premium beer sales
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev reported higher-than-expected premium beer sales, driving revenue growth despite a declining Chinese market. The brewer now expects revenue per hectolitre to grow ahead of inflation, driven by strong premium brand sales. Third-quarter core profit was $4.40 billion, a 9.6% increase excluding currency and scope changes. Volumes rose 1.5% in the July-Sept period, with increases in beer sales across the Americas, but revenue grew 7.9% due to price hikes and consumer shifts to more expensive beers.

site_title: Xi's dream for a high-tech China is becoming a reality in stocks
summary: China's stock market is shifting towards technology companies, with the weighting of tech firms in the MSCI China gauge set to nearly double to 26% by May. The change, which will affect investors with at least $400 billion in Chinese stock holdings, is part of President Xi Jinping's government's efforts to boost the role of privately-owned tech and service businesses. The move is expected to trigger $78 billion of net buying and will give China a higher concentration of software companies than any other MSCI index worldwide.

site_title: From Memphis to Malaysia, cotton goes global with new ICE contract
summary: The Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) launches its first global cotton contract, 0#WCT, allowing for delivery of cotton grown abroad. The new contract aims to provide a more representative global price, potentially supplanting the US benchmark 0#CT, which has set prices for textile industry customers since the 1990s. The launch is seen as a response to the US market's dwindling influence on global trade, with many merchants and traders shifting to Texas and other locations. The contract has garnered support from industry players, including Olam International and Louis Dreyfus Commodities, and may provide a more flexible hedging tool for the $41 billion cotton industry.

site_title: China to allow foreign central banks to open yuan settlement accounts
summary: China's central bank has allowed foreign central banks to open yuan settlement accounts at domestic financial institutions. This move aims to increase yuan's global usage and acceptance. Foreign central banks can also open deposit accounts at local banks for bilateral local currency swaps. The decision is seen as a step towards further liberalizing the country's currency market and increasing its economic influence.

images.alt_text: China's central bank will allow its foreign counterparts to open yuan settlement accounts at domestic financial institutions, it said in a statement on Friday.

site_title: M Development to fund subsidiary's 'causes of action' against 13 defendants
summary: M Development Ltd has funded its subsidiary Winsta Holding Pte Ltd's causes of action against 13 defendants, after creditors declined to provide funding due to insufficient funds. The decision comes after an internal audit uncovered "undisclosed interested party transactions" by Winsta Group's executive directors and officers. All seven subsidiaries have been placed in creditors' voluntary liquidation since August. M Development will vigorously prosecute the litigation, despite the liquidation of the Winsta Group subsidiaries. The company views this as in the interests of its shareholders and stakeholders.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers' outlook turns sour, survey shows
summary: Singapore manufacturers have become pessimistic about their future prospects, with 26% expecting a weaker business climate in the next six months, according to a quarterly survey by the Economic Development Board. This marks a significant deterioration from a positive net weighted balance of 2% a quarter earlier. The softening in business expectations is attributed to global economic conditions, particularly China's slowdown and weak oil and commodity prices.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing firms in Singapore have turned pessimistic about their future prospects, according to a quarterly Economic Development Board (EDB) survey report released on Friday.

site_title: More than 1 in 5 homebuyers applied for Proximity Housing Grant
summary: More than one in five homebuyers in Singapore applied for the Proximity Housing Grant (PHG) in the past two months, with nearly half of eligible families and about nine in 10 singles qualifying. The PHG, introduced on August 24, provides a one-time grant of S$20,000 for families living with or near parents or married children, and S$10,000 for singles. The response to the measure has been "most encouraging," according to Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong, who noted that nearly half of eligible families and nine in 10 singles would have been ineligible under previous rules.

site_title: Government to help food firms promote digital solutions to raise productivity
summary: The Singapore government will support food firms in adopting digital solutions to boost productivity, including automated systems for taking orders and dishwashing, and new dining formats. The second Food Services Productivity Plan, launched at the Singapore Food Services Productivity Conference 2015, aims to help food companies transition to a leaner workforce. Since the first plan in 2011, 3,700 establishments have received support for 940 projects, with Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang emphasizing the sector's vital role in Singapore's economy.

site_title: Fashion sheds its skein
summary: French fashion house Lanvin has announced that creative director Alber Elbaz is leaving the company, citing the decision of the company's majority shareholder. Elbaz, who has been at the helm since 2001, is known for his talent, generosity, and self-questioning approach to fashion. His departure follows recent exits of designer Raf Simons from Dior and Alexander Wang from Balenciaga, sparking concerns about the changing nature of the fashion industry. The constant cycle of collection after collection and the trend of treating designers as "work for hire" may be contributing to the dissatisfaction among creative talent.

images.alt_text: DESTRUCTIVE TREND: Fashion is now on a slippery slope of its own making with the departures of Alexander Wang (left) from the house of Balenciaga; Raf Simons (middle) from Christian Dior; and Alber Elbaz (right) from Lanvin. The exits are seen as a powerful reflection of an insidious, and potentially more destructive trend plaguing fashion.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific's Q3 net profit up 7% to S$13.25m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 7% increase in Q3 net profit to S$13.25 million, driven by a 31% rise in revenue from property development and investment. Earnings per share rose to 1.11 cents, and net asset value per share increased to 37.05 cents. The company's revenue growth was partly offset by a decline in hotel ownership revenue.

site_title: Yuan firms after China reaffirms economic goals
summary: China's yuan firmed on Friday after the Communist Party reaffirmed plans for "medium to high" economic growth in its next five-year plan. The currency was also supported by the easing of family planning restrictions to two children, aiming to alleviate demographic strains. State-owned banks intervened in offshore markets to eliminate the spread between onshore and offshore markets, with the yuan trading 0.01% higher at 6.3464 per dollar.

site_title: Shares in childcare companies soar after China scraps one-child policy
summary: Shares in childcare companies surged after China scrapped its one-child policy, allowing couples to have two children. Goodbaby International Holdings Ltd and Hengan International jumped 8.9% and 3.3%, respectively, while infant formula maker Biostime International rose 11.8%. The move is expected to boost demand for baby products and increase sales for companies in the industry.

site_title: Baidu announces US$2b share buyback after profit beats
summary: Baidu reported a third-quarter profit of $1.43 per share, exceeding analyst projections. The company announced its second share buyback program, worth up to $2 billion over two years. Baidu's chairman, Robin Li, plans to boost spending on services like online shopping and travel to compete with Alibaba and Tencent. The company is targeting the "O2O" market, expected to grow to $1.54 trillion by 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks lower after open
summary: Hong Kong stocks decreased slightly on Friday, following a soft lead from Wall Street, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.50% to 22,705.00. Shanghai's benchmark composite index eased 0.21% to 3,380.28, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.17% to 2,011.07. The declines were attributed to concerns over Chinese corporate earnings.

site_title: Second 'gin craze' sweeps London
summary: A "gin craze" has swept London, with sales of premium gin rising 49% over the past two years. The city is home to a boom in distilleries and dedicated bars, with over 25 types of gin available. The industry is keen to shake off gin's reputation as "mother's ruin" and instead promote high-quality, unique flavors. A second "Gin Craze" is underway, following a similar boom in the 18th century, and the market is now worth £345 million in Britain, with the industry growing 18% in value over the past two years.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower
summary: Malaysian shares opened lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 1.90 points to 1,665.08. Trading volume reached 67.3 million lots valued at RM19.55 billion. Despite 110 gains, 65 losses were reported.

site_title: BOJ keeps monetary policy steady
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, sticking to its pledge to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen through purchases of government bonds and risky assets. This decision, made by an 8-1 vote, aims to lift wages and consumption to accelerate inflation towards its 2% target. The BOJ has kept monetary policy steady since expanding stimulus in October last year, despite weak exports and oil prices. A news conference will be held later to explain the policy decision.

site_title: Asia: Shares edge down as investors nervous over Fed path
summary: Asian shares declined on Friday, poised for a weekly loss, as investors worried about the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike. The US GDP grew at 1.5% in the third quarter, missing expectations, but solid consumer spending kept the possibility of a rate increase alive. The Fed hinted at a rate hike in December, sparking concerns about global growth.

site_title: Justin Bieber storms out of a concert in Norway
summary: Justin Bieber abruptly cancelled his concert in Oslo, Norway, after performing just one song, citing that fans didn't listen to him while he was trying to clean up spilled water. The 13-year-old pop sensation, who scooped five prizes at the MTV Europe Music Awards, expressed frustration and exhaustion in a post on Instagram. His private jet took off from Oslo's airport, leaving fans shaken and in tears. This incident risks damaging his family-friendly image, which is extremely popular in Norway.

site_title: Baidu's revenue rises 36%
summary: Baidu Inc, China's largest internet search company, reported a 36% rise in quarterly revenue to 18.38 billion yuan, driven by increased advertising money for its core search engine business. Net income fell to 2.84 billion yuan, down from 3.88 billion yuan in the previous year. The company's revenue growth was attributed to its search engine business, with no specific details provided on the reasons behind the decline in net income.

site_title: Google said to blend Chrome operating system into Android mobile
summary: Google is merging its stripped-down Chrome operating system into its Android software for mobile devices, a move expected to unify the two platforms. The combined software will be previewed in 2016 and debut the following year. This move reflects the blurring of lines between mobile phones and traditional computers. Google will continue to develop the Chrome browser, which shares roots with Chrome OS. The news was first reported by The Wall Street Journal.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index opened 22.49 points lower at 2,979.02, following a decline in US stocks and mixed earnings reports from Singapore-listed companies. The potential US Federal Reserve interest-rate hike in December and ongoing US-EU trade talks may be weighing on investors. Trading volume was 90.5 million shares worth S$182.3 million, with losers outpacing gainers 86 to 38. Key stocks fell, including Noble Group, CapitaLand, Global Logistic Properties, and OCBC.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg chided by judge over board pay
summary: A Delaware Chancery Court judge ruled that Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg must follow corporate formalities when it comes to executive pay, despite being the company's controlling shareholder. The judge found Zuckerberg violated the rights of other investors by failing to vote on the 2013 executive pay, allowing directors to award themselves excessive stock grants. The ruling clears the way for a trial on allegations of improper pay practices and breaches of fiduciary duties.

site_title: Trading of Saizen Reit units halted pending announcement
