summary: Trading in Saizen Reit units has been halted pending an announcement by its Reit manager, Japan Residential Assets Manager. The halt took effect immediately, with no further information provided.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet may open units to China: report
summary: Google parent Alphabet may expand business operations in China, allowing each unit autonomy on the matter. Co-founder Sergey Brin stated that each Alphabet business can make its own decisions on countries to operate in, following the reorganization of the technology giant. Alphabet already does business in China, selling ads to businesses, but Google services are not officially available. This move comes after Google bought a stake in Chinese AI startup Mobvoi and announced plans to reshape under the new parent company, offering more flexibility for long-shot projects.

site_title: Creative Technology unit settles lawsuit with Apple
summary: Creative Technology's subsidiary ZiiLabs Inc has settled a patent infringement lawsuit with Apple. As part of the agreement, Apple will take a licence for ZiiLabs' patents, expected to contribute approximately $0.23 to earnings per share. The settlement was reached after a lawsuit filed in the US in March 2014. This marks a positive development for Creative Technology, which had previously warned that its second-quarter revenue may be below target due to operating losses similar to those in the first half of the year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, GLP, Global Premium Hotels, Tuan Sing, AusGroup, Baker Technology
summary: Asian stocks may be directionless on Friday following overnight Wall Street retreats, amid tech earnings disappointment and potential interest-rate hike in December. UOB Group reported a 1% drop in Q3 net profit to S$858 million, while Global Logistic Properties (GLP) posted a 27.4% increase to US$114 million. Other companies, including Global Premium Hotels, Tuan Sing Holdings, AusGroup, and Baker Technology, also released earnings reports with varying results.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat ahead of Bank of Japan meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on October 30, 2015, ahead of a potential Bank of Japan stimulus meeting. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.06% to 18,924.31. Investors are focused on the Bank of Japan's possible move to stimulate the economy, following a weak session on Wall Street.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip again on global growth concerns
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.5% on Friday, marking the week's fourth consecutive decline, amid concerns about global growth, particularly in China and the US. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,238.7, on track for a 2% weekly drop. Lower-than-expected bank profits and a decline in resource counters, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, contributed to the losses. Despite this, Macquarie Group rose 2% after posting a record half-year profit, and Asciano shares gained after Qube took a stake in the freight firm.

site_title: Novo's controlling shareholder makes mandatory takeover offer for group
summary: Novo Group's controlling shareholder, Golden Star Group, made a mandatory takeover offer at HK$3.755 per share in cash. Golden Star Group, owned by Zhu Jun, holds a 54.87% stake in the group. An independent board committee will review the offer's fairness and recommend to shareholders. Executives Dicky Yu Wing Keung and Lawrence Tse To Chung resigned, and Zhu Jun was nominated as an executive director. The offeror plans to maintain the group's business and listing status, and conduct a strategic business plan review.

site_title: Hu An Cable to divest assets, shares of subsidiaries
summary: Hu An Cable announced the divestment of its three Chinese subsidiaries to Yixing Jinxiao Copper Industry Co, transferring shares to Plenty Jade. The move aims to minimize potential claims from customers regarding non-compliant products. The group faces termination of purchase contracts, loss of approved vendor list, and potential compensation claims. If the asset disposal doesn't occur, Hu An Cable may face unemployment compensation and penalties for unpaid bank loans. The group has appointed RHB Securities Singapore as the financial adviser for the asset disposal and share transfer, with a long-stop date of December 21, 2015.

site_title: Big US shale oil savings fast becoming a thing of the past
summary: US shale oil companies are experiencing a decline in cost savings, marking the end of a 16-month price cut on equipment and services. The drastic cuts, which included 20-30% price reductions from oilfield service companies, helped companies survive the industry downturn. However, productivity gains have stalled, and deflation may be slowing, as producers face a lower-for-longer price outlook. This marks a shift away from the significant cost savings that helped companies cope with the 50% drop in crude prices.

images.alt_text: A drill rig stands on the site of an oil well outside Williston, North Dakota, US, on Thursday, Feb 12, 2015.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on weaker financials, miners
summary: European shares fell slightly on Thursday, with banking stocks leading the way after disappointing updates from Deutsche Bank and Barclays. The FTSEurofirst 300 index ended down 0.04% and the Euro STOXX 50 index fell 0.23%. US interest rates remained unchanged, but investors assessed the negative impact of a potential rate hike by year-end. Mining stocks fell 1.9% due to declining metals prices, while TMT sector stocks rose, with Nokia and Alcatel-Lucent surging 10% each.

site_title: Volkswagen has small US sales gain in 1st post-scandal month: sources
summary: Volkswagen reported a slight increase in US sales in October, the first full month since the emissions scandal broke. Sales of VW-brand vehicles are expected to grow between 1-5% due to discounts and incentives offered to offset a sales ban on 2.0-litre diesel models. US sales in September rose 0.6% to 26,141 cars. The company is under pressure to fix up to 11 million affected vehicles and regain customer trust.

site_title: Japanese consumer prices fall 0.1% in September
summary: Japanese consumer prices fell 0.1% in September, the second straight month, due to weak domestic demand and plunging energy prices. This data keeps the possibility of more stimulus by the central bank open, particularly as the Bank of Japan considers its next move. The fall in core inflation, excluding volatile fresh food prices, was slightly better than economists' expectations. This data underscores the challenges to Japan's campaign to lift the country out of deflation, led by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and the central bank.

site_title: UK consumer confidence slips to 4-month low: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence has dropped to its lowest in four months, according to a survey by GfK. The indicator fell to +2 in October from +3 in September, bucking economists' forecasts for a small rise. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in Britain's economy, driven by a fall in construction and manufacturing exports. The UK economy is expected to continue easing in the final three months of the year, with consumer and investment demand being the main drivers of growth. This marks a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Japan jobless rate unchanged at 3.4%
summary: Japan's jobless rate remained unchanged at 3.4% in September, matching the median forecast. The jobs-applicants ratio reached its highest level since January 1992, increasing to 1.24. This indicates a strong labor market, with available positions exceeding applicants. The unchanged rate suggests the Japanese economy is stable, but policymakers may still face pressure to address potential economic challenges.

site_title: Taiwan economy contracts 1.015% y-o-y in Q3, dodges recession
summary: Taiwan's economy contracted 1.01% in Q3, its first year-over-year decline in six years and narrowly avoiding a recession. This contraction was worse than forecast and marked the first time since the 2009 global financial crisis. The decline was attributed to a crippling blow from slackening global demand, primarily affecting exporters.

site_title: Noble Group shorts finally get burned on 25% rebound in October
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a Singapore-based commodity trader, has surged 25% this month, reversing its 54% loss for 2015. The rebound, fueled by fresh funding from lenders and speculation that the worst of the commodity price collapse is over, has lifted the short-interest ratio to 14.8%. Analysts attribute the gain to Noble's efforts to increase transparency and improve its liquidity position. However, Moody's Investors Service warns that Noble may lose its investment-grade ranking if its liquidity position doesn't improve in the next quarter.

site_title: Barclays sees risk of more conduct costs, cuts profit target
summary: Barclays has cut its 2016 profit target due to rising conduct costs, including a 560 million-pound charge for misconduct and redress. The bank's third-quarter pretax profit fell 10% to 1.43 billion pounds, missing analyst estimates. Barclays expects conduct and litigation costs to remain elevated, with a projected 1 billion pounds of restructuring costs. The bank's shares slumped 6.3% after the announcement, and its return on equity fell to 5.7%. New CEO Jes Staley aims to speed up cost cuts and boost profitability.

site_title: Apple TV challenges developers to take apps to the big screen
summary: Apple has launched a new version of its Apple TV, starting shipping in 80 countries, with a long-awaited update that includes an App Store for big-screen apps. Hundreds of apps, including gaming, shopping, and photography, will be available at launch. Developers are embracing the opportunity to reach users in a more intimate setting, despite competing with other platforms. The device starts at $149 and is expected to be lucrative for developers who reimagine their work for the big screen.

site_title: GLP reports 27.4 per cent growth in Q2 net profit
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 27.4% growth in Q2 net profit to US$114 million, driven by growth in China, development gains in Japan, and the absence of forex losses. Revenue slipped 1.9% to US$189.3 million, affected by the sale of properties and weakening of the Japanese Yen. The company's fund management revenue increased 51% to US$74 million, with total fund management assets under management reaching US$27 billion, up 107% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported on Friday that its net profit for the fiscal second quarter grew 27.4 per cent from a year ago to about US$114 million.

site_title: Carmakers win reprieve on EU pollution testing
summary: The European Union has agreed to ease pollution limits for diesel cars, reprieving the car industry from stricter emissions testing. The EU will phase in real-driving tests over six years, with new models allowed to overshoot the limit by 110% initially, before bringing it down to 50% by 2023. The move was criticized by environmental campaigners, but car manufacturers welcomed the delay, citing the need for a significant grace period to meet new standards.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips on tech results, chances of Fed hike
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday, despite reaching records earlier in the week, due to disappointing tech earnings reports and concerns about a potential interest rate hike in December. The Federal Reserve kept rates unchanged, downplaying concerns about global growth and expressing confidence in the US job market's recovery. The market had been boosted by the Fed's statement on Wednesday, but a "cooling pause" was expected after a strong run from the end of September.

images.alt_text: US stocks ended slightly lower on Thursday as the market digested disappointing tech earnings reports and the potential for an interest rate hike in December.

site_title: UOB's Q3 net profit slips 1 per cent, declares one-off 80th anniversary dividend
summary: UOB Group reported a 1% drop in Q3 net profit to S$858 million, driven by strong core income and one-off gains from investment securities sales. Total income rose 5.8% to S$2.1 billion, with net interest income increasing 6.9% to S$1.2 billion. A one-off 80th anniversary dividend of 20 cents per share was declared. The bank's capital position remains robust, with a loan-to-deposit ratio of 81.6% and non-performing loan ratio of 1.3%.

site_title: Union Steel to buy two land parcels, plant from Chye Hup Heng
summary: Union Steel Holdings' subsidiary, Union CHH Sdn Bhd, has acquired two land parcels in Johor Baru and a scrap metal shredder plant for RM16.5 million. The acquisition was made after Chye Hup Heng Sdn Bhd (CHH), the original seller, was wound up by a Malaysian High Court order in 2014. The deal comes after Union CHH initially planned to acquire eight parcels of land, equipment, and machinery from CHH but was unable to complete the purchase due to CHH's winding up.

site_title: No respite from S'pore's economic headwinds
summary: Singapore's economy faces economic headwinds, with the latest industrial production data showing an eighth consecutive month of manufacturing contraction. The country's growth is expected to underperform its official forecast of 2-2.5% for 2015, marking its lowest growth since the 2008/2009 global financial crisis. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) latest monetary policy move was seen as a slight easing, contradicting market calls for aggressive easing to boost growth. MAS believes the economy is not experiencing a retraction in economic activity, but rather cyclical challenges that will continue to weigh on it, emphasizing the need for a strategy to drive productivity gains via technology and skill upgrades.

site_title: Bigger Pharma: Allergan in merger talks with Pfizer
summary: Allergan, maker of Botox, is in "friendly" merger talks with Pfizer, potentially forming a $300 billion pharmaceutical behemoth. The deal could move Pfizer's tax domicile to Ireland, taking advantage of lower corporate tax rates. Allergan's price could run $113 billion or more, making it the largest takeover in a record year of merger and acquisition activity. The negotiations would not interrupt plans to sell off Allergan's global generic drugs business to Teva.

images.alt_text: Botox-maker Allergan said on Thursday it was in "friendly" merger talks with Pfizer that have the potential of forming a US$300 billion pharmaceutical behemoth.

site_title: Disrupting the norm: how to innovate successfully
summary: Disruptive innovation, defined by Professor Clayton Christensen, is key to creating value for large corporations, changing industry structures, and introducing new players to the market. Successful examples include Uber, Spotify, and Airbnb. However, established multinational corporations (MNCs) struggle to leverage disruptive innovation, despite 20 years of research on its failure and countermeasures. Small and lean startups are more likely to achieve disruption, but MNCs can still maintain their competitive edge by adopting a culture that encourages experimentation and risk-taking. Effective disruption requires a willingness to challenge the status quo and disrupt traditional business models.

site_title: Gold touches two-week low
summary: Gold prices dropped to a two-week low after the Federal Reserve signaled a possible interest rate hike this year, citing moderate economic growth. The Fed's statement increased the odds of a rate hike in December to 50% from 34% a week ago. Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of gold, as it doesn't generate returns like bonds or equities. This move is expected to curb gold prices further, making it a challenging time for gold investors.

site_title: Pfizer in takeover talks with Allergan: report
summary: Pfizer Inc has held early talks with Allergan plc, a Botox-maker, to discuss a potential takeover deal valued at around US$330 billion, creating the world's largest healthcare group. The deal would combine Pfizer's US$219 billion market value with Allergan's US$113 billion market value. A takeover could offer tax advantages, as Allergan is based in lower-tax Dublin. Analysts believe the deal could boost Pfizer's top-line growth, despite the company's expected revenue slide of 3.3% this year. The talks are in early stages and may not yield an agreement.

site_title: Stretching their body of work to new limits
summary: Cirque du Soleil's Totem, created by Robert Lepage, premiered on opening night with 12 acts that defied gravity, physics, and human limitations. The show features a range of acts, including a Native American roller-skating duo and a female quintet balancing on unicycles while juggling bowls. The storyline is unclear, but the technical mastery and bravery of the performers make the show "slick, well-executed, and mind-bogglingly brave." Totem is a testament to Cirque's reputation as the best in the business.

site_title: Strengthen Singapore's three comparative advantages to create value: Iswaran
summary: Singapore needs to deepen its comparative advantages in public-private sector collaboration, internal coordination, and nurturing new capabilities to compete globally and create value. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran emphasized the importance of these areas, citing examples such as SkillsFuture and public-private cooperation. To achieve value-creation, Singapore should focus on strengthening its proprietary advantages, raising labor productivity, and investing in individual sectors. This will help the country move up the innovation ladder and create opportunities for Singaporeans.

site_title: Starbucks' forecast misses estimates after labour costs climb
summary: Starbucks' first-quarter forecast missed analysts' estimates due to rising labor and technology costs. The company reported earnings of 44-45 US cents per share, lower than the estimated 47 cents. Despite this, Starbucks' mobile-payments system now accounts for 21% of US store transactions, and the company expects to increase spending on employees and technology by US$100-125 million next year. Net income rose 11% to US$652.5 million, and sales increased 18% to US$4.91 billion, beating analysts' projections.

site_title: Nintendo delays launch of smartphone video game; shares plunge
summary: Nintendo has delayed the launch of its smartphone game Miitomo, initially aiming for the end of 2015, until March 2016. The delay led to a 10% drop in Nintendo's shares, with the company's new president Tatsumi Kimishima citing the need to "boost the quality" of the game. The move adds to uncertainty surrounding the company, which has been struggling since the death of its former CEO Satoru Iwata. The delay also affects DeNA, a mobile gaming company that developed the game with Nintendo.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler posts surprise quarterly loss on recall costs
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV (FCA) reported a surprise third-quarter net loss of 306 million euros due to one-time charges from handling a US recall, despite an 17% revenue increase to 27.5 billion euros. This contrasts with analysts' expectations of a profit rise. Adjusted earnings before interest and taxes rose to 1.3 billion euros from 968 million euros in the 2014 period. The loss was attributed to recall costs, not a decline in earnings.

site_title: CityDev's M&C Hotels posts one-third fall in Q3 profit
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne Hotels (M&C), the London-listed hotel arm of City Developments, reported a 33.3% drop in Q3 net profit to £24 million, down from £36 million a year ago. Revenue fell 2.8% to £211 million, while earnings per share slipped to 7.3 pence from 10.9 pence. The decline was attributed to weaker performance in Singapore and Rest of Asia, with hotel room inventory growth continuing to affect the market.

site_title: Qatar joins Brookfield's US$8.6b mixed project in Manhattan
summary: Qatar Investment Authority has formed a joint venture with Brookfield Property Partners LP on the US$8.6 billion Manhattan West project in New York, acquiring a 44% stake. The 7 million sq ft mixed-use development includes residential and office towers, with completion scheduled for 2019. This deal expands Qatar's global investments, following recent acquisitions in London, as investors seek safe havens in Manhattan real estate, driving prices to records.

site_title: Inflation won't start roaring ahead but expect an imminent increase
summary: Economists expect a minor increase in inflation, around 0.8-0.9%, as the negative influence of low oil prices on inflation is removed. This means headline consumer price inflation will converge with core inflation rates, indicating a return to more normal inflation levels. While core inflation rates have been creeping up, the overall inflation environment remains low, and investors may become more balanced in their assessment of risks, shifting from a pessimistic outlook to a more neutral stance.

site_title: LNG Marine Value Chain
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors considered market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Gold prices increased after US President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada and threatened others. In other news, Chinese solar stocks surged amid Beijing's efforts to calm price wars, and OPEC announced a reduction in oil demand for the next four years. Exxon Singapore is reportedly in talks to sell its stations to Aster.

site_title: STI falls on likely December US rate hike
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 39 points, or 1.3%, to 3,001.51 on Thursday, marking its third consecutive loss. The decline was attributed to a likely US interest rate hike in December, as indicated by the Federal Reserve's recent statement. Volume remained low, with a total turnover of S$957 million. Bank OCBC reported Q3 earnings, with its shares dropping 0.08 and then 0.12, but brokers maintained a neutral stance.

site_title: MTQ S$0.5m in the red for Q2; revenue down 28%
summary: MTQ Corp, a Singapore-based engineering and maintenance services group, reported a net loss of S$501,000 in Q2, down from a profit of S$5.28 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 28% to S$57.82 million due to weak demand for oilfield engineering services. Gross profit fell 43% to S$15 million, with gross profit margin at 26%, down from 33% a year ago. The company continues to cut operating expenses and staff costs to combat the softer outlook.

site_title: The joy of wine
summary: A wine enthusiast revisited old wines from their cellar, discovering pleasant surprises. They tasted three wines: Barrua 2003 (Agricola Punica), an Italian blend of Carignan, Cabernet Sauvignon, and Merlot, which developed significantly over time; Eisele Syrah 2004 (Araujo Estate) from Napa Valley, a warm climate Syrah with good richness and backbone; and Château Rayas Blanc 2001 (Château Rayas), a Southern Rhone white wine with a smooth, long finish. The wines showcased the potential of aged wines and the importance of terroir in wine production.

site_title: Singapore is on track to double productivity growth: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that Singapore is on track to double its productivity growth, contradicting reports to the contrary. This comes after visiting a Cold Storage supermarket to see its new smart shopping technologies.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q3 profit hit by impairment loss
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported an 8% drop in Q3 net profit to S$16.2 million due to an impairment loss of S$7.7 million related to a Chinese development land. Excluding this impact, net profit would have been 36% higher. Revenue increased 85% to S$184.3 million, with property revenue driving growth. The company's net asset value per share rose to 71.8 cents, and the counter ended trading one cent higher at 34.5 cents.

site_title: The Cirque-us is back in town
summary: Cirque du Soleil's Totem has returned to Singapore, featuring a 12-act show that follows the evolutionary journey of the human species from its original amphibian state to its ultimate desire to fly. Artistic director Neelanthi Vadivel aims to keep the show fresh and evolving while staying true to creator Robert Lepage's original intention. The intimate setting, with a focus on high-level skill sets, complements the multicultural musical inspiration, making it a unique experience for the audience.

images.alt_text: Cirque du Soleil artists performing on segments of the Russian Bars (above) during a press preview in Singapore on Oct 27.
Cirque du Soleil artists performing on segments of the Russian Bars (above) during a press preview in Singapore on Oct 27.
Cirque du Soleil artists performing a Native American Hoop Dance during a press preview in Singapore on Oct 27. Totem was conceived in Montreal in 2010, and has now found its way to Singapore.

site_title: CNA sells core business to CEO for S$300,000
summary: CNA Group's judicial managers announced the sale of its Singapore business to CEO Michael Ong for S$300,000, plus bond and guarantee replacement costs. The business, which provides building-controls systems and IT solutions, will be transferred to CNA Development. The sale follows a demand for winding up by Kele & Associates due to S$175,148.71 debt. The business is unable to bid on government projects and lacks sufficient financial resources. Existing contracts and guarantees will be transferred to the new entity, allowing the company to avoid insolvency.

site_title: A slice of The Mahabharata
summary: Theatrical duo Peter Brook and Marie-Helene Estienne are staging a stand-alone play, "Battlefield," based on the last chapter of the 3,000-year-old Hindu epic "The Mahabharata." The play, which explores the consequences of war, features a four-actor cast and simple staging. Brook, now 90, says the production is relevant to today's world, allowing it to address questions about life, death, and the search for answers. The play will premiere in Singapore on November 17 and embark on a world tour.

site_title: Q3 unemployment stays at 2%, but total employment grows
summary: Singapore's overall unemployment rate remained unchanged at 2% in the third quarter, but citizens and residents experienced a slight increase, rising to 3.1% and 3% respectively. Total employment grew by 16,400, driven by growth in services and construction, while redundancies declined for the third consecutive quarter, with 2,900 workers laid off. Experts note that policymakers may focus on the rising citizen unemployment rate, but still expect wage growth to pick up.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singaporean playwright-director Chong Tze Chien returns to the stage with "Seed", a play about the Fukushima nuclear disaster and its impact on food and identity. Meanwhile, international chef Susur Lee presents his "Ocean's Best II" menu at TungLok Heen, and the hit musical "Ghost the Musical" comes to Singapore. The city's nightscape is explored in the "Nightscape 2050" exhibition, and a sake bar "Kakure" offers a unique sake-pairing experience. A charity auction features artworks created by special needs children, with proceeds going to support a vocational institute and the Special Olympics Singapore.

site_title: End of an era as China scraps one-child policy
summary: China has officially ended its one-child policy, allowing all couples to have two children, after decades of enforcing a restrictive population control measure. The policy change was announced without explanation by the Communist Party's Central Committee. Economists doubt the new policy will quickly address the population imbalance, raising concerns about potential long-term consequences. The move marks a historic change in China's demographic landscape.

site_title: Bank of Japan could ease further despite strong industrial output data
summary: The Bank of Japan's Policy Board may announce further monetary easing despite stronger-than-expected industrial output data, which rose 1% in September. Analysts suggest the BOJ is widening its focus to support Japanese stock prices and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic growth targets. The US Federal Reserve's recent statement may provide "cover" for the BOJ to ease further, and a massive IPO of Japan Post shares next week could benefit from a BOJ easing move. The BOJ may announce increased purchases of government bonds and ETFs to boost confidence and support the economy.

site_title: Global smartphone sales pick up on fierce competition: poll
summary: Global smartphone sales increased by 6.8% in the third quarter to 355.2 million units, the second-highest quarterly total on record. Major vendors, including Apple and Samsung, offered special deals and financing plans to attract buyers. Samsung remained the top vendor with 23.5% market share, followed by Apple with 13.5%. Huawei saw a 60.9% growth in sales, becoming the fastest-growing vendor. The competition between Apple and Samsung intensified at the high-end, while low to mid-range handsets continue to drive growth in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Samsung remained the top vendor, delivering 84.5 million handsets or 23.5 per cent of the total market, followed by Apple's 48 million which gave the US firm 13.5 per cent.

site_title: US budget: A messy deal in a messy political setting
summary: The US budget deal, reached by congressional leaders, aims to end the threat of a national default and reduce the possibility of a government shutdown. The deal relaxes spending caps, increasing US$50 billion in fiscal 2016 and US$30 billion in 2017, while making modest cuts in other programs and raising government fees and taxes. However, the deal lacks a genuine public debate on the role of government and resorts to "budget gimmicks," including the use of the Overseas Contingency Operations category to fund ordinary spending. The agreement raises government spending by about US$111 billion over two years, with only about half the costs offset.

site_title: Olam in a very good place today: CEO
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based company, has emerged from a damaging shortseller attack three years ago and is now on the growth trajectory again. The company refocused its strategy and made changes following the crisis, which sent its shares spiralling. Olam is now in a good place, indicating a successful recovery from the setback.

site_title: VW scandal will be a driving force for hybrid technology
summary: The Volkswagen diesel emissions scandal is expected to accelerate the shift towards hybrid technology, particularly petrol-electric and plug-in electric hybrids, as diesel technology becomes less viable due to stricter regulations and public perception. Automakers such as Toyota and General Motors are already investing in plug-in hybrids, while Honda is gaining momentum with hydrogen fuel-cell cars. Industry experts predict conventional gas-electric hybrids will be useful in the short term, but diesel technology's future is uncertain, with some companies still investing in diesel engine capacity.

site_title: Regime change may not be for the better
summary: US foreign policy's experience in the Middle East, particularly in Iraq, Syria, and Libya, suggests that regime change may not be for the better. Unlike the optimistic liberal elites after World War I, the aftermath of the US-led interventions in the region has led to instability, civil wars, and the rise of radical Islamist forces. The ousting of Saddam Hussein in Iraq and Muammar Gaddafi in Libya resulted in power vacuums that empowered extremist groups, making the region more violent and unstable. This experience challenges the conventional wisdom of exporting liberal democracy through regime change.

site_title: GP Hotels Q3 profit down 30%
summary: Global Premium Hotels reported a 30.1% year-on-year decline in profit to S$3.57 million for the third quarter ended Sept 30, due to lower revenue amid a challenging operating environment. Occupancy rates and revenue per available room (RevPAR) fell, with average occupancy rate at 85.9% and RevPAR at S$89.50. The group attributed the decline to a dip in tourist arrivals and additional supply in the hotel industry. The company expects the trend to continue in the last quarter of the year and is embarking on asset enhancement works.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit posted a 1.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.8 Singapore cents for the second quarter ended Sept 30, 2015. Gross revenue rose 3.2% to S$31.3 million, while net property income climbed 2.4% to S$20.7 million. The trust secured 13 new and renewal leases at a weighted average rental increase of 4.7% and improved occupancy to 96.5% from 96.1%.

site_title: Time to rethink the need for buying-in
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) forcibly bought-in 6.9 million YuuZoo shares at an average price of S$0.20 apiece, raising concerns about the need for the buying-in system. The buying-in process, which covers uncovered short positions, can result in punitive prices and significant losses for investors. Despite efforts to streamline the system, the SGX continues to use an outdated method, leaving many questions about its effectiveness and fairness. Experts suggest that a more modern system, which immediately rejects unsufficient sell orders, could minimize errors and losses.

site_title: Fifa's Blatter claims backroom deal on Russia World Cup
summary: SEPP Blatter, outgoing FIFA president, claims a backroom deal gave Russia the 2018 World Cup, blaming England and the US for the corruption scandal. He alleged a secret meeting between Sarkozy and Qatar's prince influenced the vote, resulting in Qatar's 14-8 win. Blatter accused Michel Platini of being the original cause of the crisis, sparking a 90-day suspension. FIFA's Electoral Committee will consider Platini's candidacy once his ban is lifted.

site_title: A new retelling of what war does to the human spirit
summary: Theater director Oliver Chong is directing "The Spirits Play" by Kuo Pao Kun, exploring the grim realities and consequences of war on the human spirit. The play features five Japanese spirits recalling their World War II experiences and has been staged multiple times in Singapore since its debut in 1998. Chong aims to stay true to Kuo's anti-war message, while also reflecting on the play's themes of collectivism and nationalism. The play will run from Nov 5-15 at Drama Centre's Black Box.

site_title: More to Peranakan culture than just makan
summary: The inaugural Peranakan Arts Festival in Singapore aims to showcase the rich heritage of the Peranakan community through a diverse line-up of events. The five-day festival, held from Nov 4 to Nov 8, features four exhibitions, three seminars, two theatre productions, and a bazaar. The festival highlights the community's artistic heritage in food, design, theatre, and music, and provides a platform for Peranakans to celebrate and share their stories. The event is the brainchild of festival director Joyce Lim and chairman of GenerAsia Richard Tan, who sought to promote the Peranakan culture through the arts.

site_title: Private banks should watch crowdfunding space: report
summary: A Swiss research firm, MyPrivateBanking, warns private banks about the growing threat of the crowdfunding market, expected to reach $1 trillion in 10 years. The market is currently valued at $34 billion and primarily targets accredited investors, posing a risk to wealth managers. To mitigate this, private banks should consider "hand-holding" clients who engage in crowdfunding and fulfill an investment advisory role, regarding crowdfunding as an asset class.

site_title: Sembcorp warns of doubtful debts ahead as Q3 profit dives
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 37.8% drop in Q3 net profit to S$122.30 million, with the marine arm experiencing a 75% decline due to lower rig building projects. The utilities arm also saw a 21% decrease in earnings. The company warned of potential further provisions for doubtful debts, citing a customer in receivership, although CEO Tang Kin Fei expressed optimism about recovering the debt.

site_title: Energy majors brace for long period of low oil and gas prices
summary: Energy majors Royal Dutch Shell and BP reported dismal results due to low oil and gas prices. Shell's third-quarter net loss was $7.42 billion, while BP's profits fell 40% to $1.8 billion. Analysts question whether cuts in capital and exploration expenditure will lead to an eventual recovery, with Saudi Arabia's influence on global oil supplies being a key variable. Some predict oil prices will remain low for an extended period, while others expect a gradual increase to $80 a barrel by 2018.

site_title: PayPal chief defends long-term strategy after sales miss
summary: PayPal's shares dropped 7.8% after the company reported a decline in its take rate, a measure of how much money it keeps from each payment made on its platform, to 3.24% in the third quarter. Despite adding 4 million new accounts and increasing total payments volume by 20%, the company's strategy to attract more customers and merchants and offer expanded services is being questioned by investors. CEO Dan Schulman defended the strategy, saying it's expected to lead to lower take rates over time.

images.alt_text: Mr Schulman said that PayPal's strategy is to keep increasing its presence in the flow of money from shoppers to merchants as well as from family and friends to one another.

site_title: Samsung Elec unveils 11.3t won buyback as Q3 profit rebounds
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 29.3% surge in third-quarter net profit to 5.46 trillion won, snapping a streak of seven consecutive quarterly declines. The company attributed the increase to favorable exchange rates and a renewed focus on components, including chips, displays, and screens. Samsung also announced an 11.3 trillion won share buyback and plans to invest 27 trillion won in capital expenditures this year. The company's cash reserves stood at 70 trillion won, and analysts welcomed the move to boost investor satisfaction.

site_title: Four shows to catch
summary: A triple bill featuring T.H.E Dance Company will run from Dec 3-5 and 8pm, showcasing three new and promising works. Kuik Swee Boon's Pellucid, a minimalist piece, will be performed alongside Jecko Siompo's fusion of Jakarta street dance, Papuan tribal dance, and American hip-hop, and Iratxe Ansa's emotionally raw and rigorous choreography. This event marks the company's debut of new works and promises a unique and captivating experience.

site_title: Google parent to launch Internet beaming balloons in Indonesia
summary: Alphabet Inc, the parent company of Google, has signed a deal with three Indonesian telecommunications firms to test its Internet-beaming balloons across the country. The project, known as Project Loon, aims to bring internet access to the 150 million Indonesians who lack it. The balloons, which use wireless spectrum secured by the firms, will be tested over the next year to refine the technology before a potential commercial launch. Indonesia's President Joko Widodo was initially scheduled to visit Google, but cancelled due to haze caused by forest fires.

site_title: BW Maritime looks to expand regas capacity
summary: BW Maritime plans to expand its fleet of floating regasification and storage units (FSRUs) to meet growing demand for fast-tracked liquefied natural gas (LNG) import solutions. The company aims to capitalize on lower LNG spot prices and has two FSRUs under construction. BW Shipping's managing director, Yngvil Asheim, noted the growth potential in Central and South America, the Middle East, and Asia. The company will prioritize FSRU expansion to meet customers' requirements, with plans to build-to-order FSRUs for clients with sufficient lead time.

site_title: Foodie flick that's only mildly satisfying
summary: Burnt, a dramedy starring Bradley Cooper as a disgraced chef, is an entertaining but predictable film that captures the intensity of a restaurant kitchen. Director John Wells brings a frenetic pace, with close-ups of dishes prepared by celebrity chefs Marcus Wareing and Mario Batali. While the film is mildly satisfying, it lacks originality, similar to Chef and The Hundred-Foot Journey. Cooper's performance is notable, but the story follows a familiar Rocky-like trajectory. Overall, Burnt is an enjoyable but unremarkable film.

site_title: English hitmakers learn to balance work and play
summary: The Vaccines, an English rock band, have managed to balance their prolific work schedule with touring and personal life. Since forming in 2010, they have released multiple studio albums and EPs, and are now working on a new batch of 50 songs. Lead singer Justin Young attributes their touring lifestyle to "institutionalizing" them, but also values the experiences and memories they make along the way. Despite shifting their musical direction, the band remains committed to creating "good and simple rock and roll songs." They will play their first headlining show in Singapore next week.

site_title: Q3 DPS drops 9.7% at CDL Hospitality Trust
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) reported a 9.7% drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.36 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2015, due to weaker performance of its Singapore, Australia, and New Zealand hotels and incremental interest expenses. Despite a 2.4% rise in gross revenue, net property income declined 2.2% to S$33.1 million. Occupancy for Singapore hotels remained robust at 90.2%. The trust expects room rates to remain competitive amid caution in corporate travel expenditure.

site_title: Alibaba shows consumers are now king in China
summary: Alibaba's strong third-quarter sales figures indicate a shift in China's economy, with retail sales driving growth and surpassing investment. This trend, driven by President Xi Jinping's government rebalancing, may lead to the world's greatest consumption story of the 21st century. Consumer spending is expected to continue, with Apple and other companies expanding their presence in China, and local services market growth projected to reach $7.28 trillion by 2017. Experts believe consumers will play a key role in China's growth for years to come, despite challenges in sentiment and confidence.

site_title: The region's story, told through art
summary: The National Gallery Singapore's UOB Southeast Asia Gallery features a collection of 400 works by Southeast Asian artists, marking the first time the Bangko Sentral of the Philippines has loaned an artwork to an institution outside its country on a long-term basis. The exhibition, "Between Declarations And Dreams," showcases the region's art, including a rare copy of Filipino artist Félix Resurrección Hidalgo's 19th-century painting "The Christian Virgins," which earned the second prize in a Spanish art competition. The gallery aims to capture the zeitgeist of Southeast Asia through its visual representation, highlighting the region's artistic and cultural heritage.

site_title: Billionaire Niel buys Telecom Italia Stake, follows Vivendi
summary: Billionaire Xavier Niel has bought a 1.7 billion-euro stake in Telecom Italia SpA, becoming the second-largest investor after Vivendi's Vincent Bollore. Niel's investment gives him an 11% voting stake in the company, which owns a significant mobile and broadband carrier in Italy and controls Brazil's second-largest wireless provider. The move comes as Telecom Italia seeks to revive its Italian business and reduce a debt load of almost 27 billion euros. Niel, founder of Iliad SA, has invested in various startups, including Square and Deezer, and has a net worth of US$7.5 billion.

site_title: Olam CEO shares pointers on avoiding shortseller attacks
summary: Olam International CEO Sunny Verghese shared strategies to avoid shortseller attacks, citing the need for committed long-term shareholders and maintaining stakeholder trust. He emphasized that shortselling is a legitimate market activity, but companies should respond with integrity to prevent misleading research. Since being targeted by US shortseller Muddy Waters in 2012, Olam has developed a strategy to prevent future attacks, and the company now has a strong backing of long-term shareholders, including Temasek Holdings and the founding family.

site_title: Contemporary dance festival revs up
summary: The M1 Contact Contemporary Dance Festival 2015 is set to take place, featuring a diverse lineup of performances, including acclaimed dance companies Chunky Move and R.se Dance Company. The festival boasts a broad range of performances, from student showcases to under-the-radar artists, with a focus on emerging talent. The event is part of a growing trend in the arts scene, with overall ticketed attendance of dance shows rising by over 50% between 2009 and 2013. The festival is expected to attract a large audience, solidifying its position as a major event in the contemporary dance scene.

site_title: Visitor spending down 12% in first half as arrivals drop
summary: Visitor spending in Singapore declined 12% in the first half of 2015, with tourism receipts falling to S$10.5 billion, while visitor arrivals dropped 3% to 7.3 million. The decline was attributed to softening volumes from key source markets and a strengthening Singapore dollar. However, the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) reported a rebound in visitor arrivals since May, fueled by a recovery from top source markets such as China and India. The STB is working with the tourism industry to boost visitor arrivals and has launched initiatives to develop new tourism experiences and expand its digital footprint.

site_title: Baker Tech's Q3 profit falls 38% as revenue slides 74%
summary: Baker Technology reported a 38% drop in net profit to S$2.66 million for the third quarter, due to a 74% decline in revenue. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in the oil and gas industry. Despite a foreign exchange gain of S$3.6 million, the company's earnings per share decreased to 0.26 Singapore cent. The company expects a challenging operating environment for the next 12 months and is exploring external avenues for strategic alliances and acquisitions.

site_title: HK home transactions seen headed for 20-year low
summary: Hong Kong's existing-home transactions are likely to reach a 20-year low in October, with sales possibly falling to 2,000, according to Ricacorp Properties Ltd. The drop is attributed to prospective buyers waiting for prices to drop and sellers refusing to settle for less money. The government has implemented cooling measures, including tightening mortgage rules and raising transaction levies, in an effort to address the housing issue, which has seen home prices jump 370% since 2003.

site_title: Judicial managers of CNA Group sell core Singapore business to CEO
summary: Judicial managers of CNA Group's Singapore business have sold the company to CEO Michael Ong for S$300,000, including replacement of performance bonds and guarantees. The sale is due to the company's inability to bid for government projects and retain existing management. The Singapore business will be transferred to CNA Development, and all existing contracts and guarantees will be transferred. This move is aimed at ensuring the completion of ongoing projects and mitigating contingent liabilities. Existing management is crucial for project completion.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to shed 26,000 jobs, exit markets
summary: Deutsche Bank plans to reduce its workforce by 26,000 people by 2018, including a 9,000 net job cut, as part of its strategy to improve returns and cut costs. The bank will close operations in 10 countries and move trading businesses to global and regional hubs. It will also reduce its number of investment banking clients by about half. The move aims to lower costs by 3.8 billion euros and boost capital buffers, with the goal of achieving a common equity tier 1 ratio of at least 12.5% by 2018.

site_title: Horror-comedy aimed at the whole family
summary: Goosebumps, a horror-comedy film based on the popular children's book series, is set to release in time for Halloween. Directed by Rob Letterman, the movie features Jack Black as RL Stine and follows teenager Zach as he navigates a new town, friendships, and romance. The film's tone is light-hearted and family-friendly, making it suitable for viewers of all ages. With its fast-paced plot and special effects, Goosebumps aims to deliver a fun and entertaining experience for its target demographic of under-17s.

site_title: London and HK facing housing bubble risk, says UBS
summary: UBS warns that London and Hong Kong are at risk of a housing bubble due to overvalued real estate prices. London is the second-least affordable city, with price-to-income values at all-time highs despite a 7% decline in real earnings since 2007. The report advises caution and notes that a "substantial price correction" is possible if fundamentals deteriorate. Other cities, including Sydney, Vancouver, and Amsterdam, are also considered overvalued, while Chicago is undervalued.

site_title: Dollar's post-Fed rally fizzles as investors focus on US growth
summary: The US dollar retreated from its strongest level in over two months versus the euro after investors focused on US growth and jobs data due on Thursday. The dollar had surged on Wednesday as traders boosted bets on a possible interest-rate hike by the Federal Reserve this year. However, economists predict a slowdown in US growth in the third quarter and a rise in jobless claims, which dampened the dollar's rally. The dollar weakened 0.4% to US$1.0962 per euro, while the euro rose against other major currencies, including the yen.

site_title: US Fed sends clear signal about a December interest rate hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, but sent a clear signal that a December interest rate hike is likely. The economy expanded at a 1.5% annual rate in the third quarter, slightly slower than expected. The Fed downplayed global financial market turmoil and said the US labor market is still healing. Investors now see a 43% chance of a rate hike in December, up from 34% before the statement.

images.alt_text: Ms Yellen has been saying that a rate hike would likely be needed in 2015 to keep the economy from eventually overheating

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singaporean bank OCBC's Q3 2015 core net profit fell 14% quarter-over-quarter due to lower non-interest income and higher provisions. OCBC maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of S$10.70. Linc Energy's share price is expected to stage a corrective rebound after testing a support level at S$0.15. Wing Tai Holdings Ltd's Q1 FY2016 profit fell 92% year-over-year, but revenues increased 6% year-over-year. Despite this, OCBC Investment Research maintains a "buy" rating for Wing Tai with a fair value estimate of S$2.58, citing the group's well-positioned position to ride out the current down-cycle.

site_title: Ascott Reit's Q3 DPU dips 2% on one-off item's interest cost
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) reported a 2% year-on-year dip in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.07 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, due to a one-off item of about S$1.2 million related to interest costs on perpetual securities issued in June.

site_title: Growth-hungry US utilities avoid MLPs for Pipes
summary: US power utilities are acquiring natural gas pipeline networks, but avoiding master limited partnerships (MLPs) due to their high risk and volatility. Duke Energy's $4.9 billion deal to buy Piedmont Natural Gas Co. is the latest example. Utilities prefer regulated, lower-risk businesses that offer consistent dividends, unlike MLPs with commodity and volumetric risk. Southern Co and WEC Energy Group Inc. have also followed this trend, opting for gas businesses that rely on transportation fees rather than long-haul shipments. MLPs have lost 40% of their value in the past year.

site_title: BCA CEO wins award for sustainability effort
summary: BCA CEO John Keung won the World Green Building Council's Chairman's Award 2015 for his efforts in advancing the green building movement in Singapore. This recognition is a result of his collaboration with the Singapore Green Building Council, a member of the WorldGBC. The award is a testament to BCA's commitment to green building and its impact on the local built environment.

site_title: Sino-SingaporeJilin Food Zone unveils first product
summary: Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone (SSJFZ) has unveiled its first product, SSJFZ-branded Fragrance 43ºN japonica rice, which will be launched in Singapore by the end of the year. The rice is produced in compliance with SSJFZ's Integrated Food Safety System, established based on Singapore's expertise. The zone has attracted 15 investment projects worth over $2.2 billion, with 60 tonnes of rice to be imported for the pilot launch. The SSJFZ aims to draw foreign investors due to its association with Singapore, which carries a trusted brand.

images.alt_text: At Thursday's unveiling of the Fragrance 43ºN japonica rice were (left to right) Li Chengjun, general manager, COFCO Rice (Jilin); Zheng Chao, minister counsellor (economics and commercial office) at the Chinese Embassy in Singapore; Miguel Ko, CEO, Ascendas-Singbridge Group; Jilin City mayor Zhang Huanqiu; Yeo Chun Cheng, executive vice-president, Singbridge Group, and CEO, Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone Development and Management Co, Ltd; and Mui-Kok Kah Wei, senior director (purchasing and merchandising), NTUC FairPrice.

site_title: China's C.banner to buy British toy store chain Hamleys
summary: Chinese footwear retailer C.banner International Holdings has agreed to buy iconic British toy store chain Hamleys for £100 million (US$153 million) in cash. The acquisition comes after Ludendo Groupe, France's owner of Hamleys since 2012, announced the deal earlier this week. The purchase follows a week after Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to the UK, where business deals worth £40 billion (US$61 billion) were signed. The acquisition marks a significant expansion of C.banner's presence in the global market.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust's Q4 DPS lower than forecast
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's Q4 distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 1.2% to 1.66 Singapore cents due to higher interest expenses. Group revenue and net property income outperformed forecasts, driven by strong performances in Japan, Australia, and the UK. The company aims to increase average daily rates at InterContinental Singapore and The Westin Kuala Lumpur, and is exploring acquisitions in Europe to capitalize on growth markets.

site_title: Bids for Ubi industrial site 'too low', says HDB
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) has rejected all five bids for an industrial development site at Ubi Avenue 1, citing prices that were too low. The top bid, from BP-DC Pte Ltd, was S$19.9 million, or S$120.91 per square foot per plot ratio. Consultants had expected more bids and higher prices, with some citing the government's intention to bring down prices in the market. The site's lease term of 30 years and proximity to MacPherson MRT station are also seen as attractive features.

site_title: India makes rare purchases of soymeal from China, Ukraine
summary: India has made rare purchases of non-genetically modified soymeal from China and Ukraine, importing 7,000 tonnes at around $350 per tonne. The imports are aimed at putting downward pressure on Indian domestic prices, which have jumped 16% in two months due to lower soybean production. The move is expected to push inventory holders into selling, and if the government removes the 16% import duty, more imports are possible.

site_title: No 'one-size-fits-all' approach to sustainable growth: Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that there is no "one-size-fits-all" approach to sustainable economic development, as countries must make complex trade-offs. Three key principles guide long-term growth: market-oriented policies underpinned by macro-economic fundamentals, equitable distribution of wealth, and prioritizing investment in people. These principles are adaptable to each country's unique culture, history, and politics, and are mutually-reinforcing, with growth and equity needing each other.

site_title: New Circle Line stations to give direct access to southern Singapore
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to build three new Circle Line stations, connecting HarbourFront to Marina Bay, and improve access to the Central Business District. The S$3.7 billion project, set to be completed by 2025, will close the loop of the Circle Line and provide direct East-West travel. The new stations will also support the redevelopment of the city-port area, known as the Greater Southern Waterfront, and increase property values along the stretch. The project is expected to ease traffic in the city area and provide commuters with more efficient travel options.

site_title: MTQ Corp goes into the red for Q2
summary: MTQ Corp reported a net loss of S$501,000 for Q2, down from a net profit of S$5.28 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 28% to S$57.82 million due to weak demand for oilfield engineering services in Singapore. The company attributed the decline to weak oil prices and competitive pricing pressure. CEO Kuah Boon Wee stated that the company will focus on securing business while monitoring costs and raising utilization levels, despite a challenging market outlook.

site_title: China cannot afford to join the SDR club now
summary: China's pursuit of joining the Special Drawing Rights (SDR) quasi-reserve currency of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) may be a "mistaken path" similar to Japan's 1985 experience under the Plaza Accord. By depreciating its currency, China may sacrifice monetary freedom and hinder economic transition. Experts argue that China should prioritize domestic economic imperatives over global monetary objectives, as devaluing the yuan significantly could encourage export-oriented enterprises to revert to old ways, delaying economic transition. China's massive foreign exchange reserves could be depleted if it pursues SDR membership.

site_title: Uber launches car service for people with disabilities
summary: Uber launched uberASSIST, a car service for people with disabilities and seniors, in Singapore. The service allows riders to book private car rides on-demand for a low fare of S$12 to S$15 for a 10km trip. uberASSIST has 50 trained drivers and can be booked through the Uber app. This marks Uber's first transportation service for seniors and people with disabilities in Asia, aiming to improve accessibility and affordability for riders with accessibility needs.

site_title: On money, work and success
summary:
The Singapore Writers Festival features talks by three writers on money, work, and success. Harvard University's Michael Sandel will discuss the role of money and society, arguing that a market society where everything is up for sale dominates every aspect of life. He believes preserving social cohesion and community is crucial. 

Businesswoman Heather McGregor will talk about the challenges faced by women in the workplace, emphasizing the importance of hard work, delegation, and financial literacy. She believes women will see fairer representation in business and politics in the future. 

Ayesh Khanna, CEO of The Keys Academy, will discuss the future of work, highlighting the shift towards flexibility, freelancing, and technology. She predicts the hot industries of the future will be advanced manufacturing, robotics, and the sharing economy.

site_title: New wave filmmakers turn an uncensored lens on Myanmar
summary: A new generation of filmmakers in Myanmar is turning to previously taboo subjects, such as homosexual relationships and refugee marginalization, after decades of censorship by the military. The country's film industry has begun to flourish since the end of military rule in 2012, with emerging documentary-makers tackling issues like land grabbing and human rights. Despite freedom of expression still being imperfect, the November elections are seen as a potential watershed moment for greater opportunities to debate the nation's issues through the arts.

site_title: Lower tourism receipts, visitor arrivals in H1 2015
summary: Singapore's tourism receipts dropped 12% year-over-year to S$10.5 billion in the first half of 2015, while visitor arrivals declined 3% to 7.3 million. The decline was mainly due to a decrease in business and meetings, incentives, conferences, and exhibitions (MICE) travellers and a strengthened Singapore dollar. However, visitor arrivals from China and India rebounded, and the leisure segment showed a 1% growth. The hotel industry also suffered declines in key metrics, including average room rate, occupancy rate, and revenue per available room.

site_title: AusGroup turns in smaller Q1 profit
summary: AusGroup reported a Q1 net profit of A$348,000, down from A$2.83 million a year ago, due to higher costs and expenses. Revenue edged up 1.7% to A$132.75 million, driven by better-than-expected performance in maintenance services and access services. Earnings per share declined to 0.06 Australian cent from 0.44 cent. The company's revenue growth was attributed to improved performance in its business units.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as Q3 growth ebbs
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday after the Commerce Department reported third-quarter US economic growth slowed to 1.5% annual rate. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 50.88 points (0.29%), while the S&P 500 dropped 5.54 (0.27%) and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 24.60 (0.48%). Lower private inventory investment and profit taking may have contributed to the market pullback, following a 9% gain in US stocks in October.

site_title: Pending sales of previously owned US homes fall
summary: Pending US home sales unexpectedly fell 2.3% in September, the largest decline since 2013, indicating a cooling residential real estate market. The decline was driven by a limited selection of properties and stricter credit standards. Despite this, housing demand is expected to be supported by cheap borrowing costs and employment opportunities. The median forecast for economists was a 1% gain, but the actual decline was lower than expected. This marks the lowest level of pending sales since January, with all four US regions experiencing a decline.

site_title: Attacks on India's beef industry hit buffalo meat trade
summary: Rising tensions over eating beef in Hindu-majority India are impacting the buffalo meat trade, with exports falling 13.2% in the last six months. Hindu activists have stepped up attacks on the beef industry, alleging that cows are being killed and labeled as buffalo meat. As a result, exporters are facing supply shortages and harassment, with some states imposing bans on cow slaughter. The government has taken steps to inspect meat and tighten checks at ports, but the industry's future remains uncertain, with some politicians calling for a complete ban on the meat export industry.

images.alt_text: A butcher cuts meat for a customer inside his shop in Mumbai, India, Sept 8, 2015.

site_title: Harvard donations top US$1b for second straight year
summary: Harvard University has received its second consecutive year of donations exceeding $1 billion, with a total of $1 billion collected in the year ended June 30. The university has already reached its campaign goal of $6.5 billion by 2018, with $6.1 billion in donations and pledges. This surge in donations follows a trend of mega donations to the richest institutions, with Harvard leading in receiving significant gifts. Despite a budget surplus, the university expressed concerns about its main sources of revenue, including federal research funding and tuition growth.

site_title: MasterCard profit beats estimates as consumer spending climbs
summary: MasterCard reported a 3.7% decrease in third-quarter net income to $977 million, or 86 cents a share, beating analyst estimates. Profit excluding one-time items was 91 cents a share, exceeding the 88-cent average estimate. CEO Ajay Banga attributed the growth to double-digit growth in most regions worldwide. Despite a stronger dollar and lower US gas prices, consumer spending on MasterCard's network climbed. The company's shares rose 16% this year, beating the S&P 500 Information Technology Index's 7.3% advance.

site_title: Bombardier reports loss, outlines Québec investment in CSeries
summary: Bombardier Inc reported a quarterly loss of $4.6 billion, largely due to impairment charges on the CSeries and Learjet 85 programs. The company will form a joint venture with the Québec government to complete the CSeries program, with the government investing $1 billion and holding a 49.5% stake. The partnership aims to keep C Series operations in Québec for at least 20 years, with Bombardier retaining 50.5% ownership and transferring 1,700 employees, assets, and intellectual property to the new venture.

site_title: Israeli medical-agritech incubator files for Catalist IPO
summary: Trendlines Group, an Israeli medical and agricultural technology incubator, has filed a preliminary offer document for its proposed listing on the Catalist board of Singapore Exchange. The company has secured a cornerstone subscription agreement with German healthcare company B Braun, which will subscribe S$7.1 million worth of Trendlines' shares. This move is aimed at boosting mutual deal flow and supporting the incubator's growth.

site_title: Tenaga Q4 profit falls 39% on forex loss
summary: Malaysia's largest power group, Tenaga Nasional Bhd, reported a 39.5% drop in fourth-quarter net profit to 820.9 million ringgit (US$191.2 million) due to a translation loss from the strengthening of the dollar and Japanese yen against the ringgit. Revenue remained flat at 11.74 billion ringgit. The company expressed caution over the group's prospects for 2016 due to a global economic slowdown and declining commodity prices.

site_title: Time Warner Cable profit tops Street as subscriber additions rise
summary: Time Warner Cable reported a better-than-expected adjusted profit in the third quarter, driven by 232,000 high-speed data subscriber additions. The company lost 7,000 residential video subscribers, a significant improvement from the 45,000 lost in the second quarter. Net income fell to $437 million, or $1.53 per share, beating analyst estimates. The deal to buy Time Warner Cable by Charter Communications is expected to close by the end of the year, despite regulatory scrutiny. Revenue rose 3.6% to $5.92 billion.

site_title: Luxury market seen heading for weakest year since Lehman crash
summary: The global luxury market is expected to experience its weakest year since the 2009 Lehman crash, with sales projected to rise only 1% to 253 billion euros (US$280 billion) in 2015. A combination of stock market turmoil, a strong dollar, and a commodity-price rout are curbing demand, particularly in China and the US. However, jewelry sales are expected to rise 6% as a safe investment in uncertain economic conditions. Total luxury spending is forecast to surpass 1 trillion euros, led by accelerating sales of luxury cars, hotels, and fine art.

site_title: China says to extend old-age insurance to all
summary: China will extend old-age insurance to its entire population, with state funds to be invested into existing insurance schemes to improve coverage. The move aims to strengthen the social safety net and boost consumption. The Communist Party also plans to ease family planning restrictions, allowing all couples to have two children after decades of the strict one-child policy. This move is aimed at alleviating demographic strains on the economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of equitable wealth distribution for sustainable economic growth. Unemployment in Singapore remained steady at 2% in September 2015. Changi Airport achieved a record quarterly traffic in Q3 with a 3.9% increase in September. Deutsche Bank plans to cut 15,000 jobs. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% due to US interest rate hike concerns.

site_title: China to allow two children for all couples
summary: China has announced a major policy change, allowing all couples to have two children, effective immediately. This move comes after decades of the one-child policy, aimed at controlling population growth, but now seen as outdated and responsible for China's shrinking labor pool. The policy change is a significant liberalization, with scholars and experts hailing it as an "historic event." However, critics argue that the relaxation of rules is too little, too late to address substantial negative effects on the economy and society.

images.alt_text: China will ease family planning restrictions to allow all couples to have two children after decades of the strict one-child policy, the ruling Communist Party said on Thursday, a move aimed at alleviating demographic restraints on the economy.

site_title: US economy slows to 1.5% growth in Q3
summary: The US economy experienced a slower growth rate in Q3, with a 1.5% expansion, according to the Commerce Department's first estimate for the quarter. This was slightly weaker than expected, but in line with forecasts of a cooling economy after the second quarter's 3.9% expansion. Exports and private inventory investment fell, contributing to the slower growth.

site_title: ANZ cuts back on trade finance in Asia
summary: ANZ, a major Australian bank, is reducing its trade finance business in Asia to protect margins and boost returns. The bank reported its slowest profit growth since 2008, with a 1% increase in cash profit for the year to September. ANZ is stepping away from "lower return financial institutions" trade finance and focusing on cash management, including transaction banking and treasury services. The move is part of a broader strategy to bolster lagging returns at its international business, led by new CEO Shayne Elliott.

images.alt_text: Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ) has begun reducing its trade finance business in Asia to protect margins and bolster returns after the lender reported its slowest profit growth since 2008.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels' Q3 profit drops 30%
summary: Global Premium Hotels reported a 30% year-on-year decline in Q3 profit to S$3.57 million, citing lower occupancy rates and revenue per available room. Revenue fell 5.3% to S$16.29 million, impacted by lower hotel room revenue and asset enhancement works. The group expects a continued decline in AOR and RevPAR due to global economic uncertainties and regional currency volatility.

site_title: Baker Tech's Q3 profit down 38%
summary: Baker Technology's Q3 net profit dropped 38% to S$2.66 million, in line with a 74% decline in revenue to S$5.56 million, primarily due to a slowdown in the oil and gas industry. The company attributed the decline to a challenging business environment and low oil prices. Despite this, the group reported a 29% increase in nine-month net profit to S$9.11 million, driven by a foreign exchange gain. Baker Technology continues to explore strategic alliances and acquisitions to navigate the challenging market.

site_title: BMW plans to market sedan fuel cell vehicle after 2020
summary: BMW plans to market its first fuel cell vehicle, a larger-sized sedan, after 2020, when a hydrogen development partnership with Toyota ends. The vehicle will use compressed hydrogen, allowing it to travel further than Toyota's Mirai fuel cell model, which can travel around 700 kilometers on a single fueling. BMW is developing a way to compress hydrogen at ultra-low temperatures to increase its storage volume. The company's head of fuel cell development, Merten Jung, stated that the sedan will be a "long distance car" and likely to be bigger than the Mirai, targeting a different market.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q3 net profit down 8% on impairment loss on Fuzhou site
summary: TUAN Sing Holdings reported an 8% drop in Q3 net profit to S$16.2 million due to an impairment loss of S$7.7 million related to Fuzhou development land. Excluding this impact, net profit would have been 36% higher than last year, driven by contributions from Singapore property and Australian hotels. Revenue rose 85% to S$184.3 million, while earnings per share fell to 1.4 cents.

site_title: Bank of China Q3 profit falls 1.5%, bad loans rise
summary: Bank of China Ltd reported a 1.5% fall in net profit in Q3, with a profit of 40.8 billion yuan (US$6.42 billion) compared to 41.4 billion yuan in the same period last year. Bad loans increased, with the non-performing loan ratio rising to 1.43% at September-end from 1.41% three months prior. The result fell short of analysts' 0.975% average growth estimate.

site_title: Lotte to buy Samsung's chemical assets for over 3t won: paper
summary: Lotte Group will acquire Samsung Group's chemical assets for over 3 trillion won (US$2.63 billion), including a 31% stake in Samsung Fine Chemicals and 90% of Samsung SDI Co Ltd's chemicals business. This deal comes after Samsung Group has been exiting non-core businesses, including selling stakes in affiliates in the defense and chemical sectors to Hanwha Group. Lotte Chemical Corp, an affiliate of Lotte Group, will acquire these assets, marking a significant expansion into the chemical sector for the South Korean conglomerate.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 19.53 points lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 19.53 points to 1,666.98. 2.16 billion lots valued at RM2.28 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 511 to 393.

site_title: Europe: Shares shrug off US rate hike fears
summary: European shares rose 0.3% to 1,489.45 points, shrugging off US rate hike fears after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. Nokia surged 10% on strong earnings, while Solvay and Alcatel-Lucent also gained. Deutsche Bank and Barclays faced losses due to dividend cuts and quarterly profit drops, respectively.

site_title: Indonesia central bank to intervene in forward market through auction
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, announced it will intervene in the forward currency market through auctions to stabilize the rupiah currency, which hit 17-year lows last month. The auctions will start this week, allowing banks and intermediary institutions to participate with a minimum transaction of $1 million. The move is part of a policy package announced in September to address volatility in the rupiah exchange rate. The rupiah traded at 13,640 per dollar, 7.99% off its 17-year low.

site_title: Oil prices fall after Fed hints at Dec rate hike
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday as the dollar strengthened, with US crude down 55 cents at $45.39 a barrel and Brent crude down 58 cents at $48.47 a barrel. The Federal Reserve hinted at a December interest rate hike, contributing to the dollar's rise and the decline in oil prices. The move is seen as a sign of divergent monetary policies among the world's major central banks. Despite a recent rally, oil prices have been volatile due to various factors, including supply and demand imbalances.

site_title: Volkswagen likely to recall 100,000 cars in India: CNBC-TV18
summary: Volkswagen's Indian unit is likely to recall 100,000 cars due to the diesel emission scandal. The recall, expected to happen before November 8, primarily affects cars imported with engines that have been found to cheat on emissions tests. Additionally, 20,000 diesel vehicles made in India will also be included in the recall. This comes as Volkswagen faces its first quarterly loss in 15 years and global fallout from the scandal.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower as Fed flags US rate hike
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.60% to 22,819.94, following the Federal Reserve's hint of a possible US interest rate hike in December. This move contrasted with Shanghai, which rose 0.36% to 3,387.32, as China's leaders concluded a key policy meeting.

site_title: Macau's top gaming regulator steps down
summary: Macau's top gaming regulator, Manuel Neves, is stepping down from his post by November 25, after overseeing the gaming industry for 31 years. The move comes amid a slump in Macau's revenues, which have fallen for 16 months in a row and are expected to drop 30% in October. Neves cited a desire to spend more time with his family, but the government has not announced a replacement. The regulatory bureau is increasing monitoring of casino and junket regulations, implementing tighter rules on accounting and auditing of gambling debts.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to cut workforce by 15,000
summary: Deutsche Bank plans to cut 15,000 jobs, including 9,000 full-time and 6,000 external contractor positions, as part of its restructuring efforts under new CEO John Cryan. The bank aims to reduce its workforce by a quarter and dispose of assets with a 4-billion-euro cost base over the next 24 months. This move is part of a broader revamp to improve returns, with plans to reduce technology activities and spin off its Postbank unit.

site_title: Former NMP Mary Liew elected as NTUC's second female president
summary: Former Nominated Member of Parliament (NMP) Mary Liew, 52, was elected as the second female president of the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore. She succeeds Diana Chia, 59, who stepped down due to age. Liew's election marks a milestone for the labour movement, with the NTUC now having two female leaders.

site_title: China warns of severe winter smog, worsened by El Nino
summary: China is warning of severe winter smog due to the El Nino phenomenon, which is expected to worsen air pollution in the country. The Ministry of Environmental Protection has urged heating providers to use high-quality coal and conduct boiler renovations to reduce pollution. The government will also increase inspections of construction sites and limit the use of fireworks and big polluting industries. Last winter, concentrations of PM2.5 in Beijing, Hebei, and Tianjin reached an average of 111 micrograms per cubic meter, exceeding the yearly average of 88. China's "war on pollution" aims to cut coal use and shut polluting industries.

images.alt_text: China could face another bout of severe air pollution this winter with unfavourable weather expected to aggravate the problem, the environment ministry said on Thursday.

site_title: LG mobile business sinks into the red in Q3
summary: LG Electronics' mobile business posted an operating loss of 77.6 billion won (US$67.8 million) in Q3, its first loss in 18 months. The loss was attributed to increased global competition and foreign exchange losses. Despite this, the home appliance division saw a four-fold increase in operating profit to 246 billion won. Overall, net profit declined 38% to 124.8 billion won and sales dropped 5% to 14 trillion won. The losses were largely offset by the home appliance division's success in high-end refrigerators and washing machines.

site_title: PetroChina net profit down 68.1% in first nine months of 2015
