summary: PetroChina, China's largest oil and gas producer, reported a 68.1% drop in net earnings for the first nine months of 2015 due to falling oil prices. The company's average realised oil price declined by 48.8% to US$51.16 a barrel, resulting in a nine-month net profit of 30.6 billion yuan (US$4.81 billion). Despite a 3.3% increase in crude output, operating profit fell across most segments, with the marketing division posting an operating loss of 978 million yuan.

site_title: Barclays' US$1.5 billion UK separation costs to hit 2016 profitability
summary: Barclays reported a 10% drop in quarterly profit to $1.43 billion, citing costs associated with separating its UK retail business and compensating customers mis-sold foreign exchange products. The bank raised its core costs guidance for next year to $14.9 billion and cut its return on equity target to 11% from 12%. Barclays expects to spend $1.5 billion on UK separation costs and $500 million more in 2017 and 2018.

site_title: Lufthansa lifts full-year forecasts after strong Q3
summary: Lufthansa raised its full-year forecasts after strong Q3 results, with net profit increasing 41.5% to 794 million euros and revenues up 5.1% to 8.939 billion euros. The airline attributed the improvement to low oil prices and positive passenger numbers. Lufthansa now projects a full-year underlying operating profit of 1.75-1.95 billion euros, up from its previous estimate of 1.5 billion euros. CEO Carsten Spohr credited the airline's improved earnings to both low oil prices and increased passenger volumes and load factors.

site_title: UK house price growth picks up in October, Nationwide says
summary: UK house price growth accelerated in October, with Nationwide reporting a 0.6% increase compared to a 0.5% rise in September. This brings the year-on-year growth to 3.9%, up from 3.8% in September. Economists' expectations of a 0.5% growth this month were met. The housing market shows signs of renewed momentum, with homebuyer demand rebounding to a six-month high, according to an index.

site_title: Portugal economic, consumer confidence drops on political uncertainty
summary: Portugal's economic climate indicator fell to 1.2 in October, its first drop since December 2008, due to a political crisis triggered by an inconclusive election. The National Statistics Institute also reported a decline in consumer confidence, dropping to -17.4 in October, its lowest since June 2001. The economic downturn is attributed to the uncertainty surrounding the government, which risks toppling the centre-right administration.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' Q3 earnings dive as all engines stall
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 37.8% drop in net profit to S$122.30 million in Q3, with declines in all three major business segments, particularly its marine arm, which plummeted 75% to S$19.65 million. The utilities segment also saw a 21% slide in earnings. Earnings per share fell 42.1% to 6.29 Singapore cents. The decline was attributed to lower contribution from rig building projects and lower spark spreads in its Singapore operations.

site_title: Hong Kong existing home transactions headed for 20-yr low
summary: Hong Kong's existing-home transactions likely fell to the lowest level in nearly 20 years in October, with around 2,000 transactions recorded, according to Ricacorp Properties Ltd. The secondary market has been sluggish due to buyers waiting for prices to drop and sellers refusing to accept lower offers. Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying vowed to resolve the housing issue, while banks expect property prices to start falling as the economy weakens and interest rates increase.

site_title: M&C's Q3 net profit slips 33% to £24m
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne Hotels (M&C), a London-listed hotel arm, reported a 33.3% drop in group net profit to £24m in Q3 2015, citing weaker hotel performance in Singapore and Asia. Revenue fell to £211m from £217m, and earnings per share dropped to 7.3p from 10.9p. M&C chairman Kwek Leng Beng attributed the decline to factors such as growing hotel room inventory, visa restrictions, and slower economic growth in China.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker on news that US rates may be raised in Dec
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% to 3,001.51 after the US Federal Reserve hinted at a possible interest rate hike in December, although some analysts believe the index was due for a correction after a 12.5% gain in three weeks. Total turnover was low, with 1.2 billion units traded worth S$957 million. OCBC's Q3 earnings release weighed on the bank's shares, which dropped S$0.12 to S$9.08.

site_title: Deutsche Bank Q3 trading gains overshadowed by writedowns
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 20% increase in revenue at its bond trading business in Q3, partially offsetting a 6 billion-euro group pre-tax loss. Revenue rose to 3.2 billion euros, driven by higher revenue in rates, credit, and distressed markets. However, the bank's investment bank faced massive charges for goodwill, legal expenses, and litigation. CEO John Cryan announced the cancellation of the bank's dividend for this year and next, seeking to overhaul performance and address regulatory issues.

site_title: Uber launches service for seniors, people with disabilities in Singapore
summary: Uber launches uberASSIST, a transportation service for seniors and people with disabilities in Singapore. The service, available via the Uber app, will provide private car rides on demand. Uber has partnered with local accessibility consulting firm LevelField to train 50 top-rated drivers. The service will be offered at the same price as uberX, with fares potentially up to 20% lower than a taxi during peak hours. Uber aims to improve accessibility and provide a reliable mobility option, particularly for the 3,000 athletes attending the upcoming Asean Para Games in Singapore.

site_title: Toyota view on Volkswagen scandal: don't obsess over No 1
summary: Toyota's CEO Akio Toyoda advises Volkswagen not to focus on being the world's largest automaker amid the emissions scandal, instead prioritizing quality and environmental issues. Toyoda acknowledges Toyota's past quality issues but emphasizes the company's commitment to reform and cleaner cars. He believes Volkswagen's wrongdoing should not deter other automakers from striving for environmental progress.

images.alt_text: Toyota's top executive has offered some advice to German rival Volkswagen as it wrestles with a huge emissions scandal: don't focus on being number one.

site_title: Sony videogame sales help it swing to Q2 operating profit
summary: Sony Corp reported a quarterly operating profit of 88 billion yen (US$729 million) for July-September, exceeding analyst estimates. The strong videogame sales helped offset a decline in smartphone sales. In contrast, the year-ago quarter saw a significant impairment charge, resulting in a loss of 85.6 billion yen. This marked a significant turnaround for the company, with the operating profit more than doubling from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Sony Corp swung on Thursday to a quarterly operating profit as strong videogame sales helped to offset a fall in smartphone sales and as the year-ago quarter had seen a big impairment charge.

site_title: Mazda expects delays to US diesel car launch after VW scandal
summary: Mazda Motor Corp expects delays to the US diesel car launch due to tougher emissions and fuel-economy testing processes, following the Volkswagen AG scandal. The company had planned to launch diesel cars in the US in 2016, but a senior executive said the delay is unavoidable. Mazda remains committed to launching diesel cars in the US, but the exact timeline is unclear. The US market's increased scrutiny of diesel technology has made it vulnerable, with many executives saying it's far from finished despite the scandal.

site_title: Malaysia budget doubts face judgment as subway firm sells sukuk
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak faces skepticism over his budget plan to curb the deficit and reduce debt guarantees, as a subway financier sells Islamic notes. Sales of government-backed sukuk dropped 52% to RM10.5 billion, lower than last year's RM22 billion. Fitch Ratings warns the deficit reduction target will be challenging, but notes the potential slippage won't increase Malaysia's debt ratio. Experts express cautious optimism, with one stating the government has done a good job in lowering the budget shortfall.

site_title: Iras recovers S$217m in taxes and penalties after reviews, issues filing guide
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) recovered S$217 million in taxes and penalties from compliance reviews of companies in 2015. Common mistakes found include failure to keep proper records and accounts, wrongful claims of tax deductions, and inflated payments to related parties. Companies must maintain proper records for five years and follow specific guidelines for tax deductions, including restrictions on personal expenses and payments to family members. Those convicted of filing incorrect tax returns may face penalties of up to 200% of undercharged tax, fines, or imprisonment.

site_title: Nokia posts strong network results, special dividends
summary: Nokia reported strong network results, with third-quarter operating profit at 391 million euros, exceeding analysts' forecast. The company's growth in China offset weaker demand in North America and Europe. Nokia also pushed forward its cost synergy target to 2018 and announced it would distribute about four billion euros to shareholders. The company's network unit secured regulatory approval for its 15.6 billion euro takeover of Alcatel-Lucent earlier this month.

site_title: China signs deal for 100 Airbus A320s: manufacturer
summary: China signed a contract to buy 100 Airbus A320s worth US$9.7 billion, with options for 30 A330s. The deal was signed during German Chancellor Angela Merkel's visit to Beijing. This marks a significant order for Airbus, with the A320 being one of the company's most popular models. The contract was announced on October 29, 2015.

site_title: Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone harvests first rice crop for sale in Singapore
summary: Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone (SSJFZ) has harvested its first rice crop for sale in Singapore, with 60 tonnes of high-quality Fragrance 43ºN japonica rice set to be imported and distributed by NTUC FairPrice by the end-of-year. This marks the first product from SSJFZ to be sold in Singapore, with plans to introduce other products in the next one to two years. The SSJFZ aims to become a model food zone for safe and quality food production, replicable in other parts of China and beyond.

site_title: Barclays says Q3 profits fall 10%, takes hit for FX compensation
summary: Barclays reported a 10% drop in Q3 profits to £1.43 billion, largely due to a £560 million hit from compensating customers mis-sold foreign exchange products and covering a US mortgages settlement. The bank made a £290 million provision for UK customers and reported below average forecasted profits. Former JPMorgan investment bank boss Jes Staley will become CEO in December, replacing the current CEO.

site_title: Air France-KLM Q3 profit up, cost cut target reduced
summary: Air France-KLM reported a 898 million euro operating profit in Q3, nearly quadrupling from the year-earlier quarter, due to improved demand over the summer. The airline group's revenues grew 10.8% to 7.415 billion euros. However, it reduced its forecast for unit cost savings in 2015 to 0.5-0.7% from 1-1.3% due to stalled negotiations with pilots. The airline aims to reduce its debt by 1 billion euros to 4.4 billion by the end of 2015.

site_title: Singapore public transport system should be run by government: Mahbubani
summary: Kishore Mahbubani, a leading academic, has urged Singapore to reconsider its privatized public transport system, citing concerns over quarterly results prioritizing short-term gains over long-term maintenance. Mahbubani believes the system should be run by the government to ensure better service and maintenance. He also highlighted two key challenges facing Singapore: the geopolitical rivalry between the US and China, and the strategic importance of ASEAN to Singapore's survival. Mahbubani's comments come as Singapore looks to adapt to changing economic and geopolitical landscapes.

site_title: India's Modi pitches "partnership of prosperity" to Africa
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi pledged US$10 billion in credit to support a "partnership of prosperity" with Africa, promising to foster a broad alliance for global reform. He also offered grant aid of US$600 million, including a new development fund and health fund. Modi sought to strengthen ties with African nations, urging cooperation on global issues such as trade and climate change. His goal is to elevate India as a global player, breaking its history of isolation, and to catch up with China's economic influence in the region.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi turned on the charm for African leaders on Thursday, promising US$10 billion in credit to back a "partnership of prosperity" and pitching a broad alliance for global reform.

site_title: Only three Indonesian tin firms meet new export rules: industry
summary: Only three Indonesian tin companies have met new export rules set to take effect in November, limiting shipments and potentially curtailing the country's top tin export. The halt in exports was introduced in August to address environmental damage and royalty payment issues. Benchmark tin prices have decreased 21% this year due to a decline in demand growth for metals.

site_title: China, Germany sign deal for Chinese airlines to buy 30 A330 Airbus jets
summary: China and Germany signed a deal for Chinese airlines to buy 30 A330 Airbus jets, valued at 17 billion euros. The order aims to secure more jet orders in China, where demand is expected to reach $1 trillion over the next two decades. This deal follows Airbus' agreement to build a completion centre in Tianjin and Boeing's cooperation with China's Comac to build a completion centre for its 737 passenger jets. The move is seen as a boost for Comac, which has been struggling to build its C919.

site_title: HDB rejects bids for Ubi industrial site as they are 'too low'
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) has rejected bids for an industrial development site at Ubi Avenue 1 due to "too low" prices. The site, zoned "Business 1", was launched for tender in June 2015 and received a single bid of S$19.9 million from BP-DC Pte Ltd, translating to S$120.91 per square foot per plot ratio. The HDB stated that the bid was below market value, leading to the rejection of the bid.

site_title: Shell profits slump after huge write-offs
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a 68% drop in third-quarter profits to $1.8 billion, driven by low oil prices and a $8.2 billion write-off in Alaska and Canada. The write-off was attributed to lower oil and gas price outlook and efforts to reduce Shell's longer-term option set. Despite the decline, Shell maintained its dividend at 47 cents per share, citing a determination to become a more focused and competitive company.

site_title: LTA to add three stations to Circle Line to boost connectivity in south Singapore
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to add three stations to the Circle Line 6 (CCL6) in Singapore, connecting areas like Pasir Panjang and Kent Ridge to the Central Business District and Marina Bay. The $3.7 billion 4km expansion, set to be completed in 2025, will provide direct routes and improve connectivity. The new stations include Keppel, Cantonment, and Prince Edward, with the Circle Line eventually serving 33 stations, including 12 interchange stations. This expansion aims to support future redevelopment of the city port area and the Greater Southern Waterfront.

site_title: Google 'Loon' Internet balloons to take flight over Indonesia
summary: Google's "Project Loon" internet-beaming helium balloons will test in Indonesia next year, targeting remote areas with slow internet access. The balloons, twice as high as commercial airliners, will be used to deliver high-speed LTE connections to over 100 million Indonesians. This is a key milestone for the project, which aims to bring internet access to impoverished areas worldwide. Tests have already been conducted in New Zealand, California, Brazil, and Australia, and the project is part of Google X, Alphabet's secretive laboratory for experimental projects.

site_title: Rains clear the air in Southeast Asia, raising hopes in smog crisis
summary: Southeast Asia has experienced a significant reduction in air pollution due to rain and favorable winds, clearing skies in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore after weeks of hazardous smoke from forest fires. The rainy season, which began in Malaysia, is expected to bring further relief, with officials hoping the crisis can end soon. Rainfall on islands of Sumatra and Borneo has reduced smoke clouds, and cloud-seeding activities are planned to continue. The region's haze crisis has affected tens of thousands and caused flight cancellations and school closures.

site_title: Japan: Nikkei edges up in choppy trade ahead of BOJ meeting
summary: Japanese stocks edged up 0.2% to close at 18,935.71, boosted by solid industrial output data and the US Federal Reserve's downplaying of global market turmoil. However, trading remained thin ahead of the Bank of Japan's meeting on Friday. Nintendo's shares tumbled 9% after delaying its smartphone-based video game service launch, while the securities sector shed 2.3% due to weaker-than-expected profits from Nomura Holdings and Daiwa Securities Group. Defensive shares, such as pharmaceuticals and precision instruments, saw gains.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to suspend dividends for two years
summary: Deutsche Bank has announced it will suspend dividend payments for two years, starting in 2015 and 2016, as part of a major restructuring effort to cut costs and meet new financial targets by 2020. The move aims to increase the bank's capital ratio to 12.5% by 2018. The bank's third-quarter net loss was reported as 6.2 billion euros, and it is currently involved in around 6,000 litigation cases and has been fined a record $2.5 billion for interest rate rigging. Dividends are expected to resume in 2017.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank, Sharp to set up solar power services joint venture
summary: SoftBank Group Corp and Sharp Corp are forming a joint venture to offer solar power services, including panel installation and maintenance, in Japan. The venture, launching in December, will initially serve 30 solar power plants operated by SoftBank's solar energy subsidiary. Sharp, once a leader in solar panels, aims to turn around its loss-making business. SoftBank will own the majority, with a $1 million capital investment. This move is part of SoftBank's interest in the solar business, following its entry into the market in 2011.

site_title: Australia to join Chinese navy exercises in South China Sea
summary: Australia will hold naval exercises with China in the South China Sea, with two warships visiting China's Zhanjiang base before participating in live-fire drills. The move comes amid tensions following a US patrol near a Chinese man-made island. Australia seeks to balance its relationship with the US and China, avoiding being seen as "deputy sheriff" to the US. The exercises aim to demonstrate Australia's commitment to freedom of navigation and stability in the region.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won finish down after Fed rekindles rate hike views
summary: South Korean shares and the won fell on Thursday as the US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates in December. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed down 0.4% at 2,034.16 points, while the won dropped 1.0% to 1,142.3 per dollar.

site_title: Koh Brothers' JV with Samsung C&T bags S$1.12b CAG contract
summary: Koh Brothers Group has secured a S$1.12 billion contract from Changi Airport Group (CAG) for the development of three-runway operations at Singapore's Changi Airport through an integrated joint venture with Samsung C&T Corporation. The 30% equity stake JV beat 10 bidders and marks Koh Brothers' second contract with CAG. The project scope includes runway extension, taxiway system development, and ancillary buildings, with a total length of approximately 40km. The contract win boosts Koh Brothers' construction order book to S$632 million.

site_title: Pfizer in merger talks with Botox-maker Allergan: WSJ
summary: Pfizer Inc is reportedly in merger talks with Botox-maker Allergan Plc, the largest US drugmaker, to discuss a potential takeover deal worth around $113 billion. The deal could offer Pfizer tax benefits as Allergan is based in lower-tax Dublin. The talks come after Pfizer's previous attempt to acquire AstraZeneca Plc was rejected in 2014. A successful deal would boost Pfizer's top-line growth and give the company a boost in revenue, which is expected to slide 3.3% this year.

images.alt_text: Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc recently approached Botox-maker Allergan Plc to discuss what could be the biggest takeover deal this year, the Wall Street Journal said on Wednesday, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Equitable distribution of wealth key for sustainable growth: Swee Keat
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of equitable distribution of wealth in sustainable economic development. This includes both intergenerational equity and equity between different groups in society. He also highlighted the need for market-oriented and pro-trade policies, as well as investments in timeless resources like land and people. However, he noted that there is no "one-size-fits-all" approach, and that complex trade-offs must be considered in implementing these principles.

site_title: Changi Airport achieves record quarterly traffic in Q3 after 3.9% rise in Sept
summary: Changi Airport recorded a 3.9% year-on-year increase in September, handling 4.42 million passengers, contributing to a 5.8% rise in total quarterly traffic to 14.3 million. This marks the highest-ever quarterly traffic at the airport. China saw the strongest growth of 14.9%, while traffic between Singapore and Indonesia declined 0.4%. The airport's top markets for the quarter were China, Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia, and Thailand, with Jakarta remaining the busiest route.

site_title: Fish cry for help to escape predators: Australian scientists
summary: Australian scientists discovered that distressed fish emit a chemical alarm to attract other carnivores, allowing them to escape during the ensuing chaos. This "cry for help" results in the initial predator dropping the prey 40% of the time, increasing the prey's survival rate. The study found that this behavior is advantageous for the prey, leading to the maintenance of the alarm-cue signaling in the population. Researchers plan to expand their research to explore how damaged reefs affect fish distress calls, which could alter predator-prey interactions.

site_title: South Korea: Shares, won down on Fed rate hike views
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.4% on Thursday, driven by expectations of a US interest rate hike in December, which bolstered the greenback and safe-haven assets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) hit its highest level since July 23, but Samsung Electronics' announcement to buy back shares initially boosted the market. Tech shares outperformed, with Samsung Elec and LG Display gaining 1.8% and 2.6% respectively. The won dropped 1.1% against the dollar, its worst daily loss since August.

site_title: China's FX trading operator, Deutsche Boerse agree to form JV in Germany
summary: China's foreign exchange trading operator and Deutsche Boerse agree to form a 50-50 joint venture in Germany, with the agreement signed in Beijing by German Chancellor Angela Merkel and China's Premier Li Keqiang. The joint venture aims to establish a major FX trading platform in the European market, providing a competitive edge for both parties.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel (right) walks with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang during a welcome ceremony outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Oct 29, 2015.

site_title: Singapore resident unemployment stays low but inching up: MOM
summary: Singapore's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained at 2% in September 2015, with residents' unemployment increasing to 3% and citizens' to 3.1%. Employment grew 16,400 in the third quarter, driven by services and construction, but moderation compared to the previous year. Layoffs declined for the third consecutive quarter, with 2,900 workers laid off. The Ministry of Manpower is ready to help displaced workers re-skill and upgrade for new jobs.

site_title: Deutsche Bank said to near US$200m sanctions settlement
summary: Deutsche Bank AG is nearing a US$200 million settlement with US regulators over alleged violations of sanctions laws, according to a person briefed on the matter. The New York Department of Financial Services and the Federal Reserve may announce the deal as soon as next week. However, the agreement won't resolve investigations opened by the Manhattan district attorney's office and the US attorney's office. The settlement is reportedly confidential, and a spokesperson for Deutsche Bank declined to comment. The deal's details and timeline are still unclear.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up, Apple suppliers, Coretronics gain
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.4% to 8,698.01 points, driven by gains from Apple suppliers Coretronics and Largan Precision. The electronics subindex rose 0.5%, while Coretronic's panels for iPads were impacted by falling iPad sales. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.649 per US dollar.

site_title: Mazda exec: committed to selling diesel cars in US despite VW scandal
summary: Mazda Motor Corp remains committed to launching diesel-powered cars in the US market, despite the Volkswagen emissions scandal. According to Kiyoshi Fujiwara, a Mazda managing executive officer, the company will delay plans due to tougher fuel-economy and emissions-testing processes. Mazda's diesel cars are expected to face increased scrutiny in the US market, but the company remains committed to its diesel offerings, saying "we're committed to launching diesel-fuelled cars in the United States."

site_title: Malaysia seeks more classes in English as proficiency declines
summary: Malaysia is encouraging schools to teach more English classes as the country's proficiency in the language declines, affecting competitiveness. Over 90% of respondents in an online poll support more English classes. The government, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, has introduced a dual-language programme and plans to spend RM135 million to raise English proficiency. Critics argue the focus on building schools has been misplaced, and the country's education system has not kept pace with peers in East Asia.

site_title: Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ opens Islamic finance business in Dubai
summary: Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ (BTMU) has launched its Islamic finance business in Dubai, targeting commercial loans and trade finance services. The bank, which received approval from the Dubai Financial Services Authority, plans to leverage its existing client base to participate in sharia-compliant loan syndications and project financing. BTMU aims to expand its product line to include ijara and istisna contracts by mid-2016, building on its existing experience in Sharia-compliant financing deals in Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, and Indonesia.

site_title: Oil rally fizzles as Fed rate hike comments boost dollar
summary: Oil prices tumbled in Asia after the US Federal Reserve hinted at a possible interest rate hike in December, boosting the dollar and making oil more expensive for holders of weaker units. Oil prices rose earlier in the week after the US Department of Energy reported a decrease in commercial crude stockpiles, suggesting stronger demand. The US Fed signaled optimism for the economy, citing "solid" consumer spending and business investment, which led to a decline in oil prices, with West Texas Intermediate falling 16 cents to US$45.78 and Brent crude down 21 cents to US$48.84.

site_title: Nintendo delays launch of smartphone videogame, shares plunge
summary: Nintendo has delayed the launch of its smartphone videogame service to March 2016, citing a need for stable service. The move comes after the previous CEO's death, and the company's shares plummeted over 10% in morning trade. Nintendo had previously planned to release its first smartphone games by the end of 2015, with fans and investors hoping for the inclusion of the Mario franchise. The delay is seen as a cautious approach to ensure the service's long-term success.

site_title: iFast reports 0.5% fall in Q3 profit citing poor market conditions
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 0.5% decline in net profit to S$2.95 million for Q3 2015, primarily due to a 58.8% drop in Hong Kong profit. Despite a 1.9% increase in net revenue to S$10.1 million, assets under administration rose 5.5% to S$5.42 billion. The decline was attributed to market conditions, reduced investment subscriptions, and increased office rental costs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Koh Brothers, K1 Ventures, AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit, CDL Hospitality Trust, Ascott Residence Trust
summary: Stocks in Singapore are expected to benefit from a positive spillover from the US Federal Reserve's interest rate signal, potentially raising rates as soon as December. Key corporate developments include Koh Brothers securing a $1.12 billion project at Changi Airport, K1 Ventures reporting a 29,000% jump in net profit, and AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit posting a 1.8% increase in distribution per unit. However, CDL Hospitality Trust and Ascott Residence Trust reported declines in distribution per unit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher after Fed comments
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Thursday, tracking global market gains, following the Federal Reserve's positive assessment of the US economy. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.27%, while Shanghai's composite index added 0.37% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.67%. The gains were driven by investors welcoming the Fed's upbeat assessment and shrugging off a hint of a December interest rate hike.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.76% higher as Fed lifts US stocks
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.76% on October 29, 2015, following US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates near zero, lifting US stocks. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 143.14 points to 19,046.16.

site_title: Committee needs to look at strengthening Singapore's comparative advantages: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran emphasizes the need for the Committee on the Future Economy to strengthen the country's comparative advantages in three areas: internal coordination, public-private sector collaboration, and nurturing new capabilities. These areas are crucial for Singapore's global competitiveness, and the committee will canvass views from various stakeholders to address them. The focus will be on positioning Singapore's economy for a rapidly-changing and technology-intensive world.

site_title: Alibaba shows how consumers are now king in China's economy
summary: Alibaba's third-quarter sales figures exceeded expectations, with the company's stock price reaching its highest level in over two months. The upbeat results suggest a shift towards sectors like consumption and services in China's economy, which is expected to rebalance from debt-fueled investment and exports. Retail sales grew faster than investment, and top officials are expected to sign off on a new five-year blueprint with consumption at the center. Experts say this marks the beginning of the world's greatest consumption story of the 21st century, with China's middle class population expected to reach 500 million by 2030.

images.alt_text: When Alibaba Group Holding on Tuesday released bumper third quarter sales figures, the e-commerce company's stock price shot to the highest level in more than two months.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.19 points to 1,689.34. Gainers outnumbered losers 177 to 52, with a total of 86.4 million lots worth RM33.1 million traded.

site_title: Naver Q3 operating profit rises 5.6% y-o-y, in line with forecast
summary: Naver Corp reported a 5.6% increase in its third-quarter operating profit to 200 billion won (S$245 million), matching analyst estimates. This growth is in line with forecast. The company plans to buy back 185.9 billion won worth of its own shares by January 28, 2016, to stabilize its stock price and boost shareholder value.

site_title: Japan's Sept factory output rises 1%
summary: Japan's factory output rose 1.0% in September, ending two months of declines, and manufacturers expect a further 4.1% increase in October. The turnaround suggests the economy is emerging from a slowdown, possibly due to China's economic slowdown abating. The Bank of Japan may not need to expand its stimulus program, but is expected to revise its forecasts downward.

site_title: Hyatt in talks to buy Starwood Hotels, say sources
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp is in talks to acquire Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc in a cash and stock deal, valued at approximately $12.75 billion for Starwood and $7.23 billion for Hyatt. The combined company would retain Hyatt's management, with a potential announcement in the coming weeks.

site_title: Germany mulls abandoning balanced budget goal due to refugee crisis: report
summary: Germany is considering abandoning its goal of achieving a balanced budget due to the rising costs of coping with a record influx of refugees. The government expects to spend around 10 billion euros in 2016, a significant increase from the previously expected 7 billion euros. This decision comes as the country aims to balance its budget from 2016 to 2019, but the rising refugee crisis may force a reevaluation of this goal.

site_title: AIMS AMP Reit's Q2 DPU up 1.8% at 2.8 Singapore cents
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit posted a 1.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.8 Singapore cents for the second quarter ended Sep 30, 2015. Gross revenue rose 3.2% to S$31.3 million, with net property income increasing 2.4% to S$20.7 million. The increase was attributed to higher rental income and recoveries from certain properties.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 18.66 points, or 0.6%, to 3,059.17 on Thursday, following overnight gains from Wall Street and European markets. The US Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike push and upgrade of its economic outlook boosted Asian markets. Active stocks, such as Addvalue Technologies and Ezra, gained 4.17% and 1.6%, respectively. The rally extended a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust's Q4 DPU at 1.66 cents, tad lower than forecast of 1.68 cents
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a distribution per unit of 1.66 Singapore cents for Q4 2015, slightly lower than forecast, due to higher fixed-rate borrowings. Despite this, the trust's gross revenue and net property income exceeded expectations, driven by strong performances in Japan, Australia, and the UK. The trust's full-year distribution per unit was 7.56 cents, 2.6% higher than forecast. Strong occupancies at InterContinental Singapore and The Westin Kuala Lumpur helped balance softer performances in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trust's Q3 DPU slips 9.7%
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) reported a 9.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.36 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2015. The decline was attributed to a 2.2% decrease in net property income and a depreciation expense from the Japan Hotels. Despite this, gross revenue rose 2.4% to S$41.1 million, driven by the acquisition of Japan Hotels in December 2014 and incremental rental income. The company attributes the slowdown to unfavourable trading conditions in some markets and looks forward to diversifying earnings with new acquisitions.

site_title: IndoAgri posts 153.8b rupiah loss for Q3
summary: IndoAgri, an AGRIBUSINESS group, reported a net loss of 153.8 billion rupiah (S$15.84 million) for Q3 2015 due to lower commodity prices, higher losses from its Brazilian subsidiary, and unrealised foreign-currency losses. Revenue dropped 9.3% to 3.3 trillion rupiah, with core profit of 129 billion rupiah, a 49% contraction from the year-ago period.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang ties up with China firm to start clinic in Shanghai
summary: Eu Yan Sang International has collaborated with Shanghai Rong Yue Medical Consultancy and Management Company to start a TMC clinic in Shanghai, subject to Chinese authorities' approvals and licensing. This marks Eu Yan Sang's entry into the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: A child with her parents at a traditional chinese medicine (TCM) clinic.

site_title: Samsung misses estimates as new phones fail to revive growth
summary: Samsung Electronics Co reported a third-quarter profit of 5.31 trillion won, missing analyst estimates. The company's new Galaxy S6 smartphones failed to boost sales, despite price cuts. Increased marketing spending, including a $120 rebate program, didn't spark demand for premium devices. Sales of lower-end smartphones were strong, but didn't lift margins. Samsung is trying to revive demand with mobile payment services and early releases of larger devices to regain market share from Apple. The company's shares rose 0.8% on the news, but have dropped 1.4% this year.

site_title: Update: Samsung to buy back 11.3t won in own shares over next year
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd plans to buy back and cancel 11.3 trillion won (S$13.85 billion) worth of its shares over the next year, aiming to boost shareholder value. The company will initially purchase 4.2 trillion won worth of shares from Friday to Jan. 29, 2016, due to undervalued share prices. Additionally, Samsung will return between 30 to 50% of its annual free cash flow as dividends or share buybacks over the next three years.

site_title: Global smartphone sales pick up on fierce competition
summary: Global smartphone sales increased 6.8% in the third quarter to 355.2 million units, the second-highest quarterly total on record. Samsung remained the top vendor with 23.5% market share, followed by Apple with 13.5%. Huawei's sales surged 60.9% due to its partnership to produce Google's Nexus 6P phone, solidifying its third place position. The intense competition in the high-end market between Apple and Samsung drove growth, while low-to-mid-range handsets continue to dominate volume and growth, particularly in emerging markets.

site_title: New Zealand leaves benchmark rate at 2.75%
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank left its benchmark interest rate at 2.75% as it assesses the impact of recent rate cuts. Governor Graeme Wheeler stated that the bank will "watch and wait" before considering further reductions to support growth without fuelling inflation. The country's inflation rate is currently 0.4%, below the target range of 1.0-3.0%. The bank aims to strike a balance between encouraging growth and avoiding a housing boom in Auckland.

site_title: Smartphone the center of US tech universe: survey
summary: A Pew Research Center report found that 68% of Americans use a smartphone, with growth outpacing other electronic gadgets. Smartphone adoption has reached "near-saturation levels" among certain groups, including 18-29 year olds, 30-45 year olds, and those earning over $75,000 annually. Meanwhile, tablet ownership has increased to 45% of US adults, but growth has cooled in recent years. The report suggests that smartphones are transforming into all-purpose devices, having a major social, political, and cultural impact on society.

site_title: Automakers win reprieve on EU pollution testing
summary: The EU agreed to ease nitrogen oxide emissions limits for diesel cars by 50% when measured in real driving conditions, providing a reprieve to the auto industry. This decision comes despite the fallout from the Volkswagen emissions cheating scandal. The new, more realistic tests will be phased in over six years, with a 50% reduction in discrepancies by 2023. Environmental campaigners have condemned the decision, citing the risks to public health.

site_title: Barclays to pay new CEO up to £8.24m a year
summary: Barclays has appointed James Staley as its new CEO, with an annual salary of up to £8.24m. Staley, a former JPMorgan investment bank boss, will take over the role at the start of December. He plans to complete a restructuring of the investment bank and avoid an adversarial relationship with regulators. Staley's appointment comes after a series of scandals and challenges facing the bank, including improving its reputation and cutting costs to improve profitability.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust posts 2% dip in Q3 DPU
summary: Ascott Residence Trust reported a 2% year-on-year dip in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.07 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2015. Excluding a one-off item, the adjusted DPU would be 2.15 cents, 2% higher than a year ago. Revenue increased 21% to S$113.2 million, driven by additional revenue from Ascott Reit's acquisitions in 2014 and 2015. The trust completed half a billion dollars worth of acquisitions in Australia, Japan, and the US during the quarter.

site_title: Oil surges after better-than-expected stockpiles report
summary: Oil prices surged 6.3% on Wednesday after the US Department of Energy reported a 3.4 million barrel increase in crude supplies, beating expectations. Gasoline and distillates also saw declines in stockpiles. The market rebounded after being oversold, but analysts cautioned that the supply glut remains a concern. The US-Mexico oil swap deal was also a positive factor, with Mexico to import 75,000 barrels of light-crude oil per day in exchange for fuel oil. Oil prices rose to $45.94 a barrel for WTI and $49.05 a barrel for Brent North Sea crude.

images.alt_text: Oil prices surged on Wednesday after a US stockpiles report showed oil supplies rose less than expected last week, bringing a whiff of relief to concerns about the global glut.

site_title: US House passes two-year budget deal that averts default
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a two-year budget deal, boosting federal spending by $80 billion, reducing a government shutdown threat, and raising the debt ceiling through the end of Barack Obama's presidency. The bipartisan deal, which passed 266-167, was the result of secret negotiations between the White House and outgoing House Speaker John Boehner. The bill now heads to the Senate, where it is expected to pass, bringing an end to a series of fiscal fights. The deal aims to avoid a potential default on US debt.

site_title: Fed statement boosts US dollar
summary: The US dollar surged on Wednesday following the Federal Reserve's policy statement, which suggested an interest rate hike could come in December. The dollar jumped against the euro, trading at US$1.0921, and advanced to 121.09 yen. The Fed kept its benchmark federal funds rate unchanged near zero, downplaying concerns about international developments. The statement presented a rosier view of the economy, highlighting "solid" increases in consumer spending and business investment, bolstering expectations for a rate hike.

site_title: Singapore must earn its place in the world through innovation
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasizes the importance of innovation for Singapore's future, stating the country must "earn its place" in the world by having unique and original ideas, products, and services. He calls for a pervasive culture of innovation across society, involving both large and small companies, and encourages business schools to address the challenges of creating an innovative economy and society.

site_title: GM promises additional US investment to secure 3,300 jobs
summary: General Motors has promised an additional $1.9 billion investment in its US factories to secure 3,300 union jobs and pay higher wages and bonuses under a proposed four-year contract with the United Auto Workers union. The deal includes raises for veteran and newly hired workers, as well as profit-sharing formulas that could pay up to $1,000 for every $1 billion in North American profit. The contract also includes bonuses of up to $8,000 for nearly 53,000 workers and early retirement packages for 4,000 workers.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co. headquarters is seen in Detroit, Michigan, Sept 17, 2015.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end higher as Fed tops agenda
summary: Europe's major stock markets closed higher on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's decision on borrowing costs. The Fed is expected to signal the next step for US interest rates, with investors anticipating a rate hold due to weak economic data. European stocks rose, with London's FTSE 100 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices increasing 1.14% and 1.31% respectively. US stocks also opened higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbing 0.26% to 17,627.96 points.

images.alt_text: Traders are pictured at their desks in front of the DAX board at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, Oct 28, 2015.

site_title: Pollution scam pushes Volkswagen into first quarterly loss in 15 years
summary: Volkswagen reported its first quarterly loss in 15 years due to the global pollution-cheating scandal, which led to a 6.7 billion euro charge. The company booked a net loss of 1.673 billion euros in the third quarter, with operating profit expected to be down significantly year-on-year. Despite this, deliveries to customers are expected to be on par with the previous year, and sales revenue is forecast to increase by up to 4.0% above the prior-year figure. The scandal has also led to a fine of up to $18 billion from the US Environmental Protection Agency.

images.alt_text: German auto giant Volkswagen on Wednesday booked its first quarterly loss in more than 15 years in the wake of the global pollution-cheating scandal which also forced it to lower its full-year forecasts.

site_title: HRM Asia
summary: Singapore-based HRM Asia won the Exhibition Organiser of the Year award at the Singapore Experience Awards 2015 for its outstanding work in organizing the HR Summit 2014. The event featured a record-breaking 4,100 attendees and a new venue layout, the C-Suite Stream, and exclusive workshops. The summit also introduced a "fast track experience" and mind mapping to enhance the learning experience. The event's success was attributed to its comprehensive list of topics, inspiring speeches, and interactive elements, cementing the HR Summit as Asia's largest gathering of HR and management professionals.

site_title: Hyatt said to be in talks to buy Starwood Hotels
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp is in talks to acquire Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc, with Hyatt management retaining control of the combined company. The deal comes after at least three Chinese suitors, including HNA Group, China Investment Corp, and Jin Jiang International, have applied to the Chinese government for permission to pursue a bid for Starwood. The Chinese authorities are reviewing the applications, weighing Starwood's valuation and potential political risks. The acquisition would mark a significant consolidation in the global hotel industry.

site_title: Apple Q4 profit up 31% on iPhone sales but outlook seems muted
summary: Apple reported a 31% increase in Q4 profit, driven by strong iPhone sales, with revenue reaching $53.8 billion. Sales in Greater China nearly doubled to $12.5 billion. However, the company's holiday quarter outlook remains uncertain, and CEO Timothy Cook avoided discussing future sales strategies in the earnings call. This raises concerns about Apple's ability to sustain its growth momentum.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund suffers biggest loss in 4 years
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest, posted its biggest loss in four years, with a 4.9% decline in the third quarter. The fund lost $45 billion due to Chinese stocks and Volkswagen AG, amidst market turbulence caused by China slowdown worries and US rate increase concerns. The fund's stock holdings declined 8.6%, while bonds and real estate returns were 0.9% and 3% respectively. The fund faces a new era with potential cash injections halted next year, and is shifting investments to emerging markets and out of Europe.

site_title: Federal Reserve sees better outlook; December rate hike possible
summary: The Federal Reserve kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 0-0.25% in a decision that showed increased confidence in the US economy. The decision, made during a two-day meeting, leaves the door open for a possible rate hike in December, citing solid consumer spending and business investment. The FOMC also dropped warnings about global downturns and China's slowdown, citing moderate economic expansion. A rate hike would raise costs of capital and weaken emerging-market currencies, causing the dollar to surge and US stocks to rebound.

site_title: Jakarta delays nod for first floating LNG plant
summary: Indonesia's energy ministry has delayed the approval for the country's first floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) plant, citing a need for an independent study to re-evaluate onshore and FLNG concepts for the Abadi field development. The study, commissioned by the government, aims to provide quantitative data to compare the FLNG proposal with onshore processing at Aru Island. The decision follows fresh arguments over the use of FLNG to commercialize the Abadi field's massive gas resources.

site_title: Trans revolution makes Thailand a global gender-change destination
summary: Thailand has become a popular destination for transgender individuals seeking sex-reassignment surgery, with over 3,500 procedures performed in the past three decades. The country's low cost, high-quality treatment, and experienced surgeons have made it an attractive option for those who cannot afford or wait for the procedure in their home countries. The industry generates significant revenue, with patients from China, the Middle East, and Australia among the most common. Thailand's medical tourism industry, which attracts over two million visitors annually, has contributed to the country's growing reputation as a hub for gender-affirming surgery.

site_title: S'pore consumer confidence index dips again in Oct: poll
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence index slipped 4.6 points in October to 125, marking the second consecutive month of decline. The index remains above its long-term average, but respondents expressed less optimism about personal financial conditions and scaled back plans for big-ticket purchases. Key indicators include a 26.9% of respondents saying their families are better off financially than a year ago, down from 33.8%, and 51.1% expecting "good times" financially in the next 12 months, down 4.5 percentage points.

site_title: Volkswagen strong enough to cope with emission scandal, says CEO
summary: Volkswagen's CEO Herbert Diess expressed confidence that the company can overcome the diesel scandal, citing its financial and human resources as strengths. With over 10 million engines affected, Diess acknowledged the challenge but emphasized the brand's ability to rebuild trust and accelerate product investments. He stated that Volkswagen is strong enough to cope with the crisis and emerge from it even more resilient.

site_title: MCI Group Asia Pacific
summary: MCI Group Asia Pacific won the Association Conference Organiser of the Year award at the Singapore Experience Awards 2015 for organizing the International Symposium on Pediatric Neuro-Oncology 2014 in Singapore. The biennial symposium, attended by 900 delegates from 55 countries, featured a high-quality scientific program and networking opportunities. The event was well-supported by local hospitals, non-profit organizations, and the Singapore Tourism Board, and included highlights such as the ISPNO-CCF Learning Xchange and the St Jude-VIVA Forum. The symposium's success contributed to MCI's win in the BTMICE awards category.

site_title: How globally connected is S'pore?
summary: Singapore is a leader in globalisation, ranking second in depth and third overall on the DHL Global Connectedness Index. The city-state's strong suit is its high international trade, capital, information, and people flows, with only four economies beating its depth metrics. Despite concerns about immigration, Singapore's global connections are more evenly distributed than feared, with 3% of the global population living outside their birth country. Greater depth in globalisation is associated with faster economic growth, and correcting misperceptions about globalisation is crucial for informed debate.

site_title: Hello Kitty, farewell Rolex, as HK shoppers go downmarket
summary: Hong Kong's luxury retail market is shifting as high-end brands such as Rolex and Cartier abandon high-rent locations in favor of more affordable options. US luxury handbag maker Coach Inc has terminated its HK$5.6 million lease and Adidas is moving in, paying 23% less rent. Mid-tier retailers are filling the gaps, with brands like Adidas and Hennes & Mauritz expanding into coveted locations. The decline in luxury sales, driven by a slowing mainland economy and Chinese tourists seeking cheaper alternatives in Europe and Asia, is paving the way for fast fashion brands to expand.

site_title: What can Indonesia do about the haze?
summary: Indonesia struggles to combat the haze problem caused by forest fires, with a three-year target to reduce fire episodes seeming unrealistic. Despite increased efforts, identifying and prosecuting fire-starters remains a challenge due to lack of land ownership information and vested interests in industries worth US$18 billion. Implementing the law of strict liability, providing incentives for fire prevention, and using remote sensing technologies could help. A cost-benefit analysis is needed to determine the returns from pollutive industries and whether the costs outweigh the benefits. Resolving the haze problem will take time, requiring sustained political will, coordination among government institutions, and international cooperation.

site_title: US regulator probing IBM's books; move sends shares down 4%
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating IBM's revenue recognition practices, particularly for deals in the US, Britain, and Ireland. The investigation, announced Tuesday, has sent IBM's shares down 4% to a five-year low. IBM, the world's largest technology services company, is cooperating with the SEC and maintains a "rigorous and disciplined process" for reporting revenue. The probe comes after the company posted lackluster quarterly results and cut its 2015 profit forecast, with some analysts suggesting the issue may be related to warranty reserves or revenue timing.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands
summary: Marina Bay Sands, Singapore's iconic integrated resort, has been awarded the Business Event Venue of the Year award. The venue, which opened in 2010, offers a seamless experience combining work and play under one roof. It boasts state-of-the-art facilities, luxury hotel, and celebrity chef restaurants. Marina Bay Sands prides itself on promoting Singapore as a key MICE destination through marketing efforts and partnerships with international associations. Its unique approach to hosting events showcases the country's dynamism and innovative spirit.

site_title: Goldman boosts bullish bet on Aussie banks
summary: Goldman Sachs Asset Management has increased its bullish bet on Australian bank shares, citing expectations of higher mortgage rates and credit growth that can sustain expansion in earnings and dividends. The firm, which oversees A$6 billion in Australian equities, believes stock-price declines among the big four lenders were overdone. With the banks raising variable mortgage rates to cover capital requirements, Goldman expects a 3% boost to profit and 5 basis point increase in net interest margins, leading to higher dividends.

site_title: Towards higher quality reporting
summary: Companies worldwide must prepare for a new standard for recognizing revenue, set to be implemented in 2017, after the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) converged their standards in 2014. The converged standard, "Revenue from contracts with customers," aims to provide a consistent global standard for revenue recognition. After over a decade of development, stakeholders and standard-setters are working together to ensure a smooth implementation of the new standard, which will have a wide-ranging impact on businesses globally.

images.alt_text: "Entities are strongly encouraged to start working with their professional advisers to avoid roadblocks that could derail implementation."- Nagaraj Sivaram, deputy chairman, Singapore Accounting Standards Council

"With the expanded disclosure requirements, companies will find the efforts and decisions surrounding disclosures more onerous and challenging."- Ronald Wong, partner, Financial Accounting Advisory Services, EY in Singapore

"Such data (that organisations need to collect in order to apply the new standard) can be very useful if meaningfully collated and analysed for business decision making."- Shariq Barmaky, chairman, Revenue Working Group, Financial Reporting Committee, Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants

site_title: Indonesia in work-permit U-turn following businesses' pushback
summary: Indonesia has reversed some of its onerous work permit rules for foreign professionals and offshore directors of local companies, following pushback from businesses and industry groups. The move comes as concerns grow over the country's unpredictable regulatory environment, which has deterred foreign investors. The changes, made by the Ministry of Manpower, include dropping requirements for temporary work permits for business meetings and non-resident foreign directors. Industry watchers say the U-turn reflects the government's lack of consultation with industry groups and could harm Indonesia's competitiveness.

site_title: Aussie dollar and emerging market units fall
summary: The Australian dollar plummeted over 1% against the US dollar in Asian trade due to lower-than-expected inflation rate of 0.5% and concerns about China's slowing growth. The US dollar rose against the Malaysian ringgit and slipped against other emerging currencies. Markets are awaiting the outcome of the US Federal Reserve meeting, with traders betting that the central bank will hold off an interest rate hike until next year.

site_title: WTA chief hopes S'pore will host Finals even beyond 2018
summary: WTA President Micky Lawler expressed hope that Singapore will continue to host the WTA Finals beyond 2018, citing the need for investment and time to make the event "very special." The tournament, which features the top eight women's singles players and doubles teams, has seen record highs in attendance, TV viewing, and online audiences since its first staging in Singapore last year. Lawler praised the players for their professionalism and investment in growing women's tennis in Asia, but noted that Serena Williams' absence due to injury was understandable.

site_title: Two warehouse buildings up for sale, asking S$70m
summary: Two adjacent warehouse buildings in Tampines, Singapore, have been put up for sale through an expression of interest exercise, with a combined asking price of S$70m. The six-storey warehouse and the eight-storey warehouse with over 200 parking lots are being sold together.

images.alt_text: The two properties at 21 (above) and 23 Tampines Street 92 are zoned for heavy industrial use and can be bought jointly or separately. The owner is also open to a sale-and-leaseback arrangement.
The two properties at 21 and 23 (above) Tampines Street 92 are zoned for heavy industrial use and can be bought jointly or separately. The owner is also open to a sale-and-leaseback arrangement.

site_title: Fed rate hike could burst HK property bubble
summary: A US Federal Reserve interest rate hike is expected to burst Hong Kong's property bubble, with prices potentially dropping 17% by 2017, according to analysts. The expected rate hike, which could occur before the end of 2015, would make it more difficult for Hong Kong homeowners to repay mortgages, leading to negative equity and potential defaults. The peg with the US dollar, which has fueled the city's housing boom, is also under scrutiny, with some analysts suggesting a switch to the yuan could be more suitable for Hong Kong's economy.

site_title: Barings Futures debacle: A lesson learnt for Singapore
summary: Singapore's economy has made significant strides, becoming a top financial hub and home to one of the world's top places to do business. However, the country still faces challenges, particularly the haze caused by forest fires, which has been a persistent problem. The haze has also raised concerns about the nation's ability to regulate and oversee financial markets. The Barings Futures debacle in 1995 was a significant lesson for Singapore's regulators and corporate governance, highlighting the importance of effective oversight and regulation. Since then, Singapore has adjusted its approach and is now regarded as a trustworthy financial center.

site_title: Singdollar seen sliding after MAS pared its pace of gains
summary: Singapore's dollar is predicted to weaken by 2% against the US dollar by year-end, reaching S$1.42, following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's slight reduction in the pace of appreciation. Analysts believe this easing will be due to the Federal Reserve's possible interest rate hikes. The central bank eased monetary policy in October, avoiding a technical recession, and will make its next policy announcement in April. Projections from analysts vary, with ANZ forecasting S$1.43 and Mizuho predicting S$1.39.

site_title: Forecasts from Twitter, flat user growth send stock diving
summary: Twitter's fourth-quarter forecast sent the company's stock diving 13% in after-hours trading, as the social media giant reported dismal revenue and profit projections. Despite exceeding analysts' expectations for the third quarter, Twitter warned of a decline in revenue and profits for the fourth quarter, citing challenges in winning over advertisers. The company's user growth remains stagnant, with 320 million users in the third quarter, and its efforts to lure new users are not yet showing results.

site_title: Jumbo Group launches Catalist IPO
summary: Jumbo Group, a Singapore-based seafood restaurant owner, launched a S$22.06 million initial public offering (IPO) of 88.23 million shares on Catalist, a junior stock exchange. The IPO, valued at S$160.3 million post-listing, will be used to expand the company, buy a new central kitchen, and shore up working capital. The group, which owns brands such as Jumbo Seafood and JPot, plans to list on the Singapore Exchange to have a bigger platform and better exposure for growth.

site_title: VW slumps to first quarterly loss in at least 15 years
summary: Volkswagen reported its first quarterly loss in at least 15 years due to costs related to its diesel emissions rigging scandal. The German group posted a third-quarter operating loss of 3.48 billion euros, in line with analyst forecasts. The company also lowered its profit outlook due to the ongoing scandal and increased regulatory scrutiny. This marks a significant turnaround for the company, which had previously been a model of German industry success.

site_title: US: Stocks jump as Fed view of US improves
summary: US stocks rose 1.13% on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 198.09 points to 17,779.52, the S&P 500 up 24.46 points to 2,090.35, and the Nasdaq Composite Index up 65.55 points to 5,095.69. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates near zero and modestly upgraded its US economic outlook, boosting investor confidence. Large banks rose sharply, with JPMorgan Chase up 2.9% and Bank of America up 5.4%.

site_title: Brooklyn becoming a serious rival to Manhattan
summary: Brooklyn is poised to become a rival to Manhattan as office space construction and renovation projects continue to surge, with about 16 million sq ft under construction or planned. The Brooklyn Navy Yard and Sunset Park waterfront are among areas seeing significant development, with projects like the 675,000-sq ft office complex in Brooklyn Navy Yard and the mixed-use complex in Sunset Park. Despite concerns over a lack of amenities, Brooklyn's proximity to tech hubs and venture capital investment could attract tenants, with rents potentially undercutting Manhattan's average of $77/sq ft.

site_title: Development opportunities in Asia
summary: Asia's urbanisation boom is expected to drive business opportunities, with 2.5 billion people projected to live in cities by 2050, mostly in Asia and Africa. India, China, and Nigeria are set to account for 37% of global urban population growth between 2014 and 2050. Myanmar is seen as a promising market, with strong GDP growth and significant foreign investment. The country's urban population is expected to grow by at least 3% annually over the next five years, driven by infrastructure investments and a need for redevelopment of existing cities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel DC Reit acquired mainCubes Data Centre in Germany for €84 million, expanding its footprint in Europe. SIM Lian Group acquired Lara Village Shopping Centre in Australia for A$30.2 million. Citic Envirotech reported a 17% year-on-year decline in second-quarter profit to S$15 million. K1 Ventures saw a significant jump in first-quarter net profit to S$87.33 million. Omni United acquired US tyre wholesale distributor Interstate Tire Distributor for an undisclosed amount, adding around S$100 million to its revenue.

site_title: OCBC Q3 profit falls 27% in absence of one-off gain
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 27% decline in Q3 net profit to S$902 million, excluding a one-off gain from 2014. Core earnings rose 7% to S$902 million, beating analyst expectations. Loan demand was weak, and bad loans rose to 0.9%, the highest in 14 quarters. The bank revised down full-year loan growth expectations to a low single digit. OCBC attributed the subdued results to interest rate volatility and uncertainty from China's economic growth.

site_title: Credit Suisse Asia-Pac aims to double pre-tax gain by 2018
summary: Credit Suisse Asia-Pacific aims to double its pre-tax income by 2018, driven by a strategy targeting Asian entrepreneurs and providing targeted private and investment banking services. The bank has seen significant revenue growth, with a 17% increase in revenue to $4.26 billion for the first nine months of the year. Pre-tax income surged 48% to $1.1 billion, exceeding the market average. The bank plans to grow its private banking business, increasing assets under management to $25 billion by 2018 and expanding its pool of relationship managers to 800 by 2018.

site_title: China-Europe rail links open way for more trade in fresh food
summary: China is investing in rail links with Europe, potentially boosting imports of fresh foods like meat and dairy products. The new facilities would allow for more imports of perishable goods, reducing transportation times from 40-50 days to 13 days or two weeks. China imports $6-7 billion of perishable food from Europe annually, mainly pork, dairy, and seafood. However, cold storage facilities are inadequate, and more investment is needed to handle imports in new rail terminals. This could give European exporters an advantage in transport times over major agricultural exporters like the US and Brazil.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages have released their assessments of various companies. Maybank Kim Eng downgraded SMRT Corporation due to its lacklustre earnings outlook, while Starhill Global Reit was upgraded to 'Buy' by RHB Research Institute after its Q1 FY2016 results exceeded expectations. OSIM International was downgraded to 'Reduce' by CIMB Research after its Q3 2015 profit fell short of expectations, primarily due to poor sales.

site_title: Race is on for Indonesia LNG supply chain deal
summary: Indonesia's state-owned utility PLN plans to issue a request for proposals for a liquefied natural gas (LNG) supply chain contract to meet its 35-gigawatt electrification program. 11 companies, including Shell and Pertamina, have been shortlisted to participate in the tender, which will involve the supply and distribution of LNG across 32 locations in Java, Sulawesi, and Kalimantan. The contract will also include a "design, build and operate" contract for small-scale LNG distribution infrastructure. PLN projects that LNG will contribute 9.4% of power generation by 2019.

site_title: NTUC co-ops to team up to provide more and better goods and services(Amended)
summary: Singapore's National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) plans to integrate its social enterprises to offer workers more and better products and services at affordable prices by 2019. The goal is to provide care to workers, lean on employers to treat workers fairly, and develop workers' careers. NTUC aims to create a positive work environment, protect workers' rights, and provide skills training to help workers adapt to the evolving job market. The labour movement will also work with the government and employers to strengthen labour laws and collective bargaining.

site_title: CCT posts higher Q3 DPU; expects pressure on market rents
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 2.4% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.14 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2015. The increase was attributed to higher rents. However, CCT expects downward pressure on market rents due to an "above-normal volume of new supply" of office space in Singapore between 2016 and 2017.

site_title: US drugstore Walgreens buying peer Rite Aid
summary: Walgreens Boots Alliance agreed to buy Rite Aid for over $9.4 billion in cash, creating a new giant in the US healthcare industry. The combination may raise concerns among regulators about a shrinking retail pharmacy market. The deal is the latest example of consolidation in the healthcare industry, with companies accelerating their pace of mergers and acquisitions. The acquisition is expected to bolster Walgreens' influence with drugmakers and pharmacy benefit managers.

site_title: Online freedom falls for fifth year in row: survey
summary: Global online freedom declined for a fifth consecutive year, according to a Freedom House survey, with 61% of the world's population living in countries where criticism has been subject to censorship. The decline was particularly notable in the Middle East, reversing gains from the Arab Spring. 58% of the population lives in countries where bloggers were jailed for sharing content online, and many governments are now pressuring online platforms to remove content, rather than relying on blocking and filtering. 18 countries were rated "free" online, while 28 were "partly free" and 19 were "not free".

images.alt_text: Global online freedom declined for a fifth consecutive year as more governments stepped up electronic surveillance and clamped down on dissidents using blogs or social media, a survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Japan's carmakers proceed with caution on self-driving cars
summary: Japan's major carmakers, including Nissan, Honda, and Toyota, are proceeding with caution on self-driving cars, delaying their introduction to 2025. Unlike companies like Google and Tesla, which aim to have fully autonomous vehicles on the road by 2020, Japan's carmakers prioritize software testing and regulatory approval before deploying features on public roads. The country's cautious approach is driven by concerns over safety and public acceptance.

site_title: Quiet trading ahead of FOMC meeting
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 12.02 points down at 3,040.51 on Wednesday, amidst low trading volumes of S$826 million. Markets in Hong Kong and China also ended weaker, awaiting the outcome of the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting. Banks, including OCBC, ended weaker due to soft earnings expectations, with OCBC's net profit falling 27% year-over-year.

site_title: Prices of completed condos up 0.1%: NUS index
summary: Singapore's National University of Singapore released a 0.1% month-on-month increase in completed condominium prices in September, ending a streak of five straight price declines. Despite this, market watchers expect downward pressures on private residential prices to continue. The uptick broke a streak of five straight months of price declines from April, but its impact was minimal.

images.alt_text: Prices of completed condominiums in Singapore inched up 0.1 per cent in September from the previous month, the National University of Singapore's flash estimates for its Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) released on Wednesday showed.

site_title: New player in specialty-insurance space heats up competition
summary: US-based general insurer Great American Insurance Group has launched its Singapore branch, Great American Insurance Company (GAIC), with about 70% of revenue expected to come from specialty lines such as marine, property, and professional risk insurance. The move is seen as a response to the growing competition in the Singapore specialty insurance space. GAIC aims to write over S$100 million in premiums by 2017 and achieve an 8% underwriting profit margin. The company's CEO, Chee Keng Koon, believes a physical presence in Singapore will enable it to do more business.

site_title: South Africa's economy at risk from possible US rate hike
summary: South Africa's economy remains at risk due to high external debt levels and a possible US rate hike, according to the Reserve Bank. The country's debt-to-GDP ratio is 47.5%, and a US interest rate increase could lead to market volatility, capital outflow, and a decline in the rand. This has resulted in a 15% decline in the rand against the dollar in 2015, and President Jacob Zuma has admitted that the economy faces a "serious struggle" to meet growth targets.

site_title: Haze cuts Indonesia's oil production as pollution affects workers
summary: Indonesia's forest fires have disrupted oil production, causing crude oil output to fall below 800,000 barrels per day. The haze pollution has led to more frequent maintenance and staff being unable to work properly, affecting industry. The country's biggest oil producer, Chevron, had to shut down hundreds of oil wells in Sumatra's Riau province last year, and Indonesia may take up to a decade to permanently curb land-burning. The haze also affected operations at a BP gas plant, and oil production is expected to average 810,000-815,000 barrels per day for this year.

site_title: PARKROYAL on Pickering
summary: PARKROYAL on Pickering, a Singapore hotel, has been recognized as a global leader in green high-rise developments since its opening in 2013. The hotel's unique architecture and design, featuring a hotel-in-a-garden concept and energy-saving features, has earned it the Business Event Venue of the Year award. The hotel's secret to service excellence lies in its dedication to creating memorable guest experiences, as demonstrated by its hosting of the 20th Century Fox crew and main cast of the movie Agent 47. Its innovative approach has made it a standout in the hospitality landscape.

site_title: Tour East Singapore
summary: Tour East Singapore has won the Meeting/Incentive Organiser of the Year award at the Singapore Experience Awards for organizing the Telstra GES LKO 2014 event at Marina Bay Sands in July 2014. The event, which involved over 1,200 executives from Telstra's worldwide offices, featured successful "Dive into Singapore" dinner and gala dinner events. Director Margaret Soh credited the team's creative planning capabilities for the event's success, citing the unique dining experience and global theme.

site_title: Singapore to focus on 5 futures, says Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the establishment of a new panel, the Committee for the Future Economy, to focus on five key areas: jobs, companies, resources, technology, and markets. The panel aims to chart Singapore's economic path in a rapidly-changing world, with a focus on keeping the city-state competitive. The committee, expected to submit its report in December 2016, will look at ways to redesign jobs, build companies' capabilities, and optimize land and labor use. Heng emphasized the need for a deep and frank discussion, and proposed measures to create good jobs and opportunities for citizens.

images.alt_text: Mr Heng doubts success can be measured by one or two metrics, and prefers to look at whether good jobs and opportunities have been created for citizens.

site_title: Apple seen taking up half the space at Fusionopolis Two tower
summary: Apple has leased approximately 215,000 square feet at Innovis, one of the towers in Fusionopolis Two in Singapore, occupying about half the space. The tech giant plans to use the new space primarily for research and development, boosting Fusionopolis's standing as an innovation hub and creating buzz for the one-north locale. The lease is part of Apple's expansion in Singapore, following reports of plans for its first Singapore store at Knightsbridge mall.

site_title: Global meltdown and the resulting crisis of confidence in financial engineering
summary: The article discusses how the 2008 financial crisis discredited financial engineering, a field that was often mistakenly linked to economics. Financial engineering focuses on mathematical models of financial products, whereas economics studies individual decision-making and human behavior. The crisis was caused by excessive confidence in financial engineering models, which relied on assumptions of efficient markets. The models failed when housing prices deviated from statistical relationships, leading to massive losses. To prevent future crises, experts recommend reducing leverage and increasing faith in qualitative approaches, as mathematical models will always be plagued by uncertainty.

site_title: What's hot, what's not on the M&A scene in 2016
summary: M&A deals are expected to surpass the $2.8 trillion value of 2007 this year, but a slowdown in deal closures is predicted due to heightened uncertainties. Consumer staples, financial services, tech, and internet-related sectors are expected to remain hot investment areas, particularly in Southeast Asia. However, economic growth prospects in Singapore and the US are expected to remain sluggish, with the Singapore economy susceptible to global headwinds. Analysts recommend a diversified investment portfolio in 2016, with a focus on yield in a low-flation environment.
