site_title: Bailout exit, unity moves make Cyprus attractive: entrepreneur
summary: Serial entrepreneur Stelios Haji-Ioannou, founder of easyJet, believes Cyprus is an attractive investment opportunity due to low property prices and the country's impending exit from its international bailout program. He notes that property prices may increase after reunification, which could happen if unity negotiations between Turkish-Cypriot leader Mustafa Akinci and President Nicos Anastasiades succeed. Haji-Ioannou sees this as a "one in a generation chance" to solve the island's division, which has been ongoing since 1974.

site_title: Alibaba defies China slowdown amid mobile-spending shift
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd defied China's economic slowdown by capturing the shift of consumer spending to smartphones, with 346 million monthly average mobile users and 59% growth in mobile users. The e-commerce company generated 2.39% of mobile transaction value as revenue, up from 1.87% a year ago, and saw sales jump 32% to 22.2 billion yuan. Alibaba's shares climbed 4.1% to US$79.44, reaching the highest closing price since August.

site_title: Optimum course for China, Japan is fuller economic cooperation
summary: China's economic cooperation with Japan is gaining momentum, with Beijing outpacing Tokyo in selling nuclear reactors and high-speed rail networks worldwide. Chinese President Xi Jinping's diplomatic efforts, including a recent audience with Queen Elizabeth II, demonstrate Beijing's growing influence. In contrast, Japan's world-famous Shinkansen system has failed to secure similar success. This cooperation could benefit overall Asian resources, as the rivalry between the two powers is wasteful. China's economic prowess is poised to continue its upward trajectory, while Japan's efforts to compete remain stagnant.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping's triumphal drive along London's famous Mall to Buckingham Palace for his recent audience with Britain's Queen Elizabeth II was more than just pomp and ceremony: it capped China's success in achieving what Japan is also eager to do, which is to sell nuclear reactors overseas.

site_title: Amex to roll out Apple Pay in S'pore next year
summary: American Express (Amex) plans to roll out Apple Pay to its Singaporean card users in 2016, following the service's availability in the US, UK, Canada, and Australia. The mobile payment service uses near-field communication (NFC) technology, allowing users to add credit card details to a digital wallet on their devices. This expansion is part of Apple's growing presence in the Asia-Pacific region, with Singapore being one of the key markets.

site_title: Landlord boom a bigger risk for Australian bad debts than businesses
summary: Australia's household debt is now higher than in other developed nations, with a record 134% of GDP, driven by a buy-to-let mortgage boom. This may lead to a greater risk of bank bad debts rather than corporate defaults, as households are increasingly leveraging themselves through mortgages. Experts warn of risks in the housing market and regulators have forced lenders to boost capital allocation to cover losses.

images.alt_text: CoreLogic Inc says home prices across Australia's capital cities have climbed 28% in the three years to Sept 30, with prices in Sydney (above) jumping 44%. But price growth is starting to slow.

site_title: IPO target out of reach with tepid Malaysian market
summary: Malaysian companies are struggling to meet their initial public offering (IPO) targets due to weak investor appetite and negative market sentiment. Despite initial optimism, funds raised via public share sales are likely to fall short of the RM13 billion target, with only about a third of the target raised so far. Most IPOs have raised small amounts, and only a few have seen their share prices remain above water. The market downturn has led bigger funds to reserve their capital to buy undervalued shares, and some companies have opted to sell assets instead of going to the market.

site_title: The five-step model
summary: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued a converged standard on revenue recognition in May 2014, aiming to increase financial statement comparability and reduce complexity. The standard applies a five-step model for revenue recognition, which is intended to provide clarity and consistency in revenue reporting across companies and industries. This move is expected to enhance financial statement comparability and promote transparency in financial reporting.

site_title: Olam secures US$1b revolving credit, term loan facility
summary: Olam International Limited has secured a US$1 billion revolving credit and term loan facility to refinance existing debt and meet working capital requirements. The facility consists of a US$850 million 364-day revolving credit and a US$150 million five-year term loan. The loan is part of Olam's proactive capital management strategy to diversify its debt portfolio and achieve an optimal borrowing cost mix. The mandated lead arrangers for the loan are 18 international banks.

site_title: Meeting the needs of Asia's cities
summary: Asia's cities are experiencing rapid urbanization, with 64% of its population expected to live in cities by 2050. Private sector players are crucial in meeting the challenge of infrastructure development, including housing, transportation, and utilities. Experts emphasize the need for sustainable and disaster-resilient development, striking a balance between economic growth and quality of life. Countries like China and Singapore are leading the way in urban planning, with the Chinese government releasing its "National New-Type Urbanisation Plan" and Singapore-based companies like Ascendas-Singbridge and Surbana Jurong providing expertise in infrastructure development.

site_title: HSBC shifting derivatives trades to HK as HQ decision looms: sources
summary: HSBC is shifting billions of dollars worth of derivatives trades from London to Hong Kong as its headquarters decision looms. The move aims to take advantage of Hong Kong's favourable funding and regulatory environment, reducing HSBC's exposure to the US and European bank levy. The bank is focusing on interest rate swaps, which comprise the bulk of the global over-the-counter derivatives market, and is positioning itself for a potential relocation of its headquarters to Hong Kong.

site_title: Illegal modifications: More frequent car checks for errant motorists
summary: Singapore has introduced a new inspection regime for vehicles with illegally-modified engines or exhaust systems. Motorists caught with such modifications for a second or subsequent time will face more frequent inspections, with second-time offenders required to bring their vehicles in every six months for two years, and third-time or subsequent offenders every three months for two years. Failure to comply can result in fines up to S$1,000 or three months in jail, with penalties doubled for repeat offenders. The move aims to deter motorists from modifying vehicles without proper certification and approval.

images.alt_text: A photo given by the Land Transport Authority showing an illegal modification done to a car, with a twincam engine.

site_title: Early indications suggest China's economy is stabilising
summary: China's economy appears to be stabilizing, according to early private surveys. Manufacturing and services indices improved in October, with the manufacturing reading rising to 43.3 and the non-manufacturing measure climbing to 44.2. Analysts expect the official Purchasing Managers' Indexes to be released soon, which may further confirm the stabilization. The People's Bank of China cut interest rates for the sixth time in a year to address growth challenges, and economists are watching for policy moves ahead.

site_title: EU to open up services sector in revamp of single market
summary: The European Commission proposes a revamp of the EU single market to open up the services sector, aiming to lower competitive barriers in construction, engineering, and accounting. The plan, set to introduce a "service passport" for companies to expand abroad, aims to improve competitiveness and lower prices for consumers. The Commission also plans initiatives to end diverging prices for consumers, further open up the retail sector, and reduce red tape for small companies. The goal is to revive sluggish economic growth in the EU, which has seen signs of moving backwards as states prioritize protecting national industries.

site_title: APB to end exclusive sales practice following probe by competition watchdog
summary: APB, a Singapore-based brewery, has agreed to end its exclusive sales practice for draught beer, following a probe by the Competition Commission of Singapore. The company will no longer impose outlet-exclusivity conditions, allowing retailers to stock a greater variety of draught beers, benefiting consumers and new suppliers. The change, effective December 28, comes after the CCS found APBS's practice restricted choices and prevented competing suppliers from entering the market.

site_title: AB InBev extends SABMiller offer by a week
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev has agreed to extend its offer to acquire British brewer SABMiller by a week to allow for further discussions. The offer, worth over $120 billion, includes debt. The review of SABMiller's business has confirmed the terms of the bid.

site_title: Dispute with Cameron opens new challenge to Britain's House of Lords
summary: Britain's House of Lords faces a new challenge to its power after derailing planned budget cuts, which opponents claim unfairly target the poor. The chamber's office announced a review of its powers after a dispute with Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative government. The move comes after the chamber recently survived the resignation of a senior member caught in a scandal. The review is seen as a response to the chamber's ability to block the budget cuts, which could impact the government's ability to implement its economic policies.

site_title: Gold retailer Degussa opens first Asian branch in S'pore
summary: Degussa, a German gold retailer, has opened its first Asian branch in Singapore, marking its first international expansion outside Europe. The branch will focus on selling gold jewellery and accessories, with plans to develop the investment market in the country. Degussa aims to start its online store in two weeks and plans to offer scrap gold cash-in services. The addition of Degussa is expected to boost Singapore's gold sector, which is valued at US$0.5 billion and set to create 1,000 jobs by 2020.

site_title: Shell takes US$2b charge to quit oil-sands project
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has taken a $2 billion charge to quit its Carmon Creek oil-sands project in Alberta, Canada, after deciding it couldn't compete in its portfolio. The project, which was expected to produce 80,000 barrels a day, will be halted. The decision reflects the challenges faced by the oil-sands industry due to low oil prices and lack of transportation infrastructure. Shell joins other energy companies in deferring investment in the oil sands, with 18 future projects delayed this year.

site_title: Long journey ahead for OECD's tax plan
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has announced new tax proposals under its Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) Action Plan, aiming to tax profits where economic activity occurs. However, the implementation of these proposals is uncertain, with various countries needing to adopt actual laws to give effect to the OECD recommendations. Key issues include limiting interest deductions, taxing economic activity not connected to a taxable business presence, and preventing taxpayers from investing via third countries for tax benefits. The adoption of these measures is expected to unfold over time, with countries such as the US, Asia-Pacific region, and Europe taking varying approaches.

site_title: A-HTrust's Q2 DPS up 8.7% despite income hit from currency movements
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) reported a 8.7% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for its Q2 2015, despite a 6.1% decline in gross revenue and a 2.9% drop in net property income due to currency movements. The trust's portfolio saw improvements in local currencies across Australia, China, Japan, and Singapore, but was negatively impacted by currency fluctuations. Key hotels saw strong room demand, with Sydney and Melbourne hotels posting a 4.4% growth in average revenue per available room (RevPar).

site_title: Love locks: A scourge in Paris prevails in other cities
summary: Paris, where an estimated 45 tonnes of love locks were removed from the Pont des Arts bridge in June, remains plagued by the trend, with officials viewing it as a scourge. Despite a citywide effort to ban the locks, tourists continue to deposit them, causing damage to infrastructure and aesthetics. The locks have spread to other cities worldwide, with some, like Vancouver, finding creative solutions to accommodate them. The trend has sparked debate, with some cities embracing it as a tourist attraction, while others, like Paris, are determined to put an end to it.

site_title: US third-quarter GDP forecasts raised after trade data
summary: US third-quarter GDP forecasts were raised after trade data showed the goods trade deficit narrowed to a seven-month low in September, shaving off about 0.8 percentage points from the initial forecast. Economists now estimate trade subtracted only one-tenth of a percentage point, leading to revised estimates of 2.0% growth. Despite a slowdown from the second quarter's 3.9% pace, the revised GDP forecast suggests a more balanced composition of growth, with a smaller drag from net trade and more modest equipment investment.

site_title: SingEx Exhibition Ventures
summary: SingEx Exhibition Ventures won the Trade Conference Organiser of the Year award for organizing the inaugural Internet of Things Asia conference in 2014. The event, held at MAX Atria @ Singapore EXPO, attracted 1,630 delegates from 33 countries and generated S$4.62 million worth of business transactions. The conference received widespread endorsement and positioned Singapore as a frontline nation in the IoT revolution, with plans to continue charting the future of IoT in Asia in 2016.

site_title: Koh Brothers holds 30% stake in JV handling Changi's 3rd runway works
summary: Koh Brothers, a Singaporean construction company, has secured a 30% stake in a joint venture (JV) to develop Changi Airport's third runway. The S$1.12 billion contract, won in a competitive tender, will increase Koh Brothers' construction order book to S$632 million. The JV, led by Samsung C&T Corp, will extend the existing runway and develop supporting taxiways to handle larger aircraft. The project is part of Changi Airport Group's plans to transition to a three-runway system by the early 2020s, enhancing airport capacity for growth beyond the decade.

site_title: HDB's up-sized issue of S$1.2b five-year bonds snapped up
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) sold S$1.2 billion in 5-year bonds, upsized 50% from its initial S$800 million issue due to strong demand. The bonds offered a 2.10% coupon, reflecting HDB's triple A rating. This issuance allows HDB to deepen its investor pool, joining other AAA-rated issuers like Temasek and the Asian Development Bank. The lower pricing is attributed to HDB's statutory board status, giving it a 32.4-point advantage over Singapore Government Securities. The bonds now qualify as "Level 1 High-Quality Liquid Assets", making them attractive to banks and investors.

site_title: Paris 'palace' hotels face growing challenges
summary: Luxury hotels in Paris, known as "palaces," face growing challenges due to terror attacks, websites like Airbnb, and the rise of luxury boutique hotels. Despite a 20% occupancy rate drop in the first quarter, analysts say the appeal of these high-end establishments remains. However, the increasing competition from new networks and luxury boutique hotels may lead to a decrease in prices per night. Market experts acknowledge the trend, but dispute its scale, citing the unique offerings of Parisian palaces, such as fine dining and 24-hour concierge services.

site_title: Sim Lian plans to buy shopping centre in Australia
summary: Sim Lian Group plans to acquire Lara Village Shopping Centre in Victoria, Australia for A$30.2 million (S$30.02 million). The shopping centre has a total gross lettable area of 6,449 square metres, anchored by a Coles Supermarket. The acquisition will be funded by internal funds and bank borrowings.

site_title: Great American Insurance Group opens Singapore office
summary: Great American Insurance Group (GAIC) has opened its first office in Singapore, marking its entry into the South-east Asian market. The new branch, led by Chee Keng Koon, focuses on specialty insurance sectors such as marine, general liability, and professional liability. GAIC aims to tap into the abundant market opportunities in Asia, particularly in the specialty classes, and leverages Singapore's stable and substantial insurance hub.

site_title: Few listed companies producing 'truly balanced' sustainability reports: EY
summary: Only three out of 50 major listed companies in Singapore have produced "truly balanced" sustainability reports, according to a study by auditor EY. The remaining 47 firms either failed to report on sustainability or provided one-sided reports focusing on positive progress. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is set to implement a "comply or explain" requirement for sustainability reporting by 2017, with EY advising firms to start producing reports by investing in a few thousand dollars' worth of data analysis and reporting tools.

site_title: Crude stocks rise as distillate declines more than expected: EIA
summary: US crude stocks rose 3.4 million barrels last week, exceeding analyst expectations, while gasoline stocks fell 1.1 million barrels and distillate inventories declined 3 million barrels. Refinery crude runs increased by 271,000 barrels per day, and refinery utilization rates rose by 1.2 percentage points. Crude imports fell by 417,000 barrels per day. The data contradicts expectations for a 1.7 million barrel drop in distillate stockpiles and an 817,000 barrel drop in gasoline stocks.

site_title: Japan's Hulic to buy Simplex for 155b yen amid many bids
summary: Japanese developer Hulic Co will acquire Tokyo-based Simplex Investment Advisors for approximately 155 billion yen (S$1.16 billion) from US investment Aetos Capital, marking Japan's largest property deal this year. Hulic plans to keep Simplex's five properties, including a hotel near Tokyo Disney Resort, and sell other assets to Mizuho Financial Group. The deal follows aggressive monetary expansion policies under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, which have lowered borrowing costs, attracting multiple bidders including Chinese insurance group Anbang and US investment funds.

site_title: K1 Ventures' Q1 profit, revenue leap
summary: K1 Ventures reported a significant increase in net profit to S$87.33 million for Q1, driven by higher revenue and investment income. Revenue rose to S$89.29 million, up from S$2.88 million last year. Profit before tax reached S$88.32 million, with earnings per share increasing to 4.03 Singapore cents from 0.14 cents in the same period last year.

site_title: Drugs giant GSK posts upbeat Q3
summary: British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) posted a 34% rise in net profit to £538 million in its third-quarter earnings, driven by sales of HIV drugs and its asset swap deal with Novartis. Revenue climbed 9% to £6.127 billion. This marks a significant improvement from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline on Wednesday posted rising third-quarter earnings and revenues, buoyed by sales of HIV drugs and its asset swap deal with Swiss peer Novartis.

site_title: Samudera Shipping Line's Q3 profit drops almost 77% amid industry headwinds
summary: Samudera Shipping Line reported a 77% drop in Q3 net profit to US$1.23 million, citing industry headwinds. Revenue declined 14.8% to US$75.16 million due to lower contributions from its container and bulk tanker business segments. The group expects ongoing operating challenges in the container and bulk sectors.

site_title: ECB is reviewing monetary toolbox without taboos: Praet
summary: The European Central Bank is reviewing its monetary policy toolbox without restrictions, aiming to boost euro zone inflation. ECB Chief Economist Praet stated that the ECB is examining the experiences of other central banks, including the Bank of Japan, Federal Reserve, and Bank of England, to inform its decisions. This review may lead to an expansion of the ECB's asset-purchase program to include new asset classes, in an effort to stimulate inflation and support the euro zone economy.

site_title: China's growth could beat forecast in 2015: IMF official
summary: China's economy could exceed the IMF's forecast of 6.8% growth in 2015, potentially reaching 7%, according to a senior IMF official. This growth rate is attributed to China's 6.9% expansion between July and September. The IMF is concerned about the potential impact of slower growth on other regional economies, particularly those with closer trade ties with China. A one percent growth shock from China could shave 0.3 percentage points from overall Asian growth.

site_title: ECB's Hansson sees no need to ease policy in December
summary: Ardo Hansson, a member of the European Central Bank's governing body, stated that there is no need to ease policy in December, contradicting a recent dovish message from ECB President Mario Draghi. The euro zone economy appears resilient, and long-term inflation expectations are well-anchored, making a rate cut unnecessary. Hansson cited the domestic euro area economy's growth and the bank lending channel working well as reasons for his stance, which contradicts the ECB's previous consideration of policy easing in December.

site_title: Australia's NAB to sell insurance stake, divest British bank
summary: NAB, Australia's largest bank, has sold an 80% stake in its insurance business to Japan's Nippon Life for $1.7 billion. The move aims to bolster the bank's balance sheet and meet tougher regulatory requirements. NAB also plans to divest its troubled British asset Clydesdale Bank. The bank reported a 19.7% rise in annual net profit to A$6.34 billion for the year to August 31.

site_title: BoE says will map out move to Libor alternative in 2016
summary: The Bank of England has announced plans to map out a move to an alternative to the Libor benchmark interest rate by 2016. The existing benchmark, used for interest rates that banks charge each other, has come under scrutiny after traders were accused of colluding to rig it. The BoE has been working on an alternative near-risk-free reference rate, which would replace Libor in contracts where users want to hedge general interest rates. The transition aims to reduce the bank credit risk component in Libor, but may pose challenges for companies raising funds on fixed income markets.

site_title: IBM, looking to cloud, to buy Weather Company's digital assets
summary: IBM to buy Weather Company's digital assets for over $2 billion, boosting its Watson cloud and Internet of Things platforms. The deal excludes the Weather Channel, which will use IBM's weather forecast data and analytics under a long-term contract. The move highlights IBM's focus on high-growth areas, as it divests low-margin businesses. The Weather Company is owned by private equity firms Blackstone Group LP and Bain Capital, and Comcast Corp's NBC Universal.

site_title: Downgrade potential in emerging markets elevated: S&P
summary: Standard & Poor's reports that the potential for credit rating downgrades in emerging markets is elevated, with 134 potential downgrades, a 30% increase since 2011. The risk is highest in eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa, and Latin America, driven by low commodity prices and decelerating economic growth. Nearly 28% of emerging market companies have a downgrade warning, with China's banking and real estate sectors particularly vulnerable due to slowing growth and property market corrections.

site_title: Spain court begins proceedings against Volkswagen over rigged engines
summary: Spain's high court has opened proceedings against Volkswagen over allegations of rigging diesel emissions tests, potentially committing fraud and environmental crimes. The public prosecutor argues that Volkswagen may have taken subsidies illicitly and polluted the environment. The company must present a representative before the Spanish judge by November 10. The case is related to the global scandal surrounding Volkswagen's emissions tests, which led to the company's admission of cheating in 2015.

site_title: Second Chance Properties reports fall in Q4 profit
summary: SECOND CHANCE PROPERTIES SEES Q4 PROFIT FALL. The company reported a net profit of S$2.08 million for the three months ended Aug 31, down from S$5.67 million, with earnings per share dropping to 0.31 cents. For the full year, net profit slumped 38% to S$10.26 million, while revenue decreased 5.5% to S$45.79 million due to weaker performances from its apparel and properties businesses. The firm has declared a dividend of 3.55 cents per share.

site_title: Saipem plans 3.5b euro rights issue as Eni steps back
summary: Saipem, an Italian oil contractor, plans a 3.5 billion euro rights issue to weather the oil service recession and recover without the support of main investor Eni. Eni will sell 12.5% of its Saipem stake to a state-owned investment fund, relinquishing control and cutting 5.1 billion euros of debt. Saipem aims to become a standalone company, refinancing its remaining 3.2 billion euros of gross debt with new credit lines. The move is seen as a major step towards recovery, with analysts expecting the market to recover in 2017.

site_title: Jumbo Group's S$40m IPO in the pot
summary: Jumbo Group, a crab restaurant owner, has finally completed its S$40 million initial public offering (IPO) via a S$22.1 million Catalist IPO of 88.23 million shares at S$0.25 apiece. Cornerstone investors Temasek arm Heliconia and OSIM founder Ron Sim have also invested S$10 million and S$8 million respectively. Jumbo Group's main revenue generator is its Jumbo Seafood outlets, selling about 1.6 tonnes of crabs daily. The IPO aims to give the group a bigger platform and better exposure for growth.

site_title: Citic Envirotech posts profit fall of almost 17% for Q2
summary: CITIC Envirotech reported a 17% year-on-year decline in Q2 profit to S$15 million, with revenue falling 33% to S$70.88 million. Earning per share dropped to 1.23 cents from 1.83 cents. For the six-month period, net profit fell 54% to S$18.71 million and revenue declined 10% to S$154.73 million, largely due to lower contributions from its engineering business.

site_title: Screening period for Hepatitis C cluster at SGH should be extended: review committee
summary: A review committee appointed by the Singapore Ministry of Health recommends extending the screening period for a Hepatitis C cluster at the Singapore General Hospital's renal ward from July to end-September. The committee, led by Prof Leo Yee Sin, has been conducting on-site visits, reviewing cases, and analyzing infection control practices. International advisers Dr Scott Holmberg and Prof Trish Perl will continue to provide input through emails and phone calls. The investigation is ongoing, and all potential exposures or sources are being considered.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly up ahead of Fed statement
summary: US stocks opened mostly higher on Wednesday, driven by strong Apple earnings, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 46.53 points (0.26 percent) to 17,627.96. The S&P 500 advanced 3.22 (0.16 percent) to 2,069.11, while the Nasdaq Composite Index dipped 2.45 (0.05 percent) to 5,027.70. Investors await the Federal Reserve policy statement, which is expected to provide clues about future rate hikes. Analysts expect the statement to rule out a rate hike in 2015, potentially boosting market sentiment.

site_title: Toyota chief says would be wrong for diesel use to fall due to VW scandal
summary: Toyota President Akio Toyoda stated that it would be wrong for diesel use to decline due to the Volkswagen emissions scandal, and the company will continue using diesel engines in trucks and other suitable applications. He also expressed confidence in Toyota's leadership in developing advanced automated driving technology, with the goal of bringing autonomous vehicles to market by 2020.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit acquires data centre in Germany
summary: Keppel DC Reit has acquired mainCubes Data Centre in Germany for 84 million euros (S$130 million). The four-storey data centre, located in the Offenbach am Main hub near Frankfurt, will be fitted out to Tier III specifications and completed in 2018. The acquisition is backed by a 15-year triple-net lease agreement and increases the Reit's portfolio weighted average lease expiry to 10 years, making it immediately accretive to its distribution per unit. The move expands Keppel DC Reit's presence in the European data centre market.

site_title: HDB sells jumbo S$1.2 billion 5-year bond
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) sold a S$1.2 billion 5-year bond, upsized 50% from an initial S$800 million due to strong demand. This was HDB's first issue after receiving a 'AAA' rating from Moody's, allowing it to deepen its investor pool and achieve a tight bond deal. The 2.10% coupon rate is lower than previous deals, reflecting HDB's triple A rating. This move makes HDB one of AAA-rated issuers, joining Temasek and supranationals like the Asian Development Board, and provides good value for banks looking for liquidity requirements.

site_title: Ferrari Q3 earnings jump on higher vehicle shipments
summary: Ferrari reported a 22% rise in third-quarter adjusted core profit to 213 million euros, driven by a 21% increase in sportscar shipments to 1,949 vehicles. Revenues rose 9% to 723 million euros. The company expects deliveries of 7,700 vehicles and adjusted EBITDA of 725-745 million euros for 2015. Ferrari's parent Fiat Chrysler Automobiles sold 10% of the company in an initial public offering, valuing it at $9.8 billion. Analysts question whether Ferrari can sustain high valuations due to its small-volume, capital-intensive business model.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 10.44 points to 1,686.51. The market saw 2.1 billion lots worth RM2.05 billion in volume, with 449 gainers and 383 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down as China markets retreat
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.8% to 22,956.57 points, following mainland China's decline after late afternoon profit taking. Banks and insurers led the decline due to concerns over China's slowing economy and increasing bad loans. The China Enterprises Index lost 1.5% to 10,558.47.

site_title: CNOOC's third-quarter revenue falls almost a third on low oil prices
summary: China's top offshore oil producer CNOOC Ltd reported a 32.3% decline in third-quarter revenue from oil and gas sales to 36.25 billion yuan (S$7.96 billion) due to low oil prices. The average realized oil price fell 51% to US$48.84 a barrel. Capital expenditure also decreased 44% to 14.75 billion yuan amid belt-tightening measures.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy panel will submit its report by December 2016, reviewing the country's future economic direction. Consumer confidence remained on a downtrend in October, while Singapore remains the easiest place to do business globally. Completed condo prices in Singapore increased 0.1% in September. Jumbo Group's chilli-crab IPO attracted cornerstone investors, including Temasek Holdings and the Osim founder. Lippo Group plans to shift two Reits from Singapore to Indonesia to benefit from tax breaks. The STI closed lower on Wednesday, ahead of the US FOMC meeting.

site_title: Barclays says to pay new CEO Staley up to US$12.6m a year
summary: Barclays appoints James 'Jes' Staley as its new CEO, effective December 1. Staley, former JPMorgan investment bank boss, will be paid up to 8.24 million pounds (US$12.6 million) annually, including a salary, shares, and bonus. Chairman John McFarlane praised Staley's leadership talent and experience in corporate and investment banking, which aligns with Barclays' priorities. Staley, currently managing partner of BlueMountain Capital Management, previously spent 30 years at JPMorgan.

images.alt_text: British bank Barclays Plc has appointed James 'Jes' Staley as its new chief executive and said the former JPMorgan investment bank boss will be paid up to 8.24 million pounds (US$12.6 million) a year.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg in India to get 'next billion online'
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg visited India, emphasizing the country's importance in connecting the "next billion online." He stated that Internet access is vital for economic development, creating jobs, and lifting people out of poverty. Zuckerberg defended Facebook's Internet.org project, which provides free access to the Internet in poor rural communities, despite criticism over net neutrality. He also explored new ways to increase access, including solar-powered planes and data-light apps. Zuckerberg's visit came after meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who advocated for the power of social media.

site_title: VW slumps to first quarterly loss in at least 15 years
summary: Volkswagen reported its first quarterly operating loss in at least 15 years, with a 3.48 billion-euro deficit, mainly due to costs related to the diesel emissions scandal. The German group maintained its guidance for full-year deliveries of 10.14 million vehicles, despite the losses. This move comes as Volkswagen faces significant financial penalties for its role in rigging emissions tests. The company's operating group profit is expected to be significantly lower than last year's levels.

site_title: Lloyds profits hit by new mis-selling charge
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported flat net profits of £690 million in the third quarter, despite a 8% decline in underlying pre-tax profits due to a £500-million payment protection insurance charge. The charge, part of the mis-selling scandal, increased the total bill to £13.9 billion. Lloyds shares fell 4.7% in response. The bank's CEO, Antonio Horta-Osorio, stated that the company is making "strong financial progress," but the mixed results have dampened expectations for future dividends. The government, which rescued Lloyds in 2008, is selling shares to the public and exiting its holding in the coming months.

site_title: Singapore-based Omni acquires US tyre wholesale distributor
summary: Singapore-based Omni United acquired US tyre wholesale distributor Interstate Tire Distributor (ITD) for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition will more than double Omni's existing retail reach in the US, where it generates nearly 65% of its revenue. ITD serves over 2,500 tyre retailers in the US, distributing mid-tier and value-driven brands such as Yokohama and Goodride. The deal expands Omni's presence in the US market and strengthens its retail network.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower in low volume ahead of US FOMC meeting
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 12.02 points lower at 3,040.51 in low trading volume of one billion units worth S$826 million. Markets in the region remained quiet ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting. Local banks, including OCBC, ended weaker due to soft earnings expectations. OCBC reported a 7% growth in core net earnings for the third quarter, but its shares fell S$0.08 to S$9.20.

site_title: Indonesia scraps rules restricting foreign workers
summary: Indonesia has scrapped rules restricting foreign workers, four months after they were introduced. The rules, which required firms to hire 10 Indonesian employees for every foreign worker, have been dropped to support investment and create jobs. Permit requirements for non-residential directors, foreigners attending work meetings, and giving speeches have also been eliminated. The decision was made in response to complaints from companies, with the goal of encouraging foreign investment and boosting the economy. The move is seen as a policy flip-flop, but aims to create a more favorable business environment.

site_title: Italy knocks France off top spot for wine production
summary: Italy surpassed France as the world's top wine producer, with 48.9 million hectoliters (Mhl) of wine produced, a 10% increase from 2014. Global wine production rose 2.0% to 275.7 Mhl, with the US, Argentina, and Chile also experiencing significant growth. France remained second with 47.4 Mhl, followed by Spain with 36.6 Mhl. The global wine market appears to be in balance, with sufficient production to cover global consumption and industrial use.

site_title: Football: Seven to run for Fifa presidency
summary: Fifa has confirmed seven candidates to run in its election for a new president on February 26, 2016. The candidates include Prince Ali Bin Al Hussein, Musa Bility, Jerome Champagne, Gianni Infantino, Michel Platini, Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim Al Khalifa, and Tokyo Sexwale. Former Trinidad and Tobago footballer David Nakhid had announced his candidacy last week, but his candidacy was not mentioned by Fifa. The election is scheduled to take place on February 26, 2016.

site_title: Australia shares pare losses, NZ stocks end winning streak
summary: Australian shares narrowly reversed early losses, closing 0.2% lower at 5,335.2, as subdued inflation reinforced speculation of monetary easing. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index ended a 12-session winning streak, closing 2.03 points down at 5,998.99. The losses followed a 2-1/2-month peak on Monday.

site_title: Asia Pacific Breweries ends exclusive sales practice after CCS probe
summary: Asia Pacific Breweries (APBS) will cease its exclusive sales practice for draught beer to retailers after a probe by the Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS). The company has given CCS a voluntary commitment to end outlet exclusivity, allowing beer suppliers to compete on merit. This change will apply to all draught beer contracts entered into on and after December 28. The move aims to increase competition and variety in the market, benefiting consumers and suppliers, including microbreweries and craft beer suppliers. CCS will monitor market practices to ensure compliance with competition law.

site_title: Gold retailer Degussa opens Singapore branch, its first outside Europe
summary: Degussa, Europe's largest gold retailer, has opened its first branch outside Europe in Singapore. The 3,000-square-foot branch near Dhoby Ghaut MRT Station offers physical bullion products, including gold, silver, and platinum coins, as well as investment bars, and retail gift collection items. Degussa aims to capture the growing retail market for gold and precious metals in Singapore and Asia. The company plans to start its online store in two weeks and allow customers to cash in their scrap gold in the near future.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence index dips again in October
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence index dropped 4.6 points month-over-month to 125 in October, marking the second consecutive decline. The index remains above its long-term average of 123.5, but respondents expressed pessimism about personal financial conditions, with 26.9% saying their families are better off financially than a year ago, the lowest point since 2014. Expectations for future economic conditions also fell, with 51.1% expecting "good times" financially over the next 12 months, down 4.5 percentage points from September.

site_title: South Korea's Park to play balancing act between China and Japan
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye is set to host a three-way summit with China and Japan, marking a diplomatic breakthrough for Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The summit comes amid pressure from the US to mend ties between Seoul and Tokyo, which have been strained by historical disputes, particularly over "comfort women" and wartime atrocities. Park aims to promote business ties and address regional issues, including North Korea's arms program, while Abe seeks to normalize the relationship between the two countries. The summit is seen as a key step in balancing ties with Beijing and Washington.

site_title: Toshiba says to sell sensor business to Sony, overhaul chip unit
summary: Toshiba announces plans to sell its image sensor business to Sony and overhaul its unprofitable semiconductor businesses, following a $1.3 billion accounting scandal. The company will also withdraw from the white LED business. These restructuring steps are the first since the scandal was revealed earlier this year, aiming to recover from the financial impact.

site_title: China: Stocks slide nearly 2% on profit taking
summary: China's stocks slid nearly 2% on Wednesday, with the CSI300 index falling 1.9% to 3,524.92 points. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.7% to 3,375.20. Analysts attributed the decline to profit-taking after recent gains. Despite short-term volatility, they expect the market to rebound in the medium term due to ongoing reforms and economy-boosting measures.

site_title: Nintendo says sales jump on 3DS console demand, but net profit falls
summary: Nintendo reported a 19% increase in revenue to 204.1 billion yen (S$2.4 billion) in the first six months of the year, driven by strong demand for its 3DS handheld console and games for the Wii U system. However, net profit declined nearly 20% due to a special gain booked in the previous period. The company faces increasing competition from Sony and Microsoft in console sales, as well as the shift towards cheap, downloadable games on smartphones. Following the death of CEO Satoru Iwata, Nintendo's future remains uncertain.

site_title: Train service on East-West Line suspended for 20 minutes due to track fault
summary: Train service on the East-West Line in Singapore has been suspended for 20 minutes due to a track fault. The halt occurred on October 28, 2015, and affected travel in both directions between Pasir Ris and Tampines stations.

site_title: Japan carrier ANA says profit soars on international business
summary: All Nippon Airways (ANA) reported a 51% surge in six-month net profit to 53.97 billion yen (S$625 million), driven by a significant increase in international business and strong inbound tourism. Falling oil prices also contributed to the carrier's improved finances. Revenue rose 6.6% from the previous year, with ANA Holdings' parent company seeing a strong performance. The airline's international business and tourism growth were key factors in the company's increased profit.

site_title: Japan PM oversees Central Asia business deals worth US$26b
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe completed a week-long tour of Central Asia, securing business deals worth over US$26 billion with representatives of 50 Japanese firms. This marks the first time a Japanese prime minister has visited five Central Asian countries at once. Abe aimed to strengthen business ties in the region, where China is investing heavily, to boost Japan's economy.

site_title: AB InBev, SABMiller extend takeover deadline to Nov 4
summary: AB InBev, SABMiller extend takeover deadline to November 4, pushing back the deadline from October 31 to 5 pm on November 4, as SABMiller requests an additional week to consider a US$100 billion-plus takeover offer.

images.alt_text: Brewer SABMiller Plc has extended the deadline for rival Anheuser-Busch InBev to make a formal US$100 billion-plus takeover offer by a week.

site_title: Europe: Shares get results lift, with Fed in focus
summary: European shares rose 0.1% to 1,470.79, boosted by company earnings reports from Heineken, UCB, and Volkswagen. The FTSEurofirst 300 is 1.8% below a two-month high. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, with strategists predicting "dovish tweaks" to its statement. The decision comes amid US and global economic headwinds, which may hinder the Fed's ability to tighten monetary policy before year-end.

images.alt_text: European shares edged higher in early deals on Wednesday, buoyed by a fresh batch of company earnings reports ahead of a Federal Reserve policy decision later in the day.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise 0.67% as Japan earnings kick off
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.67% on Wednesday, driven by Japan's earnings season kicking off. The Nikkei 225 index rose 125.98 points to 18,903.02, while the Topix index climbed 0.26% to 1,547.19. Investors await the outcome of the Federal Reserve policy meeting, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge down, won flat as markets await Fed decision
summary: South Korean shares edged down 0.1% at 2,042.51 points, awaiting the US Federal Reserve policy decision. The won closed flat at 1,131.0 to the dollar. Investors adopted a wait-and-see stance ahead of the Fed's decision, which may impact global markets.

site_title: HSBC names new CEO for Singapore asset management business
summary: HSBC has appointed Puneet Chaddha as the new CEO for its Singapore asset management business, effective November 1. Chaddha, previously head of HSBC's asset management unit in India, will drive growth in Asean and support clients in Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines. He succeeds Kalen Lim, who will move to another senior role within HSBC.

site_title: Panel reviewing Singapore economy to submit report around December 2016
summary: Singapore's economy review committee will submit its report by December 2016, focusing on five key areas: jobs, companies, resources, technology, and markets. The 12-month process aims to develop a strong strategy for the future economy, creating good opportunities and jobs for Singaporeans. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat chairs the committee, which will be announced by early December. The review aims to prepare Singapore for the future economy and achieve its goal of creating a strong and sustainable economy.

site_title: Biosensors gets buyout offer from Citic Private Equity
summary: Biosensors International Group received a buyout offer from Citic Private Equity Funds Management Co for the proposed amalgamation with its substantial shareholder, CB Medical Holdings. The offer was received on October 23, and the company's board of directors is reviewing it. Discussions are ongoing, and there is no certainty that they will result in a transaction. This offer comes after Citic Private Equity acquired a stake in Biosensors last year from Shandong Weigao Group Medical Polymer.

site_title: Japan small firms' mood hits 4-month low: survey
summary: Japan's small firms reported a 4-month low business sentiment, with an index of 48.7 in October, down 0.3 points from September. Rising import prices offset the boost from slumping fuel costs, according to a Shoko Chukin Bank survey. Manufacturers' sentiment remained unchanged, while service-sector morale worsened for two consecutive months due to rising raw material costs. The drop suggests broadly flat economic activity, according to economist Marcel Thieliant. This is a setback for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus strategy, which relies on boosting corporate spending.

site_title: Asia traders run for safety as US data fuels worries
summary: Weak US data dented investor confidence, sending Asian traders seeking safe investments ahead of Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan policy announcements. The US Conference Board reported a decline in consumer confidence and durable goods orders, while jobs growth was weaker than expected. Asian markets fell, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney down, while Tokyo rose. The yen strengthened against the dollar, and emerging market currencies declined. Despite Alibaba's better-than-expected sales, analysts warn the result was largely due to the company's sales strategy, not the Chinese consumer.

site_title: Japan investment bank Nomura's quarterly net falls after lawsuit settled
summary: Japan's investment bank Nomura Holdings Inc reported a quarterly net profit of 46.6 billion yen (US$387.14 million) in July-September, down from 52.9 billion yen in the previous year. The decline was attributed to costs incurred to settle a lawsuit with Italian bank Monte dei Paschi. This result fell short of analysts' expectations, with a mean estimate of 11.3 billion yen.

site_title: M&S website temporarily suspended after shoppers' details shown
summary: Marks & Spencer temporarily suspended its website on Tuesday after some customers complained they saw other people's contact details when logging in. The retailer stated that the issue was resolved and the site was restored by 2100 GMT. M&S said no financial data was exposed or extracted, and there was no third-party attack on the site. The website suspension occurred after the launch of the new "Sparks" members club and card scheme, which requires customers to register online.

site_title: Prices of completed condos in Singapore edge up 0.1% in September
summary: Prices of completed condominiums in Singapore rose 0.1% in September, following a 0.7% drop in August. Small units in non-Central Region and units in Districts 1-4 showed resilience with 0.4% and 0.3% price increases, respectively. However, units in Central Region and prime Districts 9-11 experienced a 0.4% drop. This marks a stabilization in prices after the previous month's decline, indicating a possible return to growth.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks inch down amid regional tensions; techs slide
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% to 8,694.31, led by a 0.2% decline in the electronics subindex, amid regional tensions and a US guided-missile destroyer's close approach to a Chinese island in the South China Sea. The US rebuke from Beijing followed the ship's passage. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.440 per US dollar.

site_title: Micro-mechanics posts 28.4% jump in Q1 profit on record quarterly sales
summary: Micro-mechanics Holdings reported a 28.4% increase in Q1 profit to S$3.6 million, driven by record quarterly sales of S$13.6 million, mainly due to strong sales of its semiconductor tooling business. Revenue growth was also driven by a 4.3% increase. The company expects to complete its state-of-the-art Machining facility by Q2 2016 to meet customer demands.

site_title: China punishes Shanghai airport for flight delays
summary: China's Shanghai Pudong airport suffered severe flight delays in August, with 51.16% of departures delayed. The Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) has punished the airport by denying it new routes. The airport's average delay was 75.6 minutes, with passengers often blaming air traffic control for the issues. This is not an isolated incident, as Shanghai's airport is one of the worst in China, and the phenomenon of constant flight delays is a common complaint among travelers. The CAAC has also penalized other airports, including Hangzhou and Tianjin, for similar delays.

site_title: Oil prices flat in Asia before supplies report, Fed decision
summary: Oil prices remained stable in Asia on Wednesday as investors awaited a US Energy Information Administration report on crude inventories and the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. Analysts expect a rise in US oil stockpiles, typically a sign of softer demand and lower prices. The report is expected to be released later Wednesday, with investors hoping for insight into the Fed's interest rate plans. The outcome of the Fed's decision will also influence oil prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices barely moved in Asia Wednesday as investors waited for a report on US crude inventories and the conclusion of a Federal Reserve policy meeting hoping for an idea about its plans for interest rates.

site_title: Internet freedom falls for fifth year in row: survey
summary: Global online freedom declined for the fifth consecutive year, with 32 countries experiencing declines in online freedom of expression, according to the "Freedom on the Net 2015" report by Freedom House. The survey found 61% of the world's population lives in countries with censorship, and 58% are subject to online censorship or imprisonment for sharing content. Governments are increasingly targeting online platforms, pressuring services like Google, Facebook, and Twitter to remove content.

site_title: Fed rate call could burst Hong Kong housing bubble
summary: A potential US interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve could burst Hong Kong's housing bubble, which has seen prices more than double in six years due to record-low borrowing costs. The expected rate hike has sparked debate on whether Hong Kong should maintain its decades-old peg with the US dollar, given its growing ties with China. Experts warn that a rate hike could send valuations plummeting, potentially leading to a market correction.

site_title: Thailand to seek patent protection for innovators through Singapore
summary: Thailand has appointed the Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) as an international search authority in patent examination, allowing businesses and entrepreneurs from over half of Asean to seek patent protection internationally through Singapore. The move is part of a memorandum of cooperation signed between Thailand and Singapore, which will provide expedited patent application services and cost savings of up to 75% on PCT filing fees. This partnership joins other global economies, including the US, Japan, and Mexico, in utilizing Singapore as an international authority for patent protection.

site_title: Lippo to shift Reits from Singapore to Indonesia: CEO
summary: Indonesian conglomerate Lippo Group plans to shift two Reits with 35 trillion rupiah in assets from Singapore to Indonesia to benefit from tax breaks. CEO James Riady said Indonesia has good potential for Reits due to government incentives. The two Singapore-listed Reits are Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust and First Real Estate Investment Trust, with a goal to boost asset value to over 100 trillion rupiah in three to four years.

site_title: Japan's quarterly retail sales rebound offers BOJ some relief
summary: Japan's retail sales rebounded 1.8% in the third quarter, driven by falling prices and gradual wage gains, suggesting the economy may narrowly escape recession despite China's slowdown. The data offers relief for the Bank of Japan, which faces pressure to expand stimulus, and could keep the economy on track for a recovery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 2.5 points to 1,694.64. The index saw 57.2 million lots traded worth RM20.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 85 to 81.

site_title: Indonesia failed to predict severity of El Nino weather: security chief
summary: Indonesia's state weather agency failed to predict the severity of El Nino weather this year, with the effects being worse than in 1997, according to security chief Luhut Panjaitan. Nineteen people have died fighting fires, and haze has affected Southeast Asia. The failure to predict the severity of the weather phenomenon has raised concerns about the government's response. The country is dealing with devastating wildfires and haze, with no clear end in sight.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's state weather agency (BMKG) failed to predict that the effects of the El Nino weather phenomenon this year would be worse than in 1997, the country's security chief said on Wednesday.

site_title: China steel industry expected to be forced into deeper output cuts
summary: China's steel industry is expected to make deeper output cuts due to shrinking demand, soaring losses, and tighter credit. Major steel producers suffered total losses of 28.12 billion yuan in the first three quarters of 2015. State-owned mills are shutting plants, with Bayi Steel and Hangzhou Iron & Steel already closing production bases. Analysts predict output cuts will accelerate in 2016, with iron ore prices expected to fall further. China's steel output dropped 2.1% in the first nine months, and the country has a surplus of around 300 million tonnes of annual crude steel capacity.

images.alt_text: Chinese steel mills are likely to be forced into making deeper cuts in output over the next few months, as shrinking demand, soaring losses and tighter credit undermine firms in the world's biggest producer, industry officials and analysts said.

site_title: Apple Store coming to Singapore: 5 things about the tech giant's retail chain
summary: Apple is set to open a store in Singapore, taking over the space currently occupied by Pure Fitness at Knightsbridge mall in Orchard Road. The 15,000 sq ft space will also be vacated by other tenants, including luxury watch boutique The Hour Glass and Abercombie & Fitch. No official opening date has been announced, but plans are expected to move forward next year. The new store will be Apple's first in Singapore, marking the company's expansion into the Southeast Asian market.

site_title: Oil dips as US stockpiles expected to rise again
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 78 cents to $43.20 per barrel, and Brent North Sea crude shedding 73 cents to $46.81 per barrel. The market expects another rise in US stockpiles due to mild weather, which limited demand, and comments from Saudi Arabia's oil minister implying the country won't intervene to stabilize prices. Analysts predict another increase in US commercial crude stockpiles, adding to the oversupply, and a proposed budget deal to sell off part of the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover on soft inflation, NZ stocks near record highs
summary: Australian shares rose almost 20 points after inflation data showed a 0.5% increase in the third quarter, below expectations and below the target, fueling speculation of a potential rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The S&P/ASX 200 index recovered from early losses, closing flat at 5,351.1 points. Healthcare stocks, including Ramsay Health Care and CSL, drove gains, while energy and natural resources sectors were weighed down by lower oil and iron ore prices.

site_title: South Korea's Sept department, discount store sales rebound
summary: South Korea's department store sales rebounded 2.8% in September, the strongest rise since May, driven by increased sales of produce and snapped up fresh produce for the Chuseok holiday. This partially recouped the 6.5% decline in August. Discount-store sales also rose 7.0% on-year, marking the first increase in three months. On a quarterly basis, department store sales fell 1.0% and 0.7% for discount stores, respectively.

site_title: Soft Australian inflation boosts rate cut hope
summary: Australian inflation rose 0.5% in the September quarter, lower than expected, boosting hopes for a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) reading follows a 1.5% annual increase, with underlying inflation at 2.15% year-on-year. Experts, including Shane Oliver at AMP Capital, say the data increases the likelihood of a 0.25% rate cut, with the RBA seen as comfortable with the decline in the Australian dollar and significant declines in commodity prices.

site_title: Singapore shares open 9.95 points lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 9.95 points lower at 3,042.58 on Wednesday, following a retreat on Wall Street. Despite this, the index saw a slight recovery with 66 gainers outpacing 58 losers. Notable movers included Noble Group, OCBC, and Thai Beverage, which traded lower, while Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust rose 1.01% after reporting a 12.6% increase in distribution per unit.

site_title: Alibaba defies China's slowdown amid mobile-spending shift
summary: Alibaba Group Holding defied China's economic slowdown by recording 32% sales growth to 22.2 billion yuan in the third quarter, driven by a shift to mobile spending and increased advertising opportunities. The company's mobile transactions generated 2.39% of revenue, up from 1.87% a year ago. Alibaba's shares rose 4.1% to US$79.44, with the company investing in online-to-offline services and expanding partnerships. Despite a slowing economy, Alibaba's non-manufacturing industries remain in growth mode, and the company is focused on internationalization and cloud computing expansion.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed as Aussie, Euro drop on price woes before Fed
summary: Asian stocks were mixed, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index little changed, as traders await Federal Reserve commentary amid signs of a global slowdown. The Aussie and Euro dropped on price woes, while oil traded near a two-month low. Despite a decline in the US business equipment orders, investors remain cautious, with some viewing the Fed's next move as uncertain. Meanwhile, Chinese e-commerce stocks rose after Alibaba's results beat estimates, and Apple's sales topped projections.

site_title: IBM nears deal to buy Weather Company's digital assets: source
summary: IBM is nearing a deal to buy the Weather Company's digital assets, valued at over $2 billion, according to a source. The deal, which excludes the Weather Channel, would include data, forecasting, and apps. Weather Company CEO David Kenny is expected to join IBM after the deal closes. The Weather Company, owned by private equity firms Blackstone and Bain Capital, declined to comment. IBM and the Weather Company had previously signed a deal in March to integrate weather data services with IBM's cloud services. A deal announcement could be made as soon as this week.

site_title: Temasek arm, Osim founder said to join Singapore chilli-crab IPO
summary: Temasek Holdings' arm and Osim International chairman Ron Sim are investing in Jumbo Group's initial public offering (IPO), which aims to raise S$40 million. Jumbo Group, a Singapore-based restaurant operator, plans to use the funds to open new outlets in China and Singapore. The IPO, which starts taking orders on Thursday, will see shares sold at a fixed price of 25 Singapore cents apiece. This would be the largest IPO in Singapore this year, surpassing the US$117 million raised by nine other offerings.

site_title: US Senate passes cybersecurity bill over tech objections
summary: The US Senate passed a cybersecurity bill, the Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act, with a 74-21 vote, sending it to the House of Representatives for reconciliation. The bill aims to facilitate sharing of attack threats between the government and private sector, but critics say it opens the door to greater surveillance. Tech giants and privacy activists oppose the bill, citing concerns over personal information sharing with the FBI and NSA. The bill's passage comes after a similar bill was approved by the House earlier this year.

site_title: Indonesians take fight against haze into their own hands
summary: Indonesians are taking matters into their own hands to combat the country's worst haze crisis, as the government struggles to control thousands of fires burning in Borneo and Sumatra. Civilians are using makeshift tools and limited resources to fight the blazes, despite the government's water-bombing raids and warship deployments. Residents are frustrated with the lack of action and are calling for those responsible to be punished, with some blaming major corporations and local farmers. Conservation groups and scientists are also weighing in on the cause of the fires, with some suggesting that medium-scale plantation owners may have asked farmers to burn the land on their behalf.

site_title: SGX derivatives market resumes normal operations after tech glitch overnight
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) derivatives market resumed normal operations after a temporary suspension due to a tech glitch overnight. The market opened on Wednesday as scheduled at 7:30am after a pre-open at 11pm, with trading commencing at 11:15pm and closing normally. This is not the first time the platform was disrupted by a technical issue, following a similar glitch in August that halted trading for nearly two hours.

site_title: Oxley's bonds under placement see four times subscription
summary: Oxley Holdings' maiden four-year retail bond offering of up to S$125 million has seen a four-time subscription rate, with S$50 million of bonds reallocated to the placement. The placement received valid applications for S$100 million in aggregate principal value of bonds, exceeding initial expectations. The strong interest indicates investor confidence in Oxley's business strategies and growth potential, with the company viewing the retail bond offering as a step towards diversifying its investor base and developing the Singapore bond market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.27% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.27% on October 28, 2015, despite a weak lead from Wall Street, as investors await earnings from major Japanese companies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index advanced 49.90 points to 18,826.94.

site_title: Slower eurozone inflation rise could mean ECB deposit rate cut: Coeure
summary: European Central Bank executive board member Benoit Coeure suggests the ECB may lower its deposit rate further if eurozone inflation rises back to target more slowly than expected. This could happen if inflation returns to 2% in a more sluggish manner, increasing real interest rates. The ECB has already lowered its deposit rate to -0.2% and is considering further cuts, with markets pricing in a potential reduction to -0.3% in December.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong: Stocks down in opening exchanges
summary: Stocks in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Shenzhen declined in early trading on October 28, 2015, following a negative lead from Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.50%, the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.66%, and the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong dipped 0.30%. Weak US data raised concerns about the US economy, contributing to the market downturn.

site_title: OCBC's Q3 net profit down 27%, core net profit up 7%
summary: OCBC Group reported a net profit of S$902 million for Q3 2015, down 27% from the previous year, due to a one-off gain in 2014. Excluding the gain, core net profit increased 7% year-over-year. Banking operations drove growth, while insurance contributions declined. The group's non-performing loans ratio rose to 0.9%, but its capital adequacy ratio remained well above regulatory minima. OCBC's CEO, Samuel Tsien, stated the group will maintain a strong capital position and focus on prudent cost management as it grows its franchise.

site_title: Olam secures US$1 billion in loan facility
summary: Olam International has secured a US$1 billion loan facility, consisting of a US$850 million revolving credit and a US$150 million five-year term loan, to refinance debt and meet working capital needs. The loan is part of Olam's proactive capital management strategy to diversify its debt portfolio. The lead arrangers include major banks such as ANZ, HSBC, and JPMorgan Chase. This comes after Olam's acquisition of ADM's global cocoa business in October 2015.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, CCT, OSIM, MGCCT
summary: Singapore stocks await a catalyst as investors await a US Federal Reserve meeting. OCBC Group posted a 27% lower net profit of S$902 million for the third quarter, driven by a 25% increase in banking earnings. OSIM International reported a 62% slump in net profit to S$6.2 million, while CCT and MGCCT delivered positive results with distribution per unit rises. CCT's distribution per unit rose 2.4% to 2.14 Singapore cents, while MGCCT's rose 12.6% to 1.808 Singapore cents.

site_title: Goldman Sachs spins out internal technology in Synchronoss deal
summary: Goldman Sachs is selling its internal technology, including a mobile application management framework and a set of programs like email and a browser, to Synchronoss Technologies. The deal, valued by Goldman Sachs, will allow Synchronoss to offer a product to other companies, while Goldman Sachs will retain a stake and be a customer. The technology was developed for Goldman Sachs' 12,000 employees and will compete with Bloomberg's electronic messaging system. The deal is part of Goldman Sachs' strategy to spin out internal technology for broader use and potential revenue.

site_title: Lure of gold draws hundreds to Bulgaria's rivers
summary: Hundreds of people in Bulgaria's Kazanlak region are searching for gold in the Tundzha river, 2,000 years after the ancient Thracians mined the area. Dozens of prospectors, including a 59-year-old couple, sift through gravel and stones in hopes of striking it rich. The site is believed to be rich in gold, with the Thracians reportedly choosing it as their capital. While some may be driven by the lure of easy wealth, others are drawn to the historical significance of the site and the chance to follow in the footsteps of the ancient civilization.

images.alt_text: More than 2,000 years after the ancient Thracians crafted their exquisite jewelry from gold deposits in Bulgaria, hundreds are combing its rivers again in the hope of striking it rich in the EU's poorest country.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall awaiting Fed rate decision
summary: European stocks fell on Tuesday as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, with the UK's FTSE 100 index shedding 0.81% and the eurozone's CAC 40 index falling 1.02%. The Fed is expected to delay raising borrowing costs, and investors are hoping for more guidance on its timetable. Sluggish US economic data, including a decline in durable goods orders, also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Developing world champion World Bank to aid Greece
summary: The World Bank's International Finance Corporation (IFC) is planning to provide financial aid to Greece through private-sector engagement, stepping outside its traditional role. The IFC aims to boost investors' confidence in the country, which has been struggling with a debt crisis since 2010. This move is seen as a temporary engagement, following Greece's three-year, 86 billion euro bailout with the European Union. The IFC will lend money to companies to support private-sector development projects, such as clean energy and infrastructure, in an effort to jump-start investment in the country.

images.alt_text: People are silhouetted under a fluttering Greek national flag atop the archaeological site of the Athens Acropolis, Greece in this Mar 20, 2015 file photo.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust posts 2.4% rise in Q3 DPU
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 2.4% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.14 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2015, driven by higher rents. Gross revenue rose 2.9% to S$68.35 million, with net property income increasing 1.5% to S$52.67 million. CCT signed about 226,000 square feet of new leases and renewals, with portfolio occupancy at 96.4%. The company aims to retain strategic tenants and attract new ones to its portfolio, prioritizing lease expiry profiles.

site_title: Ford Motor 3rd quarter profit misses estimate, shares drop
summary: Ford Motor Co reported a 75% increase in quarterly profit to $1.9 billion, driven by record sales in North America. However, the company's shares fell 5% after missing Wall Street estimates due to higher taxes. Ford plans to launch a new sales promotion, the "Friends and Neighbors" program, to boost sales in the last two months of the year. The company reaffirmed its full-year profit forecast of $8.5-9.5 billion and remains optimistic about China's market.

site_title: Australia's NAB to sell insurance stake to Nippon Life, divest British bank
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) announced the sale of an 80% stake in its insurance business to Japan's Nippon Life for $1.7 billion. The move aims to bolster NAB's balance sheet and meet tougher regulatory requirements. Additionally, NAB plans to divest its troubled British asset Clydesdale Bank, with 75% to be spun off to shareholders and 25% sold through an initial public offering. The bank reported a 19.7% lift in annual net profit to $6.34 billion.

site_title: World Bank to create its first infrastructure hub in Singapore
summary: The World Bank is expanding its Singapore office to create its first Infrastructure and Urban Development Hub, employing over 200 people from the World Bank and its private sector arms. The hub will provide services globally, focusing on energy, transport, and urban development, and will leverage Singapore's position in global capital markets. The move aims to support emerging and developing economies, particularly in East Asia, where the center of global economic activity is gravitating towards. The hub will also include expanded investment and advisory programs.

site_title: SingPost awards Shimizu S$150 million contract to upgrade SingPost Centre
summary: SingPost has awarded Japan's Shimizu Corporation a S$150 million contract to upgrade its flagship SingPost Centre in Singapore. The redevelopment will feature a new retail mall with a cinema hall and a food court, and is expected to be completed by mid-2017. The project aligns with SingPost's strategy to maximize returns to shareholders by realizing the full potential of its assets, and is funded solely by internal funds and borrowings. The redevelopment is also in line with the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Masterplan 2008 to develop the area into a suburban commercial node.

images.alt_text: Singapore Post has appointed Japan's Shimizu Corporation as the main contractor to undertake the redevelopment and office works at its flagship SingPost Centre for about S$150 million.

site_title: Japan's carmakers proceed with caution on self-driving cars
summary: Japan's major automakers, including Nissan, Honda, and Toyota, are proceeding with caution on self-driving cars, with a predicted timeline of 2025 for full deployment. Unlike companies like Tesla and Google, which aim to have fully autonomous vehicles on the road by 2020, Japan's carmakers prefer to wait for technology to be 100% complete and test it through manual settings before introducing it to the public. This cautious approach is driven by concerns over liability and the need for practicality in the real world, with the government aiming to showcase autonomous driving technology at the 2020 Tokyo Olympic Games.

site_title: Emerging markets see first weekly inflows since June: IIF
summary: Foreign investors injected $13.9 billion into emerging markets in October, the first weekly inflows since June, driven by expectations of a delayed US interest rate hike. Most of the funds went to Asia, with $9 billion invested in the region. This marked a rebound from previous months and was influenced by the Fed's decision to wait for further evidence of a global economic slowdown.

site_title: House votes decisively to revive US Export-Import Bank
summary: The US House of Representatives voted to revive the Export-Import Bank, with a majority of Republicans supporting the measure. The 81-year-old bank provides favourable financing to US firms selling products abroad and protects them against foreign buyer defaults. The reauthorisation, if approved by the Senate and signed by President Barack Obama, would mark a significant victory for the bank after it lapsed months ago. The move is seen as a blow to Republicans who had vilified the bank.

site_title: ABN Amro confirms IPO before year-end
summary: ABN Amro, the Netherlands' third-largest bank, confirmed plans to sell its first state-owned shares in an initial public offering (IPO) later this year, seven years after a multi-billion euro bailout during the 2008 banking crisis. The government will sell around 20-30% of the bank, valued at around 15 billion euros, with approvals received from the Dutch parliament, central bank, and European Central Bank. The IPO marks an important step towards the bank's new future, with the sale expected to be launched in Q4 2015.

site_title: US: Stocks fall; Rite Aid, Starwood surge on takeover talk
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average declining 41.62 points (0.24%) to 17,581.43, while the S&P 500 dipped 5.29 (0.26%) to 2,065.89. Despite a surge in Rite Aid and Starwood shares due to potential takeover bids, economic data showed a decline in consumer confidence and durable goods orders. The Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates on Wednesday due to the mixed economic data.

site_title: China's 'new economy' stock gains an echo of dotcom boom: Mobius
summary: MARKET EXPERT MARK MOBIUS PREDICTS CHINA'S 'NEW ECONOMY' SECTORS WILL DRIVE GROWTH, BUT WARNS INVESTORS ARE ALREADY OVERWEIGHT. The chairman of Franklin Templeton's emerging-markets group believes China's push into technology and consumer industries will lead to sustainable expansion, but notes that many stock valuations already reflect a successful transition, making it challenging for equity investors to benefit. The ChiNext index, a proxy for new economy companies, is three times more expensive than the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index after a 25% surge in the past month.

images.alt_text: "We are facing a little bit of what we faced in 2000 . . . of some people getting too excited," said Mr Mobius.

site_title: New Airbus-SIA training centre set to open in Q1 2016
summary: Singapore Airlines and Airbus are set to open a new training centre in Q1 2016, the Airbus Asia Training Centre (AATC), in Seletar Aerospace Park. The 9,250 sqm facility will be the fourth Airbus flight training centre globally, offering simulator bays, classroom facilities, and office space. The centre aims to cater to the growing demand in Asia, which is expected to account for 40% of global demand in the next 20 years. Training costs for entry pilots can range from $90,000 to $50,000, depending on experience, with some courses lasting two-and-a-half months.

site_title: A smashing good time
summary: Four-time Grand Slam champion Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario, 43, sparred with six tennis fans at the Singapore Sports Hub, sharing tips and playing a game with them. Sanchez-Vicario teamed up with Tracy Austin to face Martina Navratilova and Marion Bartoli in her Legends Classic match, which will continue on Wednesday.

site_title: Come back and build tech giants, French firms tell overseas citizens
summary: France Inc is seeking to attract French expatriates to return and start new businesses, citing the country's strong engineering and math talent. Startups like Blablacar and Sigfox are touring the US and Europe to woo candidates, with support from luxury conglomerate LVMH. The "ReviensLeon" campaign aims to counter the perception that France is good for study but bad for business, as the country faces challenges in portraying a business-friendly image amid protests and labor law reforms.

site_title: Car owners can modify vehicle software: US copyright authorities
