summary: The US Copyright Office has issued new guidelines stating that car owners and security experts can modify vehicle software without incurring copyright liability. This decision was made in response to fair use advocates, who argued that vehicle owners have the right to alter software. Automakers such as General Motors and Deere & Co opposed the rules, suggesting that owners visit authorized repair shops for modifications. The Library of Congress agreed with fair use advocates, paving the way for car owners to modify their vehicles' software without copyright infringement concerns.

images.alt_text: Car owners and security experts can tinker with automobile software without incurring some US copyright liability, according to new guidelines issued this month that had been opposed by the auto industry.

site_title: Tokyo museum undergoes facelift
summary: The National Museum of Western Art in Tokyo's Ueno Park has closed its exhibition rooms for renovations until March 2016. The museum aims to boost momentum for UNESCO's World Heritage Committee deliberations in July 2016, which could determine its registration as a world cultural heritage site. The closure coincides with a critical period for the museum's bid, but its impact on the registration process remains uncertain.

site_title: Twitter knocked again on slow user growth
summary: Twitter shares plummeted 13% after the company reported a slim growth in its user base and a disappointing revenue outlook. The social network reported 320 million monthly active users, a 11% increase from last year, and $569 million in revenue, up 58% year-over-year. Despite this, the outlook for the coming quarter was lower than expected, and the company's shares fell below their 2013 debut price of $26. Twitter's new CEO, Jack Dorsey, attributed the growth to simplified services and better communication of the platform's value, but acknowledged the challenges in expanding the user base.

images.alt_text: Twitter shares tumbled on Tuesday after the struggling messaging platform reported only slim growth in its user base and a disappointing revenue outlook.

site_title: Keppel O&M, SembMarine set to make LNG shipbuilding foray
summary: Keppel O&M and SembMarine are poised to enter the shipbuilding market for liquefied natural gas (LNG) vessels, driven by increasing demand for small-scale LNG activity in Southeast Asia and globally. Indonesia is set to lead the way, with plans to roll out tenders for miniaturized gas-to-power solutions to meet President Joko Widodo's 35 gigawatt electricity plan. Singapore yards, including Keppel O&M and SembMarine, are well-positioned to benefit from this growth, with established track records and technological competencies.

site_title: Singapore still tops for doing business: World Bank
summary: Singapore remains the easiest place to do business, holding its top ranking from last year, according to the World Bank's "Doing Business 2016" report. New Zealand took second place, followed by Denmark and South Korea. The report highlights improvements in regulatory frameworks in 122 economies, with 85 developing countries implementing 169 reforms. China slipped to 84th place, while Russia moved up to 51st. The World Bank aims to encourage regulation that contributes to economic growth and prosperity through its annual report card.

images.alt_text: Singapore remains the easiest place to do business, while developing countries stepped up their pace of business-friendly reforms in the past year, according to a World Bank report published on Tuesday.

site_title: Consumer confidence down; Sept business equipment orders fall
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 97.6 in October, down from 102.6 in September, according to The Conference Board. Business equipment orders declined 0.3% in September, and durable goods orders fell 1.2%. The decline is attributed to global uncertainty and weaker overseas sales. Corporate investment is expected to be slow, and the US economy may not experience a strong growth boost until inventories are worked off and foreign economies improve.

site_title: Yen higher, dollar mixed as Fed meets
summary: The Japanese yen strengthened against the dollar and euro as the Federal Reserve began a two-day meeting, expected to delay a rate hike due to signs of slower US economic activity. Consumer confidence fell and durable goods orders declined for the second straight month in September. The dollar edged up to $1.1041 per euro from $1.1059 late Monday, while the yen reached 120.48 and 133.02 against the dollar and euro, respectively. Market expectations suggest a rate hike will not occur before March, with the Fed expected to keep its options open on rates this year.

site_title: Airbnb fights move to curb San Francisco business
summary: Airbnb is fighting a ballot measure in San Francisco that would restrict short-term rentals to 75 days a year. The measure, known as Proposition F, aims to curb the use of San Francisco apartments for commercial purposes and increase affordable housing. Airbnb has donated millions to defeat the measure, while supporters argue it removes affordable housing from the market. The company claims that home-sharing allows middle-class families to make ends meet and stay in the city, generating over $460 million in economic activity. The measure is part of a growing trend to restrict short-term home rentals nationwide.

site_title: Japan opens up its US$67b retail electricity market
summary: Japan has opened its $67 billion retail electricity market, with over 750 applicants, including rice farmers and companies like SoftBank, signing up to compete with 10 regional monopolies. The move aims to reduce costs and increase grid reliability for residential consumers. Analysts predict increased competition may drive down retail electricity costs by 15% and intensify competition in areas like Tokyo and Osaka. Existing companies with customers are expected to fare best under new rules, with Tokyo Electric Power and Tokyo Gas Co. planning to enter the power business.

site_title: Oaktree's Marks says China a 'teenager' with best years ahead
summary: Oaktree Capital Group's Howard Marks sees China as a promising investment opportunity due to its low prices and weak sentiment following the yuan's surprise devaluation in August. Marks likened China to a "teenager" with its best years ahead, citing an above-average future growth potential. This sentiment comes as junk and distressed debt in developing markets posted their biggest quarterly declines for 2015, making China more appealing as an investment proposition. Marks' firm dedicates over a quarter of its $100 billion assets to distressed-debt investing.

site_title: Been hacked? It's your fault!
summary: Talk Talk's hacking incident has sparked criticism that the company is equally culpable for not securing its systems. The UK's North P&I Club warns that shipping companies face penalties for inadequate cyber security measures, with the US Coast Guard's new cyber strategy set to lead to new regulations. The club advises shipowners to establish a cyber risk management program, including continuous assessment and response planning. Meanwhile, Century Marine Services warns of the threat of sophisticated cyber fraud, highlighting the need for companies to protect themselves from hackers and cloners alike.

site_title: Once bitten, power producers take steps to beat winter's freeze
summary: US power producers have taken steps to prepare for winter's freeze, following the 2013-2014 polar vortex that caused widespread outages and shortages. Record-high natural gas inventories, with estimates of 3.856 trillion cubic feet, are expected to ease supply concerns. Utilities have enhanced coordination with gas markets and improved forecasts, and some power plants have taken steps to prepare for extreme cold, such as installing thermometers and stockpiling alternative fuels. Grid operators are also providing gas-burn forecasts to improve communication with gas utilities.

site_title: Republicans, White House reach deal on debt extension to 2017
summary: US President Barack Obama and top lawmakers from both parties reached a deal to extend US borrowing authority until March 2017, averting a debt default and reducing government shutdown chances. The two-year budget agreement includes a $80 billion spending increase, primarily paid for by hedge funds paying full taxes and cutting wasteful programs. The deal maintains Social Security and Medicare funding, but raises defense spending by over $7 billion per year. The agreement must still be finalized and approved by Congress before it takes effect.

site_title: Australia's bank earnings return to earth after record run
summary: Australia's major banks, including ANZ, National Australia Bank, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, and Westpac, are expected to post record profits despite slower earnings growth due to tighter capital rules and a cooling economy. Lending growth is easing, and bad debt charges are set to rise. Dividend yields of over 5% are attractive to investors, who see value in the banks' shares. The four lenders have together raised over A$20 billion in capital since May to meet tougher requirements, and are expected to continue returning profits to shareholders.

site_title: 48 million iPhones boost Apple profits
summary: Apple reported a record-breaking fiscal year with profits rising 31% to $11.1 billion and revenues increasing 22% to $51.5 billion, driven by strong iPhone sales. The company delivered 48 million iPhones, a 22% increase from last year, and sold an all-time record 5.7 million Macs. Apple Watch revenue was not disclosed, but the company expects to expand Apple Pay to three new markets in 2016. The company's fiscal year ended with a record $53.4 billion profit and $233.7 billion in revenue.

site_title: JPMorgan targets new branches in India for wholesale banking
summary: JPMorgan Chase is seeking branch licenses in India to bolster its wholesale banking operations, targeting corporate clients in cash management, foreign-currency payments, and trade finance. The bank is in talks with the Reserve Bank of India to open new outlets in addition to its existing wholesale branch in Mumbai. JPMorgan aims to expand its services to large domestic companies, multinationals, and government-backed institutions active in cross-border transactions. The bank's expansion will need to comply with RBI rules requiring foreign banks to extend a certain percentage of their lending to the priority sector.

site_title: MAS: Housing sector has no strong link to jobs and business cycles
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has found that the housing market in Singapore has no strong link to business cycles and the domestic labor market. The MAS report, released in October 2015, analyzed nine growth recession episodes in Singapore's economy, concluding that residential investment's contribution to GDP growth was "modest or countercyclical." The MAS also noted that the construction workforce can adjust flexibly to changes in demand, limiting the impact of housing market fluctuations on unemployment.

site_title: Zuckerberg's speech hints at China hopes
summary: Mark Zuckerberg's speech at Tsinghua University in Beijing hinted at Facebook's hopes to expand into China, despite the country's blocked social media sites. Zuckerberg praised China's history and traditional wisdom, citing innovation and the importance of connecting people. He emphasized Facebook's strategy of putting users first, similar to Chinese companies Alibaba and Xiaomi. Zuckerberg acknowledged the challenges of censorship but expressed his ambition to connect everyone worldwide. His speech was seen as a calculated move to appeal to Chinese users, and its implications include the possibility of Facebook cooperating with the Chinese government or corporate partners to censor posts.

site_title: EU membership will help UK stability
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney says EU membership is good for the UK's economic dynamism but creates challenges for financial stability. The UK's exposure to EU problems, such as the euro crisis, has affected its economy, but EU membership also provides opportunities for the UK to make its economy steadier. The EU can act as a shock absorber, diluting the effect of domestic shocks and providing alternative sources of business and labour. To fully benefit from EU membership, the UK must improve financial regulation and the single market's shock-absorbing capacity, Carney concludes.

site_title: Hurricane Patricia thrashes Mexico's luxury resorts
summary: Hurricane Patricia recently ravaged luxury resorts in Mexico's Costa Careyes, a private beach destination favored by A-list stars. The storm, packing 266 kph winds, destroyed homes and properties, including villas that can rent for up to $12,000 a night. Despite the damage, no one was killed, and the impact was largely contained due to the storm's speed and mountainous terrain. Local residents, however, suffered significant losses, with one resident saying he will try to rebuild his home with materials from the storm debris.

site_title: MAS sees modest pass-through of rising costs to inflation
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, predicts that domestic cost increases will lead to modest pass-through to inflation, with consumers not bearing the brunt. Despite higher wages and rising business costs, tepid global demand and low oil prices will deter price increases. MAS expects headline CPI inflation to decrease 0.5% this year and range between -0.5 and 0.5% next year, while core inflation is expected to rise to 0.5-1.5% next year. The effects of local budgetary measures and lower global oil prices are temporary and will wear off next year.

site_title: M'sia e-recruitment down for sixth straight month
summary: Malaysia's online recruitment activity declined by a fourth in September, marking the sixth consecutive month of decline. The drop underscores uncertainties in the job market due to a softening economy and slowing consumer demand. None of the nine sectors monitored by Monster.com experienced positive growth, highlighting the challenges faced by the country's job market.

site_title: Primus, Jereh partner to market systems for gas to liquid projects
summary: Primus Energy and Jereh have partnered to market systems for gas to liquid (GTL) projects using Primus' proprietary STG+ process technology. The technology can transform natural gas into liquid products such as petroleum and methanol, with a feed gas flow rate as low as four million cubic feet per day. The partnership will jointly market and deploy systems for lump-sum, turnkey delivery of GTL systems, combining Primus' technology with Jereh's engineering and fabrication expertise.

site_title: Uber of trucks gets funding from A-list investors
summary: Convoy, a Seattle-based startup, has raised $2.5 million in early financing from A-list investors, including Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, Salesforce.com's Marc Benioff, and eBay founder Pierre Omidyar. The company is betting on disrupting the $749 billion US trucking market with its mobile technology platform, which connects drivers and customers. Convoy, which focuses on short-haul trucking, plans to expand to other areas in the next year and may raise more money. Founder Dan Lewis believes trucking is an outdated industry ripe for innovation, and Convoy aims to compete with middlemen brokers by providing instant price quotes and tracking drivers.

site_title: MGCCT's Q2 DPU up 13% despite weak HK retail market
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 13% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.808 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from newly acquired Sandhill Plaza and rent increases at Festival Walk and Gateway Plaza. Gross revenue rose 25.4% to S$84.6 million, with net property income increasing 26%. The trust's occupancy rates remained high, with 100% occupancy at Sandhill Plaza and 96.3% at Gateway Plaza.

site_title: Sharapova trounces Halep as semis beckon
summary: Maria Sharapova dominated Simona Halep 6-4, 6-4 in the WTA Finals, securing her spot in the semi-finals. The Russian's five-star performance showcased her confidence and powerful shots, returning almost everything Halep could throw at her. Sharapova's win gives her a comfortable lead in the Red Group, with one more round robin match to navigate. The result sets up a potential showdown with US Open champion Flavia Pennetta in the next round.

images.alt_text: A jubilant Maria Sharapova after she beat Romania's Simona Halep during the women's singles round robin tennis match at the WTA Finals at the Singapore Indoor Stadium on Tuesday.

site_title: S'pore to upgrade to new production frontier
summary: Singapore is shifting towards a knowledge-based economy powered by technology and innovation, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The country aims to become a supplier of high-tech and high-value goods and services, driven by intellectual capital and skilled workers with technical expertise in industries like technology, engineering, and math. MAS emphasizes the need for workers to master multi-disciplinary skills and highlights the importance of intellectual property, with Singapore's share increasing to over 20% of total real capital stock since 1990.

site_title: Ping An, partner, in US property fund
summary: Ping An Insurance Group Company of China has formed a US$600 million US property fund with Blumberg Investment Partners to invest in logistics assets across the US. The companies plan to invest an additional US$400 million. This move follows a growing trend of cash-rich Chinese insurers investing in Western markets, particularly in real estate. Last October, Anbang Insurance Group Co acquired the Waldorf Astoria New York hotel for US$1.95 billion, further indicating the trend.

site_title: China industry core earnings fall in Sept; Q3 unemployment stable
summary: China's industrial companies reported a 0.1% decline in profits in September, following a record 8.8% drop in August. Core business revenues fell 0.5% in the first nine months of the year, the first time in "many years." The National Bureau of Statistics attributed the decline to currency fluctuations. Despite a stable 4.05% unemployment rate, economists warn that the slowdown could lead to financial distress in heavily indebted manufacturing firms and potentially cascade into the banking system.

site_title: Airlines stepping up efforts to tackle cyber security risks
summary: Airlines are stepping up efforts to combat cyber security risks, following a security researcher's claim in April that he hacked into flight controls via an underseat entertainment unit. Industry representatives are sharing more information to improve efficiency and security, but this also increases vulnerabilities. A team is working on a declaration on cyber security, which will be presented to the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) next September, with the goal of securing the aviation industry's defences against threats from hackers and those seeking to exploit IT systems.

site_title: OSIM Q3 earnings dive 62%
summary: OSIM International reported its worst Q3 earnings since 2009, with a 62% drop in net profit to S$6.2 million. Revenue fell 11% to S$141.6 million, attributed to haze, ringgit weakness, and soft consumer sentiment in key markets. The company attributed the decline to a 20-30% drop in retail sales across the board, and will focus on effectively running its outlets rather than cutting costs. Despite the challenges, OSIM's dominant brand enabled the company to maintain a stable gross margin.

site_title: Foreign bank card firms fear tough China regulatory regime
summary: China is considering imposing strict conditions on foreign bank card providers, potentially forcing them to partner with local companies and governments. This could limit their control and returns in the country's $7 trillion card payments market. Industry sources and US business lobbies are concerned about the move, which may breach a 2012 WTO ruling. The new conditions could lead to foreign companies operating through a domestic consortium, reducing their influence in the market.

images.alt_text: Currently, China requires all foreign card companies to use UnionPay's network when accepting yuan payments, effectively giving it a cut of every credit or debit card transaction.

site_title: Dementia incurs greatest healthcare costs
summary: A study of patients on Medicare found that dementia had the highest healthcare costs in the last five years of life, with an average total cost of $287,038. This is significantly higher than the costs for patients with heart disease ($175,136) and cancer ($173,383). The main reason for this is that dementia patients require caregivers for daily activities, which are not covered by Medicare, resulting in an average out-of-pocket cost of $61,522, nearly 80% higher than for patients with heart disease or cancer.

site_title: TPP may lose out in GOP presidential nomination fight
summary: US Republicans are facing a challenging presidential nomination fight with a large field of contenders, including Donald Trump. Despite Trump's lead in some national polls, his divisive stance and incoherent positions on key international issues, such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, may harm his chances of winning the nomination. Establishment Republicans are concerned that Trump's anti-free trade rhetoric could make it difficult for Republican senators to support the treaty, potentially benefiting Democrats in the general election. A sustained Trump insurgency may also make it harder to re-unify the party, potentially leading to a divisive and costly nomination contest.

site_title: Dow futures weakness drags STI down
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% to 3,052.53 points, weighed down by weakness in US Dow futures, despite slight gains in Hong Kong and China. Addvalue Tech and Raffles Medical were actively traded, with Addvalue Tech falling S$0.005 to S$0.068 after signing a memorandum of understanding with a China government party. Experts expect the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) to raise interest rates by 3.5-4% in the current cycle, citing hawkish FOMC members.

site_title: BP to undergo more spending cuts, asset sales
summary: BP announces a third round of spending cuts and asset sales, totaling $3-5 billion, to tackle low oil prices. The company's capital spending for 2015 is reduced to $19 billion, down from $24-$26 billion, and is expected to fall to $17-19 billion annually until 2017. BP also plans to increase restructuring costs by $1 billion, bringing the total to $2.5 billion, and has reduced operating costs by $3 billion. The company maintains its dividend and expects to balance its cash flow by 2017 based on an oil price of $60 a barrel.

site_title: Swedish miner Boliden rallies thanks to its smelters
summary: Boliden AB, a Swedish copper and zinc miner, has seen its stock rally 32% this year, outperforming the Bloomberg World Mining Index, despite a 22% decline in the industry. The company's smelters have benefited from lower ore prices and a stronger dollar, with smelting profits improving and earnings more than doubling in the first nine months of the year. CEO Lennart Evrell attributes Boliden's success to its diversified assets, with smelting and mining operations in different cycles.

site_title: What can Singapore do about the haze?
summary: Singapore can adapt to the haze in the meantime, rather than focusing on tackling the root problem of the burning. Behavioral economics can be used to change consumers' behavior, and a boycott of haze-linked products could be employed. However, the effectiveness of such measures is uncertain, and pressures levied against Indonesian goods may result in trade retaliation. The government can also improve information dissemination and impose measures such as mandatory shutdowns of outdoor sports facilities to reduce haze-related illnesses and loss of productivity. A more comprehensive approach involving multiple disciplines is needed to understand the haze problem and estimate its damage costs.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase says it is building a rival to Apple Pay
summary: JPMorgan Chase is launching Chase Pay, a mobile payment service rivaling Apple Pay, allowing consumers to pay retailers using their smartphones in stores. The bank has secured the endorsement of major retailers, including Walmart and Best Buy, and promises superior security. Chase Pay will initially work with 94 million existing Chase credit, debit, and prepaid cards and will be available on both Apple and Android-based phones. The bank aims to cut fees for Chase Pay transactions and offer discounts to merchants, hoping to gain market share in the mobile payments market.

images.alt_text: China has seen nearly US$1 trillion in capital leave the nation since the second quarter of 2014, and according to analysts at JPMorgan Chase & Co, the sky's the limit for outflows going forward.

site_title: China online travel firm Ctrip in tie-up with rival Qunar
summary: Chinese online travel firm Ctrip.com International Ltd has formed a tie-up with rival Qunar Cayman Islands Ltd and backer Baidu Inc through a share swap valued at $3.4 billion. The deal aims to tap into the growing number of Chinese travelers heading overseas.

site_title: Tyson share price tumbles after JPMorgan rating cut, WHO cancer judgement
summary: Tyson Foods Inc, the largest US meat producer, dropped 4.9% to $45.10 after JPMorgan Chase & Co downgraded its rating on the stock, citing weak earnings. The World Health Organization (WHO) also stated that consuming processed meat is a cancer hazard, further impacting the stock.

site_title: Yen rises in Asia ahead of BOJ meeting
summary: The yen rose in Asia ahead of the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) policy meeting on Friday, amid expectations that the US Federal Reserve will delay an interest rate hike until early next year. The Japanese economy's struggles and tepid inflation are putting pressure on the BOJ to increase its bond-buying stimulus. China's interest rate cut and European Central Bank's hints of wider stimulus also contributed to the yen's rise. The BOJ meeting is expected to be closely watched for its impact on the yen's value.

site_title: The fastest growing new ETF costs more than a mutual fund
summary: The First Trust Dorsey Wright Focus 5 ETF (FV) has attracted $4.2 billion in assets in less than two years, despite a 0.94% annual fee, the highest among over 500 launched ETFs. Investors are drawn to the ETF's convenience, offering a sector rotation strategy that allows for tax-efficient and rules-based investing. The underlying sector ETFs have a 0.65% total cost, with the remaining fees covering strategy licensing, operations, and profit for First Trust. This contradicts conventional wisdom that investors prefer low-cost ETFs.

site_title: Infrastructure financing has challenges, and opportunities
summary: The World Bank-Singapore Infrastructure Finance Summit highlighted the challenges of financing infrastructure development in Asia, with a need for $8 trillion in investment by 2020. Existing financial institutions, including governments and multilateral banks, cannot meet this demand, and commercial banks are hesitant due to capital requirements. To address this, Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for capital markets and institutional investors, such as pension funds and sovereign wealth funds, to play a larger role in infrastructure financing, with currently less than 0.2% of global assets allocated to infrastructure investment.

site_title: 'One wife, many husbands' solution to correct China's gender imbalance
summary: China's gender imbalance, resulting in an estimated 30 million bachelors by 2020, may be addressed by allowing polyandry, or marriage between two men, according to economics professor Xie Zuoshi. This solution aims to correct the issue of single men, particularly poor ones who cannot afford a wife and are condemned to living without offspring. The idea is to increase the value of women by having multiple men share the same partner, similar to a practice in some remote, impoverished areas where brothers marry the same woman to pool resources and avoid property disputes.

site_title: Viva Q3 income up but DPS dips on bigger unit base
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) reported a 15.1% year-on-year rise to S$11.6 million in third-quarter distributable income, driven by secured and retained tenants, and proactive portfolio strengthening. However, the distribution per stapled security (DPS) dipped 2.4% due to an enlarged unit base. Gross revenue increased 23.1% year-on-year to S$18.4 million, with the annualized DPS translating to an annualized yield of 8.9%. VIT has secured 200,000 sq ft of renewals and 98,000 sq ft of new leases, and has embarked on an asset enhancement initiative at Technopark@Chai Chee.

site_title: Asia investors more worried about returns than Fed rate hike: Pimco
summary: Asia investors are prioritizing returns over potential US interest rate hikes, according to Pimco's annual survey. 80% plan to boost investments in European and Japanese stocks, while 70% seek more in liquid alternative investments. This shift reflects growing concerns about global growth slowing.

site_title: SGX drops private notification plan for significant deals
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has dropped its plan to require private notifications for significant deals, citing a lack of consensus among companies and controlling shareholders. Instead, listed firms will be required to maintain a privy list for all material transactions, which will help instill best practices among issuers. The changes, effective Dec 1, 2015, aim to reduce regulatory burden and improve enforcement of SGX listing rules. Market watchers see the removal of the private notification rule as a positive step, while noting that the regulatory burden on listed companies remains heavy.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages have issued varying recommendations for Singapore stocks. Ezra Holdings is upgraded to a "trading buy" with a target price of S$0.33, while Singapore Airlines is downgraded to a "sell" with a target price of S$10.65. Raffles Medical Group is maintained at a "hold" with a target price of S$4.59. Frasers Commercial Trust is upgraded to a "buy" with a target price of S$1.53. The companies' balance sheets and financial performance are being closely watched, with Ezra's debt refinancing and Raffles' revenue growth seen as positive indicators.

site_title: SMRT's Q2 profit rises 1.9% to S$25.74m
summary: SMRT Corp reported a 1.9% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$25.74 million for the second quarter ended Sept 30, 2015, driven by higher share of profits from associates and joint ventures. Revenue rose 4.7% to S$328.76 million, but operating profit fell 2.4% to S$32.52 million due to higher expenses. The group's fare business recorded operating losses, while its non-fare business saw a 21.7% increase in operating profit.

site_title: It's even harder to gauge China's monetary policy now
summary: China's central bank has abolished the deposit ceiling, part of a shift to a price-based monetary policy framework, but the new system's clarity is unclear. The People's Bank of China will use short-term repos and its Standing Lending Facility to guide market levels, but seven-day interbank rates, medium-term liquidity programmes, and one-year lending benchmarks will also be used. This change aims to ease the economy's slowing growth and capital outflows, but analysts warn of confusion and potential market instability. The PBOC will continue to set benchmark saving and lending rates for a period, before shifting focus to the seven-day repurchase rate.

site_title: UK-China partnership still needs to be greatly developed
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's four-day UK visit marked a significant milestone in the country's economic and diplomatic rise, with the two nations pledging a global comprehensive strategic partnership. The UK and China agreed on over $60 billion in investments, including a $28 billion nuclear power station, and China has promised to be the UK's strongest advocate in the West. However, the UK's relationship with the US has declined, and Beijing's growing influence has raised concerns about the country's values and human rights record. The visit highlights the need for the UK to develop its partnership with China further.

site_title: A caring NTUC seeks fairness and better careers for workers
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore has set new goals for the next four years, known as Labour Movement 2019 (LM2019), aiming to show greater care for workers, promote fairness, and help them grow their careers. NTUC chief Chan Chun Sing reported that the labour movement has achieved success in the past four years, including low jobless rates, increased union membership, and real wage increases. LM2019 targets include extending protection to more professionals, boosting tripartism, and preparing workers for the changing job market.

site_title: Iswaran flags potential for S'pore cleantech sector
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry S. Iswaran flags the potential for the country's cleantech sector to grow due to regional demand for clean energy, financing models, and business structures. The sector is expected to create over 100 jobs and S$150 million in business spending over the next five years. Key investments secured include Grass Energy's global headquarters in Singapore, and Accenture's Smart Grid Services team. Iswaran emphasizes the importance of public-private partnerships and living lab platforms in driving innovation and commercialization of cleantech technologies in Singapore.

site_title: HomeAway buys remaining stake in Singapore startup Travelmob
summary: HomeAway, a US$2.9 billion vacation rental company, has fully acquired Singapore startup Travelmob. This marks HomeAway's expansion into the Asian market, with a focus on competing with Airbnb and Roomorama. Travelmob, which was acquired in 2013, will be rebranded as HomeAway and will continue to operate under the HomeAway Asia team. The acquisition allows HomeAway to tap into the growing demand for vacation rentals in Asia, with the potential for US$14 billion to US$16 billion in rental revenue this year.

site_title: Indonesia considers declaring national emergency over forest fires
summary: Indonesia considers declaring a national emergency due to weeks of smoldering forest fires across the archipelago, affecting 40 million people and causing hazardous haze in South-east Asia. Vice President Jusuf Kalla announced the consideration, stating the problem is too big and thousands of troops will be deployed to combat the fires. President Joko Widodo is expected to make a decision after returning from the US, amid concerns about the impact on businesses and the economy. The last national emergency was declared in 2004 following the Indian Ocean tsunami.

site_title: Valeant to examine ties with speciality pharmacy
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International has formed a special committee to investigate its relationship with Philidor Rx Services, a speciality pharmacy that dispenses some of Valeant's dermatology drugs. The company had acquired an option to buy Philidor, raising concerns about potential phantom sales to improve financial results. Valeant's stock fell 5% on Monday, amid criticism over its business practices and lack of transparency. The company maintains that its accounting related to Philidor is legal and appropriate, but analysts remain skeptical, citing concerns about the credibility of Valeant's business practices.

site_title: Central bank sees no grounds to weaken the Singdollar
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that there are no grounds to weaken the Singdollar, contrary to market expectations of a more aggressive easing of monetary policy. The central bank's latest Macroeconomic Review revealed a softer-than-anticipated outlook for GDP growth and inflation, leading to a modest and gradual appreciation path for the exchange rate policy band. MAS emphasized that its policy decision minimizes macroeconomic volatility and promotes medium-term price stability, with no room for further policy easing unless significant shifts in core inflation occur.

site_title: Keppel O&M, SembMarine set for LNG shipbuilding foray Continued from Page 1
summary: Keppel O&M and SembMarine are set to enter the LNG shipbuilding market with the Gravifloat terminal, which can be built for regasification and liquefaction of LNG in shallow waters. The Gravifloat terminals can be built to suit small-scale LNG requirements and can be adapted to suit most soil conditions. The companies expect the majority of the 35 identified FSRU and near-shore floating LNG prospects to be FSRUs, with at most 10 taking off in the next three to four years due to lower oil-linked LNG spot prices.

site_title: CapitaLand to build its 6th condo in Ho Chi Minh
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property developer, has entered a joint venture with Thanh Nien Corporation to build its sixth condominium project in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The US$55 million project will feature 1,000 units, marking CapitaLand's eighth in Vietnam. The company will hold an 80% stake in the joint venture, following Vietnam's lifting of foreigner ownership curbs. This move is expected to boost CapitaLand's residential portfolio in Vietnam, with the company already selling 873 units in the country this year.

site_title: Kyoto II - is it a done deal?
summary: The Kyoto Protocol, a global climate deal, is nearing completion. The UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is working towards a new agreement, dubbed "Kyoto II," which aims to stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations. The 2006 Stern Review and recent commitments from China and the US suggest that a deal is likely. However, critics argue that the market-based approach of carbon trading may reinforce technological lock-in and increase costs, which could delay sustainable reductions. Despite this, the author believes a "done deal" is possible, driven by a worldwide crusade to save the planet.

site_title: Walmart joins Amazon, Google in race for delivery-by-drone
summary: Walmart has applied to the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for a waiver to test drones outdoors for delivering products, joining Amazon and Google in the delivery-by-drone market. The company aims to use drones to deliver goods to consumers, track merchandise, and assist with inventory management. However, the FAA has not yet approved the use of drones for long-distance, robotic flights required for deliveries. Walmart plans to test two models from SZ DJI Technology Co and will need to wait for further testing before determining if drones will become part of its daily operations.

site_title: Greek banks' stress test results will be better than expected: source
summary: The European Central Bank's upcoming stress test results for Greece's four major banks are expected to be better than anticipated, according to a Bank of Greece official. The test, conducted under baseline and adverse scenarios, will assess capital shortfalls and projected credit losses. The official stated that the results will be below the initially expected limits. The test results are set to be released on Saturday.

site_title: Growth of loans to eurozone private sector starts to slow
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) faces increased pressure to boost the euro area's lacklustre recovery as disappointing data shows growth of loans to the private sector slowing down. Loans to private businesses and households increased by 0.6% in September, slower than the previous month. The ECB's monetary policy stance will be re-examined in December to determine additional stimulus needs, amid chronically low inflation and external economic uncertainties.

site_title: Even before diesel scandal bites, VW loses its sales crown
summary: Volkswagen has lost its position as the world's largest carmaker, with Toyota surpassing it in the first nine months of 2015. Volkswagen had briefly regained the top spot just three months prior, but Toyota's sales took the lead. The company is currently facing an emissions-cheating scandal, and has appointed a new head of corporate strategy amidst this turmoil.

site_title: The good life gets cheaper for HNWIs
summary: Asia remains the best bet on economic growth and wealth creation, according to Julius Baer. The Lifestyle Index, tracking luxury goods and services, showed a modest rise of 1.77% in 2014-2015, outpacing average inflation. Key cities like Singapore, Hong Kong, and Shanghai saw modest growth, while others like Indonesia and Korea experienced significant contractions. The index also revealed a decline in prices for luxury items such as wine, Botox treatments, and tooth implants. Despite China's slower growth, Julius Baer expects the region to continue driving economic growth and wealth creation.

site_title: China summons US ambassador over South China Sea patrol
summary: China has summoned US Ambassador Max Baucus over a US naval patrol near China's man-made islands in the South China Sea, calling the action "extremely irresponsible" and urging the US to cease harming China's sovereignty and security interests. The US patrol is seen as a challenge to China's claims in the disputed waters.

site_title: China to allow pension funds into stock market in 2016
summary: China plans to allow its multi-billion-dollar pension fund to invest in the stock market in 2016, aiming to boost share prices after a 30% plunge since June. The government is drafting a plan to invest up to 30% of the pension fund in stocks, with a 3.5 trillion yuan net asset value at the end of 2014. The move is part of a rescue package to support the market, which has been down more than 33% from its peak in June. The plan is expected to be carried out in 2016.

site_title: Pfizer lifts outlook on higher oncology, vaccine sales
summary: Pfizer reported third-quarter earnings of $2.1 billion, down 20.1% from the year-ago period, due to patent expirations. However, strong sales in oncology and vaccines offset the decline, with global vaccines and oncology sales increasing. Adjusted earnings per share beat analyst estimates at 60 cents, and the company raised its 2015 forecasts to $47.5-$48.5 billion in sales and $2.16-$2.20 in adjusted earnings.

site_title: Blackstone seeks mortgage for Manhattan complex
summary: Blackstone is seeking a $2 billion mortgage from Freddie Mac or Fannie Mae to finance its $5.3 billion purchase of the 110-building Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan. The company, along with Canada's Ivanhoe Cambridge, has already funded half of the purchase with equity. Blackstone prefers a lower-leverage loan from a housing giant over commercial-mortgage backed securities (CMBS) debt. This deal comes after the company faced criticism for its handling of the property in 2007, including a $147 million settlement with tenants over rent overcharging.

site_title: Global bourses going all out to attract big-name foreign IPOs
summary: The New York Stock Exchange is expanding its reach to attract foreign companies for initial public offerings (IPOs). In two years, cross-border IPOs on major exchanges have more than doubled. This trend is driven by exchanges stepping up efforts to attract foreign companies. The number of cross-border IPOs has grown significantly, with data showing a more than doubling of such deals on major venues.

site_title: Pavilion Energy to place trades using Singapore LNG index
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Temasek-backed company, plans to use the Singapore LNG Index Group (Sling) to place trades in the coming years, potentially accelerating the evolution of the liquefied natural gas (LNG) market. The index, launched with 13 traders in June, is based on submissions from international LNG players and now includes about 20 players. Liquidity in LNG trading is expected to increase, driven by buyers adopting a wait-and-see approach due to uncertainty over oil prices. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is developing a Sling swap product, and the region is expected to benefit from a clearer price benchmarking, with Asia accounting for 76% of global LNG demand.

site_title: Lion Asiapac posts S$1.08m Q1 profit on income tax credit
summary: Lion Asiapac reported a Q1 profit of S$1.08 million, up from S$204,000 in the previous year, thanks to an income tax credit of S$0.47 million. Revenue declined 46% to S$4.09 million due to lower demand for lime manufacturing and steel trade. Earnings per share increased to 1.33 Singapore cents. The company remains vigilant amid market uncertainty and will continue to divest its interest in a Chinese development project.

site_title: UK's Q3 GDP growth eases to 0.5%, below forecasts
summary: The UK's third-quarter GDP growth slowed to 0.5%, below forecasts, indicating a slowdown in the economy. This marks a decrease from 0.7% in the second quarter and 2.3% year-over-year growth, the lowest in two years. The services sector drove growth, while manufacturing and construction sectors shrank. Economists view the slowdown as consistent with a modest slowdown rather than a contraction, and financial markets reacted mutedly. The Bank of England forecasts a revised growth of 0.6% and is unlikely to raise interest rates soon.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on durable goods report, earnings
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 64.31 points (0.36%) to 17,558.74, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes down 8.44% (0.41%) and 13.20% (0.26%), respectively. Durable goods orders fell for a second straight month, and companies such as DuPont, Pfizer, and UPS reported lower sales, highlighting slow growth in the manufacturing sector. The decline was attributed to concerns about declining revenue at many companies.

site_title: Grand Banks in the black with Q1 profit of S$1.22m
summary: Grand Banks Yachts reported a net profit of S$1.22 million for the first quarter of 2016, compared to a net loss of S$1.27 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the improvement to restructuring efforts, including integrating design, production, and marketing after acquiring Palm Beach Motor Yacht Co in 2014. Revenue jumped to S$14.05 million, with gross profit increasing to 24.5% due to improved internal efficiencies and a stronger greenback. The company's accumulated net order book stands at S$32.1 million, with expectations for a significant improvement in fiscal 2016 performance.

site_title: Govt agencies must collaborate to achieve best policies: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for government agencies to collaborate and develop policies that cut across disciplines and agencies to address Singapore's changing needs. He highlighted the need for collaboration with the private sector and civil society to create broad ownership over the country's future, particularly in addressing the social and health needs of an aging population. Tharman cited examples of successful collaborations, such as the Housing and Development Board's selective en bloc redevelopment project and the Health Promotion Board's efforts to provide health screenings for taxi drivers, as models for future policy development.

images.alt_text: "We'll have to work harder than before to sustain mobility, starting with efforts to even out the odds early in life, and intervene to promote second chances well beyond the school years," says Mr Tharman.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lion Asiapac reported a profit of S$1.08 million for the quarter ended Sept 30, despite a 46% decline in revenue to S$4.09 million. The company attributed the decline to tepid market demand and lower revenue from lime manufacturing. TEE Land announced the acquisition of a 6,544 sq meter plot of land in Bangkok for S$12.4 million to develop a high-rise condominium. The proposed acquisition is part of Chewathai's strategy to build up a portfolio of development properties.

site_title: US durable goods orders fall for 2nd month in September
summary: US durable goods orders fell 1.2% in September for the second consecutive month, with transportation equipment orders dropping 2.9% and commercial aircraft orders slumping 35.7%. Motor vehicle orders, however, saw a 1.8% increase. Year-over-year, new durable goods orders were down 4.6%. The decline highlights weakness in the manufacturing sector, which has lagged behind other sectors due to faltering foreign demand and a strong dollar.

site_title: Alibaba's online sales jump despite slowing China growth
summary: Alibaba's online sales surged 28% in the September quarter, reaching $112 billion in gross merchandise volume, despite China's slowing growth. The company's revenue and net profit also rose, beating expectations. This growth is crucial for China's transition to a "new normal" economy driven by consumer demand. However, Alibaba's stock has fallen nearly 40% since November due to concerns over China's economic slowdown. The company's dominance in the Chinese e-commerce market is seen as a key indicator of the country's economic health.

site_title: US home prices rise faster in August than July
summary: US single-family home prices rose 5.1% in August, surpassing July's 4.9% growth and meeting economist estimates. This marks a faster pace than the 1997-2005 housing boom. The low inflation rate, with unchanged consumer prices from September, contributed to the rebound. The increase in home prices now holds more value than in 2005-2006, when inflation rates were higher.

site_title: OSIM Q3 profit plunges 62% to S$6m
summary: OSIM International reported a net profit of S$6 million for Q3 2015, down 62% from S$16 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 11% to S$142 million. The company attributed the drop to increased fixed costs despite falling sales. The interim dividend was maintained at one Singapore cent per share, and the company's stock price closed down 0.9% to S$1.615.

site_title: Civil servants must be close to the ground: Tharman
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the importance of civil servants being close to the ground and listening to citizens' concerns to formulate policies. He urged government agencies to collaborate and engage with the community, private sector, and other stakeholders to build broad ownership in Singapore's future. This approach, he said, would help address the gaps in policy delivery and ensure policies are effective. Tharman's call comes as the country's public service needs to adapt to changing citizen needs in an evolving environment.

site_title: China Vanke Q3 net profit jumps 22% as sales pick up
summary: China Vanke Co Ltd reported a 21.8% increase in third-quarter net profit to 2 billion yuan, driven by government policies to boost the housing sector. The company completed half of its full-year target for project area in the first nine months and expects to exceed it in the fourth quarter. This follows government measures, including interest rate cuts, to support the market, which saw home prices rise for a fifth consecutive month in September. The company's net profit for the first three quarters of the year rose 6.1% to 6.9 billion yuan.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced its October policy decision, aiming to keep real GDP close to its potential and promote price stability. The decision was influenced by the slowdown in Singapore's major trading partners. Meanwhile, the World Bank expanded its Singapore office to create an Infrastructure and Urban Development Hub. Singapore is also focusing on clean technology, with plans to grow thought leadership in the sector. In other news, Vietnam reacted to the Trump tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs.

site_title: TEE Land's associate plans to develop condominium in Thailand
summary: TEE Land's associate, Chewathai, has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a 6,544 sqm plot of land in Bangkok for 316.3 million baht (S$12.4 million). The plan is to develop the site into a high-rise condominium, likely to be completed in July 2016. Chewathai will finance the acquisition using its own internal funds and bank borrowings as part of its strategy to build up a portfolio of development properties.

site_title: Indonesia to announce new economic stimulus measures next week: VP
summary: Indonesia's Vice President Jusuf Kalla announced that the country will introduce new economic stimulus measures next week, including tax incentives to attract investment. The measures come as Indonesia's annual economic growth slowed to 4.67% in the second quarter, the lowest rate in six years. The announcement follows previous stimulus measures rolled out by President Joko Widodo's administration, which include lowering energy prices and reforming the minimum wage formula. No further details on the new measures were provided.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets fell on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 dropping 0.17% to 6,405.89 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 losing 0.37% to 10,761.37 points. The declines were attributed to a cautious trading atmosphere ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting and the Bank of Japan's upcoming policy update. Investors are seeking guidance on interest rate hikes and are bracing for potential economic slowdowns.

site_title: SGX changes rules on significant transactions
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has updated its rules on significant transactions. Listed companies will now be required to maintain a "privy list" containing details of parties privy to material transactions, rather than just certain significant ones. The SGX will also remove a rule that requires companies to privately inform it about significant transactions before news is made public. This change aims to improve transparency and compliance with regulatory requirements.

site_title: Blackstone in talks to buy Taipei 101 tower stake-sources
summary: Blackstone Group is in talks to buy a nearly 38% stake in the operator of Taiwan's Taipei 101 tower, Taipei Financial Center Corp (TFCC), for a reported US$250 million. The US private equity firm has assured the Taiwan government it will not use Chinese-backed money in the deal. TFCC will hold a board meeting to decide whether to give Blackstone access to its books for due diligence. The discussions are confidential, and an external Blackstone spokeswoman declined to comment.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Group is in talks to buy a nearly 38 per cent stake in the operator of Taiwan's Taipei 101 tower, among the world's 10 tallest buildings, people with direct knowledge of the matter told Reuters.

site_title: China plans regular shipping services through Arctic
summary: China's COSCO plans to launch regular shipping services through the Arctic Ocean to Europe, reducing shipping times by up to nine days. The state-owned company has successfully completed two previous voyages through the Northeast Passage, and experts hail the route as a "golden waterway" for trade. China has no territorial claim to the Arctic but recognizes its strategic value and potential for scientific research. The move is seen as a key part of Beijing's northern ambitions as global warming makes the route more viable.

site_title: UPS third-quarter profit rises, tops estimates
summary: UPS reported a 4% increase in third-quarter net profit to $1.26 billion, or $1.39 per share, surpassing analyst estimates. The strong US dollar and lower fuel surcharge revenue contributed to a 1% decline in revenue. Despite this, the company's earnings per share still topped expectations. The results demonstrate UPS's resilience in a challenging market environment.

site_title: SMRT posts near 2% rise in Q2 profit
summary: SMRT Corp reported a 1.9% year-on-year increase in Q2 net profit to S$25.74 million, driven by higher revenue from rail, bus, and non-fare business segments. However, total expenses rose 7.1%, resulting in an operating profit of S$32.52 million, 2.4% lower than the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares declined on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 9.84 points to 1,696.95. A total of 1.9 billion lots, valued at RM1.9 billion, were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 588 to 269. The decline was attributed to a lack of significant trading activity.

site_title: Australia shares end flat; New Zealand hits record high
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Tuesday, finishing at 5,346.2 points, after losses in resource stocks were offset by gains in banks ahead of full-year earnings. The S&P/ASX 200 index is up 6.5% in October, its best monthly performance since 2011. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index hit a record high, closing up 0.5% at 6,001.02. Trading has been subdued ahead of the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan meetings, as well as a patchy US corporate earnings season.

site_title: Novartis Q3 income lags estimates as Alcon, dollar hit results
summary: Novartis reported a 2% decline in core net income to US$3.06 billion in Q3, missing analyst estimates, due to weakness at its Alcon eye-care business and a stronger dollar. Sales fell 6% to US$12.265 billion, but the company still expects annual sales growth at a mid-single-digit rate. Reported net income fell 42% to US$1.8 billion, mainly due to a prior-year gain and a US$400 million legal settlement provision.

site_title: BP quarterly profits collapse on tumbling oil prices
summary: BP's quarterly profits plummeted 64% to $46 million due to tumbling oil prices, which halved from a year earlier. The company will cut investment further and sell more assets, lowering its full-year 2015 capital spending forecast to less than $20 billion. CEO Bob Dudley said the results reflect BP's efforts to rebalance its financial framework in the new price environment. The company has also taken another $426-million charge for the US oil disaster and plans to sell $3.0-5.0 billion of assets in 2016.

site_title: Indonesian capital's minimum wage to rise 15% next year: Jakarta Post
summary: Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, is set to increase its minimum wage by 15% next year to 3.1 million rupiah (S$316), according to Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama. This rise is based on the country's economic growth rate plus inflation rate, as announced by the government earlier this month. The new wage increase will be implemented by a wage-setting committee, which will meet on Wednesday to finalize the decision.

images.alt_text: The official minimum wage in the Indonesian capital will rise by around 15 percent next year, the Jakarta Post on Tuesday quoted the governor as saying.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower ahead of expected Wall Street weakness
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% to 3,052.53, closing at 30.54 points, in low volume of 1.3 billion units. The decline came ahead of the US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting, despite no expected rate hike. This shift in cautious market sentiment followed gains for four consecutive days driven by European central bank stimulus promises. AddValue Tech fell S$0.005 after rising S$0.021 on Monday following a memorandum of understanding with a China government party.

site_title: Kong Hee and City Harvest Church leaders found guilty: What next?
summary: Six City Harvest Church leaders, including founder Kong Hee, were convicted of all charges related to funneling $24 million in church building funds into bogus investments to support Kong's wife, Ho Yeow Sun. The six were found guilty of varying counts of criminal breach of trust and falsifying accounts. Sentencing is scheduled for November 20, with bail remaining in place for the convicted leaders. Kong and his co-defendants face up to 20 years in prison, while Ho Yeow Sun was ordained as a pastor and has been overseeing church operations since 2012.

site_title: UK economy slows more than expected in Q3
summary: The UK economy experienced slower-than-expected growth in the third quarter, with gross domestic product growth slowing to 0.5% from 0.7% in the previous quarter. The slowdown was driven by a 2.2% decline in the domestic construction industry, the largest fall in three years. Despite this, services output continued to grow strongly, and consumer demand remained solid. The slower-than-expected growth raises concerns about the end of a period of rapid economic growth, with the International Monetary Fund forecasting growth would slow to 2.5% this year.

site_title: South Korea: Shares ease ahead of Fed meeting; won edges up
summary: South Korean shares decreased 0.2% to 2,044.65 points, while the won edged up slightly to 1,131.0 to the dollar ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision later this week. Most investors remained on the sidelines due to uncertainty surrounding the Fed's move.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust's DPU up 12.6% in Q2
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust reported a 12.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.808 Singapore cents for Q2 2015, outperforming the 1.606 cents paid in the same period last year. The trust's gross revenue rose 25.4% to S$84.6 million and net property income increased 26% to S$69.5 million.

site_title: New Adelaide mall, Singapore portfolio boost Starhill Reit's Q1
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 3.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.31 Singapore cents for its Q1, driven by the full-quarter contribution from the recently-acquired Myer Centre Adelaide and strong Singapore portfolio performance. Group revenue rose 16.8% and net property income increased 10.2%. Unitholders can expect to receive their Q1 DPU on Nov 27, 2015, with units ending 1.5 cents or 1.8% lower at S$0.80.

site_title: China: Stocks close slightly higher, recoup early losses
summary: China's stocks closed 0.1% higher on Tuesday, recouping early losses of nearly 2% led by financials. The CSI300 index ended at 3,592.88 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.1% to 3,434.34. Total A-share volume traded was 69.3 billion shares.

site_title: World Bank expands Singapore office to create first infrastructure, urban development hub
summary: The World Bank Group is expanding its Singapore office to create its first Infrastructure and Urban Development Hub, employing over 200 people from 2016 to 2018. The hub will provide global services, focusing on energy, transport, urban development, and more, to address pressing infrastructure needs worldwide. The expansion aims to capitalize on Singapore's role as a regional business and trade center, and to leverage its position in global capital markets. The hub will complement existing investment and advisory programs, aiming to enhance solutions for developing countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: City Harvest Trial: Who's who
summary: City Harvest founder Sim Kong faces three charges of criminal breach of trust in Singapore. Kong maintains that he and other defendants had assurance from lawyers and auditors that their financial transactions were legitimate. He questioned the need to see auditor Foong Daw Ching, suggesting he would not have sought to commit fraud if he had. Kong's defense relies on the assurances received from professionals.

site_title: What you need to know about the City Harvest trial
summary: The City Harvest trial, which began in 2013, has concluded after more than two years. Six co-accused, including senior pastor Kong Hee and former finance managers, are accused of misappropriating $24 million in church funds through sham bond investments. They face varying counts of criminal breach of trust and falsifying accounts, punishable with life imprisonment or up to 20 years in prison. The verdict, delivered on October 21, 2015, allows for potential appeals. The trial, one of the longest in history, drew significant media attention and interest from church members.

site_title: DanaInfra to seek up to 50b ringgit in Islamic financing
summary: DanaInfra Nasional Bhd, a Malaysian company, plans to raise up to 50 billion ringgit (US$11.7 billion) through Islamic financing to complete the country's MRT rail network. The funds will be used to complete an existing line and a new line with an estimated cost of 42 billion ringgit, set to be completed by 2022. The government guarantees the funds, which will be raised in the form of Islamic commercial papers or notes. This move aims to set pricing benchmarks for large-scale infrastructure deals in Malaysia.

site_title: Santos to get US$1.1b offer for Australian gas fields
summary: Santos Ltd has received a binding bid of around US$1.1 billion from Quadrant Energy Pty for its stakes in Australian oil and gas fields in Western Australia. This comes as the energy producer considers strategic options and divestments amid a broader review of its assets. Santos previously rejected a US$5.2 billion takeover offer and is evaluating different proposals. The company is also in talks with Japanese trading house Marubeni Corp to sell a stake in an Exxon Mobil liquefied natural gas plant in Papua New Guinea.

site_title: Air Asia Philippines postpones US$200m IPO to 2018
summary: AirAsia Philippines postpones its US$200m IPO to 2018 from 2016, citing a desire to make its operations profitable. CEO Josephine Joy Caneba stated that the IPO will happen, but it will be deferred to 2018's first quarter. The airline plans to lease five A320 aircraft to launch flights to China next year.

site_title: Temasek's Pavilion Energy to use Singapore LNG price index for trades in next few years
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Temasek-backed company, plans to use Singapore's LNG price index (SLinG) for trades in the next few years. The index, which averages submissions from 20 international LNG players, aims to provide a fair assessment of LNG cargo prices. Pavilion Energy CEO Seah Moon Ming announced a 10-year sales and purchase agreement with Gazprom and signed MOUs with Asian LNG players, including Huadian and JERA, to supply LNG cargoes and collaborate on joint procurement. The company aims to strengthen its LNG supply portfolio and add price indexation.

site_title: Slowdown in Singapore's major trading partners, opportunities in Asean: MAS (Amended)
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to see growth of 2-2.5% in 2015, with risks tilted to the downside due to regional headwinds, particularly from major trading partners China, Indonesia, and Malaysia. These countries' total imports have contracted by 16% since the start of 2015, affecting Singapore's goods exports and services demand. However, emerging trade patterns within the Asean region offer new growth avenues for Singapore, with Vietnam and other emerging trading partners expected to be bright spots in the middle term.

site_title: India's top airline starts IPO bidding in Modi sentiment test
summary: India's top airline, IndiGo, has started its initial public offering (IPO) with a proposed valuation of up to 275.66 billion rupees ($4.62 billion). The airline aims to raise 30.01 billion rupees (US$462 million) with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government pitching India as a lucrative destination for foreign investment. This is India's largest IPO since 2012, and it will gauge investor sentiment towards the country's growing economy. IndiGo is the only Indian airline to have made a profit in each of the past seven years.

images.alt_text: Bidding opened on Tuesday for shares in the parent company of India's leading airline, IndiGo, the nation's biggest initial public offering in almost three years.

site_title: City Harvest trial: Saga highlights crucial role of whistle-blower
summary: The City Harvest Church trial resulted in guilty verdicts for all six accused, highlighting the importance of whistle-blowers in exposing charity malfeasance. Roland Poon, a church member, initially raised concerns in 2003 about the church's spending on its pastor's wife's music career. This sparked a series of investigations and reforms, including the creation of the Charity Council and increased transparency in charity finances. The court's verdict emphasizes the need for accountability and good governance in charity management, even when faith is involved.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks drop ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Tokyo shares dropped 0.90% on Tuesday, following a weak lead from Wall Street, ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,777.04, while the Topix index fell 1.02% to 1,543.11. Investors await the Fed meeting's potential impact on interest rates and the US economy.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong: Stocks retreat in opening exchanges
summary: Shanghai stocks slipped 0.60% on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling to 3,409.14, and the Shenzhen Composite Index losing 0.87%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index also dipped 0.27%. The declines follow the previous day's highest levels in two months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up marginally, erasing morning losses
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index closed 0.1 percent higher at 23,142.73 points on Tuesday, erasing morning losses, as financial and resource stocks initially declined before a late-afternoon rally. The China Enterprises Index also closed 0.3 percent lower. Total trading volume was 1.6 billion shares.

site_title: Copper falls as Codelco cuts seen inadequate to reverse surplus
summary: Copper prices declined 0.6% to $5,162 a metric ton on the London Metal Exchange, amid a global glut driven by sputtering demand in China. State-owned Codelco, the world's largest copper miner, cut its 2015-2019 investment plan to $21-22 billion, citing falling prices and reduced earnings. The move is seen as insufficient to reverse the surplus. Copper prices have been impacted by China's reduced demand and global oversupply, leading to a decline in prices.

site_title: Daewoo shipbuilding posts quarterly loss
summary: Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co, the world's second-largest shipbuilder, posted its second straight quarterly loss due to a slump in oil prices increasing costs for its offshore operations. The company reported a third-quarter loss of 1.35 trillion won (US$1.2 billion), wider than estimated losses of 95.2 billion won. Creditors plan to announce how much money they will lend to the shipyard to improve its cash flows. Daewoo Shipbuilding's results reflected losses from a cancelled contract and delayed deliveries of two drill ships.

images.alt_text: Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co, the world's second-largest shipbuilder, posted its second straight quarterly loss as a slump in oil prices increased costs for its offshore operations.

site_title: China Sept industry core earnings fall
summary: China's industrial companies saw profits fall 0.1% in September, with core business revenues declining 0.5% and industrial profits down 1.7% in the first nine months. This follows a record 8.8% collapse in August. The National Bureau of Statistics warned that the industrial profit outlook remains pessimistic due to ongoing downward pressure on the economy. High debt levels in heavy industries and inefficient state-owned enterprises are contributing to the slowdown, with some firms reporting losses and supply gluts.

site_title: Ringgit falls as Fitch warns Malaysia may miss its deficit target
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell the most in a week after Fitch Ratings warned that the country may miss its 2016 fiscal deficit target due to economic pressure from lower commodity prices. The shortfall could exceed 3.1% of GDP, contrary to Prime Minister Najib Razak's estimate. Fitch estimates the slippage won't increase Malaysia's debt ratio, which remains around 52% of GDP until 2017. The decline was attributed to worsening economic headwinds and the impact of low oil prices on the nation's revenue.

site_title: Uber of trucks startup Convoy backed by Jeff Bezos, Marc Benioff
summary: Convoy, a Seattle-based startup, has raised $2.5 million in early financing from investors including Jeff Bezos, Marc Benioff, and Garrett Camp. The company aims to disrupt the US$749 billion trucking industry by connecting shippers with mobile technology, offering instant price quotes, and tracking drivers. Convoy focuses on short-haul trucking, typically one-day trips between companies, and plans to expand to other areas within the year. The startup's co-founder, Dan Lewis, believes trucking is one of the largest outdated industries in the US, with an enormous market opportunity.

site_title: Wave of Australian gold mine M&As receding
summary: A wave of gold mine acquisitions in Australia may be receding due to rising valuations and companies focusing on exploiting existing assets. Evolution Mining Ltd Executive Chairman Jake Klein said valuations have increased since the company's last big buys, making operating assets more expensive. As a result, companies like Evolution and Northern Star Resources are shifting their focus to integrating existing assets and increasing production, rather than acquiring new mines. This trend may reduce the amount of gold mine deals in the country this year, with fewer than $1.7 billion in announced deals so far compared to $2.2 billion in 2013 and 2014.

site_title: Why It Matters: The City Harvest case
summary: The City Harvest case involves a former church leader, Tan Chong-Ping, and his associates, who were accused of misusing millions of dollars in donations for personal gain. The verdict in the case was recently delivered, with the court ruling that Tan and his associates had committed fraud. The Commissioner of Charities investigation was also deferred. The case has significant implications for the church and the community, raising questions about accountability and transparency in charitable organizations. The outcome of the case will be closely monitored in the coming weeks and months.

site_title: Indonesia Shariah hub goal fading as Malaysia assets race ahead
summary: Indonesia's ambitions to become an Asian Islamic finance hub are shrinking as its Shariah-compliant banking assets fell 27% to $20.5 billion in the first eight months of 2015. In contrast, Malaysia's Islamic banking assets rose 13.7% to $220 billion, driven by aggressive government support and tax breaks for sukuk. Indonesia's sluggish growth is attributed to a lack of incentives and infrastructure investment programs, while Malaysian banks are better positioned to encourage sukuk sales to fund projects. The country's Islamic finance industry is also struggling to attract clients who prioritize economic parameters over religious ones.

site_title: Japan's Nippon agrees to buy NAB's life unit for US$1.7b
summary: Japan's Nippon Life Insurance Company has agreed to purchase 80% of National Australia Bank's life insurance unit for approximately US$1.65 billion. The deal is expected to be announced on Wednesday, following a trading halt by NAB earlier in the day. This move comes as NAB prepares to release its full-year earnings.

site_title: Oil prices retreat in Asia
summary: Oil prices retreated in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) falling 63 cents to US$43.35 a barrel and Brent easing 43 cents to US$47.11 a barrel. Analysts expect a rise in US crude inventories and a persisting global supply glut, which will prolong oversupply issues. The International Energy Agency's executive director, Fatih Birol, stated there's ample supply until mid-2016, contributing to the price decline.

site_title: Melco opens US$3.2b casino with bet on Batman to revive fortunes
summary: Melco Crown Entertainment Ltd has opened its $3.2 billion Studio City casino in Macau, a move aimed at reviving fortunes in the Asian gambling hub. The Hollywood-themed resort features non-VIP gaming elements and a focus on mass-market casual gamblers, a departure from the traditional VIP baccarat lounges. Despite the opening, analysts predict a gloomy outlook for the industry due to China's economic slowdown and corruption crackdown. The move is seen as a strategic shift by Melco, positioning itself towards the non-VIP sector, which is expected to drive growth.

site_title: Apple Store coming to Singapore
summary: Apple is set to open a new store in Singapore, taking over a 15,000 sq ft space at Knightsbridge mall in Orchard Road. The store, scheduled to open next year, will replace a Pure Fitness gym and other tenants. The move is part of Apple's expanding presence in Southeast Asia, following the opening of stores in other countries.

site_title: JPMorgan targets new branches in India for wholesale banking
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to expand its wholesale banking operations in India by opening new branches, targeting clients including large domestic companies, multinationals, and government-backed institutions. The bank is in talks with the Reserve Bank of India to obtain permits for the new centers, with a goal of opening them next year. JPMorgan's current presence in India dates back to 1922, and the bank aims to increase its lending to the country's priority sector, including farmers and smaller businesses.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co, the largest US bank, is seeking branch licenses in India to bolster its wholesale banking operations in the country.

site_title: Australia: Shares tread water, NZ hits new high
summary: Australian shares remained unchanged on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index at 5,349.7 points. Despite gains in banks ahead of full-year results, losses in resources due to concerns over Chinese and European demand weighed on the market. National Australia Bank is expected to post a record cash profit on Wednesday, while ANZ Banking Group's earnings growth is expected to be its slowest since the global financial crisis. Market analysts predict a "Santa Claus rally" but note the medium-to-long-term outlook remains negative due to concerns about global growth.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses as glut worries persist
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday, extending losses for a third week, as US inventory data is expected to show another increase in crude stocks. Brent crude for December delivery dropped 38 cents to $47.16 a barrel, while US crude for December delivery fell 51 cents to $43.47 a barrel. The losses come as concerns about a glut in oil supplies persist, despite OPEC's decision to trim oil demand for the next four years.

site_title: MAS explains latest monetary policy decision
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has decided to maintain the modest and gradual appreciation path for the S$NEER policy band, while reducing its slope. This decision aims to promote medium-term price stability and minimize macroeconomic volatility. The MAS estimates that this approach will lead to comparatively more favorable growth and inflation outcomes for the Singapore economy. The decision was made due to a softer-than-anticipated outlook for GDP growth and inflation, and is considered a balanced approach between maintaining the policy status quo and adopting a more lenient stance.
