images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) October policy decision will keep the level of real GDP close to its potential over the medium term, and therefore help to promote price stability in the economy, said the central bank on Tuesday.

site_title: Link Administration debuts at 11% premium
summary: Link Administration Holdings Ltd debuted at an 11% premium to its issue price after raising A$947 million in Australia's largest IPO this year. The shares first traded at A$7.10, compared to A$6.37. Major owner Pacific Equity Partners sold 42% of the company, giving it a market capitalization of A$2.6 billion.

site_title: German transport minister meets with US counterpart on VW
summary: German Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt met with US Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx in Washington to discuss Volkswagen's admission to rigging emissions tests. The meeting comes as Volkswagen faces sales slowdown and criticism over its reporting of vehicle deaths and injuries. Foxx and Dobrindt also discussed self-driving cars and reducing greenhouse-gas emissions. Volkswagen has agreed to an independent audit and will coordinate with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The two countries aim to increase collaboration on policy issues, including emissions and technology.

images.alt_text: The German Transport Minister met with his US counterpart Monday in Washington to discuss Volkswagen AG's admission that it rigged its cars to pass emissions tests.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.07% to 18,961.16. The move followed a mixed lead from Wall Street, which had rallied the previous day on a Chinese interest rate cut. The flat opening was likely due to ongoing concerns over US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats, which have been weighing on markets.

site_title: Third Point buys stake in Japan's Seven & I
summary: US hedge fund Third Point, run by billionaire Daniel Loeb, has acquired a stake in Japan's Seven & I Holdings, the operator of 7-Eleven convenience stores. The stake, less than 5%, is aimed at pressuring the retailer to downsize its general merchandise business and improve profitability. Seven & I has forecast a fifth consecutive year of record operating profit, but has also announced plans to close unprofitable stores. The investment is the latest in Japan for Third Point, which has previously invested in firms such as Sony and Fanuc.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 7.88 points or 0.26% lower at 3,075.19 on Tuesday, following a retreat on Wall Street overnight. Trading was light, with 85.7 million shares changing hands. Investors are in a wait-and-see mode ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting, where policymakers will decide on interest rates. Losers marginally outpaced gainers, with Addvalue Technologies, Swiber Holdings, and Jiutian Chemicals among the top gainers.

site_title: Blackstone seeks mortgage for Manhattan complex
summary: Blackstone Group is seeking a $2 billion mortgage from Freddie Mac or Fannie Mae to finance its $5.3 billion purchase of the 110-building Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village complex in Manhattan. The company and its partner Ivanhoe Cambridge have already secured half of the funding with equity, and they prefer a lower-leverage loan through a housing giant rather than a conduit CMBS debt from bank lenders. The deal aims to close by the end of 2015, and Blackstone has secured city backing and a $144 million loan from the city's Housing Development Corporation to preserve affordability.

site_title: Global Palm Resources warns of 'substantially lower' profit for Q3
summary: Global Palm Resources Holdings has issued a profit warning, expecting a net profit after tax for Q3 to be "substantially lower" than the year-ago period. The decrease is primarily due to lower sales revenue for crude palm oil and palm kernel. The company will release its unaudited financial results on or before Nov 13.

site_title: Singapore to grow thought leadership in cleantech
summary: Singapore aims to boost its thought leadership in cleantech by launching the Sustainable Energy Centre of Excellence (SECOE), a joint initiative between the Asian Development Bank, International Enterprise Singapore, and the Sustainable Energy Association of Singapore. The SECOE will provide training programs for regional policymakers and a platform for sharing experiences and networking. It will also connect cleantech companies in Singapore to projects in the region, aiming to increase the city-state's attractiveness for international clean technology companies.

site_title: Hu An Cable halts trading of shares; Raffles Education suspends trading
summary: HU An Cable Holdings and Raffles Education have requested trading halts on their shares. HU An Cable's halt is pending an announcement, while Raffles Education's suspension has expired but no details on an impending announcement have been released.

site_title: Seoul: Shares and won steady ahead of Fed policy meeting
summary: South Korean shares and the won remained steady ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) at 2,041.43 points. The won was quoted at 1,133.0 per dollar, slightly higher than Monday's close. Investors are cautious, focusing on the Fed's statement on the timing of a potential US rate hike and China's new five-year plan. Foreign investors were net sellers of KOSPI shares, while Hyundai Heavy Industries shares rose 6% after announcing poor third-quarter earnings.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Pteris, VIT, Grand Banks Yachts
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Corporate news is expected to drive trading activity on Tuesday, with no major catalysts mentioned. CapitaLand has entered a joint venture in Vietnam for a US$55 million project. Pteris Global secured contracts worth S$64.2 million from Chinese and US customers. Viva Industrial Trust reported a 2.4% decline in distribution per stapled security, but a 15.1% rise in distributable income and 29.6% rise in net property income. Grand Banks Yachts swung to a net profit of S$1.2 million, with a 24.5% jump in gross profit margin after restructuring efforts.

site_title: Asia: Share markets turns cautious as central bank decisions loom
summary: Asian share markets paused on Tuesday, October 27, 2015, ahead of central bank meetings in the US and Japan. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index fell 0.07% and Japan's Nikkei dropped 0.1% despite near two-month highs. Risk sentiment remains supported by China's rate cut and expected European Central Bank easing. Investors expect no rate hike from the US Federal Reserve this week, but may react to recent economic data and global market events.

site_title: Nestle plans to resume Maggi sales in India next month
summary: Nestle plans to resume sales of Maggi noodles in India in November, after a nationwide ban due to lead contamination concerns. The company restarted manufacturing and will send samples for testing before resuming sales. The ban, imposed in May, cost Nestle around 66 million Swiss francs. Nestle has maintained that the noodles are safe, but the company must clear the new batches through testing before sales can resume.

site_title: JTC launches Tuas industrial site under confirmed list, Tampines site under reserve list
summary: JTC has launched two industrial sites under the second half 2015 industrial government land sales programme. A 0.5-hectare site at Tuas South Link 2 (Plot 11) was launched under the confirmed list, zoned for Business-2 development with a 20-year tenure and maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.4. A 0.5-hectare site at Tampines Industrial Drive (Plot 1) was launched under the reserve list. The launch aims to offer more choices for industrial development.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust posts 2.4% decline in Q3 DPS
summary: Viva Industrial Trust reported a 2.4% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q3, ending Sept 30, due to an enlarged DPS base following a recent placement exercise. Distributable income rose 15.1% to S$11.6 million, while net property income increased 29.6% year-over-year to S$12.5 million. The company's annualized yield is 8.9%. CEO Wilson Ang expressed confidence in seeking further growth opportunities to enhance long-term value for stapled securityholders.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end down slightly as Apple, energy weigh
summary: US stocks ended the day slightly lower, with the Dow and S&P 500 down 0.13% and 0.19%, respectively. Energy shares fell 2.5% due to declining oil prices, while Apple shares dropped 3.2% ahead of its quarterly results. Investors are cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which begins on Tuesday.

site_title: Facebook expands smartphone alerts to news, weather
summary: Facebook is expanding its smartphone alerts to include sports scores, weather updates, and local news updates, in addition to postings by friends and events. The new alerts will be personalized for users based on their community and can be adjusted through the social network's settings. The change will be rolled out gradually to Android and iOS users, with opt-in notifications that will not affect current notification settings. This expansion aims to deliver more relevant information to users, based on their feedback.

site_title: Pteris Global bags three contracts worth S$64.2m in China, US
summary: Pteris Global secured contracts worth S$64.2 million in China and the US. In China, the company won two contracts: one for passenger boarding bridges (PBBs) at Wuhan Tianhe International Airport for S$31.9 million, and another for PBBs at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport for S$26.3 million. In the US, Pteris subsidiary Pteris Global (USA) Inc secured S$6 million worth of orders for baggage handling systems at Phoenix Sky Harbour International Airport. These contracts are expected to contribute positively to the group's financial performance by December 31, 2016.

site_title: JPMorgan joins proxy access trend, adopts clawback disclosure
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has adopted a bylaw amendment allowing small groups of investors to nominate candidates for the bank's board of directors. The change, known as "proxy access," requires shareholders to own at least 3% of the company for three years to nominate candidates. This move follows McDonald's Corp's similar announcement earlier in the day. Additionally, JPMorgan has adopted a policy to disclose whether it has recouped incentive compensation from senior executives.

site_title: Grand Banks Yachts swings into the black in Q1
summary: Grand Banks Yachts reported a net profit of S$1.2 million in Q1, reversing a net loss of S$1.3 million in the same period last year. The company's gross profit margin increased to 24.5% due to restructuring efforts after acquiring Palm Beach Motor Yacht Co. Revenue more than doubled to S$14 million, driven by progressive recognition of orders. The board expects fiscal 2016 performance to improve significantly, barring unforeseen circumstances.

images.alt_text: The Grand Banks 55 Aleutian RP yacht.

site_title: Cementing Singapore's maritime status
summary: Singapore solidified its position as a leading maritime centre, ranking as the world's top maritime capital in 2015, according to Menon Business Economics. Over the past decade, the city-state has strengthened its maritime research and development (R&D) landscape, transforming from a lack of world-class research to a key player in the maritime industry. This growth has been driven by the development of a robust R&D ecosystem, enabling Singapore to maintain its leadership in the maritime sector.

site_title: Oracle's Ellison Says cloud industry still in early days
summary: Oracle executive chairman Larry Ellison stated that the cloud industry is still in its early days, with the largest cloud-only businesses remaining relatively small. Oracle is investing heavily in the cloud, competing with Amazon, Microsoft, and others, and has successfully led in certain cloud-based software sectors. Despite revenue pressure during the company's transition, Ellison believes Oracle will lead the decade-long shift to the cloud, with nearly 100% of its portfolio rewritten for cloud use.

site_title: US House vote moves trade bank a step closer to revival
summary: The US House of Representatives has voted 246-177 to move the Export-Import Bank (EXIM) one step closer to revival, bypassing House Financial Services Committee Chairman Jeb Hensarling. The measure, which was approved using a discharge petition, sets up a vote on Tuesday to renew EXIM's charter through September 30, 2019, with governance reforms. The vote is seen as a victory for Democrats, who argue that the bank helps create jobs and a competitive America, but faces an uphill battle for revival due to opposition in the Senate.

site_title: CapitaLand in JV to develop site in Ho Chi Minh City for US$55m
summary: CapitaLand has entered into a joint venture with Thanh Nien Corporation to develop a prime site in District 2, Ho Chi Minh City, for US$55 million. CapitaLand will hold an 80% stake, while Thanh Nien will hold 20%. This marks CapitaLand's sixth residential project in Ho Chi Minh City and eighth in Vietnam. The partnership aims to increase CapitaLand's residential portfolio in Vietnam to 7,850 homes. The joint venture follows a previous partnership with Thien Duc Trading-Construction Company to develop a S$200 million project in District 2.

site_title: Banks can learn from SingPost
summary: Banks in Singapore can learn from SingPost's transformation into an e-commerce player by extending their products' reach through strategic collaboration and partnerships. Customers can apply for banking products online or through video-chats with advisers, receive instant pre-approval, and have documents collected through partnerships with e-players like Uber. Banks can also consider using kiosks for cash disbursal and financial planning sessions for customers. This approach can help reduce costs and improve customer experience, making it a model for banks to follow.

site_title: MPA's LNG bunkering drive gives shipbuilding sector a boost
summary: Singapore's Maritime Port Authority (MPA) has launched initiatives to boost the shipbuilding sector with liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering. The MPA has issued calls for LNG bunkering licenses and announced S$12 million in incentives for the construction of up to six LNG-fueled vessels. This move aims to meet the global sulfur cap, set to be implemented by 2020, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. LNG is considered a longer-term solution, with modern engines reducing carbon dioxide emissions by up to 20% compared to heavy fuel oil.

site_title: Yahoo's NFL debut bodes well for game streaming: media buyers
summary: Yahoo's first global live-stream of an NFL game on Sunday drew 15.2 million viewers worldwide, with an average of 2.36 million watching at any given time. The game, between the Jacksonville Jaguars and Buffalo Bills in London, attracted a third of its viewership from outside the US. Although smaller than traditional NFL broadcasts, the event marked a success for game streaming, with media buyers predicting the NFL will strike future deals with online distributors. This could lead to digital distributors bidding on Thursday night games or the NFL selling rights for overseas games.

site_title: Indonesia's Jokowi says intends to join TPP trade deal
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo announced his country's intention to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal during a meeting with US President Barack Obama. The move comes as the US has forged the agreement with 11 countries. The two leaders also discussed climate change, maritime security, and ongoing Indonesian fires. The development is seen as a significant step in Indonesia's economic integration with the US and other Pacific nations.

site_title: VW testing Takata air bags as US weighs wider recalls
summary: Volkswagen is collecting Takata air bags from its vehicles for testing as the US weighs a wider recall. The carmaker stated that developing and testing new air bag inflators and a shortage of production capacity would delay replacement parts by over a year. Volkswagen listed 2.4 million Takata air bag inflators used in US models of its cars, including VW, Bentley, Porsche, Audi, and Lamborghini. A wider recall could further impact Volkswagen, which is retrofitting 11 million diesel vehicles worldwide.

site_title: Student dorms drawing billionaires have record sales in UK
summary: UK student dorms have seen record sales this year, with investors such as Goldman Sachs, Mikhail Fridman, and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board agreeing to deals worth US$6.5 billion in the first nine months. This surpasses US spending on similar properties during the same period. Strong overseas demand for university places in London drives the investments, with limited opportunities leading to further yield compression in the market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 5.59 points to 1,701.200, with 143 million lots traded worth RM37.4 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 109 to 101.

site_title: STI closes higher despite profit-taking
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 14.61 points higher on Monday, despite profit-taking, following China's monetary policy easing news from Friday. The index gained 0.9% in the morning but lost steam, ending the day up 0.47% at 3,083.07. Gainers outnumbered losers 230-185, with blue chips accounting for most of the market's dollar volume. Analysts expect the rally to continue towards 3,150, with support around 3,045 and 3,000.

site_title: Global IPO wars: Exchanges wage all-out fight for next Alibaba
summary: The New York Stock Exchange is intensifying its efforts to attract foreign companies for initial public offerings (IPOs), as the number of cross-border IPOs has more than doubled in two years. The trend follows the success of Alibaba's record-breaking US$25 billion IPO last year and Ferrari's recent US listing. Foreign listings have become a key source of growth for exchanges, as the industry faces a slowdown in trading revenue due to increased online transactions. The global "IPO wars" are underway, with exchanges competing to secure high-profile listings.

site_title: Wal-Mart joins Amazon, Google in race for delivery-by-drone
summary: Wal-Mart has applied to the US Federal Aviation Administration for a waiver to test drones for delivering products, entering a race with Amazon and Google. The company aims to use drones to deliver goods to consumers and assist with tracking merchandise. The FAA has issued over 2,000 waivers for low-altitude flights, but regulations for long-distance, robotic flights required for deliveries are still being finalized. Wal-Mart plans to test drones from SZ DJI Technology Co and will have to wait for further testing before determining if drones will become part of its daily operations.

site_title: China rate liberalisation unlikely to trigger deposit war
summary: China has scrapped a deposit rate ceiling, allowing banks to set deposit rates competitively. However, with one-year lending rates at 4.35%, banks are reluctant to raise deposit rates further, focusing on protecting margins. The move aims to encourage banks to lend more to the real economy, but may not have a significant impact due to the large amount of deposits already flowing into wealth management products. Depositors continue to pour money into online finance products, threatening the banks' deposit base.

site_title: JPMorgan challenges Apple Pay with mobile app offering discounts
summary: JPMorgan Chase unveiled its digital wallet, Chase Pay, to challenge Apple Pay and other payment systems. The service, set to roll out in mid-2016, allows users to collect reward points and redeem them for purchases, while also reducing transaction fees for retailers. JPMorgan is partnering with the Merchant Customer Exchange and offering discounts to merchants whose customers use the service frequently. The move aims to speed adoption of digital payment systems, which are expected to reach $142 billion in the US by 2019.

site_title: Benghazi: Republicans fail to make history
summary: US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton testified before the House of Representatives' Select Committee on Benghazi, repeating the same answers she gave three years ago. The hearing aimed to investigate the 2012 attack on the US consulate in Benghazi, Libya, which killed four Americans, including the ambassador. Despite intense questioning, Republicans failed to find a "smoking gun" to disqualify Clinton from running for president. The hearing was seen as a media event rather than a historic moment, with many critics accusing Republicans of politicizing the attack to derail Clinton's campaign.

site_title: New home sales drop to one-year low
summary: US new home sales dropped 11.5% in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 468,000 units, the lowest level since November 2014. This decline, after two straight months of gains, suggests a temporary cooling in the market for new houses. Despite this, economists believe the moderation in new home sales is temporary due to other housing reports showing an upbeat sector. The median price of a new home rose 13.5% from a year ago to $296,900.

site_title: The grooming of future tripartite leaders
summary: Singapore's Labour chief Chan Chun Sing is pushing to groom the next generation of tripartite leaders by cross-posting union leaders and government officials, and attaching promising civil servants to unions. This aims to build trust and foster cooperation between the government, businesses, and workers. The move is seen as crucial to address economic challenges, including disruptions from new technology and business models. Chan emphasized the need for a long-term perspective and the labour movement to evolve to care for workers in the face of these changes.

site_title: Supply glut still a hurdle to China property rebound
summary: China's efforts to ease mortgage restrictions and cut interest rates are showing signs of success in smaller cities, where home prices have rebounded. However, a supply glut of unsold homes remains a significant hurdle, with 424.7 million square meters of homes languishing nationwide. To address this, the government has cut mortgage down-payment requirements and scrapped a deposit-rate ceiling. Despite these measures, experts warn that further easing is needed to boost investment and stimulate economic growth, which is forecast to grow at the slowest annual rate in a quarter century.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Land is hosting a 50-day "Singapore Unboxed" exhibition to celebrate Singapore's Golden Jubilee, showcasing the transformation of the city's landscape through stories behind key developments, including Ocean Financial Centre, Bugis Junction, and Marina Bay Financial Centre. The exhibition will feature at five locations, including Keppel Land's properties and the National Library.

site_title: Buildings for a happier, healthier and more productive life
summary: A New York startup, Delos, has developed the Well Building Standard, a set of guidelines for designing buildings that promote a happier, healthier, and more productive lifestyle for occupants. Founded by twin brothers who were former Goldman Sachs partners, the standard aims to reduce threats to good health in office buildings, such as poor air quality, lighting, and sedentary lifestyles. Delos has received $108 million in investment and is partnering with developers to adopt the standard, which offers certification services and fees. The company hopes to make a profit from its services, while promoting healthier living spaces.

site_title: VW CEO to join Merkel on China trip, update on emissions probe: source
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller will join German Chancellor Angela Merkel on a trip to China to update her on the company's internal investigation into an emissions-rigging scandal. The scandal has led to a stock market value drop of over a quarter, the ousting of the previous CEO, and a significant loss for the company. Mueller will also meet with VW's Chinese joint ventures to discuss strategy. Analysts expect Volkswagen to report a third-quarter operating loss of almost 3.5 billion euros due to the scandal.

site_title: India aims to project soft power in biggest Africa meeting
summary: India hosts its largest Africa summit, seeking to challenge China's dominance and project soft power. The summit aims to highlight India as an alternative partner for trade and investment, despite its smaller economy. India's trading ties with Africa date back to antiquity, and the country has seen significant growth in trade since the first India-Africa Forum Summit in 2008. India wants to focus on development partnerships rather than resource extraction, and is in talks with South Africa to buy coal mines and with Sudan to invest in foreign assets.

site_title: Sotheby's celebrates former chairman with US$500m sale of his art collection
summary: Sotheby's is celebrating former chairman Alfred Taubman's legacy with a record-breaking $500 million sale of his art collection. The sale, featuring works by old masters like Raphael and 20th-century masters like Modigliani and Picasso, will be held on November 4. Sotheby's hopes to resurrect Taubman's positive image as a respected collector and patron, and the sale is seen as a test for new president and CEO Tad Smith. The collection includes over 500 pieces, with estimated values ranging from $20-100 million, and will be sold in four dedicated auctions.

site_title: China rate cut may prompt Fed to raise US borrowing costs: Nomura
summary: China's interest rate cut may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise US borrowing costs this year, according to Nomura's John Gorman. The cut, announced last week, aims to curb market volatility and pave the way for the Fed's possible rate hike in December. Asian stocks rose on the news, while the probability of a Fed rate increase by December is about 36%, according to Bloomberg data.

site_title: Steve Jobs disappoints at US box office
summary: Steve Jobs, a biopic about Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, underperformed at the US box office, earning $7.3 million in ticket sales, less than a third of estimated projections. The film, starring Michael Fassbender, cost $30 million to make and received criticism from Apple executives and fans, who felt it was a retelling of a well-known story. Despite this, Universal Pictures president Nick Carpou believes the film's critical acclaim and potential for awards consideration will help boost ticket sales in the long run.

site_title: RafflesMed's Q3 profit up 1.2% at S$15.6m
summary: Raffles Medical Group posted a 1.2% year-on-year rise in Q3 net profit to S$15.6 million, driven by a 7.4% increase in revenue to S$101.5 million. The group's hospital and healthcare services divisions contributed to the growth, but higher depreciation and operating lease expenses offset the gains. The company expects its joint venture with International SOS to expand its services and presence in Asia. Despite headwinds from a strong Sing dollar, Raffles Medical aims to increase its foreign revenue contributions.

site_title: Good Class Bungalow deals in Q3 down from previous quarter
summary: In the third quarter of 2015, 9 Good Class Bungalows (GCB) transactions worth S$177 million were recorded, down from S$282 million in Q2 but higher than the S$167 million in Q3 2014. The value of landed residential properties sold reached S$3.54 billion in the first nine months of the year, up from S$3.07 billion last year. Experts attribute the increase in demand to attractive prices and limited stock, with buyers often purchasing for owner occupation or capital appreciation, and developers seeking to redevelop old houses.

site_title: China, Japan, S Korea to discuss trade deal at summit
summary: China, Japan, and South Korea will discuss a pending free-trade agreement at their first trilateral summit in three years. The meeting, hosted by South Korean President Park Geun Hye, aims to boost communications and stability in the region. The stalled trade deal is a priority, following the completion of the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership. The summit's success could ease tensions and support the US in balancing China's growing assertiveness and deterring North Korea's expanding military muscle. A Chinese premier's visit to South Korea is also a significant event, marking the first in five years.

site_title: Japan's Seibu eyes Tokyo hotel redevelopment project
summary: Seibu Holdings Inc, a Tokyo hotel operator, plans to redevelop an area with four hotels in Shinagawa district to capitalize on Japan's surging overseas tourist arrivals and the opening of the country's first high-speed maglev train line in 2027. The project aims to double the allowed floor space and may cost around S$1.1 billion. The move follows a 49% surge in overseas visitors to Japan and a 53% increase in earnings for Seibu. The company aims to make Shinagawa a "front door to Tokyo" with the redevelopment.

site_title: Communist meeting eyes a leaner, greener China
summary: China's Communist leaders gathered for the Fifth Plenum, focusing on the nation's course for the next five years, amid economic malaise and pollution concerns. The meeting aims to establish a "new normal" of slower, more sustainable expansion after years of double-digit growth. China's economic growth slowed to 6.9% in the third quarter, prompting calls for structural reforms to sustain long-term expansion. The meeting also discusses environmental reforms, with experts emphasizing the need to balance economic growth with environmental concerns.

site_title: Mitsubishi UFJ enters fray for ANZ stake in Bank Panin: sources
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc has entered the running for a 39% stake in PT Bank Panin, a Jakarta-based bank, as part of ANZ's sale of its stake in the bank. Other bidders include Mizuho Financial Group Inc, Taiwan's CTBC Financial Holding Co, and Fubon Financial Holding Co. The sale is part of ANZ's efforts to comply with Australian regulators' new rules requiring banks to subtract the value of overseas minority investments from Tier 1 capital. Mitsubishi UFJ is seeking growth in Indonesia to counter an aging population and declining lending profits.

site_title: It's cloud all the way for Oracle at OpenWorld
summary: Oracle's CTO Larry Ellison asserts the company is "cloud all the way" and no longer considers traditional rivals SAP and IBM competitors, as they have not successfully transitioned to cloud computing. Ellison notes Oracle is competing with cloud leaders like Salesforce and Workday, and the company has taken a leadership position in SaaS and PaaS markets. Oracle has also announced a new cloud programme for partners, aiming to fully capitalize on the cloud opportunity and expand its partner ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Mr Ellison asserted that when Oracle competes for a cloud computing contract it sees Amazon all the time, Microsoft frequently and Google "sometimes".

site_title: Sony said to be in talks to buy Toshiba's image sensor business
summary: Sony is in talks to acquire Toshiba's image sensor business for 20 billion yen (S$230.4 million), aiming to expand its dominant position in smartphone camera chips. The deal would boost Sony's capacity by 100,000 units a month, increasing sales by 60 billion yen to 70 billion yen. Toshiba is seeking to raise cash after an accounting scandal. The acquisition is seen as a positive move for both Sony and Toshiba, with analysts expecting the sale to be announced as early as this week.

site_title: Chinese banks raise funds as bad loans rise
summary: Chinese banks are issuing preference shares and bonds to shore up capital amid a 30% rise in bad loans in the first half of 2015. The bad loan ratio is expected to worsen, forcing banks to raise additional funds, with some analysts warning of a systemic credit crisis. Despite raising a record $57.6 billion last year, banks may need to raise an additional $121.2 billion to meet regulatory requirements. The economic slowdown and structural adjustment have caused overdue loans to increase quickly, increasing pressure on credit risk management.

site_title: Restructuring fails to lift productivity, drag on economy to go on: Nomura
summary: Singapore's restructuring efforts to boost productivity have failed, with labor productivity growth remaining sluggish, according to a report by Nomura's Global Markets Research. The country's aging population and reliance on foreign labor are cited as major factors. Productivity growth is predicted to fall from 3.8% to 2.1% in the next five years, and the economic restructuring is unlikely to be completed by the end of the decade. The government's fiscal costs of restructuring are estimated to reach 5.6% of GDP, straining finances and leading to potential tax increases.

site_title: Ethiopian Airlines to woo China market with Chinese crew
summary: Ethiopian Airlines plans to increase its presence in the Chinese market by deploying Chinese crew members on all flights to China starting next month. The airline is training 30 Chinese recruits at its aviation academy to cater to the 90% of Chinese passengers who do not speak English. Ethiopian Airlines aims to become the primary carrier between Africa and Asia, with CEO Tewolde Gebremariam stating that Asia is the airline's biggest market. The move is part of the airline's expansion plans, which include adding new destinations in Asia and Africa.

site_title: New WTA chief exec outlines his priorities
summary: Steve Simon, the new chief executive of the Women's Tennis Association (WTA), outlined his priorities in an interview at the BNP Paribas WTA Finals in Singapore. Simon, who took over after Stacey Allaster's resignation, aims to study the tour calendar to address player concerns about the physical strain and injuries from the 59 tournaments held in over 30 countries this year. He emphasized the need to deliver a "premium product" to the market while ensuring player health and safety.

site_title: Factory output fall revives technical recession chatter
summary: Singapore's industrial production contracted for the eighth consecutive month in September, with a 4.8% year-on-year decline. This has revived concerns of a technical recession, narrowly avoided in Q3, as the likelihood of a technical recession is back on the table. The Economic Development Board's data shows a 0.1% quarter-on-quarter seasonally-adjusted annualized growth in Q3, and economists predict a downward revision of Q3 GDP growth to 1.3% year-on-year or -0.4% quarter-on-quarter.

site_title: Barclays opens up an African corridor to Asian businesses
summary: Barclays is expanding its African operations to tap into growing demand from Asian businesses, aiming to drive its corporate banking business. The bank expects to grow Africa-related revenue by 40% this year, with a focus on capturing trade and business that flows through the UK, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Despite the volatile market, Barclays sees opportunities in Africa, particularly with Chinese clients and in countries like Mozambique and Nigeria, which have potential for growth in energy and other sectors. The bank's strategy is supported by corporate clients and its chairman, and plans are expected to stick despite expected changes in leadership.

site_title: Caterpillar shifts its focus after commodity collapse
summary: Caterpillar Inc, the world's largest maker of mining and construction machinery, is shifting its focus from selling more machines to helping its customers better use the ones they have due to a commodity collapse. The company expects at least a year for a sales or earnings upturn and has announced a restructuring that could affect over 20 global facilities and lead to 10,000 job cuts. Caterpillar aims to sell more replacement parts and win loyalty for the long term, preserving research and development and spending on data and technology initiatives.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality to launch Modena brand in Bangkok
summary: Frasers Hospitality is set to launch its Modena by Fraser brand in Bangkok with the opening of a 239-unit serviced residence in 2016. Designed for "road warrior" business travelers, Modena by Fraser offers eco-friendly amenities and provincially sourced goods. The property, part of the eco-friendly FYI Center mixed-use development, will cater to socially conscious travelers seeking affordable home comforts. This marks Frasers Hospitality's second property in Thailand, following the GoldStandard Fraser Suites Sukhumvit in central Bangkok.

site_title: Addvalue shares soar on news of One Belt, One Road deal
summary: Addvalue Technologies' shares surged 40.4% on Monday after the company announced a memorandum of understanding with China International Security Solution Corporation Limited to develop and supply satellite communication-based solutions for China's One Belt, One Road initiative. The collaboration will provide reliable satellite communication solutions for the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) project, a key component of the One Belt, One Road initiative. This marks a significant rebound from the company's downward trend since the beginning of the year.

site_title: World trade deal could boost global exports by US$1t: WTO
summary: A new World Trade Organization (WTO) report estimates that full implementation of the 2013 trade accord could increase global merchandise exports by up to $1 trillion annually. Emerging economies are expected to capture more than half the gains. The report notes that the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) will expand world trade, reduce costs, and help countries integrate into a globalized production system. However, the deal remains unratified by two-thirds of the 161 member-states, with only 50 countries having done so due to disagreements on agricultural and industrial goods.

site_title: Pushing the envelope in the South China Sea
summary: The US Navy plans to conduct freedom of navigation patrols in the South China Sea, sailing close to artificial islands built by China. The US strategy is justified under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, which recognizes 12 nautical mile territorial limits only on naturally formed islands. The US-led operations, which began in 1979, aim to assert the right of innocent passage in territorial seas. China claims the entire South China Sea and has undertaken significant land reclamation work, sparking concerns of a potential confrontation.

site_title: Modi's worldview a recipe for disaster for modern India
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's worldview is criticized for its divisive and intolerant nature, threatening the country's open and inclusive democracy. Recent incidents, including a lynching, beatings, and a family set on fire, have raised concerns about the rise of hatred and intolerance. Modi's government has been accused of stoking the fire of intemperance, with some ministers promoting "love jihad" and the conversion of Muslims to Hindus. Critics argue that his real agenda is to polarize the country on sectarian lines and consolidate a Hindu vote bank, which could lead to disaster for modern India.

site_title: Tech, innovation key to growth, profit
summary: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) can become a disruptive force in their industries by adopting social media, cloud computing, and other digital technologies. This shift in power dynamics requires companies to be aware of challenges with technology and adapt to changes. To achieve this, SMEs can expand into new markets, invest in new technologies, and leverage cloud-based communication services. Venture capital can also provide growth and expansion opportunities. By mastering mobile, analytics, and cloud computing, SMEs can boost innovation, strengthen customer interactions, and improve their competitiveness.

site_title: German business confidence surprises with only marginal dip
summary: German business confidence dipped slightly in October, falling to 108.2 points, but remaining above expectations. The Ifo institute's business climate index showed a marginal drop, with the current business sub-index reaching its lowest level since March, but the outlook sub-index rising. Despite the Volkswagen scandal and concerns over the global economy, companies expressed optimism for future business developments, with production plans and exports expected to continue. Analysts welcomed the better-than-expected reading, citing the German economy's resilience and continued growth in the service sector.

site_title: Oxley offers up to S$125m retail bonds in maiden issue
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singaporean developer, has launched its first retail bond offering, raising up to S$125 million. The four-year bonds carry a 5% fixed interest rate and will be issued by Oxley's wholly owned unit. The bonds will be listed on the Singapore Exchange and are expected to be issued on Nov 5, with trading commencing on Nov 6. The company plans to use the net proceeds for general corporate purposes, refinancing borrowings, and capital expenditure requirements.

site_title: Najib's Budget fails to cheer market
summary: Malaysia's Budget 2016 failed to lift the stock market, closing 0.24% lower, as analysts deemed the incremental handouts limited in impact due to headwinds facing the country. The budget included cash transfers and wage hikes but was criticized for its fiscal constraint and lack of incentives for businesses. Analysts warned of "fiscal slippage" and a risk of fiscal deficit, with some predicting a balanced budget by 2020. The budget's populist approach was seen as potentially off-putting to foreign investors and skilled talents.

site_title: Two-child policy too little, too late for China
summary: China may consider relaxing its "one-child" policy to two children, but a two-child policy may be too little, too late. China's population is aging, with fewer working-age adults by 2050, and most Chinese already have two or more children. To address the issue, China could consider importing labor, a strategy Japan has used to address its own aging population. China has already allowed high-skilled immigrants and has a large, but largely undocumented, population of South-east Asian laborers. Establishing a temporary guest worker program targeting factory workers could help formalize this trend, but acceptance of foreign workers remains a challenge for the Chinese government.

site_title: Partnership of trust still robust in Singapore
summary: Singapore's tripartism, a partnership between government, businesses, and workers, remains robust, but faces challenges ahead, according to Cornell University professor Sarosh Kuruvilla. Tripartism, which promotes efficiency and equity, has declined globally since the 1980s. However, Singapore's unique commitment from top leaders, the labour movement, and employers has allowed it to thrive. The partnership has been successful in keeping the economy humming and has been instrumental in Singapore's transformation from a third-world to a first-world economy.

site_title: Perpetual bonds stay hot, hitting S$2.5b year to date
summary: Perpetual bonds in Singapore continue to attract investors, with Keppel Reit selling S$150 million perpetual bonds, bringing total proceeds to S$2.5 billion this year. The bonds offer higher yields than traditional fixed-maturity bonds, despite concerns over potential interest rate hikes and credit risks. Industry experts expect more Reits to issue perpetual bonds to meet leverage limits, citing benefits such as lower cost of capital and reserve leverage capacity. However, investors must consider the risks of credit risk and extension risk associated with these bonds.

site_title: Keppel unit designs award winning dual fuel engine tug
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine Technology Centre (KOMtech) has been awarded the Outstanding Maritime R&D and Technology Award for its design of an ASD tug that can run on both liquefied natural gas (LNG) and diesel fuel. The tug features a patented LNG vaporiser design, which reduces capital expenditure and operating costs, and incorporates smart designs to enhance safety and comfort. This award recognizes KOMtech's focus on developing innovative solutions for the marine sector, particularly in the area of LNG solutions, which aligns with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore's (MPA) objective of establishing Singapore as an LNG bunkering port by 2020.

site_title: Sale of Philips' lighting unit hits regulatory snags
summary: Philips' US$2.8 billion sale of its lighting unit, Lumileds, to China-based GO Scale Capital Investment is in doubt due to US regulatory concerns. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the US has expressed unforeseen concerns, casting a cloud over the deal. Despite this, Philips reported a net profit of 324 million euros and 12% sales growth in the third quarter, with CEO Frans van Houten stating that operational performance continues to strengthen. The sale's uncertainty affects the planned cash influx of US$2.8 billion for Philips.

site_title: Big money coming from eurozone spells trouble for Sweden
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's eurozone stimulus measures have raised concerns for Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, as the krona appreciates due to the influx of money from the south. The Riksbank is set to announce its next rate decision on October 28, with most economists predicting a possible expansion of its quantitative easing program to combat the stronger krona. Sweden's central bank has been forced to take unprecedented measures to drive up consumer prices, and a growing chorus of voices warns of unsustainable housing price developments.

images.alt_text: ECB's stimulus has forced Swedish central bank chief Stefan Ingves to resort to unprecedented steps, such as cutting the main rate below zero, to drive up consumer prices.

site_title: Green energy boom cushions oil & gas downturn
summary: A record number of jobs in the solar, wind, and hydroelectric sectors have been created, with 18% growth in direct and indirect employment globally to 7.7 million, according to the International Renewable Energy Agency. This boom in green energy is partly offsetting the biggest round of job losses in the oil and gas sector in almost two decades, with over 200,000 jobs cut worldwide since oil prices collapsed last year. The shift towards renewable energy is driven by governments in countries like China and India embarking on massive programs to use more renewable energy.

site_title: Japan Post to raise 693b yen in IPO priced at top of range
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co. priced its initial public offering at 1,400 yen per share, the top of an indicative range, to raise 693 billion yen (S$8 billion). This follows strong demand from retail investors, marking Japan's biggest privatisation in three decades.

site_title: Broadband providers face New York scrutiny
summary: New York State Attorney General Eric Schneiderman is investigating three major US broadband providers, Verizon, Time Warner Cable, and Cablevision, for potentially delivering slower-than-advertised internet speeds. Schneiderman's senior enforcement counsel, Tim Wu, is seeking detailed performance metrics and sales-employee training materials from the companies. The probe aims to address interconnection disputes and ensure that customers receive the promised speeds, which are essential for activities like downloading movies and performing web-enabled tasks quickly.

images.alt_text: Time Warner Cable's "Ultimate 100" broadband service promises customers enough speed to "upload large files" and "enjoy power gaming and streaming multiple videos simultaneously".

site_title: Oil at US$50 is 'gift to world' as Abu Dhabi sees higher prices
summary: Abu Dhabi's Department of Economic Development head Ali Al Mansoori says $50 oil is a "gift to the world" that should spur economic growth, despite not being ideal for the UAE. Prices are expected to reach $60 next year, and demand growth will slow due to a weaker global economy. Al Mansoori believes $50-$60 oil is a "win-win" for consumers and producers, allowing for economic growth and continued major projects in Abu Dhabi, including the Guggenheim museum.

site_title: China malls closing despite data showing retail sales rebound
summary: China's malls, despite showing a sharp rebound in retail sales, are closing at an alarming rate due to rising competition from online shopping and poorly managed properties. Vacancy rates and plummeting rents are common, with some malls even closing down. The struggles of brick-and-mortar retailers amplify China's corporate debt problem, currently at 160% of GDP. The country's central bank recently cut interest rates, but e-commerce sites continue to post double-digit growth rates, and entertainment venues like movie theaters are thriving.

site_title: Carmakers eye digital-savvy at Tokyo Motor Show
summary: The Tokyo Motor Show, a biennial event, kicked off on Wednesday, showcasing concept models from major carmakers, including self-driving cars and latest environmental technology. Nissan unveiled an electric vehicle with touch screens that turn it into a "digital space," while Toyota displayed a three-seater exoskeleton car and a fuel-cell offering. Honda also plans to put a commercialized self-driving car on the road by 2020. The event highlights the growing demand for green vehicles and the industry's shift towards autonomous driving and sustainable technologies.

site_title: China's rate cut weighs on most Asian units
summary: China's interest rate cut led to a decline in most Asian currencies, with the South Korean won falling 1.2% and the Malaysian ringgit easing as low oil prices raised concerns over revenue. The Philippine peso hit a near four-week low after foreign investors sold local stocks. Regional currencies recovered later, but remained weak due to investors focusing on monetary policy differentials ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. Analysts expect the dollar to strengthen amid caution over the Fed meeting and potential policy divergences.

site_title: Property price drop will only have a small impact on GDP growth: Nomura
summary: Nomura reports that a 10% decline in Singapore's real private residential property price index would lead to a 0.6 percentage point drop in real GDP growth, with the impact being short-lived and dissipating within six quarters.

site_title: IMF set for green light on yuan joining currency basket: sources
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is set to approve China's yuan to join the Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, a move that would make the yuan a key currency alongside the US dollar, yen, euro, and pound sterling. The IMF's executive board is scheduled to decide in November, with staff recommending the yuan's inclusion based on its performance against technical criteria. Beijing's push for the yuan's inclusion is seen as a strategic goal to reduce dependence on the US dollar and mark China's emergence as an economic power.

site_title: Aberdeen shares surge on report that it is seeking buyers
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management's shares surged 7.2% in London trading after a report that the company is seeking potential buyers. The move comes as the company grapples with an outflow of funds due to waning investor sentiment towards emerging markets. Aberdeen's CEO, Martin Gilbert, has made informal approaches to rival companies, but a spokesperson denied any formal approach has been made. The shares rose to 376.6 pence, a 15% increase from the year's start, amid concerns over the company's market value of £4.8 billion.

site_title: CEO's health issues warrant prompt disclosure
summary: United Continental Airlines Inc appointed an interim CEO four days after CEO Oscar Munoz suffered a heart attack, raising questions about the company's prompt disclosure of his condition. Unlike Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein and JP Morgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, who disclosed their health issues in a timely manner, Munoz's hospitalization was not publicly confirmed until a week after the incident. The delayed disclosure highlights a cultural issue of "face" in Singapore, where executives may be reluctant to disclose health issues due to perceptions of weakness and bad luck.

site_title: Ukraine and Russia ground direct flights in latest spat
summary: Ukraine and Russia have grounded direct flights between the two countries, starting a new trade war that affects tens of thousands of families. The decision comes after Ukraine banned Russian airlines from landing in the country but not flying over it, in response to Russia's refusal to hand back Crimea. The move has led to increased travel costs and time for Ukrainian citizens visiting relatives in Russia, with estimates suggesting 70% of flights are for Ukrainians visiting Russian relatives. Alternative routes, including overnight trains and flights through other countries, are now necessary.

site_title: Electricity retail market to be fully open by 2018
summary: Singapore's electricity market will be fully liberalized by 2018, allowing all consumers, including households, to choose their own electricity retailers. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) is working with industry stakeholders to ensure key service providers have the infrastructure to fulfill requirements. This move aims to increase efficiencies, provide greater flexibility and choice for consumers, and create opportunities for suppliers. The government is also studying how to prepare for future power generation investments and has released a consultation paper on the long-term outlook of the electricity market.

images.alt_text: Singapore's electricity market will be fully liberalised by 2018, with all consumers including households being able to choose their own electricity retailers, said Minister for Trade and Industry (Industry) S Iswaran on Monday.

site_title: Tripartism is right for Singapore but must be adapted to new challenges: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the tripartism model, consisting of government, employers, and labor unions, remains the right formula for the country despite global economic uncertainty. He emphasized the need for continual adaptation to new challenges to safeguard this model.

site_title: Powerful earthquake rocks South Asia, more than 160 dead
summary: A 7.5 magnitude earthquake struck South Asia, killing over 160 people, including 12 Afghan schoolgirls in a stampede. At least 1,000 were injured and hundreds of homes destroyed in Afghanistan, Pakistan, and India. The quake, centered near Jurm, Afghanistan, has caused significant damage and disruption, with thousands of people fleeing into the streets. The death toll is expected to rise, and aid agencies have been asked for relief. The epicenter is near the site of a 2005 quake that killed over 75,000 people.

site_title: Japan's Sharp warns over smartphone screen loss
summary: Sharp, a Japanese electronics giant, warns it will lose nearly $700 million in the half-year through September due to a slump in demand for its smartphone screens. The company blamed a downturn in Chinese demand and cut its revenue and profit forecasts. Sharp is expected to announce its earnings later this week, which will likely reignite concerns about its future. The company has been working to turn around its business, but its financial strength remains weak, according to analysts.

site_title: China's richest man 'doubled fortune in 12 months': Forbes
summary: China's richest person, Wang Jianlin, saw his fortune double to $30 billion in the past year, according to Forbes. The windfall was driven by the flotations of two of his company's subsidiaries, Wanda Group. Despite sluggish economic growth, Wang attributed his success to market forces and creative abilities, not personal connections. He unseated Jack Ma, founder of Alibaba, who dropped to second place, and the top 100 Chinese billionaires are now worth $450 billion, a 20% increase from last year.

site_title: Lifting gains through the family formula to sustain growth
summary: Moh Seng Cranes, a Singapore-based mobile crane-rental company, has attributed its success to its 50-year history of cultivating a strong family bond and culture. The company prioritizes safety, investing in modern equipment and a young fleet, with an average age of eight years. Moh Seng's unique approach of renting out each crane with an in-house operator has earned it a premium for its services, with 80% of its operating revenue coming from repeat customers. The company is also expanding into the mobile-crane trading business, seeking to acquire pre-owned branded cranes to refurbish and sell to other countries.

site_title: NTUC to get new president this week after incumbent Diana Chia retires
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore will elect a new president on Thursday, replacing incumbent Diana Chia who is retiring. This move aims to refresh the labour movement's leadership.

site_title: Controversy taints Japan Post IPO
summary: Japan Post is set to make its public debut on November 4 with a $12 billion initial public offering (IPO), raising funds to reduce the country's massive debt and repair damages from the 2011 Fukushima earthquake. However, the move has sparked controversy, with some analysts warning that privatization could lead to foreign control and undermine the postal service's core operations. The IPO's timing has also raised questions, with the Tokyo stock market currently weak. The government's goal of reducing debt and increasing shareholder democracy may be at odds with concerns over the potential impact on Japan's state-owned enterprises.

images.alt_text: An advertising poster at the Japan Post head office in Tokyo. Japan Post Bank Co set the price for its IPO at 1,450 yen a share, after gauging investor demand to be between 1,250 and 1,450 yen, a regulatory filing showed on Monday.

site_title: High medication error rate in US hospitals
summary: A new study at Massachusetts General Hospital found that nearly half of all surgeries in the US involve medication errors or unintended side effects, with 277 procedures observed. This rate is significantly higher than previous studies, which relied on self-reported data from clinicians. The study's findings are based on direct observation of operations, providing a more accurate representation of the issue. The high medication error rate has serious implications for patient safety and highlights the need for improved quality control measures in US hospitals.

site_title: Magnitude 7.6 quake strikes in northeast Afghanistan: USGS
summary: A magnitude 7.6 earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan on October 26, 2015, centered 82 km southeast of Feyzabad. The quake was 196 km deep and was felt in India and Pakistan, but no immediate damage or injuries were reported.

site_title: Singapore preparing to develop domestic secondary gas trading market
summary: Singapore is preparing to develop a domestic secondary gas trading market, which will allow gas buyers and sellers to trade gas on a short-term basis domestically. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) launched a consultation paper to seek industry feedback on the proposed market design and implementation roadmap. The market will enhance Singapore as a liquefied natural gas (LNG) hub and pave the way for a gas futures market in the future. The development is expected to take several years, with a phased approach to establish a trading platform, and the government will create an enabling infrastructure to facilitate its evolution.

site_title: Thailand plans tax measures to spur investment: finance minister
summary: Thailand's finance minister plans to propose tax incentives to boost private investment this year and next, aiming to revive the country's stagnant economy. With exports and domestic demand sluggish, the government seeks to drive investment and close the gap between public and private sectors. Tax benefits will be offered for various industries, including building, machinery, computers, and cars, to encourage firms to improve productivity and compete globally. The goal is to strengthen Thailand's fundamentals over the next 10 to 20 years and support economic growth, which is expected to reach 2.8% for 2015.

site_title: PSA develops advanced technologies
summary: PSA Singapore Terminals, in collaboration with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, is developing advanced technologies to enhance efficiency and sustainability in the port environment. The company is investing in research and development, including driverless automated guided vehicles (AGVs), automated cranes, and renewable energy solutions. The goal is to improve manpower productivity, reduce emissions, and create job opportunities for tech-savvy Singaporeans. The new Tuas Terminal, set to become the world's largest container transhipment hub, will be equipped with these innovative technologies, aiming to reduce reliance on conventional fuels and promote a clean port.

site_title: ARA sets up third private Reit in South Korea
summary: ARA Asset Management has launched its third private real estate investment trust (Reit) in South Korea, ARA ShinYoung Residential Development Real Estate Investment Company. The Reit invests in homes in Seoul, with its first investment completed in a residential development project valued at approximately 43 billion won (S$52.7 million). ARA Korea, the subsidiary managing the Reit, is mandated to oversee its investments, marking the third privately-held Korean Reit wholly managed by ARA.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index losing 4.14 points to 1,706.79, due to a 466-402 loss of gainers to losers. 1.9 billion lots valued at RM1.8 billion were traded.

site_title: Drones to circle Australian beaches to monitor sharks
summary: Australia has launched a five-year plan to combat shark attacks along its eastern coast, with a focus on monitoring and safety measures. Drones will circle popular beaches to track tagged sharks, while "listening stations" use 4G technology to monitor shark movements. The A$16 million plan includes sonar detecting buoys, boosted helicopter surveillance, and research into new technologies to deter sharks. The initiative aims to minimize harm to sharks while keeping beachgoers safe, following a spate of 13 shark attacks in New South Wales this year, resulting in one death and seven injuries.

site_title: US new home sales drop to near one-year low
summary: US single-family home sales dropped 11.5% to 468,000 units in September, the lowest level since November 2014. This decline follows two months of gains and suggests a temporary cooling in the market. Despite this, the housing market remains strong, with existing home sales, builder confidence, and housing starts showing positive trends. The moderation in new home sales may be temporary, and the economy is supported by a sturdy housing market, which is helping to soften the blow from global growth and weak capital spending.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks close higher after rate cut
summary: Shanghai stocks rose 0.50% after China cut interest rates for the sixth time in a year, ahead of a Communist party policy meeting. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 17.15 points to 3,429.58, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.68% to 2,030.48. The rate cut is seen as a sign of the government's efforts to boost economic growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower
summary: Europe's major stock markets declined Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.25% to 6,428 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 losing 0.03% and 0.31% respectively. The decline follows a pre-weekend bounce fueled by expectations of economic stimulus for the eurozone. China's interest rate cut also boosted markets on Friday. The region's markets are now under pressure from bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality to launch Modena brand in Bangkok
summary: Frasers Hospitality is set to launch its serviced residence brand, Modena by Fraser, in Bangkok with the opening of Modena by Fraser Bangkok in 2016. The 239-unit property caters to "road warrior" business travelers seeking affordable home comforts, with eco-friendly amenities and provincially sourced goods. Modena by Fraser has previously proven successful in China, and its introduction in Thailand aims to appeal to socially conscious millennials. The brand's expansion is part of Frasers Hospitality's target to achieve 30,000 residence units over the next four years.

site_title: Singapore must prepare for economic slowdown: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has warned the country must prepare for a possible economic slowdown due to global headwinds, including a stagnant US economy and a slowdown in China. The country's exports are flat, and its GDP expanded only 1.4% in the last quarter. Lee cited globalisation and technological advancements as twin challenges, which are putting pressure on wages and causing job displacement. He emphasized that Singapore, a developed economy, must "ride the wave" of progress and use free markets to its advantage, and urged the government, employers, and unions to work together to address the challenges ahead.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee believes the way forward for Singapore is not to resist globalisation, but to ride the power of free markets to its advantage.

site_title: Labour movement and civil service to start long-term staff exchange
summary: The labour movement and civil service in Singapore will start exchanging staff in long-term postings from the end of this year, bolstering their already-strong relationship. This move aims to promote mutual understanding and cooperation between the two sectors.

site_title: Hot stock: Addvalue Technologies shares surge on major pact inked
summary: Addvalue Technologies shares surged 25% to 6.5 cents after the company signed a memorandum of understanding with China International Security Solution Corporation Limited to develop and supply satellite communication-based solutions for China's "One Belt One Road" initiative. The collaboration is expected to forge a win-win partnership between the two companies, with Addvalue tasked to design and supply satellite communication products to meet the complex communication and monitoring demands of CSS. The shares rebounded from a downward trend since the beginning of the year.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% up on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% on Monday, closing at 3,083.07 points. The index received a boost after China eased monetary policy, cutting interest rates and reserve requirements. The bluechip index saw a gradual decline throughout the day. The most actively traded stock, New Silkroutes, finished flat. Gainers outnumbered losers 230 to 185, with an average unit price of S$0.62 per share.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's electricity market will be fully liberalized by 2018, allowing all consumers to choose their own electricity retailers. Industrial output declined 4.8% year-on-year in September, exceeding market expectations. Oxley Holdings and FSL Trust announced bond and MOU deals, respectively. Meanwhile, ValueMax filed a police report on a probable case of criminal breach of trust by an employee. The Straits Times Index closed 0.5% higher on Monday.

images.alt_text: Singapore's electricity market will be fully liberalised by 2018, with all consumers including households being able to choose their own electricity retailers, said Minister for Trade and Industry (Industry) S Iswaran on Monday.

site_title: Seoul: Shares climb as China rate cut lifts sentiment
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.4% on Monday as China's interest rate cut provided assurance of ample liquidity in global financial markets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,048.08 points. The South Korean won strengthened against the dollar, closing at 1,133.8 to the dollar. The rate cut is seen as a positive sign for the region's markets, which have been influenced by US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Three Singaporean companies' stock prices were analyzed: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT), Sheng Siong Group, and United Engineers. FCOT's Q4 FY2015 results exceeded expectations, with a 16.9% increase in gross revenue and 14% in distribution per unit. Analysts from OCBC Investment Research and UOB Kay Hian reiterate "buy" recommendations with target prices ranging from S$1.59 to S$2.25. Analysts also expect growth in FY2016, driven by built-in step-up rents and store makeovers.

site_title: Sausages, ham are cancer-causing, red meat 'probably' too: UN agency
summary: A World Health Organization arm, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, has found that consuming sausages, ham, and processed meats may increase the risk of colon cancer. Red meat is "probably" also a cancer-causing agent. The agency based its findings on over 800 studies and recommends limiting meat intake. The global impact of these findings on cancer incidence is considered of public health importance, especially given the high consumption of processed meats worldwide.

site_title: Update: China online travel firms Ctrip and Qunar in share-swap deal
summary: China's largest online travel firms, Ctrip and Qunar, have agreed to a share-swap deal to create the country's biggest internet travel service. Baidu, which controls Qunar, will own 25% of Ctrip, while Ctrip will own 45% of Qunar, valuing Qunar at $7 billion. The deal aims to drive synergy through consolidation in the travel market, driven by China's expanding middle class and fierce competition for online bookings.

site_title: US: Stocks flat ahead of Fed meeting
summary: US stocks remained flat on Monday ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 18 points at 17,629. The S&P 500 dipped 6 points to 2,069, while the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 5 points at 5,026. Earnings reports from ExxonMobil, Chevron, and Apple are expected to shape market sentiment, with the Fed likely to keep interest rates unchanged but provide further guidance on future rate hikes.

site_title: Communist conclave seeks leaner, cleaner China
summary: China's Communist leaders gathered for the Fifth Plenum, focusing on addressing economic malaise and pollution. The nation's slowest growth rate since the global financial crisis, coupled with structural inefficiencies, prompted the gathering. Official media reported a surprise interest rate cut, but the meeting's key outcome remains unclear. The plenum aims to chart China's course for the next five years, with policymakers under pressure to address growing concerns about the country's economic and environmental stability.

site_title: Ample crude supplies until mid-2016: IEA chief
summary: IEA executive director Fatih Birol said oil supplies will remain ample until mid-2016, despite low prices. Oil investment is expected to decline further, down 20% worldwide this year, and another drop in 2016. Geopolitical tensions in the Middle East pose a risk to prices, but Birol emphasized that short-term focus on oil security should not be prioritized. The market is expected to remain supplied due to record production by Opec and a strong dollar, but ongoing troubles in the region could disrupt supplies.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on China rate cut, upbeat Japan earnings
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.65% on Monday, following a global rally triggered by China's interest rate cut. Major Japanese firms, including Panasonic and Hitachi, reported bumper profits, contributing to the gains. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 121.82 points to 18,947.12, while the broader Topix index closed up 0.72%. The rally comes as investors look to emerging markets for growth opportunities.

site_title: Japan Post Holdings prices IPO at top of range, raising US$5.7b
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co priced its IPO at 1,400 yen apiece, raising $5.7 billion, at the top of a 1,100-1,400 yen range. This follows the top-of-range pricing of its banking and insurance arms. The IPO will raise 693 billion yen, with proceeds used to fund Japan's reconstruction programs. The three stocks will begin trading on November 4.

site_title: German business confidence little changed in October: Ifo
summary: German business confidence remained little changed in October, falling to 108.2 points from 108.5 points in September, according to the Ifo economic institute. This represents a shallower drop than analysts had anticipated. The resilience of Europe's largest economy amidst numerous challenges suggests ongoing stability, but the results may indicate potential future challenges.

site_title: Peugeot says it never cheated on emissions as its car sales rise
summary: Peugeot denies cheating on diesel emissions, stating it has never fitted vehicles with software to turn on emissions controls only during testing. The French carmaker reported a 3.2% increase in third-quarter revenue and raised its full-year European market growth forecast to 8% from 6%. Peugeot plans to publish real-world fuel economy figures vetted by an independent body for its diesel vehicles soon. The company reiterated mid-term targets, including an operating margin of 2% in 2018, and expressed confidence in reaching its targets despite a difficult economic environment.

site_title: NEA, Hyflux-Mitsubishi consortium sign waste-to-energy services deal
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) signed a 25-year waste-to-energy services agreement with a consortium led by Hyflux and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI). The consortium will build Singapore's sixth waste-to-energy plant, with a capacity to incinerate 3,600 tonnes of waste and generate 120MW of electricity daily. Construction is expected to start in 2016 and end in 2019, with the plant being the largest and most land-efficient.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down after China rate cut
summary: Hong Kong shares closed down 0.2% on Monday, following China's interest rate cut and bank reserve ratio reduction on Friday. The Hang Seng index fell to 23,116.25, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.1%. The total trading volume was 1.5 billion shares. The rate cut was seen as a positive move for China's economy, but had a negative impact on Hong Kong stocks.

site_title: Testing of new train caused power fault that led to 2-hour NEL disruption during Monday rush hour
summary: A two-hour train disruption on Singapore's North-East Line (NEL) occurred on Monday morning due to a new train's power fault during testing. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) found that the train damaged the overhead catenary system as it was withdrawn to the depot. The incident caused a significant disruption during the rush hour.

site_title: China leaders meet for five-year plan amid calls for reform
summary: China's Communist leaders gathered for the Fifth Plenum, a five-year plan meeting, amid slowing growth and structural inefficiencies. The meeting aims to address economic malaise, pollution, and public discontent. The plan includes loosening remaining economic controls and considering reforms to the one-child policy. Analysts call for broader structural reforms to sustain long-term expansion, as the ruling party's legitimacy depends on projecting competence. The meeting also discussed changes to the party's upper ranks, following a widespread anti-corruption drive.

site_title: LTA to raise ERP rates at 3 gantries along AYE after Jurong Town Hall towards city
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will double the Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) rates at three gantries along the Ayer Rajah Expressway (AYE) from Nov 2, increasing the rate to S$2 during 6pm to 6.30pm. The rates for other gantries remain unchanged. The revised rates follow LTA's quarterly review of traffic conditions. The next ERP review is scheduled for mid-November.

site_title: Dollar dips after rally, but improved risk appetite curbs losse
summary: The US dollar dipped 0.2% to 96.953 on Monday after reaching a 2-1/2-month high, but was limited by improved risk appetite following China's monetary easing. The euro rose 0.2% to $1.1035 after falling to its lowest since August 11. The US Federal Reserve makes a policy decision on Wednesday, with expectations of no interest rate hike. Meanwhile, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand meets on Thursday and the Bank of Japan on Friday, with speculation of potential monetary easing.

site_title: Australia: Shares tip-toe higher as uncertainty takes shine off China cut
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, despite caution about the global economy, following China's decision to cut rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,368.3, its highest level in four sessions. Banks led gains, while miners and steelmakers also rose. However, analysts expressed disappointment, citing muted market response and weak commodity prices. Despite this, BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto gained, while Telstra and Woolworths also moved.

site_title: China, Japan, South Korea to hold first summit in three years
summary: China, Japan, and South Korea will hold their first summit in three years on November 1 in Seoul, South Korea, marking a significant step towards improving ties between the three nations. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang will visit South Korea from October 31 to November 2, during which he will meet with South Korean President Park Geun-hye. The trilateral summit aims to clear obstacles to better relations with Japan, particularly regarding Japan's wartime past and territorial disputes. This marks a positive development in Northeast Asia, with the three countries seeking to restore cooperation and stability.

site_title: Singapore rail system needs more street-smart engineers: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore's rail system requires more "street-smart engineers" to improve train reliability, Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan stated after a two-hour train breakdown on the North-East Line. He emphasized the need to "catch rats" - referring to skilled engineers - to enhance the system's performance. The minister reiterates the government's commitment to improving train reliability to meet Singaporeans' expectations.

images.alt_text: Singapore's rail system needs more "rat catchers" - a reference to street-smart engineers, Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan said in a blog post following a train disruption on Monday (Oct 26) morning.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as global unease cuts China rate rally short
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Monday as global concerns cut short a rally sparked by China's interest rate cut. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 3.6 points or 0.1% to 5,348.0, down 1.2% for the year and 11% from its peak in March. Despite initial gains, the benchmark retreated as investors weighed the impact of the global economic uncertainty.
