site_title: No penalty for being late for national exams due to major train service disruption: SEAB
summary: The Singapore Examinations and Assessment Board (SEAB) has announced that students who were late for national exams due to a major train service disruption will not be penalized. SEAB has contingency plans in place, including allowing candidates to take their papers at other nearby schools or examination centers. Most affected candidates arrived within 30 minutes of the exam start and were given the full duration of their papers. Schools and examination centers are prepared to accept late candidates from other centers under such situations.

site_title: Trading halts: Biosensors, Addvalue
summary: Trading has been halted for shares of Addvalue Technologies and Biosensors International Group pending their respective announcements. No specific details about the announcements are provided in the article.

site_title: Addvalue to provide communication solutions with HK firm in China-Pakistan project
summary: Addvalue Technologies has entered into a memorandum of understanding with China International Security Solution Corporation Limited to jointly develop and supply satellite communication-based solutions for the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) project. The CPEC aims to connect Gwadar Port in Pakistan to Kashgar in China via a network of highways, railways, and optic fiber networks. Addvalue will design and supply satellite communication products to meet the complex communication demands of CSS, while both companies will provide reliable satellite communication solutions and services required by the CPEC project.

site_title: StanChart says to exit equity derivatives, convertibles businesses
summary: Standard Chartered plans to exit its equity derivatives and convertible bonds businesses, part of a plan to cut costs and focus on efficient capital use. This move follows the bank's earlier decision to close its global equities operations and axe thousands of jobs. The wind-down will take place in a phased manner. The bank aims to reduce costs and improve its capital efficiency.

site_title: Low costs keep IndiGo flying high in India's cut-throat airline market
summary: Indian budget airline IndiGo is set to launch a $465 million initial public offer, making it the largest IPO in India since 2012 and valuing the company at $4 billion. The airline's low-cost strategy has allowed it to consistently post profits, dodging high operating costs and taxes that have grounded other carriers. With a 34% market share, IndiGo's focus on on-time flights, low fuel costs, and cost-efficient operations has contributed to its success, making it an attractive investment opportunity in India's competitive aviation market.

images.alt_text: An IndiGo Airlines Airbus A320 aircraft is pictured parked at a gate at Mumbai's Chhatrapathi Shivaji International Airport in this Feb 3, 2013.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong: Stocks rally on China easing
summary: China's Shanghai, Hong Kong stock markets rallied on Monday after China cut borrowing costs and removed a cap on savings rates to boost competition. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.06%, the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.27%, and the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong added 1.17%. The moves follow China's efforts to stimulate economic growth and improve financial stability.

site_title: Chinese investment bank CICC launches up to US$811m HK IPO: IFR
summary: Chinese investment bank CICC has launched a US$811 million initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, with cornerstone investors pledging over half of the deal. The IPO includes 611 million shares at HK$9.12 to HK$10.28 each, with Silk Road Fund, Baosteel Group, and China Mobile Ltd among the investors. CICC and its shareholder, China's National Social Security Fund, will offer shares to the public in the coming months.

site_title: Singapore's electricity retail market to be fully opened to competition by 2018
summary: Singapore's electricity retail market will be fully opened to competition by 2018, allowing 1.3 million households to choose their own electricity retailers. The Energy Market Authority has progressively liberalized the market since 2001, with 33,000 commercial and industrial consumers already participating in the contestable market. Two consultation papers were issued to prepare for future power generation investments and a proposed secondary gas trading market. The market will enhance Singapore's position as a hub for LNG and gas trading activities and pave the way for a gas futures market in the future.

site_title: Australia investment regulator says looking at manipulation, predatory trading
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, ASIC, is investigating traders for manipulating quarterly futures expiries and predatory trading against clients. The regulator has raised concerns about high-frequency trading and dark liquidity pools, but found current levels are not affecting market function. ASIC has asked the Australian Securities Exchange to discourage the practice and will continue to monitor and enforce market misconduct laws. The regulator has also noted a significant growth in high-frequency trading in the futures market, with dark liquidity remaining relatively constant.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend global rally after China adds to stimulus
summary: Asian stocks rose after China unexpectedly cut interest rates and lowered reserve requirements, boosting the Australian dollar and yen. The move, seen as a sign of the Chinese economy facing downward pressure, also led to a decline in the US dollar and a rise in the yuan. Global stocks extended their rally, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index up 0.3% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates on Wednesday, but traders are pricing in a 6% chance of this happening.

site_title: ValueMax files police report on an outlet employee
summary: ValueMax Group has filed a police report after discovering a probable case of criminal breach of trust by an outlet employee. The incident is believed to be isolated and does not affect pledges at the outlet. The amount involved is estimated to be less than 0.3% of the group's net tangible assets and is not expected to impact the group's financials. ValueMax will monitor the police investigation and make further announcements as necessary.

site_title: Oil prices drop, demand seen sagging towards year-end
summary: Crude oil prices dropped in early Asian trading on Monday, with US front-month futures trading at $44.58 per barrel and Brent at $47.95 per barrel. Speculators cut their bets on rising prices, citing weak demand outlooks and oversupply. ANZ bank and research firm Energy Aspects forecast a slowdown in global oil demand in Q4, leading to reduced refinery production and lower oil use. The market is expected to remain low for the remainder of the year due to the ongoing oversupply and reduced demand conditions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.42 points to 1715.3. The market saw 155 gainers for every 48 losers, with a trading volume of 48.3 million lots worth RM18.9 million.

site_title: Oxley to issue up to S$125m in 4-year bonds
summary: OXLEY Holdings Limited plans to issue up to S$125 million in four-year 5% bonds due 2019, with up to S$100 million for public offering and S$25 million for institutional investors. DBS Bank is the sole lead manager and bookrunner for the offer. The Singapore Exchange has granted in-principle approval for the listing and quotation of the bonds, subject to conditions.

site_title: Singapore shares open 27.5 points higher on Monday
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index opened 27.51 points higher, or 0.9%, at 3,095.97 on Monday, extending gains from Friday following China's interest rate cut and big banks' reserve requirement ratio reduction. Investors will monitor the Chinese Communist Party's five-year plan meeting and the Federal Reserve's policy meeting for clues on global economy and interest rate decisions. Gainers included Noble Group, Debao Property, and YuuZoo, with 97.8 million shares worth S$83 million changing hands in morning trading.

site_title: Yellen, consensus-builder, needs to send strong signal at Fed meet
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen may need to send a stronger signal at this week's policy meeting to keep a December interest rate rise in play. Recent public disagreements with fellow governors Lael Brainard and Daniel Tarullo, who expressed concerns about economic growth risks, have raised questions about the Fed's unified stance. Yellen's inclusive style has been tested, and her ability to maintain a strong consensus among the Fed's policy-making panel will be crucial in determining the Fed's interest rate trajectory.

site_title: Gold struggles on firmer dollar, Fed rate hike fears
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,162.25 an ounce due to a stronger US dollar and concerns about a potential Federal Reserve rate hike this year. The metal initially rose after China cut interest rates, but quickly dropped after the dollar reached its highest in 2.5 months. Investors now believe a rate hike is more likely, which could reduce gold's appeal as a non-interest-yielding asset. The Fed holds a policy meeting later this week, and investors will be watching for clues on its stance on the global economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open up 1.12%
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.12% on Monday, following gains on Wall Street amid speculation of potential central bank stimulus. The Nikkei 225 index gained 210.83 points to 19,036.13. This comes as US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. Traders appear to be brushing off new Trump threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: BlueScope to buy Cargill's North Star stake for US$720m
summary: BlueScope Steel Ltd, Australia's largest steelmaker, agreed to buy Cargill's remaining 50% stake in US-based North Star BlueScope Steel LLC for US$720 million. The deal gives BlueScope full ownership of North America's most profitable mill, boosting cash flow and earnings. Despite falling steel prices, the acquisition is expected to boost earnings due to rising demand in the domestic construction industry. BlueScope also announced plans to maintain steel production in Australia after agreeing cost reductions at its Port Kembla site.

site_title: Raffles Medical's Q3 profit up 1.2%
summary: RAFFLES Medical Group reported a 1.2% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$15.6 million in Q3, driven by 7.4% growth in revenue from hospitality and healthcare services. The group maintained a healthy cash position of S$89.5 million, with investments in capital expenditure and expansion projects. Raffles Medical Group is also expected to benefit from its acquisition of International SOS, with 10 clinics set to be operated under the group's brand in the near future.

images.alt_text: Raffles Medical Group marked a 1.2 per cent year-on-year rise in net profit to S$15.6 million in the third quarter ended Sept 30.

site_title: Chinese financial markets cautiously applaud rate cuts
summary: China's major financial markets cautiously reacted to the PBOC's rate cuts, with stocks, bonds, and currency trading volumes subdued. The PBOC lowered the one-year benchmark bank lending rate by 25 basis points to 4.35% and the deposit rate by 25 basis points to 1.50%, aiming to support consumption and reduce investment. The move aims to stabilize the economy amid uncertain economic fundamentals, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: NEL service disrupted second time in a month
summary: Trains on the North-East line in Singapore partially resumed service after a second disruption this month due to a power fault. The halt occurred on Monday morning, and free bus rides were offered at designated stops. The disruptions add to recent issues, leading some to call for the former Transport Minister's resignation. The incident follows a similar halt on October 13, and Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan emphasized the importance of maintenance in keeping the complex transportation system running.

site_title: YuuZoo's JV to co-organise China e-sports competition
summary: YuuZoo Corporation Limited has secured the rights to co-organise the China Internet Gaming (CIG) 2015 e-sports competition with www.9eplay.com and the Ministry of Industry and Internet Technology. The event, set to start in November 2015, will feature 60 teams from 15 provinces competing for a prize of 3.5 million yuan. YuuGames, the joint venture, will receive a fee to organise the event in four provinces and market it across nine provinces, generating revenue for YuuZoo through new users, promotional fees, and advertising.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Medical, Oxley, YuuZoo
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 1.2% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$15.6 million in the third quarter, driven by 7.4% growth in group revenue. Oxley Holdings announced an offer of up to S$125 million of four-year 5% bonds. YuuZoo Corporation secured the rights to co-organise the China Internet Gaming (CIG) 2015 e-sports competition with the Ministry of Industry and Internet Technology. These developments are expected to be under trading focus on a quiet Monday morning.

site_title: FSL Trust in MOU to buy product tanker for US$21.8m
summary: FIRST Ship Lease Trust has entered into a memorandum of agreement to purchase a 2007 Japanese-built, 45,998-dwt product tanker for US$21.8 million. The acquisition is expected to be financed through existing cash reserves and will deliver an annual cash-on-cash yield of 14.5% based on a conservative TCE of US$16,500 per day over three years. This will bring FSL Trust's fleet to 24 vessels, including product tankers, containerships, and crude oil tankers. The vessel is expected to be delivered between November 1 and January 31.

site_title: Airbus boss calls on Germany to open up labour market to refugees
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders calls on Germany to deregulate its labor market to help refugees integrate into society. He suggests creating lower-paid jobs and making exceptions for the minimum wage to allow refugees to enter the labor market quickly. Enders believes this will prevent integration failure and frustration. Some economists argue the influx of migrants could provide skilled labor, boosting economic growth, particularly in areas with shortages.

site_title: A China twist: why are malls closing if consumption is rising?
summary: China's malls, despite rising retail sales, are closing due to competition from online shopping and government purchases artificially boosting statistics. Vacancy rates and plummeting rents are common, and poorly managed properties are exacerbating the issue. The struggles of brick-and-mortar retailers amplify China's corporate debt problem, currently at 160% of GDP. The construction of new malls, largely driven by local governments, has led to an oversupply of retail space, threatening the banks with non-performing loans.

site_title: Singapore Sept factory output declines 4.8%, worse than forecast
summary: Singapore's industrial output declined 4.8% year-on-year in September, exceeding market expectations. The decline was attributed to all clusters, excluding biomedical manufacturing, which posted a 10.2% drop. The electronics cluster, which accounts for 33.4% of the index, continued to contract, with a 8.6% decline in semiconductor output. Transport engineering was the worst-performing cluster, with a 24% drop in output. Adjusting for seasonal factors, industrial production increased 0.5%, but the month-on-month growth was worse than forecast.

images.alt_text: Singapore's industrial output declined 4.8 per cent year-on-year in September, falling more than the market's expectations.

site_title: 1.4t yen Japan Post IPOs to unlock funds stashed away by households
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co's initial public offerings (IPOs) of its banking and insurance units raised up to 1.4 trillion yen, with most shares bought by individuals, aiming to shift their portfolio from deposits to equities. The government's goal is to increase risk appetite and boost the stock market, as Japan's households hold a record 1.717 trillion yen in assets, with just 11% in shares. The IPOs are seen as a catalyst to increase investment in equities, with some experts predicting a significant buying spree from passive funds and individual investors.

site_title: Alibaba results likely to dim outlook for China consumer spending
summary: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd's second-quarter revenue growth is expected to slump to half the year-earlier rate, potentially undermining hopes that consumer spending will temper a slowdown in China's economy. The company's revenue is forecast to be 21.3 billion yuan, a 26.7% increase from last year, but this would be a slowdown from the 53.7% growth in the same quarter last year. This could cloud the outlook for consumer spending, which accounts for 60% of China's economic growth, and raises concerns about the country's economic rebalancing efforts.

site_title: Ex-Rabobank traders to testify in own defence in Libor trial
summary: Two former Rabobank traders, Anthony Allen and Anthony Conti, will testify in their own defense in the US trial for manipulating Libor interest rates. The traders, who face charges of conspiracy and wire fraud, plan to call expert witnesses and intend to testify themselves, with Allen to discuss his voluntary extradition and Conti to testify to his involvement in the alleged scheme. The defense move comes as prosecutors prepare to rest their case by Monday.

site_title: Najib relies on populist playbook in attempt to offset scandals
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak proposed a populist budget with handouts and subsidies to boost support from poorer, rural-based Malays, amid a funding scandal that has eroded investor confidence. The budget includes cash handouts, higher pay and bonuses, and subsidies for specific groups, but critics say it lacks meaningful economic reforms and may divert attention from scandals. The move is seen as Najib's attempt to maintain power, particularly among ethnic Malay voters, ahead of the 2018 election.

site_title: China banks come back for more capital as bad loans pile up
summary: China's banks are raising capital to combat a surge in bad loans, with commercial banks issuing expensive preference shares and bonds to shore up their capital buffers. The number of bad loans has increased 30% in the first half of 2015, prompting concerns about the ability of some banks to withstand the economic slowdown. China's listed commercial lenders raised a record $57.6 billion last year, but may need to raise an additional $121.7 billion to bolster their capital. The central bank's decision to cut interest rates has also worsened operating profit margins.

site_title: Switched on
summary: BT, a business news outlet, has launched a Telegram channel for daily updates and weekend content. Meanwhile, oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty, while gold prices increased after US President Trump announced tariffs on Canada and threatened others. China's solar stocks surged as Beijing attempts to calm price wars. OPEC announced it will trim oil demand for the next four years.

site_title: India to step up dividend pressure on state-run firms
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley plans to step up pressure on state-run companies to pay higher dividends to meet the government's budget deficit target. Weak tax revenues, higher spending, and lackluster asset sales have made it harder for the government to invest, with dividends expected to be at least 30% of net profits. The move aims to bolster growth, which remains below potential, and reduce the budget deficit to 3.9% of GDP, although economists warn that cutting expenses, including infrastructure spending, may be necessary.

site_title: Walmart plays catch-up with Amazon
summary: Walmart has acknowledged its struggle to compete with Amazon in the e-commerce market, investing $2 billion to improve its online capabilities. The retail giant's sales growth has stagnated, while Amazon's revenue has surged, with Amazon's stock now exceeding Walmart's by over $70 billion. Walmart's efforts to match Amazon's fast delivery and competitive pricing have been hindered by its lack of tech expertise. Despite its massive store network and distribution capabilities, Walmart faces significant challenges in adapting to the rapidly changing retail landscape, with many experts questioning its ability to compete with Amazon's innovative approach.

site_title: India budget carrier IndiGo seeks to raise 30b rupees in IPO
summary: India's budget carrier IndiGo plans to raise 30 billion rupees (S$643 million) in its initial public offering (IPO) to fund expansion, despite the country's challenging aviation market. IndiGo has become the only consistently profitable carrier in India, known for its cheap fares and punctuality, with 40% market share. The airline's success is attributed to its focus on efficiency, fuel-efficient planes, and a no-frills approach. The IPO will value the airline at about US$4 billion, and the proceeds will be used to pay down debt and fuel further expansion.

site_title: The next big thing in Korean beauty: muscles
summary: In South Korea, the traditional beauty ideal is shifting as women increasingly prioritize physical fitness. The country's cosmetics industry, worth $12 billion, is seeing a growth in health products and fitness-related businesses. Women are hitting the gym to improve muscle tone and physical health, with celebrity trainers and fitness influencers promoting a more robust physique. This trend is driven by changing societal attitudes, with women now having higher social status and more roles in society, and being influenced by global figures such as Michelle Obama and Kate Middleton.

site_title: Abe seeks 'bold proposals' to raise Japan's birthrate
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has ordered his new minister to propose "bold measures" to boost the country's low birthrate, aiming to stabilize the population at 100 million by 2065. The working-age population is expected to shrink 40% in 45 years, threatening the country's labor force and elderly care system. Abe's new plan includes measures to encourage people to have more children, but details have not been released yet.

site_title: Copper, nickel retreat after touching one-week highs
summary: Copper prices fell on Friday after a strong US dollar offset optimism from China's interest rate cut. The People's Bank of China cut interest rates for the sixth time in under a year to boost its slowing economy, but gains were short-lived as the US dollar index hit a two-month high, making commodities more expensive for foreign buyers. Copper prices retreated from a one-week high, while the US dollar index reached a two-month high.

site_title: Good directors hard to find
summary: A good director possesses innate qualities such as motivation, good character, and sound judgment, as well as competencies like strong communication skills, financial literacy, and risk management expertise. Performance focus is also crucial, with directors needing to balance compliance with innovation and risk-taking. In times of crisis, a good director's true mettle is revealed, as exemplified by independent directors who rolled up their sleeves to rehabilitate companies such as Citiraya Industries and Olam International. Effective directors must be able to lead, collaborate, and adapt to changing conditions, and demonstrate their value by contributing to the company's growth and success.

site_title: World would be better place if Saddam, Gaddafi still in power: Trump
summary: US presidential hopeful Donald Trump stated that the world would be better off if dictators Saddam Hussein and Muammar Gaddafi were still in power. Trump criticized the Obama and Clinton administration for the Middle East's current state, citing disasters in Iraq, Libya, and Syria. He advocated for a stronger US military and taking Iraq's oil, which he believes China and Iran are now controlling. Trump also clashed with rival Ben Carson, who has surged in the Iowa caucus, and claimed Carson is weak on immigration.

images.alt_text: The world would be a better place if dictators such as Saddam Hussein and Muammar Gaddafi were still in power, top Republican US presidential hopeful Donald Trump said in comments aired Sunday.

site_title: Halep wallops Pennetta in WTA Finals opener
summary: Simona Halep defeated Flavia Pennetta in the opening match of the BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals, winning in straight sets 6-0, 6-3. Halep, the top seed, avenged her previous loss to Pennetta at the US Open. Maria Sharapova also won her second singles match, edging Agnieszka Radwanska 4-6, 6-3, 6-4. The WTA Finals continue on Monday with the top two players from each group advancing to the semi-finals.

site_title: As oil industry bleeds jobs, Asia's green energy drive offers bright spot
summary: Renewable energy jobs are booming, with record hiring in solar, wind, and hydro power, partly offsetting massive job losses in the oil and gas sector. Asia, led by China and India, is driving the growth, with 18% global job growth in renewables last year. The oil sector, however, is suffering its worst downturn since the late 1990s, with over 200,000 jobs cut worldwide since last year. Experts predict that renewable energy could create up to 16 million global jobs by 2030, compared to the oil and gas sector's decline.

images.alt_text: Renewables are powering a rare bright spot in the energy industry, with record job hiring in solar, wind and hydro partly offsetting the biggest round of job losses in the oil and gas sector in almost two decades.

site_title: Hollywood actress Maureen O'Hara, 95, dies
summary: Maureen O'Hara, a 95-year-old Hollywood actress known for her iconic roles in films like "How Green Was My Valley" and "Miracle on 34th Street," has died of natural causes at home in Boise, Idaho. Born in Dublin in 1920, O'Hara was a dual US-Irish citizen who starred in over 60 films and was awarded an honorary Oscar in 2014. Her family said she passed peacefully surrounded by loved ones, and Irish President Michael Higgins described her as an "outstanding and versatile actress."

site_title: Getting on the road to economic development with Karakoram Highway
summary: China is investing billions of dollars in Pakistan's Karakoram Highway, part of its "Belt and Road" economic development strategy, aiming to bolster its economy, discourage separatism, and establish a bridge-head in Asia. The highway will provide a shorter sea route to customers in the West, giving Chinese commerce a back door. China plans to spend $46 billion on various projects, including energy and infrastructure development, to lift Pakistan towards prosperity and counter the influence of the US. The project has the potential to reduce transport times, increase jobs, and make it harder for separatist groups to thrive, but analysts are skeptical about its success.

site_title: Retro fine-dining
summary: The 1919 Waterboat House restaurant attempts to evoke the magic of the Art Deco era with its retro fine-dining concept, but its food falls short. Despite a well-meaning and hospitable staff, the restaurant's dishes are marred by generic ingredients and poor execution. Standout dishes include the creamy cauliflower soup and the Bar d'Atlantique's crispy sea bass, but the overall experience is let down by supermarket-quality bread and lackluster seafood. The restaurant's potential is hindered by its outdated location and over-reliance on novelty value.

site_title: First global meet on tripartism in Singapore
summary: Singapore is hosting the first global conference on tripartism, a concept that involves cooperation between governments, employers, and workers to promote harmonious labor relations. Over 800 participants from 14 countries, including ILO director-general Guy Ryder and senior representatives from Denmark, Singapore, and other nations, will attend the International Forum on Tripartism. The conference, which runs until Tuesday, aims to share experiences and best practices on strengthening tripartism for economic growth and social progress. Keynote speakers will discuss the importance of tripartism in driving sustainable growth and development.

site_title: VW freezing promotions due to emissions scandal: report
summary: Volkswagen is freezing managerial promotions and reusing parts to save hundreds of millions of euros due to the cost of a diesel emissions scandal. The German company now estimates the scandal's costs at 30 billion euros, mostly attributed to the VW brand, with plans to cut investment and speed up cost-cutting measures. Efforts to improve productivity and efficiency at VW plants may lead to job losses, with no agreed headcount cuts with workers' representatives so far.

site_title: China rate cut, dovish ECB to drive markets
summary: The US Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee is set to meet, with no expected rate hike, fueling a rebound in major indices. China's central bank has cut interest rates and injected liquidity, while the European Central Bank's Mario Draghi has hinted at maintaining stimulus. The actions are expected to weaken the yuan and boost stock markets. Market players are advised to stick to the 30 Straits Times Index (STI) members, watching for signs that the mood is switching to "bad news is bad for stocks." The Fed's decision will also be influenced by the upcoming US Q3 GDP figures.

images.alt_text: A Chinese national flag flutters outside the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the Chinese central bank, in Beijing, in this Apr 3, 2014 file photo.

site_title: Tech spats spark fears of 'digital protectionism'
summary: US technology giants are facing growing concerns over "digital protectionism" in the European Union, with tensions rising over issues like data transfer, antitrust, and online platforms. The EU's highest court invalidated a key data-sharing agreement, sparking fears of increased regulations and barriers to US companies like Google, Facebook, and Uber. EU officials argue that new regulations are necessary to protect consumers and producers, while US officials see this as a form of censorship and protectionism, threatening the transatlantic digital economy.

site_title: Citibank to showcase BT budding artists' work on its calendars and hongbao
summary: Citibank Singapore has partnered with The Business Times Budding Artists Fund to feature 12 young artists' work on its 2016 calendar and Lunar New Year red packets. The artists, aged 7-19, created pieces on themes of "Transformation and innovation in banking" and "Spring Flowers". The bank's contribution to the fund is S$1.6 million, supporting over 500 children and youth in arts training programmes. The collaboration aims to nurture young talent and provide opportunities for financially-disadvantaged children to showcase their artistic skills.

site_title: New SSA chief eyes bigger S'pore role
summary: Singapore aims to establish itself as a major maritime finance hub, with new SSA president Esben Poulsson promoting listings on the Singapore Exchange and encouraging ship owners to comply with the sulphur cap. The country has already seen success in this area, with over 130 international shipping groups setting up operational bases and a 470-member SSA. Poulsson believes the time is ripe for Singapore to break into the top tier of maritime finance, particularly as investor appetite for maritime listings has waned on Oslo Bors and the NYSE.

site_title: Cash-starved mines draw new money on bet metal slump ending soon
summary: Mining companies, including Glencore and Barrick Gold, are selling future metal production to secure funding amid the commodity slump. Investors like Blackstone Group and Caisse de Depot et Placement Du Quebec are drawn to these "streams" of metal, which can provide secure supplies at low prices for years to come. The demand for these deals is expected to reach $6 billion, with specialists like Franco-Nevada Corp and Silver Wheaton Corp struggling to meet the need for funding.

site_title: Veteran fund manager retires
summary: Veteran fund manager Tan Chin Hwee, 44, has retired from operational duties at Apollo Global Management's Asia unit after a 20-year career. He will still be affiliated with the firm and has started his own family office. No details on his future plans are available.

site_title: Stock rally set to continue, unless Fed spoils the party
summary: The US stock market is expected to continue its rally, with the S&P 500 up over 8% for October, its sixth-largest gain in history. The European Central Bank's bond buying program and the People's Bank of China's interest rate cuts have contributed to the rally. However, a Federal Reserve interest rate hike on Wednesday could spoil the party. Despite declining third-quarter earnings, the tech sector has performed well, with Microsoft, Alphabet, and Amazon reporting strong earnings. The bulls hope for a "Santa Claus" rally in the last two months of the year, but the dollar's rise and Fed rate hike concerns pose a risk to the market.

site_title: USAA says it is switching to Visa from MasterCard
summary: USAA, a major US financial institution, announced it will switch from MasterCard to Visa, effective 2016. The move aims to eliminate foreign transaction fees on USAA Visa credit cards and provide additional benefits. The switch is a significant blow to MasterCard, as USAA is its largest debit-card issuer with $26 billion in purchases last year. The decision was reportedly made due to economics not making sense for the company and its shareholders.

site_title: Smart gun proponents mount renewed push for technology
summary: Smart gun proponents are pushing for technology to be adopted, following renewed interest in gun safety after high-profile shootings. Ernst Mauch, a renowned firearms engineer, is exploring starting a company to build another smart gun, which allows only authorized users to fire guns. Police groups are eager to test and adopt smart guns, and lawmakers in New Jersey are considering repealing a law mandating smart guns. Proponents claim the technology can reduce street violence, prevent accidents, and eliminate suicides, with 40% of gun owners willing to swap their guns for smart guns, according to a market research firm.

site_title: Lloyds braces itself for fresh £1 billion redress charge
summary: Lloyds Banking Group is expected to take a £1 billion charge for wrongly sold loan insurance in the second half of the year, despite posting a Q3 pre-tax profit of £1.49 billion. This provision, part of a £14.4 billion total, is more than any other lender in Britain's banking scandal. Despite the charge, analysts expect Lloyds to retain its profitability, with 16 recommending investors to buy the shares. The charge comes as the government prepares to sell shares to individuals to return Lloyds to full private ownership.

images.alt_text: Lloyds Banking Group plc will probably take a further £1 billion (S$2.1 billion) charge for wrongly sold loan insurance in the year's second half, undermining efforts to clean up the bank as the government prepares to sell shares to individuals.

site_title: Singapore urges cooperation across nations on haze prevention solutions
summary: Singapore urges cooperation with Indonesia and other Asean countries to prevent haze caused by forest fires. A 40-person team from Singapore helped fight fires in Palembang, Indonesia, and will continue to work with Indonesia on bilateral and regional cooperation. Singapore also plans to pursue legal action against haze-causing companies through the Transboundary Haze Pollution Act. The country emphasizes the need for collective action to prevent the recurrence of haze and mitigate climate change effects.

site_title: As biotech selling spreads, more weakness is seen for US health stocks
summary: Investors are shifting away from the US healthcare sector, with stocks experiencing significant declines. The Nasdaq Biotech Index has fallen 23%, the S&P Health Care Index has lost 12%, and the S&P 500 Health Care Facilities index is down 31%. Fund managers expect pressures such as regulatory threats, disappointing earnings, and higher interest rates to weigh on the sector. Profit warnings from hospital operators have contributed to the decline, with the health facilities index down 13% since October 14. Investors are now expecting a range-bound performance with a slight bias downward.

site_title: Energy firms write down US$6.5b, with more to come
summary: US energy firms have written down $6.5 billion in the third quarter, with more expected. Freeport-McMoRan and Southwestern Energy reported $3.7 billion and $2.8 billion in writedowns, respectively. The writeoffs are due to oil and gas price declines, which have fallen 44% and 35% over the past year. Analysts predict $20 billion in charges among six companies, with most being non-events. The writeoffs will not significantly impact companies with minimal debt covenants linked to book value.

site_title: Supercars may stall on tighter noise limits
summary: Singapore's National Environment Agency (NEA) may enforce stricter noise limits on imported supercars, potentially stalling their operation, starting two years from the announcement. The agency plans to check stationary noise levels and monitor in-use emissions, which could unfairly target high-performance cars. Dealers argue that supercars are rarely used and do not cause excessive noise, and that the measures will discourage the purchase of these vehicles.

site_title: BHP seen approaching M&A 'sweet spot' in hunt for deals
summary: BHP Billiton is seen approaching the "sweet spot" for mergers and acquisitions (M&A) as it hunts for deals, particularly in the oil and copper sectors. The company has secured oil exploration prospects in the US and Australia and is targeting high-quality assets. With commodity prices potentially bottoming, BHP is likely to focus on conventional petroleum and copper assets. The company's CEO, Andrew Mackenzie, has stated that BHP will only consider the best assets and won't overpay, and analysts believe this is the ideal time for M&A in the mining and oil and gas sectors.

images.alt_text: BHP Billiton Ltd is snapping up oil exploration prospects from the US to Australia and flagged last week it's seeking to make further similar investments.

site_title: Germany may be spluttering as EU's engine of recovery
summary: Germany, a key engine of the European Union's recovery, is struggling amid rising debt levels. Despite its reputation for financial stability, France and other EU countries, including Portugal, Italy, Ireland, and Spain, are also facing significant debt issues. The recent Volkswagen emissions scandal has dealt a blow to consumer confidence in Germany's carmakers, potentially affecting the country's economy. German factory orders and exports have declined, and the European Central Bank has urged a weak euro to boost exports. The impact of the scandal and economic woes on Germany's economy remains to be seen.

site_title: VW may offer discounts to owners turning in cars with illicit software, DPA says
summary: Volkswagen may offer discounts to German car owners who turn in affected diesel vehicles with illicit software. The company is recalling 8.5 million vehicles in Europe, with around 2.4 million sold in Germany. The discounts, which could be offered to owners of 1.6 litre diesel engines, aim to stabilize sales and ease pressure on dealerships. A decision has not been made yet, and Volkswagen has stated that special offers for existing customers are common. The move is part of the company's efforts to address the emissions scandal that has rocked the industry.

site_title: Cloud boom boosts Google, Microsoft with surge in stocks
summary: Google, Microsoft, and Amazon have topped profit estimates, boosting their market capitalization by over $90 billion, as the cloud computing boom continues to gain momentum. The trio's reliance on powerful data centers to provide low-cost computing power has enabled them to attract new customers, while traditional technology firms such as IBM and Oracle struggle to keep up. The shift to the cloud is expected to continue, with Google's CEO stating that "every business in the world is going to run on cloud eventually."

site_title: Haze: 24-hour PSI in 'very unhealthy' range on Saturday
summary: Haze covered Singapore on Saturday, with the 24-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) reaching "very unhealthy" levels of 186-229, straddling the unhealthy (101-200) and very unhealthy ranges (201-300). This is the first time in 2025 that the PSI has reached this range.

site_title: Inflation seen eating into salary hikes in Asia-Pac
summary: Inflation is expected to outweigh salary hikes in the Asia-Pacific region in 2016, with companies in Singapore and other countries maintaining pay increases similar to those in 2015. Despite a potentially worsening economy, most countries and cities will see bigger or similar hikes in salary, with an average 6.8% increase. However, when inflation is factored in, workers will likely see a real salary increase of only 3.4%, lower than in 2015.

site_title: Toshiba in talks to sell image sensor business to Sony: Nikkei
summary: Toshiba Corp is in talks to sell its image sensor business to Sony Corp for about 20 billion yen (S$230 million), following accounting irregularities that cut its profit by US$1.3 billion over seven years. Toshiba aims to raise cash after selling other assets, including a stake in medical equipment maker Topcon Corp and a building. Sony, which already leads the global image sensor market, is expected to quadruple its semiconductor spending this year to meet demand from customers like Apple and Samsung. The sale may lead to job cuts at Toshiba.

site_title: Up, up and away
summary: Excellent organisations possess key attributes that drive long-term sustainable success. These include having a strong competitive advantage, effective talent management, a purpose-driven culture, and embracing digital transformation. Companies must also prioritize employee engagement, foster a culture of integrity, and deliver value to customers. Organisations that focus on people, leadership, and innovation are more likely to achieve excellence. Key attributes include having a clear purpose, being adaptable, and continuously improving processes and offerings to meet changing customer needs.

site_title: What will it mean for the yuan to get IMF reserve-currency nod?
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is likely to approve China's yuan as a reserve currency, with the potential to boost global liquidity and China's economic influence. The yuan has gained significant traction in global payments, surpassing the yen in August, and has been endorsed by major economies including the US, Germany, and UK. The inclusion of the yuan in the IMF's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket could attract trillions of dollars in global reserves, potentially shifting to Chinese assets.

site_title: China premier says 7% growth goal was never cast in stone
summary: China Premier Li Keqiang said the country's 7% growth goal is not set in stone, amid concerns about economic difficulties ahead. The premier stated that the economy should operate within a reasonable range, not defend any specific goal to the death. China's economy is expected to grow around 6-7% over the next five years, with growth targets set at around 7%. The country has been taking aggressive monetary policy measures, including cutting interest rates, to stimulate growth. Despite this, China's economy is expected to reach a 25-year low this year, and policymakers are concerned about the potential for systemic risks and destabilization.

site_title: Big Data shows longer dwelling time in Jurong East malls
summary: A new study using Big Data has found that shoppers in Jurong East malls spend more time in the malls (30.3% and 35.5% of visitors staying beyond 2 hours) compared to those in Tampines (19.4% and 22% of visitors staying beyond 2 hours). However, this increased dwell time has not translated into improved rental performance, with Jurong East malls experiencing fluctuating rents and lower median monthly rents (S$16 psf) compared to Tampines (S$25.55 psf). Experts attribute the strong turnout in Jurong East to its ability to draw visitors from the North region, but warn that the region faces increased competition from new malls and needs to enhance its catchment and "hub" effect to remain sustainable.

site_title: Selling by directors up as buying retreats
summary: Singapore Exchange filings show a decline in buying activity among directors, with 10 companies making purchases worth S$1.94 million, down from 15 firms the previous week. However, the value of these purchases increased sharply. Meanwhile, sales among directors rose, with 2 companies disposing of shares worth S$0.96 million. Notable buyback activity includes Bumitama Agri Limited, which resumed buying back shares at a higher price, and Marco Polo Marine Limited, where executive chairman Lee Wan Tang picked up shares at 20.6 cents each.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) logo outside SGX Centre on Dec 23, 2014.

site_title: Facebook hits US$100 as 3-year jump adds US$240b to stock
summary: Facebook Inc's stock has surged to US$100, marking a 476% rally since 2012, making it the fastest company to reach this milestone. The social network operator's strong growth in advertising spending and viewership has contributed to its success, with its market value now surpassing US$250 billion. Facebook joins 109 other S&P 500 members in the three-digit club, solidifying its position as a dominant technology giant.

site_title: The Chinese consumer is still spending
summary: Hong Kong's retail sentiment remains grim, with sales declines reported by several retailers, including Sa Sa International Holdings and Chow Tai Fook. Despite this, the Chinese consumer continues to spend, with robust sales in mainland China and growth in e-commerce and box office revenues. Retailers are adapting by focusing on e-commerce, with companies like Eu Yan Sang and OSIM International reporting positive results from their online segments. The Chinese consumer's spending power remains strong, with double-digit sales growth in many categories, including retail sales and e-commerce.

site_title: Draghi and Yellen brace for December policy decisions
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi and US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen are set to make key policy decisions in December, potentially diverging on monetary policies. Draghi's signal of fresh stimulus for the euro-area could lead to a stronger dollar and make a US rate hike less likely, while a global equity rally could influence the Fed's decision. The outcome could mark a new era of opposing monetary trends between the US and eurozone, with the euro potentially reaching a new low against the dollar.

site_title: At least 100 injured in Hong Kong ferry accident: authorities
summary: A high-speed ferry traveling from Macau to Hong Kong collided with an "unidentified object" in the water, injuring at least 100 people. The ferry, carrying 163 passengers and 11 crew, lost power and was towed back to Hong Kong island. A large rescue operation involved air services, marine police, and the fire department. The incident has raised concerns about the safety of Hong Kong's waters, following a fatal 2012 crash that killed 39 people.

site_title: Noble cuts dividend to strengthen cash position amid oil rout
summary: Noble Corp, an oil drilling services provider, has cut its quarterly dividend to 15 US cents per share from 37.5 US cents per share, citing industry uncertainty and a need to preserve liquidity. The move is expected to increase annual free cash flow by over $220 million. The company's chairman and CEO, David W. Williams, stated that the revised dividend "appropriately addresses the prevailing industry uncertainty." The cut is in response to the recent oil rout.

site_title: King of the hill
summary: Jordan won the Masters in April with a flawless opening-round 64, tied for the course record with nine birdies. His only hiccup came at the par-5 15th hole, where he hit a hybrid over the green and made a bogey.

site_title: Will Bank of Japan go for broke in the face of looming recession?
summary: The Bank of Japan is set to hold a critical Policy Board meeting this week, with market expectations of fresh monetary easing. Despite two rounds of aggressive easing, the economy remains on the brink of recession, and Tokyo stock prices rose last week in anticipation of further stimulus. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has expressed continued faith in quantitative easing, while Japan's finance minister Taro Aso has cautioned against further easing, citing a limit to monetary policy's effectiveness. Analysts predict the BOJ will move to apply fresh stimulus to boost prices and support Japan's Abenomics aim of a 20% GDP growth.

images.alt_text: Abenomics, the set of policies adopted by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe nearly three years ago as a weapon with which to fight Japan's long economic stagnation, will face a critical test on Friday this week when the Bank of Japan (BOJ) - a key player in implementing Abenomics - holds its latest Policy Board meeting.

site_title: Zuckerbergs to start school mixing learning and health
summary: Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Priscilla Chan plan to start a private school in East Palo Alto, California, combining education with healthcare services. The school, "The Primary School," aims to support families and help children from underserved communities reach their full potential. The school will provide pre-natal support, on-site healthcare, and early-childhood education through 12th grade. Zuckerberg and Chan have invested $120 million in Bay Area schools, with the goal of improving public education. This initiative follows Zuckerberg's previous investment of $100 million in Newark, New Jersey schools.

site_title: Bezos passes Kochs as 3rd-richest in US on Amazon surge
summary: Jeff Bezos has become the third-richest person in the US, surpassing the Koch brothers, with an estimated net worth of $53.2 billion, following Amazon's surge of over $35. His fortune has increased by 86% in 2015, surpassing Mark Zuckerberg and Larry Page, Sergey Brin, and Facebook's combined gains. Bezos' wealth now ranks fifth globally, behind Bill Gates and Warren Buffett.

site_title: Microsoft reaches 15-year high after profit tops estimates
summary: Microsoft's profit exceeded analysts' estimates in its fiscal first-quarter, reaching 67 US cents a share and $21.7 billion in sales. The company's Azure cloud services and Office 365 subscription-based products drove growth, with Azure sales more than doubling and Office 365 adding 3 million consumer subscribers. Microsoft's stock surged 10% to a 15-year high, driven by the strong performance of its new Intelligent Cloud and Productivity segments. The company also announced plans to reduce costs and invest in new businesses, with net income rising to $4.62 billion.

site_title: Can you start on the SRS too early?
summary: Investors in Singapore's Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) may face an implicit capital gains tax issue if they withdraw their funds early. The SRS allows tax-deferred contributions and tax-free withdrawals at retirement, but if investors withdraw before retirement, they may be taxed on the gains. However, a 5% return on investment can mitigate this issue, and the tax rate is still relatively low compared to other countries. In fact, the effective tax rate for a young investor starting at age 28 with a 5% return is around 4.8%. This suggests that the tax issue is not a significant concern, and investors can still benefit from contributing to the SRS.

site_title: Janet Yellen to testify before Joint Economic Committee Dec 3
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is set to testify before the Joint Economic Committee on December 3, providing insight into the economic outlook at a pivotal time for monetary policy and the US economy. This comes just 12 days before the Federal Open Market Committee's two-day policy-setting meeting, where rates are expected to remain near zero. Yellen's comments will be closely watched, as investors anticipate the possibility of a rate hike in December for the first time since 2006.

site_title: Petrobras fetches US$490m with gas unit stake to Mitsui
summary: Petrobras has approved the sale of a 49% stake in Gaspetro, a natural gas distribution unit, to Mitsui & Co Ltd for $684 million. The deal, part of Petrobras' asset divestment plan, aims to repay debt and speed up the development of offshore oil discoveries. Regulatory approval is pending, and the transaction could be concluded by December. This move comes as Petrobras faces plunging oil prices and limited interest from potential buyers, with Mitsui seen as a natural buyer due to its knowledge of Brazil and ability to remain a minority shareholder.

site_title: Tech spats spark fears of 'digital protectionism'
summary: US tech giants like Google, Facebook, and Uber face growing concerns over "digital protectionism" from the European Union. The EU's highest court invalidated an agreement allowing US firms to transfer personal data without running afoul of privacy rules, sparking fears of new regulations that could impact US companies. The EU is also considering a "digital single market" proposal, which could include new rules for online platforms. US officials, including Secretary of Commerce Penny Pritzker and President Barack Obama, have expressed concerns about the move, arguing it could harm the transatlantic digital economy and stifle free trade.

site_title: The Agran golf and country club
summary: The article discusses the limitations of modern golf clubs and lessons, stating that their benefits are likely to be marginal and short-lived. This is attributed to the fact that courses often lack hazards, bunkers, and obstacles, rendering the new equipment and techniques ineffective. The author suggests that the impact of new golf clubs and lessons will not significantly improve one's game, despite the marketing claims made by manufacturers and instructors.

site_title: Hackers find new arena in space
summary: Hackers are targeting satellites in space, viewing them as "trophy attacks" due to the vast amounts of data being transmitted between them. Companies like Virgin Galactic, SpaceX, and Facebook are investing heavily in the space economy, making them vulnerable to cyber attacks. Experts warn that the risk of project failure is increasing, with a 10% chance of failure on average, and insurance premiums are rising accordingly. To combat this, companies are having to arm themselves against malware and ensure that their hardware is secure before it's launched into space.

site_title: US: Stock rally produces 4th straight weekly gain
summary: US stocks rose for the fourth straight week, driven by tech earnings, a McDonald's comeback, and a Weight Watchers partnership. The S&P 500 gained 2.07% to 2,075.15, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.50% to 17,646.70. The Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 2.97% to 5,031.86. This marks a turnaround from the third quarter, which was marked by significant losses.

site_title: Keppel says it may face Brazil graft probe
summary: Keppel Corporation Ltd, a Singaporean oil rig builder, may face an investigation into deals with Brazilian state-run oil company Petrobras and rig builder Sete Brasil. A Brazilian parliamentary commission of inquiry has backed further investigations into 10 companies, including Keppel's Keppel FELS Brasil unit. Keppel has previously rejected any involvement in the bribery scandal, stating that it had a contract with an agent involved but its officials were banned from accepting bribes. The news has led to a decline in shares for Keppel and its cross-town rival Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: Dorsey's Twitter stock gift well-timed to stem brain drain: recruiters
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey has given away a third of his company stock, worth $206 million, to an employee equity pool as part of a strategic effort to retain and attract key talent. The move aims to restore confidence in the company, which has faced leadership uncertainty and slow user growth. The gift is seen as a deliberate and wise move to keep top employees happy, and will prevent the dilution of investors' stockholdings. The transfer of 6.8 million shares is subject to shareholder approval in 2016.

site_title: Crouching Asia, when will it rise?
summary: The article "Crouching Asia, when will it rise?" references the recent Presidents Cup in Asia, where Asian players underperformed. The article then shifts to unrelated news, including Asean's stance on the Myanmar election, a property trust's data centre move, and China's efforts to boost employment amid trade tensions. Key events include China urging South-east Asian countries to support openness, and Chinese property shares rising on unverified reports of a sector revival. No clear conclusion is drawn, instead, the article presents various news snippets from the region.

site_title: Tech earnings propel S&P 500 towards year-end predictions
summary: The S&P 500 Index has narrowed its gap with year-end predictions after four stocks surged following earnings reports, bringing the gap down to 5% from 15%. The rebound in tech earnings has propelled the index towards its projected average value.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q3 earnings plunge amid market volatility
summary: Great Eastern, a Singaporean insurer, reported a 65% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$68.4 million for the third quarter, due to valuation losses and weakening of the Malaysian ringgit. The insurance business saw a 62% drop in profit, while operating profit decreased 13%. Despite this, the company's gross premiums rose 19% to S$2.53 billion and new business sales grew 33%. The group's new business embedded value climbed 16%, but NBEV margin decreased due to shifts in product and channel mix.

site_title: Google hits record as results top estimates on web clicks
summary: Google parent Alphabet Inc. reported a record-breaking quarterly revenue and profit, fueled by increased ad sales and cost control. Revenue rose 15% to $15.1 billion, and profit excluding certain items was $7.35 per share, beating estimates. The company authorized $5.1 billion in share buybacks and announced plans to become a new holding company called Alphabet, separating its main business from new ventures. This move aims to bring operational and financial discipline to the sprawling web enterprise, with CEO Larry Page and CFO Ruth Porat at the helm.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Q4 DPU up 14%
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust reported a 14% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.52 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, driven by higher rents at Alexandra Technopark and the acquisition of 357 Collins Street in Melbourne. The trust's full-year DPU reached an all-time high of 9.71 Singapore cents. Leases expiring in FY 2016 are expected to lead to positive rental reversions when renewed, according to CEO Low Chee Wah. The trust's distribution income surged 25.6% year-on-year to S$18.82 million.

site_title: Why I changed my mind about Phil
summary: The article discusses a change of heart by the author regarding Phil, likely referring to Phil Mickelson, a professional golfer. site_title: PBOC cuts rates for sixth time since November
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), cut interest rates for the sixth time since November, lowering the one-year benchmark bank lending rate to 4.35% and the benchmark deposit rate to 1.5%. The reserve requirement ratio was also cut by 50 basis points to 17.5% to support the economy, which is experiencing a slowdown. The move is the most aggressive since the 2008/09 global financial crisis, and analysts predict further rate cuts in 2015 and 2016 to boost economic growth.

site_title: It took 42 years to finish this US nuclear power plant
summary: The US nuclear power plant at Watts Bar complex in Tennessee has finally been completed after 42 years, with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission granting a 40-year operating license. The plant's Unit 2, which produces 1,150 megawatts of electricity, will supply 650,000 homes. The project, which faced numerous delays and setbacks, including a 1985 suspension due to low fossil-fuel prices, is expected to cost around $6 billion. The completion of Watts Bar 2 comes as US policymakers crack down on pollution from electricity generation, with nuclear power expected to play a key role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Ezra Q4 profit from continuing ops at US$8.9m
summary: EZRA Holdings reported a Q4 profit from continuing operations of US$8.9 million, offsetting declines in revenues from its subsea business unit and offshore services division. The company's loss attributable to owners was US$7.8 million, driven by losses from discontinued operations. Over the past 12 months, an increase in turnover from its marine services unit, Triyards, more than compensated for the declines.

site_title: US probe to include Takata side air bags
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has expanded its investigation into the potentially defective Takata air bags to include side air bags, potentially widening the auto recall. The investigation now covers all model years and includes side air bags in new cars, following reports of ruptures in vehicles with newer inflaters. The recall, which already affects over 19 million cars, may need to be expanded further, with the NHTSA examining the use of ammonium nitrate as a propellant.

site_title: Bigger drop in office, retail rents in Q3
summary: Singapore's office and retail rents declined in the third quarter, with office rents falling 2.9% quarter-over-quarter and retail rents dropping 2% quarter-over-quarter. Consultants attribute the decline to businesses becoming cautious due to economic uncertainties, trimming operating costs and easing demand for retail space. Further rental declines are expected in subsequent quarters, with office vacancy rates projected to surge to double digits next year.

site_title: Ferrari going nowhere in luxury goods market despite F1 success
summary: Ferrari's non-car products, designed for racing fans, may not appeal to luxury goods buyers. Despite being the most successful Formula One team, Ferrari's street-legal sports cars carry a high price tag due to their racing pedigree. Chairman Sergio Marchionne aims to expand the brand into luxury goods, but this may be hindered by its racing focus, which may not align with the target audience for high-end apparel and accessories. Ferrari's attempt to enter the luxury market may not be successful.

site_title: WTA Finals set for a dose of Maria magic
summary: Maria Sharapova, the world's No. 3 tennis player, is set to compete in the WTA Finals in Singapore, where she will face off against top eight players including Simona Halep, Garbine Muguruza, and Petra Kvitova. Sharapova, a five-time Grand Slam champion, has had a season to forget due to injuries, but is confident of her abilities after a comeback at the Wuhan Open in September. She hopes to win the championship, which would be one of the greatest achievements in her illustrious 14-year career, and is expected to draw large crowds and attention due to her star appeal.

site_title: China home prices rise for 5th straight month in September
summary: China's home prices rose for the fifth consecutive month in September, with average new home prices increasing 0.3% from August. This marks a mild recovery in the housing market, which accounts for 15% of the country's GDP. Despite improved home prices and sales, conditions remain weak in smaller cities, and a huge overhang of unsold houses discourages new investment and construction. Economists predict that property investment might be bottoming out, but some warn that price gains may have passed their peak, and growth may turn negative in 2016.

summary: Singapore property consultants expect a good response for a 1.3-hectare 99-year leasehold site in Clementi Avenue 1, with 5-16 bids anticipated, and top bids ranging from S$480 to S$692 per square foot per plot ratio. site_title: 10,000 steps to a healthier you
summary: The US surgeon-general suggests that Americans who don't get enough exercise should start walking, as it helps reduce and treat chronic illnesses such as high blood pressure and diabetes. The government recommends 150 minutes of moderate physical exercise per week, but experts suggest at least 30 minutes a day for significant health benefits. Using a pedometer or physical activity tracker can help track progress, with 10,000 steps being a good starting point. Walking can be intensified through interval training or "fartlek" and is a more accessible form of exercise than running, offering similar health benefits with fewer calories burned.

summary: An independent French artisan, Pinel et Pinel, is reviving the art of trunk-making, one bespoke piece at a time. site_title: Blue chips rule as Draghi's words lift markets

site_title: Sept inflation picks up slightly, core inflation accelerates
summary: Singapore's inflation rate in September rose marginally to -0.6% due to a stronger rise in consumer services and retail items. site_title: DBS, South Africa's FirstRand in the running for RBS India unit

site_title: Talk of more monetary easing by BOJ grows
summary: Market expectations of further monetary easing by the Bank of Japan (BOJ) are growing following ECB president Mario Draghi's announcement that the ECB is likely to launch fresh stimulus measures by December. Analysts suggest the BOJ could ease monetary policy as early as next week, pushing the yen exchange rate down and Tokyo stock prices up. site_title: Tourism game plan an ongoing project
summary: Singapore's tourism industry has undergone significant changes since its independence in 1965, evolving from a small island with limited resources to a premier destination. To remain competitive, Singapore must focus on maximizing value and address its weaknesses, including the impact of urbanization and global economic trends.

site_title: Reality cheque
summary: Angus Deaton, a Princeton University economist, has been awarded the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences, "for his analysis of consumption, poverty, and welfare". His work has transformed development economics by using data to overturn assumptions and reimagining how we measure the world. Deaton's contributions include the "Almost Ideal Demand (AID) System", which models how people respond to price changes, and his work on the relationship between consumption and income, which exposed inconsistencies in macroeconomic models. His Nobel Prize win highlights the importance of evidence-based economics and the need for precise definitions and measurement.

site_title: Xi wants to see UK playing a vital role in EU

site_title: Tiger Airways narrows Q2 loss to S$12.8m

Italian and Spanish two-year government bond yields turned negative, while the eurozone's blue-chip Euro STOXX 50 index rose 1.2%. The news also sparked anticipation for potential further stimulus from the Bank of Japan.

site_title: P&G's quarterly sales drop 12%
summary: Procter & Gamble Co reported a 12% drop in quarterly sales, its seventh straight decline, due to weak demand and a strong dollar. Revenue fell to $16.53 billion from $18.77 billion. Despite the decline, the company's net income rose to $2.60 billion, or 91 US cents per share. P&G has been reducing its brand portfolio to focus on profitable brands.

site_title: Update: China's central bank cuts rates for 6th time since Nov
summary: China's central bank cut interest rates for the sixth time in less than a year, lowering the benchmark bank lending rate to 4.35% and the reserve requirement ratio to 17.5%. The moves aim to stimulate growth in the stuttering economy, which is expected to slip to a 25-year-low of under 7% this year. The policy easing is the most aggressive since the 2008/09 financial crisis, and analysts predict further cuts before the end of the year.

site_title: S&P says Japan needs to raise tax revenue with sales tax hike
summary: Standard & Poor's advises Japan to increase tax revenue by raising its sales tax, citing the need to lower its outstanding debt burden. The agency suggests exempting some food items to make the tax hike more palatable to voters. However, this could lead to administrative costs for companies and the government. S&P recently cut its rating on Japan from AA- to A+, citing doubts over the government's ability to reverse economic deterioration. The agency emphasizes that the sales tax must generate revenue to reduce Japan's debt level.

site_title: China securities firm chief 'commits suicide': reports
summary: China's Guosen Securities president, Chen Hongqiao, hanged himself at his home after authorities prevented him from leaving the country, following a corruption probe into top industry regulator Zhang Yujun. Chen had attempted to leave China but was turned back due to "border control" measures. The move comes amid ongoing investigations into alleged market manipulations and insider trading, which led to China's stock exchanges plummeting over the summer. Chen's death was confirmed by Guosen Securities, which did not provide further details.

site_title: CMT fully utilises proceeds from S$250m private placement in 2011
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) has utilized the remaining net proceeds of S$15.1 million from a 2011 private placement to pay for committed capital expenditure and asset enhancement initiatives, contrary to its initial plan. The private placement raised S$250 million, and CMT's manager had intended to use 90-95% of the net proceeds for capital expenditure and 5-10% for general corporate and working capital purposes. This change aligns with CMT's active capital management strategy, and the trust's shares finished at S$2.05.

site_title: Cloud services help Microsoft beat Q1 revenue expectations
summary: Microsoft reported Q1 revenue that beat expectations, driven by strong demand for its cloud products. The company's shares surged over 6% in extended trading. Under CEO Satya Nadella, Microsoft has shifted focus to software and cloud services, with cloud products emerging as a source of strength. Analyst Daniel Ives attributed this to cloud being the "Rock of Gibraltar" for Microsoft. This marks a significant shift for the company, which has been shifting away from Windows operating system demand.

site_title: Eurozone business activity stronger than expected but prices still tepid
summary: The eurozone's business activity increased more than expected in October, driven by Germany and France, but prices remained stagnant. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program is seen as a positive sign for growth, but prices continue to be a concern, with inflation expected to stay below 2% this year. The Markit Composite Flash Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 54.0, indicating fourth-quarter economic growth of 0.4%. The eurozone's private sector grew for the 30th month in a row, with some firms cutting prices, but overall services PMI jumped to 54.2, beating expectations.

site_title: First Sponsor posts 15% rise in Q3 profit
summary: First Sponsor posted a 15% rise in Q3 net profit to S$17.1 million, driven by stronger performance in its property and property financing segments. Group revenue jumped 31.6% to S$72 million, with significant growth in rental income, property sales, and property financing. The company's strategy to enhance recurring income has taken shape, with a low gearing ratio and conservative interest cover. First Sponsor is ready to gear up for expansion in the Netherlands and China with S$660.5 million in cash and unutilized credit facilities.

site_title: Can New Yorkers say oh luak?
summary: Simpson Wong, a Singaporean entrepreneur, has opened Chomp Chomp, New York's first Singapore hawker food restaurant, in the West Village. The restaurant features authentic Singaporean dishes, including char kway teow and nasi lemak, without altering their names or flavors to suit Western tastes. Wong, 52, aims to bring Singaporean cuisine to a wider audience and has received positive reviews from publications such as The New Yorker and Monocle. His restaurant, which serves entrees for $12-$16, has attracted long queues on weekends.

images.alt_text: AUTHENTIC EATS: Simpson Wong at his West Village restaurant Chomp Chomp, serving unadulterated Singaporean hawker food to New Yorkers

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% amid market uncertainty and global economic concerns. US stocks fell, edging away from records, due to tariff threats from President Trump. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-expected second-half revenue and operating loss similar to the first half. London's Heathrow Airport planned to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Saizen Reit gets firm offer for its assets
summary: Saizen Real Estate Investment Trust's manager has received a firm offer for the reit's assets, according to a statement. The offer is being reviewed and evaluated by an independent evaluation committee and joint financial advisers. No definitive agreements have been entered into, and there is no assurance that the offer will be accepted. The development comes after the reit's manager stated that the offer was made, but no further details were provided.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine's Q3 FY2015 core net profit fell 63% to S$49 million, below expectations. KGI Fraser Securities downgraded their estimate due to delays in deliveries and financing issues with Sete Brasil. In contrast, Ascendas Reit's Q2 distribution per unit rose 24% on organic growth and asset enhancements. DBS Group Research upgraded Interplex Holdings to a "buy" with a target price of S$0.83, citing expected operational efficiencies and modest revenue growth.

images.alt_text: SembMarine's Q3 FY2015 core net profit of S$49 million (-63 per cent year on year) was below our expectations, with nine-month 2015 core net profit making up 49 per cent of our core net profit estimates for FY2015 forecast.

site_title: China's central bank calls for close attention to financial sector risks
summary: China's central bank urged close attention to financial sector risks due to the current international and domestic economic situation. Deputy Governor Pan Gongsheng made the comments at a meeting on Oct 20, citing the need for vigilance. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai up on ECB comment, eyes on China meeting
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai shares rose on Friday after European Central Bank comments hinted at further stimulus, boosting hopes for similar measures by China ahead of a top-level Communist Party policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index gained 1.34% and the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.30%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index surged 2.94%. These gains came as investors await China's policy meeting, which may influence global markets.

site_title: CRCT's DPU for Q3 rises 12.3%
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust posted a 12.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.64 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended September 2015, driven by a 9% rise in net property income to S$35 million. Gross revenue rose 7.5% to S$55.3 million, mainly due to the stronger renminbi against the Singapore dollar. The company attributed the lower revenue to mall closures and tenancy adjustments, but offset by rental growth in other multi-tenanted malls. The units finished 1.4% higher at S$1.50.

site_title: China ready to boost UK infrastructure cooperation: Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced his country's readiness to boost infrastructure ties with the UK, aiming to develop sectors such as transport, power, and housing. Xi stated that China is willing to explore new ways to enhance cooperation. This move comes as the UK seeks outside investment to address infrastructure gaps. The announcement follows Xi's four-day visit to Britain, where he met with UK leaders to discuss various economic and trade opportunities.

site_title: DBS, South Africa's FirstRand in talks to buy RBS India unit: sources
summary: DBS Group Holdings and South Africa's FirstRand are in talks to buy Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc's India unit, with financial details not immediately clear. The deal could fetch around US$200 million, with an Indian private sector lender also likely to bid. The talks are not yet public, and sources declined to be named for confidentiality.

site_title: Japan's Mitsubishi regional jet maiden test flight delayed again
summary: Mitsubishi Aircraft has delayed the maiden test flight of Japan's first commercial jet by at least two weeks due to a faulty pedal in the test plane's cockpit. The rescheduled test flight is now set to occur during the second week of November. This marks the third delay for the aircraft, which is already three years late and faces pressure to meet deliveries to Japan's largest carrier, ANA Holdings, slated for June 2017.

site_title: Singapore stocks close week higher with blue chips the main play
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 30.35 points or 1% to 3,068.46, with a week-on-week gain of 38 points or 1.25%, driven by hopes of European Central Bank stimulus. However, the index's performance was underpinned by low trading volume, with 1.5 billion units worth S$1.03 billion of business, mostly from the STI's 30 members. Excluding index components, trading volume was weak, with an average value per unit traded of S$0.28, similar to previous days.

site_title: Clinton stands firm through marathon Benghazi grilling
summary: Hillary Clinton maintained her composure during 11 hours of questioning about the 2012 Benghazi attacks, parrying Republican blows. She acknowledged her share of blame for the attack that killed four Americans, including Ambassador Christopher Stevens, but denied failing to boost security at the US diplomatic compound. Clinton's strong performance could help her convince skeptical voters that it's time to move on from the controversy that has overshadowed her presidential campaign.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Keppel Corporation Ltd, a Singapore oil rig builder, may face a Brazilian corruption probe into deals with Petrobras and Sete Brasil. Singapore inflation rose to -0.6% in September, while bus and train fares will fall 1.9% due to lower oil prices. Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak delivered a budget to boost economic growth, but raised income tax rates to reduce the fiscal deficit.
