Meanwhile, the Singapore Stock Index closed the week higher, driven by hopes of European Central Bank stimulus.

site_title: Unipec's Singapore oil trading head Zhang Nie resigns: sources
summary: Zhang Nie, the Singapore oil trading head of Chinese state trader Unipec, has resigned after 10 years of service, citing "family reasons". Nie, who led middle distillates trading for five years, will remain with the company until the end of the year. A replacement has not been identified yet, and Unipec Singapore did not comment on the matter. Nie previously worked for Unipec's parent company Sinopec.

site_title: Malaysia sees current account surplus halved in 2016, but lower fiscal deficit
summary: Malaysia forecasts a halved current account surplus of 11.3 billion ringgit (S$3.65 billion) in 2016, amid a negative trend that has contributed to the ringgit's 17% fall this year. The country predicts economic growth of 4.0-5.0% next year and a lower budget deficit, supporting its investment grade rating for sovereign debt.

site_title: New facility opens in Jurong for Rolls-Royce subsidiary MTU Asia
summary: MTU Asia, a Rolls-Royce subsidiary, has opened its new headquarters building in Jurong, Singapore. The facility features a 26,500 sqm space, a training center with 30 training engines and 15 electronic simulators, and can accommodate up to 720 employees, customers, and partners annually. The six instructors, including five locals, will provide training to the region's high-speed engine users. The new center aims to enhance MTU Asia's capabilities and support the growth of its high-speed engine business in the region.

site_title: HPH Trust posts higher revenue, earnings in Q3
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings (HPH) Trust reported a net profit of HK$525.9 million for its Q3, up 7.2% from last year, with revenue and other income rising 2.3% to HK$3.5 billion. Earnings per unit increased to 6.04 HK cents. Despite a weak market outlook, the trust's throughput of deep-water ports was in line with last year, and outbound cargoes to the US showed an upward trend. Management remains cautious on volume outlook for the remainder of the year due to depressed European markets.

site_title: Eurozone October business growth surprisingly strong: PMI
summary: Eurozone business activity grew more than expected in October, with services companies experiencing the fastest rate of new work since April, according to a survey. The data is a welcome boost to the European Central Bank, but prices fell for the second consecutive month, contrary to expectations of a rise. The survey's results come as the ECB continues its quantitative easing program to boost inflation and growth. Despite the mixed signs, the data suggests that the Eurozone economy is showing signs of improvement.

site_title: Indonesian haze reaches southern Philippines
summary: Haze from Indonesian forest fires has spread to the southern Philippines, disrupting air traffic and prompting warnings for residents to wear face masks. The haze, which has worsened over the past week, has caused flight cancellations and delays at 10 airports on Mindanao, affecting thousands of passengers. Visibility has dropped to 1.2 kilometers, forcing aircraft to circle and wait above runways for up to an hour. The haze has also disrupted the Manila airport, with some Mindanao-bound flights being held back, and residents are advised to wear face masks due to the potential for respiratory illnesses.

site_title: Indonesia prepares warships to evacuate "haze" refugees
summary: Indonesia prepares warships to evacuate children and others affected by haze from slash-and-burn fires, a last resort measure if other efforts fail. The country is struggling to contain fires caused by El Nino weather, pushing air pollution to hazardous levels across Southeast Asia. Indonesia has asked for aid from several countries, including Russia, Canada, and the US, and has taken steps to prevent further fires, including banning new permits for plantation companies. The haze has cost the state airline $8 million and forced 120,000 passengers to cancel flights last month.

site_title: Credit Suisse exiting dealer role rings alarm in debt market
summary: Credit Suisse has announced its withdrawal from the UK primary-dealer market, marking the first time a primary dealer has left the market since 2011. The move is part of the bank's overhaul to cut costs and reduce its investment bank business. Credit Suisse will remain a primary dealer for US Treasuries but will no longer make markets for gilts. The bank's decision is seen as a sign of pressure on global investment banks to scale back their bond-trading activities due to stricter capital requirements.

site_title: Gold rises above US$1,170, but set for weekly drop
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,173.16 an ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar, despite expectations of a potential US rate hike this year. However, the metal is poised to snap two straight weekly gains due to strong US housing and labor market data. The dollar dropped 0.1% on Friday, but gains were capped by upbeat markets. The Fed's decision to raise rates remains uncertain, with traders citing robust US data and a possible December rate hike.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 5.84 points to 1,710.93, driven by 525 gainers versus 318 losers, with 2.42 billion lots valued at RM2 billion traded.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends week on high note as risk appetite revives
summary: Japanese stocks rose on Friday, with the Nikkei share average gaining 2.1% to its highest close since August 31, as European Central Bank President Mario Draghi signaled new stimulus measures could come as early as December. The food sector led gains, with snack food company Calbee and dairy producer Megmilk Snow Brand rising 9.6% and 10.5%, respectively. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also rose, with all 33 subindexes in the Topix in positive territory.

site_title: China's Q3 property loans rise as market steadies
summary: China's property loans rose 20.9% in Q3, the fastest pace in six months, as the housing market steadies. Banks extended 1.92 trillion yuan (S$420 billion) in mortgages over the first nine months, up from 596.1 billion yuan last year. This marks a recovery from the market's slump, with a 19.4% increase in Q2. The data suggests a nascent recovery in the housing market, but experts caution that the market still faces challenges.

site_title: Quick takes: Pick-up in Singapore core inflation in September
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to 0.6% in September, surpassing the market's projection of 0.4% and August's 0.2%. The increase was mainly driven by a stronger rise in consumer services and retail prices. Private-sector economists, including Citi, ANZ, and Barclays, have varying views on the inflation outlook, with some predicting a gradual rise and others expecting further weakness. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the higher reading to a stronger pick-up in consumer services and retail items.

site_title: Harry Potter play to open on London stage in summer 2016
summary: A new Harry Potter play, "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child", will open on London's West End stage in summer 2016, two years after the seventh book's conclusion. Based on an original tale by J.K. Rowling, the play follows a grown-up Harry working for the Ministry of Magic. The two-part production will premiere at the Palace Theatre on July 30, with reduced price previews starting on June 7. Commercial success is expected, given the franchise's massive popularity, with over 450 million copies sold worldwide.

site_title: ECB speculation sends Asia stocks surging, euro sinks
summary: The European Central Bank hinted at potential fresh stimulus measures for the eurozone economy, sending Asia stock markets and emerging currencies surging. The euro fell to US$1.1111 and 134.10 yen, while Frankfurt and Paris surged over 2% in equities. The Asian markets ended with gains of 2.11% in Tokyo, 1.67% in Sydney, 0.86% in Seoul, and 1.30% in Hong Kong. The speculation fueled a rally in financial markets, with emerging currencies such as the Malaysian ringgit and Indonesian rupiah rising, and investors awaiting a top-level policy meeting in China next week.

site_title: Bus, train fares to fall 1.9% on oil prices
summary: Singapore's bus and train fares will decrease by 1.9% due to lower oil prices, resulting in a S$36.1 million reduction in fare revenue. The fare review by the Public Transport Council (PTC) will take effect on December 27, with adult fares expected to decrease by between one and four cents. The 1.9% reduction accounts for inflation, wages, and energy costs.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump 1.7 per cent to 2-month high on ECB-led rally
summary: Australian shares rose 1.7% to a two-month high, driven by expectations of continued easy monetary policy in Europe. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,351.6, its largest daily gain since October 5. The index ended the week up 1.7% despite subdued trading earlier in the week due to concerns about the ECB meeting and US Federal Reserve policy reviews. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also rose 0.8%.

site_title: OSIM: Not affected by Oregon GNC case
summary: OSIM International, the sole franchisee of GNC in Singapore, Malaysia, Taiwan, and Australia, stated that it does not sell the allegedly adulterated GNC supplements mentioned in an Oregon lawsuit. The Oregon Attorney General claimed that these supplements contained unapproved Russian prescription medicines and synthetic amphetamines. Following GNC's announcement to remove the affected products from sale, OSIM shares rose 1.9% on Friday.

site_title: China: Stocks rise as President Xi rules out hard landing, up for 3rd week
summary: China stocks rose over 1% on Friday, extending a three-week gain, as President Xi Jinping ruled out a hard landing for the economy. Xi acknowledged downward pressure on the world's second-largest economy, but said China would avoid a sharp slowdown. Housing data showed home prices rose for the fifth consecutive month, suggesting a mild recovery in the housing market. The CSI300 index rose 1.1% and the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.6%. A solid rebound is unlikely, with weak conditions in smaller cities and a large overhang of unsold houses.

site_title: Prudential Singapore gets new CEO
summary: Prudential Singapore has appointed Philip Seah as its new CEO, effective immediately with regulatory approval. Seah, with over 35 years of experience, replaces Tomas Urbanec. The company believes Seah's leadership skills and business experience will drive growth for the Singapore business. This appointment follows a long tenure with the company, with Seah being dedicated to the business.

site_title: French private sector picks up in October: flash PMIs
summary: French private sector activity accelerated in October, beating expectations, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 50.7 and services PMI to 52.3, both above the 50 mark. New orders for manufacturers rose for the first time in 18 months, while export orders increased at the fastest pace in two years. Employment was trimmed at a marginal pace. The positive PMI figures suggest a recovery is taking hold, contradicting concerns of a Chinese slowdown. This is in line with other surveys, including INSEE's business morale index, which rose to a four-year high in October.

site_title: MyRepublic starts 4G trials as part of bid for fourth telco licence
summary: MyRepublic, a Singapore fibre broadband service provider, has started 4G mobile service trials as part of its bid for the fourth telco licence. The trial, limited to 1,000 users, is taking place in specific areas such as JCube, public housing blocks, and Jurong East bus interchange. This move aims to test the company's 4G capabilities and demonstrate its readiness to join Singapore's mobile market.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend ECB-led rally
summary: European shares rose 0.7-0.9% on Friday, extending a rally from the previous session, amid speculation on further monetary support from the European Central Bank. Shares in Norwegian insurer Gjensidige and home appliances maker Electrolux gained 11.2% and 3.8% respectively, while Ericsson fell 4.3% after reporting below-expectations earnings. The rally is seen as a response to investor optimism about future ECB support, with the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index reaching a 2.1% gain from the previous session.

site_title: Japan Aso voices caution over further BOJ easing
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso expressed caution over further Bank of Japan (BOJ) easing, citing the limitations of monetary policy in achieving the 2% inflation target. Aso noted that cheaper oil prices and low demand hindered price increases, and called for steps to support low-income groups to stimulate private consumption. The BOJ is set to meet on October 30, with some speculating about a fresh round of quantitative easing, but Aso said there was no need for further easing and the central bank should persist with its strategy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rally on ECB stimulus comments
summary: South Korean shares and the won surged on Friday, driven by European Central Bank chief comments signaling stimulus expansion. The won rose 1.2% to its strongest onshore weekly closing level since early July, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.9%. South Korea's economy accelerated to its fastest growth in over five years, but policymakers did not guarantee sustained consumption recovery.

site_title: Maersk cuts profit outlook due to weak shipping market
summary: AP Moller-Maersk downgraded its 2015 profit outlook by $0.6 billion to $3.4 billion due to weaker-than-expected market conditions, particularly in the container shipping market. The company cited deteriorating market conditions, especially in the third quarter and October. This downgrade is attributed to the global shipping market's weaker-than-expected performance.

site_title: Singapore pollution hits 'very unhealthy' level as forests burn
summary: Singapore's air quality worsened to a "very unhealthy" level due to haze from Indonesian forest fires, with a three-hourly pollution index of 184. The haze, exacerbated by dry conditions from El Nino, has forced schools to shut and outdoor events to be suspended. The government warned the public to avoid prolonged outdoor activities. The haze affects not only Singapore but also other parts of Southeast Asia, with smoke blown towards neighboring countries.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust plans equity fund-raising of up to S$110m
summary: Viva Industrial Trust plans to raise up to S$110 million through an equity fund-raising of up to 160.82 million new stapled securities, representing about 22.8% of existing issued securities. The trust aims to fund part of three industrial property acquisitions worth around S$191 million. An extraordinary general meeting has been called on Nov 16 to seek shareholder approval. Major stapled security holders have agreed to vote in favor of the fund-raising proposal.

site_title: Emerging currencies soar as ECB hints at fresh stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) hinted at fresh stimulus measures for the eurozone economy, causing the euro to hold losses and emerging currencies to soar. ECB head Mario Draghi suggested expanding the bond-buying program or cutting interest rates to combat tepid inflation and stagnant growth. This move boosted confidence in an easier borrowing environment, causing currencies like the Malaysian ringgit, Indonesian rupiah, and South Korean won to advance more than 1% against the dollar.

site_title: GNC plunges after Oregon says unapproved drugs in supplement
summary: GNC Holdings Inc plummeted 21% after Oregon's attorney general sued the company, claiming it sold supplements with unapproved Russian prescription medicine picamilon and banned substance BMPEA. The company, the world's largest health retailer, had previously reached an agreement with New York's attorney general to test its supplements more stringently. GNC removed products containing the ingredients from sale and intends to vigorously defend against the allegations, calling the claims "without merit".

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rise at open
summary: Stocks in Hong Kong and Shanghai rose at the open on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 1.57% and the Shanghai composite index gaining 0.26%. The move followed comments from the European Central Bank's head suggesting new measures to stimulate the eurozone economy before the end of the year.

site_title: Rupiah strengthens most in a week on tax breaks, ECB stimulus
summary: The Indonesian rupiah strengthened 0.7% to 13,560 a dollar, its largest weekly gain in a month, after the government reduced property asset revaluation tax to 3% and the European Central Bank hinted at further stimulus. The move boosted emerging-market assets, with the rupiah up 7.9% in October, its best performance this year. The Jakarta Composite Index rose, and sovereign bond yields fell 9 basis points, with some economists predicting further gains for the rupiah.

site_title: Malaysia inflation cools more than expected in September
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index rose 2.6% in September from a year earlier, below expectations and moderating from August's 3.1% reading. The inflation rate, influenced by the 6% Goods and Services Tax introduced in April, has been picking up. This marks a cooling of inflation, contrary to previous expectations. The data suggests a decrease in price pressures, providing relief to the government.

site_title: Australia oil, gas deals heat up with billion dollar merger
summary: Australian oil and gas producers Beach Energy and Drillsearch Energy Ltd agreed to a $1 billion merger, creating the country's largest onshore oil and gas producer. The deal follows a string of bids, including a $5 billion offer from Santos, and signals the industry's fortunes may be bottoming out. Analysts believe oil prices are expected to rise next year, making assets more attractive to buyers, and the merger provides opportunities for growth. The combined company expects to produce 10.6-11.8 million barrels of oil equivalent in the year to June 2016.

site_title: Singapore inflation rises marginally to -0.6% in September
summary: Singapore's inflation rose marginally to -0.6% in September, exceeding the forecast. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport, increased to 0.6%, higher than the previous month. This was driven by a stronger rise in consumer services and retail items. The government expects core inflation to reach 0.5% and headline inflation to remain at -0.5% for the full year, with core inflation ranging from 0.5-1.5% and overall inflation between -0.5-0.5% in 2016.

site_title: Ringgit leads advance in Asia before Najib's 2016 budget speech
summary: Malaysia's ringgit led gains in Asia before Prime Minister Najib Razak's 2016 budget speech, driven by speculation that the budget will focus on infrastructure and boosting consumer spending. The currency strengthened 1.3% to 4.23 a dollar, following a 3.9% loss in the last five trading days. The European Central Bank's suggestion of potential stimulus measures also buoyed emerging-market assets. Najib's budget aims to cut the fiscal deficit to 3.2% of gross domestic product, following a 17% slump in the ringgit this year.

site_title: German private sector grows in October despite worries over China and VW: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector grew for the 30th month in October, according to a survey, despite concerns over the Volkswagen scandal and a slowdown in China. The Markit PMI index rose to 54.5, above the 50 mark that separates growth from contraction. The manufacturing sector disappointed, with growth slowing to its weakest since May, but the services sector picked up, with new orders and backlogs of work increasing. Staffing levels in the private sector were a bright spot, with the recruitment rate the strongest in nearly four years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.88 points to 1716.98 on Friday, with volume reaching 54.9 million lots worth RM17.4 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 175 to 46.

site_title: Council for Estate Agencies names new executive director
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) has appointed Lee Kwong Weng as its new executive director, succeeding Chionh Chye Khye, who retired after 41 years in public service. Lee, 58, had been the CEA's deputy executive director since 2015 and previously worked at the Agri-food and Veterinary Authority. He took over on October 22, following the implementation of a regulatory framework and licensing regime by Chionh during his tenure.

site_title: ANZ Bank joins Australia's three major lenders in raising rates
summary: ANZ Bank has raised its benchmark variable mortgage rate by 18 basis points, effective November 20, in response to regulatory changes. This move follows similar increases by National Australia Bank (17 basis points) and Commonwealth Bank of Australia (15 basis points). The rate hikes aim to cover the cost of holding more capital. The Australian dollar has fallen amid speculation that the central bank may cut interest rates to offset higher home-loan costs. Westpac Banking Corp has also increased its rate by 20 basis points.

images.alt_text: Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd joined its three main competitors in raising its benchmark variable mortgage rate as Australian lenders seek to cover the cost of holding more capital.

site_title: Indonesia hopes disenchanted IS fighters can deter recruits
summary: Indonesia is hopeful that disenchanted former Islamic State (IS) fighters, like Ahmad Junaedi, can deter potential recruits by sharing their stories of disappointment and disillusionment. At least five Indonesians have returned home after being disillusioned with the group, and authorities believe their testimonies can serve as a warning to others. Experts say the emergence of IS has sparked alarm, but the country's counter-terror agency sees a silver lining in the growing number of defectors, who are now working to undermine the group's propaganda and ideology.

site_title: Singapore's AAA cachet spurs 28% gain in India's best junk bond
summary: Singapore's investment fund GIC Pte has agreed to take full control of a renewable energy business in India's Greenko Group Plc, leading to a 28% gain in the company's dollar notes. This is the best performing high-yield bond in India, surpassing a 1.5% loss in a Bank of America Merrill Lynch index. The deal is seen as a positive signal to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plan to produce 175 gigawatts of green energy by 2022, attracting global investors to India's renewable sector.

site_title: First US interest rate rise seen in Dec: EIU
summary: The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) predicts the US will raise interest rates in December, followed by steady increases through 2016-18, due to rising domestic demand and inflationary pressure. This decision will likely trigger similar rate hikes by other central banks. China's economy is expected to slow to 6.9% in 2015 and 4.9% by the end of the decade, but it will surpass the US in nominal GDP by 2026 and maintain its position until 2050. Global growth is forecast to accelerate to 2.7% in 2016, with improvements in Europe, Japan, and India.

site_title: Ascott to open first international serviced residence in Cambodia
summary: The Ascott Limited, a unit of CapitaLand, has secured a contract to manage its first international serviced residence in Cambodia, set to open in Phnom Penh in 2018. The Somerset Norodom will feature 105 apartment units, expanding Ascott's South-east Asian portfolio to over 13,000 units in 74 properties across nine countries. This marks Cambodia's first international serviced residence and follows recent management contract signings in the Philippines and Thailand.

site_title: Crude ticks higher ahead of key data
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia ahead of key manufacturing indicators from the US and eurozone, extending a slight recovery from Wednesday's decline. Crude ticked higher by over 2% on bargain-buying, despite global oversupply and a slowdown in major economies. Analysts warn of fresh selling pressure as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: URA launches private housing site in Clementi Ave 1 for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) launched a 1.3-hectare private residential site in Clementi Avenue 1 for sale by public tender. The 99-year leasehold site is estimated to yield 460 units. The tender for the land parcel will close on December 9, 2015. The site is part of the second half 2015 Government Land Sales Programme.

site_title: Q4 boost lifts Frasers Commercial Trust's FY DPU to record high
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust reported a record-high full-year distribution per unit (DPU) of 9.71 Singapore cents, up 14.1% year-on-year, driven by a 14% increase in Q4 DPU to 2.52 Singapore cents. The Q4 boost was attributed to income from Alexandra Technopark and a maiden contribution from an Australian property. This marked an all-time high for the trust, exceeding previous year's DPU.

site_title: Keppel says may face Brazil corruption probe
summary: Keppel Corporation Ltd, a Singaporean oil rig builder, may face a Brazilian corruption probe following a parliamentary commission of inquiry's backing of investigations into 10 companies, including Keppel's unit in Brazil. The probe follows allegations in a massive procurement corruption scandal affecting Petrobras. Keppel rejected involvement in the scandal, stating it had a contract with an agent and its officials were banned from accepting bribes. The company will cooperate with investigators if approached.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won join global rally on ECB views
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.4% to 2,050.21 points, with the won increasing 1.2% to 1,125.6 per dollar, following the European Central Bank's comments signaling its readiness to expand stimulus. The KOSPI's gain was in line with a 1.55% rise in Asian stocks outside Japan, driven by the ECB chief's openness to monetary policy measures. However, some stocks bucked the trend, including LG Display, which fell 5.7% after reporting weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings.

site_title: URA rental index for retail space eases 2% in Q3
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) reported a 2.0% decrease in its rental index for retail space in Q3, a smaller drop compared to the 0.5% fall in Q2. Retail space prices dipped 0.3% in Q3. The vacancy rate for retail space decreased slightly to 7.0% at end-Q3, down from 7.2% at end-Q2.

site_title: Singapore office prices dip 0.1% in Q3, rents fall accelerates with 2.9% decline
summary: Singapore office prices dipped 0.1% in Q3, marking a reversal from a 0.3% increase in the previous quarter. Office rents fell 2.9% quarter-over-quarter, accelerating from a 2.6% decline in the second quarter. Despite a 9.6% vacancy rate, the island-wide vacancy rate decreased from 9.8% in the previous quarter. The total supply of office space in the pipeline remains at approximately 908,000 sq m.

site_title: Twitter's Dorsey says to give a third of his stock to employee equity pool
summary: Twitter's CEO Jack Dorsey plans to give a third of his stock, approximately 1%, to the employee equity pool to "reinvest directly in our people." This move aims to support employee growth and development.

site_title: China home prices rise 0.3% in Sept from Aug, 5th month of gains
summary: China's average new home prices rose 0.3% in September, marking the fifth consecutive month of gains. Compared to the same period last year, prices fell 0.9%. The improvement in home prices and sales, driven by government support measures, could alleviate pressure on China's cooling economy. However, conditions remain weak in smaller cities, and a huge inventory of unsold houses is discouraging new investment and construction, dampening demand for materials.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up tracking US market rally, local techs gain
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1.1% on Friday, driven by gains in US tech stocks, which led to a rally in the local electronics subindex. Chipmakers TSMC and UMC were up 1.5% and 2.1% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.388 per US dollar. The rally followed a similar trend in the US, where the S&P 500 closed at its highest in two months on Thursday.

site_title: URA private home price index down 1.3% in Q3
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) reported a 1.3% decline in the private home price index in Q3 2015 compared to the preceding quarter. Landed home prices fell 0.4%, while non-landed home prices dropped 1.5%. The rental index for private homes eased 0.6% in Q3, with a vacancy rate of 7.8%. These results follow a 0.9% decline in Q2 2015.

site_title: Japan's giant IPO becomes tiny as households flock to stocks
summary: Japan's largest initial public offering (IPO) has raised 1.4 trillion yen ($16.2 billion), less than 0.2% of the money held by households, indicating strong demand from individuals. The IPO, which includes Japan Post Holdings and its banking and insurance units, aims to increase risk appetite and encourage a shift from deposits to equities. With over 70% of the offering targeting individuals, the government expects a successful listing to boost investment in stocks, as households have just 11% of their wealth in shares.

site_title: Private housing supply in pipeline continues to shrink in Q3
summary: The supply of uncompleted private homes in Singapore's pipeline decreased to 58,348 units at the end of Q3 2015, down from 61,237 units at the end of Q2. This decline was reported by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). The decrease is attributed to a reduction in new project launches.

site_title: Tiger Airways narrows loss for Q2
summary: Budget carrier Tiger Airways narrowed its loss for its fiscal second quarter, posting a net loss of S$12.76 million, 93% smaller than the S$182.38 million loss in the previous year. Revenue increased 12.8% to S$167.89 million, driven by higher passenger seat revenue. The airline also avoided losses related to divestment and onerous aircraft leases. Tiger Airways plans to capitalize on yield improvement opportunities during the holiday season, introducing new services to Lucknow and Lijiang before the end of the year.

site_title: Asia: ECB speculation sends stocks surging, euro sinks
summary: The European Central Bank hinted at potential fresh stimulus measures, sending Asian stock markets and emerging currencies surging while the euro sank. The euro plummeted to US$1.1103 and 134.01 yen, while Frankfurt and Paris surged over 2%. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney, also rallied, with Seoul adding 1.32%. The ECB's head, Mario Draghi, stated that monetary policy accommodation will need to be re-examined at the December meeting, fueling speculation about potential interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank's hint at fresh stimulus measures for the stuttering eurozone economy sent Asia stock markets and emerging currencies surging Friday, while the euro came under further selling pressure.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q3 profit dives 65 per cent
summary: Great Eastern's Q3 net profit fell 65% to S$68.4 million, mainly due to a 62% plunge in insurance profits. The insurer attributed the decline to large death claims and higher medical claims in Singapore, as well as realised losses from investment sales. Earnings per share dropped to S$0.15, down from S$0.41 in the previous year.

site_title: Alphabet, formerly Google, sets share buyback, shares jump
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, announced its first share buyback and beat Wall Street's profit forecast in Q3 2015, with revenue and profit exceeding analysts' expectations. The company's mobile search strength and growth in paid clicks and cost-per-click were highlighted. Shares rose 9% in after-hours trading to a record $741, valuing the company at around $500 billion. Analysts welcomed the results, citing Alphabet's dominance in the advertising space, but questioned the long-term prospects of its internet-based business in an app-based world.

site_title: HDB resale prices slip 0.3% in Q3
summary: HDB resale prices declined 0.3% in Q3, marking a ninth consecutive quarter of decline. Resale transactions fell 7.4% to 4,893, and subletting applications dropped 4.7% to 10,018 cases. In the first half, 13,036 BTO flats were offered. Next month, HDB will launch 12,000 BTO flats and 5,000 balance flats in a concurrent sale. The decline in prices and transactions follows a Q2 drop, indicating a slowing market.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.1% up on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.1% to 3,070.94 on Friday, driven by dovish remarks from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi, which may signal further eurozone stimulus. Noble Group led gains with a 2.8% increase, followed by Stratech Group and New Silkroutes. Gainers outnumbered losers 128 to 30, marking a fifth consecutive day of gains.

site_title: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos promises Wall Street a profit
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos reassured Wall Street that his company will make a profit in the holiday shopping season, reversing a trend of wide-ranging forecasts since 2010. Bezos' statement was a departure from Amazon's history of caution and came as investors cheer his efforts to disrupt brick-and-mortar retailers. The promise of a profit comes as Amazon expands its services, including selling goods online, producing tablets, and delivering food.

site_title: China to expand financial reform, give markets more say: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang announced plans to expand financial reform and increase the market's role in the country's economy. The Shanghai free trade zone will see financial reform, RMB interest rate marketization, and improvements to the RMB exchange rate mechanism. Li stated China successfully navigated systemic financial risks and dismissed concerns over the renminbi's value. This move aims to promote market-driven reforms and reduce government intervention in the financial sector.

site_title: Australia flags concerns on US$35b Halliburton bid for Baker Hughes
summary: Australia's competition watchdog has expressed concerns over Halliburton's proposed US$35 billion takeover of Baker Hughes, citing potential harm to competition in oilfield goods and services markets. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is particularly worried about the supply of complex projects, such as off-shore drilling. The ACCC initially expected a decision by July 9 but has postponed it twice, with the merger now expected to close by December 16, potentially into 2016.

site_title: 3M plans 1,500 job cuts as US dollar pinches overseas sales
summary: 3M plans to cut 1,500 jobs globally as part of a restructuring effort to combat sluggish overseas sales and a strong US dollar. The move will result in pretax savings of $130 million next year. CEO Inge Thulin emphasized the need for the company to become "a stronger, more agile, more focused company." The restructuring plan will focus on reducing US overhead and retrenchment in slow-growth international markets, with a fourth-quarter pretax charge of about $100 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.77% higher on weak yen, ECB comments
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.77% higher on October 23, 2015, driven by a weaker yen and positive signals from the European Central Bank. The Nikkei 225 index rose 326.78 points to 18,762.65. This follows a strong positive lead from Wall Street.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump to 2-mth high after ECB sparks global rally
summary: Australian shares rose 1.6% to a 2-month high on Friday, driven by a global rally sparked by the European Central Bank's potential to offer more stimulus to stimulate the euro zone economy and combat weak inflation. The ECB signaled it could extend its quantitative easing program, causing a surge in markets. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,350.40, its largest daily percentage gain since October 5.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Far East Orchard, Sheng Siong, Keppel, SembMarine
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies made announcements that may influence trading. Far East Orchard plans to expand its Oasia brand with three new hotels and serviced residences, adding over 700 rooms. Sheng Siong Group posted an 18.7% growth in net profit due to new-store sales and higher margins. Keppel Corp's third-quarter net profit fell 12.4% due to a challenging offshore industry, while Sembcorp Marine's revenue declined 17% due to low oil prices and oversupply. These announcements may impact trading on Friday.

site_title: Volkswagen says second type of engine not fitted with cheating device
summary: Volkswagen has confirmed that 11 million vehicles, including those with the EA 288 engine, do not have the cheating device installed, potentially easing the company's emissions scandal. The company had previously tested whether the EA 288 engines, which replaced the EA 189 engines, were equipped with the software. Volkswagen has set aside 6.5 billion euros for repairs, but analysts estimate the cost could be as high as 15-20 billion euros. The revelation may help the company avoid a fresh blow, but the scandal continues to impact Volkswagen's market capitalization and global reputation.

site_title: Ezra sinks into the red for Q4
summary: Ezra Holdings, an offshore services group, reported a Q4 net loss of US$7.81 million due to a loss from discontinued operations, reversing a US$11.04 million profit in the same period last year. However, net profit from continuing operations increased 22% year-on-year to US$8.89 million. Full-year profit declined 3% to US$43.73 million, with earnings per share falling to 2.29 US cents.

site_title: US investigators still unsure of cause of airbag ruptures
summary: US safety investigators remain uncertain about the cause of deadly Takata airbag ruptures, despite linking the issue to volatile ingredients, age, and use in hot climates. Seven deaths and scores of injuries have been reported in the US from 121 unintended eruptions, with the problem also affecting cars in other countries. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is working to accelerate a replacement campaign, which will require more than six months to complete, affecting 23 million airbags in US cars. The recall affects cars of at least 12 automakers and could be expanded if necessary.

site_title: Euro drops as ECB whets hopes for more stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) held its interest rate steady at a record low 0.05%, but signaled it could consider additional stimulus to combat low inflation and weak growth. ECB President Mario Draghi hinted at the possibility of a further interest rate reduction, potentially even negative interest rates. This led to a significant decline in the euro against the US dollar, trading at its lowest level in over two months. The ECB will review its monetary policy stance in December, raising expectations of potential economic stimulus.

site_title: Xi heads north as Britain seeks Chinese cash for regeneration
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping concluded a four-day state visit to Britain, sealing 40 billion pounds of business deals. The visit focused on attracting Chinese infrastructure investment, particularly in the north of England, aiming to regenerate the region. New air links between China and Manchester were announced, with Hainan Airlines Co Ltd to operate direct flights, boosting the city's economy by 50 million pounds. The visit also included partnerships to build and finance regeneration projects and the finalization of a 85 million pound acquisition. Human rights concerns were not explicitly addressed.

site_title: Malaysia Budget Day guide: juggling spending against deficit
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak will unveil the government's budget plans on Friday, navigating an economic slowdown and a commitment to balance the budget by 2020. The country faces a funding scandal linked to Najib, spooking foreign investors and contributing to market sell-offs. Moody's Investors Service will monitor efforts to trim the budget deficit. Najib must balance stimulating the economy with convincing investors of his fiscal rectitude, amid potential political implications.

site_title: Oil prices rebound on bargain-hunting
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, rebounding from a sharp decline the previous day, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) adding four cents to $45.24 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude rising nine cents to $47.94 a barrel. Despite the gain, analysts said the market remains hobbled by an oversupply, with US crude inventory building by eight million barrels to 476.6 million. A meeting between Opec and non-Opec oil producers did not produce meaningful results, and the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' policy-setting meeting on December 4 is expected to provide vital clues about price development.

images.alt_text: World oil prices rose on Thursday on bargain-hunting after a sharp decline the day before, although analysts said the market remains hobbled by an oversupply.

site_title: Ex-Rabobank trader describes 'culture' of manipulating rates
summary: A former Rabobank trader testified against two colleagues, citing a "culture" of manipulating Libor rates to benefit their own trading positions. Takayuki Yagami, who pleaded guilty last year, described a system where senior traders, including Anthony Allen and Anthony Conti, would submit artificially low interest rates. Yagami cooperated with prosecutors and testified that he was part of this "culture" since joining the bank in 2000. The case is the first to go to trial following investigations into banks submitting artificial rate estimates to bolster profits on trading derivatives tied to Libor.

site_title: Retooled Microsoft gets earnings boost
summary: Microsoft reported a 2% increase in profits to $4.6 billion in the past quarter, beating analyst forecasts. Revenue dipped 12% to $23.2 billion due to currency movements. The company's focus on cloud-based software is delivering results, with "intelligent cloud" revenue growing 8% and customer excitement for new devices and services increasing. Microsoft shares jumped 6% after the announcement, with analysts calling it a "strong and clean quarter." The company is shifting to offer more services through the cloud to adapt to a changing landscape.

site_title: KL-S'pore high-speed rail seen adding RM100b to M'sia's GDP
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail project is expected to contribute RM100 billion to Malaysia's GDP, with RM70 billion from construction and operations, and RM30 billion from increased economic activity in realty, tourism, and service sectors. Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong reiterated their commitment to the project, with 150 companies showing interest in the proposed high-speed rail link. A response to a request-for-information (RFI) exercise is due next month, with feedback crucial in shaping the project's commercial model.

site_title: Realising a magnificent obsession
summary: Philippe Petit's daring attempt to walk between New York's World Trade Center towers is chronicled in "The Walk," directed by Robert Zemeckis. Petit, played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt, narrates his journey from a street performer in Paris to a high-wire artist, and ultimately, to his 1974 stunt. With a team of conspirators, Petit executes the "artistic coup of the century" despite numerous mishaps and a lack of safety precautions. The film, with stunning 3D visuals, captures the thrill and danger of Petit's feat, making it an entertaining and fresh take on the true story.

site_title: The China story keeps getting better
summary: China's film industry is experiencing significant growth, with a 45% year-on-year increase in box-office sales and over $7 billion in revenue. Bona Film Group, a major player in China's film industry, is capitalizing on this trend, financing films like Southpaw and co-producing Kung Fu Panda 3 with DreamWorks Animation. CEO Yu Dong attributes China's success to its large and growing market, with over 30% year-on-year growth in the last decade. The company is poised to take advantage of this growth, with plans to delist from Nasdaq and relist on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

site_title: US stocks surge on earnings, dovish ECB
summary: US stocks surged on Thursday, driven by dovish signals from the European Central Bank and strong earnings from McDonald's, Texas Instruments, and others. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 1.87% to 17,489.16, while the S&P 500 rose 1.66% to 2,052.51. Technology companies, including Apple, Facebook, and Intel, saw significant gains, while health stocks, including UnitedHealth Group and Aetna, fell. The US rally followed big jumps in equity markets in Paris and Frankfurt after ECB chief Mario Draghi hinted at possible additional monetary stimulus.

site_title: Amazon shares catch fire on surprise profit
summary: Amazon reported a surprise profit of $79 million in the third quarter, surpassing analyst expectations of a loss. The company's total sales grew 23% year-over-year to $25.4 billion, driven by a 28.3% increase in North America sales and a 78.4% gain in cloud computing services. Amazon's shares rose 10.7% in after-hours trade to $624.50. The company's online video services, including Prime, have been successful, with 47 million US members spending an average of $1,200 per year. Amazon expects net sales to grow 14-25% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: 'Despicable' conditions at China iPhone plant: report
summary: An undercover report by China Labour Watch alleges severe labor rights violations and poor working conditions at a Pegatron Group factory in Shanghai, China, where Apple iPhones are manufactured. The report documents 23 violations, including low pay, long hours, unpaid work, and despicable living conditions, with workers earning only $318 per month and living in overcrowded dorms with mould and bed bugs. Despite Apple's pledge to improve conditions, the report found ongoing problems since a 2013 report.

images.alt_text: An Apple contractor factory in China houses its workers in overcrowded dormitories lined with mould and crawling with bed bugs, a labor watchdog alleged on Thursday.

site_title: South Korea's economy rebounds from Mers outbreak as shoppers return
summary: South Korea's economy rebounded in the third quarter, expanding 1.2% from the previous quarter, driven by consumers returning to shops after the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome outbreak receded. This growth offset weakness in sales abroad, with GDP expanding 2.6% from a year earlier. Economists had projected a 1% increase. Policymakers highlighted positive signs, but cautioned about ongoing risks and uncertainties in overseas markets.

images.alt_text: South Korea's economy rebounded in the third quarter as an outbreak of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome receded and consumers ventured back to the shops, offsetting weakness in sales abroad.

site_title: ECB signals Dec policy review, keeps money-printing unchanged
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) left interest rates and its money-printing programme unchanged, signaling a review in December to tackle weak inflation and boost economic recovery. ECB President Mario Draghi emphasized that the bank will fully pursue its asset purchase scheme, potentially extending it beyond September 2016. Draghi urged eurozone governments to support economic recovery through fiscal policies, while monetary policy should not be the only game in town.

site_title: Google shares leap as quarterly profit beats expectations
summary: Google's parent company Alphabet reported a 45% increase in quarterly profit to $3.98 billion, beating Wall Street expectations, with revenue up 13% to $18.67 billion. Shares surged over 10% in after-market trades. The company's mobile search business and YouTube contributed to the growth, with expenses kept in check. Alphabet also authorized $5.09 billion in new shares. The new parent company aims to focus on core business while offering flexibility for long-shot projects, led by CEO Larry Page and executive chairman Eric Schmidt.

site_title: Wind orchestra pays tribute to Singapore
summary: The Philharmonic Winds orchestra is paying tribute to Singapore and its founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew with their upcoming concert, Singapore Compose! 2015. The concert features five new pieces written by Singaporean composers, including veterans Zechariah Goh and Robert Casteels, and young talents Terrence Wong Fei Yang and Gregory Gu Wei. The pieces, including L.K.Y. - Legacy by Dr. Goh, aim to showcase a softer side of the late leader and pay homage to his legacy. The concert takes place on October 24 at the Esplanade Concert Hall, with free admission.

site_title: Smaller price growth in Q3 shows end of Sydney housing boom: Domain
summary: Sydney's housing boom appears to be ending, with house prices growing just 3.2% in Q3, the slowest quarterly rate since March 2014. Economists predict a fall in prices over the next two years due to increased supply and lower-than-expected population growth. Regulatory changes and rising mortgage rates are also contributing to market slowdowns in Sydney and Melbourne, with some experts predicting a 40% valuation overvaluation in Sydney homes.

site_title: Comics as instruments of US diplomacy
summary: US comic book star Donald Duck has been identified as a symbol of American imperialism, spreading American culture and values abroad. His character has been viewed as an imperialist in Latin American countries, particularly in Chile, where a US-approved coup led to the overthrow of a popularly elected president in 1973. The US government uses comic books as part of its overseas propaganda strategy to achieve specific foreign policy goals, reflecting the influence of American culture and values on host countries.

site_title: China's record capital outflows put Tobin Tax back on agenda
summary: China is considering implementing a Tobin Tax to curb record capital outflows, which have resulted in a record $329 billion decline in foreign exchange reserves in the first nine months of 2023. The move aims to stabilize the yuan and interest rates by penalizing currency speculation. However, experts warn that a Tobin Tax may not be effective in the long run, as it could drive high-quality capital out of the market. China's leadership is also considering liberalizing its capital account by 2020, which could further impact the yuan's value.

site_title: Majors face heaviest toll yet from oil downturn
summary: Oil majors are expected to post the worst earnings since the sector's downturn, with writedowns dominating headlines due to a 17% drop in crude prices. Companies have made drastic cuts to investment budgets, mainly in exploration activities, with Shell's Alaskan Arctic drilling program resulting in a potential $4.1 billion write-off. Analysts predict further impairments across the industry, with 20% of upstream investments at risk if oil prices remain at $70 a barrel.

site_title: Choose-your-own-romance over dinner
summary: A Singaporean theatre company has created a "choose-your-own-romance" dinner play called Mind Map of Love, where diners decide the fate of a romantic couple's relationship. Based on a book by Christian Zott, the play explores various stages of love, including romance, jealousy, and infidelity. The dinner theatre production, which takes place at Zott's True Alps restaurant, features two couples and allows diners to influence the story's outcome. The play runs from November 4-14, with tickets starting at $160.

site_title: Xiaomi's plans include online services and e-commerce
summary: Xiaomi aims to become an Internet company, rivaling Alibaba, with plans for online services, e-commerce, digital movies, and games. CEO Bin Lin envisions a future where smartphones serve as the center for various smart devices, including self-balancing scooters and TVs. The company predicts a shift in revenue from hardware sales to online services and content, challenging Alibaba's dominance in e-commerce. Xiaomi's tailored Android software and growing presence in emerging countries, including India, where it has sold over 3 million smartphones, position the company for a future beyond hardware sales.

site_title: China and UK sign extensive trade and investment deals worth £40b
summary: China and the UK signed £40 billion trade and investment deals, focusing on bilateral investment, infrastructure, and innovation. The agreements include China's stake in the Hinkley nuclear power plant and cooperation on cyber-espionage. The deals helped lift the sterling against the US dollar. Key investments include a £15.4 billion nuclear power plant in Somerset and £3.8 billion in infrastructure projects. The agreements marked a significant expansion of trade and investment between the two countries.

site_title: Dual-class shares worth considering, but tread carefully
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering lifting its ban on dual-class shares, a move that could attract large-cap listings and inject interest into the local market. The ban was implemented in 1989 after a failed experiment with "Local and Foreign" shares, which led to a 20% price difference between the two. Advocates argue that safeguards can protect shareholders, but caution warns that artificial divisions can lead to complicated outcomes. The move aims to elevate Singapore's market to the level of the US, where dual-class shares are common.

site_title: GIC partners Tishman Speyer in Hyderabad JV
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has partnered with New York-based real estate company Tishman Speyer in a 50-50 joint venture to co-own an office development project in Hyderabad, India. The project, called WaveRock, will have a total area of 2.5 million sq ft and house over 20,000 professionals. GIC declined to disclose the investment amount, but described it as an "accretive income asset." The final phase of the project is expected to be completed over the next two years, with existing space fully leased to global technology and industrial companies.

site_title: SATS makes offer for Brahim's-owned unit
summary: SATS Ltd has made a conditional binding offer to buy a 49% stake in Brahim's Airline Catering Holdings Sdn Bhd for RM218 million (S$71 million). The offer includes an earn-out sum of up to RM108 million, conditional on meeting financial targets. Brahim's shares surged 44% following the announcement, while SATS shares rose 1% to S$3.86. The move comes after Brahim's catering unit suffered losses due to delayed payments from Malaysian Airlines.

site_title: S'pore's future as financial centre to be innovation-driven
summary: Singapore aims to maintain its position as a leading regional and global financial hub through innovation, driven by the convergence of technology and finance. The country has consistently ranked highly in global competitiveness and transparency, but faces challenges from neighboring nations. To stay ahead, Singapore must balance constructive regulation with innovation, adoption of technology, and building a differentiated talent base. The private sector, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore, is responding to this challenge, with a focus on strengthening liquidity in Asian bond markets and innovation through advanced analytics.

site_title: Different ways to shop till you drop
summary: Suntec City in Singapore is hosting various shopping events, including a grand opening and pop-up designer fashion bazaars, to attract customers for the next two weekends. The mall has undergone a $410 million renovation, introducing flagship stores of international brands Uniqlo and H&M, as well as new-concept stores like W Optics. Other attractions include the revamped Sky Garden and the optical illusion museum Alive Museum. Additionally, boutiques and the Club 21 Bazaar are offering discounted prices and charity initiatives, with proceeds going to local charities.

site_title: MBS rakes in record Q3 mass gaming gains
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) achieved its best quarterly mass gaming win in Singapore since its opening five years ago, with a record US$4.8 million daily win in the third quarter. This helped Las Vegas Sands (LVS) offset a 47% year-on-year decline in net income from Macau operations, with adjusted property Ebitda climbing 10.8% to US$389.7 million. The mass gaming segment's strength is attributed to the successful execution of LVS's strategy to attract premium mass customers from Asia, with MBS's business deemed "not China dependent" and "very sustainable".

site_title: Tech firms seeking record funding
summary: Tech firms are seeking record funding amid slowing global growth, with investors demanding a premium to lend in an industry prone to disruption. Western Digital, Lam Research, and Dell are among companies planning major deals, raising over $105 billion in debt across US investment and high-yield markets. Investors are wary of the obsolescence factor and challenges that may surface, and companies may have to pay up for longer-term paper. Despite this, some analysts are more confident about Western Digital's deal, which aims to return to investment grade status within three to five years.

site_title: When you are truly your own best critic
summary: A wine enthusiast shares the importance of trusting one's own judgement when evaluating wine, rather than relying on others' opinions. According to the author, individual experiences and backgrounds shape our perception of taste, making it impossible for others to replicate our unique memory bank of flavors. The author emphasizes that it's okay to disagree with others, even if a wine has high ratings or a famous name, and encourages readers to trust their own assessments, even if they don't like a particular wine.

site_title: Logistics sector to get high-tech boost
summary: The Singapore government plans to boost the logistics sector with a S$35 million investment in technology. The funds will be used to test automated guided vehicles in warehousing and coordinate deliveries to malls, aiming to reduce trucks on the road by a quarter, delivery manpower by 40%, and waiting time by 65%. The government also plans to develop a national digital infrastructure for trade systems, build a logistics talent pipeline, and establish an industry chassis pool to optimize fleet utilization.

site_title: China looking at merging parts of country's big 3 airlines
summary: China is considering merging parts of its three biggest airlines, Air China, China Southern, and China Eastern, as part of a broader reform of state-owned enterprises. A plan to combine cargo operations has been circulated among regulators, while other options include combining passenger businesses or combining at least two of the airlines. The move would create Asia's largest airline, with over 1,000 planes, and give them a virtual monopoly in the world's growing air travel market. No decision has been made, but the potential merger would follow similar moves in other sectors such as railways and shipping.

site_title: Nothing soft about a personal and hard-hitting performance
summary: Choy Ka Fai's documentary and dance performance, SoftMachine, was showcased at Singapore International Festival of Arts. The performance featured interviews with contemporary dance artists from 13 cities in five countries, spanning three years. SoftMachine demonstrated how documentation can be integrated into a personal and impactful performance, highlighting the intersection of dance and documentary. The event was part of TheatreWorks' massive contemporary dance documentation project, which began in 2012.

images.alt_text: Zi Han and Xiao Ke of Shanghai have never performed in China - only overseas.
Keigo Mikajiri, Choy and Tsukahara getting physical in their segment.

site_title: Singapore property developer sentiment worsens in Q3: survey
summary: Singapore property developers' sentiment worsened in Q3, with 83% of respondents calling for cooling measures to be lifted or tweaked within the next 6 months. The main concerns include a global economic slowdown, rising inflation, and interest rates. Developers expect a moderate decline in residential property prices and believe they should cut prices to move unsold stock. The Current Sentiment Index dipped to 3.7, while the Future Sentiment Index also fell to 3.7, indicating a decline in market confidence.

site_title: FCT Q4 DPU up; eyes on rental reversions
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 2.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, driven by higher rental revenue. The trust's full-year DPU rose 3.8% to 11.608 Singapore cents. Despite a dip in average occupancy rate to 96% for FY15, steady shopper traffic lifted rental figures. However, analysts are cautious about the impact of upcoming lease expirations and potential tenant mix changes on FCT's performance, particularly at its largest malls.

site_title: New Qingdao branch is DBS's 34th outlet in China
summary: DBS Bank officially opened its 34th outlet in China, a new branch in Qingdao, Shandong province. The branch will provide corporate banking services, including deposit facilities, loans, and trade financing, to Shandong clients. This move boosts DBS's network in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Shanghai halts land auctions as surging prices worry officials
summary: Shanghai has halted six land auctions since October 12, citing concerns over surging property prices. The city's officials aim to regulate the market after the government's easing of curbs led to rapid price increases. Land auctions have been rescheduled to increase the number of apartments that can be built, bringing down prices. Shanghai's mayor, Han Zheng, has stated that controlling home prices is crucial for the city's competitiveness, with prices already at their highest since 2011, averaging 34,632 yuan per square meter.

site_title: Far East Hospitality to expand Oasia brand next year
summary: Far East Hospitality plans to expand its Oasia brand next year, adding over 700 rooms in Singapore and Malaysia. The move aims to replicate the success of Oasia Hotel Novena and will include the opening of three new hotels and serviced residences. This expansion will further grow the company's portfolio, positioning it for success in the European market as well.

site_title: Jakarta seeks China funds to boost growth as FDI stagnates
summary: Indonesia seeks more Chinese funds to boost economic growth, as foreign direct investment (FDI) stagnated at $7.4 billion in the last quarter. The government aims to exceed its full-year target of 519.5 trillion rupiah, despite a World Bank forecast of 4.7% GDP growth, below the government's target of 5%. President Joko Widodo has reshuffled his cabinet and issued policy measures to encourage business, and the government has announced a tax incentive to encourage companies to revalue their fixed assets. China has offered $100 billion in total investments, but the realisation rate of Chinese investment is only 10%.

site_title: Changi Airport awards S$1.12b contract for three-runway system
summary: Changi Airport Group awarded a S$1.12 billion contract to Samsung C&T Corp and Koh Brothers JV to convert an existing 3rd runway for civil-military use, as part of its plan to roll out a three-runway system by the early 2020s. The award follows a competitive tender and marks the first of several packages to be completed.

site_title: Julius Baer looks to S'pore for its first foreign-currency Additional Tier 1 notes
summary: Julius Baer Group, a Swiss bank, plans to issue Singapore dollar Basel III-compliant Additional Tier 1 (AT1) notes in Singapore, marking its first foreign-currency AT1s under the Basel III regime and the first AT1s from a foreign bank in the country.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: EMS Group, formed after merging EMS Energy and Koastal Group, has signed a binding letter of intention with an Asia-based shipyard worth US$570 million. The contract is expected to significantly impact the group's financial performance from 2016 to 2019. Meanwhile, Sim Lian Group issued a profit warning, expecting a significant reduction in pre-tax profit and a net loss for the first quarter ended September 2015.

site_title: Work-pleasure divide now fuzzy for Asian biz travellers (Amended)
summary: A survey commissioned by the Singapore Tourism Board found that Asian business travelers have more autonomy in choosing airlines and hotels, and often blur the lines between work and leisure. 69% of respondents can choose their preferred airline, and 74% can choose their accommodation. Asian business travelers are also more likely to extend their business trips to include leisure time, with 12% doing so compared to 7% of Europeans. The report suggests that travel companies should focus on marketing to business travelers themselves, rather than relying on traditional corporate contracting functions, as the distinction between business and leisure trips becomes increasingly fuzzy.

images.alt_text: ASIAN business travellers today have more autonomy in business travel, and often blur the lines between work and play, a report commissioned by the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has found.

site_title: MPA may grant more than one LNG bunkering licence in next 2 years
summary: The Maritime Port Authority (MPA) in Singapore plans to award more than one liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering license within the next two years, with a target start-up date of 2017. This move aims to create initial demand for LNG bunkering in Singapore, which is part of the country's goal to become an LNG bunkering hub by 2030. MPA has also initiated funding for shipowners to build LNG-fuelled vessels and is exploring technology to optimize the use of land-scarce resources, including the use of unmanned aerial vehicles for port surveillance.

site_title: A unique alliance of kindred spirits
summary: Akram Khan, a kathak exponent, and Israel Galvan, a flamenco dancer, collaborated on a dance theatre piece called Torobaka, blending their traditional art forms with a contemporary mindset. The six performers, including musicians, took the stage in a minimalist setting, communicating through movement and dialogue. The piece showcased fluidity and energy, highlighting similarities and echoes between kathak and flamenco styles. The audience gave a standing ovation, praising the unique collaboration of "kindred spirits." Torobaka was a true interaction of artists, where they drew out the best in each other and poked fun at their respective traditions.

site_title: Worlds apart but together at heart
summary: Andrea Bocelli and Cantopop singer-actress Karen Mok recorded a duet of "Cheek to Cheek" despite never meeting, using technology to join their separate recordings. The song, from Bocelli's album "Cinema", features a collection of movie themes and was originally performed by Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. Mok credits her acting background for helping her get into character while recording the duet, and emphasizes the importance of communication and teamwork in creating a great duet. The song is now available on the Deluxe Asian edition of "Cinema".

site_title: Japan offers soft loan for India's US$15b high-speed train
summary: Japan has offered India a soft loan of less than 1% interest for a $15 billion high-speed train project, potentially beating China's bid. The project, connecting Mumbai and Ahmedabad, would reduce travel time to 2 hours from 7, with 80% of costs covered by Japan. India must buy 30% of equipment from Japanese firms. The decision comes as Japan pushes back against China's involvement in infrastructure development in South Asia, with Tokyo's Transport Minister stating that Japan aims to step up exports of transport systems to India and South-east Asia.

site_title: California 'duck curve' will jolt its power grid
summary: California's power grid will face increased price volatility and potential disruptions due to the "duck curve" phenomenon, where the need for gas-fired generation surges to meet electricity demand after sunset. As solar power generation drops off, the state's reliance on natural gas-fired plants will become more pronounced, exacerbating the issue. Regulators warn that the grid's vulnerability to price spikes and power disruptions will worsen unless flexible resources are implemented to balance shifts in demand and supply. California's goal of getting half its electricity from renewable sources by 2030 will also contribute to the problem.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers have issued updates on First Reit, Tigerair, and Singapore Exchange. First Reit is recommended to 'accumulate' with a target price of S$1.49 due to attractive divestment and acquisition prices. Tigerair's results are expected to be disappointing, maintaining a 'hold' rating with a target price of S$0.315. Singapore Exchange's earnings per share are expected to be lower, upgrading to 'hold' with a target price of S$7.98.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q3 profit up 18.7%
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 18.7% growth in net profit for its fiscal third quarter, reaching $14.5 million, driven by new-store sales and higher operating margins. Revenue increased by 7.3% to $200 million, with five new stores contributing 6.2 percentage points to revenue growth. Despite weak same-store sales, the company attributed this to factors such as the Malaysian ringgit and renovation works. Cumulative net profit improved by 17.8% to $42.2 million for the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Keppel Corp's Q3 profit falls 12.4%
summary: Keppel Corp's third-quarter net profit fell 12.4% to S$362.9 million due to a 23.4% drop in revenue. The company attributed the decline to lower profit contribution from its offshore & marine segment. Despite this, the group's other business segments showed higher net profit contributions. CEO Loh Chin Hua credited the results as "creditable" given the challenging global environment, citing resilience and opportunities in other areas, such as floating liquefied natural gas conversion and offshore rig acquisition.

site_title: A seamless collaboration between visuals and verse
summary: Singaporean artist Lin Lu Zai and photographer Kwek Leng Joo collaborate to create a fresh art format by merging Chinese brush painting with photographs. The duo's works, unveiled at the National Museum, feature verses and Chinese motifs, with Lin adding elements to Kwek's nature photographs. The collaboration resulted in 40 works, with proceeds going towards the President's Challenge 2015, raising over S$500,000 for the needy. This unique art format showcases the seamless collaboration between visuals and verse, blending traditional Chinese art with modern photography.

site_title: Nothing new about retro teen movie
summary: Our Times, a Taiwanese coming-of-age high school rom-com, has become a surprise domestic box-office smash, grossing NT$400 million (S$17.1 million). The film, directed by Frankie Chen, marks her directorial debut and features a fresh-faced cast, including Vivian Sung, who earned a Golden Horse Award nomination for Best Actress. The movie's predictable storyline and long running time of over two hours may disappoint some viewers, but its nostalgic value and fun cast make it a hit among die-hard romantics and 15-year-old girls.

site_title: RBC to tap Samurai market amid optimism after Liberal party victory
summary: Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) plans to sell its first Samurai bond in 10 years, tapping into Japanese demand for yield amid optimism over Justin Trudeau's election win. The 10-year security is expected to pay more than double the yield on local government debt. The move follows a decline in Japan's benchmark 10-year bond yield and RBC's decision to leave its benchmark rate unchanged. The bank is also marketing other Samurai bonds with varying maturities.

site_title: Do you really need a chief data officer?
summary: The article discusses the need for a Chief Data Officer (CDO) in today's technology-driven world, where big data is becoming increasingly important for businesses to gain a competitive advantage. The CMO and CIO are often unable to handle the task of managing big data, as it requires a different set of skills and expertise. A mathematician with business acumen is needed to handle data analysis and develop strategies. The CDO will work alongside the CIO and CMO to ensure accountability and compliance, and will be responsible for exploiting data into tangible strategies. The CDO role is a new addition to the C-suite, designed to fill the gap in data management and analysis.

site_title: Ex-banker creates venture combining dark pool, sales desk
summary: Ex-banker David Klinger is launching Block Event, a venue that combines attributes of dark pools and sales desks in Australia, starting in November. The firm will facilitate large share trades and plans to expand into Japan and Indonesia in 2016. Block Event aims to address complaints about other venues by allowing users to send trading intentions without disclosing them, while also providing access to liquidity selectively. The firm will charge lower fees than ASX's Centrepoint and institutions will pay a commission of about 10 basis points.

site_title: Existing home sales rise more than expected
summary: US existing home sales rose 4.7% in September to an annual rate of 5.55 million units, surpassing expectations. This marks the second-highest monthly sales pace since February 2007, suggesting the housing market's continued strength. Sales increased in all regions, with inventory tightening to a 4.8-month supply. Economists expect the housing market to continue recovering at a moderate pace due to labor market improvements and rising employment.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore Restaurant Week returns with a social responsibility angle, raising S$100,000 for The Food Bank Singapore through the "Two-Bucks-For-A-Truck" initiative. Over 100 restaurants, including Haha Thai and Ristorante OSO, will offer exclusive menus and donate up to S$2 per receipt. Meanwhile, Lazada's Battle of the Reds features wine and Singapore Slings from local sellers, with customers winning match-day VIP tickets and a bottle of Reymos Classic Sparkling Wine. The Martell AiR Gallery showcases augmented reality art around Marina Bay Sands, while the Singapore Craft Beer Week kicks off with various beer-related events.

site_title: EU rules Starbucks, Fiat tax deals illegal
summary: The European Commission has ruled that Starbucks and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles benefited from illegal tax deals with the Dutch and Luxembourg authorities. The ruling orders the Netherlands to recover 20-30 million euros in back taxes from Starbucks and Luxembourg to recover a similar amount from Fiat. The decision aims to send a clear message that national tax authorities cannot give any company an unfair competitive advantage. The ruling is seen as a significant blow to profit-shielding arrangements used by multinationals, and one consultant describes it as "rocking the corporate world to its very core".

site_title: No swift recovery seen for depressed bulk freight rates
summary: Bulk freight rates are expected to remain under pressure due to decreasing commodity demand and an increase in vessel fleet, leading to increased pressure for consolidation in the sector. Industry analysts, including JP Morgan's Sokje Lee, predict low shipping rates for years, advising companies to focus on cost-saving measures rather than seeking rate increases. This trend is expected to continue, with no swift recovery in sight for depressed freight rates.

site_title: Twitter to reboot ties with developers: CEO
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey announced plans to "reboot" the platform, seeking to fulfill its mission as a rapid source of information. The company aims to improve ties with third-party developers, providing tools to analyze usage data and enhance integration with apps and websites. This move is seen as a response to strained relationships between Twitter and developers. The goal is to create a more collaborative environment, allowing for better innovation and growth.

images.alt_text: Twitter chief executive Jack Dorsey said on Wednesday that the struggling messaging platform is in the midst of "rebooting" as it seeks to fulfil what he sees as its vital mission as a rapid source of information.

site_title: United profit misses estimates, hurt by strong dollar
summary: United Airlines parent United Continental reported a third-quarter profit of $4.82 billion, missing estimates due to a strong dollar. This was largely due to a one-off tax benefit, with net income excluding the benefit being $1.62 billion. The company's revenue was also impacted by the strong dollar.

site_title: Euro broadly lower with ECB expected to be dovish
summary: The euro fell to a one-month low against the British pound after the European Central Bank kept interest rates unchanged, as expected. The euro was down 0.2% against the US dollar at $1.1320 and 0.5% against the pound at 73.15 pence. Speculation on further quantitative easing by the ECB has dominated currency trading, with a 70% chance of an extension of the program, according to Reuters polling.

site_title: Gold and silver shine again as investors add US$393m to ETFs
summary: Investors added $393 million to US exchange-traded funds backed by precious metals in October, the largest monthly inflow since February, as gold and silver prices rose. The Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged has increased expectations that it will wait until next year to raise rates, making precious metals more attractive. Retail investors are returning to the market after a rout, while bears are retreating, with short positions on silver shrinking by over half this month.

site_title: Manager at Seoul fund pessimistic about country's shipping industry
summary: A South Korean fund, Korea Asset Management Corp (Kamco), is struggling to support the country's shipping industry due to an oversupply of ships, difficulty in securing loans, and lack of bank investment. Kamco is prepared to spend $100 million annually until 2018 to support capital spending. Despite efforts, the shipping industry continues to face widespread distress, with freight rates still lower than a year ago, and South Korean President Park Geun Hye's efforts to revive exports being curbed by declining shipments.

site_title: YouTube to launch ad-free subscription service, music app
summary: YouTube has launched YouTube Red, a paid subscription service offering commercial-free access for $9.99/month, starting October 28 in the US, with plans to roll out worldwide in 2016.
