images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Wednesday after data from an industry group showed a larger-than-expected build in US crude inventories last week, fanning worries over global oversupply, even as a slightly weaker dollar provided some support.

site_title: JPMorgan sees US$90b of short covering left in US stocks
summary: JPMorgan analysts found that despite a three-week rally in the S&P 500 Index, short interest in US stocks remains near a three-year high, indicating no significant short covering. The level of short interest is about 7% and has not budged, suggesting that the rally may not be driven by short-sellers buying back borrowed shares. To bring short interest back to pre-August levels, traders would need to buy back approximately $90 billion of shares, a positive sign for stocks.

site_title: Sony to pay as much as US$8m to settle data-breach case
summary: Sony Corp agreed to pay up to $8 million to settle a data-breach case linked to the theft of employee personal information in a computer hack related to the 2014 release of "The Interview." The breach, blamed on North Korean hackers, exposed Hollywood secrets and caused the movie studio to initially cancel the film's release. Sony Pictures Entertainment agreed to pay current and former employees up to $4.5 million, with lawyers receiving up to $3.5 million. The settlement follows a court ruling that Sony was negligent in maintaining adequate security to prevent the hack.

site_title: Regulators mull reforms to fragile US bond markets
summary: US regulators are considering reforms to the fragile US bond markets, citing the need for stability over speed in electronic trading. Following a 2014 flash rally, regulators have ramped up scrutiny of the $13-trillion market, which has seen an increase in algorithmic strategies that can move billions of dollars rapidly. Proposals include batch auctions, minimum life-spans on orders, and tighter oversight on algorithmic trading, with the goal of reducing volatility and increasing liquidity provision.

site_title: Tesla Model S sedan no longer recommended by Consumer Reports
summary: Consumer Reports no longer recommends Tesla's Model S sedan due to reliability concerns, citing issues with transmission technology and digital multimedia systems. Despite this, 97% of Tesla owners would buy another Model S, with the company addressing issues quickly and efficiently. The decision reflects the challenges of introducing innovative technology in vehicles, which can lead to malfunctions and reliability issues.

site_title: China aims to lure private investors to projects: state media
summary: China aims to attract private investors to infrastructure projects through tax breaks, financial incentives, and streamlined approval processes. The National Development Reform Commission plans to promote public-private partnership funding models, which could improve investment and financing, energize private investment, and enhance public services. Deputy head Zhang Yong said these partnerships could drive structural reform and improve public products.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Industrial Trust, Keppel T&T, Wilmar
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust increased distribution per unit by 7.3% to 2.79 Singapore cents in Q2, driven by a BTS project and higher occupancies and rental rates. Keppel T&T reported a 17.1% drop in Q3 net profit to S$15.31 million, citing a 34.5% fall in operating profit due to decreased revenue and other income.

site_title: Regulation of Treasuries trading needs update, SEC's White says
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission Chair Mary Jo White called for updated oversight and risk controls on high-frequency traders in Treasuries, citing lax regulation and disruptions to stressed markets. She recommended requiring firms to report trades and restricting trading that can cause market volatility. The move comes after Treasury yields plummeted in 2014, with high-frequency traders accounting for over 50% of Treasuries trading on electronic platforms. White emphasized the need for regulators to keep pace with the rapidly changing market, which increasingly resembles the automated world of stock trading.

site_title: Tougher times ahead for Islamic finance as core markets slow
summary: Islamic finance is expected to face tougher times as core markets in the Gulf and southeast Asia slow down due to plunging oil and commodity prices. The industry, which grew at double-digit annual rates for much of the past decade, is now expected to see single-digit growth in 2016, according to Standard & Poor's. The decline in growth is attributed to higher costs, lack of standardization, and reduced investor interest. Despite this, some countries are still expanding the industry, and sukuk issuance remains strong, but overall, Islamic finance is vulnerable to economic slowdowns.

site_title: Wells Fargo signs deal to recruit Credit Suisse's US brokers
summary: Credit Suisse has awarded Wells Fargo the exclusive right to recruit the Swiss bank's US brokers, citing the US brokerage business's profitability but insufficient size to sustain itself without significant investment. Wells Fargo aims to put as many brokers in its offices by early 2016, while Credit Suisse operates about 13 US offices with 275 brokers. Terms of the arrangement were not disclosed.

site_title: Fragmented post-recession Europe harder to govern
summary: A prolonged European financial crisis is exacerbating political divisions, making it harder for governments to govern and implement economic reforms. The crisis has led to a surge in anti-immigration populists, boosting far-right parties and weakening traditional parties of government. Economic growth is not a guarantee of political success, with anxiety over immigration driving electoral behavior in many European countries. A study analyzing 20 advanced economies after financial crises found that policy uncertainty rises and polarization increases, making crisis resolution more difficult, and voters are attracted to the rhetoric of the extreme right.

images.alt_text: A migrant talks to Slovenian police officers at the exit of a makeshift camp near the Austrian border in Sentilj, Slovenia, Oct 20, 2015.

site_title: Hedge fund exit requests drop in October: data
summary: Hedge fund investors reduced their exit requests in October, with the SS&C GlobeOp Forward Redemption Indicator falling to 3% from 3.8% in September. This decline suggests that investors have largely rebalanced their portfolios in response to market volatility. The decrease is attributed to the easing of market conditions, according to SS&C Technologies Chairman Bill Stone. The indicator represents about 10% of the global hedge fund sector and is based on data from fund administrators.

site_title: Japan's Sept export growth slows sharply, adds to recession fears
summary: Japan's annual export growth slowed to 0.6% in September, the third straight month of decline, raising recession fears. Exports to China fell 3.5% from a year earlier, while shipments to Asia declined for the first time in seven months. In contrast, exports to the US rose 10.4% in September, driven by car shipments. The trade balance was a deficit of 114.5 billion yen, marking six straight months of deficits. A third quarter contraction would put Japan into recession, following the second quarter's negative GDP data.

site_title: Britain changes China visa rules to woo big-spending tourists
summary: Britain is introducing a two-year multiple-entry visa for Chinese tourists, aiming to attract high-spending visitors and boost the economy. The new visa, costing 85 pounds, will allow holders to leave and return without paperwork. The move is part of a broader effort to capitalize on China's growing middle class and increase tourism revenue. The number of Chinese tourists visiting Britain has doubled in five years, contributing 500 million pounds annually to the economy. The UK hopes to capitalize on China's luxury spending habits, with analysts estimating 50% savings on overseas purchases compared to China prices.

site_title: Apple tells US judge 'impossible' to unlock new iPhones
summary: Apple has told a US judge that it's "impossible" to unlock a new iPhone with its latest operating system, citing strengthened encryption methods. However, the company has the "technical ability" to help law enforcement access older phones. Apple's lawyers urged the judge not to require the company to comply with the Justice Department's request, citing potential harm to customer trust and the Apple brand. A hearing is expected on Friday to determine the outcome.

site_title: US adds charges against Macau billionaire in UN bribe case
summary: US prosecutors have added charges against Macau billionaire Ng Lap Seng and three others in a UN bribe case. Ng, 68, faces two additional counts including money laundering, along with his assistant Jeff Yin and suspended deputy UN ambassador Francis Lorenzo. Ng previously faced bribery conspiracy charges and paid former UN General Assembly president John Ashe over $500,000 to support a conference center in Macau. Ashe, 61, faces two tax-related charges. The defendants are expected to appear in court on grand jury charges.

site_title: Housing starts rise as construction bolsters US economy
summary: US housing starts rose 6.5% in September to a 1.21 million annualized rate, the second-highest level in eight years. The increase was mainly driven by gains in multifamily home construction. Single-family house construction rose 0.3%. Building permits declined 5% to the lowest since March, indicating a slow rebound. The data suggests American consumers, fueled by an improving job market, will continue to support the housing industry.

site_title: Asia private equity funds hurt Morgan Stanley's Q3 profit
summary: Morgan Stanley's quarterly earnings were hit by a US$235 million loss in its Asian private equity funds, primarily due to a reversal of carry from the funds' strong performance earlier this year. The funds, which manage over US$4.5 billion in Chinese and South Korean companies, suffered losses due to China's stock market turmoil and suspended shares of two large companies in their portfolio. The bank's Asia buyout funds are at odds with some rivals, which are scaling back due to the Volcker rule, and Morgan Stanley executives declined to comment on the potential for the funds' performance to recover.

images.alt_text: A dramatic fall in the value of Morgan Stanley's Asian private equity funds hit the bank's quarterly earnings, highlighting the risks of such investing at a time when rivals are scaling back to avoid losses and higher regulatory costs.

site_title: Spotify partners with Virgin America for in-air streaming
summary: Spotify partners with Virgin America for in-air streaming, offering its entire 30 million-song catalog to passengers on select flights equipped with ViaSat WiFi through March 2. The partnership aims to gain new subscribers and expand the company's reach. This is Spotify's first US airline partnership, following similar collaborations with Uber and British Airways. The move is part of the company's efforts to bring music into consumers' lives, wherever they are.

site_title: Oil ends mixed, US crude eases before inventory report
summary: Oil prices ended mixed on Tuesday, with US crude futures down slightly, ahead of the US government's inventory data. Industry group American Petroleum Institute reported a 7 million barrel increase in US crude stockpiles, exceeding analyst expectations. Brent futures rose 10 cents to $48.71 a barrel, while US crude futures for November settled down 34 cents to $45.55 per barrel. Analysts expect the US Energy Information Administration to report a fourth straight week of builds, citing excessive global supply and the threat of Opec production cuts.

site_title: BOC Aviation's planned IPO could fetch US$5-8b valuation
summary: BOC Aviation, the Singapore-based aircraft leasing unit of Bank of China, is set to list on the Hong Kong mainboard with a planned initial public offering (IPO) valued between US$5 billion and US$8.1 billion. The IPO will account for up to 40% of the enlarged share capital, with funds raised for buying new aircraft and general corporate purposes. The unit's valuation is based on its 2014 net profit of US$308.6 million and a trailing price-to-earnings (P/E) range of 15-20 times earnings.

site_title: Subway shifting all US meat supplies to no-antibiotics
summary: Subway to phase out antibiotic-treated meat in US supply chain, shifting to antibiotic-free chicken and turkey by 2026. The decision follows similar moves by competitors Chipotle and McDonald's. Advocacy groups had been pressing the company to set a timeline for removing antibiotic-treated meat from its menu. The shift aims to reduce the overuse of human antibiotics in livestock production, a growing health concern.

site_title: An Austrian student forces big tech firms to rewrite privacy policy
summary: Austrian student Max Schrems, 28, has prompted big tech firms to rewrite their privacy policies after the European Union's top court struck down the Safe Harbor agreement, allowing for the transfer of Europeans' personal data to the US. The ruling, a result of years of legal wrangling, aims to protect Europeans' privacy rights from US government surveillance. Schrems, the primary plaintiff, requested data from Facebook in 2011, leading to a court case that led to the agreement's downfall. This decision has opened the door for European regulators to investigate US tech companies for their privacy practices.

site_title: Australian opposition clears path to landmark China trade agreement
summary: Australia's main opposition Labor Party has dropped its final objections to a landmark free trade agreement with China, clearing the way for its ratification before the end of the year. The deal, signed last year, will open Chinese markets to Australian farm exporters and the services sector, while easing curbs on Chinese investment in Australia. The agreement is considered the best ever between Beijing and a Western country, significantly expanding ties between the world's second-largest economy and one of Washington's closest allies in Asia.

site_title: JPMorgan close to selling most of Highbridge's PE business: WSJ
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is close to selling the majority of Highbridge Capital Management's private equity business to its management team, led by CEO Scott Kapnick, for an undisclosed amount. The deal would allow Highbridge to operate independently and free from JPMorgan's constraints. JPMorgan would retain a minority stake in the private equity business and its entire hedge fund business. The move is part of JPMorgan's efforts to simplify its business and shed assets that require large capital holdings. The deal is expected to close by the end of this year.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co is close to finalizing a deal to sell the majority of Highbridge Capital Management LLC's private equity business, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: China's financial sector fuels Q3 growth, shrugging off stock rout
summary: China's financial sector drove Q3 growth, despite a stock market rout, with financial services rising 16.1% and services sector output increasing 8.6%. The industrial and construction sectors expanded 5.8%, contributing to a 6.9% overall GDP growth rate. However, economists predict a slowdown in financial services growth in the fourth quarter, which may impact headline GDP growth.

site_title: Facebook instant articles hit iPhones
summary: Facebook's Instant Articles feature has launched on iPhones, displaying news stories from partner publications, such as NBC News and The New York Times, in a faster, 10x quicker loading time than standard mobile web articles. The feature, aimed at improving news consumption, will expand to Android devices by the end of the year. Facebook's chief product officer, Chris Cox, emphasized the feature's goal of providing users with faster access to news, rather than keeping them within the social network.

site_title: Anheuser-Busch to pay up to US$28 million over Beck's labeling
summary: Anheuser-Busch has agreed to pay up to $28 million to settle a class action lawsuit over false labeling of its Beck's beer products, which consumers claimed were made in Germany. The settlement, approved by a Florida federal court, will see households with proof-of-purchase receive up to $50 and those without receive $12. The company has also agreed to label its products as made in the US and make similar changes to its website. The lawsuit was filed in 2013, and over 60,000 claims have been filed, with more expected.

site_title: ETF businesses upbeat on industry growth
summary: Exchange-traded fund businesses predict a 18% annual growth for the next three to five years, according to a global survey by EY. This growth is attributed to ETFs taking market share from traditional active asset managers and passive mutual funds.

site_title: Possibilities abound in infrastructure funding, but hurdles exist
summary: World Bank officials discuss infrastructure financing mismatches at the sixth World Bank-Singapore Infrastructure Finance Summit. Three key issues were highlighted: (1) liquidity mismatch due to regulatory barriers and project structure issues, (2) currency mismatch in public-private partnership projects, and (3) debt maturity mismatch between banks' and private equity firms' loan tenures. These mismatches create challenges for infrastructure funding, leading to a funding gap and difficulties in financing long-lived assets. Experts suggest developing a strong domestic bond market and finding patient capital to address these issues.

site_title: Philippine billionaire Villar may merge his residential, mall units
summary: Philippine billionaire Manuel Villar is considering merging his residential and shopping mall units, combining Vista Land & Lifescapes Inc and Starmalls Inc, to create self-contained communities. The move could make sense given the combined market value of the two companies is around $2.5 billion. Villar aims to diversify by adding shopping malls, schools, hotels, and hospitals to his residential projects, creating "communicities" that cater to homeowners' needs for shopping, entertainment, and services. This move follows a similar strategy by Philippine billionaire Henry Sy, which led to his company SM Prime Holdings becoming the country's largest developer.

site_title: US Senate considers controversial cyber security bill
summary: The US Senate is debating a long-delayed cybersecurity bill that would allow corporations to share information about cyber attacks with the government without concern about lawsuits. The bill, known as the Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act (CISA), has received support from industry groups and lawmakers, but some tech companies and lawmakers, including Rand Paul and Ron Wyden, have expressed opposition due to concerns over user privacy and inadequate protection against cyber attacks. A Senate committee approved the measure 14-1 in March, with a possible Senate passage expected within days.

site_title: BOC launches RMB bond trading index
summary: Bank of China (BOC) has launched its RMB (renminbi) Bond Trading Index, allowing overseas investors to track market prices and raise trading efficiency. The index includes Chinese government bonds and "policy financial bonds" issued by state-owned banks, and will be rebalanced monthly. This move comes as China's capital markets and currency continue to internationalize, with the yuan now taking up a quarter of cross-border settlements and ranking as the fourth most-used currency in the world for payments. The index is a significant step towards China's growing global financial influence.

site_title: Netflix faces challengers in its global campaign
summary: Netflix faces challenges as it expands globally, with some customers like Miguel Díez Ferreira choosing to stick with local streaming services due to lower costs and familiarity with content. Despite adding Spain, Portugal, and Italy to its European roster, Netflix faces regulatory restrictions, stiff competition, and a preference for local-language programming. The company's international base has grown to 24 million paying subscribers, but it reported a 50% drop in US profits, highlighting the need for future growth.

site_title: Lessons for Mario Draghi from a land of sub-zero interest rates
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may consider negative interest rates, as seen in Denmark, but it may not provide a quick fix for Europe's sluggish economy. Negative rates, introduced in Denmark in 2012, have not led to significant economic growth, with Danish households and businesses showing limited investment and consumption. Instead, equities and property markets have benefited, with Danish stocks rising over 100% since 2012. Economists argue that monetary policy loses effectiveness when rates are close to zero, and that negative rates may only raise risks in the short term.

site_title: Yahoo to reshape itself again, after weak results
summary: Yahoo to reshape itself again, after weak results. Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer announced a new focus and partnership with Google to take over search and advertising operations. The struggling Internet pioneer faces ongoing declines in older businesses and will make further changes to operate. Yahoo released quarterly results showing disappointing results, prompting Mayer's restructuring efforts. The partnership with Google aims to boost Yahoo's search and advertising capabilities.

site_title: CNQC International completes RTO deal
summary: CNQC International, a Singapore-based developer and construction company, has completed a reverse takeover (RTO) deal with Guotsing Holding (South Pacific) Investment Pte Ltd, acquiring its target group of companies. The deal marks CNQC International's backdoor listing on the Hong Kong mainboard. The acquisition is CNQC International's latest move in its expansion efforts.

site_title: Norway's fund to seek approval for top property deals, central bank says
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest at $860 billion, will introduce an extra layer of supervision for top property deals over $250 million. The fund's management will need approval from a new investment committee for deals over $250 million and the central bank's board for deals worth over $1 billion. The change aims to ensure a collective anchoring for big real estate investments, as property investments are less reversible than listed shares. This comes after criticism for a $1.6 billion Formula One investment in 2012.

images.alt_text: The board of Norway's central bank is introducing an extra layer of supervision for the country's sovereign wealth fund, which will need to seek approval for all property deals over US$250 million, the bank said on Tuesday.

site_title: Money glut: more to come
summary: Central banks worldwide are expected to continue easing monetary policy in the coming months to combat global low inflation and deflationary pressures. The European Central Bank, Bank of Japan, and People's Bank of China are likely to cut interest rates and increase quantitative easing, while the US Federal Reserve may also ease policy gradually. However, some argue that monetary easing may be less effective this time due to diminishing returns on quantitative easing and the potential for deflationary effects in producer economies. Despite these concerns, the author believes that the "AAA" liquidity cycle will continue, and central banks will likely continue to provide positive returns through monetary policy.

site_title: Mapletree Ind Trust posts 7.3% rise in Q2 DPU
summary: Mapletree Ind Trust (MIT) posted a 7.3% increase in distribution per unit to 2.79 Singapore cents in Q2, driven by 6.2% gross revenue growth and 8.6% net property income. The trust's distributable income rose 7.7% to S$48.9 million. MIT's CEO announced plans for an S$77 million asset enhancement initiative to develop a new high-specification industrial building at the Kallang Basin 4 Cluster, aiming to create an industrial hub for high-value-add businesses.

site_title: Lending data helps euro recover against greenback
summary: The euro rose 0.5% against the US dollar on Tuesday, driven by solid lending data and a change in ECB policymakers' stance before their meeting, reducing the need for further monetary easing. Eurozone banks loosened lending standards, and portfolio inflows continued, supporting the euro. ECB Governing Council member Christian Noyer stated the quantitative easing programme was well-calibrated, and Austrian central bank chief Ewald Nowotny expressed concerns about further stimulus.

images.alt_text: The euro rose 0.5 per cent against the US dollar on Tuesday, helped by solid data and a change in the mood music from European Central Bank policymakers before Thursday's meeting, beating back market bets on further monetary easing.

site_title: Euro edges higher as ECB reports improved bank lending
summary: The euro strengthened to US$1.1346 against the dollar after the European Central Bank reported improved lending conditions in eurozone banks, thanks to its stimulus program. The positive report came ahead of an ECB policy meeting in Malta. Analysts expect the ECB to maintain its dovish stance, potentially extending its quantitative easing program in December. Meanwhile, the Canadian dollar rose after Liberal leader Justin Trudeau's landslide victory, which could lead to increased spending and reduce pressure on the Bank of Canada to cut interest rates.

images.alt_text: The euro edged higher against the dollar on Tuesday after the European Central Bank reported eurozone banks were improving lending conditions for businesses, thanks to its stimulus program.

site_title: WTA Finals line-up still taking shape
summary: The WTA Finals, a US$7 million tournament, is set to take place in Singapore from October 25 to November 1. Only five of the eight berths have been confirmed, with Agnieszka Radwanska becoming the latest to qualify. Top-ranked players Simona Halep, Maria Sharapova, Garbine Muguruza, and Petra Kvitova are also participating, along with Angelique Kerber, Lucie Safarova, Flavia Pennetta, Carla Suárez Navarro, and Karolina Pliskova. Serena Williams will not participate due to injury, and the draw ceremony will be held this Friday to determine the exact groups and matches.

site_title: Sydney housing market cools as auction rate falls
summary: Sydney's housing market has cooled, with the auction clearance rate falling to 66.6% for the week ending Oct 18, the lowest level in 10 months. This follows a surge in home values, which rose 44% in three years, reducing affordability. Westpac Banking Corp increased home loan rates, and economists predict a fall in prices over the next two years due to increasing supply and lower population growth. Property researchers also estimate a slowdown in price growth to 4-9% in 2016, citing an oversupply of homes in some areas.

site_title: Morgan Stanley Q3 casts doubt on low-risk strategy
summary: Morgan Stanley's Q3 earnings cast doubt on CEO James Gorman's low-risk strategy, with the bank earning US$740 million, its worst annualized return on equity among major US banks. Wealth management performed relatively well, but fixed-income trading and other revenue declined significantly due to restructuring and losses in China. Shareholders wiped out US$4.7 billion of value, pushing the bank below book value, while Goldman Sachs trades at almost 1.1 times book value.

site_title: United Air names general counsel as acting CEO
summary: United Continental Holdings Inc appointed general counsel Brett Hart as acting CEO, effective immediately, following CEO Oscar Munoz's heart attack four days prior. Hart, 46, will lead the airline until Munoz's recovery is confirmed. The airline's future plans and treatment timeline remain uncertain.

site_title: Liftboat orders help Triyards' earnings
summary: Marine and engineering firm Triyards Holdings reported a 2% rise in full-year net profit to US$27.15 million, driven by constant liftboat order intake despite a lower oil price environment. Q4 earnings climbed 59% to US$8.4 million. The company's net order book doubled to US$564 million, with over US$300.9 million in new liftboat construction contracts. Triyards faces increasing competition in the liftboat segment but remains resilient in charter rates.

site_title: Fifa's leaders meet amid latest scandal storm
summary: FIFA's executive committee met in Zurich, amid a scandal storm, as acting president Issa Hayatou attempts to restore public trust. President Sepp Blatter, secretary general Jerome Valcke, and Michel Platini were suspended for 90 days from all football-related activities. The meeting comes after a Swiss investigation into Blatter's management and allegations of bribery in awarding the 2018 and 2022 World Cups. Platini, a potential candidate for the presidency, admitted to a "man-to-man agreement" for a payment to him, while Blatter's presidential election is set for February 26.

site_title: Big oil companies are back in favour
summary: Big oil companies such as Total, Shell, and BP are regaining favor among analysts as they cut spending and reduce output to ride out the oil-price downturn. Despite bleak forecasts, these companies have the highest proportion of "buy" ratings in a year, indicating faith in their ability to weather the commodities rout. Analysts predict that the industry's spending cuts and job losses will be sufficient to bolster oil prices and foster profit growth, with some expecting a recovery in the oil market.

site_title: Interferry growing in strength as advocate for ferry sector
summary: Interferry, a ferry operators' association, has been increasingly effective in advocating for the ferry sector, addressing environmental issues and safety concerns. At its 40th annual conference in Copenhagen, Interferry's regulatory affairs director, Johan Roos, emphasized the need for realistic solutions to control emissions, working closely with EU officials. Environmental regulations and fire safety were also discussed, with Interferry advocating for enhanced passive protection and improved security measures. Despite concerns over the industry's impact on air pollution, Interferry aims to balance sustainability with commercial viability.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Boustead Projects clinched two contracts worth S$59 million in Singapore, while COSCO Corp won US$150 million contracts to build an oil tanker and two cargo transfer vessels. UNITED Overseas Bank expanded its Hong Kong premises, increasing its area by 70%, and CITIC Envirotech secured a S$88 million EPC contract for a wastewater treatment plant in China. SunMoon Food Company settled a lawsuit with nTan Corporate Advisory for S$2.1 million plus 7% GST.

site_title: Morgan Stanley's lending business shines
summary: Morgan Stanley's wealth management arm saw a 6% profit increase in the third quarter, driven by a 25% rise in net interest income from its lending business, which rose 33% from the same period last year. The bank's efforts to build up its lending business, including hiring staff and revamping its compensation structure, are part of its broader strategy to make itself safer after the financial crisis. The growth in lending income helped lift the business's pre-tax profit margin to 23%, up two percentage points from the same quarter last year.

site_title: Palm oil, paper firms want to fight haze, but ground situation remains complex
summary: Thick haze in Central Kalimantan, Indonesia, poses health risks due to fine particles. Local activist Emmanuela Shinta distributes 25,000 masks from Singapore, warning that local surgical masks are ineffective. The haze affects nearby villages, with residents advised to use the provided masks. The situation remains complex, with efforts to combat haze from palm oil and paper firms hindered by ground conditions.

site_title: Sale-and-leaseback gain boosts EMAS bottom line
summary: EMAS Offshore Ltd posted a Q4 net profit of US$36.3 million, more than doubling from US$12.9 million a year ago, driven by a 178% increase in net other operating income from US$48.3 million. This was despite lower revenue and a gross loss, resulting from vessel sale-and-leaseback transactions.

site_title: Australia seeks more capital, competition for major banks
summary: Australia has accepted most key recommendations of a government-backed inquiry, calling for more competition and stronger capital reserves for the country's four major banks. The "Big Four" lenders must raise an additional A$20 billion over two to three years to ensure they become among the world's safest lenders. The government will also review the superannuation system to boost after-fee returns for fund members and provide more retirement income products. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull emphasized the importance of ensuring banks' safety for the economy.

site_title: DBS board and its top managers hold retreat in London
summary: DBS Group, Singapore's largest bank, held its annual board meeting in London, marking the first time the off-site retreat was held outside Asia. The four- to five-day trip allowed directors to bond, draw up strategies, and meet key institutional clients. The meeting, which included spouses, is part of DBS' pro-family culture that contributes to low staff turnover and high staff engagement. DBS aims to "dial up" its presence in London, where it has a branch, and has delivered record earnings in recent years while keeping costs low.

site_title: Taiwan's DPP candidate, Beijing know when to keep quiet
summary: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party has replaced its original presidential candidate, Hung Hsiu-chu, with Eric Chu, mayor of New Taipei City, in a bid to boost chances in the upcoming January elections. The move may limit the loss of seats in the parliament but is unlikely to prevent the election of opposition candidate Tsai Ing-wen, who is expected to become Taiwan's first female president. Tsai's support is over 20 points ahead of her opponent, and her center-right stance may appeal to Beijing, which has kept quiet about the election.

site_title: Will technology kill economic convergence?
summary: Emerging economies' growth slowdown may signal the end of their era of rapid expansion and convergence with advanced country income levels. China's slowing growth is affecting other emerging economies that rely on commodity exports, while advanced economies are recovering from the 2008 crisis. The growth differential between emerging and advanced economies has declined, but the question remains whether it will remain low. Some argue that technological advancements, such as automation, could weaken growth globally, but others suggest that developing countries may still be able to catch up through leap-frogging and good governance.

site_title: Basel III will up costs for EU banks trading gold
summary: EU banks trading gold may face significant costs under new Basel III liquidity rules, potentially forcing them to withdraw from the market. The rules, which take effect in 2018, require banks to hold more cash and cash equivalents to act as a buffer against adverse gold price moves. The new "haircut" of 85% increases the cost of funding gold transactions by up to 300%, making it difficult for commercial banks to operate. Industry bodies have urged the European Banking Authority to reconsider gold as a "high quality, liquid asset".

site_title: Tharman unveils 3 initiatives to draw institutions to infrastructure
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam launched three initiatives to attract institutional investors to infrastructure investments. The initiatives include defining non-commercial risks, developing benchmarks and data for performance and risks, and creating infrastructure debt as a significant asset class. The move aims to address the underdeveloped nature of the asset class and increase institutional investment in infrastructure, which currently accounts for only 3% of global funds under management.

images.alt_text: "There's tremendous opportunity at the level of individual projects, and when you talk to the businesses, banks, investors, there is interest in taking up these opportunities," says Mr Tharman.

site_title: What's behind UK's determined courtship of China
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron has strengthened his country's ties with China, hosting Chinese President Xi Jinping in Britain. This move is part of the UK's bid to attract Chinese trade and investment, despite criticism from other countries, particularly the US. The UK's approach has been criticized for being too accommodating to China's leadership, with the US labeling it "constant accommodation." Seven reasons cited for the UK's desire to expand economic ties with China include seeking to capitalize on China's growing economy and emerging as a global power.

site_title: Asean's long journey towards integration doesn't end on Dec 31
summary: Asean is set to officially launch the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Economic Community (AEC) on December 31, marking the culmination of an 11-year integration process. The AEC aims to unify the 10-member Asean bloc into a single market and production base, offering new growth and investment opportunities for regional and foreign investors. The AEC will bring about economic benefits, creating a more unified and integrated region.

site_title: 'No watch' millenials a challenge for luxury watchmakers
summary: Omega, a luxury watchmaker, faces a significant challenge in attracting younger consumers, with over half of 16-34 year-olds relying on mobile phones for time-keeping. The company aims to reach this demographic through its James Bond franchise and celebrity ambassadors, such as Eddie Redmayne. Despite the growing list of challenges, including a crackdown in China and competition from smartwatches, Omega plans to invest heavily in the 007 franchise and target Asia's younger market, where buyers tend to be between 25 and 45 years old.

site_title: VW's 12-brand behemoth under scrutiny as scandal costs mount
summary: Volkswagen AG faces billions of euros in costs due to its emissions cheating scandal, potentially forcing a restructuring of its 12-brand empire. The company's non-core brands, such as Bugatti, Lamborghini, and Ducati, may be targeted for cost-cutting measures. New CEO Matthias Mueller has announced delays or cancellations of non-essential projects to cut costs. The scandal is estimated to cost VW up to 30 billion euros, with the carmaker already setting aside 6.5 billion euros. The company's mass market brands, including Seat and Skoda, are also under scrutiny, with Seat facing a potential overhaul due to its financial struggles.

site_title: The waning of Merkel, Germany's Mutti
summary: Angela Merkel, Germany's Chancellor, is facing a waning of support as her country grapples with the influx of 1.5 million displaced migrants, nearly double the initial forecast. This unprecedented burden is placing pressure on policing, social services, and Merkel's leadership. The influx of people, similar to the 20,000 East Germans per month in 1989, is a significant departure from Merkel's initial policy of welcoming refugees. As Merkel's grip on power falters, her people are questioning whether she has a clear stance on the issue, with support for her slipping.

site_title: Grocery delivery startup honestbee gets US$15m funding
summary: Honestbee, a Singapore-based grocery delivery startup, secured US$15 million in Series A funding led by Formation 8. The funds will be used to expand across Asia, following the launch in Hong Kong and plans to enter Taiwan and other Asian markets. Honestbee partners with local retailers to deliver over 15,000 products, aiming to make grocery shopping quick and enjoyable for customers, while creating job opportunities for its shoppers and deliverymen.

site_title: New database tracks large land deals
summary: A new online database, OpenLandContracts.org, has been launched to track large land deals globally by publishing contracts between governments and investors. The database, backed by the World Bank, lists 69 deals in eight countries, including palm oil plantations and sugarcane farms. The site aims to increase transparency around land deals, which can be controversial when signed in secret without local input, and promote social investments such as environmental management and jobs for local people. The database expects to have 100 entries by year's end.

site_title: The science of picking the right music at work
summary: Research suggests that listening to music or background noise can increase productivity and improve mood at work. Studies have shown that listening to music with a rhythmic structure between 70-90 beats per minute can calm anxiety and boost productivity, while music with a faster tempo (120-140 beats per minute) can increase alertness. Moderate background noise can also enhance creativity. However, the impact of music on productivity varies depending on individual skill levels, with moderate-skill workers experiencing the greatest output bump.

site_title: Takata air bag recall probe could expand
summary: US regulators may expand their investigation into Takata air bag inflators beyond 11 carmakers, following questions about vehicle design's role in the devices posing a deadly risk. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is set to make a public case on Thursday to coordinate the Takata recall, affecting 23.4 million air bag inflators in 19.2 million US vehicles. At least eight deaths and over 100 injuries have been linked to the faulty inflators, which can explode with too much force and spray metal shrapnel.

site_title: Blackstone buys NY's Stuyvesant Town complex
summary: Blackstone Group LP has agreed to buy New York's Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village, a 32-hectare apartment complex, for approximately US$5.3 billion. The deal includes an agreement with the city to keep almost half of the 11,000 apartments affordable for 20 years. The purchase ends five years of uncertainty over ownership and will make Blackstone one of the largest apartment landlords in New York. The deal also includes tax breaks worth US$225 million.

site_title: Verdict, finally, for long-drawn case against City Harvest leaders
summary: The verdict in the long-drawn case against City Harvest Church leaders is set to be announced on Wednesday. Church founder Kong Hee and five deputies, including his wife singer Sun Ho, are accused of misusing church funds to fuel Ho's music career, totaling millions of dollars. The trial, which started in 2013, has been marked by intense scrutiny and public interest, with the prosecution alleging "sham bond investments" and the defence claiming they acted on the advice of lawyers and auditors. The verdict may be appealed, potentially delaying the outcome.

site_title: Win WTA Finals tickets!
summary: The Business Times is giving away three pairs of Category 1 tickets to the 2015 BNP Paribas WTA Finals presented by SC Global, worth S$130 a pair. To enter, email the answer to the question: name two players competing at the event, to btnews@sph.com.sg by 6pm on Wednesday. Three winners will be selected at random and notified by email.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse set to scale back global ambitions
summary: Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse, two of Europe's last remaining global banks, are scaling back their ambitions amid struggles to adapt to rising capital requirements and record-low interest rates. Deutsche Bank is expected to shed almost 25% of its workforce and sell assets, while Credit Suisse plans to prune its investment bank and focus on wealth management. The move is expected to further squeeze lending to economies in the region and hand more business to US competitors. Analysts say the banks' retrenchment is necessary to meet tougher capital requirements and achieve sustainable returns.

site_title: Applications open for more than 500 SkillsFuture Study Awards
summary: Applications for the SkillsFuture Study Awards in Singapore officially opened, offering more than 500 awards worth S$5,000 to support recipients' out-of-pocket expenses for courses. The awards aim to help individuals deepen their specialist skills.

site_title: Bangkok Mass Transit buying more trains as govt plans 300km of track additions
summary: Bangkok Mass Transit System Pcl is buying up to 43 trains valued at 10 billion baht (S$392 million) for its current and planned routes. The company, operator of Bangkok's elevated railway network, is considering purchasing all trains at once or in batches. The government plans to add 300km of electric train lines in the capital, aiming to stimulate the economy. The expansion is expected to boost economic growth and make the city more livable, with BTS also planning to enter the logistics business and operate a 500km cargo rail line.

site_title: Private firms urged to be more transparent
summary: Investors in Europe's high-yield bond market are pushing for private companies to disclose more financial information, citing restricted access as a hindrance to trading. The Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME) has identified over 75 companies that are deemed too protective of their data, aiming to establish standardized reporting. This move seeks to increase transparency and potentially improve market efficiency, as analysts argue that restricted access can hinder trading and analysis.

site_title: LinkedIn and NTUC team up to run mentorship sessions led by industry innovators for PMEs
summary: LinkedIn and the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) have partnered to host mentorship sessions called Meet LinkedIn Power Profiles, offering 10 participants a chance to engage with industry innovators in a casual setting. The first session featured Lazada Singapore CEO Martell von Hardenberg. This initiative aims to provide professionals with opportunities to learn from influential industry leaders, promoting growth and development in the Singaporean workforce.

site_title: Commodity price rout: World Bank sees continued slide for this year
summary: The World Bank predicts a continued slide in commodity prices throughout 2015, with a modest recovery in 2016. Oil prices are expected to plummet, with a forecasted decline of 43% compared to 2014. Coal, metal, and agricultural prices are also predicted to fall, driven by abundant supplies and slowing demand. Deflation is expected to remain a global threat, with all main commodity price indices expected to decline in 2015.

site_title: Global funds continue to be net sellers of stocks
summary: Global mutual funds sold more Singapore stocks than they bought in the three months to Oct 14, with net sells totaling S$1.01 billion and net buys at S$493 million. Finance stocks excluding Reits saw a similar trend, with net sells of S$413.7 million and net buys of S$151.7 million. UOB was the top sell, and DBS Group Holdings was the top buy. The data, provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, offers insight into fund managers' market focus, but may not reflect the complete picture of trading by other investors.

site_title: Noble bags LNG delivery slots for Egypt's 2nd floating import terminal
summary: Noble Group secured a significant number of LNG delivery slots for Egypt's second floating import terminal, set to start operations next month. This deal comes as Egypt emerges as a key LNG market, with Noble having a successful track record in the country. The company has delivered the first two LNG cargoes to Egypt and has further deliveries scheduled for this year and next. Noble's shares rose 1 cent to close at 51.5 Singapore cents after the announcement.

site_title: Honda joins Toyota to lead surge in new cars
summary: Singapore's new passenger car market surged in the first nine months of 2015, with 38,933 units, a 93.5% increase from the same period last year. Honda overtook Mercedes-Benz as the second most popular brand, thanks to replacement demand driven by the expanding supply of Certificate of Entitlement (COEs). Toyota remains the top seller, followed by Nissan, which swapped positions with Mazda. Japanese brands now dominate the top five spots, reversing previous years' trends.

site_title: AGC-Bank Negara clash over 1MDB clouds M'sia
summary: Malaysia's financial system faces uncertainty due to a disagreement between the central bank and attorney-general's chambers over the 1MDB scandal. Analysts say the divergence of opinion is eroding investor confidence and highlighting the need for effective enforcement. The AGC claims 1MDB violated the Exchange Control Act, while the central bank disputes this. The situation is casting a shadow over the country's due process, raising concerns about the stability of the financial system.

images.alt_text: Has the outlook for Malaysia's financial system become "cloudy with a diminishing chance of clarity"?

site_title: Penny stocks in play in mixed session
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 5.47 points to 3,019.03, as the Singapore stock market experienced a mixed session. Penny stocks dominated the trading, with turnover at 2.5 billion units worth S$935 million. Weakness in Hong Kong and US futures, along with traders' reluctance to make large commitments ahead of the FOMC meeting, contributed to the quiet session. Loyz Energy and Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments topped the actives list, with Loyz Energy receiving a "Trade with Caution" notice from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare issues. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, similar to H1 operating loss. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Ferrari IPO price expected as high as US$53: CNBC
summary: Ferrari's initial public offering (IPO) is expected to price as high as $53 per share, valuing the luxury carmaker at $10 billion, according to CNBC. This price is above the previously indicated range of $48-$52 per share. The company is set to start trading as a public company on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Luxury carmaker Ferrari's initial public offering could be priced as high as US$53 per share, CNBC reported, citing sources.

site_title: Aerospace incubator uses TV show format to match startups with investors
summary: Starburst Accelerator, the world's largest incubator for aerospace startups, has signed agreements with major companies such as Boeing and Raytheon to organize events where startups present their products. The incubator uses a TV show format similar to Shark Tank to match startups with investors and venture capitalists. Since its California office opening, 29 startups have received funding from 100 industry executives and venture capitalists. Starburst plans to expand to Singapore next year, focusing on commercial aerospace and potentially moving into weapons-related markets.

site_title: Parallel imports surge on Honda Vezel's popularity
summary: Parallel imports in Singapore surged 306% from January to September 2015, with a total of 5,036 registered, driven by the low COE premium environment. The Honda Vezel compact crossover is the most popular parallel import model, with 2,062 units registered, accounting for 41% of total parallel imports. Toyota remains the top-selling parallel import brand, followed by Honda. The parallel import market now accounts for 12.9% of the total new cars on the road in Singapore, a significant increase from its 6.7% market share in 2014.

site_title: Jokowi marks disappointing first year in power
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's first year in office has been marked by disappointment, with critics saying his plans to usher in cleaner, more effective governance have come to nothing. Despite initial successes, such as cutting fuel price subsidies, the economy has stagnated, and corruption has persisted. Widodo's attempts to attract investors have been hindered by protectionist policies, and his popularity has been sliding due to criticism over his handling of graft. Experts say the president's efforts to reform the economy and fight corruption have been slow and ineffective.

site_title: China's CICC to launch US$800m Hong Kong listing next week: IFR
summary: China International Capital Corp (CICC), the country's top domestic investment bank, plans to launch an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong next week, seeking to raise approximately US$800 million. CICC, backed by private equity firms KKR & Co and TPG Capital, will use the funds to expand its businesses. The IPO will see new shares make up 90% of those on offer, with the remaining 10% coming from shares to be sold by China's National Social Security Fund. Trading will commence on November 9.

site_title: Burning shame
summary: Indonesia has seen 106,783 fires detected in 2015, raising concerns about deteriorating conditions. According to the Global Fire Emissions Database and the World Resource Institute, this is a significant increase. Experts warn that the situation may worsen. The article highlights the need to understand the severity of the issue in comparison to past years and other countries' emissions.

site_title: Comply or risk breaching listing rules
summary: Singapore Exchange officials have issued a clarification on the "comply or explain" requirement in the 2012 Code, stating that it is mandatory. The requirement, which was previously subject to interpretation, now requires listed companies to disclose and explain any deviations from the Code's guidelines. The clarification aims to prevent companies from taking a "voluntary" approach to corporate governance, which has led to confusion among management and professionals. Companies must review their processes to ensure compliance and risk breaching listing rules by adopting a relaxed view of the "comply or explain" concept.

site_title: IBM shares hit 5-year low after disappointing results
summary: IBM shares plummeted to a 5-year low, falling 5.8% to $140.51, after the company reported disappointing third-quarter results and cut its full-year profit forecast. The company's revenue dropped, and analysts lowered their price targets, citing that growth in strategic areas is not yet sufficient to offset pressures in legacy businesses. For the 14th consecutive quarter, IBM reported a revenue decline as it focuses on high-growth areas like security software and data analytics. Analysts expect a revenue increase only in the third quarter of the next fiscal year.

site_title: Maersk Line aims to raise freight rates from Asia to Europe
summary: Maersk Line plans to raise spot freight rates from Asia to Europe by $1,000 per twenty-foot equivalent unit container, a 429% increase, starting November 1. This corresponds to a rate of $233, which is considered a loss-making level according to the Shanghai Containerized Freight Index. The price hike is part of a trend where container rates typically rise in big jumps before gradually easing back.

site_title: Hedge funds eyeing small banks lead CDO revival
summary: Hedge funds are reviving collateralized debt obligations (CDOs), a financial vehicle that caused billions in losses during the 2008 crisis. StoneCastle Financial, backed by subordinated debt from 35 community banks, has completed a $250 million deal with Citigroup. The CDO, backed by subordinated debt, offers a higher yield than traditional bank bonds, and Moody's Investors Service plans to give it a rating of "A3". This revival is seen as a retooling of earlier CDOs, such as TruPS CDOs, which were proposed by Joshua Siegel in the late 1990s.

site_title: Noble Group may lose Moody's investment-grade rank on liquidity issue
summary: Noble Group may lose its investment-grade credit rating due to liquidity concerns, according to Moody's Investors Service. The company's secured lending move may not immediately affect its rating but could lead to a downgrade if leverage continues to rise. Noble's shares have slumped 55% this year amid criticism and concerns over raw material prices. Moody's rates Noble at Baa3, the lowest investment grade, and its shares rose 2% on Tuesday to close at 51.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: US: Stocks drop on mixed earnings; IBM shares dive
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, October 20, 2015, due to mixed earnings reports, including a disappointing IBM report that sent shares plummeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.40%, the S&P 500 fell 0.26%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.29%.

site_title: US housing starts surge in September
summary: US housing starts surged 6.5% in September to an annual rate of 1.206 million units, the highest in two months. Multi-family units led the increase, jumping 17.0%, while single-family home starts edged up 0.3%. However, building permits, a sign of future home building activity, dropped 5.0% in September, suggesting slower growth ahead. Analysts predict construction will slow in the coming months due to the slower year-over-year pace of building permits.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore launched three initiatives to encourage private sector investment in infrastructure. Commodities trader Noble Group secured LNG delivery slots for Egypt's second floating import terminal. Singapore's bond market is bracing for Indonesia's debt defaults and currency woes, which have affected the city state's economy. Applications for SkillsFuture Study Awards open on Tuesday, offering over 500 awards to help applicants deepen their specialist skills. The proposed float of Singapore-based BOC Aviation could fetch a US$5-6 billion valuation.

site_title: PBOC's London debt sale said to be marketed at about 3.3%
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has conducted its first overseas debt sale in London, offering five billion yuan (S$1.09 billion) of one-year bills with a yield guidance of 3.3%. The move aims to boost global usage of the yuan and cement London's dominance of yuan trading in Europe. This sale follows a state visit by President Xi Jinping and is part of China's efforts to gain official reserve status at the International Monetary Fund. The sale is expected to enhance London's role as the world's currency trading centre and provide a benchmark interest rate for the offshore market.

site_title: Will a progressive Hillary win the White House?
summary: Hillary Clinton has become the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee after the first Democratic presidential debate in Nevada. Despite the large number of Republican candidates, the debate drew significantly fewer viewers, with around 24 million worldwide, compared to the Republican debates. Clinton's path to the White House may require her to transform into a centrist politician to appeal to the general electorate, potentially altering her progressive stance. She will face off against Republican nominee Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election, which is expected to be one of the most watched media events in television history.

site_title: Indian sugar mills seal export contracts but won't meet govt target
summary: Indian sugar mills have contracted to export almost 100,000 tonnes of white sugar to Asian countries, but are unlikely to meet the government's target of 4 million tonnes. The government is pushing mills to export to clear debts owed to farmers and reduce stockpiles. With export subsidies not expected to be approved before state elections, mills are focused on raising cash for the new crushing season. Most mills will start crushing operations in November, with prices ranging from $390-410 a tonne.

site_title: SunMoon to pay S$2m to settle legal dispute with corporate advisory firm
summary: SunMoon Food Company has agreed to pay S$2.1 million to nTan Corporate Advisory, plus 7% GST in instalments, to settle a legal dispute. The settlement, which includes half the amount already provisioned for, may impact SunMoon's financial performance but allows the company to focus on its business. Trading in SunMoon's shares was halted in October, and the company has confirmed all payments will be made from internal resources. nTan has also discontinued the suit and confirmed no further claim against the firm.

site_title: IBM revenue falls more than expected, cuts profit forecast
summary: IBM's revenue fell 13.9% to $19.28 billion in the third quarter, missing analysts' average forecast of $19.62 billion. The company cut its full-year profit forecast to $14.75-$15.75 per share, citing weakness in its consulting and storage businesses. A strong US dollar exacerbated the decline, particularly in China, where revenue fell 17%. Despite rising revenue from strategic imperatives like cloud and data analytics, the company has yet to make up for lost revenue from divestitures.

site_title: Keppel T&T Q3 profit falls 17.1% to S$15.31m
summary: Keppel T&T reported a 17.1% drop in Q3 net profit to S$15.31 million, from S$18.47 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 5.1% to S$50.91 million, while operating expenses fell 4.7% and other income decreased 66.3%. This led to a 34.5% drop in operating profit to S$7.44 million. The company's Q3 performance was impacted by declining revenue and operating expenses.

site_title: Britain says expects over 20b pounds of deals during Xi's visit
summary: Britain is set to announce over 20 billion pounds of business deals during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit, according to British Business Secretary Sajid Javid. This announcement is expected to support jobs in the country.

images.alt_text: British business secretary Sajid Javid said on Tuesday Britain would announce 20 billion pounds (S$43 billion) of business deals during this week's visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: New UK bank rules not watered down: Bank of England's Bailey
summary: The Bank of England's Andrew Bailey stated that new UK bank rules are not being watered down, despite concerns from some lawmakers. The "guilty-until-proven-innocent" rule was scrapped, requiring bankers to prove they were not responsible for rule breaches. Bailey said this change would avoid legal uncertainties and prevent a "tick-box" mentality within the industry. The Senior Managers Regime, introducing new conduct rules in March, remains a major strengthening of existing rules, providing relief to bankers and signaling the easing of tough new regulations.

site_title: Cosco Corp bags new jobs worth US$150m
summary: Cosco Corp's shipyard division has secured contracts worth US$150 million to build an oil tanker and two cargo transfer vessels, scheduled for delivery in 2016 and 2017. The firm has also secured options for four additional cargo transfer vessels. The contracts follow a recent suspension of trading in its shares due to uncertainty over a restructuring plan involving its parent company China Ocean Shipping (Group) Company.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 13.17 points to 1,705.03. The trading volume reached 2.13 billion lots worth RM1.85 billion, with 623 losers outweighing 290 gainers.

site_title: Trudeau's Liberals oust Harper with surprise Canada majority
summary: Justin Trudeau's Liberal Party won a surprise majority in Canada's election, ousting Prime Minister Stephen Harper. With 99% of polls reporting, the Liberals secured 184 seats, the Conservatives 99, and the New Democratic Party 44. Trudeau's victory reflects a thirst for change and a rejection of Harper's budget restraint agenda. Trudeau will now pursue a platform of higher infrastructure spending, middle-class tax cuts, and fiscal deficits to finance his plans. His challenges include reviving the economy, building new pipeline capacity, and managing inflation.

site_title: Google Inc makes first China investment since 2010 pullout
summary: Google is making its first direct investment in a Chinese firm since 2010, leading a $75 million round of funding for artificial-intelligence startup Mobvoi Inc. The investment underscores Google's return to the Chinese market, where it has been blocked since 2010 over censorship concerns. Mobvoi, which operates a Chinese-language voice-activated search engine, will use the funding to strengthen its AI development and explore smart car technologies. The deal marks a strategic shift for Google, which is considering opening an app store for Chinese users and has invested in other Chinese companies in the past.

site_title: Boustead Projects wins contracts worth S$59m
summary: Boustead Projects secured two contracts worth S$59 million in Singapore. One contract is for an integrated facility at the Seletar Aerospace Park for JEP Precision Engineering, while the other is for an integrated facility at Pioneer Crescent for Markono Print Media. Both projects are expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2016.

site_title: Approval ratings boost marks Jokowi's first year in office
summary: President Joko Widodo's approval rating has increased to 52% after his first year in office, up from 41% in June, according to a survey of 1,220 Indonesians. The president launched a drive to regain voter trust in August, including a cabinet reshuffle and stimulus package, and acknowledged the difficulties in finding his footing. Investors see Jokowi as starting to strike the right tone, with the rupiah currency rebounding 7% and the stock market jumping 12% since September. However, obstacles remain, including a US Fed hike and weak domestic consumption.

site_title: Keppel T&T reports 17.1% drop in Q3 profit
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) reported a 17.1% drop in Q3 net profit to S$15.31 million, from S$18.47 million a year ago, driven by a 5.1% decline in revenue to S$50.91 million. Earning per share also fell 15.2%. The company's nine-month net profit dropped 2.5% to S$46.97 million, while revenue declined 3.7%. Net asset value per share decreased 5.5% to S$1.20.

site_title: Harley-Davidson third quarter profit falls on slowed sales
summary: Harley-Davidson Inc reported a net income of $140.3 million in the third quarter, down 6.5% from the same period last year. Global new motorcycle sales fell more than 1% and diluted earnings per share were 69 cents, missing analysts' expectations of 78 cents. The decline in sales led to the lower profit.

site_title: Stop that drone: UK's Chess Dynamics eyes orders
summary: UK-based defence company Chess Dynamics expects to sign its first customer for the Anti-UAV Defence System (AUDS) in the next six months, offering a drone-downing technology. The system can detect drones from 8km away, track them, and disrupt communications to force them to the ground. This technology is needed as drone use rises on the battlefield and commercially, with concerns for government security and safety. The AUDS could help Chess Dynamics grow beyond its naval customer base and expand into new markets.

site_title: Yum Brands plans to separate China business
summary: Yum Brands plans to separate its China business into a publicly traded company, Yum China, which will retain exclusive rights to KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell in Mainland China. The separation, expected to be completed by the end of 2016, aims to focus Yum Brands on global expansion while allowing Yum China to drive growth in China. The move is intended to be tax-free to shareholders and will not affect the company's global operations.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust posts 7.3% rise in DPU for Q2
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust posted a 7.3% increase in distribution per unit to 2.79 Singapore cents in Q2, driven by a 6.2% rise in gross revenue and 8.6% growth in net property income. The trust's distributable income rose 7.7% to S$48.9 million, while the counter shed 1.3% to close at S$1.50. The increase in revenue was attributed to higher occupancies and rental rates in the portfolio, as well as the contribution from the Equinix Singapore build-to-suit project.

site_title: Singapore shares close mixed with penny stocks in play
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed down 5.47 points at 3,019.03, following a broadly mixed session. The market was influenced by weakness in Hong Kong and US Dow futures, with traders hesitant to make large commitments ahead of the Federal Open Markets Committee meeting. Penny stocks dominated trading, with Loyz Energy's shares rising 21% on high volume. The average value per unit traded was S$0.37, indicating heightened activity in penny stocks.

site_title: Europe: Stocks diverge at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets opened mixed on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.13% to 6,360.42 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.10% and Paris' CAC 40 added 0.09%. The mixed performance was attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, but US-EU trade talks were also a focus.

site_title: ECB survey shows bank sector on mend
summary: Europe's financial sector is showing signs of recovery, according to the European Central Bank's quarterly bank lending survey. Banks are easing credit standards for loans to enterprises, a positive sign for the euro area's economic growth. Demand for loans is also increasing, driven by low interest rates and housing market prospects. However, credit standards on loans to households for house purchases are tightening due to national regulation. The ECB expects further easing of credit standards for enterprises in the fourth quarter, but a slight tightening for housing loans.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks end higher on stimulus bets
summary: Shanghai stocks ended higher on Tuesday, gaining 1.14% to 3,425.33, as traders bet on further economic stimulus measures following data showing third-quarter growth at a six-year low. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.97%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index eased 0.37%. The gains were seen as a response to the economic stimulus, with investors hoping for increased government support to boost growth.

site_title: Funding Circle expands into Europe through purchase of Zencap
summary: Funding Circle, a British peer-to-peer lender, has expanded into Europe through the acquisition of Zencap, a German small business lender. The acquisition gives Funding Circle a greater international presence, enabling it to help millions of businesses worldwide bypass the inefficient banking system. Zencap, which has lent over $47.4 million to 500 businesses, will now operate as Funding Circle across Europe. Financial details were not disclosed. The acquisition is expected to further grow Funding Circle's international presence, allowing it to compete with rivals.

site_title: Australia shares fall on China worries; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Tuesday due to concerns over slowing China's growth, outweighing gains in the telecom and healthcare sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 34.11 points to 5,235.60, despite a 4.3% monthly gain. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index rose 1% to 5,895.49. Market experts attribute the decline to "macro storm clouds" including China, US Fed, and global growth issues.

site_title: Greek bank recap needs seen less than 20b euros: bankers
summary: Greek bank recapitalisation is expected to require less than 20 billion euros, according to two senior bankers with direct knowledge. The four main banks, National Bank of Greece, Piraeus Bank, Alpha Bank, and Eurobank, are undergoing stress tests by the European Central Bank to define their capital needs, depleted by mass deposit withdrawals and non-performing loans earlier this year. The exact amount is not yet known, but the shortfall is expected to be significantly lower than the initial estimate of 20 billion euros.

site_title: Dhanabalan to chair Temasek's Mandai rejuvenation unit
summary: Temasek Holdings has set up a unit to oversee the development of Mandai into an integrated wildlife and nature heritage area. Former chairman S Dhanabalan will chair the unit, which aims to publish environmental impact assessment findings in 2016. The development is expected to cost around S$1 billion and will be completed in phases over a decade. Mandai Safari Park Holdings will also oversee the business and strategic development of Wildlife Reserves Singapore, which operates the Singapore Zoo and other wildlife parks.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings' proposal to turn Mandai into an integrated wildlife and nature heritage area has been taken another step towards realisation.

site_title: 53% say Singapore government should legislate private car sharing apps: survey
summary: A recent YouGov survey found that 53% of Singaporeans believe the government should legislate private car sharing apps like UberX, UberEXEC, and GrabCar. This comes after Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan announced a review of third-party apps and a potential leveling of the playing field for private-hire drivers and taxi drivers. The survey was conducted among 1,929 Singaporeans, with many expressing passionate opinions on the issue, highlighting the public's desire for government regulation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.42% after China-linked sell-off
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded 0.42% on Tuesday after a China-linked sell-off the previous day. The Nikkei 225 index rose 75.92 points to 18,207.15, while the Topix index gained 0.30% to 1,499.28. Investors jumped back into the market, likely driven by concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Diamond industry dragged into slump as China demand ebbs away
summary: The diamond industry is experiencing a slump due to decreased demand from China, the world's second-largest market after the US. Anglo American Plc's De Beers unit, which owns 85% of the company, is struggling to meet demand as customers reject 35-50% of diamonds offered at prices deemed unaffordable. De Beers has cut production and lowered prices, but inventories continue to build, causing prices to slide. The industry's reliance on Chinese demand and financing has also been impacted by a credit crunch, with lenders reducing loans to lower their exposure.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop led by energy shares as October rally halts
summary: Asian stocks fell, halting the region's largest monthly rally in five years, as energy and material shares led losses. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index slipped 0.1% to 133.98, despite a strong October rally that restored over $4 trillion in equity value. Energy shares declined, with BHP Billiton and Newcrest Mining falling 2.9% and 5.1% respectively. The rally's exhaustion was attributed to high valuations and unupgraded earnings, with the MSCI Asia Pacific index trading at 13.6 times estimated earnings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall on profit-taking after strong rebound
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.4% on Tuesday, marking the end of a three-week rebound that boosted the Hang Seng Index by 13% since its low in September. Despite better-than-expected China's third-quarter economic growth data, the economy's momentum remains uncertain, adding to concerns over demand and corporate profits.

site_title: Delhi court finds Uber driver guilty of rape
summary: A Delhi court has convicted an Uber driver, Shiv Kumar Yadav, of raping a 25-year-old woman in 2014. Yadav was tried in a special fast-track court and found guilty of rape, abduction, intimidation, and causing harm. He will be sentenced on October 23. The conviction comes amid ongoing safety concerns in India's capital, where Uber was banned in 2015 following the attack. The case highlights issues with Uber's background check processes, which were criticized for failing to identify Yadav's previous allegations against him.

site_title: Apple Music hits 6.5 million paid users: Tim Cook
summary: Apple Music has reached 6.5 million paid users, with an additional 8.5 million participating in a free trial, totaling over 15 million users. CEO Tim Cook described the service's debut as successful, citing a "really good runway" ahead. Released in June, Apple Music aims to compete with music streaming pioneers like Spotify.

site_title: Smartphones put power to deal currencies into retail traders' hands
summary: Smartphones are democratizing access to foreign exchange trading, enabling retail traders to make fortunes or lose large sums. Mobile trading now accounts for 60% of transactions, up from 10% four years ago, with over 40% of trading at major platforms done on mobile devices. Critics warn of "gamification" and reckless trading, but proponents argue that mobile apps provide a safer, less complex environment for retail traders. The rise of mobile trading has grown the retail currency market to $320 billion daily, rivaling 3.5% of the global market.

site_title: BOC launches RMB bond trading index
summary: Bank of China (BOC) has launched the RMB Bond Trading Index, aimed at internationalising China's capital markets and currency. The index, built on the most liquid bonds, allows overseas investors to track market prices and trading efficiency. It includes Chinese government and policy financial bonds, with rebalancing every month. The index provides insights into interest rate fluctuations and total gains/losses, enabling investors to replicate the returns. This move is part of China's efforts to deepen its financial integration with the global economy.

site_title: Noble bags LNG delivery slots for Egypt's second floating import terminal
summary: Noble Group has secured a significant number of LNG delivery slots for Egypt's second floating LNG import terminal, set to start operations next month. This marks Noble's continued presence in the Egyptian market, where it has a successful track record, including delivering the country's first two LNG cargoes. The company has a portfolio of purchase and supply agreements in place until the end of this decade, as its deliveries continue to grow.

site_title: First Fukushima worker diagnosed with radiation-linked cancer: Japan official
summary: A former Fukushima nuclear plant worker in his thirties has been diagnosed with radiation-linked cancer, specifically leukaemia, according to Japanese health authorities. The diagnosis, which met the criteria for radiation-related cancer, is the first such confirmation over four years after the 2011 nuclear crisis. The worker's cancer developed after he worked at the plant following the accident.

site_title: Amazon says creating more than 100,000 jobs for holiday season
summary: Amazon plans to create over 100,000 seasonal jobs in the US for the 2015 holiday season, up from 80,000 last year. The company has already hired over 25,000 full-time employees since August. This move aims to meet increased customer demand and follows last year's trend where many seasonal employees found full-time roles with Amazon. With this addition, Amazon will have more than 90,000 full-time employees across its US fulfillment and sortation centers.

site_title: Yum Brands prepares to separate China business: Bloomberg
