summary: Yum Brands is reportedly preparing to separate its Chinese and US businesses in a major restructuring. The company, parent to KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell, has appointed activist investor Keith Meister to its board, fueling speculation of a spin-off. Meister has urged Yum to separate its 6,900-restaurant China division, which contributed 57% of overall revenue and 54% of operating profit in the latest quarter. Details of the separation have not been finalized, and the company could still decide to retain its current structure.

site_title: Thai PTT signs deal with Malaysia's Petronas for LNG imports
summary: PTT Pcl, Thailand's top energy firm, signed a long-term contract with Petronas to import 1 million tonnes of LNG annually, securing 70% of Thailand's LNG need. The remaining 30% will be sourced from spot markets. This deal is part of Thailand's energy policy, which allows PTT to import LNG from three suppliers, including Qatar Liquefied Gas Co Ltd, Shell Eastern Trading, and BP Singapore Pte Ltd. The contract aims to ensure a stable and reliable gas supply for Thailand.

site_title: Star Wars fans crash ticket sites as new trailer premieres
summary: Star Wars fans overwhelmed cinema websites selling advance tickets for "The Force Awakens" after a new trailer premiered, causing site crashes and loading issues. The demand was particularly high in the US and Britain, with fans eager to secure seats for the film's December 18 release. The viral trailer also sparked widespread excitement among fans, fueling the frenzy.

site_title: Apple will open 24th store in China on Saturday, Cook says
summary: Apple is set to open its 24th store in China on Saturday, according to CEO Tim Cook. This expansion is crucial for introducing Chinese consumers to the brand and educating users. China has become a critical component of Apple's global business, with the company selling a record 13 million iPhones during the debut weekend of its latest handsets last month.

site_title: Applications for SkillsFuture Study Awards open on Tuesday
summary: Applications for SkillsFuture Study Awards open on Tuesday, offering over 500 awards worth S$5,000 to support specialist skills development in eight areas: built environment, air transport, and more. The awards, announced by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, aim to encourage lifelong learning and upskilling in Singapore, while also helping employers strengthen their talent pool and improve staff retention. The awards can be used on top of existing government course fee subsidies and are bond-free.

site_title: Education quality trumps quantity for economic gains: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) suggests that improving the quality of education, focusing on teaching students skills, is more effective in driving economic growth than increasing the quantity of education. The bank projects that developing Asian economies can reap substantial economic gains by focusing on basic skills and targeting early childhood education. If economies focus on developing "top-end" skills, such as problem-solving and strategizing, the economic gains could be even higher. The ADB recommends making test scores and school performance publicly available to maximize gains.

site_title: Malaysia to address US$700m fund scandal linked to Najib
summary: Malaysia's government will address the US$700 million fund scandal linked to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in parliament. The scandal involves alleged donations that ended up in Najib's personal bank accounts before elections in 2013. The government will provide an explanation in the current parliament sitting, but the exact date has not been determined. Najib has denied taking money for personal gain, describing the controversy as a campaign to remove him from office.

site_title: China eyes S$44b of investments in Laos border economic zone
summary: China plans to invest over S$43.7 billion in 240 projects in the Mengla economic zone on the border with Laos, aiming to establish a comprehensive transport hub linking China with Southeast Asia. The zone, covering 4,500 sq km, will include energy, education, and transport projects, with railways and an airport expected to be operational by 2020. Long-term plans call for a railway connecting Yunnan to Singapore, solidifying China's strategic cooperation with Laos.

site_title: Oil halts slide near two-week low before US crude supply data
summary: Oil prices halted their decline, rising 0.9% in New York after falling to a two-week low, ahead of US data showing expanded crude stockpiles. Inventories likely rose by 3.5 million barrels last week. Iran is preparing to boost output once sanctions are removed, regardless of OPEC's decisions. Oil remains oversupplied, with West Texas Intermediate trading between $43.50 and $50 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil halted its decline after slipping to a two-week low before US government data forecast to show crude stockpiles expanded in the world's biggest consumer.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.1% higher on Tuesday, gaining 2.2 points to 3,026.7, following a mildly higher finish on Wall Street despite weak corporate earnings reports. About 61.7 million shares were traded, with QT Vascular being the most actively traded stock, rising S$0.004 to S$0.178. Gainers outnumbered losers 79 to 41, marking a two-to-one advantage for gainers.

site_title: Vietnam's GDP growth to accelerate to 6.7% in 2016: premier
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung announced the country's 2016 GDP growth target at 6.7%, exceeding the 6.5% growth rate in 2015. The government aims to keep annual inflation below 5% and targets 6.5-7.0% growth over the next five years.

images.alt_text: Vietnam has targeted its economy to expand 6.7 per cent in 2016, after this year posting the quickest growth in five years estimated at above 6.5 per cent, the prime minister said on Tuesday.

site_title: PBoC markets its first overseas Dim Sum bonds
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBoC) has marketed its first overseas Dim Sum bonds, a one-year renminbi bond at around 3.30% per cent, to promote international use of the renminbi and boost its chances of being added to the International Monetary Fund's special drawing rights basket. The 5 billion renminbi (US$786 million) offering is seen as attractive given the low 10-year onshore Chinese government bond yield of 3%. The net proceeds will be used to support the Chinese central bank's functions, increasing the supply of high-quality bonds in offshore renminbi markets.

site_title: Obama officials resist calls to release Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac
summary: US officials dismiss calls to release Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac from government conservatorship, citing a lack of congressional action. Michael Stegman, a top housing adviser to President Obama, says the administration is sticking with keeping the mortgage-finance giants under US control. Fannie Mae CEO Timothy Mayopoulos and Freddie Mac CEO Donald Layton also express skepticism about the companies' potential release, citing concerns about the cost of mortgages and taxpayer exposure.

site_title: Dollar strengthens on China worries
summary: The US dollar strengthened against emerging currencies on Tuesday due to renewed concerns about a global economic slowdown and potential interest rate hikes. China's economic growth slowed in the July-September quarter, sparking doubts about stimulus measures and influencing currency markets. Analysts warned that recent gains in higher-risk currencies may be nearing exhaustion, while a Federal Reserve official suggested a rate hike could still happen this year. The dollar rose against the yen, and lower-yielding currencies like the yen and dollar gained against higher-risk currencies like the Indonesian rupiah and Malaysian ringgit.

site_title: BOC Aviation's proposed HK float may fetch US$5-6b valuation
summary: BOC Aviation, a Singapore-based aircraft leasing unit of Bank of China, plans to list on the Hong Kong mainboard with an estimated valuation of US$5-6 billion. The IPO is based on the 2014 net profit of US$308.6 million and a trailing 12-month price-to-earnings (PE) range of 15-20 times earnings. The funds raised will be used for capital expenditure and general corporate purposes. BOC Aviation reported a first-half net profit of US$171.5 million, up 5% from a year ago. The listing is expected to be up to 40% of the unit's enlarged share capital.

site_title: Thailand expects record 30.3m visitors in 2015, despite bomb
summary: Thailand is projected to receive a record 30.3 million visitors in 2015, with 7.7 million coming from China. Despite a bomb attack in Bangkok in August and political unrest in 2014, the country's tourism industry has rebounded, driven by its beaches, bars, and Buddhist temples. The sector accounts for 10% of GDP, showing resilience in the face of an underperforming economy.

images.alt_text: A record 30.3 million tourists are expected to visit Thailand this year, with more than a quarter coming from China, the tourism council said on Tuesday, as the country rebounds from political unrest in 2014 and a bomb attack in August.

site_title: Maritime crimes in South-east Asia could get worse in Q4
summary: Maritime crimes in South-east Asia have increased by 38.6% in the first nine months of 2015, with 194 reported incidents, according to Dryad Maritime. The Singapore Strait accounted for a significant portion of these incidents, with 90 reported cases of theft or attempted theft. The main focus of criminal gangs is petty theft of ship stores, with a high number of incidents occurring at night. Dryad's chief operating officer warns of a potential increase in hijackings and petty thefts in the final quarter of 2015, emphasizing the need for a joined-up security effort.

site_title: Update: Oil prices nudge up on short-covering; glut, economy concerns persist
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asian trade, with Brent crude rising 11 cents to $48.72 a barrel and US crude up 13 cents to $46.02 a barrel. Short-covering led to the rally, but concerns over oversupply, Iran's potential production increase, and China's economic slowdown weighed on markets. US crude stocks likely rose for a fourth straight week, and investors await data from the American Petroleum Institute and US Department of Energy.

site_title: Japan Post IPO might just shake up lagging regional lenders
summary: Japan's upcoming initial public offering (IPO) of Japan Post Bank Co, a state-owned bank, may shake up the country's lagging regional lenders. The bank's privatization could allow it to make loans and accept higher deposits, putting it in direct competition with the 105 regional banks. The IPO could also lead to a cap on deposits being raised, potentially siphoning savings from regional lenders into the postal bank. Experts say the situation for some regional banks will be severe if they remain independent, and consolidation is necessary to improve their financial prospects.

images.alt_text: Japan's regional banks need a little shaking up: There are far too many of them, profits from loans are shrinking, and their customers are disappearing.

site_title: Leaders call for carbon pricing worldwide
summary: World leaders, including the World Bank and major countries like Germany, France, and the Philippines, have called for global carbon pricing to combat climate change. The Carbon Pricing Panel, comprising 8 countries and 7 organizations, urges nations to implement carbon pricing schemes to drive investment in low-carbon technologies. With about 40 nations and 23 cities already initiating carbon pricing, the panel aims to create a level playing field for investment and trade. The call comes ahead of the UN climate conference in Paris, where a global agreement is expected to be finalized by 2020.

site_title: Yuan falls to three-week low as more easing seen to boost growth
summary: The Chinese yuan fell to a three-week low due to speculation that authorities will ease monetary policy to boost growth. The currency dropped 0.04% to 6.3626 a dollar after China's economy recorded its weakest quarterly expansion in six years. The US Treasury softened its criticism of China's exchange-rate policy, but maintained the yuan is undervalued. China's central bank is expected to cut reserve-requirement ratios to stimulate growth, with a possible further cut before year-end.

site_title: Takata air bag recall probe could expand: US regulator
summary: US regulators are expanding their investigation into Takata air bag inflators, which have been linked to at least eight deaths and over 100 injuries worldwide. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) can add more automakers to the recall, potentially affecting 23.4 million inflators in 19.2 million US vehicles. The investigation may also consider vehicle design, with experts suggesting that auto design, including how well sealed passenger compartments are against humidity, could be a factor. Takata has increased production of air bag replacement kits to 1 million per month, and some automakers, like General Motors, are moving quickly to address the issue.

site_title: Behind the strife, Hollande grinds out French reforms
summary: French President Francois Hollande held a workers-and-bosses conference to produce a consensus on social policy, despite a boycott by the largest union, CGT. The conference aimed to address ongoing labor disputes, including a recent incident involving Air France managers and workers. Hollande's government is pushing through economic reforms, which have been slow to materialize due to the labor strife. The conference is seen as a step towards resolving the issues and moving forward with reforms.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.50 points to 1,715.70. The index saw a trading volume of 88.1 million lots worth RM29.54 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 106 to 88.

site_title: United Airlines names general counsel as acting CEO
summary: United Airlines has named its general counsel, Brett Hart, as acting CEO, following Oscar Munoz's medical leave due to a heart attack. Hart, who joined the airline in 2010, will lead an agenda set by Munoz to improve customer service, employee teamwork, and innovation. Munoz's treatment and recovery timeline are unknown, and this marks the second leadership transition at United in the past two months.

site_title: Emas Offshore posts jump in Q4 profit
summary: Emas Offshore, an offshore services company, reported a 181% jump in post-tax profit to US$36.3 million in the fourth quarter, driven by a gain from sale and leaseback transactions. Revenue fell 19% to US$54.31 million due to weakness in certain segments. The full-year post-tax profit increased 626% to US$199.54 million, while revenue fell 13% to US$247.17 million.

site_title: Singapore signs UN convention on eliminating racial discrimination
summary: Singapore has signed the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (ICERD) at the UN in New York. The country aims to ratify the convention by 2017 and work with stakeholders to eliminate racial discrimination. Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Grace Fu stated that signing the ICERD further solidifies Singapore's commitment to a nation where every citizen matters, regardless of race, language, or religion. This move is seen as a significant step towards entrenching Singapore's approach to nation-building.

images.alt_text: Grace Fu, the Minister for Culture, Community and Youth, said in a statement: ""Over the last 50 years, we have built a Singapore where every citizen matters, regardless of race, language or religion.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop on miners as China worries hurt
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Tuesday, with mining and energy firms pressured by China growth worries, while healthcare and telecom stocks limited the market's decline. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 20.81 points to 5,248.9, with major miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto down 2.5% and 1.8% respectively. Telecoms giant Telstra rose 2%, while healthcare shares CSL, Resmed, and Ansell gained 0.6-1.5%.

site_title: Fed's Williams sees reason to increase rates soon and slowly
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams expressed confidence that the economy is on a good trajectory, paving the way for interest rate increases in the near future. Williams believes inflation will stabilize and growth will continue, allowing policymakers to act soon. Despite this, investors are less optimistic, with the probability of a December rate hike estimated at around 32%. The Federal Open Market Committee will meet again on October 27-28 and in December to make a decision.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up slightly on caution ahead of key orders data
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.1% to 8,640.21, driven by chipmaker Inotera's 2% gain, but gains were cautious due to overseas market concerns and anticipation of weak export orders data for September, which is expected to show the sixth consecutive month of falling orders. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.408 per US dollar.

site_title: Stocks to watch: M1, Mapletree Logistics Trust, Keppel Infrastructure Trust
summary: Singaporean stocks to watch include M1, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and Keppel Infrastructure Trust, which released Q3 results. M1's net profit increased 0.8% to S$44.9 million, while Mapletree Logistics Trust's DPU dropped 1.1% to 1.86 cents, and Keppel Infrastructure Trust posted a net profit of S$4.13 million, up 159% from the previous year. The companies estimate low single-digit growth for 2015 and expect capital expenditures of around S$120 million.

site_title: Ex-Rabobank trader says 'Libor time' was call to fix rates
summary: A former Rabobank trader testified at the US trial of Anthony Allen and Anthony Conti, accusing the duo of manipulating the London interbank offered interest rate (Libor) submissions to make money. The Libor benchmark affects over $350 trillion in loans and securities. The trial marks the first US case of Libor manipulation.

site_title: Noble awarded tender to sell 2.88m bbls of diesel to Ecuador
summary: Noble Group won a tender to sell 2.88 million barrels of diesel to Petroecuador, Ecuador's state-run oil company, at a bid price of $4.88 per barrel. The diesel shipments, starting in November, will meet the country's increasing demand for refined products. This deal follows Noble's $1 billion loan-for-oil agreement with Petroecuador last year, as Ecuador's 110,000 barrel-per-day Esmeraldas refinery undergoes a major overhaul.

site_title: Morgan Stanley lending business shines amid gloomy overall results
summary: Morgan Stanley's wealth management lending business showed significant growth in the third quarter, with a 6% increase in profit and a 33% rise in loan book. The unit's net interest income increased 25% due to growth in loan book and a revamped compensation structure. This growth contrasts with declines in bond trading, investment banking, and investment management. The bank's efforts to expand lending reflect the trend of investment banks shifting towards universal banking, with Morgan Stanley's loan income accounting for about a fifth of total revenue for the unit.

site_title: CME Group to raise transaction fees in January
summary: The CME Group plans to raise transaction fees on various products starting January 1, 2016, pending regulatory approval. Fees for agricultural options will increase to 36 cents for members and $1.34 for non-members, matching agricultural futures fees. Interest rate products, including 10-year Treasury futures, will also see fee increases. The proposed changes aim to ensure the exchange's pricing is competitive and reflects its business costs. The fee changes must be approved by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

site_title: US softens stance on China's undervalued yuan
summary: The US Treasury has softened its stance on China's undervalued yuan, stating it wants to monitor market forces rather than criticizing Beijing's exchange-rate policy. The report notes the yuan remains below its medium-term valuation but appreciates nearly 30% against the dollar over the past five years. China has implemented a new approach to the currency, selling reserves in August to stem the decline. The Treasury will closely monitor the implementation of this new policy and whether China allows the yuan to respond to market forces.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.63% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.63% higher on Tuesday, tracking modest gains on Wall Street after falling a day earlier due to weak Chinese economic growth data. The Nikkei 225 index rose 114.31 points to 18,245.54.

site_title: Volkswagen diesel owners in US face lost value and limbo
summary: US Volkswagen diesel owners face financial uncertainty as resale values of their polluting vehicles drop, with prices falling 6.5% since the emissions scandal broke in September. No concrete answers are available on how the company will compensate owners or dealers on how to handle non-compliant models. Volkswagen plans to start fixing the first 500,000 affected vehicles in January, but earlier models may require hardware changes and take longer. Owners are stuck, unwilling to sell at a loss but lacking information on what fixes may be in store, with car-buying websites seeing a significant drop in searches for VW diesel cars.

site_title: Singapore to spur private investments in infrastructure: Tharman
summary: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam launched three initiatives to encourage private investments in infrastructure. The initiatives include promoting better project documentation, developing benchmarks and performance measures, and increasing infrastructure debt as a segment of the asset class. Currently, infrastructure debt accounts for less than 0.2% of global funds under management by institutions, and developing this asset class will help banks recycle capital and pass projects to institutional investors. This move aims to increase private sector capital in the infrastructure sector and ensure banks' liquidity in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam on Tuesday launched three initiatives to encourage more institutional investors to put private sector capital into the infrastructure asset class.

site_title: Liftboat construction drives up Triyards' Q4 profit
summary: TRIYARDS, the fabrication arm of offshore group Ezra Holdings, reported a 59% surge in Q4 net profit to US$8.41 million, driven by four completed liftboats. Revenue surged 81% to US$88.4 million. Full-year net profit increased 2% to US$27.15 million, while earnings per share (EPS) dipped to 8.43 US cents. The company's net asset value per share rose to 64.32 US cents. The four completed liftboats were secured earlier in FY15 and contributed significantly to the orderbook visibility despite challenging operating conditions.

site_title: US Fed awards most reverse repos in 2 weeks
summary: The US Federal Reserve awarded $136.36 billion in one-day fixed-rate reverse repurchase agreements at an interest rate of 0.05% to 47 bidders, the highest amount in two weeks. This surpasses the previous record of $156.56 billion on October 5. The overnight interest rate in the repo market was 0.15-0.20%, compared to 0.20% on Friday.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher despite weak oil shares
summary: US stocks ended higher Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 14.57 points to 17,230.54, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.55 to 2,033.66. Gains in tech shares, led by Netflix and Priceline, offset weakness in petroleum-linked equities following weak Chinese economic data. However, Morgan Stanley fell 4.8% and Valeant Pharmaceuticals International dropped 7.7% after earnings reports.

site_title: Singapore set to suffer Indonesia's defaults as well as its smog
summary: Singapore's bond market is bracing for potential defaults by Indonesian companies, following two dollar bond defaults in Indonesia, as Southeast Asia grapples with a slump in commodity prices. Indonesian phone retailer PT Trikomsel Oke's Singapore-dollar bonds plunged to record lows after it blamed a weak rupiah for flagging a possible bond restructuring. The plunge in the rupiah has caused Singapore's capital markets to be tested, with funding costs expected to rise and investors becoming more selective.

site_title: City Harvest trial: Verdict on S$50m case expected tomorrow
summary: A verdict is expected in the S$50m City Harvest Church trial, where six former and current leaders face charges of criminal breach of trust and falsifying accounts. The case began in 2002, alleging misappropriation of S$24m in church funds, which were allegedly used to fund the music career of church founder Kong Hee's wife. The outcome will determine the fate of the church and its leaders.

site_title: Oil prices drop on China slowdown
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday as China's economy posted its slowest growth for more than six years, reinforcing concerns about weak demand from the world's top energy consumer. US and Brent crude oil prices slid $1.07 and $1.36 per barrel, respectively. Analysts attributed the decline to weak Chinese industrial production data, which may lead to weaker oil prices and worsen manufacturing PMI. The market awaits a meeting of OPEC and non-OPEC experts in Vienna on Wednesday, where oil production cuts may be discussed.

site_title: Deutsche Bank accidentally sent client US$6 billion: report
summary: Deutsche Bank accidentally sent US$6 billion to a client in June after a junior employee entered the wrong numbers, using a "gross figure" instead of a "net figure". The error was recovered the next day. The incident follows a series of scandals at the bank, including the resignation of two co-CEOs and a record US$2.5 billion fine for interest rate rigging. This is the latest in a string of errors and fines for the Frankfurt-based bank.

images.alt_text: Germany's biggest lender Deutsche Bank accidentally sent US$6 billion to a client after entering the wrong numbers, Bloomberg News reported on Monday.

site_title: Euro slips as traders anticipate dovish stance at ECB
summary: The euro slipped against the dollar and yen amid anticipation of a dovish stance from the European Central Bank at its meeting this week. The euro fell to US$1.1322 and 135.30 yen, while the dollar remained flat against the yen and slightly lower against the pound. Experts expect no concrete policy change but more "dovish rhetoric" from ECB President Mario Draghi to stem the euro's appreciating trend, which was fueled by a tough September for the eurozone's largest economy.

site_title: Morgan Stanley's Q3 profit down 42% as trading revenue falls
summary: Morgan Stanley's Q3 profit dropped 42% to $939 million, or 48 cents per share, due to a 17.2% decline in trading revenue to $2.03 billion. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over US interest rate hikes and concerns about China's cooling economy. The bank's wealth management business saw a 3.5% revenue decline, but its pre-tax margin expanded to 23%. This marks the second straight quarter of declining trading revenue for Morgan Stanley, joining other major US banks in reporting grim results.

site_title: Apple quashes apps that collect personal data
summary: Apple has removed hundreds of apps from its online store that collect personal data in violation of the company's privacy policies. Researchers discovered the apps using Chinese advertising software that extracts user information, including email addresses and device identifiers. Apple confirmed the discovery and stated that the apps, which have an estimated one million downloads, will be removed and new apps using similar SDKs will be rejected. The company is working with developers to update their apps to comply with its guidelines.

images.alt_text: Apple is kicking out applications that collect personal data in violation of the company's privacy policies from its online store, the tech giant said Monday.

site_title: IBM revenue falls more than expected, cuts profit forecast
summary: IBM's revenue fell 2.9% in Q3, marking the fifth consecutive quarter of decline, due to a strong US dollar and the exit of low-margin businesses. The company cut its full-year profit forecast, citing a shift towards more lucrative cloud computing business. Shares dropped 4.8% in after-hours trading to $141.95. Analysts attribute the decline to the shift in customer preference towards cloud services.

images.alt_text: International Business Machines Corp posted a bigger-than-expected drop in revenue for the fifth straight quarter, hurt by a strong US dollar, and cut its full-year profit forecast, sending its shares lower.

site_title: Japan solar-panel maker sees lower costs with process revamp
summary: Japan-based solar-panel maker Solar Frontier KK is revamping its production process to cut costs by more than a fifth at its new factory in Miyagi prefecture. The goal is to reduce production costs to 40 US cents per watt, or 30 US cents excluding depreciation, to remain competitive. The company aims to achieve this by reducing manufacturing time from 24 hours to eight hours and changing its module structure. This move is part of Solar Frontier's plan to expand overseas and stay competitive in the rapidly expanding Japanese solar market.

site_title: Bank of England to release EU membership report on Wednesday
summary: The Bank of England is set to release a report on EU membership's impact on the economy and banking sector on Wednesday. The report, scheduled to be released by Governor Mark Carney, comes as Prime Minister David Cameron has promised a referendum on EU membership by the end of 2017. The Bank of England had previously stated it was examining the implications of Britain leaving the EU.

site_title: Australia calls for more competition, capital for major banks
summary: Australia has accepted most key recommendations from a government-backed inquiry, calling for increased competition and stronger capital reserves for major banks, including raising an additional A$20 billion over two to three years. The inquiry also recommended improving the superannuation system to boost after-fee returns for fund members and limiting excessive charges for bank and credit cards. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull emphasized the importance of ensuring the nation's banks are safe for the economy.

images.alt_text: Australia on Tuesday accepted most key recommendations of a government-backed inquiry which called for more competition and stronger capital reserves for the nation's four major banks as well as reforming the US$1.2 trillion superannuation system.

site_title: United stays silent on medical condition of airline CEO
summary: United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz was admitted to the hospital with a reported heart attack, but the airline has remained silent on his medical condition and who will lead the company in his absence. The company has declined to provide updates, prompting concerns from observers about accountability and transparency. United's shares dropped 3.1% after the news, and experts argue that the company has an obligation to disclose material developments and inform shareholders. The airline's silence has sparked comparisons to other high-profile CEOs who have kept their health issues private.

site_title: Chinese visit to Britain to see £30 billion in deals
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to sign £30 billion in deals with Britain during his four-day visit, including a £24.5 billion project to build Britain's first new nuclear power station, Hinkley Point C. The visit aims to strengthen business ties and create 3,900 jobs. Prime Minister David Cameron has described the trip as a "golden era" in relations, despite concerns over China's human rights record. The visit follows a similar trip by British finance minister George Osborne to China last year, and marks a decade since Xi's predecessor Hu Jintao visited Britain.

images.alt_text: Deals worth over £30 billion (S$64.4 billion) are to be signed during the four-day visit of Chinese President Xi Jinping to Britain this week, the London government said on Tuesday.

site_title: Barclays, Wachovia to pay US$378m to settle US mortgage claims
summary: Barclays and Wachovia, now part of Wells Fargo, will pay US$378 million to settle claims over toxic mortgage-backed securities sold to failed credit unions. Barclays will pay US$325 million and Wachovia US$53 million, settling without admitting wrongdoing. The National Credit Union Administration announced the settlement, which will be included in Barclays' third-quarter results.

site_title: LME launches gold reforms amid China threat
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) is launching gold reforms to increase transparency and liquidity in the $5 trillion market, amid China's growing influence. China aims to become a price setter with its yuan-denominated gold benchmark by the end of 2015, potentially disrupting London's dominance. The reforms will make the market more transparent, profitable, and liquid, with the LME in talks with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) to develop a European gold futures contract. Regulatory scrutiny and shrinking global liquidity are driving changes, with banks and brokers withdrawing from the London gold market.

site_title: Bank Negara asserts right to act amid row with Attorney-General
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, asserts its right to take regulatory action against 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) amid a dispute with the Attorney-General over alleged financial irregularities. Bank Negara can order restitution, issue compliance orders, or impose monetary penalties, separate from any potential criminal proceedings. The central bank has revoked 1MDB's investments abroad and instructed the company to repatriate US$1.83 billion, citing breaches of the Exchange Control Act. The dispute highlights the differing views between the Attorney-General and Bank Negara on the company's actions.

site_title: China mulling over bad-debt securitisation to cut bad loans
summary: China is considering reintroducing bad-debt securitization to help banks cut their massive pile of non-performing loans. This instrument, which packages soured loans into notes sold to investors, has been dormant since 2009. Only three Chinese firms have issued such bonds before, and regulators are under pressure to address the issue amid sliding corporate profits, rising defaults, and a stock rout. The move is driven by banks themselves, with some analysts warning that Chinese rating agencies may not be as effective as their US counterparts in assessing the risks.

site_title: Norway's lack of clarity in insurance rules spooking investors: Storebrand
summary: Norway's lack of clarity in insurance regulations is spooking investors, according to Storebrand ASA, the country's largest listed life insurer. The government's surprise move in August allowed for a more lenient transition to Solvency II, eroding the effect of transitional rules. This has raised concerns that other measures, such as new tax rules, may have adverse outcomes. As a result, investors fear Storebrand's profits may be affected, leading to a 20% drop in its shares since July. The company plans to cut costs and restructure its operations to improve margins.

site_title: UBS to pay US$17.5m in SEC settlement over fund's strategy change
summary: UBS AG has agreed to pay US$17.5 million to the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for failing to disclose a change in investment strategy at its closed-end fund, UBS Willow Fund LLC. The fund initially focused on distressed debt but shifted to credit default swaps in 2008, betting on deteriorating credit market conditions. The SEC charges stem from the firms' alleged failure to disclose this change. The settlement resolves the charges, with UBS AG agreeing to pay the fine.

site_title: Aver Asia makes quality customer service its guiding principle
summary: Aver Asia, a Singapore-based equipment provider, has prioritized quality customer service to stand out in a standardized industry. Since its inception in 1999, the company has grown significantly, expanding its revenue from S$20 million to over S$80 million. Aver Asia's 24-hour service hotline, emergency-response team, and equipment maintenance checks are key to its commitment to delivering seamless experiences for its customers. The company's focus on quality service has led to a loyal customer base, with over 90% of customers being repeat customers, and has enabled it to expand into overseas markets.

site_title: AIA rolls out digital underwriter amid upgrading glitches
summary: AIA Singapore has launched its first fully mobile digital underwriter, reducing the time needed for policy applications from three days to minutes. The digital underwriter is available to over 4,000 tied agents and other distribution channels, enabling underwriters to focus on complex cases and expedite approvals. The rollout comes as the insurer struggles to deal with glitches from upgrading its administration systems, which also affected claims processes and customer commissions. The digital underwriter aims to improve business operations and customer experience.

site_title: Web or app? Sites are caught in the middle of competing visions
summary: Apple's focus on apps and Google's emphasis on the mobile Web are fragmenting the online world, causing businesses to struggle. Websites are caught in the middle, with publishers often investing time and money in both a website and an app. Recent moves by Apple and Google, such as blocking ads on mobile websites and penalizing websites with pop-up screens, have further complicated the issue. This has made it difficult for small publishers to afford a large technology staff, leading some to shut down their apps and focus solely on the Web.

site_title: Cost concerns weigh on industrial leasing deals and rents in Q3
summary: Cost concerns led to fewer industrial leasing deals, stagnant rents, and low strata-titled sales in Q3 2015, according to Colliers International. The number of leasing deals fell to 2,081, while rents eased by 0.4% for prime conventional factory space and 1% for ground- and upper-level space. Strata-titled sales also declined, with 176 caveats lodged in Q3, the lowest quarterly sales seen since 2008. Sellers held on to price expectations, keeping average capital values stable. Rents are expected to dip further in Q4 2015, while business park rents may decline.

site_title: Visitors to get a last look at NYC's iconic TWA Flight Center
summary: Thousands of visitors are expected at New York's John F Kennedy International Airport on Sunday to view the iconic TWA Flight Center before its renovation into a 500-room hotel. Designed by Eero Saarinen in 1962, the terminal will be renovated to include guest rooms, conference space, and an observation deck. The $265 million project, funded by JetBlue and MCR Development, is expected to open in 2018. The event is part of Open House New York, and former TWA employees are among those returning to the beloved mid-century modern-style building.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to split investment unit in two
summary: Deutsche Bank announced plans to split its investment unit in two, as part of a major reorganization aimed at addressing criticism of inefficiency and overcoming legal problems. The changes include the departure of several top executives, including Michele Faissola and Stephan Leithner, who faced criticism over their handling of benchmark interest rate manipulation allegations. The bank's new structure will focus on corporate and investment banking, sales and trading, and regulatory oversight, with a new chief regulatory officer and chief operating officer appointed.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Biosensors International Group announced the Leaders Free clinical trial demonstrated superior safety and efficacy for BioFreedom, a breakthrough technology, suggesting potential benefits for patients at high risk of bleeding and unable to tolerate prolonged DAPT. The company will focus on expanding its geographical reach for BioFreedom, with a full commercial launch in the current financial year. Analysts raised target prices, with OCBC Investment Research pegging its fair value estimate at S$0.66 and Guocoleisure setting a target price of S$1.26, citing higher net asset value and earnings visibility.

site_title: M1's Q3 profit up 0.8% at S$44.9m
summary: M1 Ltd, a Singapore-based telecommunications company, reported a 0.8% increase in net profit to S$44.9 million for the third quarter, driven by a 11% rise in operating revenue to S$277.6 million. Ebitda increased 2.6% to S$86.6 million. The company added 12,000 postpaid mobile customers and 6,500 fibre customers, with mobile data revenue rising 48% to 44.7% of service revenue. Despite a 28.5% increase in cost of sales, M1's CEO expects low single-digit growth in net profit for the year 2015.

site_title: China top in built asset wealth; S'pore 2nd to Qatar in per capita terms
summary: China has overtaken the US to become the wealthiest country in the world based on built asset wealth, according to the Global Built Asset Wealth Index 2015. China's built asset wealth is valued at US$47.6 trillion, surpassing the US with US$36.8 trillion. Despite an economic slowdown, China's continued investment in infrastructure and rebalancing towards consumer spending are expected to drive further GDP growth, with its built asset wealth doubling to US$100 trillion in the next decade. Singapore ranks second in per capita terms, while Qatar tops the list.

site_title: Noble boosts credit facility for two US energy units to US$1.1b
summary: Noble Group has increased a US$450 million credit facility to US$1.1 billion to support its US energy products distribution segment. The expanded revolving borrowing base facility will be used by two of its units, Noble Americas Corp and Noble Petro, to fund growing business requirements. This comes after Noble's management reported that its oil liquids and gas and power businesses contributed 60% of operating income in the past 12 months. The deal was backed by six key banks, including Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ and Societe Generale.

site_title: Loss of 300,000 subscribers in Q3 seen as good news for US pay-TV
summary: The US pay-TV industry saw an estimated 300,000 subscribers lose TV service in Q3, a significant drop from 600,000 in the second quarter. This decline is seen as a positive trend, indicating a shift towards cord-cutting and cheaper video entertainment options. Analysts predict a slight improvement in the industry's performance, with some cable companies, like Comcast, expected to have lost fewer subscribers than previously thought. The trend highlights the challenges faced by traditional TV providers as they compete with streaming services like Netflix and Amazon.

images.alt_text: How bad have things been for the pay-television industry lately? An estimated 300,000 Americans dropped TV service last quarter, and analysts are calling it good news.

site_title: Euro hits 10-day low vs US dollar before ECB meeting
summary: The euro fell to a 10-day low against the US dollar, reaching US$1.13085, ahead of a European Central Bank meeting that could lead to further stimulus to boost inflation in the eurozone. Many banks expect the euro to fall to parity with the US dollar by the end of the year due to the ECB's monthly injections of 60 billion euros. The eurozone faces deflationary pressures, and investors are betting on the ECB to announce additional easing measures.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 250% increase in net profit to S$35 million for the first quarter, driven by revenue recognition from industrial property development Ecotech @ Sunview. Revenue rose to S$434 million, with earnings per share increasing to 1.19 cents. The company declared an interim dividend of 0.50 cents per share. Meanwhile, Nordic Group secured new orders worth S$4.1 million, with contracts expected to be completed by the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Facebook will warn users of state-sponsored attacks
summary: Facebook has begun warning users of state-sponsored cyber attacks, following Google's lead. The social media platform's chief security officer, Alex Stamos, announced that users will be notified if their accounts are targeted or compromised by attackers suspected of working on behalf of a nation-state. The company advises users to take action to secure their online accounts, including rebuilding systems or replacing computers believed to be infected with malicious code. This move aims to protect users from advanced and dangerous cyber attacks.

site_title: Seoul successfully copies a US strategy to boost retail sales
summary: South Korea successfully replicated the US Black Friday strategy, boosting retail sales by 24% over two weeks. The campaign, launched to offset online shopping and attract tourists back into stores, saw over 34,000 stores offer deep discounts, including 80% off. The move is seen as a temporary relief, but could redirect local consumers back to Korean malls, which lose billions of won to US retailers during peak shopping periods. The government plans to host similar retail campaigns in the future to stimulate local consumption.

site_title: Flash crashes, debt default and panic selling haunt IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings in Lima, Peru, addressed concerns about a potential global financial crisis. The main issues discussed included the possibility of the US Federal Reserve raising interest rates, China's economic slowdown, and the impact of commodity market slumps on exporters. Corporate debt default in emerging markets, particularly in Asia, was also a major concern, with the potential for "flash crashes" and "panic selling" in debt and equity markets. The IMF and World Bank played down risks, but warned of the dangers of a repeat of the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: Pan Pacific to launch serviced suites in Puteri Harbour project
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group is partnering with developers of the Puteri Cove Residences and Quayside project in Malaysia to operate Pan Pacific-branded serviced suites, marking the hotel group's first such launch in the country. The serviced suites are expected to open in early 2018 and will occupy 16 floors within the mixed-use project. The move is seen as a strategic expansion for the hotel group, driven by demand from businesses and healthcare services in the region, with plans to operate serviced suites in key gateway cities across Asia-Pacific.

site_title: More stimulus a matter of time, say analysts, as ECB heads to Malta meet
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is set to convene a meeting in Malta to discuss the euro-area economy's recovery, which is being impacted by slowing international trade and global market volatility. Analysts predict the ECB will likely expand bond buying to stimulate the economy, with some economists forecasting this could happen as early as Thursday. This move is seen as a response to muted inflationary pressures and the need to support the region's recovery, which is expected to be a topic of discussion at the meeting.

site_title: Big leveraged ETF blamed for amplifying Nikkei moves in closing minutes
summary: A Japanese leveraged exchange-traded fund (ETF) has been blamed for amplifying Nikkei 225 stock market moves in the final minutes of trading, with the fund's assets more than doubling to $6.5 billion over five months. Despite Nomura Asset Management's denial, the fund has been accused of increasing volatility, and the company has halted new subscription orders. Experts suggest that investors' contrarian strategies and the fund's size are contributing to the issue, which could be mitigated if investors pull out.

site_title: Companies Act must be amended now to ensure real independence of directors
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) should inspect over 550 listed firms on the company's governance code to ensure real independence of directors. A 2014 report warned that some companies may miss the 2017 deadline for complete board independence, potentially undermining compliance with the Code of Corporate Governance. The author argues that the Companies Act must be amended to make it compulsory for directors to disclose real independence in annual reports and prosecute those who contravene the law. This is crucial to protect Central Provident Fund members' investments and maintain public trust.

site_title: Changes in store for London gold market at bullion meet?
summary: The London gold market is set to undergo changes, with the London Bullion Market Association exploring ways to modernize the spot market, including standardized central clearing and listed derivatives. The industry is responding to regulatory scrutiny and pressure from lawmakers to tighten bank controls. The World Gold Council has agreed with five banks to discuss these changes, and the LBMA is considering a new electronic platform to boost transparency and efficiency. The changes aim to address concerns over market risk and increase transparency, with the goal of making the market more efficient and resilient.

site_title: Core inflation expectations lowest in 4 years
summary: Singapore households' core inflation expectations have dropped to their lowest levels in four years, falling to 3.31% in September from 3.5% in June. The softer rate is attributed to sliding oil prices, weak global growth prospects, and benign domestic price pressures. Overall inflation expectations also slipped to 3.23%, below the historical average of 3.94%. The decline is seen as a positive sign for the Singapore economy, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore expecting core inflation to "rise gradually" over the course of 2016 towards its historical average of close to 2%.

site_title: Retail employees in Singapore set for 4.5% salary hike in 2016
summary: Retail employees in Singapore are expected to receive a 4.5% salary hike in 2016, the largest wage increment of any sector in the country. This is higher than the 4.1% jump they received in 2015. The high-tech and professional services industries are also set for healthy salary increases, with 4.3% and 3.9% hikes, respectively. Overall, salary budgets in Singapore are projected to rise by 4.4% in 2016, but inflation reduces this to 2.9%.

images.alt_text: Retail employees are on track for a 4.5 per cent pay increase in 2016, higher than the 4.1 per cent jump they got this year. This will also be the largest wage increment of any sector here in 2016.

site_title: Xi's visit paves way for major investment, trade deals with the UK
summary: China President Xi Jinping is expected to sign an accord with the UK, giving China a significant stake in Electricite de France's Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project in Somerset, England. The deal, finalized over the weekend, will also include investments and trade agreements. China is the UK's second-largest investor in China and its second-largest trading partner in the EU, according to Zhang Ji, China Assistant Minister of Commerce. The agreement is seen as a major breakthrough in bilateral relations.

site_title: China's wise men come down to earth with a bump
summary: China's economic growth slowed to 6.9% in the third quarter, the lowest rate in six years, sparking concerns about the country's ability to manage an alarming slowdown. The slowdown is attributed to a collapse of the Shanghai stock market and a surprise devaluation of the yuan, which has led to market instability. The Chinese government's efforts to transition from high-speed manufacturing to slower-paced expansion driven by consumption and services are facing challenges, with the old economy decelerating sharply. The services sector, which accounts for half of all economic output, is seen as a potential solution, but investors are left to guess the real picture due to lack of transparency in official data.

site_title: Walmart suppliers under more pricing pressure
summary: Walmart suppliers face increased pressure to cut prices and costs, following the retailer's earnings warning last week. Suppliers, who already bear the brunt of demanding prices from the discount store, are bracing for further price reductions and cost sharing. This pressure is unusual even for Walmart's standards, with suppliers reporting that the retailer has been aggressively pushing for lower prices this year. The squeeze on suppliers is likely to have a ripple effect on the global supply chain, with potential implications for vendors and the broader economy.

site_title: Private capital in infrastructure: Illiquid assets still a hurdle
summary: Private sector investors are urging governments and banks to make infrastructure investments tradable assets to ease financial burdens. Currently, infrastructure projects rely heavily on bank loans, making it challenging for private investors to participate. The World Bank and Singapore's Ministry of Finance are working to create more sophisticated financial products to invest in infrastructure, with the aim of boosting global growth. Experts believe that infrastructure spending can have a 1:3 growth multiplier effect and can benefit from inflation, making it an attractive option for long-term investors.

site_title: China crude import expected to stay at record levels
summary: China's crude oil imports are expected to remain at record levels, driven by demand from private refiners and stockpiling of cheap oil. Despite a slowdown in growth, buying for October-November delivery has picked up strongly, easing concerns of a sharp slowdown. China's crude imports are expected to rise 12% in the second half of the year, reaching 6.75 million barrels per day, putting it close to the US's 7.3 million bpd. The country's strategic petroleum reserves are also expected to continue to grow.

site_title: Yahoo development chief said to leave company to join Square
summary: Jacqueline Reses, Yahoo's chief development officer, is leaving the company to join Square Inc, where she will help boost the startup's executive team. Reses' departure comes as Yahoo prepares to spin off its stake in Alibaba Group, worth about $27 billion. The move could help alleviate concerns about Jack Dorsey's dual responsibilities as CEO of Twitter and Square. Reses' exit marks another departure from Yahoo, which has struggled to build a stable management team amid increased competition from Google and Facebook.

site_title: China economic growth slows to 6.9% in Q3
summary: China's economy grew by 6.9% in Q3, its slowest rate since 2009, but shows signs of stabilisation. The figure is slightly above forecasts and within the government's target. Analysts welcome the data, citing a cyclical recovery in some parts of the economy, but remain uncertain about its accuracy due to flaws in the calculation method and political pressure to meet growth targets. The economy has been slowing since 2010, and China is struggling with overcapacity and debt. The government has implemented stimulus measures, and analysts expect further easing in 2016.

site_title: DuPont sets up Asean innovation HQ in S'pore
summary: DuPont is setting up a new innovation and business headquarters in Singapore, with a 11,000 square meter facility expected to open in Biopolis next year. The new headquarters will house nearly 200 scientists and engineers and grow to over 300 employees by 2020, solidifying DuPont's presence in the region. The firm aims to develop and deliver innovative solutions for South-east Asia, leveraging Singapore's inter-disciplinary research capabilities and creating job opportunities for Singaporeans. This move comes as DuPont, the world's fourth largest chemical company, continues to expand its operations in the region.

site_title: Chinese govt hackers still at work despite Xi's pledge, say analysts
summary: Chinese government hackers have continued to target US companies despite President Xi Jinping's pledge not to conduct cyber-economic espionage. CrowdStrike reported that at least seven US companies have been targeted since Xi's vow, highlighting a potential breach of trust. Analysts say the continued hacking attempts undermine Xi's promise and suggest the Chinese government's intentions may not be genuine.

site_title: Big Oil argues 'ethanol is worse for climate' in advertising pitch
summary: Big Oil is launching a new advertising campaign to roll back government mandates for the use of biofuels, arguing that ethanol is worse for the climate than petrol. The campaign, sponsored by a group of refiners, environmentalists, and chain-restaurant owners, claims that mandating corn for ethanol doubles greenhouse-gas emissions over 30 years. However, experts argue that the evidence is mixed, with some studies showing ethanol has a positive net fossil energy value and others suggesting it can lead to greater carbon emissions. The move comes as the Obama administration prepares to set ethanol mandates and participate in global climate talks in Paris.

site_title: Enforcing the comply or explain requirement
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to review 550 mainboard-listed companies' compliance with the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance, with some issuers failing to meet the "comply or explain" requirement. The review aims to educate companies on how to improve implementation of the code and identify challenges faced in implementation. SGX should apply enhanced enforcement powers to non-compliant companies, including Catalist companies, and consider disclosing company names found wanting. The review also highlights the need for improved disclosures and explanations, particularly uninformative/boilerplate disclosures, to better inform shareholders.

site_title: S Koreans gather for rare reunion with North relatives
summary: South Koreans gathered near the North Korean border on Monday for a rare reunion with separated family members. The event, set to take place in the North Korean resort of Mount Kumgang, marks the second such reunion in five years, following an agreement between the two Koreas to de-escalate tensions. The reunions aim to reduce animosity and promote reconciliation between the divided nations.

site_title: Japan Post sets IPO prices at top of their ranges
summary: Japan Post sets initial public offering prices at the top of their ranges for its bank and insurance arms, indicating strong demand from retail investors. The two companies, worth US$65 billion, will raise a combined 1.4 trillion yen (S$16.2 billion) in a triple IPO set for November 4. The listings are part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's campaign to unlock massive household savings and boost domestic stock investments. Despite concerns about the lack of dynamic future growth potential, investors see the businesses as a safe-haven alternative, bolstering demand and price for Japan Post Holdings.

site_title: 150 firms, consortia have offered views on S'pore-KL rail project
summary: Around 150 firms and consortia have responded to a request for information (RFI) for the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur high-speed rail (HSR) project by Singapore and Malaysia, described as "positive" by the two governments. The responses include firms from Asia-Pacific, Europe, the Middle East, and North America, providing feedback on the project's commercial model and technical aspects. The feedback will help the governments determine the project's commercial viability and ensure a successful start.

site_title: China property now a 'buy': BlackRock
summary: BlackRock's Helen Zhu believes China's property market is now a "buy" due to the country's transition from an old investment-fuelled economy to a services-oriented one. The government's easing of cooling measures and reduced funding costs are positive fundamentals. Zhu notes that some property names are trading at a 50-70% discount to book value, making it an attractive sector. This contrasts with Bank of America Merrill Lynch's views that the housing market may be running out of steam. Zhu is optimistic about the market's potential for growth and is adding to her fund's property exposure.

images.alt_text: "Most people hate Chinese property. We're putting our neck out there and saying, you know what, it's all in the price, and in fact the delta of change is very positive," said Ms Zhu.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust Q2 DPU falls 1.1%
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 1.1% drop in its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.86 Singapore cents, primarily due to higher borrowing costs, tax, and management fees. The Reit's distribution reinvestment plan also contributed to the decrease.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q3 distribution up 4.6% at S$54.4 million
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 4.6% year-on-year rise in distribution income to S$54.4 million for the third quarter, driven by better performance of three properties in Singapore and Sydney. However, the distribution per unit (DPU) dropped 8.1% due to a bigger unit base. Net property income slipped 13.3% year-on-year, while total return attributable to unitholders was 63.1% lower. Despite challenging leasing market conditions, the Reit manager remains optimistic, citing positive rent reversion and a well-staggered lease expiry profile.

site_title: India to overhaul century-old bankruptcy laws to revive reform agenda
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to overhaul the country's century-old bankruptcy laws in an effort to revive his reform agenda. A government-backed committee has submitted recommendations to the Finance Ministry for a bill that aims to streamline the process of resolving insolvency and recover dues from defaulters. The new law, which is expected to be tabled during the parliament session next month, will provide more flexibility and speed to the bankruptcy process, balancing creditor and debtor interests. The goal is to reduce the time it takes to wind up a dying company or recover dues from a defaulter.

site_title: More resources and commitment are the keys to fighting the haze
summary: Indonesian haze persists despite annual debates, with complexity often cited as an excuse for inaction. The haze is attributed to multiple causes, including Indonesian President Joko Widodo's administration, lax enforcement, and inadequate fire-fighting resources by concession owners. The Indonesian government's role in the haze is clear, with laws and regulations failing to address the problem effectively. The solution lies in increased resource allocation, better equipment, and sustainable farming methods. Companies must also invest in fire prevention and control measures, rather than relying on excuses. Immediate action is needed to tackle the haze.

images.alt_text: It seems like an annual tradition to have a debate about the haze and to be told that there is no simple solution to the regional scourge.

site_title: Help for SMEs to spread their wings
summary: The Singapore government has introduced targeted new schemes to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) expand their international footprint. The International Growth Scheme (IGS) provides a 10% concessionary tax rate for up to five years on qualifying incremental income from approved activities, while the Double Tax Deduction (DTD) scheme enhances tax incentives for internationalisation efforts. The Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A) scheme has also been extended to encourage SMEs to scale up through strategic acquisitions. These schemes aim to help SMEs overcome financial risks and lack of market familiarity in expanding globally.

images.alt_text: SMEs should familiarise themselves with the finer details of the incentives available so that they do not miss out on the opportunities to grow beyond Singapore.

site_title: Beijing, Bangalore challenge Silicon Valley for venture capital
summary: Asia is rivaling North America in venture capital investments, with China and India accounting for over $16.9 billion in the third quarter, more than tripled from last year. Beijing and Bangalore are competing with Silicon Valley for big deals, with Chinese ride-hailing service Didi Kuaidi securing $3 billion in funding. Despite China's slowing economy, venture capital investment remains strong, driven by the growth of mobile users and mobile payments. Total venture capital investment in China and India for the first nine months of the year reached $36.2 billion, compared to $19.9 billion for all of last year.

site_title: Firms scan PCs for child sex images
summary: Ericsson has become the first major company to scan employee computers for child sexual abuse images, using software from Netclean Technologies. The system scans web searches, emails, and hard drives for specific images or videos already classified as child pornography. Since installation in 2011, Ericsson has dealt with around one alarm each month, flagging acts that could lead to prosecution. The alerts are sent to a security adviser, who confirms the images are on an international blacklist, and the company aims to remove such content from its system, while also raising concerns about potential false positives and the impact on employee privacy.

site_title: Ageing cars and new technology help US auto parts retailers to surge
summary: US auto parts retailers, including AutoZone, Advance Auto Parts, and O'Reilly Automotive, are experiencing significant sales surges, with stock prices increasing by at least 20% this year. The industry is benefiting from the aging of vehicles on US roads, with a record 250 million vehicles in circulation, and the growing demand for replacement parts from professional mechanics. Online retailers, including Amazon, are not yet a significant threat to the brick-and-mortar stores, as customers require immediate assistance. Analysts attribute the retailers' success to their ability to meet the needs of customers who cannot wait for delivery, and their strong distribution systems.

site_title: Trans-Pacific Partnership: time for small businesses to think big
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has concluded among 12 Pacific Rim nations, covering 40% of the global economy and a third of world trade. The agreement aims to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs) by simplifying border clearance processes, shortening lead times, and improving competitiveness. Key features include time-release guarantees, advanced rulings, and self-certification of origin, designed to enhance predictability and simplify trade for SMEs. The agreement also includes capacity building and technical assistance to help developing country members implement new policies and systems.

site_title: Singapore's score for retirement savings systems takes a step back
summary: Singapore's retirement savings system has been downgraded from B grade to C+ in the 2015 Melbourne Mercer Global Pension Index, scoring 64.7 out of 80. The downgrade is due to decreased net household savings rate and reduced pension assets as a percentage of GDP. Despite this, Singapore is on the right track with plans to improve the Central Provident Fund system, including increasing wage limits and introducing the Silver Support Scheme. Denmark remains the top-ranked country with an overall score of 81.7.

site_title: PM Lee: Fusionopolis Two to bring manufacturing to next level
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong launched Fusionopolis Two, a research and development hub in the one-north area, aiming to bring manufacturing to the next level. The complex will integrate capabilities in materials science, chemistry, and semiconductor processing to support multinational corporations and small and medium enterprises. The hub will build upon the success of Fusionopolis One, which has catalyzed industry projects and collaborations with companies such as Singtel and Rolls Royce. The move is expected to further boost Singapore's economy and innovation ecosystem, with the government investing heavily in research and development.

site_title: Star expert witness to testify in Kovan double murder trial
summary: A star expert witness, Henry Lee, a renowned forensic scientist, is set to testify in the Kovan double murder trial, scheduled to begin on October 20, 2015. Lee, 76, has testified in high-profile cases, including the OJ Simpson and JonBenét Ramsey murder trials. Another expert witness, Thai forensic pathologist Porntip Rojanasunan, is also being considered, but her confirmation is pending. The trial concerns the murders of two men, Tan Boon Sin and Tan Chee Heong, by former policeman Iskandar Rahmat, who faces the death penalty if convicted.

site_title: West prepares to end trade sanctions as Iran deal adopted
summary: The US and Europe prepared to lift trade sanctions on Iran as a historic nuclear deal came into effect, 90 days after the UN Security Council endorsed the accord. The sanctions will remain in place until Iran fulfills its end of the bargain, including scaling back its nuclear program. Iran must surrender or dilute enriched nuclear fuel stocks, dismantle centrifuges, and halt a reactor capable of making plutonium. The sanctions will be lifted in stages, with foreign firms allowed to resume ties once the UN nuclear watchdog confirms Iran's compliance.

site_title: Singapore dollar bond rally continues
summary: Singapore's Fixed Income (SFI) index reached an all-time high of 122.25 last week, driven by expectations of interest rate hikes being pushed further away. The SFI rose 0.78% from the previous week, outperforming the Straits Times Index by 12.17%. Corporate bonds also gained, with the SFI Corporate Bond Index increasing 0.49%. The index has risen for five consecutive weeks and 2.23% year-to-date. Fixed income bankers attribute the rally to the "lower for longer" feeling for interest rates, driven by lower growth prospects and a downward revision by the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: United says to release more details about CEO's health
summary: United Continental Holdings Inc. plans to release more details about CEO Oscar Munoz's hospitalization, following a heart attack reported on Friday. Munoz, 56, was admitted to the hospital on Thursday and took over as CEO in September. The company has remained silent on his medical condition.

site_title: Tan Chorh Chuan first Singaporean to be elected into US National Academy of Medicine
summary: Tan Chorh Chuan, president of the National University of Singapore, has become the first Singaporean member to be elected into the US National Academy of Medicine (NAM), an esteemed organisation advising on health and science issues. NAM unveiled its new members, including Prof Tan, at its annual meeting, with over 2,000 US and international members. The election is seen as a strong recognition of Singapore and NUS contributions to medicine and health in Asia, and Prof Tan views it as an incredible privilege. Membership is for life, and Prof Tan will serve voluntarily to provide unbiased information on health and science matters.

site_title: Boost for Keppel Infrastructure Trust from acquisitions
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a net profit of S$4.13 million for the second quarter, a significant improvement from a loss of S$1.6 million a year ago, due to contributions from acquisitions of Crystal Trust and KMC. Revenue rose 20.3% to S$153 million, driven by full quarter contributions from these assets. Earnings per unit improved to 0.11 Singapore cents, and the trust's net asset value per unit grew to 35.9 Singapore cents. KIT also announced a distribution per unit of 0.93 Singapore cents, payable on November 20.

site_title: Steve Jobs biopic wraps London Film Festival
summary: The 59th London Film Festival concluded with the European premiere of the Danny Boyle-directed biopic "Steve Jobs," starring Michael Fassbender as the Apple co-founder. The film, written by Aaron Sorkin, explores Jobs' personal conflicts and relationships, including with his daughter and former Apple CEO John Sculley. Despite criticism from Jobs' widow and Apple CEO, the film received support from Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak and praise from Kate Winslet, who portrayed Joanna Hoffman. The festival also highlighted women's struggles through films such as "Suffragette" and "He Named Me Malala."

images.alt_text: Kate Winslet and Michael Fassbender at the film's premiere at the London Film Festival; Winslet said that she had been struck by the "incredible loyalty" of those around Jobs.
Director Danny Boyle (left) with screenplay writer Aaron Sorkin at an industry screening of Steve Jobs.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on China data, earnings
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 59.39 points (0.34%) to 17,156.58, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index down 7.48 (0.37%) and 11.13 (0.23%), respectively. Weak Chinese economic data and disappointing earnings from Morgan Stanley contributed to the decline.

site_title: S&P retains India rating, unlikely to change till at least 2016
summary: Standard & Poor's retained India's BBB- rating with a 'stable' outlook, unlikely to change until at least 2016. The rating is influenced by India's low per capita income, high government debt, and supply constraints. This decision aligns with Fitch's 'stable' outlook, but Moody's raised India's rating to 'positive' in April. The stable outlook balances India's sound external position with its vulnerabilities, indicating no rating change in 2015 or 2016 based on current forecasts.

site_title: Price of donated eggs now subject of legal battle
summary: A federal lawsuit challenges industry guidelines limiting egg donors to $10,000, citing price-fixing. The lawsuit, certified as a class action, claims the guidelines are too restrictive and allow high-end fertility clinics to pay donors up to six figures. The guidelines were established in 2000 to prevent exploitation of low-income young women, but critics argue the cap is too low and fails to address the rising demand for eggs. The case could lead to increased negotiation and potentially shake up the $80 million egg donor market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed on China slowdown
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed Monday as China's economy grew at 6.9% in the third quarter, beating market expectations of 6.8%. This news lifted mining and healthcare shares, while dragging down others. The outcome was seen as a positive sign for global growth, but investors remain cautious due to ongoing US-EU trade talks and ongoing US-China tensions.

site_title: US presidential election ignoring large social realities
summary: The US presidential election is ignoring large social realities, including the country's ageing population, its immigrant society, and stagnant economic growth. The number of people aged 65 or older is expected to increase by 76% by 2040, straining Social Security and Medicare spending. Immigrants, both skilled and unskilled, are also a pressing issue, with unskilled immigrants contributing to poverty rates. Economic growth has slowed to 2%, hindering wage gains and tax collections. Candidates' proposals often fail to address these pressing issues, instead focusing on policy proposals that are disconnected from reality.

site_title: Oxley Holdings posts three-fold rise in Q1 net profit
summary: Oxley Holdings, a property developer, reported a three-fold increase in Q1 net profit to S$35 million, driven by revenue recognition from the Ecotech @ Sunview project. Revenue rose nearly four-fold to S$434 million. Earnings per share increased to 1.19 Singapore cents from 0.34 cents a year ago. The company declared an interim dividend of 0.50 Singapore cent per share. Oxley shares ended 1 Singapore cent lower at 41 Singapore cents.

site_title: Amazon steps up battle over NY Times workplace probe
summary: Amazon has criticized a New York Times investigation into its workplace, saying the article misrepresented the company and ignored key facts. Amazon spokesman Jay Carney stated that the article was based on interviews with a former employee who had attempted to defraud vendors, and another employee whose issues were related to work-life balance. Amazon presented its findings to the Times, but they were not corrected, leading Amazon to write about the issue itself. The article sparked a discussion about Amazon's workplace culture, with some employees citing stress and competition to boost productivity.

site_title: Foreign investment pledges in Thailand fall 83% y/y in Jan-Aug: BOI
summary: Foreign investment proposals in Thailand decreased 83% in the first eight months of 2015 compared to the same period last year, reaching 50.3 billion baht. The Board of Investment attributed the decline to the introduction of new investment policies. Despite the drop, the agency believes Thailand remains an attractive investment destination, with China expected to become the top foreign investor this year, overtaking Japan. The government is shifting its incentives towards more value-added sectors, providing tax exemptions and exemptions on import duties for industries focusing on research and development.

site_title: Xi in the UK: Economics the dominant note
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping begins a four-day state visit to the UK, marking the first visit by a Chinese president in a decade. The trip aims to strengthen bilateral ties and promote economic cooperation, with the UK pledging to be China's "best partner in the West." Xi will receive red-carpet treatment at Buckingham Palace and other key locations, amid a backdrop of economic uncertainty in China. The visit comes as the UK seeks to tap into China's vast market, and Beijing is eager to boost its influence in the West.

site_title: Mixed session as momentum of last 2 weeks stalls
summary: The Straits Times Index closed 6.11 points lower at 3,024.5 on Monday, amid low trading volume of 1.7 billion units. China's weak third-quarter GDP numbers and mixed sessions for Hong Kong and Dow futures likely contributed to the decline. The market's momentum from the past fortnight appears to have stalled, with 269 rises versus 187 falls in the 30 STI components.

site_title: Canada starts voting in key legislative elections
summary: Canada begins voting in key legislative elections, with 65,000 polling stations opening across the Atlantic seaboard. The Liberals, led by Justin Trudeau, hold a strong lead with 38.2% support, ahead of the Conservatives (30.1%) and New Democratic Party (21.2%). The election marks a challenge to Prime Minister Stephen Harper's nine years of Tory rule, as Trudeau seeks to unseat him. Up to 26.4 million electors are expected to vote, with a high turnout anticipated, particularly in provinces that opened earlier today.

site_title: NUS president elected to US academy of medicine
summary: Tan Chorh Chuan, president of the National University of Singapore, has become the first Singaporean to be elected to the US National Academy of Medicine (NAM), a prestigious organization advising the US and global communities on health and science matters. NAM elected 70 new regular members and 10 international members in its annual meeting.
