The council, a group of labour representatives, will support securing temporary jobs, but acknowledges the company's board is discussing "different scenarios". This move comes as the carmaker faces significant financial implications from the scandal.

site_title: Credit Suisse says euro set to drop with Draghi close to more QE
summary: Credit Suisse predicts euro weakness next week due to expected ECB president Mario Draghi's signal for further monetary easing. Draghi is expected to verbally lay groundwork for extending quantitative easing by year-end, potentially at the December meeting. The euro stalled after a two-week gain amid speculation of a US Federal Reserve rate hike delay. Inflation data showed the euro area's consumer-price index slipped 0.1% in September, undershooting the central bank's target, and signaling more stimulus may be needed.

site_title: Greece 'on the way up', things likely to stabilise
summary: Greece is on the path to recovery from its debt crisis, according to financial expert Stavros Thomadakis. After being on the brink of leaving the eurozone, the country has a new political majority in favor of an adjustment program. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' coalition government won a parliamentary vote of confidence, and the economy grew 0.8% in the second quarter. While European bailout money is financing the public sector, private investment is needed to support growth. Thomadakis is hopeful that the country will stabilize, but notes that Greece still lacks domestic savings.

site_title: Oil up on low US rig count; prices down sharply on week
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Friday as traders covered short positions after four days of sharp losses, despite a US oil rig count falling for a seventh week in a row. US crude settled up 88 cents at $47.26 per barrel, while Brent for December delivery settled up 73 cents at $50.46 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 7.6 million-barrel increase in crude inventories last week, contradicting analyst expectations. A meeting of Opec technical experts on October 21 may indicate a shift in output levels, potentially influencing market sentiment.

site_title: Philippine authorities prepare for typhoon Koppu
summary: Typhoon Koppu is approaching northeastern Luzon with winds of up to 160 kph, expected to make landfall in 12-18 hours. Authorities have cancelled flights, urged residents and tourists to move to safer ground, and ordered 2,000 people to evacuate seaside resorts. Rain has already started in Manila, and ferries and fishing boats are advised to seek shelter. The storm is expected to cause life-threatening flooding and mudslides, with AccuWeather predicting 300-600 mm of rain and 2-meter storm surges. President Aquino has urged calm preparations, with an average of 20 typhoons hitting the Philippines each year.

site_title: Brazil's Levy has not resigned, to stay on as finance minister
summary: Brazil's Finance Minister Joaquim Levy has denied plans to resign, contradicting a news report that said he would step down over austerity measures. Levy, who has struggled to push through austerity proposals, said in an interview he had President Dilma Rousseff's support and would stay in his job as long as necessary to pull the economy out of its slump. The report of Levy's potential resignation led to a decline in Brazilian asset prices, including a 1.4% drop in the iShares MSCI Brazil ETF.

site_title: Bank of China votes for IPO of aviation leasing unit in HK
summary: Bank of China Ltd voted unanimously to spin off its aviation leasing unit, BOC Aviation Pte Ltd, in a Hong Kong share sale. The unit will raise funds by selling up to 40% of shares to international investors and 10% to Hong Kong investors. The funds will be used for purchasing new aircraft and supplementing working capital. BOC Aviation owns 236 aircraft and manages 20 others, with total assets of $11.4 billion and net assets of $2.1 billion. The plan was approved by Bank of China's board of directors on Friday, with no disclosed timing or amount.

site_title: China must hasten infrastructure investment to stabilise growth - state advisor
summary: China's top state advisor, Yu Bin, urged the government to hasten infrastructure investment to stabilize economic growth, citing weak property and manufacturing investments. The advisor called for increased credit and lower financing costs for companies. China needs to speed up 172 hydropower projects, develop 800 million mu of high-standard agricultural land, and increase rural road investment. The government is expected to report GDP growth below 7% for the first time since the global financial crisis, prompting concerns about the economy's stability.

site_title: New lease of life for old, non-green offices
summary: Singapore's Building & Construction Authority (BCA) is encouraging older-generation non-green offices to retrofit and upgrade to reduce energy usage and boost capital values. The BCA offers a S$50 million incentive scheme, including cash incentives of up to half the qualifying costs, to encourage existing building owners and tenants to take up energy improvement works. Since 2008, the BCA has also put in place mandatory minimum sustainability standards for existing buildings, with some buildings achieving comparable performance standards to new Green Mark GoldPlus or Platinum-rated buildings. Retrofitting can lead to energy savings of up to 13.5% and an increase in capital value of up to 2.7%, with an average payback period of 6.3 years.

site_title: New off-the-course footwear
summary: FOOTJOY launches two new off-the-course footwear options in South-east Asia: the Club Casuals and HyperFlex Fitness Trainers. The Club Casuals feature full grain leather uppers and DuraMax rubber soles, priced at S$225, while the HyperFlex Fitness Trainers offer lightweight EVA mid-sole and DuraMax rubber outsole, also priced at S$225. These shoes cater to players who want to wear them both on and off the golf course.

site_title: US will require drones to be registered: NBC News
summary: The US government plans to announce a new requirement for drone registration, citing concerns over close calls between drones and aircraft at major airports. The Transportation Department will work with the drone industry to set up a registration structure, with regulations potentially in place by Christmas. The move aims to address safety concerns and prevent accidents.

site_title: Lacklustre global economy weighing on China
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that the global economy's sluggish performance is weighing on his nation's growth. Despite this, China reported a 6.8% expansion in the third quarter, its weakest since 2009. Xi pledged to deepen market-oriented financial reforms and develop an open, transparent capital market. He also reiterated that the South China Sea's islands and reefs are Chinese territory, and the country will work to peacefully resolve disputes through negotiation. China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: UK official sees sound case for China's yuan to join IMF basket
summary: A senior UK Treasury official, Katharine Braddick, believes China's yuan has a solid case for being included in the IMF's basket of currencies, valued by the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights. Convertibility is the central condition for inclusion, and China is making progress in creating the necessary market infrastructure. Braddick stated that the yuan is trading, will be an investment currency, and is here to stay, despite some concerns about liquidity and the lack of easily accessible Chinese government bonds.

site_title: Poor exchange
summary: Singapore sets up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. The country is also exploring opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The government has announced a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses hit by tariffs. Additionally, Deputy Prime Minister Gan has planned a visit to the US for trade talks. Experts advise graduates to remain calm, citing better employment rates, and encourage workers to future-proof their careers before a potential crisis.

site_title: US: Wall St closes up, registers third week of gains
summary: US stocks closed higher on Friday, marking a third week of gains, driven by a surge in General Electric shares and upbeat consumer sentiment data. The S&P 500 rose 0.46% to 2,033.11, while the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.43% to 17,215.97. Consumer sentiment data, including a rebound in the University of Michigan's preliminary index, also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Russian hackers breached Dow Jones for trading tips: Bloomberg
summary: Russian hackers breached Dow Jones in 2015 to steal trading tips, according to a Bloomberg report. The breach was more serious than initially disclosed by the company, which had reported unauthorized access to its systems between August 2012 and July 2015. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, Secret Service, and Securities and Exchange Commission are leading the investigation, but Dow Jones has denied any knowledge of the alleged matter. The hackers targeted stories being prepared for publication, including trading tips.

site_title: Chipmaker Micron's CEO to take voluntary 50 per cent pay cut
summary: Micron Technology Inc CEO Mark Durcan will take a voluntary 50% pay cut, reducing his annual base salary to $525,000, amid cost-cutting measures. The move comes as the company struggles with weak demand for its memory chips used in computers. China's state-backed Tsinghua Unigroup has offered $23 billion for Micron, but the plan is clouded by US security concerns. The temporary pay cut is effective October 18.

site_title: Macau billionaire in UN bribery case gets US$50m bail
summary: Billionaire Macau real estate developer Ng Lap Seng, accused of bribing a former UN General Assembly president, has been released on $50 million bail with conditions. Ng will live under house arrest in a luxury Manhattan apartment with 24-hour security, and wear an electronic monitoring bracelet. The decision was made despite a federal prosecutor's objections, and the US government may appeal. Ng, with a net worth of $1.8 billion, was arrested in September for allegedly bribing John Ashe and other officials to secure UN support for a conference center in Macau.

site_title: Uncertainty over Fed rate hike becoming too costly for markets: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore Tharman Shanmugaratnam urged the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to reduce uncertainty and move past the economic crisis. He stated that the benefits of near-zero interest rates for economic growth are outweighed by the costs, particularly the impact on business sentiment and market volatility. Tharman emphasized the need for the Fed to normalize rates to reduce uncertainty, which has affected exchange rates and capital flows.

site_title: Alibaba offers US$4.6b for rest of Youku video site
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd offered US$4.6 billion to buy the remaining 18.3% of Youku Tudou Inc, a YouTube-like video site. The offer, valued at US$26.60 per share, is 30% higher than Thursday's closing price. Youku's net cash is US$1.1 billion, resulting in a lower price. Alibaba's acquisition would give it control over the site, allowing it to deliver more video content to Chinese internet users, as it competes with Baidu Inc. and Tencent Holdings Ltd. for internet users' attention.

site_title: Gold down on day but up on week, outlook soft
summary: Gold prices fell on Friday, settling down $4.40 to $1,182.10 an ounce, despite a strong weekly gain. The metal had reached a 3-1/2 month high earlier in the week, but a recovering dollar and weak buying support for physical bullion markets pushed prices down. Despite no Federal Reserve meeting or minutes to influence the dollar, gold is expected to remain in a trading range, with $1,190 being a possible high. The weekly gain, however, still resulted in a 0.4% increase.

images.alt_text: Gold prices slipped on Friday as a recovering dollar pulled them off a 3-1/2 month high, but the metal still eked out a weekly rise after gaining in recent sessions on bets against a US interest rate hike.

site_title: China to build US$5.5 billion high-speed rail line in Indonesia
summary: China has won the rights to build a $5.5 billion high-speed rail line in Indonesia, connecting Jakarta to Bandung. The project, valued at $5.5 billion, is part of Indonesia's efforts to upgrade its infrastructure and drive economic growth. Construction can begin early next year and is expected to be completed by 2018, with trains operating by 2019. The project will use Indonesian materials and workers, but faces potential resistance from local labor unions concerned about foreign workers.

site_title: Apple ordered to pay US$234m to university for infringing patent
summary: A US jury ordered Apple Inc to pay the University of Wisconsin-Madison's patent licensing arm $234 million in damages for incorporating its microchip technology into iPhones and iPads without permission. The verdict came after jurors deliberated for 3-1/2 hours, finding Apple infringed on a 1998 patent for a "predictor circuit" developed by computer science professor Gurindar Sohi. Apple plans to appeal the verdict, which is less than the claimed $400 million.

site_title: Match Group to look for love on Wall Street
summary: The Match Group, parent company of online dating services Tinder, Meetic, and OkCupid, plans to go public on Wall Street with an initial public offering (IPO) of US$100 million. The company operates a portfolio of 45 brands and reported revenue of US$888.3 million and annual net earnings of US$148.4 million in 2022. Match boasts of reaching 59 million users monthly and offering dating products in 38 languages in 190 countries. The IPO details, including the number of shares, price, and intended date, were not disclosed.

site_title: Service at a click
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

New online services are emerging in Singapore, offering a range of conveniences and solutions. A Better Florist provides instant flower delivery, while GroupHunt allows users to collectively buy products at discounted prices. ALADY offers a female-centric promotion and coupon marketplace, and Tompang enables users to request overseas products to be fulfilled by others. ServisHero consolidates various service providers into a single app, and Fynd offers on-demand technology repair and support services. These services aim to improve customer experience, save time, and provide affordable solutions for various needs.

site_title: Abe urges Japan Inc to raise capital investments, staff wages
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged Japan Inc to raise capital investments and staff wages to spur growth in the economy, which is flirting with its second recession in a year. With GDP predicted to contract in the third quarter, Abe called for increased corporate capital investment and human resource spending. Analysts say the corporate sector has not responded adequately to previous policies, with profits instead being invested in cash reserves and offshore investments. The government aims to expand Japan's nominal GDP to 600 trillion yen by 2020.

site_title: Why tipping is wrong
summary: Restaurateur Danny Meyer has eliminated tipping at his restaurants, establishing a transparent, fair salary for staff. This move aims to address the two-tiered wage system created by tipping, which has deep social and economic consequences for millions. To achieve widespread change, law reform is needed to address the lower minimum wage for tipped workers. Meyer's move sets a new standard for the industry, but broader industry reform is required to create a more equitable system.

site_title: Greek parliament approves reform bill ahead of bailout review
summary: The Greek parliament approved an omnibus bill containing key reforms ahead of the review of Greece's third financial rescue package, set to begin in late October. The bill includes measures such as cutting pensions, raising the retirement age, and liberalizing the energy market. The European Commission and IMF inspectors will assess Greece's progress, with the goal of securing fresh aid and debt relief. The reforms are part of the 86-billion-euro bailout plan, and Athens aims to conclude the review and recapitalize its banks to secure additional aid.

images.alt_text: The Greek parliament approved an omnibus bill on Friday cutting pensions, raising the retirement age, increasing punishment for tax evasion and liberalising the energy market ahead of the first review of the country's new bailout programme later this month.

site_title: Measure of a man
summary: High-end tailors are expanding their services to cater to the growing demand for bespoke suits in Singapore and Asia. Tom Ford's made-to-measure specialist will hold private appointments in Singapore, while Huntsman, a 166-year-old Savile Row tailor, will visit the city-state three to four times a year. Each bespoke suit requires 80 hours of hand-made work and can cost upwards of S$6,000. Tailors are adapting to the demand for "slow fashion" and customization, offering services beyond classic business suits, including shirts, pants, and ties.

site_title: Deloitte invests, hires to expand in S-E Asia
summary: Deloitte South-east Asia plans to invest in human resources and digital systems to prepare for future business opportunities in the region. The company recruited 62,000 new staff globally in fiscal 2015 and opened offices in Myanmar, Laos, and Cambodia. Despite regional economic uncertainties, Deloitte expects 9% revenue growth for fiscal year 2016, driven by healthy growth in financial advisory and risk consulting services. The company attributes growth to government investments and tax reforms, which will create business opportunities.

site_title: IE Singapore and Latin America's CAF sign MOU
summary: Singapore and the Development Bank of Latin America (CAF) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on October 16, 2015, to foster stronger ties between the two regions. The agreement covers areas such as infrastructure development, energy, and electronic government services, aiming to build capacity, exchange knowledge, and collaborate on development projects in Latin America. Despite Latin America's projected economic contraction this year, Singapore sees opportunities for investment, citing lower commodity prices and the potential for long-term sustainable economic growth.

site_title: American Apparel sees bright future after bankruptcy
summary: American Apparel, a fashion chain, has filed for bankruptcy in Delaware and projects a return to profit in 2018, its first since 2009, with a net profit of $23.7 million by 2020. The company aims to lower crushing interest costs and has assured suppliers and creditors that their contracts are secure. However, ongoing legal battles with founder Dov Charney remain a risk. The company will provide a budget to creditors' committee to hire attorneys and financial experts to test and challenge the bankruptcy plan.

site_title: CEFC International Q3 net soars to US$11.97m
summary: CEFC International posted a net profit of US$11.97 million for the third quarter, up from US$661,000 in the same period last year, driven by a 73% year-over-year revenue increase to US$162.3 million. The company attributed the growth to its partnership with CEFC China and the introduction of a derivatives trading business. As of September, the group had US$67.5 million in cash and cash equivalents, and its shares ended trading at S$0.295, down 0.5 Singapore cent.

site_title: United CEO suffers heart attack, shares drop even lower
summary: United Continental Holdings Inc's CEO Oscar Munoz suffered a heart attack, prompting a board meeting to gather information about his medical condition and prognosis. Munoz, 56, was taken to hospital on Thursday, and shares dropped 3.1% to a one-week low, down nearly 17% this year. The airline operates normally despite the incident, with Munoz's family respecting their privacy. The board is waiting to hear from doctors and Munoz's family about the severity of the heart attack before deciding on an interim CEO.

images.alt_text: United Continental Holdings Inc CEO Oscar Munoz is seen in an undated handout picture courtesy of United Airlines.

site_title: US university wins patent suit against Apple
summary: A US federal jury has awarded the University of Wisconsin-Madison's licensing arm, the Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation (WARF), $400 million in damages against Apple for infringing on a patent for improved chip efficiency. WARF claimed Apple used the technology in its phones and tablets, despite the university not traditionally engaging in patent litigation. This verdict could be one of the largest patent payouts ever to a university, highlighting the growing role of research institutions in patent disputes.

site_title: AB InBev-SABMiller deal: Rivals see local battles but no global war
summary: AB InBev's takeover of SABMiller, the world's second-largest brewer, is seen as the end phase of consolidation in the brewing industry. Despite being the global market leader, Anheuser-Busch InBev's strength is limited to local markets, where rival brewers such as Heineken and Carlsberg continue to compete. The merger is unlikely to lead to a global price war, and smaller players are expected to benefit from antitrust authorities' likely disposals of assets.

site_title: Mattel's revenue, profit miss estimates
summary: Mattel reported quarterly revenue and profit that missed analysts' estimates, with sales of Barbie dolls falling 4% on constant currency and 14% on a reported basis. The company attributed the decline to a strong dollar, which hurt sales in overseas markets. Net income fell to $223.8 million, and shares fell 10% in after-market trading. Mattel is in the middle of a turnaround plan, and CEO Christopher Sinclair said the results were in line with expectations, with plans to offset the Disney Princess revenue gap.

site_title: End of safe-harbour deal: S'pore's position
summary: The European Court of Justice (ECJ) has declared the EU-US safe-harbour agreement invalid, allowing individual EU countries to regulate data transfers. This decision affects personal data transfers from the EU to the US, and Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) must reassess its position on international data transfers. The ruling highlights the need for organisations in Singapore to ensure a comparable standard of protection for personal data when transferring it overseas, and raises concerns about the potential for foreign governments to access and use personal data.

site_title: Higher margins lift Qian Hu's Q3 profit
summary: Qian Hu's third-quarter earnings rose 17.7% to S$93,000, driven by higher margins in its fish exports and plastics segments. Revenue fell 12.8% to S$17.84 million, primarily due to eurozone uncertainties and a traditionally low season for ornamental fish exports. The group's ornamental-fish segment saw operating profit surge 21.8% to S$318,000, while its accessories segment saw a 26.7% drop in operating profit to S$311,000.

site_title: Feeling the pain from investment fees
summary: Mutual fund expenses continue to decrease, but experts say they should fall faster. The asset-weighted average expense ratio for all funds dropped 15% to 0.64% in 2015, down from five years earlier. Despite this, fees still eat into investors' returns. Industry fee revenue has grown by 78% over the last decade, while assets under management have more than doubled. Experts say cheaper funds are likely to provide better returns, and investors should prioritize low-cost index funds or actively managed funds with low expense ratios.

site_title: A whole new world of cooking
summary: TWG Tea's group executive chef David Thien has developed a 100-dish menu incorporating various tea-based recipes, including brining, infusing, pickling, and powdering. Chef Thien, who joined TWG Tea in January, has used 75 different teas to create the menu. The new menu showcases the versatility of tea in cooking, offering a fresh culinary experience for customers.

site_title: China economy may be bigger than thought
summary: China's third-quarter GDP report is set to be released, sparking concerns over the accuracy of its economic data. Mark Mobius, chairman of Franklin Templeton Investments, believes China's economy may be growing at least 7%, despite skepticism over official statistics. Mobius attributes the discrepancy to China's shift from a manufacturing to a service economy, with many sectors not being counted in the official numbers. This raises pressure on policymakers, who may need to adjust their strategies to address slowing growth.

site_title: S'pore-based investors pump S$3.8b into real estate abroad in Q3
summary: Singapore-based investors invested at least S$3.8 billion in overseas real estate markets in Q3, with significant investments in Australia and the UK. In Singapore, private investment in office space rose to S$828 million in Q3, up from S$465 million in Q2. Most investors are seeking higher returns and diversification opportunities abroad. Investment sales originating from the Government Land Sales programme contracted to S$490 million in Q3, but are expected to boost by S$3.5 billion due to the pending sale of Asia Square Tower 1.

site_title: On the road to Turkey
summary: A national qualifying finals for Singapore's World Amateur Golfers Championship (WAGC) 2015 team will be held on October 20 at Tanah Merah Country Club's Garden Course. Over 200 golfers participated in the qualifying rounds, with around 80 qualifying to participate in the finals. One golfer from each of the five handicap categories will represent Singapore in the WAGC in Turkey next month, with the team's selection to be finalized after the finals.

site_title: Arduous budget ahead for Najib
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak faces an arduous task in crafting a budget that will satisfy the common man amid rising costs, a devalued ringgit, and weak business and consumer sentiment. The opposition has threatened to derail the budget as a means to force Najib's resignation, but the ruling Barisan Nasional holds a robust majority in Parliament. Najib must balance the need to present a budget that mollifies households affected by double-digit cost increases with the need to trim the fiscal deficit and prioritize development expenditure.

images.alt_text: TOUGHER RIDE: Recent petrol and toll hikes in Malaysia have worsened the strain on many retirees, wage earners and the urban poor - who are struggling to keep afloat and hoping for some relief from next Friday's budget.

site_title: Four artists awarded Cultural Medallion
summary: Four Singaporean artists, playwright Haresh Sharma, musician Margaret Leng Tan, painter Chua Mia Tee, and literary advocate Lin Gao, were awarded the 2015 Cultural Medallion for their groundbreaking works. The recognition acknowledges their perseverance in the face of obstacles, including funding revocations and criticism. The medallion winners will receive grants of S$80,000 to fund their original works, while seven younger artists were recognized in the Young Artist Award category. The awards aim to promote and celebrate artistic excellence in Singapore.

site_title: Hidden benefits for servers and customers
summary: Danny Meyer's Union Square Hospitality Group will eliminate tipping at its establishments, potentially bringing American restaurant culture closer to the global standard. However, economists argue that the end of tipping could lead to increased taxes and minimum wage laws taking a bigger bite out of employment. Tipping also provides a personal connection between customers and servers, which may not be accounted for in standard economic theory. Some experts suggest that experimenting with no-tip service could be a more effective solution to the issue.

site_title: Economic uncertainty hits super luxury car sector
summary: The super luxury car sector is experiencing economic uncertainty, with some dealers unable to sell even one unit for a month. Ferrari is the only brand in the high-end segment that has managed to register sales, with 37 units sold in the first nine months of the year. In contrast, Rolls-Royce, Lamborghini, McLaren, and Aston Martin have seen significant declines in sales, with some dealers selling no cars in a month. Economic uncertainty, fueled by stock market turmoil and low oil prices, has heightened sentiment, with sales managers citing the need for a 50% cash downpayment and a five-year loan period.

site_title: BT scribes bag top awards for financial journalism
summary: Singaporean journalists Cai Haoxiang and Anita Gabriel won top awards for financial journalism at the SIAS Investors' Choice Awards. Cai Haoxiang, who runs the Young Investors' Forum section, received the Financial Journalist of the Year award, while Anita Gabriel won Financial Story of the Year for her story on a market-disrupting glitch at a data centre. The awards recognize their efforts in providing clarity and insight to readers on financial matters.

site_title: Silicon Valley IPO boom easing
summary: The Silicon Valley IPO boom is easing, with 42% of tech companies this year pricing their shares at a valuation below or nearly the same as their private market value, down from 24% in 2014. Late-stage investors are seeing smaller returns, with some expecting returns similar to the S&P 500 over the past year. The shift is attributed to a surge in funding from late-stage investors allowing tech startups to stay private longer, making it harder to achieve high IPO valuations.

site_title: Wonder wagon
summary: The Audi RS6 Avant 4.0 TFSI quattro tiptronic is a high-performance estate car disguised as a family model. With a powerful turbocharged V8 engine and all-wheel-drive, it delivers instant response and agility, reaching 0-100 km/h in under four seconds. The car features a sporty yet practical design, customizable settings, and advanced technology such as adaptive air suspension and Dynamic Ride Control. Despite its size, the RS6 Avant boasts a comfortable ride and luxurious interior, making it a unique and desirable vehicle.

images.alt_text: QUICK MOVER: Despite being five metres in length (4,979 mm to be exact), the generously sized RS6 Avant, which weighs in at a hefty 1,950 kg, has instantaneous response. Zero to 100 kmh comes in at under four seconds.

QUICK MOVER: Despite being five metres in length (4,979 mm to be exact), the generously sized RS6 Avant, which weighs in at a hefty 1,950 kg, has instantaneous response. Zero to 100 kmh comes in at under four seconds.
TEUTONIC STYLING: The cabin of the Audi RS6 remains a testimony to German design and craftsmanship, with a logical layout and beautiful materials.

site_title: Smart technologies bring new risks
summary: Singapore is set to become the world's first Smart Nation, with government initiatives leveraging technology to improve lives and build stronger communities. However, this shift also brings new risks, including cyber, privacy, and security threats from autonomous vehicles, drones, and 3D printing. Insurers, such as AIG, are adapting to these emerging technologies, identifying potential insurance risks and developing solutions to mitigate them. Autonomous vehicles are expected to improve road safety, but liability and cyber risks remain concerns. Drones pose third-party liability and privacy risks, while 3D printing raises issues with intellectual property and supply chain responsibility.

site_title: From track to road
summary: The Lexus GS F is a high-performance sedan that offers a smooth drive to and from the track. Designed by its chief engineer, Yukihiko Yaguchi, to appeal to connoisseurs and novice drivers alike, it incorporates sound, steering response, and acceleration. The GS F promises a practical and comfortable driving experience, making it one of the few high-performance models that can handle both track days and daily commutes.

site_title: Too smart not to share
summary: The sharing economy, including companies like Uber, AirBnB, and iCarsClub, has revolutionized the way people monetize their unused time, skills, and assets, offering consumers cheaper alternatives to traditional options. However, it also raises concerns over safety, security, and risks, with reported incidents of sexual assaults and misuse of listings. As the sharing economy continues to grow, its potential to optimize society's resources and change relationships between people must be weighed against these challenges.

site_title: Ups and downs for hedge funds
summary: Two prominent macro hedge funds, Bain Capital Absolute Return Capital and Fortress Investment Group's flagship macro fund, have shut down after suffering double-digit losses. Despite the closures, some lesser-known macro-focused hedge funds have made double-digit gains for investors this year. Market turmoil, including the Swiss central bank's unexpected move to lift its cap on the Swiss franc and the Chinese central bank's decision to devalue its currency, has contributed to the losses. However, some financial advisers recommend allocating more money to macro hedge funds, citing their outperformance in the broader industry.

site_title: NODX makes unexpected turnaround in Sept
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) unexpectedly rose 0.3% year-over-year in September, alleviating fears of a technical recession. The uptick may be unsustainable, however, as exports remain vulnerable to external demand, which remains weak. Economists warn that the surprise pickup may not keep up, citing the contraction in exports to key markets like China, the US, and the European Union.

images.alt_text: A surprise turnaround in non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in the closing month of the third quarter should dilute the return of fears of a technical recession when the final estimates for the July-to-September gross domestic product (GDP) are made.

site_title: UEFA wants fast decision in the case of Platini
summary: UEFA is urging for a swift decision in Michel Platini's case, allowing the planned February Fifa presidential election to proceed. However, UEFA general secretary Gianni Infantino stated there have been differing opinions among the 54 member associations, leaving room for another European candidate to enter the race.

site_title: Pain could be coming to Singapore's corporate bond market: S&P
summary: Standard & Poor's warns that Singapore's dollar bond market may face pain over the next 12-18 months due to the potential restructuring of Indonesian company PT Trikomsel Oke Tbk's bonds. The company's assets are mostly in Indonesia, adding complexity to debt restructuring, and a swift restructuring could spur other companies to propose similar options. However, a proposal implying substantial loss of value could limit access to the market, leading to rising funding costs and investors becoming more selective.

site_title: Living heritage
summary: A boutique hotel, LTK Residences, has been opened in Penang, Malaysia, in a cluster of five turn-of-the-century shophouses. The hotel, designed by Ministry of Design, features five suites with lush gardens and private balconies, blending traditional and contemporary elements. The project aimed to preserve the heritage of the shophouses while providing modern amenities. Despite challenges with local construction quality and conservation committee approval, the project was completed in about two years. Room rates start at RM850++ (S$280) per night, offering guests a unique experience amidst the historic buildings.

site_title: Green Build Technology to dispose of packaging business
summary: Green Build Technology has entered a conditional sale and purchase agreement to sell its packaging business to Youcan Foods (Hangzhou) Co Ltd for 38.95 million yuan. The business, which was engaged in manufacturing and selling flexible packaging products since 2007, will be disposed of as the company focuses on its green technology business. The packaging business had seen steadily decreasing profits, contributing to the decision.

site_title: Rio Tinto boosts iron ore output
summary: Rio Tinto reported a 12% increase in iron ore production to 86.1 million tonnes and a 17% jump in shipments to 91.3 million tonnes for the three months to September. This drew down on stockpiles, with sales exceeding production by 4.2 million tonnes. The company expects 2015 shipments to remain unchanged at 340 million tonnes. Despite a slight drop in shares, analysts find the move encouraging, as it suggests Rio can manage inventory levels without affecting China's inventory.

site_title: High-frequency traders call for transparency in Treasuries
summary: High-frequency traders in the US$12.9 trillion Treasuries market are calling for greater transparency, citing a lack of data on market transactions and the potential for exacerbating volatility. The market's recent swing on October 15, 2014, highlighted the issue, with officials from the Federal Reserve to the Treasury Department acknowledging the need for more information. Traders argue that increased transparency would provide a level playing field and improve market efficiency, while regulators see it as essential for better monitoring of market activity and potential risks.

site_title: Split SGX's roles, mandate internal auditors: SIAS
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) president, David Gerald, recommends separating the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) commercial and regulatory functions, mandating full-time internal auditors, and requiring new listings to have compliance advisers. This would increase investor protection and confidence in the main board, which has seen more corporate scandals. SGX may also need to stop wearing multiple hats as a market regulator and commercial business.

site_title: StanChart S'pore announces more changes at the top
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore has announced new heads for its retail banking, commercial banking, and transaction banking divisions. Andrew Chia will lead retail banking, Vanessa Leung will head commercial banking, and Goh Beng Kim will oversee transaction banking. The appointments are part of the bank's efforts to streamline its organization and improve client service. The changes come as the bank aims to cut costs and reposition itself for growth, with up to 25% of senior staff set to be cut globally and locally.

site_title: Stable China, Wall Street help STI regain 3,000 mark
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) regained the 3,000 mark, closing at 3,030.61, driven by a 1.06% gain over the week. The index moved ahead of Wall Street, with 70-75% of trading volume coming from its components. The main focus is on big players, with banks and key stocks like Singtel, Keppel, and Noble Group leading the play. Corporate announcements have had limited impact, and brokers are gearing up for the reporting season, with RHB predicting a 4.5% drop in net profit for the third quarter.

site_title: Quakes near US oil hub raise concerns over storage security
summary: A 4.5-magnitude earthquake struck central Oklahoma, near the Cushing Hub, a major crude oil storage complex, on Saturday. The quake raised concerns about the security of the facility, which is a key part of the US oil pipeline network. The Cushing Hub is among the largest oil storage facilities in the world, with an estimated 8,000 people living nearby. The injection of wastewater has made Oklahoma the second most seismically active state, according to experts. The incident highlights the risks associated with oil storage and injection activities.

site_title: Global slowdown in real danger of persisting: economists
summary: The global economic slowdown shows a clear risk of persisting into next year, with 87% of economists polled by Reuters predicting a prolonged period of disinflation. Despite easy monetary policy, economies such as the US, eurozone, and Britain are exposed to waning global demand, and emerging markets face challenges due to a decline in China's growth. Global growth is forecast to be 3.1% this year and 3.4% next, with inflation outlooks trimmed across the board. The US economy is expected to stall, while Scandinavian economies are seen performing better.

site_title: Ballmer says he has amassed a 4% stake in Twitter
summary: Former Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer has acquired a 4% stake in Twitter, expressing his support for the company's recent efforts to improve its focus under new CEO Jack Dorsey.

site_title: SOS to rescue legendary US liner from scrap heap
summary: The SS United States, a legendary US ocean liner, is in danger of being scrapped due to lack of funding. Moored in a Philadelphia dock, the 990-foot vessel, which holds the record for crossing the Atlantic in 3 days, 10 hours, and 40 minutes, is in dire need of conservation efforts. The non-profit SS United States Conservancy is seeking donations and investors to save the ship, which could be repurposed as a hotel, floating apartments, or a museum. The organization must pay $60,000 per month to keep the ship afloat, with a deadline of the end of the month to avoid being sent to the scrap yard.

site_title: Factory output falls in latest sign of weak growth
summary: US factory output fell 0.1% in September, marking a second consecutive decline, due to bloated inventories and weak overseas demand. This follows a revised 0.4% decrease in August. The decline is attributed to high inventories and a strong dollar, which affects manufacturers' competitiveness. Total industrial production also dropped 0.2%. The drop is a sign of weak growth in the US economy.

images.alt_text: SILVER LINING: The output of motor vehicles and parts increased 0.2 per cent. Vehicle demand remains a mainstay for factories.

site_title: Emerging nations trimming US$5t debt
summary: Emerging nations are trimming their US$5 trillion debt by paying back US$38 billion of dollar-denominated bonds and loans, marking the first reduction in net issuance in seven years. This shift may cut short a rally in currencies from Brazil to Malaysia, as economic growth slows and lenders demand higher yields. Analysts expect the depreciation trend to resume as dollar debt repayments accelerate, with most emerging-market currencies forecast to weaken against the dollar over the next 12 months.

site_title: Strike averted at Alcoa's Intalco smelter as union accepts deal
summary: Workers at Alcoa's Intalco Works aluminium smelter in Washington voted to accept the company's final contract offer, averting a strike. The contract, which expires in 2017, contains no wage increases despite low aluminium prices. The agreement comes after a similar dispute at Century Aluminium's smelter in Kentucky, where workers were locked out due to weak prices caused by Chinese exports. The deal brings stability to Alcoa, which plans to split into two separate businesses next year, with the smelter belonging to an upstream company.

site_title: Staying power
summary: Singapore hotel restaurants are innovating with live stations and open kitchen concepts to cater to discerning diners. The InterContinental Singapore's Ash & Elm features three open stations, allowing guests to interact with chefs and watch food preparation. In contrast, The Line Shangri-La Hotel Singapore offers a live theatrical kitchen concept, while Colony The Ritz-Carlton, Millenia Singapore boasts eight live stations serving a variety of local and international cuisine. These innovative approaches aim to provide guests with unique dining experiences and adapt to changing preferences.

site_title: More BTO flats likely next year: minister
summary: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong announced plans to increase the supply of new Housing Board flats next year to meet higher demand due to recent policy changes, including higher income ceilings and enhanced housing grants. Wong stated that the government will continue to taper the housing program, but may need to make temporary adjustments. The expected supply of new flats is likely to be under 20,000, and cooling measures in the property market will remain in place.

images.alt_text: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong is lead on a tour of the Waterway Terraces in Punggol.

site_title: Making good decisions for a bad heart
summary: A study published in the Circulation journal found that patients with severely narrowed heart arteries and impaired left ventricle function, who refused open-heart surgery, experienced similar mortality rates as those who underwent the procedure. However, alternative minimally invasive techniques such as angioplasty and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) were successfully performed, resulting in improved heart function and reduced risk of death. The study highlights the importance of making informed decisions and seeking expert care for patients with severe heart disease.

images.alt_text: MINIMALLY INVASIVE: Image of a blocked section of the heart artery before PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention). Blood flow is restored using balloon catheters or stents to open up the blocked artery.

site_title: China's private education booms
summary: China's private education sector is booming, with parents opting for a more open and bilingual education environment to increase their children's chances of getting into foreign universities and securing better jobs. The country's public education system is highly competitive, with students competing for limited spots at top universities, leading many to seek alternative options. Private schools and online tutoring services are growing in popularity, with figures showing over 274,000 Chinese students studying abroad and a projected 14% annual growth in international schools.

site_title: Fresh faces
summary: Watches and Wonders luxury show in Hong Kong unveiled key all-new pieces, including Vacheron Constantin's Reference 57260, a pocket watch with 57 complications, and Jaeger-LeCoultre's Geophysic True Second, a vintage-style watch with a highly sophisticated movement. Other brands such as IWC, A Lange & Sohne, and Roger Dubuis showcased new timepieces, including hand-wound movements and limited-edition pieces. Cartier added two Cartier classics to its Cle De Cartier collection, while Piaget introduced its first complication timepiece for women, the Limelight Stella. The show also featured high-jewellery watches from brands like Van Cleef & Arpels and Richard Mille.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported Q3 2015 results meeting expectations but slightly above management's forecast. The company raised its occupancy rate to 95.1% due to increased workspace occupation, but not data center space. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "buy" rating and S$1.24 fair value estimate, citing long-term lease expiries and growth potential. In contrast, Vard Holdings issued a profit warning due to cost overruns in building LPG carriers, and DBS Group Research downgraded Vard to "fully valued". Meanwhile, Singapore Post acquired TradeGlobal for US$168.6 million, expanding its e-commerce portfolio.

site_title: US industrial output falls for second straight month
summary: US industrial production fell 0.2% in September for the second straight month, according to the Federal Reserve. The decline was driven by weakened oil and gas drilling, eroding demand for US manufactured goods. The sector's annual rate of growth in the third quarter was 1.8%. The weak industrial production report adds to concerns about a slowdown in growth, with third-quarter estimates below a 1.5% rate, and diminishes expectations of an interest rate hike from the Fed this year.

site_title: Samsung Elec, Thomson Reuters in tie-up for enterprise customers
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and Thomson Reuters Corp announced a collaboration to develop products and services for enterprise customers. The first phase of the tie-up will provide compatible Samsung devices with content and software applications developed by Thomson Reuters for the legal and financial sectors. No financial terms were disclosed. The companies will look to build on their capabilities in mobile security, electronic devices, and information technology.

site_title: GE earnings fall as oil and gas profits sink
summary: General Electric reported a 29.1% drop in third-quarter earnings to US$2.5 billion, driven by declining oil and gas income. Revenues declined 1.3% to US$31.7 billion, with oil and gas sales falling 15.9%. Despite this, industrial businesses saw a 4.5% increase in operating earnings. GE's CEO, Jeff Immelt, stated the company is transforming into a "world's premier Digital Industrial company" amid asset sales of over US$126 billion.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd order books for market listing fully covered: source
summary: Hapag-Lloyd's planned stock market flotation on October 30 has received bids for all shares on offer, with the order book fully covered including an overallotment option. This is a significant signal for potential investors, indicating a smooth IPO. The company now expects to raise approximately $300 million from the sale of shares to investors.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher, buoyed by GE earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by General Electric's forecast-beating earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 31.93 points to 17,173.68, while the S&P 500 increased 5.15 points to 2,023.86. GE shares jumped 2.7% after the company reported $2.51 billion in profit but missed on revenues, declining 1.3%. The Nasdaq Composite Index remained flat at 4,870.12.

site_title: Global equity rally gains momentum
summary: Global equity markets surged on Friday, driven by weak economic data from China, the US, and Europe, which delayed expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Asian markets rose, with Shanghai finishing 1.60% higher, as investors bet on Chinese stimulus measures to counter a slowdown in the Asian powerhouse economy. The rally also benefited from expectations of further monetary easing by the Bank of Japan. The global rally has been fueled by the possibility of a Fed rate hike being delayed until the new year, boosting risk appetite and sending stocks surging.

site_title: Higher margins lift Qian Hu Q3 earnings
summary: Qian Hu's third-quarter earnings rose 17.7% to S$93,000, driven by higher margins in fish exports and stable plastics prices. Revenue fell 12.8% to S$17.84 million due to "prolonged uncertainties" in the eurozone and traditionally low season for ornamental fish exports. Earnings per share increased slightly to 0.08 Singapore cent, while net asset value per share dropped to 44.47 cents. Qian Hu shares ended at S$0.165, down S$0.003.

site_title: Nestle India jumps as tests show lead in Maggi within limits
summary: Nestle India's shares rose 5.6% to 6,555 rupees after laboratory tests showed lead in Maggi noodles were within approved limits, allowing the product's resumption. The company had faced a recall and ban in multiple states following tests showing unsafe amounts of lead. The Bombay High Court overturned the ban, and the noodles were found safe in 90 samples. Sales will resume after newly manufactured products are cleared by three laboratories. The resumption is a positive for the company, which had suffered its first quarterly loss in 15 years due to the recall.

site_title: Malaysia's Tenaga submits conditional offer to buy 1MDB's power unit
summary: Malaysia's national power firm Tenaga Nasional Bhd submitted a conditional offer to buy 1MDB's power unit Edra Global Energy, amid efforts to pare back the state fund's US$11 billion debt. The move comes amid multiple investigations into 1MDB's financial mismanagement and graft allegations, which have sparked a political crisis for Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Fitch says next few months key to decision on Brazil rating
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Brazil's investment grade rating to BBB-minus with a negative outlook. A senior analyst, Shelly Shetty, stated that the next few months will be crucial in assessing Brazil's political environment. An escalation of the political crisis would negatively impact the rating. Fitch plans to reassess Brazil's rating in the coming months, as the agency believes the current downgrade is premature. The agency's decision will be influenced by the country's political stability and potential economic reforms.

site_title: Glencore said to seek improved credit rating on wider debt plan
summary: Glencore, a commodity trader and miner, is seeking a higher credit rating by selling assets and reducing its debt load. The company aims to cut its $30 billion debt by a third and has already announced plans to sell two copper mines in Australia and Chile. Glencore's CEO, Ivan Glasenberg, believes that asset sales and debt-reduction measures may lead to a one-notch upgrade of its credit rating from Standard & Poor's, from BBB to BBB+. The company's credit rating target was reported earlier, and Moody's Investors Service currently has a Baa2 rating on Glencore.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore-based investors poured S$3.8 billion into overseas real estate in Q3 despite a weaker global economy. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam warned that uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike is becoming too costly for markets. The supply of new Housing Board flats may increase to meet higher demand, while Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 0.3% in September. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed higher, following a stable China and Wall Street market trend.

site_title: Twitter to pay Kordestani annual base salary of US$50,000
summary: Twitter has appointed Omid Kordestani as its new Executive Chairman, paying him an annual base salary of $50,000. Kordestani, a former Google executive, joins the company as part of its turnaround efforts under CEO Jack Dorsey. The move aims to alleviate concerns about Dorsey's dual role as Square's head. Kordestani's appointment follows Square's filing for an initial public offering, a long-anticipated move.

site_title: Japan Post units said to be poised for high-end pricing in IPO
summary: Japan's government may raise the initial public offering price for Japan Post Bank Co and Japan Post Insurance Co to the top end of their marketed price ranges due to strong investor demand. The companies are being sold as part of a three-pronged IPO that could raise 1.44 trillion yen, with shares of the bank and insurer priced at 1,250-1,450 yen and 1,900-2,200 yen, respectively. The holding company will be priced a week later, on Oct 26.

site_title: SinoCloud to raise S$4.82m through private placement
summary: SinoCloud Group, a Catalist-listed firm, is undertaking a private placement to raise S$4.82 million. The placement involves issuing 1.38 billion new shares at 0.35 Singapore cent each to three individuals and Alternus Capital Holdings. The shares represent about 12.6% of the enlarged issued share capital and are a 75% premium to the firm's shares traded on October 15. The funds will be used for investments in data centre projects and working capital.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe and the US declined, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained an employee in a graft case involving Trafigura.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.57 points to 1,716.82 on Friday, with 487 gainers outnumbering 345 losers. The index saw a volume of 2.58 billion lots worth RM2.23 billion.

site_title: BP, China's CNPC to unveil oil alliance: sources
summary: BP Plc and China's CNPC will unveil a strategic alliance to develop oil resources in Iraq and other regions, focusing on the giant Rumaila oilfield, the world's second-largest oilfield. The deal aims to bolster cooperation between the two companies in Iraq and expand into new joint ventures globally. No clear production or investment targets are expected to be included in the agreement. This partnership is part of Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to London, marking a significant move by state-owned CNPC as Asia's largest oil producer.

site_title: BTO flat supply might go up to cope with higher demand
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) may increase new flat supply to meet higher demand following recent policy changes. National Development Minister Lawrence Wong has asked the HDB to review the supply of new flats. This move aims to address the rising demand for housing.

site_title: Europe: Stocks log early gains
summary: Europe's major stock markets advanced on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.45% to 6,367.10 points. The Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also saw gains, with the DAX 30 up 0.64% to 10,128.81 points and the CAC 40 winning 0.58% to 4,702.56 points. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks are expected to be a focus.

site_title: Schneider to invest 65m euros into its Singapore ops (Amended)
summary: Schneider Electric is investing 65 million euros (S$102 million) in its Singapore operations over the next five years, expanding its presence in the country. The company, which supplies most of Singapore's data centers, aims to enhance its green technologies and automation services. This investment will support Schneider's growth in the region and solidify its position as a global specialist in energy management and automation.

site_title: Early closure between Bugis, Tanah Merah stations on East-West Line from Nov 15
summary: SMRT will implement early closure between Bugis and Tanah Merah stations on the East-West Line from Nov 15, allowing staff to replace 25% more sleepers nightly. The closure will be in three phases, affecting stations between Bugis and Tanah Merah until end 2015, then Joo Koon and Jurong East in early 2016, and finally Jurong East and Outram Park by early 2017. This move aims to minimize inconvenience to commuters and allow for more frequent sleeper replacements.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher in line with stable China, Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.06% to 3,030.61, mirroring Wall Street's gains, driven by China and Hong Kong's rebound on government stimulus hopes. The index's components accounted for 70-75% of trading volume, with institutional investors dominating the market. The rally follows a 5-day streak, with retail participation dwindling over the past few years, and institutions running sophisticated programs driving the market.

site_title: 'IS hacker' accused of stealing US data arrested in Malaysia
summary: Malaysian police arrested Kosovo citizen Ardit Ferizi, known as "Th3Dir3ctorY," on September 15 for allegedly stealing data from over 1,000 US military and government personnel and providing it to the Islamic State group. The US Department of Justice is seeking his extradition and charges him with up to 35 years in jail. Ferizi was studying computer science in Malaysia last year, and the arrest marks the first time a hacker has been linked to the group.

site_title: Alibaba offers to buy all of video streaming company Youku Tudou
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has offered to buy all outstanding shares of Chinese video streaming company Youku Tudou Inc for US$26.60 per American Depositary Share, representing a 30% premium to its closing price on Thursday. Alibaba currently owns 18.3% of Youku Tudou. The all-cash offer is aimed at acquiring the remaining shares, marking a significant move by the Chinese e-commerce giant into the video streaming market.

site_title: Nestle cuts full-year outlook after sales miss
summary: Nestle, the world's largest packaged food company, lowered its full-year outlook after missing sales forecasts. The company's sales dropped 2.1% to 64.9 billion Swiss francs (US$68 billion) in the nine months through September, below analysts' average forecast of 65.9 billion. The Maggi noodle recall in India and undercalculated US Skin Health rebates weighed on profits. Organic growth slowed to 4.2% from 4.5% in the first half, falling short of the 5-6% target.

site_title: Indonesia launches biggest operation ever to combat fires
summary: Indonesia launched its largest operation to combat fires, deploying 32 planes and thousands of troops to tackle widespread blazes in haze covering Southeast Asia. The operation aims to improve air quality, close schools, and prevent further damage. The fires, started by illegal land clearances, are exacerbated by an El Nino weather system, with over 750 hotspots detected on Sumatra. International help, including donations of flame retardant, has been accepted, with Japan joining the effort. Despite progress, dry conditions continue to hinder efforts, with new fires still emerging.

site_title: China economy fears overdone, inevitable bumps on reform road: HSBC boss
summary: HSBC Chief Executive Stuart Gulliver said China's economy fears are overplayed, and a "hard landing" is unlikely. Despite recent market volatility, Gulliver expects China's economy to grow by 7% this year and outpace global growth. China's reforms, including allowing the yuan to move more freely, are part of its transition to a private sector-driven economy, with HSBC anticipating steady and measured easing of controls. Gulliver views China's bumps on the reform road as inevitable, but notes the long-term trends will prevail.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.08% on Friday, extending gains from the previous day. The Nikkei 225 index advanced 194.90 points to 18,291.80, while the Topix index rose 1.01% to 1,505.84. The rally was driven by investors' confidence that the US Federal Reserve will delay a rate hike and a weaker yen boosting exporters.

site_title: Hong Kong and Shanghai rise on Fed hopes, China stimulus talk
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai shares rose on Friday as investors anticipated the Federal Reserve's potential delay of a US interest rate hike and China's economic stimulus measures. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong increased 0.78% and Shanghai's benchmark composite index rose 1.60%. The week saw a 2.6% gain in Hong Kong and a 6.54% increase in Shanghai.

site_title: Standard Chartered makes senior management changes in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered has made senior management changes in Singapore, appointing Andrew Chia as head of retail banking, Vanessa Leung as head of commercial banking, and Goh Beng Kim as head of transaction banking. All three appointments will take effect by November 1.

site_title: IE Singapore, Latin America's CAF sign MOU
summary: Singapore and Latin America's CAF Development Bank of Latin America signed a memorandum of understanding to enhance institutional ties and collaboration on economically sustainable development projects in Latin America. The agreement, signed at the Latin Asia Business Forum, aims to facilitate knowledge exchange and capacity building between the two parties. The partnership also includes discussions on current global economic sentiment, interest rates, and the role of education in development, moderated by Americas Society and Council of Americas president and CEO Susan Segal.

site_title: Seoul: Shares retreat as automakers fall; won closes steady
summary: South Korean shares retreated from two-month highs on Friday, pressured by losses in automakers amid concerns about a rising local currency eroding export earnings. The KOSPI index closed down 0.2% at 2,030.14 points, despite a weekly gain of 0.5%. Hyundai Motor and Kia Motor saw significant losses, with the won closing at 1,129.1 per dollar, up 2.6% for the week, its biggest weekly gain since 2011.

site_title: Fontana US$24.7m egg painting leads Sotheby's London sales
summary: Lucio Fontana's 1963 egg-shaped canvas, "Concetto Spaziale, La Fine di Dio (The End of God)," sold for £15.9 million (US$24.7 million) at Sotheby's London, setting an auction record for the artist. The sale, part of a two-evening auction, totaled £76.7 million, a 10% increase from last year. The event coincided with the Frieze Art Fair and drew over 10,000 attendees, marking a strong start to the art market's recovery from the global investor downturn.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks climb on Fed hopes at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.07% on Friday, driven by growing confidence the Federal Reserve will hold off interest rate hikes until next year. The benchmark Hang Seng Index climbed to 23,133.59, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.61% and 0.66%, respectively, as investors awaited further Chinese economic stimulus measures.

site_title: China set to disappoint with Q3 growth: AFP poll
summary: China's economy likely grew at its slowest pace since the global financial crisis in the third quarter, with a median forecast of 6.8% annual growth. This is below the government's target and has raised concerns about a "hard landing." The slow growth has led to investor fears, a stock market rout, and a sharp decline in commodity prices. Analysts expect China to further boost fiscal spending and ease monetary policy to prevent a hard landing, but Premier Li Keqiang's forecast of 7.0% growth for 2015 may be difficult to meet.

site_title: Maersk to buy container terminals for US$1 bln from Perez y Cia
summary: APM Terminals, part of Maersk, has agreed to buy the remaining 39% of Grup Maritim TCB, a company operating 11 container ports, for approximately US$1 billion. The deal makes Maersk the sole controlling shareholder of the company. The transaction's enterprise value is US$1 billion, following a previous agreement on September 8 where Maersk bought 61% of Grup Maritim TCB from Perez y Cia.

site_title: US dollar strengthens in Asian trade
summary: The US dollar strengthened against most Asian currencies on Friday, with the yen rising to 119.12 from 118.88 yen, as investors await fresh US data that could lead to a rate hike. Emerging currencies, including Indonesia's rupiah and Malaysia's ringgit, fell more than one percent against the dollar. Analysts believe the release of US data on industrial production and consumer sentiment could increase the prospects of a first US rate rise since 2006, supporting the dollar's strength.

site_title: SGX grants Raffles Education waiver for proposed acquisition
summary: SGX grants Raffles Education waiver for proposed acquisition of Educomp-Raffles Higher Education Limited, allowing the company to proceed without shareholder approval. Raffles Education currently holds 58.18% equity interest in ERHEL, with the remaining 41.82% to be acquired from Educomp Asia Pacific Pte Ltd and Educomp Professional Education Limited. This move comes as Raffles Education's subsidiaries plan to acquire the remaining stake in ERHEL.

site_title: Japan ruling lawmaker invites China's Xi to Tokyo
summary: Japan has invited Chinese President Xi Jinping to visit Tokyo next year, a move aimed at improving soured ties between the two countries. This comes after a senior ruling lawmaker, Natsuo Yamaguchi, met with Xi in Beijing and handed over a letter from Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The visit, which has not been officially confirmed, is seen as a step towards improving bilateral relations, which have been strained since Japan's nationalization of disputed islands in the East China Sea in 2012. Japan hopes to build stable relations based on common strategic interests.

images.alt_text: Japan on Friday said it wished to improve its soured ties with Beijing, a day after a senior ruling lawmaker invited Chinese President Xi Jinping to visit Tokyo next year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.31 points to 1,718.560 on Friday, driven by a 216-60 gain-to-lose ratio. Volume reached 172.5 million lots worth RM62.9 million. The market's uptrend is attributed to gains in various sectors.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat; TSMC drags after Q3 earnings
summary: Taiwan's stocks traded flat on Friday, with TSMC declining after its Q3 earnings fell and the company cut 2015 full-year capital expenditure. The main TAIEX index remained nearly unchanged at 8,598.09, while the electronics subindex fell 0.3%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.267 per US dollar. TSMC's decline outweighed gains in the financials subindex, which rose 0.6%.

site_title: Shell declares force majeure on base chemical products from Singapore plant
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has declared force majeure on base chemical products from its Singapore plant due to an operational upset at its ethylene cracker complex, resulting in flaring. No injuries were reported, and authorities were notified. The force majeure was declared on Wednesday, affecting over 900,000 tonnes of ethylene production per year. Shell is working to resume normal operations and supply as soon as possible to minimize the impact on customers.

site_title: Australia: Shares end 0.7 per cent higher
summary: Australian shares ended 0.7% higher on Friday, despite a seven-week high during the day, due to buying in banks after a recent sell-off. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,268.2, while New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index increased 0.77%. Despite the gains, the Australian index ended the week 0.2% lower.

site_title: Uncertainty over Fed rate hike becoming too costly for markets: Tharman
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam says uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike is becoming too costly for markets. He notes that the benefits of near-zero interest rates for economic growth are outweighed by the costs. Tharman emphasizes that countries want the Fed to move gradually and normalize rates to reduce uncertainty, affecting business sentiment and market volatility. He calls for the Fed to raise interest rates sooner rather than later, citing a shift in the mood of emerging-market central bank governors and other countries.

site_title: New Zealand inflation subdued, no bar to rate cut
summary: New Zealand's inflation cooled slightly in the third quarter, rising 0.3% and taking the annual rate to 0.4%, below the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's target band of 1-3%. Non-tradable CPI, including utilities and personal services, was flat, its smallest movement in 14 years. This benign outcome may give the central bank room to cut interest rates if needed, with some analysts predicting a rate cut at the RBNZ's meeting on October 29.

site_title: CEFC posts Q3 profit of US$11.97m
summary: CEFC International posted a Q3 profit of US$11.97 million, a significant increase from US$661,000 a year ago. Revenue rose 73% year-on-year to US$162.3 million due to higher trading volume and a new derivatives trading business. Executive chairman Zang Jian Jun attributed the growth to building fundamentals and introducing strategic actions to preserve competitiveness. The company remains committed to exploring opportunities and investing in midstream and downstream petroleum assets to enhance flexibility for traders.

site_title: Indonesia sees Q3 GDP growth at 4.85%
summary: Indonesia's Q3 GDP growth is expected to reach 4.85%, according to Bank Indonesia Governor Agus Martowardojo. This marks an improvement from the 4.67% growth in the second quarter, which was the lowest rate in six years. Inflation, which earlier reached over 7%, is expected to be below 4% by year-end, meeting the central bank's target of 3-5%. The decision comes as the central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia Governor Agus Martowardojo said on Friday that the central bank expects the country's annual growth rate in the third quarter to be 4.85 per cent.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as Fed rate rise seen delayed
summary: Asia's stock markets rallied on Friday as investors expected the Federal Reserve to delay interest rate hikes due to a slowdown in global economic growth. The likelihood of a rate hike being pushed to the new year increased speculation that China will introduce further economic stimulus measures, boosting Asian markets. The dollar also rose against most currencies, while the euro fell after a European Central Bank board member suggested the ECB may widen its stimulus program.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.58% higher on Friday
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.58% higher on Friday, rising 17.52 points to 3,032.66. This follows solid gains on Wall Street and speculation that the Federal Reserve will delay raising interest rates until 2016. As of 9am, 57.6 million shares worth S$87.3 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 108 to 26. Investors await China's latest economic growth data, scheduled for release on Monday.

site_title: South Korean manufacturing wilts in inventory overhang
summary: South Korean manufacturers' inventory overhang has eased slightly, with the ratio of inventories to shipments decreasing to 1.28 in August from 1.29 in July. Despite some signs of recovery in electronics and auto exports, inventories remain near seven-year highs due to soft overseas demand, particularly from China. Manufacturing activity has contracted for seven consecutive months, and expansion plans are likely to be shelved or postponed. The impact on employment has been muted, but economists warn that the services sector cannot compensate for the slowdown in manufacturing in the long term.

site_title: Banks' record treasuries stockpile boosts case for Fed to hold
summary: US banks have accumulated a record $2.15 trillion in Treasuries, nearly doubling China's stake, amid expectations that the Federal Reserve will hold interest rates. This surge in Treasuries has led to a decline in 10-year yields to below 2%, driven by speculation that inflation is not a concern, thus rates may remain unchanged. The significant shift in investor views suggests a possible delay in the Fed's interest rate hike plans.

site_title: Singapore-based investors put in S$3.8b in overseas real estate in Q3: DTZ
summary: Singapore-based investors invested at least S$3.8 billion in overseas real estate markets in Q3, with S$1.8 billion in Australia and S$1.2 billion in the UK. In Singapore, private investment in office space rose to S$828 million, accounting for 30% of total real estate investment.

site_title: Oil prices climb on US gasoline drawdown, snap week-long fall
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, snapping a week-long decline, as US gasoline and distillate inventories dropped more than expected. Global benchmark Brent crude rose 0.88% to $50.17 a barrel, while US crude rose 1.19% to $46.93 a barrel. US gasoline stocks fell by 2.6 million barrels, and distillate stockpiles declined by 1.5 million barrels. Despite a rebound, concerns about a growing oil surplus continue to weigh on markets, with analysts expecting a measured pace of price recovery.

site_title: Asia's developing nations pessimistic on equality for women: survey
summary: A survey by Mastercard across 17 developing and emerging market countries in Asia found that people in poorer countries, such as Vietnam and Indonesia, are pessimistic about future progress in women's equality. The countries with the lowest scores, including Myanmar and Vietnam, believe the next generation of women will face a tough time combating gender inequality. In contrast, respondents in richer nations like Australia and Singapore expect progress. The survey also highlighted concerns about financial inequality, work-life balance, and climate change-related impacts.

images.alt_text: People in Asia's developing countries believe the next generation of women will face a tough time combating gender inequality, according to a survey released on Friday.

site_title: Schlumberger Q3 profit slumps as oil downturn drags on
summary: Schlumberger Ltd, the world's largest oilfield services provider, reported a 48% decline in Q3 profit to US$989 million, or 78 cents a share, due to the ongoing global crude market crash. The decline is attributed to a deteriorating North American market and accelerated downward pressure on international markets. The energy industry has slashed over US$100 billion in spending and 200,000 jobs, with further production declines expected in an oversupplied market, leading to a potential worst fourth-quarter demand for services since the downturn began.

site_title: Fed's Mester says US job growth not as bad as it looks
summary: Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester stated that the US economy only requires 70,000 to 120,000 jobs per month to maintain a 5.1% unemployment rate, contradicting expectations of 250,000 jobs. This defense of raising interest rates comes as job growth slowed to a monthly average of 139,000 in August and September. Mester expressed confidence that job growth will slow as the economy improves.

site_title: Tokyo: Japanese stocks up for second day
summary: Japanese stocks rose for a second day, with the Topix adding 0.8% to 1,502.83, and the Nikkei 225 Stock Average advancing 1% to 18,278.73. The gains followed a rally in US equities amid speculation the Federal Reserve will delay raising interest rates until 2016, lifting investor sentiment. Analysts attribute the market's optimism to weakness in US economic indicators.

site_title: Mattel sales miss estimates as Barbie slips, US dollar weighs
summary: Mattel Inc reported quarterly revenue and profit that missed analysts' estimates, with sales of Barbie dolls falling 4% on constant currency and 14% on a reported basis. The company attributed the decline to a strong dollar and young girls' preference for interactive electronic toys and tablets. Net income fell to $223.8 million, or 66 cents per share, and shares fell 3% in extended trading. Mattel's turnaround plan is still in progress, with the company developing plans to offset the Disney Princess revenue gap.

site_title: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports up 0.3% in Sept
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 0.3% in September, reversing a 8.4% year-on-year fall in August. Shipments to Japan, Thailand, and Indonesia contributed to the increase, while exports to China, the US, and South Korea declined. The electronic sector, which rose 5.7% year-on-year, outweighed the 1.9% decline in non-electronic exports. The small increase in non-oil domestic exports is a welcome rebound after a sharp drop in August.

images.alt_text: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports bounced back from a sharp 8.4 per cent year-on-year fall in August to post a small 0.3 per cent rise last month.

site_title: Lichtenstein painting expected to set record at NY auction
