Jefferies has set a target for Noble's shares to rise.

site_title: Unilever rakes in cool cash with Q3 ice cream sales
summary: Unilever reported a 9.4% rise in Q3 sales to 13.4 billion euros, driven by a strong European ice cream season and positive currency effects. The company attributed the growth to its focus on building long-term sales, particularly in the European and North American markets. Unilever also reported volumes up globally, with 8.4% growth in emerging markets. Despite the sales rise, CEO Paul Polman cautioned that global markets remain soft, with underlying sales growth expected to be around the upper 2-4% range for the year.

images.alt_text: Dutch food and cosmetics giant Unilever said Thursday sales were up for the third quarter, boosted by a bumper European ice cream season and positive currency effects.

site_title: Scoot to fly to Saudi Arabia from May, taking over from parent SIA
summary: Scoot, a long-haul budget carrier, will begin operating services to Jeddah, Saudi Arabia from May 1, taking over from its parent company Singapore Airlines. This marks Scoot's first destination in the Middle East and aims to increase capacity and optimize resource utilization. The transfer of operations is expected to benefit both Scoot and Singapore Airlines.

site_title: Luxury London home prices seen rising 21.5% in next five years
summary: Luxury home prices in London's central neighborhoods are projected to rise 21.5% over the next five years due to global economic growth and increased wealth among buyers. Despite a 2% dip in values this year, luxury homes in prime areas are expected to increase by 18.2% through 2020, driven by growing demand. The increase is partly offset by higher taxes, including a 12% sales tax on purchases above 1.5 million pounds.

site_title: Megabrew deal may fall flat with Australian regulators
summary: Australian regulators are likely to raise concerns over the planned US$100 billion-plus takeover of SABMiller by Anheuser-Busch InBev, citing potential loss of competition in the country's beer market. SABMiller would control around 46% of Australasia's 2 billion litre beer market, with the ACCC expressing concerns about a potential "cosy duopoly" emerging. The deal faces regulatory hurdles, with the possibility of being blocked in Australia or requiring asset sales in China.

images.alt_text: Australian regulators are likely to raise concerns over the planned US$100 billion-plus takeover of SABMiller by rival Anheuser-Busch InBev, wary of the impact on competition from a combination of the country's No.1 and No.3 brewers.

site_title: China Sept new loans surge to 1.05t yuan, beating forecasts
summary: China's new yuan loans surged to 1.05 trillion yuan ($165.47 billion) in September, exceeding forecasts, as the central bank eases monetary policy and speeds up infrastructure projects. The People's Bank of China reported a 13.1% growth in broad M2 money supply and a 15.4% growth in outstanding loans. Analysts predict ongoing problems on the demand side of the economy, despite the improved financing conditions. China's total social financing rose to 1.30 trillion yuan, and the central bank approved 218 fixed-asset projects worth 1.81 trillion yuan in the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Chinese media warn against US South China Sea move
summary: Chinese media have warned the US against sending warships close to artificial islands in the South China Sea, citing "ceaseless provocations" and threats to freedom of navigation. US Defense Secretary Ash Carter has confirmed plans to send warships to the area, despite China's claims of sovereignty. China's foreign ministry has warned that any US encroachment on its "core interests" will be met with force. Tensions have mounted since China transformed reefs into small islands, also claimed by neighboring countries, and have been fueled by a recent meeting of American and Australian officials.

site_title: China's telecom carriers to put US$33.7b tower assets into new firm
summary: China's three main telecom operators, China Unicom, China Mobile, and China Telecom, will consolidate their tower assets into a new firm, China Tower Corp Ltd, worth US$33.71 billion. The three carriers will transfer their tower assets, including 213.9 billion yuan (US$33.71 billion), into the new company through a combination of new shares and cash. The deal aims to centralize operations and reduce duplication of telecommunications infrastructure on the mainland. China Unicom expects to realize 9.68 billion yuan in gains from the deal.

site_title: COE quota inches down 0.9%
summary: The Singapore government has reduced the certificates of entitlement (COE) quota for the November 2015 to January 2016 period by 0.9% to 21,653 COEs. The reduction affects all COE categories except goods vehicles, which saw a 32.1% increase to 481 COEs. Category A (cars below 1,600cc/130hp) will have 3,313 COEs, down 1.8%, while Category B (cars above 1,600cc/130hp) will have 2,049 COEs, down 3%. The reduction aims to manage demand and curb inflation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally on Fed rate hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged over 1% in early trading on Thursday, driven by hopes that the Federal Reserve will delay raising interest rates until next year, following weak US data. The Hang Seng Index rose 227.51 points to 22,667.42. In contrast, Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes declined. The rally came amid US data showing weaker-than-expected economic growth, increasing speculation that the Fed may delay rate hikes.

site_title: China economic growth seen slowing despite policy easing: poll
summary: China's economic growth is expected to slow to 6.5% in 2016 from 6.8% in 2015, despite the central bank's policy easing. Analysts predict a 25-basis-point interest rate cut and 50 basis points of bank reserve requirement ratio cuts by year-end. The central bank has already lowered interest rates five times and reduced bank reserve requirements to 18%. This slowdown raises pressure on policymakers, who aim to ward off a sharper economic contraction.

images.alt_text: China's economic growth is expected to slow to 6.5 per cent in 2016 from an expected 6.8 per cent in 2015, even as the central bank eases policy further to ward off a sharper slowdown, a Reuters poll showed.

site_title: OCBC open to working with fintechs: CEO
summary: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien stated the bank is open to collaborating with financial technology companies (fintechs) in acquiring their technology. Tsien acknowledged that fintechs have been more innovative than traditional banks, but noted that regulations for fintechs will eventually catch up with those for banks. He also expressed skepticism about the "death of banks," saying it has been overstated.

site_title: Kwek Leng Beng wins HICAP Lifetime Achievement Award
summary: Kwek Leng Beng, executive chairman of Hong Leong Group Singapore and chairman of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels plc, received the HICAP Lifetime Achievement Award in Hong Kong. He is the first Singaporean to win the award, which honors exceptional individuals in the hotel industry. Mr. Kwek, who entered the hospitality industry in 1971, has expanded Hong Leong Group's hotel portfolio to over 36,000 rooms across 24 countries, and has more than 8,000 rooms in the pipeline. The award was presented by Peter Barge, retired chairman and CEO of Jones Lang LaSalle Asia Pacific, who praised Mr. Kwek's depth of industry experience and understanding of Asia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1 point to 1,710.14. The market saw 138 losers compared to 120 gainers, with a total trading volume of 142 million lots worth RM100 million.

site_title: China: Stocks rise sharply on stimulus hopes
summary: China's stocks rose sharply, jumping 2.4% to 3,486.82 on Thursday, amid signs of money flowing back into equities and expectations of fresh stimulus from a key Communist Party meeting. Consumer prices are expected to rise at a mild pace, and six transportation projects worth $10.82 billion were approved. Analysts believe this could mitigate deflationary pressures, leading to a potential economic stimulus.

site_title: Oil prices mixed in Asia as supply worries return
summary: Oil prices in Asia are mixed, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) falling 0.28% to $46.54 and Brent crude rising 0.31% to $49.30. The Opec cartel's report showing increased production and weak US economic data have led to concerns about a supply glut, while US commercial crude inventories data is expected to show a build, indicating softer demand. The price falls have wiped out most of last week's gains, with WTI failing to breach $50 a barrel since July.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 6.1% in August, again on car sales boost
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 6.1% in August, driven by a significant surge in car sales, which rose 43.9% year-on-year. Excluding car sales, retail sales would have increased 1.3%. Medical goods & toiletries also experienced double-digit growth, while petrol service stations declined 20%. On a seasonally-adjusted basis, retail sales increased 5% in August. The jump in car sales helped offset declines in other areas, such as food & beverages and optical goods & books.

site_title: Developer sales fall to 341 in Sept, but prelim Q3 figure rises to 2,509 units
summary: Developers sold 341 private homes in September 2015, down from 513 units in August and 648 units in September 2014. The provisional Q3 figure of 2,509 units surpassed Q2's 2,116 units. Excluding executive condos, 629 homes were sold in September, down from 979 units in August and 707 units in September 2014.

images.alt_text: Private homes in the Cairnhill area.

site_title: Ringgit leads Asia currency rally as Fed rate odds dip further
summary: Malaysia's ringgit led a regional currency rally as odds of a US interest-rate increase this year decreased, providing a reprieve to emerging-market assets. The ringgit appreciated 1.4% to 4.1250 a dollar, its best performance in October. The US Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike odds fell to 33% from 61% at the start of the month, citing dissenting voices from the Fed board and weak data. The ringgit's rally was also driven by a decline in Brent crude prices and domestic political headlines.

site_title: Japan restarts second reactor at Sendai nuclear plant
summary: Japan restarted its second reactor at the Sendai nuclear plant on October 15, 2015, as part of a plan to increase atomic power to 20-22% of the country's energy mix by 2030. The move is seen as a step towards recovery from the 2011 Fukushima disaster, despite public opposition to nuclear power. The Sendai No. 2 unit is expected to begin power generation on October 21 and commercial operations in mid-November, marking progress for Japan's utilities after years of shutdowns.

site_title: US growth 'modest', strong dollar weighs: Fed report
summary: The US economy experienced "modest expansion" in recent weeks, with 11 of 12 Federal Reserve districts reporting growth, according to the Beige Book survey. The strong dollar weighed on manufacturing and tourism spending, but consumer spending grew moderately, driven by auto sales. The labor market tightened, with unemployment at 5.1%, but wage growth remained subdued. The Fed's report was generally upbeat, but noted pockets of concern, including a decline in energy sector activity and heightened competition from China.

site_title: Australia: Shares steadier as miners rally, but banks subdued
summary: Australia's shares steadied on Thursday, rising 0.3% to 5,210.9, after three days of declines. The mining sector led the gains, with Newcrest Mining, Rio Tinto, and BHP Billiton increasing 4.3%, 1.9%, and 1.4% respectively. Major banks were subdued, with Westpac's shares falling 1% after a surprise rate hike and speculation of an interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. New Zealand stocks also rose, with the S&P/NZX 50 index reaching its highest in nearly two months.

site_title: Asian stocks rise first time in 3 days as tech shares climb
summary: Asian stocks rose for the first time in three days, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index gaining 1.2% as technology and phone shares advanced. The Shanghai Composite Index slipped for the first time in six days due to a slump in Chinese factory-gate prices. Despite this, stimulus hopes from China are expected to support the market, with a potential increase in fiscal spending. Other regional indexes, including Japan's Topix, South Korea's Kospi, and Taiwan's Taiex, also rose.

site_title: Indonesia posts big Sept trade surplus, thanks to 26% y/y import fall
summary: Indonesia reported a September trade surplus of $1.02 billion, surpassing forecasts, due to a 26% year-over-year decline in imports, the second-largest fall since 2009. Exports fell 18% from a year earlier. Analysts attribute the improved trade surplus to weakening domestic demand, not strengthening external demand, amid weak investment growth and a weak rupiah. The rupiah has been strengthening, potentially creating policy space for Bank Indonesia to cut interest rates, but caution is advised due to volatile times.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.41% higher at 2,996.21, driven by gains from DBS, UOB, and ComfortDelgro. The move came despite weaker regional markets and US stocks falling due to earnings concerns. About 55.7 million shares were traded, with 76 gainers outpacing 58 losers.

site_title: Taiwan filmmaker Hou eyes Oscars
summary: Taiwanese filmmaker Hou Hsiao-hsien is aiming for an Oscar with his latest movie "The Assassin," a slow-burning film set in ninth-century China. The film, which won the best director award at Cannes, may appeal to a niche audience but may not resonate with a wider American audience. Hou believes an Oscar win could increase visibility, especially in Europe, but acknowledges that the film's art-house nature may lead to disappointment from some viewers.

site_title: Australian jobs unexpectedly fall in September
summary: Australian employers unexpectedly cut 5,100 jobs in September, despite a median forecast of an increase. The jobless rate remained at 6.2%, and full-time jobs fell 13,900 while part-time employment rose 8,900. The central bank's benchmark rate has been at a record-low 2% since May, but investment by non-mining firms has yet to boost the economy. Economists warn of weak fundamental trends and intensifying macro headwinds, which may weigh on domestic demand and real GDP growth.

site_title: China inflation to maintain mild growth: state planner
summary: China's economic planner stated that consumer prices will maintain a mild growth pace in the coming months, despite concerns about deflationary pressures. The country's consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.6% in September, lower than expected. This follows a year of manufacturers cutting selling prices to win business amid weak demand and overcapacity. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Japan: Stocks fall for 3rd day as yen rises against dollar
summary: Japanese stocks fell for a third consecutive day, with the Topix index dropping 0.4% to 1,465.28, and the Nikkei 225 Stock Average declining 0.6% to 17,783.02. The yen strengthened against the dollar, reaching a seven-week high of 118.72, reducing the outlook for Japanese exporters' overseas earnings. Electrical appliance makers and shippers led losses as investors became more certain the Federal Reserve will hold off on raising US interest rates.

site_title: Indonesia chief econ minister: Rupiah strengthens towards 'fundamental' value
summary: Indonesia's chief economics minister, Darmin Nasution, stated that the rupiah's recent appreciation is a reflection of it heading towards its "fundamental" value. The rupiah jumped over 3% and traded at 13,270 per dollar. Nasution emphasized that the current value is not the "fair" value of the rupiah, indicating that the currency is still speculative. This move comes after months of speculation on the rupiah's value.

site_title: LTA, SMRT to install breakers to avoid simultaneous rail breakdowns: Khaw
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) and transport operator SMRT have decided to install breakers at Jurong East and Raffles Place interchange stations to avoid simultaneous rail breakdowns. The decision was made after a July 7 train disruption caused by a power fault on one line triggered a failure on the other line. This move aims to prevent similar disruptions in the future and ensure the reliability of the rail network.

site_title: Brookfield's US$6.5b Asciano bid faces regulatory hurdle
summary: Brookfield Infrastructure Partners' proposed A$8.9 billion (US$6.5 billion) acquisition of Asciano Ltd has faced a regulatory hurdle. The Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) has deferred a decision on the deal until December 17, citing concerns that the combined entity could lessen competition in rail haulage. Market participants have raised concerns about Brookfield's ability to favor its Pacific National rail business, leading to a more detailed review of the proposal.

site_title: Vivendi buys stakes in French gamemakers Ubisoft, Gameloft
summary: Vivendi acquired stakes in French video game developers Ubisoft and Gameloft for approximately $183 million. The investment, valued at 160 million euros, represents a 6.6% stake in Ubisoft and a 6.2% stake in Gameloft. Vivendi, a media company with a $10 billion cash pile, aims to utilize its available cash for the investment. The move shows renewed interest in the video-game industry for Vivendi, following its gradual sale of shares in Activision Blizzard.

site_title: National Australia Bank in talks with Japan's Nippon for life insurance deal
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has signed a non-binding agreement with Japan's Nippon Life Insurance Company to form a long-term partnership for life insurance products. Discussions are ongoing, with a potential future transaction uncertain and subject to regulatory approvals. Local media speculate that Nippon could buy NAB's life business for up to US$2.5 billion, as NAB evaluates options to improve returns in the wealth business.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing activity expands in September
summary: New Zealand manufacturing activity expanded in September, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index rising 0.3 points to 55.4, the highest level since February. Production reached its highest level since December last year, while new orders continued to improve, indicating a healthy outcome for the last quarter of the year.

site_title: Heavy air pollution in 80% of Chinese cities: Greenpeace
summary: Greenpeace reported that 80% of Chinese cities surveyed exceeded national PM2.5 standards, with the average level being over four times the WHO's maximum recommended. This is a significant decrease from the same period last year, where only 30% of cities exceeded the standard. The high levels of pollution pose a health risk to the population, with PM2.5 particulates penetrating deeply into the lungs.

images.alt_text: Pollution in nearly 80 per cent of Chinese cities surveyed by Greenpeace "greatly exceeded" national standards over the first nine months of this year, the advocacy group said on Thursday.

site_title: SingPost buys 96.3% stake in US e-commerce provider TradeGlobal
summary: SingPost acquired a 96.3% stake in US e-commerce provider TradeGlobal Holdings for US$168.6 million (S$236 million) through its subsidiary TG Acquisition Corporation. This deal allows SingPost's Asian clients to expand into the US market and TradeGlobal's clients to access the Asia-Pacific e-commerce landscape. The acquisition strengthens SingPost's e-commerce logistics platform, enhancing scalability and capabilities for global growth, according to CEO Marcelo Wesseler.

images.alt_text: Singapore Post Limited (SingPost) is acquiring a 96.3 per cent stake in leading US end-to-end e-commerce provider TradeGlobal Holdings for US$168.6 million (S$236 million).

site_title: ISIS 'not my cup of tea', says Briton who travelled to Syria
summary: A British woman, Shukee Begum, 33, fled Syria with her five children after traveling to join her husband, a former Guantanamo Bay detainee who joined ISIS. She claims she never supported the group and only aimed to convince her husband to return. Begum described living in an overcrowded safe house in Raqqa with other women and children, where she witnessed violent and extremist behavior. After being reunited with her husband, she was held captive and eventually smuggled out before seeking asylum in Turkey and hoping to return to Britain.

site_title: Vard issues profit warning
summary: VARD Holdings has issued a profit warning due to operational challenges at its Brazilian shipyards and the negative economic and political environment in Brazil. The company expects its Q3 FY2015 and FY2015 results to be "materially negatively affected". The unaudited Q3 results will be disclosed on November 11.

site_title: Gold comes back to life
summary: Gold prices surged 1.2% to $1,179.80 an ounce after the US economy showed signs of slowing down, decreasing the odds of a December interest rate hike to 29% from 74% two months ago. The metal's gain above its 200-day moving average boosted bulls' confidence, with some speculating it could erase its 2015 loss. A gauge of inflation dropped and retail sales missed forecasts, fueling expectations that the Federal Reserve will delay rate hikes until next year, benefiting gold.

site_title: Aussie home buyers pay for crisis steps as Westpac raises rates
summary: Westpac Banking Corp. has raised borrowing costs for Australian mortgage holders, marking the first increase in five years for owner occupiers. The move is attributed to stricter regulatory burdens, which may lead to additional interest-rate cuts from the Reserve Bank of Australia to offset the damage. Other major lenders are expected to follow suit, potentially weakening support for an already struggling economy. The decision adds to the risks for Australia's economy, which faces a severe drought and a potential housing market downturn.

site_title: Norway turns on production tap as crude collapse erodes revenue
summary: Norway's oil production is exceeding forecasts, with output expected to rise by 2% this year, according to Wood Mackenzie. The surge in production is aimed at countering plunging crude prices, which have dropped 40% over the past year, affecting the Norwegian government's finances and its massive wealth fund. Despite this, analysts warn that increased production at current low prices may lead to a drop in income for the government and potentially its wealth fund in the years ahead.

site_title: Iowa teacher takes his 'McDonald's diet' to schools, irking critics
summary: Iowa science teacher John Cisna has sparked outrage among public health advocates for promoting a McDonald's diet in US schools, funded by the fast-food chain. Cisna lost 60 pounds on a McDonald's diet and has been hired as a "brand ambassador" by McDonald's, speaking at over 90 schools. Critics argue that the program is an attempt by McDonald's to promote unhealthy food to children, despite Cisna's claims that the program aims to inform students about making informed choices. The controversy has led to protests by advocacy groups and teachers unions.

site_title: South Korea holds interest rate at record low
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, maintained its key interest rate at a record low of 1.5% on October 15, 2015. The decision was made to address concerns over snowballing household debt and sluggish exports, which account for about half of the country's GDP. Shipments have shrunk every month, and a slowdown in China, South Korea's largest trading partner, is expected to further impact the economy. The bank will closely monitor factors at home and abroad, including household debt and US monetary policy.

images.alt_text: South Korea's central bank left its key interest rate unchanged on Friday at a record low of 1.5 per cent, while voicing concern over snowballing household debt.

site_title: Corporate America's epic debt binge leaves US$119b hangover
summary: The US corporate sector has accumulated a record $119 billion in debt, with interest expenses exceeding pre-2000 levels. Despite low borrowing rates, companies are struggling to service their debt, with interest coverage at its lowest since 2009. Analysts warn that this could lead to recession if investors rein in lending. Companies are continuing to pay out record dividends and buybacks, despite stagnant earnings, and equity fund managers are increasingly prioritizing balance sheet health over shareholder payouts. This trend may worsen if earnings growth stalls amid a global economic slowdown.

site_title: Uber slip exposes data of some US drivers
summary: Uber confirmed that a software slip exposed personal data of hundreds of US drivers, including driving license, tax, and Social Security data, affecting around 674 drivers. The bug was fixed within a half-hour of being reported. This incident comes after a 2015 hacking incident exposed information of around 50,000 drivers. Uber also unveiled its local delivery service, UberRUSH, in three US cities, allowing consumers to get quick delivery of goods within minutes.

site_title: Navigating unchartered waters
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the Group of Twenty (G-20) economies have developed 15 actions to combat corporate tax avoidance through the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project. The project aims to close gaps in international tax rules, resulting in estimated annual revenue losses of $100-240 billion. Finance professionals will play a key role in implementing these changes, which include upgrading transfer pricing rules and increasing transparency. While some countries, such as China and Australia, are already pursuing a BEPS agenda, others have yet to make changes, and the project's recommendations remain "soft-law" until adopted legislatively.

site_title: Japan manufacturers' mood down again amid recession fears: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's manufacturers' confidence fell to a two-year low in October, worsened for the second straight month, amid recession fears. The Reuters Tankan poll showed a sentiment index of 7, down from 9 in September, citing sluggish demand at home and abroad. The service sector's mood improved slightly, but is expected to worsen over the next three months. This weak business outlook puts pressure on policymakers to deploy fresh stimulus, undermining their efforts to achieve a virtuous cycle of growth and investment.

site_title: US smashes US$10m data-stealing 'Bugat' botnet
summary: US authorities, in collaboration with Britain, have successfully dismantled the Bugat botnet, a malware network that stole at least $10 million in US bank data. The botnet, also known as Cridex or Dridex, was spread through emails and used to obtain bank details for millions of dollars in transfers. A 30-year-old Moldovan, Andrey Ghinkul, has been charged with botnet-related crimes and is sought for extradition. The disruption and indictment mark a significant blow to the malware threat, according to US Department of Justice officials.

site_title: New York's rich live 11 years longer than its poor
summary: New York City data reveals extreme inequality in health outcomes, with residents in the poorest neighborhood of Brooklyn, Brownsville, living 11 years less than those in Manhattan's financial district. Average life expectancy in Brownsville is 74.1 years, while it's 85.4 years in the financial district. Poor health outcomes, such as heart disease and cancer, cluster in areas with high poverty rates and limited access to healthcare, with Brownsville experiencing more than twice the citywide rates of new HIV diagnoses and psychiatric hospitalizations.

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare CEO wins EY Entrepreneur of the Year award
summary: Fullerton Healthcare Group CEO Michael Tan was named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2015 Singapore, representing the country at the EY World Entrepreneur of the Year competition in Monaco next year. Tan, who led Fullerton Healthcare to become a significant player in the healthcare sector, operating in five countries, demonstrated entrepreneurial leadership and risk-taking. The award recognizes the hard work of Fullerton Healthcare's employees and the organization's commitment to excellence.

site_title: Tesco CEO shuns more quick fixes to retailer's debt woes
summary: Tesco CEO Dave Lewis has ruled out selling major assets to cut the retailer's £17.7 billion debt burden, instead focusing on generating cash through reduced capital expenditure. This plan has raised concerns about the company's ability to regain investment-grade status, with analysts warning that selling shares could achieve this goal in a year or so. Moody's and Standard & Poor's have stripped Tesco of its investment grade, citing the need for a sustainable turnaround in UK same-store sales and operating margins.

site_title: Gundlach's main fund set to exceed US$50b in record time
summary: Jeffrey Gundlach's DoubleLine Total Return Bond Fund is expected to surpass $50 billion in assets by the end of the week, becoming the fastest active stock or bond manager to reach the milestone. The fund has grown 3% in 2015, beating 96% of its peers, and has outperformed 99% of the competition over the past five years. Gundlach invests over half of the fund's net assets in mortgage-backed securities, and its organic growth rate has averaged over 10% since inception, the fastest of 30 funds with $50 billion or more in assets.

site_title: Australia's IAG planning no more China investment
summary: Australia's Insurance Australia Group Ltd (IAG) is halting further investments in China, reversing a strategy announced just two months earlier. The decision comes after assessing opportunities in China, with the company instead focusing on growth opportunities in other Asian markets and core businesses in Australia and New Zealand. IAG's CEO Mike Wilkins, set to retire in early 2016, made the announcement, citing record claim costs from Australian storms as a factor in the shift.

site_title: Volkswagen under FTC probe in US over emissions scandal
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has joined an investigation with other government agencies into the Volkswagen emissions-cheating scandal. Volkswagen admitted that 11 million diesel cars worldwide have a "defeat device" that allows them to pass emissions tests but spew 40 times the limit of nitrogen oxide pollution. The FTC investigates deceptive advertising, and EPA fines related to US sales of affected cars could reach $18 billion. Volkswagen has set aside $9 billion in provisions and ousted its CEO, but its new CEO said the sum would only cover repair costs.

site_title: 'Embarrassing' Corbyn row overshadows Britain economy vote
summary: A parliamentary vote on Britain's economy was overshadowed by a Labour party row, with around 30 lawmakers abstaining from voting despite orders to oppose a government measure requiring a budget surplus by 2019. The bill passed with 320 MPs in favour and 258 against. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn's ability to unite his party was questioned, with critics accusing him of not providing clear economic policy. The rift within Labour was described as "embarrassing" by finance spokesman John McDonnell, who initially supported the bill before changing his stance.

site_title: Square files for keenly awaited stock market debut
summary: Square, a digital payments startup founded by Twitter chief Jack Dorsey, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise $275 million in its initial public offering. The company, which started in 2009, plans to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "SQ." Square reported a loss of $77.6 million in the first half of the year, but revenue increased to $560.6 million. The IPO comes as the company faces a potential drop in revenue growth due to a major client switching to a rival payment system.

site_title: Oil prices edge lower amid poor China, US economic data
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, extending a three-day decline, amid concerns over global economic weakness. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped two cents to $46.64 per barrel, while Brent North Sea crude fell nine cents to $49.15 per barrel. Weak Chinese trade data, poor US consumer spending, and a projected slowdown in global demand growth next year contributed to the bearish sentiment. The International Energy Agency also forecast oversupplied markets through 2016, with US crude inventories expected to rise.

site_title: UK softens rules for senior bankers, widens scope of regulation
summary: The UK has announced it will scrap plans to hold senior bankers to "guilty until proven innocent" and instead introduce a "duty of responsibility" that requires them to prevent regulatory breaches. The new rule, part of the Senior Managers & Certification regime, will cover the entire financial services industry and come into effect next March. This move is seen as a softening of the stance, easing industry fears that tough new rules would scare top talent away from London.

images.alt_text: Britain on Thursday announced it was scrapping plans that would treat senior bankers as 'guilty until proven innocent', in a move likely to infuriate regulators but ease industry fears that tough new rules will scare top talent away from London.

site_title: Poor US retail sales hammer dollar
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly rose only 0.1% in September, half the expected increase, weakening dollar prospects for a Federal Reserve interest rate hike this year. The data also showed producer prices fell 0.5% in September, the sharpest drop since January. The decline in dollar value reflects growing expectations of a rate hike in 2016, not 2015, with Fed fund futures now pricing in a 29% chance of a rate rise in December. The weak data suggests the economy may not be strong enough for the Fed to increase rates this year.

site_title: US air-traffic controller shortage threatens to raise delays: union
summary: The US air-traffic controller union, NATCA, warns of a 27-year low in staffing, threatening to increase flight delays, particularly in the New York region. A shortage of fully trained controllers, caused by retirements, budget uncertainty, and FAA failures, has reached its lowest level in 25 years. The FAA plans to hire over 6,300 new controllers over five years, but the agency has missed its hiring goals for five consecutive years due to sequestration. NATCA urges Congress to hold a hearing on staffing and to renew legislation setting policy goals for the FAA early next year.

site_title: Migrants may give Europe's economy a new lease of life
summary: The European economy may benefit from the influx of migrants, with forecasters predicting a positive impact on working-age populations and potential growth rates. The EU's institutional shortcomings in managing the refugee crisis have been exposed, but economists believe that migrants could boost the population by 5 million over the next five years and add 0.2-0.3 percentage points to euro growth. This could lift euro "potential output" growth to 1.3% on average over the next eight years, exceeding European Commission forecasts. However, the long-term effects of migration on the economy remain uncertain.

site_title: Rousseff nemesis vows no let-up in Brazil impeachment bid
summary: Brazil's opposition vows to continue its impeachment bid against President Dilma Rousseff, despite a Supreme Court decision temporarily halting the process. Congressional speaker Eduardo Cunha plans to appeal the ruling, which could allow him to reopen impeachment proceedings. Rousseff, facing steep recession and corruption allegations, is scrambling to secure support in Congress. The opposition may seek a deal with Cunha in exchange for protection from his own opponents, fueling speculation about a potential truce. Rousseff calls the impeachment threats a "coup," but the opposition signals no let-up in its drive to unseat her.

site_title: Japan Post's share offer fully subscribed
summary: Japan Post's share offer has been fully subscribed, with investor orders exceeding the number of shares being offered. The government aims to raise at least 1.19 trillion yen (S$13.8 billion) from the IPO, which could be the country's biggest privatisation since 1987. The demand may allow the postal group to price the offering at the top end of the range, which would raise 1.44 trillion yen. The IPO comes at a volatile time for Japanese stocks, following China's currency devaluation and global market turmoil.

site_title: Q3 growth not enough to lift full-year GDP forecasts
summary: Singapore's economy narrowly avoided a technical recession with a 0.1% quarter-on-quarter growth in the third quarter, beating market expectations. However, the modest growth is not enough to lift full-year GDP forecasts, which remain muted. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) forecasts GDP growth of 2-2.5% for 2015 and 2016, with the economy expected to expand at a modest pace despite global uncertainty and domestic restructuring challenges.

site_title: US: Wall St declines as Wal-Mart's weak forecast drags on retailers
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday as Wal-Mart's weak profit forecast dragged down retailers, leading to a 0.92% drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. The S&P 500 fell 0.47% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.29%. The weak forecast added to concerns about US earnings, with profits forecast to have dropped more than 4% in the third quarter.

site_title: Brighter spots in the world economy
summary: The World Bank and International Monetary Fund annual meetings in Lima, Peru, took place with a focus on the world economy's bright spots. The US Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates on September 17 was seen as a positive move for emerging markets, with countries urging the Fed to act. Fed Vice-Chairman Stan Fischer stated that the US central bank should "just do it" and raise rates. The meetings highlighted the growing influence of emerging markets and the Fed's shift towards considering global economic conditions in its monetary decisions.

site_title: Retail sales edge up 0.1% in September
summary: US retail sales rose 0.1% in September, driven by gains in automobile and other goods purchases, but core sales slipped 0.1%. Producer prices fell 0.5% in September, the largest drop since January, amid disinflation concerns. The mixed report suggests domestic demand remains strong despite a weakening global economy, casting doubt on a US interest rate hike this year. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise rates in December, but financial markets are only pricing in an increase early next year.

site_title: SME finance functions 'need to evolve to play a more strategic role in business'
summary: A report by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) suggests that small and medium enterprises (SMEs) need to evolve their finance functions to play a more strategic role in the business. This includes implementing strong financial management, becoming a central presence, and driving growth. The finance function should have a comprehensive view of the business, inform strategy, and monitor high growth. SMEs must also ensure that teams accessing financial data are adequately trained.

site_title: Mall-owner Taubman invests in China's second-tier cities
summary: US mall-owner Taubman Centers Inc is investing in China's second-tier cities, Xian and Zhengzhou, due to higher potential returns compared to the more prosperous tier-one cities. The company will build two shopping malls, one in each city, at a cost of approximately $385 million each. Taubman has partnered with local developers and retailers to minimize costs and maximize consumer knowledge. This strategic move aims to tap into the growing middle class in smaller Chinese cities, where land costs are significantly lower.

site_title: Modi's US$1t hunt earns only enough to buy India ice cream
summary: India's efforts to recover illicit funds, or "black money," have yielded only $385 million, equivalent to 0.2% of the country's total revenue last year. The funds were recovered from a three-month window before penalties increase on stashed abroad assets. Experts say the law, which imposes harsher penalties and longer prison sentences, is unlikely to bring in significant revenue. The issue is seen as deeply rooted in politics, with politicians using black money to fund campaigns, and efforts to crack down on its use failing to yield results.

site_title: Innovating to boost performance
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket chain, has successfully boosted its performance through innovative productivity measures. Since its establishment in 1985, the company has focused on cutting costs and increasing sales revenue per square foot of operations. By integrating technology, software, and computers, Sheng Siong has optimized logistics supply chains and streamlined operations. The company has implemented various initiatives, such as the Pack-to-Light system and computerized seafood procurement, resulting in significant manpower savings and increased productivity. Sheng Siong's efforts have earned it the Innovation Excellence Award, solidifying its position as the third-largest supermarket chain in Singapore.

site_title: Tesla unveils autopilot system, but don't let go of the wheel
summary: Tesla unveils its autopilot system, allowing newer Model S sedans to steer and park themselves under certain conditions, but CEO Elon Musk advises drivers to keep holding the steering wheel. The system, available through an over-the-air upgrade, will be available in the US on Thursday, with European and Asian owners to follow a week later. Musk notes that full "hands-off" driving is not recommended and that drivers should be cautious, with the system currently in beta mode. The goal is to eventually enable hands-free driving, with Musk estimating this could happen within three years.

site_title: Emerging market debt woes need urgent attention to prevent the worst
summary: Emerging market economies face high turbulence when the US Federal Reserve hikes interest rates, which may happen later this year or early next year. The IMF warns of overborrowing to $4 trillion, concentrated in construction and oil industries, which could lead to corporate failures and economic slowdown. To prevent the worst, the IMF recommends monetary policies in advanced economies remain accommodative, governments monitor vulnerable sectors, and banks impose higher capital requirements for foreign exchange exposures.

site_title: SCDF prepares for future risks
summary: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) is adopting new technologies to address growing safety challenges in the nation. With a rapidly ageing population and increasing development of subterranean structures, SCDF aims to maintain a lean and effective approach to deliver consistent service excellence. The organization has achieved world-class outcomes despite being one of the leanest emergency organizations internationally, thanks to innovative approaches and advanced technologies. SCDF plans to transform into a nation of lifesavers by 2025, with a focus on strengthening firefighting and rescue capabilities, enhancing pre-hospital emergency care, and fostering a culture of fire safety and protection.

images.alt_text: SCDF is working to enable members of the public to be first responders to incidents that occur close to them.

site_title: Leading growth with people
summary: Leading businesses prioritize people strategy as a key factor in growth, valuing diversity, and attracting talent who share the company's vision and culture. They invest in leadership development, create inclusive environments, and empower employees to innovate. Effective people strategy involves aligning rewards with business strategy, leveraging technology to predict and manage performance, and fostering a culture that supports innovation and teamwork. Successful companies prioritize people strategy as a fundamental pillar of corporate strategy, recognizing that it drives business performance and sustainability.

site_title: 2 firms, 2 govt bodies models of business excellence
summary: Two homegrown companies and two government agencies, Jumbo Group of Restaurants, Sheng Siong Group, Immigration & Checkpoints Authority of Singapore (ICA), and Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF), have won top honours in Spring Singapore's Business Excellence Awards for their commitment to business excellence and outstanding performance. Jumbo Group received the People Excellence Award, while Sheng Siong won the Innovation Excellence Award. ICA and SCDF received the Singapore Quality Award with Special Commendation, the highest accolade for business excellence.

site_title: Swatch links up with China banking giants for mobile-payment watch
summary: Swatch Group AG partners with China's banking giants to launch a mobile-payment watch called Swatch Bellamy, priced at 580 yuan (S$127). The watch will allow users to make payments at retailers with China UnionPay Co's point-of-sale machines. The device, set to be sold in China from January 2016, also includes a near-field communication chip for similar functionality to a bank card. This move challenges Apple Inc's and Samsung Electronics Co's smartwatches in the Chinese market, which has been shrinking since 2012 due to government spending restrictions.

site_title: China's crude oil imports pick up speed after Q3 lull
summary: China's crude oil imports have picked up speed after a lull in the third quarter, driven by demand from private refiners and stockpiling of cheap oil. Record imports are expected to support prices, with analysts forecasting a 12% increase in second-half imports and a 9% rise for the year. The surge in imports is attributed to the granting of nearly 700,000 bpd of crude import quotas to small refiners, known as "teapots", and state-owned refiners restocking after a third-quarter lull.

site_title: Cathay Pacific suspends flights over Iran after missile warning
summary: Cathay Pacific has suspended flights over Iran and the Caspian Sea following a missile warning issued by the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA). The warning was prompted by Russia's air campaign in Syria, with Moscow launching cruise missiles from the Caspian Sea. This decision comes after Cathay Pacific had previously re-routed some flights to and from Europe to avoid the affected area.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate's placement tranche of retail bonds oversubscribed
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' placement tranche of up to S$100 million for three-year retail bonds with a 4.65% fixed interest per annum was oversubscribed with approximately S$130 million received. Despite increasing the available amount to S$100 million, the oversubscription testifies to investors' confidence in the company's portfolio and balance sheet. The public offer may be increased to up to S$300 million, with subscriptions subject to balloting if the total subscriptions exceed the offer size.

site_title: Jennifer Lawrence tackles Hollywood sexism
summary: Jennifer Lawrence, a top Hollywood actress, recently wrote an essay criticizing film industry sexism, specifically pay inequality between men and women. Lawrence admitted she initially avoided addressing the issue due to fear of being labeled "difficult" or "spoiled." She cited her own experience with a leaked Sony email, where she was paid less than her male co-stars in the movie American Hustle. Lawrence now advocates for a more assertive approach, stating that men are often commended for being "fierce and tactical" in negotiations, while women are expected to be likable and avoid conflict.

site_title: 3 BT staffers on team that created winning haze app
summary: Three BT staffers, Kexin Yu, Ravi Gandhi, and Quah Kok Kiong, won the top prize in Hyper Haze Hack with their application Hazero, which provides location-based PSI readings and personalized outdoor activity recommendations tailored by age and health.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit posts 5.1% rise in Q3 DPU
summary: SOILBUILD Business Space Reit posted a 5.1% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.625 Singapore cents for Q3, driven by stable performance of existing portfolio and a newly acquired industrial property, Technics.

site_title: AB InBev seen facing sale of Chinese stake
summary: AB InBev, the world's largest beer company, may be forced to sell its stake in China's Snow beer due to antitrust concerns. The company's proposed $106 billion acquisition of SABMiller would give it a 40% share of China's beer market, potentially triggering an antitrust review. Analysts predict China Resources Enterprise, the joint-venture partner, would likely buy back the stake, which is valued at $4.3 billion. The deal's outcome could impact China's growing beer market, which is expected to grow 50% by 2019.

site_title: STI hazy as China concern clouds region
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.96 point to 2,983.92, mirroring a decline in other Asian markets due to concerns over China's slowdown. Hong Kong and Tokyo also experienced losses, with Hong Kong dropping 0.7% and Tokyo's Nikkei shedding 1.9%. However, some stocks like Global Logistic Properties, Keppel Corp, and Singapore Exchange (SGX) helped support the market. Noble Group gained 0.005 to S$0.475 after its CEO acknowledged transparency issues, while S-chips Jiutian Chemical Group and MMP Resources jumped 13% and 8.7% respectively.

site_title: Market volatility seen driving up mortgagee sales
summary: Market volatility and economic uncertainty have driven up the number of homes put up for mortgagee sale in Singapore, with close to 55 homes sold from January to September 2015. This is a significant increase from the total number of homes sold for the whole of 2014. The increase is attributed to factors such as job losses, volatile equity and commodity markets, and foreign labor restrictions, which have led to financial difficulties for homeowners. As a result, highly-coveted properties are being put up for auction, offering opportunistic buyers a chance to purchase distressed assets at discounted prices.

images.alt_text: The sell-off in equity markets, price fluctuations of commodities and the weaker rental market seem to have driven up the number of homes put up for mortgagee (or lender) sale in 2015, DTZ said on Wednesday.

site_title: Inspiring entrepreneurial journeys
summary: Four EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2015 award recipients, Michael Tan, Forrest Li, Mark Lee, and Neo Kah Kiat, share their success factors, challenges, and advice for new entrepreneurs. Key takeaways include the importance of innovation, strong leadership, and adapting to changing trends. They emphasize the need to surround yourself with good people, be resilient in the face of challenges, and focus on creating a positive company culture. The entrepreneurs also stress the importance of staying ahead of the curve in terms of technology and talent acquisition.

site_title: Change in relationship with EU needed for UK to stay: Lloyds chairman
summary: Lloyds chairman Norman Blackwell stated there's no "compelling economic argument" for the UK to remain in the EU without a significant change in its relationship with the bloc. This comment supports those campaigning for Brexit, ahead of a 2017 referendum. Prime Minister David Cameron is renegotiating the UK's EU membership terms, with a new settlement to be put to voters. Blackwell argued that a new treaty relationship could make the UK an attractive location regardless of the outcome, and that ignoring the democratic process could be more costly.

site_title: UK landlords renting to illegal immigrants could face jail
summary: UK lawmakers have pushed a bill that could jail landlords who rent to illegal immigrants for up to five years. The proposed law, part of the government's "hostile environment" policy, aims to deter people not authorized to be in the country. Other measures include six-month jail terms for illegal workers and a requirement for public sector workers to speak fluent English. The bill has passed its first parliamentary hurdle, but warnings of possible discrimination have been raised amid the government's hardening rhetoric.

site_title: Brazil's next big crisis - vanishing jobs and increasing loan defaults
summary: Brazil's labor market is deteriorating rapidly, with unemployment rising to 7.6% from a record-low 4.3% in 2014. The country is losing almost 20,000 jobs per month, mainly in the industrial sector. Unemployment is fueling national dissatisfaction, which is driving calls for President Dilma Rousseff's impeachment and policy paralysis. The financial crisis is deepening, with inflation soaring to 10%, the real currency falling, and the budget deficit widening. Analysts predict the economy will shrink 3% this year and unemployment will top 10% by 2016, marking a significant fall from Brazil's emergence as a key global growth engine in 2008.

site_title: CapitaLand conferred President's award for volunteerism, philanthropy
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based company, has been recognized as a "model corporate giving citizen" for its commitment to helping underprivileged children. The company launched the #100KHopeHours initiative, which received over 200,000 volunteer hours pledged. CapitaLand is also one of the first companies in Singapore to institute leave for volunteer service, making a donation to a registered charity for every employee who uses their leave. The company allocates 0.5% of its net profit to the CapitaLand Hope Foundation, which has donated over S$23 million since its inception.

site_title: Sharpening research, innovation & enterprise
summary: The article discusses the importance of research, innovation, and enterprise (RIE) systems in driving economic growth and job creation. Countries like Germany, the US, South Korea, and Japan have invested in RIE systems, while Singapore aims to remain competitive. To achieve this, Singapore needs to prioritize innovation and R&D, as highlighted by President Obama's 2013 State of the Union address. The country's RIE system should focus on translating R&D into economic growth and job creation, similar to other successful nations.

site_title: MAS ignores calls for more aggressive easing of Singdollar
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased monetary policy slightly, maintaining a "modest and gradual" appreciation of the Singapore dollar. Despite market expectations of a more aggressive move, MAS kept the policy band unchanged and reduced the rate of appreciation. The central bank narrowed its 2015 inflation forecasts and expects core inflation to rise gradually over the course of 2016. The Singapore economy narrowly avoided a technical recession in Q3, with GDP rising 0.1% quarter-on-quarter, and growth is expected to be around 2-2.5% for 2015.

site_title: Twitter to cut 8% of workforce, refocus under CEO Dorsey
summary: Twitter is cutting 8% of its workforce, approximately 336 jobs, as part of a restructuring effort under new CEO Jack Dorsey. The layoffs aim to refocus the company on boosting users and revenues. Dorsey outlined a "streamlined roadmap" to achieve this goal, which includes a revamped "Moments" feature and changes to how the company works. The move is seen as a positive step towards turning the money-losing platform around, with analysts welcoming the reorganization as a necessary step to make Twitter a successful company again.

site_title: People power Jumbo's expansion
summary: Jumbo Seafood, a seafood restaurant chain, attributes its success to focusing on talent development and retention. The chain's CEO, Ang Kiam Meng, has carefully nurtured the business, leading to a growing and thriving company. On a busy Saturday night, the restaurant is filled with customers enjoying their food, while staff work to meet the high demand. This showcases Jumbo's ability to balance growth with excellent customer service, contributing to its continued success.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma says data resource is oil, water of the future
summary: Alibaba's AliCloud is investing heavily in data technology, partnering with Foxconn for a startup incubator and unveiling enhanced security measures. The company plans to open its first European data centre next year and expects its cloud business to contribute over $1 billion in revenue by 2018. Billionaire Jack Ma sees data as the "oil, water of the future" and a public resource like water and electricity. AliCloud's expansion aims to capitalize on the $120 billion global public cloud market opportunity, as the company battles Amazon for global clients.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: M1's dividend payout ratio expected to be lowered to 90% due to higher competition from a fourth mobile player, which could impact revenue by 10% by 2022. Kingsmen Creatives upgraded to "neutral" from "sell" as the stock is now fairly valued, despite a challenging quarter. Singapore Press Holdings reported FY15 operating profit below expectations, leading to a 1-cent lower dividend recommendation.

site_title: ICA's superior brand of service
summary: The Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) in Singapore, a 2015 Singapore Quality Award winner, continues to excel in border security and identification. Leveraging technology, ICA has launched innovative projects, such as the Flexible Immigration Clearance System (Flexi-I), which has won international awards. The organization prioritizes customer service, offering online channels and minimizing visits, and supports other government agencies through systems like OSCARS. ICA aims to maintain its position as a global leader in border security and identification, focusing on future-readiness and talent development among its officers.

site_title: A US$70 oil floor? Fat chance, but Opec price plan may be first step
summary: Venezuela's plan to revive Opec's old price band mechanism, setting a US$70 floor for the oil market, may be a catalyst for finding common ground to stabilize the oil market. However, Saudi Arabia and Russia have shown little interest in returning to a strategy of supporting prices. The proposal, if unsuccessful, could represent a first step towards finding a solution, and some experts believe it could ease market volatility and soften the stance of some Opec members. The plan involves progressive production cuts to control prices, with a "first floor" of US$70 per barrel and a later target of US$100 per barrel.

site_title: Bank of America swings back into profit in Q3 as cost-cutting pays off
summary: Bank of America reported a Q3 profit of $4.51 billion, a significant turnaround from a loss of $232 million in the same quarter last year. The bank's cost-cutting efforts and revenue exceeding analysts' estimates contributed to the profit. Net income was 37 cents a share, exceeding the average analyst estimate of 33 cents. This marks a notable improvement from the previous year's loss, largely due to reduced litigation expenses.

images.alt_text: Whatever does cause the next global recession, it likely won't be China.

site_title: Giving back to society is 'right thing to do'
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR), a palm oil giant, has made significant contributions to Indonesian communities through education, infrastructure, and housing development. The company, led by CEO Franky Widjaja, has built and managed 253 schools, employed 750,000 people, and contributed 8% of Indonesia's total palm oil production. Widjaja attributes GAR's success to its focus on operational excellence and moving up the value chain, allowing the company to deliver refined products to customers and expand its global distribution network. His father, business tycoon Eka Widjaja, instilled in him a sense of drive and ambition, which has contributed to GAR's success and its commitment to giving back to society.

site_title: Marlon James' sweeping epic of Jamaica wins Booker Prize
summary: Marlon James wins the Man Booker Prize for Fiction 2015 for his novel "A Brief History of Seven Killings", a sweeping epic that explores Jamaican politics, gang wars, and drug trafficking. The novel, which uses the attempted assassination of Bob Marley in 1976 as a backdrop, was praised for its stylistic range and unflinching exploration of violence and corruption. James, the first Jamaican-born author to win the award, said he was unsure he would win and did not prepare an acceptance speech, calling himself an "easy writer to dislike" due to his experimental style.

site_title: SGD surges 1% following mild easing by MAS
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) surged 1% following a mild easing move by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), but the rally is expected to be short-lived due to weak economic conditions. The SGD gained 1.1% in the first hour after the statement, but declined 1% by the end of the day, settling at S$1.3872. Analysts attribute the gain to market expectations of more easing not being met, and warn that the SGD's strength is likely temporary due to continued economic uncertainties and a possible US interest rate hike.

site_title: Spring strengthens its international networks
summary: Spring Singapore has strengthened its international networks through the Business Excellence framework, aligning with global excellence awards. As a founding member of the Global Excellence Model (GEM) Council, Spring shares knowledge and best practices with member countries, including Australia, Europe, India, and the US. Since being appointed as a Centre of Excellence (COE) for Business Excellence by the Asian Productivity Organization (APO) in 2009, Singapore has facilitated international training workshops and helped regional economies develop their own business excellence initiatives.

site_title: A fundamental change to tax rules
summary: The OECD presented a final package of measures to fundamentally change international tax rules, ending double non-taxation and facilitating alignment with economic activity. The measures, agreed upon by G-20 finance ministers, include new minimum standards on country-by-country reporting, treaty shopping, and curbing harmful tax practices. The package aims to render BEPS-inspired tax planning structures ineffective and is being developed into a multilateral instrument to incorporate into existing bilateral treaties. Nearly 90 countries are working together on the instrument, which will be open for signature in 2016.

site_title: Tokyo chief vows stadium will be built on time
summary: Tokyo Governor Yoichi Masuzoe vows the city's Olympic stadium will be completed on time for the 2020 Games, despite a scandal-tainted design and spiraling costs. The city has opted for a cheaper alternative and is rushing to meet the January 2020 deadline. London Mayor Boris Johnson warned against "playing politics" when hosting the Olympics, citing London's 2012 success as a model of competent communication and collaboration. The stadium's cancellation has pushed back Rugby World Cup preparations and embarrassed Japanese sport officials.

site_title: World's king of beer flies coach, wears jeans and loves pressure
summary: Carlos Brito, CEO of Anheuser-Busch InBev, has completed a $106 billion deal to acquire British brewer SABMiller, expanding his company's presence in faster-growing markets such as Africa. Brito's hard-charging management style has delivered industry-beating profit margins and praise from analysts and business school deans. He has implemented a lean, results-driven culture, laying off staff and promoting younger employees to adopt his management approach. The acquisition marks a significant move to counter stagnating sales in key markets.

site_title: A well-functioning securities market is a shared responsibility
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange (SGX) have been working to strengthen Singapore's securities market. Measures include making blue-chip equities more affordable and offering retail investors access to a wider range of low-cost capital-market products. The MAS is also helping remisiers upgrade their services to deliver higher value to clients. The MAS has also been engaging with companies affected by a minimum trading price (MTP) requirement, which aims to improve the quality of listings on SGX. A well-functioning securities market is a shared responsibility.

site_title: Inflation in China slows further in September
summary: China's inflation slowed further in September, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 1.6% and the producer price index (PPI) falling 5.9% for the 44th consecutive month. Deflationary pressures continue to mount, with food inflation at 2.7% and overcapacity in factories contributing to the decline. Markets responded negatively, with Shanghai and Hong Kong closing down 1% and 0.7% respectively. Analysts expect further government intervention to forestall a hard landing of the economy, with some predicting moderate fiscal stimulus and monetary easing.

images.alt_text: Deflationary pressures continued to mount in China in September, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising less than expected, and the producer price index (PPI) falling for the 44th consecutive month.

site_title: Intel's quarterly results reflect its move to cloud computing
summary: Intel reports strong quarterly earnings, driven by growth in cloud computing business, with net income of 64 US cents a share and revenue of US$14.5 billion. The company's data centre group, which includes cloud computing, saw a significant increase in profit margins. Intel's shift to cloud computing is expected to continue, with the company's server chips for cloud data centres bringing in US$4.1 billion in revenue. The company's CEO, Brian Krzanich, said the quarter demonstrates Intel's innovations in action, as the company adapts to the changing computing industry.

images.alt_text: Intel Corp, the world's largest maker of semiconductors, is changing with the times.

site_title: Latest mega deals to test limits of US debt boom
summary: Bond investors will be asked to lend up to $120 billion to finance two mega mergers, the largest corporate-bond sale ever and a record offering by a junk-rated issuer. The deals, between Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller and Dell and EMC, come as investors face a slowdown in the market, with a recent slump in junk-rated corporate issuers and a decline in demand for high-yield bonds. Experts warn that the sudden influx of debt could be too much for the market to handle, and investors are being cautious about taking on new debt.

site_title: JPMorgan Q3 figures fall short of analyst estimates
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co reported Q3 earnings that fell short of analyst estimates, with revenue declining 6.4% and adjusted earnings per share at $1.32, missing the $1.38 average estimate. The bank attributed the decline to a slump in trading and mortgage banking results. Despite a 22% increase in net income to $6.8 billion, JPMorgan cautioned that trading is off to a slow start this quarter, prompting analysts to reassess their estimates.

site_title: Sharing and learning
summary: The Business Excellence Awards, which celebrate best practices in the business community, will feature presentations by 2015 winners in May 2016. The event aims to share knowledge and expertise among like-minded business leaders and senior managers to deliver greater value to the community. For more information, contact the Business and Service Excellence Division at 6279 3811 or be@spring.gov.sg.

site_title: Asia's family enterprises - The imperative to innovate
summary: Asia's family enterprises play a significant role in the region's economy, with over 60% of publicly-listed companies and 85% of billion-dollar businesses being family-owned. However, with the increasing integration of the global economy, family businesses must innovate to stay competitive. To achieve this, they must diffuse innovation throughout the enterprise, develop a pool of business innovators, and focus on strategic development, process innovation, and long-term interest. Successful examples include LVMH's emphasis on innovation and creative freedom, Apple's cutting-edge designs, and Samsung's adoption of TRIZ for research and development.

site_title: Ensuring success now and in future
summary: A successful organization requires a comprehensive approach to foster strong management practices for sustainable growth, including a good strategy, inspiration, purpose, and strong execution. The Business Excellence framework assesses nine attributes of excellence, such as leading with vision and integrity, creating value for customers, and driving innovation and productivity. Organizations that have been certified to the Business Excellence (BE) standards have achieved higher profit growth, with an average of 14.1% growth between 2008 and 2012, compared to their industry peers. The framework encourages continuous learning and innovation, and offers certification and award programs to recognize organizations that have achieved different levels and types of excellence.

site_title: Indonesia-based banker fined by MAS for insider trading
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has fined Vincent Rajiv Louis, a managing director at UBS AG, for insider trading in PT Bank Danamon shares. Louis bought 1 million shares in 2012 after possessing price-sensitive information on a proposed acquisition by DBS Bank. He made a profit of S$173,965 and paid a civil penalty of S$434,912 without court action. This action reflects MAS' firm resolve to enforce market conduct laws, regardless of the individual's location. Louis admitted to contravening the Securities and Futures Act.

site_title: SMEs get boost from BE initiative
summary: The 2014 Business Excellence (BE) impact study found that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) certified to the BE standards experienced significant growth, with profits increasing by 19.2% compared to the industry average of 6.1%. The BE initiative helped SMEs professionalise their management practices, leading to increased awareness of disciplined business practices, quantifiable targets, and staff innovation. This led to improved processes and efficiency, resulting in higher profits for certified SMEs.

site_title: GRP to acquire 82.91 per cent of Starland Hldgs
summary: GRP Limited plans to acquire 82.91% of Starland Holdings for S$28.3 million, with a cash price of 23.6 Singapore cents per share, a 38.8% premium over the last traded price. The acquisition is aimed at growing GRP's foothold in the Chinese property market.

site_title: Toyota targets 90% emissions reduction by 2050 on fuel-cell vehicles
summary: Toyota aims to reduce emissions from its new vehicles by 90% by 2050, with a focus on fuel-cell vehicles. The company plans to deliver over 30,000 fuel-cell vehicles annually by 2020 and reach 15 million cumulative hybrid deliveries in the same span. Toyota's chairman emphasizes the need for the industry to take on environmental challenges with a long-term vision. This comes as the auto industry faces fallout from the Volkswagen emissions scandal, with Toyota poised to become the top seller of hybrid vehicles.

site_title: KLW needs independent directors on board
summary: KLW Holdings' board is facing scrutiny over its independence as a capital-raising opportunity looms. Businessman Quek Chek Lan, who acquired a 19.4% stake, sought to remove independent directors and appoint himself and others to the board. The new board now includes Quek's associates, raising questions about their independence. Minority shareholders need assurance that the board will act in the company's best interests, particularly as KLW sits on a series of put options that could significantly increase the company's share price. The board's independence will be tested as the company considers exercising the options.

site_title: ACRA launches framework to improve quality of financial reporting in Singapore
summary: ACRA introduces an Audit Quality Indicators (AQIs) Disclosure Framework to improve financial reporting quality in Singapore. The framework, launched on Oct 14, 2015, provides audit committees of listed companies with comparable indicators on auditors' ability and commitment to deliver quality audits. The big four audit firms agree to provide this data, enabling audit committees to better evaluate and select the right auditors, with the aim of improving audit quality over time and enhancing Singapore's reputation as a transparent and trusted business hub.

site_title: Glut, tighter lending threaten South Korea property market
summary: South Korea's property market, fueled by record-low interest rates, has experienced a boom, with more housing transactions in the first eight months of 2015 than in any year since 2006. However, an oversupply of new homes and stricter lending rules may signal the end of the boom, threatening the market. Construction investment has grown more than five times as fast as the nation's economy in the April-June quarter, but the market's future is uncertain due to the potential impact of tighter lending and a glut of new homes.

site_title: Unassuming 'fanboy' bought and very briefly owned Google.com
summary: A 29-year-old MBA student in Massachusetts briefly became the owner of Google.com for 60 seconds after purchasing the domain through Google's beta website registration service. The student, Sanmay Ved, had worked for Google and was a self-proclaimed "fanboy" of the company. He was charged $12 for the purchase but it was later cancelled due to another user registering the domain first. Google later rewarded Ved with an undisclosed monetary prize for discovering a vulnerability in the system, which he said was never about the money.

site_title: Vonovia bids 9.92b euros for Deutsche Wohnen
summary: Vonovia, Germany's largest residential landlord, has offered 9.92 billion euros (S$15.7 billion) to buy Deutsche Wohnen AG, a rival company, in the event of its planned purchase of LEG Immobilien AG failing. The deal would be the largest in the rental property industry, combining Vonovia's 370,000 apartments with Deutsche Wohnen's 144,000 units. Vonovia CEO Rolf Buch believes the offer is attractive for shareholders and that a majority recognize its value.

site_title: A family business built to last
summary: Eu Yan Sang, a traditional Chinese medicine company, has been successful for nearly 200 years thanks to its family values. Founded by Eu Kong in 1879, the company's name is derived from a poem that instructs the family to behave in a righteous and steadfast manner. The company has grown to become one of the largest Chinese medicine companies in Asia, with 282 retail outlets in six countries. Despite its family-run nature, Eu Yan Sang operates professionally, with a focus on quality products, excellent customer service, and teamwork. The company aims to continue its success for the next 135 years, driven by its professional and family values.

site_title: Banks helping rich clients invest in marquee property deals
summary: Banks are now offering wealthy clients the opportunity to invest in high-profile real estate deals, such as Manhattan's 432 Park Ave and Las Vegas' Hooters hotel, typically requiring a minimum investment of $250,000. This service, known as "club" deals, allows ultra-rich clients to gain exposure to real estate without requiring a track record of investment. Banks like JPMorgan, Citigroup, and HSBC are targeting this growing class of clients, who seek alternatives to stocks and commodities and are looking for more transparency and lower fees.

images.alt_text: Among Citigroup's investments was providing equity for 432 Park Ave, where a penthouse is under contract for about US$95 million

site_title: CEO: Noble could have been more transparent earlier on
summary: Noble Group's CEO, Yusuf Alireza, acknowledged that the company could have been more transparent earlier on, in response to short-seller attacks. He stated that while Noble's business complexity makes full transparency impossible, the company could have provided more information to mitigate attacks. Alireza defended Noble's valuation methods, including its associate Yancoal, and declined to comment on its accounting choices for mark-to-market contracts. A third-party review of Noble's business was conducted, but its findings were deemed insufficient by some. Noble shares closed half a cent up following the forum.

images.alt_text: Mr Alireza: "In hindsight, I should have been more forceful with the board about supporting more transparency, because I think if we had more transparency up front we'd be less exposed."

site_title: BlackRock's profit falls 8%
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, reported an 8% decline in third-quarter profit to $843 million, or $5 per share. Despite the drop, long-term net inflows rose to $35 billion, with iShares taking in $23.3 billion in new investor money. The company's assets under management decreased to $4.51 trillion. BlackRock's shares closed at $315.12 on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: Canada urged to compile data on home purchases by foreigners
summary: HSBC Holdings has urged the Canadian government to compile data on home purchases by foreigners, citing the high demand from Asian buyers, particularly from China, which is driving up prices in Vancouver and Toronto. The bank's chief economist, David Watt, believes foreign money is playing a significant role in the Canadian housing market, contributing to rising home prices that outpace income growth. The lack of conclusive data on foreign real estate purchases has raised concerns, with some experts and officials calling for regulatory measures to address the issue.

site_title: South China Sea claims: Room for diplomacy
summary: A South China Sea arbitration court is expected to rule on the Philippines' case against China's expansive maritime claims, potentially paving the way for a peaceful resolution. The Philippines filed the case in 2013, citing the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. China is likely to reject the court's ruling, but may eventually soften its stance. Diplomatic support from the US, Japan, and Vietnam has bolstered the Philippines' position. A pragmatic response from South-east Asian nations could facilitate a diplomatic resolution to the tensions, but China's rejection of the court's ruling is expected.

site_title: Winning formula
summary: Four exceptional entrepreneurs have won the EY Entrepreneur of the Year Awards, leveraging technology to give their businesses an edge. Winners include Mark Lee of Sing Lun Holdings, who automated manufacturing facilities, and Michael Tan of Fullerton Healthcare, who digitized x-ray results and created a mobile application. Forrest Li of Garena innovated to engage customers, while Neo Kah Kiat of Neo Group built an automated technology-enabled catering business.
