The winners were chosen from 40 nominees and will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year award in 2016.

images.alt_text: (From left): Wong Ngit Liong, chairman/CEO, Venture Corporation Limited, chairman of EOY Singapore Academy; Michael Tan, group CEO and co-founder, Fullerton Healthcare Group Pte Ltd; Mark Lee, CEO, Sing Lun Holdings Ltd; Franky Oesman Widjaja, chairman and CEO, Golden Agri-Resources Ltd; Chan Chun Sing, Secretary-General, National Trades Union Congress and Minister, Prime Minister's office; Forrest Li, chairman and group CEO, Garena; Max Loh, Singapore and Asean managing partner, EY; Didier von Daeniken, head of Wealth Management, Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa, Barclays; Neo Kah Kiat, PBM, founder, chairman and CEO, Neo Group Limited; Richard Eu, Group CEO of Eu Yan Sang International Ltd

(From left): Max Loh, Singapore and Asean managing partner, EY; Michael Tan, group CEO and co-founder, Fullerton Healthcare Group Pte Ltd (EY Entrepreneur Of The Year Singapore 2015); Chan Chun Sing, Secretary-General, National Trades Union Congress and Minister, Prime Minister's office. Dr Tan will represent the Republic at the annual EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year (WEOY) award in Monte Carlo in 2016

site_title: Gullibility is synonymous with ignorance
summary: A century ago, the author believed that the truth was paramount in business, but their experience as a lawyer and auditor has led them to conclude that gullibility is synonymous with ignorance, and that many professions have become dishonest. The Volkswagen scandal is just the latest example of corporate greed, shocking the world despite the widespread knowledge of the unacceptable face of capitalism. The author attributes the gullibility to a combination of regulators, who often turn a blind eye, and the public's tendency to accept plausible explanations and acceptable language, allowing dishonest individuals to succeed.

site_title: China said to extend onshore FX trading to overlap with London
summary: China's foreign exchange market will extend trading hours for the yuan to 11:30pm (1530 GMT) to overlap with European trading hours, supporting the yuan's inclusion in the IMF's SDR basket. The move aims to boost international use of the yuan and align it with international markets, particularly European markets. The change is expected to make the yuan's movement more in line with international markets and increase convenience for international traders.

site_title: MAS makes a habit of showing up the market
summary: MAS maintained its policy of a gradual appreciation of the Singapore dollar, but on a "slightly" reduced slope, with no change to the policy band and its level. The central bank narrowed 2015 inflation forecasts to 0.5% for core inflation and -0.5% for headline inflation, slightly lower than earlier expectations. Despite this, MAS warned of downside risks to the economy and maintained its 2015 GDP growth forecast at 2-2.5%. The policy stance suggests that MAS prioritizes containing inflation over boosting growth, and room for further easing moves may be limited unless exceptional events occur.

site_title: Japan to exempt some food from sales tax hike, sparks worries about debt
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe ordered his party to devise a plan to exempt some food items from a 2017 sales tax hike, aiming to alleviate economic concerns. The 10% sales tax, set to rise from 8%, will fund rising welfare spending, but exemptions could undermine debt reduction efforts. Economists warn that exemptions may lead to reduced tax revenue and increased volatility, outweighing potential benefits for low-income households and supporting consumer spending. The move may also burden public finances further.

site_title: SunMoon Food requests voluntary suspension
summary: SunMoon Food Company has requested a voluntary suspension from trading due to uncertainty surrounding the outcome of queries from the Securities Industry Council regarding changes in shareholding interests. The largest shareholder, First Alverstone Capital, is responding to queries, which may lead to market speculations. The company aims to keep shareholders informed and will make further announcements as necessary. The voluntary suspension follows a trading halt introduced two days earlier.

site_title: Weakness in private condominium rents persists in September
summary: Weakness in private condominium rents persisted in September, with a 0.3% decline from the previous month, according to SRX Property. This decline was attributed to intensifying competition among landlords amid a surge in new home completions. Despite the decline, rental volumes dipped 4.1% in September. HDB rents remained flat in September, while private non-landed units saw a 5.6% decline compared to the same period last year. Consultants expect the private rental market to remain weak, affecting the HDB market as well.

site_title: Wal-Mart expects strong dollar to hit annual revenue by US$15b
summary: Wal-Mart CEO Doug McMillon expects a strong US dollar to reduce the company's annual revenue by US$15 billion. The retailer, which generates about a third of its revenue and a quarter of its profit outside the US, reported US$485.7 billion in revenue last year. McMillon plans to provide three-year projections for revenue and earnings at its annual investor meeting. The company's reliance on international markets, particularly China, may be impacted by the strong dollar and potential tariffs.

site_title: China loses WTO appeal in stainless steel dispute with EU, Japan
summary: China lost a World Trade Organization (WTO) appeal in a dispute over anti-dumping duties on high performance seamless stainless steel tubes. The dispute involved Japan and the European Union, which complained about China's duties affecting exporters of the tubes used in coal-fired power plants. A WTO panel initially ruled against China, but the Appellate Body strengthened the case, reversing points where the panel had backed Beijing. The decision aims to support exporters of the tubes, including Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp and Tubacex S.A. in Spain and Germany.

site_title: Twitter names ex-Google executive Kordestani executive chairman
summary: Twitter appoints Omid Kordestani as its executive chairman, replacing the position that was previously held by Dick Costolo. Kordestani, a former Google executive, was appointed after concerns were raised about Jack Dorsey's dual role as Twitter CEO and Square's CEO. Twitter shares rose 1% after the announcement, and Kordestani expressed excitement about joining Twitter, citing his experience at Google and Netscape. The move aims to alleviate concerns about Dorsey's leadership and focus on Twitter's growth.

site_title: US retail sales barely rise, dented by lower gas receipts
summary: US retail sales rose 0.1% in September, edging out expectations of a 0.2% increase. The gains were largely driven by purchases of automobiles and other goods, while service station receipts were dented by cheaper gasoline. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles and gasoline, slipped 0.1% in September, down from a previously reported 0.2% gain in August. The mixed report suggests underlying strength in domestic demand, which may shield the economy from slowing global growth. Most economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in December.

site_title: CapitaLand wins President's Volunteerism and Philanthropy Award
summary: CapitaLand has been awarded the President's Volunteerism and Philanthropy Award for its commitment to helping underprivileged children. The company launched the #100KHopeHours initiative, which received over 200,000 volunteer hours pledged. CapitaLand is also one of the first companies in Singapore to provide leave for volunteer service, with the company making a donation to a registered charity for every employee who fully utilizes the leave. The award recognizes the company's model corporate giving citizen status and marks a decade of CapitaLand Hope Foundation's commitment to "Building for Tomorrow".

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, maintains a "modest and gradual" appreciation of the S$NEER, but at a slightly reduced pace. The country's economy grew 1.4% in Q3, beating market expectations. Private condo rents dropped 0.3% in September, while HDB rents remained flat. MAS also took civil penalty action against an insider trader, Vincent Rajiv Louis, and oversaw the oversubscription of Perennial Real Estate's retail bond placement. The local market ended unchanged, following a Wall Street slide.

site_title: Germany trims 2015 growth outlook as emerging markets slow
summary: Germany trimmed its 2015 growth forecast to 1.7% due to emerging markets' slowdown, but expects domestic consumption to offset external weakness. The country now forecasts 1.8% growth for 2016. Strong domestic consumption, rising wages, and a weak euro are expected to drive growth, with unemployment predicted to fall this year and rise only by 60,000 next year. Despite a massive migrant influx, the government believes its economy is solid enough to absorb the newcomers.

site_title: Wal-Mart cuts profit outlook, sending shares plunging
summary: Wal-Mart has cut its profit outlook for fiscal 2017, citing increased spending on employee wages and e-commerce investments. The company now expects earnings per share to fall between 6-12% due to a strong dollar. Despite this, executives believe the long-term investments will lead to prosperity. The company trimmed its fiscal 2016 sales outlook to "relatively flat" and announced $20 billion in share repurchases. Shares plummeted 9.0% to $60.75.

site_title: US$ down as China woes seen restraining Fed
summary: The US dollar fell to a 31/2-week low against a basket of currencies as economic weakness in China raised expectations of the Federal Reserve waiting longer to raise interest rates. China's consumer inflation slowed to 1.6% in September, and imports fell 20% in the same period, suggesting a cloudy economic picture. Fed governor Daniel Tarullo expressed doubt about a rate hike this year, and the dollar index fell 0.3% to 94.434.

site_title: Tech funding surging despite bubble fears: survey
summary: Investors poured US$37.6 billion into startups in the third quarter, the highest since 2001, defying fears of a tech bubble. 77% of the funding went to technology startups, with healthcare and digital health taking 12% each. Mega-deals and large startups like Uber and Airbnb drove the investment, while early-stage funding declined for the fifth consecutive quarter. The cash flow fueled the creation of 23 new "unicorns" this quarter, bringing the total to 58 so far this year, with a combined valuation of US$503 billion.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly lower after tepid retail data, earnings
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday after a disappointing retail sales report and JPMorgan Chase's earnings fell short of expectations. The Dow Jones dropped 32.81 points, while the S&P 500 declined 2.21 points. Retail sales rose only 0.1% in September, half the expected increase. JPMorgan Chase's earnings per share fell 5 cents below analyst expectations, contributing to the Dow's decline.

site_title: Industrial product supplier GRP making bid for Starland Holdings
summary: GRP Limited has entered a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire 82.91% of Starland Holdings for S$28.3 million, paying 23.6 Singapore cents per share, a 38.8% premium over the last traded price. The acquisition aims to accelerate GRP's strategy to grow in the Chinese property market, where it has been active since 2008. Starland primarily develops integrated residential and commercial properties in Chongqing.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 1.89% lower
summary: Japanese stocks closed 1.89% lower on October 14, 2015, due to concerns over China's economy and a negative lead from Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 343.74 points to 17,891.00, while the Topix index fell 2.15% to 1,470.83. The decline was attributed to a lack of strong trading cues.

site_title: More certainty for sale of majority stake in China Minzhong Food
summary: China Minzhong Holdings and PT Indofood Sukses Makmur have signed a binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) to discuss the proposed acquisition of a majority stake in China Minzhong Food Corporation. The deal would see China Minzhong Holdings acquire 347 million shares, representing about 52.94% of the company, at S$1.20 per share. The two companies aim to finalize a definitive sale and purchase agreement within 12 months. This marks a turnaround from earlier uncertainty, with both parties committing to "good faith" discussions.

site_title: BofA returns to profits as consumer banking gains
summary: Bank of America (BofA) reported a net income of $4.5 billion in the third quarter, reversing a $232 million loss in the same period last year due to large legal expenses. Revenue declined 2.4% to $20.91 billion. The bank's consumer banking business saw higher profits due to increased deposits, mortgage originations, and credit card issuances. However, earnings declined in global banking, global wealth, and investment management divisions. BofA shares rose 1.7% to $15.78 following the earnings release, beating analyst expectations by 4 cents per share.

site_title: India named top investment destination in business poll
summary: India has been named the most attractive country for investment by over 500 global investors in a survey by accounting firm EY. 32% of executives chose India as their favored market, with China second at 15%. The survey reflects growing confidence in Prime Minister Narendra Modi's reform agenda, with ease of doing business in India being an attractive factor. India aims to simplify business procedures and develop world-class infrastructure to attract more investment, which is expected to drive the country's economy to become the fastest-growing major economy this year.

site_title: China to invest US$22b to extend broadband to 50,000 villages
summary: China plans to invest US$22 billion by 2020 to expand broadband internet to 50,000 underserved villages, covering 98% of the country's villages. The project aims to improve internet services for over 30 million households, with the rollout targeting 98% of the country's villages and 50,000 villages without access to broadband. The initiative is part of China's efforts to digitize its economy, following Premier Li Keqiang's calls for improved service and reliability.

site_title: New palm oil council would drop "no deforestation" pledge: Indonesia
summary: Indonesia is setting up a new palm oil producer grouping, replacing "no deforestation" pledges made by major palm companies with a joint set of standards. The move aims to protect smallholder producers and promote the image of palm oil. Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's largest palm oil producers, have agreed to harmonize and combine their standards. The new Council of Palm Oil Producer Countries will promote cooperation, stabilize prices, and coordinate production and re-planting schemes.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit posts 5.1% rise in Q3 DPU
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit reported a 5.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.625 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by stable portfolio performance and a newly acquired industrial property, Technics. Distributable income rose 20.8% to S$15.15 million, while gross revenue increased 22.4% to S$20.7 million. The Reit's occupancy rate remained high at 98.7%. The manager expects stable performance for FY2015, barring unforeseen events.

site_title: MPA-led group aims to boost maritime listings on SGX
summary: A tripartite working group led by the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) aims to boost maritime listings on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The group, in collaboration with SGX and the Singapore Shipping Association (SSA), seeks to establish Singapore as a maritime financial hub. With over 20 banks, private equity arrangers, and shipping finance advisers already involved, the working group aims to complement these sources of financing with public equity and debt to enlarge the funding pool for the sector.

images.alt_text: The Maritime Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is taking the lead in a tripartite working group recently formalised to promote maritime listings on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Striving to reach the pinnacle
summary: Singapore's government agency Spring Singapore has announced partnerships with the construction and manufacturing industries to help companies boost performance and address challenges such as high labor costs and low productivity. The Business Excellence framework, launched in 1994, aims to improve processes and culture to deliver Operational Excellence to customers. The initiatives are part of Spring's efforts to support the sectors, which are among the most affected by Singapore's economic structuring. This move is expected to benefit 1,500 local organisations already using the BE framework.

images.alt_text: "Feedback from the manufacturing industry validates operational excellence as a key driver for business growth and competitiveness," says Spring Singapore's Choy Sauw Kook

site_title: China to extend onshore FX trading hours until 1530 GMT: sources
summary: China's foreign exchange market will extend trading hours for the yuan to 2330 local time (15:30 GMT), covering the European trading session, according to sources. This move aims to support China's efforts to internationalize the yuan and increase its inclusion in the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights basket.

site_title: UBS sees sovereign assets shrinking by US$1.2t
summary: UBS predicts sovereign assets will shrink by $1.2 trillion, or 7%, by the end of 2015 due to China withdrawing foreign exchange reserves and oil-producing countries tapping foreign assets to support government spending. This decline is expected to continue into 2016, driven by lower investment returns. Sovereign wealth funds, such as those from Norway, Saudi Arabia, and Russia, are preparing to withdraw savings built up during periods of high oil prices. This marks a reversal of the trend of accumulating assets seen in the past few years.

site_title: Philippines' Aquino says wants to join Trans-Pacific Partnership
summary: Philippine President Benigno Aquino expressed interest in joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a trade pact aiming to cut trade barriers and set common standards among 12 Pacific Rim countries, including the US, Japan, and Vietnam. The Philippines is the second-fastest growing economy in Southeast Asia and has been invited to join the second round of countries. Aquino believes joining the pact would make sense due to close alliances with existing members, particularly the US, Japan, and Vietnam.

site_title: UK unemployment rate falls to new 7-year low, pay growth edges up
summary: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 5.4% in the three months to August, the lowest level since mid-2008. This marks a decline from 5.5% in the previous quarter. Pay growth was slower than expected, but still higher than forecast. The unexpected drop in unemployment rate is a positive sign for the UK economy, although it may indicate a slowdown in job growth.

site_title: Renewed China woes drag Asian markets after more weak data
summary: Asian markets were weighed down by concerns over China's economic slowdown, despite a possible easing of inflation and producer prices. China's weak data, including a 20% decline in imports and exports in September, led to a halt in the recent global rally. Traders remain cautious, with worries about the impact of the country's economic crisis on regional markets.

site_title: SGD up 1% following unexpected mild easing move by MAS
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) rose 1% following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's mild easing move. At 4pm, the SGD stood at S$1.3872 to the US dollar, a change of S$0.014 from the previous day. Analysts expect the rally to be short-lived.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open on China woes
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped at the start of trading on October 14, 2015, due to renewed concerns over China's economic slowdown. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.77% to 6,293.12 points, while the CAC 40 in Paris dropped 0.75% to 4,608.42 points and the DAX 30 in Frankfurt declined 0.84% to 9,948.49 points. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU trade tensions also in focus.

site_title: MAS takes civil penalty action against Vincent Rajiv Louis for insider trading
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has taken civil penalty action against Vincent Rajiv Louis for insider trading in PT Bank Danamon shares. Louis, a managing director at UBS AG, bought 1 million Danamon shares in March 2012 after possessing non-public information on a proposed acquisition by DBS Bank. He made a profit of 1,739,821,337 rupiah from his insider trades. Louis is accused of violating the Securities and Futures Act, and MAS has taken civil penalty action against him.

site_title: China Q3 growth seen dipping to 6.8 per cent, weakest since 2009
summary: China's economic growth is expected to dip to 6.8% in the third quarter, its weakest since 2009, as the country enters a slower growth phase after decades of rapid expansion. Policymakers are under pressure to roll out support measures amid fears of a sharper slowdown and its impact on global markets. Despite government reassurances, the devaluation of the yuan and a summer stock market plunge have fueled concerns of a hard landing. China's economic slowdown is seen as a sign of a broader global economic slowdown.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower, New Zealand stocks near two-month peaks
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% lower, marking the third consecutive session of losses, as the S&P/ASX 200 index fell 5.5 points to 5,554. New Zealand stocks, however, rose 0.4% to near two-month highs, with the NZX 50 index reaching 5,727.13. Energy and mining sectors remained under pressure, but financial stocks managed to pare losses.

images.alt_text: People walk past the display at the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) in Sydney on Sept 30, 2015. Australian shares trimmed earlier losses to close a touch lower on Wednesday, while New Zealand stocks ended the session near two-month highs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall, tracking global and China markets
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.7% on Wednesday, tracking global markets, as investor sentiment was dampened by China's deflationary pressure and September inflation data. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 22,439.91 points, while the China Enterprises Index fell 1.0% to 10,334.42 points. Most sectors declined, with financial and commodity-related stocks leading the way, reflecting lingering concerns over the economy's state.

site_title: China central bank shrugs off quantitative easing talk
summary: China's central bank has expanded a pilot relending scheme to help small firms and the farming sector, but it's not a policy of quantitative easing, according to the People's Bank of China's chief economist Ma Jun. The plan, which allows commercial banks to lend using high-quality credit assets, won't significantly impact overall liquidity and isn't the Chinese version of QE. Markets have been misinterpreting the move, which aims to support economic growth and stability.

images.alt_text: A plan by China's central bank to expand a pilot relending scheme to help small firms and the farming sector cannot be interpreted as a policy of quantitative easing, the chief economist at the People's Bank of China said on Wednesday.

site_title: IE Singapore: Public-private partnership viable model for companies keen on Jiangsu (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Public-Private Partnership (PPP) model is gaining traction in Jiangsu, China, with 13 memorandums of understanding (MOUs) signed at the 9th Singapore-Jiangsu Cooperation Council meeting. The move is seen as a key platform for Singapore companies to showcase their expertise in infrastructure, environmental services, and logistics sectors. This comes as Jiangsu, one of China's fastest-growing cities, encourages private sector involvement in infrastructure building and public utility projects. The partnership promotes strong economic relations between Singapore and Jiangsu, enabling both sides to deepen collaborations.

site_title: Update: Cathay Pacific suspends flights over Iran after missile warning
summary: Cathay Pacific has suspended flights over Iran and the Caspian Sea until further notice due to missile warnings from the European Aviation Safety Agency. The EASA warned of missiles fired at Syria from the Caspian Sea, crossing over Iran and Iraq. This move comes as Russia intensifies its air campaign against Islamic militants in Syria. Other airlines, including Singapore Airlines and Qantas, have not suspended flights over the area, citing safety advisories and their own safety assessments.

site_title: China: Stocks hit by profit-taking, inflation data has little impact
summary: China's stocks fell 1.1% on Wednesday, with the CSI300 index dropping to 3,406.11, amid profit-taking after strong recent gains. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.0% to 3,262.44 points, despite September inflation data showing the economy remains under deflationary pressure. Consumer price index rose 1.6% and producer prices slid for the 43rd straight month. The decline followed a 4-session gain of 8% and a net outflow in the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme.

site_title: Tokyo chief vows Olympic stadium on track
summary: Tokyo's Olympic stadium, originally designed by Zaha Hadid, will be completed on schedule for the 2020 games, according to Tokyo Governor Yoichi Masuzoe. The stadium was canceled due to high costs and design criticism, and a cheaper alternative will be built instead. Masuzoe assured that all six new venues for the games are proceeding on schedule. London Mayor Boris Johnson praised Tokyo's efforts, attributing London's 2012 Olympics success to competent communication among government departments. The city faces concerns about hosting the games in the summer due to heat, but Masuzoe is confident authorities can keep athletes and spectators cool.

site_title: Westpac's rates rise piles pressure on Australia's central bank
summary: Australian banking giant Westpac has raised A$3.5 billion in capital and increased home loan interest rates by 20 basis points per annum, likely increasing pressure on the central bank to loosen monetary policy. This move is in response to tougher regulations requiring banks to hold more capital reserves. The Reserve Bank of Australia may be forced to cut the cash rate from 2% to 1.75% to offset the higher funding costs the banks now face, according to analysts.

site_title: Dollar weakens against yen on demand for safer assets
summary: The US dollar weakened against the yen on Wednesday, trading at 119.68 yen, amid expectations a US interest rate rise will be delayed and demand for safer assets increased due to volatile oil prices and concerns about China's economy. The dollar had been rallying earlier in the year on interest rate expectations, but central bank policy makers have turned dovish, helping emerging markets currencies. Analysts say risk aversion is prompting investors to buy back funding currencies like the euro and yen, and a sustained recovery in risk appetite could take time.

site_title: Singapore dollar gains as central bank signals easing limit
summary: Singapore's dollar surged 0.9% to its strongest level since September 18, following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's decision to slightly reduce the pace of appreciation. New Zealand's dollar also rose 0.6% after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand signaled a limited willingness to cut interest rates. The moves were seen as a response to the narrowing of Singapore's technical recession and a slowdown in global growth. The Singapore dollar outperformed other major currencies, while the yen and euro advanced amid declining oil prices and risk aversion.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall as foreigners' 5-day buying streak ends; won edges up
summary: Seoul shares fell 0.5% to 2,009.55 points, led by chemical and refinery counters, as foreigners snapped a five-day buying streak and sold a net 100 billion won worth of shares. The South Korean won edged up 0.3% to 1,146.8 per dollar, with a foreign exchange official noting it has fallen less against the dollar than other major currencies in recent months.

site_title: Gold rallies for fourth day on hopes of delay in Fed rate hike
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to a three-month high of $1,172.40 an ounce, extending a fourth consecutive gain, due to a weaker dollar and comments from Federal Reserve officials cautioning against a rate hike this year. The market shift in expectations of a US rate hike to 2016 and a weaker dollar have boosted gold prices.

site_title: Oil prices subdued in volatile Asian trade
summary: Oil prices were subdued in Asian trade on Wednesday, influenced by the IEA's report on global crude oversupply. US West Texas Intermediate rose 4% to $46.68, while Brent crude declined 0.16% to $49.16. The market digested the report, which predicted oversupply would persist until next year, amid volatile trading.

site_title: NYC airports among worst for controller shortage, union says
summary: The National Air Traffic Controllers Association (NATCA) has warned that US air-traffic staffing is at a 27-year low, threatening to increase flight delays in the New York region. The FAA's facility guiding aircraft into New York's three commercial airports has reached the lowest level of fully trained controllers in 25 years, due to retirements, budgetary uncertainty, and bureaucratic failures. The union is calling for Congress to hold a hearing on staffing and for the FAA to hire more controllers to meet staffing needs, which have been delayed due to budget cuts and a temporary shutdown of the controller training academy.

site_title: Singapore shares close unchanged
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore ended unchanged at 2,983.92 on October 14, 2015, following a Wall Street slide. Local banks lost ground, but bluechip counters such as Global Logistic Properties and Singtel supported the index. Trading volume was 1.03 billion shares worth S$906.9 million at an average unit price of S$0.88 per share.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore avoids technical recession in Q3; growth outlook still weak
summary: Singapore's economy narrowly avoided a technical recession in Q3 with a 1.4% gross domestic product (GDP) growth from a year ago, driven by a 0.8% growth in the services sector. Despite this, economists remain cautious, citing strong external headwinds and domestic restructuring challenges. Manufacturing contracted 6% in Q3, while construction and services sectors grew 1.6% and 0.8% respectively. Growth outlook remains weak, with economists revising their forecasts, including a 2% 2015 growth forecast and a downward revision of their inflation forecast.

site_title: Jamaican Marlon James's Bob Marley novel wins Man Booker prize
summary: Marlon James, a Jamaican author, won the Man Booker prize for his 686-page novel "A Brief History of Seven Killings". The novel tells the story of a failed attempt to kill reggae star Bob Marley in 1976, set against the backdrop of Jamaica's literary tradition. James, 44, became the first Jamaican to win the award, stating that he hopes more Caribbean writers will follow and brings attention to the region's literary scene.

site_title: Private condo rents dip 0.3% in Sept; HDB rents flat: SRX
summary: Private condo rents in Singapore declined 0.3% in September, the second consecutive month, due to weak leasing conditions. However, rental volume dipped only 4.1% compared to August. HDB rents remained unchanged in September, with some flats experiencing declines, while others saw increases. Overall, year-on-year, rents are 5.6% lower than September 2014, and 13% lower than the peak in January 2013.

site_title: Japan government cuts economic assessment as output sags
summary: Japan's government lowered its economic assessment, citing output sagging and factory activity contracting. Industrial production declined, and inventories rose, raising concerns about the economy's recovery. The assessment downgrade increases pressure on the Bank of Japan's monetary policy meeting at the end of the month and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic policies. The government's monthly economic report notes a gradual recovery trend, but pockets of weakness, including weakening exports and stagnant consumer spending. This move may prompt the Bank of Japan to consider expanding its quantitative easing program.

site_title: Japan Post's IPO said to be fully subscribed after two days
summary: Japan Post's initial public offering (IPO) has been fully subscribed after two days, with investor orders exceeding the number of shares being offered. The IPO is expected to raise at least $14 billion, with demand potentially allowing Japan Post to price the offering at the top end of the range. The move is part of Japan's government's plan to privatize the postal service, with 80% of the shares being offered to Japanese investors. The IPO will be used to fund reconstruction efforts following the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, as well as to diversify the company's assets.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks dip at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks fell at the open on October 14, 2015, due to China growth worries sparked by weak trade data. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong dropped 0.89% to 22,398.82, while the Shanghai composite index slid 0.40% to 3,280.02. Traders await consumer price data later in the day.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to import 3.5 million tonnes of wheat in 2016
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to import 3.5 million tonnes of wheat in 2016, its main wheat-buying agency, the General Silos and Flour Mills Organisation (GSFMO), announced. This marks a significant increase from the 420,000 tonnes of locally produced wheat in 2015, as the country aims to save water by relying on imports. Saudi Arabia has been reducing wheat cultivation since 2008, and its demand is expected to grow at an annual rate of 3.2 percent, reaching 4.5 million tonnes by 2025.

site_title: More than US$200b worth of oil and natural gas assets for sale
summary: More than US$200 billion worth of oil and natural gas assets are for sale globally as companies face financial pressure from the prolonged commodity price rout. According to IHS Inc., there are about 400 buying opportunities as companies sell assets to meet debt requirements. Low oil prices have slashed profits, with West Texas Intermediate crude averaging around US$51 a barrel this year, down 40% from the five-year mean. Companies with strong balance sheets are seeking buying opportunities, with predictions that prices may rise to around US$55 a barrel by next year and US$70 a barrel by 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks start the day lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.70% lower on October 14, 2015, following a negative lead on Wall Street amid concerns about China's economy. The Nikkei 225 index lost 128.08 points to 18,106.66 in the first minutes of trade. Trading remained tepid, with worries about China's economic slowdown affecting global markets.

site_title: Ebook antitrust monitor to end imposed stint at Apple
summary: An antitrust monitor imposed on Apple following an e-book price-fixing case will end his two-year stint on Friday, according to a judge's ruling. The monitor, who performed a "significant public service" in a challenging environment, will not have his term extended. Apple agreed to pay $450 million in compensation in 2013, contingent on its appeal, and has since revamped its antitrust compliance programme. The monitor's departure comes after a finding of guilt by US District Court Judge Denise Cote in 2013, which was upheld by the US Court of Appeals.

site_title: Noble Group CEO says he should have pushed transparency harder
summary: Noble Group CEO Yusuf Alireza stated that he should have pushed for greater transparency to counter criticism of the company's accounting practices. The Singapore-listed commodities trader faced a significant stock slump after being criticized by Iceberg Research in February. Alireza suggested that more transparency would have reduced the company's exposure, but it was a challenge due to competitors' private status. Noble's stock rose 3.2% on the day after Alireza's comments, but remains 58% below its mid-February peak.

site_title: Thai 2015 auto sales to miss target again
summary: Thai auto sales are expected to reach 750,000 to 800,000 cars this year, down from a previous target of 950,000, due to slowing economic growth and increased caution from banks. This marks the second consecutive year that Thai auto sales are expected to miss the target. Last year's sales totalled 881,832 vehicles, with an estimated export of 1.2 million vehicles for the year.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened down 0.08% at 2,982.57 on Wednesday, with 53.3 million shares worth S$125.9 million traded as of 9:01am. Losers outnumbered gainers 68 to 57, following a decline in US equities and concern over China's economic slowdown.

site_title: China Sept consumer inflation cooler than expected
summary: China's consumer inflation eased more than expected in September, rising 1.6% from a year earlier, lower than the 1.8% forecast. Producer prices fell 5.9% for the 43rd straight month, adding to deflationary pressures in the world's second-largest economy. This decline in inflation and producer prices raises concerns for policymakers, who may need to take action to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Credit Suisse seeks banks to work on fundraising: Handelsblatt
summary: Credit Suisse has invited international banks to work on the Swiss bank's potential fundraising, which is expected to be substantial to fund a restructuring of the bank. New CEO Tidjane Thiam will provide details next week, following a shift in focus towards banking for the world's wealthy, particularly in Asia.

site_title: ACRA introduces framework to improve audit quality in Singapore
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) in Singapore has introduced the Audit Quality Indicators (AQIs) Disclosure Framework, marking the first time the big-four audit firms have agreed to provide comparable indicators on audit quality to listed companies. The framework consists of eight quality markers, including hours spent by senior audit team members and results from internal and external inspections, to help audit committees evaluate and select the right auditors. This move aims to improve audit quality in Singapore and enhance transparency for investors.

site_title: Rinehart wins royalty court battle with Rio Tinto
summary: Billionaire Gina Rinehart won an appeal in Australia's High Court, requiring Rio Tinto to pay royalties from two iron ore mines in the Pilbara region. The court ruled that Rio's Mount Bruce Mining unit is liable to pay 2.5% royalties to Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting and Wright Prospecting from the Eastern Range and Channar mines. The decision reverses an earlier Supreme Court judgment, which found royalties were payable from Eastern Range but not Channar. The total royalty payment is estimated to be around US$200 million.

site_title: Quick takes: MAS disappoints calls for more aggressive S$ easing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased monetary policy slightly, reducing the slope of the Singapore dollar policy band by half a percentage point, in line with market expectations. The decision disappointed calls for a more aggressive easing stroke, with economists citing a cautious approach to avoid a faster appreciation of the Singapore dollar. The MAS stated that the easing is in line with the current underlying fundamentals, but risks remain, including potential capital flight from higher US interest rates and a global economic outlook.

site_title: MAS keeps S$ on appreciating path, but at slightly reduced pace
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has maintained its policy of a "modest and gradual" appreciation of the S$NEER band, but at a slightly reduced pace. The policy band's width and centre level remain unchanged. The MAS projects a modest pace of economic growth in 2015 and 2016, with core inflation expected to pick up gradually towards its historical average. This adjustment aims to support economic growth while maintaining price stability in the medium term.

site_title: China Agricultural Bank sells US$1b debut "green bond" in London
summary: China's Agricultural Bank of China sold its debut $1 billion "green bond" in London, marking the first such bond from a Chinese bank. The 2-year yuan-denominated bond was priced at 4.15% and will fund environment-friendly projects. This is the latest move by Chinese banks to tap the growing green bond market as countries tackle climate change and pollution.

site_title: Mini-marts boom as Vietnam's shoppers shift spending patterns
summary: Vietnam is experiencing a mini-boom in mini-marts, with over 260% growth since 2012, as consumers seek convenience and longer hours. Convenience stores now account for less than 10% of the market, compared to 20% in other countries. Major players like Vingroup, 7-Eleven, and FamilyMart are expanding their presence, with plans to open over 2,000, 1,000, and 100 stores, respectively. This contrasts with a 3% growth in supermarkets, which remains the preferred channel for 62% of shoppers. The expansion is driven by the growing middle class and retail sector.

site_title: Oversupply, tighter lending threaten Korea's property market
summary: South Korea's property market, a key economic bright spot, may be nearing an end due to an oversupply of new homes and tighter lending rules. The market has been fueled by record-low interest rates and a surge in household debt, leading to a record 816,000 housing transactions in the first eight months of 2015. However, concerns over oversupply and loan growth have prompted the government to implement stricter lending standards, which could curb the market's growth.

site_title: Apple loses patent lawsuit to University of Wisconsin, faces hefty damages
summary: A US jury found Apple used technology owned by the University of Wisconsin-Madison without permission in its iPhone and iPad devices, potentially leading to $862 million in damages. The jury deemed the patent, which improves processor efficiency, valid. Apple had denied infringement and argued the patent was invalid. The trial will proceed in three phases to determine the extent of Apple's liability and potential enhancements.

site_title: Fed divisions exposed as Tarullo says he doesn't back 2015 hike
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Daniel Tarullo expressed disagreement with Chair Janet Yellen's plan to raise interest rates by year-end, citing a lack of justification. Tarullo's dovish stance, shared by Governor Lael Brainard, contradicts the majority of the Federal Open Market Committee members, including Yellen. This sharp disagreement sets the stage for a robust debate at the Fed's upcoming policy meetings, potentially challenging Yellen's leadership and consensus on interest rate hikes.

site_title: Update: MAS slows rate of S$ appreciation, sees 2016 GDP growth at around 2-2.5%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased its Singapore dollar policy for the second time this year, narrowing 2015 inflation forecasts to the lower end of expectations. MAS now sees core inflation and headline inflation at around 0.5% and -0.5% respectively for 2015, with core inflation expected to "rise gradually" towards 2% in 2016. The central bank also lowered its GDP growth forecast to 2-2.5% for 2015, citing a "slightly weaker" economic growth than earlier envisaged.

site_title: Brazil's next big crisis scaring bankers, wiping out jobs
summary: Brazil is facing a rapidly deteriorating labor market, with unemployment rising to 7.6% from 4.3% in 2014. The country is losing almost 20,000 jobs per month, mainly in the industrial sector, threatening to deepen the recession and leave millions of Brazilians struggling to repay loans. The situation has sparked concerns among bankers, who fear it could drive up loan defaults and intensify the economic crisis. Experts predict the economy will shrink 3% this year and unemployment will top 10% by 2016, marking a significant fall from Brazil's emergence as a key engine for global growth after the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Singapore economy grew 1.4% from a year ago in Q3
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.4% in Q3, narrowly avoiding a technical recession. The manufacturing sector contracted 6.0%, while the construction sector expanded 1.6%. The services sector grew 3.0% year-on-year, slower than the previous quarter. The economy's growth is a slight beat of market expectations. A technical recession was narrowly avoided, and the economy is expected to be released in full in November's Economic Survey of Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singapore's economy performed slightly better than market's expectations in the third quarter, with the gross domestic product (GDP) growing by 1.4 per cent from a year ago, according to preliminary estimates released by the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Wednesday.

site_title: Brazil currency rout spurs bean export
summary: Brazil's currency devaluation has led to a surge in exports of robusta coffee, as farmers can undercut Vietnamese suppliers. The Brazilian real's 36% drop in the past year has reduced production costs, while Vietnam's dong has fallen less, making Brazilian beans more competitive. Brazilian exports of robusta coffee jumped 53% to a record 3.08 million bags in the first eight months of 2015, while Vietnamese shipments declined 31%. US and European importers are buying Brazilian beans at a lower cost, shifting demand away from Vietnam.

site_title: Facebook to ramp up video viewing features
summary: Facebook is testing new video viewing features to increase user engagement and challenge YouTube. The new tools include a suggested videos feature, a "save" button for later viewing, and a dedicated stage for video watching. The suggested videos feature displays related clips after a user views a video, while the "save" button allows users to save videos for later. These features aim to encourage users to watch more videos on the platform, with initial results showing users discovering and watching more new videos.

site_title: Australia consumer confidence rebounds, upbeat on jobs
summary: Australian consumer confidence rebounded in October, rising 4.2% seasonally adjusted, according to a survey of 1,200 people by the Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank. The index of consumer sentiment reached 97.8, 3.2% higher than last year, with optimism about jobs and economic conditions improving. Job prospects showed its strongest level in almost four years, while confidence among supporters of the ruling Liberal National Party fell. The survey's measures on family finances and major household items also improved, with a 6.3% increase in the index of whether it was a good time to buy.

site_title: Asia stocks follow US shares lower
summary: Asia stocks declined for a second day, following a drop in US equities. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell 0.4% as investors awaited Chinese inflation data amid concerns about China's slowdown. Global stocks snapped their longest rally since February, with the Standard & Poor's 500 Index falling. Investors are watching for Wednesday's inflation data to gauge its impact on the global economy. The decline in Asian stocks was led by Japan's Topix index, which fell 0.8%, and South Korea's Kospi index, which slid 0.3%.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia: Markets closed on Wednesday
summary: Financial markets in Indonesia and Malaysia are closed on Wednesday due to public holidays. Meanwhile, in Europe, stocks fell with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. US stocks also edged down from records amid concerns over US-EU tariffs. In Asia, traders are optimistic despite new Trump threats, and Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Copper mine spending to sink below financial-crisis levels
summary: Copper mining investment is expected to drop to US$11.1 billion in 2016, the lowest level since 2007, according to Citigroup data. This represents a 50% decrease from the 2012 high. The decline follows a 15-fold increase in investment over the previous decade, driven by China's demand surge and rising prices. The decrease is seen as vindication for long-term copper bulls.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate's placement tranche of retail bonds oversubscribed
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' placement tranche of up to S$100 million retail bonds for three years with a fixed interest of 4.65% per annum was oversubscribed with approximately S$130 million received. Despite increasing the limit to S$100 million, demand remained high. The oversubscription demonstrates investors' confidence in the company's quality portfolio and balance sheet. The issuer may increase the total offer size to up to S$300 million, with the retail bonds expected to be issued on October 23 and commence trading on October 26.

site_title: Airbus likely to increase production in Mobile, Alabama plant: mayor
summary: Airbus is likely to increase production at its Mobile, Alabama plant to meet its backlog of 5,502 A320-family orders. The factory, which opened last month, is expected to produce up to eight single-aisle jetliners a month, a significant increase from its current target of four. This move aims to help Airbus work through its backlog and meet growing demand for new aircraft. Airbus plans to build four A320-family aircraft a month at the factory by 2017, and has already announced plans to increase global A320 production to 46 a month next year.

site_title: Singapore 2015 GDP growth forecast kept at 2-2.5%, risks 'tilted towards downside': MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has maintained its 2015 GDP growth forecast at 2-2.5% but warned that risks are tilted towards the downside due to subdued global growth. External-oriented sectors are expected to be dragged down, while domestic-oriented sectors, such as healthcare and education services, will expand at a moderate pace. The MAS also expects inflation to come in at around -0.5% in 2015 and -0.5-0.5% in 2016.

images.alt_text: Although full-year 2015 gross domestic product (GDP) growth estimates have been maintained at 2-2.5 per cent, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) cautioned that "risks are tilted towards the downside".

site_title: Magazine group to guarantee performance of print ads
summary: A US magazine trade group, Association of Magazine Media, has introduced a performance guarantee for print ads, aiming to counter the growth of digital media. The "money- or space-back guarantee" promises advertisers that their print ads will connect with consumers and boost sales. Research shows that magazine marketing is more effective than TV or online ads, especially when combined with other media. The guarantee covers 60% of ad dollars spent across media, including food, beauty, and retail products.

site_title: CapitaLand confirms talks with Asia Square Tower 1 vendor
summary: CapitaLand confirms talks with the vendor of Asia Square Tower 1 for a potential transaction, with negotiations ongoing. The real estate company expects to finance the potential deal using internal sources and available credit lines. As of June 30, CapitaLand has approximately S$3.5 billion in cash and S$3.1 billion in available undrawn facilities. There is no certainty that a transaction will materialize or a definitive agreement will be reached.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses
summary: Oil prices continued their decline, falling 44 cents to $46.66 a barrel for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 62 cents to $49.24 a barrel for Brent North Sea crude. The IEA predicted a global oversupply through 2016, with world demand growth slowing to 1.2 million barrels per day. Oil imports in China plummeted 20.4% in September, but still showed a 10% year-over-year growth. The market weighed the latest trade data and the risk of an ongoing physical surplus through 2016.

site_title: Canada needs to collect data on foreign homebuyers
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc has urged Canada to collect data on foreign homebuyers, citing their significant influence on rising home prices in Vancouver and Toronto. Asian demand for Canadian real estate, particularly from China, is driving up prices, with average home prices in Toronto and Vancouver increasing by 10% and 22% respectively. The lack of data on foreign real estate purchases has become a political issue, with the Canadian government considering regulation. Prime Minister Stephen Harper has promised to collect data and impose regulation if he wins the election.

site_title: Rebound in emerging markets 'too upbeat'
summary: Emerging markets' rebound is deemed too optimistic due to volatile currencies and weak fundamentals. Experts cite US interest rate hikes and commodity oversupply as major factors. A recent stock market rebound is expected to be short-lived, with markets facing a reality check when US companies report earnings and the Fed hikes rates. Increased volatility has led to increased demand for hedging and advisory services, with some banks advising clients to pay to exit risk and enter fixed rates.

site_title: Britain completes Royal Mail privatisation
summary: Britain completed the privatisation of Royal Mail, selling a 13% stake to institutional investors for £591 million (S$1.26 billion) and gifting another 1% to eligible employees. This sale, part of a £3.3 billion privatisation program, aims to pay down national debt. Critics, including the Communication Workers Union, accuse the government of selling the company too cheaply. The sale marks a milestone in the postal group's history, with British finance minister George Osborne stating that every penny will be used to reduce national debt.

site_title: Australia's Westpac unveils US$2.5b rights issue
summary: Westpac Banking Corp has announced a US$2.54 billion rights issue to meet stricter capital rules, raising A$3.5 billion. The move comes after the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority increased cash buffers against mortgage books amid concerns of a house price bubble. Westpac's common equity Tier-1 ratio will increase to over 14% on an internationally comparable basis. The bank has also raised home loan rates by 20 basis points, effective November 20, with analysts expecting other major banks to follow suit.

site_title: Ireland to introduce new OECD-compliant tax scheme
summary: Ireland has introduced a new OECD-compliant tax scheme, the "Knowledge Development Box," offering a 6.25% corporate tax rate for intellectual property research projects. This move aims to attract investment while closing the "Double Irish" tax loophole. The tax incentive applies to earnings from research and development projects in Ireland, subject to a reduced 6.25% corporation tax rate. This scheme replaces the existing low tax rate and is designed to promote innovation and investment in the country.

site_title: Coca-Cola, PepsiCo spar over Chobani stake: source
summary: US soda giants Coca-Cola and PepsiCo are competing for a minority stake in Greek yogurt maker Chobani, with investment bank Goldman Sachs overseeing the sale of 10-20% of the company's shares. The deal could value Chobani at over $3 billion and help the yogurt maker develop its international business. Chobani, founded in 2007, now holds 44% of the US$8 billion Greek yogurt market. The move comes as Coca-Cola and PepsiCo seek new growth opportunities due to declining soda sales, with analysts noting a "secular" decline in conventional soda.

site_title: OCBC's wealth management business growing steadily
summary: OCBC Bank's wealth management business has seen steady growth, with income and assets under management (AUM) increasing by double digits per year for the past five years. The business expects to reach a record S$2.6 billion in income this year, accounting for 30% of the bank's group income. Growth is driven by China's opening up, with OCBC leveraging its private bank unit, asset management arm, and insurer Great Eastern to capitalize on opportunities. The bank's core markets include Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Greater China, with a vast network serving wealthy businesspeople in Asia.

site_title: Global steel protests seen stemming flood of China exports
summary: Global steel protests are expected to peak this year due to China's flood of cheap steel exports, which have damaged mills' profits worldwide. Over 20 trade cases have been lodged against China's steel exports, with seven from South-east Asia. China's efforts to curb local steel output to protect the environment may also limit overseas sales. The South East Asia Iron & Steel Institute estimates 300 million tonnes of excess capacity in China, leading to a surge in exports that has sparked trade tensions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SPH Reit reported Q4 2015 results within expectations, with revenue and dividend per unit at 99.6% and 101.6% of full-year projections, respectively. The company's gearing remained healthy at 25.7%. Meanwhile, Malaysia's palm oil output was in line with forecasts, but exports are expected to ease month on month. Plantation company Wilmar is recommended for its Indonesia B15 programme benefits and recent sugar price recovery. CIMB Research upgraded Ezion, Keppel, and Pacific Radiance due to their resilience in the oil tumult, despite sector challenges.

site_title: Dollar slips on signs of weakening global economy
summary: The US dollar slipped against major currencies after weak economic data from China and Europe bolstered prospects of a delayed Federal Reserve interest rate hike. China's imports plunged 20%, British inflation fell below zero, and German investor sentiment hit a 1-year low. The euro rose to $1.1381 despite Germany's gloomy sentiment, while the pound sold off after negative inflation in Britain. Economists expect the Bank of England to hold off a rate hike, and the Fed is likely to keep interest rates steady in two weeks.

site_title: Growth of household wealth hits a snag: Credit Suisse
summary: Household wealth in Singapore has plateaued, with total wealth declining 5.8% in US dollars from mid-2014 to mid-2015, but rising 1.8% in domestic currency terms. Despite this, average wealth per adult has increased 140% to US$269,400, making Singapore the 8th richest country globally. The report attributes the growth to high savings and asset price movements from 2005 to 2012. Inequality remains moderate, with 10% of the population having wealth below US$10,000.

site_title: Fast track to leadership
summary: Many professional service companies, such as Deloitte, are placing high-potential individuals on leadership development programs. These programs aim to groom individuals for future leadership roles. However, the article does not provide specific details on Deloitte's development tracks or the companies that offer similar programs. It appears to be unrelated to the provided article content.

site_title: Lian Beng Q1 rides on devt business
summary: Lian Beng Group, a Singaporean construction firm, reported a 169.5% increase in Q1 net profit to S$32.3 million, driven by recognition of profits from development projects. Revenue fell 19.1% to S$135.6 million, while gross profit dropped 8.5%. The company has maintained a healthy cash level and is cautiously optimistic on the construction market outlook. Lian Beng aims to diversify into development, property investment, and construction-related businesses to balance its project-based construction and property development businesses.

site_title: Twitter to cut 8% of workforce, refocus under Dorsey
summary: Twitter is cutting 336 jobs, approximately 8% of its workforce, as part of a restructuring effort under new CEO Jack Dorsey. The layoffs aim to refocus the company on growth and user engagement, with Dorsey outlining a "roadmap" to boost revenues. The company has struggled to expand its user base above 300 million, lagging rival networks like Instagram and Facebook. Twitter's shares rose 1% after the announcement, with analysts expressing optimism about the move, citing Dorsey's talent and the need for changes to engage users.

site_title: JPMorgan earnings lifted by tax benefits
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a 22.3% increase in third-quarter earnings to $6.8 billion, driven by a large tax gain. Revenues fell 6.4% to $23.54 billion, with the corporate and investment bank segment down 12.9% due to lower fixed-income trading revenues. The bank attributed the earnings boost to a tax benefit, which partially offset weaker performance in other businesses.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has fully leased two development projects in Japan, GLP Atsugi II and GLP Sayama-Hidaka I, ahead of their completion. GLP Atsugi II, a 74,000 sqm facility, will be leased to a leading retailer and 3PL service provider, while GLP Sayama-Hidaka I, a 40,000 sqm facility, has been leased to a global automotive corporation. CEFC International expects to report a "significant return to profit" in the second quarter due to new revenue sources.

site_title: US:Wall St declines on China fears
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow snapping a seven-day winning streak, due to renewed fears of slowing growth in China and another bout of selling in biotech shares. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 49.97 points, or 0.29 percent, to 17,081.89. Earnings reports are expected to show a nearly 5 percent year-over-year drop in S&P 500 companies, leading to cautious sentiment. China's imports fell 20 percent in September, indicating weak domestic demand and sputtering growth.

site_title: Property flipping frenzy in Sydney spurs warnings of overheating
summary: A property flipping frenzy is underway in Sydney, Australia, with investors buying and renovating homes to sell for quick profits, sparking warnings of an overheated market. Since September 2013, over 1,500 houses and 800 apartments have been resold in less than a year, with prices rising 44% in the past three years. Regulators, including the Reserve Bank of Australia, have expressed concerns about the market's sustainability, citing record debt levels and the risk of a housing bubble. Experts predict a slowdown in the market, with some forecasting a 5% annual increase in residential values next year.

site_title: ExxonMobil to start LNG equity trading in Singapore
summary: ExxonMobil is setting up a new arm in Singapore to market liquefied natural gas (LNG) from its own projects, creating new roles for specialized personnel. The move is expected to deepen Singapore's position as an LNG marketplace and increase the expertise of people in this segment. ExxonMobil has previously established a PNG LNG marketing team and an LNG operations team in Singapore, and will market LNG from projects in Western Canada, Alaska, Scarborough, and Tanzania. The company chose Singapore for its supportive business environment and strategic location.

images.alt_text: Gan Seow Kee, Chairman and Managing Director, ExxonMobil Asia Pacific Pte Ltd.

site_title: Playboy magazine cleans up for a social media generation
summary: Playboy magazine is revamping its content to adapt to the digital age. The libertarian founder Hugh Hefner has given the green light to relaunch the magazine in March, removing full nudity but still featuring women in provocative poses. The redesign aims to compete with startups like Vice, targeting young men in cities with a mix of sex-positive content, investigative journalism, and fiction. The magazine's circulation has dropped from 5.6 million in 1975 to 800,000 now, and its executives acknowledge that the rise of digital pornography has made it difficult for print magazines to remain relevant.

site_title: Fed should have the courage to act
summary: The article discusses the US Federal Reserve's inaction on interest rates, despite the economy gathering steam. Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke's memoir "The Courage to Act" highlights the Fed's bold actions during the 2008 subprime crisis, which prevented a Great Depression. However, the current Fed has failed to act, instead citing concerns over China's economic health and the potential impact on emerging markets. This has led to a market expectation of no rate hikes this year, with interest rates currently priced in at 10% for October and 38.8% for December. The article concludes that the Fed's inaction may be due to a desire to maintain easy monetary policies and avoid market volatility.

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare said to be planning US$300m S'pore IPO
summary: Fullerton Healthcare Corp, a Singapore-based medical services provider, is planning a US$300 million initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore, with JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley, and UBS Group AG as lead bankers. The IPO, which may take place next year, aims to raise funds for the company's expansion in Asia. This move is part of Fullerton Healthcare's efforts to strengthen its position in the region's corporate healthcare market.

site_title: SPH FY15 profit falls 20.4% on lower property valuation gains
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 20.4% drop in net profit to $321.7 million for the year ended August 31, 2015, due to lower property valuation gains. The media company's recurring operating profit rose 1.3% to $353.5 million, driven by its property business, which saw a 12.6% increase in operating revenue. SPH proposed a final dividend of 13 cents per share and plans to grow its property portfolio, with CEO Alan Chan stating that digital revenue is growing at double-digits.

site_title: Banks pursue fintech geeks in awkward embrace
summary: Banks are embracing fintech companies, acknowledging their potential to disrupt traditional banking services with faster and more convenient offerings. Executives, such as Oliver Bussmann and Michael Gorriz, are now viewing fintechs as collaborators rather than competitors, citing the need for collaboration to stay competitive. Despite regulatory hurdles, banks are open to partnerships and are recognizing the value of fintechs in creating personalized experiences and leveraging data to improve customer outcomes.

site_title: 3-D printed aircraft parts help Arcam to take off
summary: Arcam AB, a Swedish 3D printer manufacturer, is experiencing rapid growth due to its technology being adopted by major aircraft and engine makers, including General Electric Co, Pratt & Whitney Holdings LLC, and Rolls Royce Holdings plc. The company's CEO, Magnus Rene, stated that the industry's shift towards using 3D printing for parts was unexpected, but Arcam is now preparing for increased demand. With new customers and orders, Arcam may struggle to keep up with production. The company's focus on 3D printing of medical implants has shifted to meet the aerospace industry's needs.

site_title: Singapore plays lobbying role on SWIFT board
summary: Singapore has maintained a unique position on the SWIFT board, representing 12 economies including Malaysia, Indonesia, and Hong Kong, for over a decade. Singapore's Neo Bock Cheng serves as an ambassador to relay the challenges faced by emerging economies in adhering to SWIFT's payment standards.

site_title: Apple co-founder Wozniak serves as Steve Jobs' conscience
summary: Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak denied that scenes in the movie "Steve Jobs" starring Seth Rogen were based on real events. Wozniak claimed that Rogen's character "said things I could never say" and that everything in the film was fiction. Wozniak did consult for the film and met with screenwriter Aaron Sorkin, but said he never read Walter Isaacson's biography that the movie is based on. Despite the inaccuracies, Wozniak praised the film as the best depiction of Apple yet, stating he's seen it three times.

site_title: Hazing, drinking deaths at Asian-American fraternities raise concerns
summary: A growing number of Asian-American fraternities and sororities have been linked to hazing-related deaths and injuries, sparking concerns about the prevalence of such incidents. At least three students have died and many more have been injured since 2005, with some organizations implementing measures to prevent hazing. Despite this, incidents continue to occur, with Syracuse University's Nu Alpha Phi fraternity facing charges for hazing-related mistreatment of pledges. The issue has raised questions about the prevalence of hazing in all Greek organizations, with experts calling for increased training and accountability.

site_title: Witches and thrones: Indian animators cash in on special effects boom
summary: India's animation industry generated 44.9 billion rupees (S$965 million) in revenue in 2014, a 13% increase from the previous year. The industry is expected to double in size to 95.5 billion rupees within five years, driven by low-cost, English-speaking animators familiar with Western culture. Indian animators have worked on prominent visual effects for Hollywood hits like "Game of Thrones," "Maleficent," and "How to Train Your Dragon," with major studios investing in Indian animation units and acquiring local studios to tap into the talent pool.

site_title: Cross-border yuan rules now cover all of Suzhou, Tianjin
summary: Singapore and China agreed on new initiatives to broaden cross-border use of the renminbi (RMB), expanding existing rules to cities of Suzhou and Tianjin. Banks in Singapore can now lend to corporates in the cities and issue RMB bonds. Corporates can also repatriate 100% of RMB proceeds raised. The expansion aims to provide more financing options and increase RMB liquidity in Singapore. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Chinese authorities will relax lending rules, allowing more businesses to access offshore funding and establishing commercial relationships between banks in Singapore and China.

site_title: More sells than buys of S'pore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds sold more Singapore shares than they bought in the three months to Oct 7, with net sales of S$826.7 million compared to net purchases of S$594.5 million. In the industrial segment excluding transportation, there were net sells of S$131 million compared to net purchases of S$11.1 million. The top-selling stock was Venture Corporation with S$83 million, while China Everbright Water Ltd was the top-buying stock with S$5.3 million.

site_title: Car industry sounds alarm as EU govts weigh tougher pollution tests
summary: The European Union auto industry is sounding the alarm over proposed tougher pollution tests, warning that unrealistic tests could drive up car prices, weaken sales, and cause job losses. The tests, set to begin in September 2017, will gauge emissions of smog-causing nitrogen oxides under real driving conditions as well as in laboratories. The industry is calling for a "robust but realistic" package to avoid making diesel models unaffordable, potentially forcing manufacturers to withdraw them from sale. The EU aims for a weighted majority of governments to approve the proposal by the end of October.

site_title: AB InBev to buy SABMiller for £69b in record deal
summary: AB InBev has agreed to buy SABMiller for £69 billion, creating a brewer that will account for a third of all beer sales globally. The deal will give AB InBev control of about half the industry's profit and brands such as Peroni and Grolsch. After years of speculation, the deal was hastened by slowing economies in emerging markets and cheap credit. The acquisition will be the largest in UK history and surpass the £47 billion purchase of BG Group by Royal Dutch Shell.

site_title: US and Australia warn China on sea access
summary: The US and Australia have warned China that they remain committed to freedom of navigation in the South China Sea, amid China's construction of artificial islands in the region. Senior US officials revealed plans to sail by these islands in the coming days or weeks, drawing a line in the sand against China's maritime territorial disputes. The move aims to assert the US's commitment to the principle of freedom of navigation and challenge China's claims.

images.alt_text: The United States and its Pacific ally Australia warned China on Tuesday that they remain committed to freedom of navigation in the waters of the South China Sea.

site_title: Mood of relief after IMF/World Bank meetings, but doubts persist
summary: IMF and World Bank annual meetings in Lima concluded with a mood of relief that "Armageddon has not arrived," despite concerns over unconventional monetary policy and massive corporate debt in emerging economies. China's economy was expected to be a major topic, but officials from the IMF and World Bank offered reassurances that China's growth rate of 6-7% could maintain global growth at around 3% and avoid recession. However, warnings were also issued about liquidity crises in global financial markets and the potential for debt to stifle capital investment.

site_title: Speculation mounts over future of IMF's Christine Lagarde
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde's future is uncertain, with speculation over whether she will be extended for a second term. Despite support from some advanced and emerging economies, the US wants a non-European successor, citing a desire for greater representation. David Lipton, the US's first deputy managing director, has expressed this view, while potential candidates from emerging economies, such as Carmen Reinhart and Agustin Carstens, have also been mentioned. Lagarde's reappointment would require agreement from the IMF board, which may be influenced by the ongoing financial crisis in Europe and the US Congress's failure to ratify a quota reform agreement.

site_title: Pepsi, Coke competing for investment in Greek yogurt maker
summary: Pepsi and Coca-Cola are in talks to invest in Chobani LLC, a Greek yogurt maker, with the goal of valuing the company at $3 billion. Chobani is exploring selling a minority stake, including warrants owned by private equity firm TPG Capital, to help expand its supply chain, distribution, and manufacturing base. The deal aims to diversify the soft drink giants into the growing healthy lifestyle segment. Other companies, including Pepsi and Coca-Cola, are also in talks with Chobani about a potential investment, with no certainty of a deal being reached.

site_title: Sri Lanka calls for oil tender after Cairn India pullout
summary: Sri Lanka will issue a fresh international tender for offshore oil and gas blocks after Cairn India relinquished its exploration rights. The country will keep Cairn's seismic study worth $300 million and won't charge any penalty for pulling out. Sri Lanka will hold an international roadshow to promote blocks on its western coast of Mannar, where technology is needed to unlock potential in the area neighboring India. The move follows a one-time impairment charge on acquisition goodwill for the SL 2007-01-001 block due to declining crude oil prices.

site_title: Porsche Panamera, Mazda 6 official cars for WTA event
summary: The Eurokars Group has been named the official limousine partner of the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals in Singapore from October 25 to November 1, marking the first time a multi-franchise dealership is involved in a high-profile event.

site_title: Citi appoints first global head for IPB business
summary: Citi appoints CR Shyam Sambamurthy as the first global head for its international personal bank (IPB) business, based in Singapore. Sambamurthy will oversee the global strategy of the IPB franchise, which serves 260,000 clients with over $60 billion in assets under management. The IPB franchise has five booking centres worldwide, including in Hong Kong, Jersey, London, Singapore, and the US.

site_title: US dollar rallies in Asia after China data
summary: The US dollar rallied against emerging currencies in Asia after Chinese trade data showed a nearly 18% year-on-year decline in imports and a 1.1% drop in exports. This fueled anxiety about China's slowing economy, leading to a risk-off mood and a decline in the Indonesian rupiah and Malaysian ringgit. The greenback advanced over one percent against the rupiah, while the yen also saw a decline as investors sought safe-haven assets.

site_title: Spread your portfolio risks over companies, not countries
summary: A recent study by Morningstar Investment Management suggests that diversifying a stock portfolio by focusing on a broad mix of businesses rather than countries is more effective. Globalization has reduced the relevance of country-based diversification, as companies operate globally and have diverse workforces. Investors should prioritize sector diversification, as sector weights contribute more to earnings and corporate health than country or region. Allocating to sectors that tend to perform well during different market cycles, such as healthcare and technology, can help investors beat the market.

site_title: Colliers appoints new MD for its Singapore business
summary: Colliers International has appointed Tang Wei Leng as managing director of its Singapore business, replacing Dennis Yeo who joined CBRE in September. Tang brings 21 years of experience and a strong capital markets expertise to the role. Colliers CEO David Hand praised Tang's collaborative culture and regional outlook, expecting her to drive client success in Singapore and across Asia Pacific. Tang, who previously worked at JLL and Wachovia Bank, is committed to delivering exceptional client services and capitalizing on the evolving real estate market.

site_title: POSH set on penetrating Middle East
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings has mobilized two new construction vessels, POSH Endeavour and Enterprise, to the Persian Gulf for a five-year charter with a Saudi Arabian field operator. The company has also secured a three-year charter extension for the POSH Pelican, with a discounted day rate. POSH is accelerating its penetration of the Middle East offshore market, positioning for an eventual recovery in the oil and gas sector. The company expects to take delivery of its fourth newbuild LCV from Paxocean Zhuhai in June 2016.

site_title: SIA to revive direct US flights in 2018 using ultra-long-haul A350
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has signed an agreement with Airbus to be the launch customer of the ultra-long-range A350 variant, allowing the carrier to restore non-stop flights to the US in 2018. This move aims to strengthen SIA's Singapore hub by providing the fastest and most convenient air connectivity between North America and Southeast Asia. The A350's capabilities will enable SIA to operate the world's longest flight, a goal the airline has made public. The agreement marks a significant step towards SIA's goal of reviving direct US flights.
