summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff's campaign will be investigated for allegedly using funds from the Petrobras corruption scheme. The opposition has filed five complaints, alleging Rousseff and her running mate Michel Temer funded their campaign with donations from companies involved in the scandal. This is the first time a sitting president has been investigated by the electoral body, and Rousseff's approval rating has slid to around 10% amid a growing scandal that has tainted many government officials and executives.

site_title: Ringgit rally best since 2013 as trade data adds to oil optimism
summary: Malaysia's ringgit has experienced its largest three-day rally since 2013, with a 2.7% gain, as Brent crude rose 5.4% overnight to above $50 a barrel. The country's trade surplus widened to its highest in almost a year, beating estimates. The rally is attributed to optimism over oil prices and declining bets on a US interest-rate increase, which has boosted emerging-market currencies.

site_title: NTUC FairPrice withdraws all paper products sourced from Asia Pulp & Paper
summary: NTUC FairPrice has withdrawn all paper products sourced from Asia Pulp & Paper Group due to a temporary restriction on the "Singapore Green Label" certification for APP products. The move affects 14 Housebrand paper products and 16 APP-related products from various brands carried by FairPrice. The decision comes after the Singapore Environment Council notified APP as a suspect in contributing to the haze, prompting FairPrice to initiate meetings with parties concerned and ultimately withdraw all APP products with immediate effect.

site_title: AB InBev bids US$104b for SABMiller After offers rejected
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev) has bid $104 billion to acquire SABMiller Plc, offering 42.15 pounds a share in cash with a partial stock alternative. SABMiller rejected two previous proposals of 38 pounds and 40 pounds a share without meaningful engagement. AB InBev's latest bid is the highest, exceeding SABMiller's valuation.

site_title: China's foreign exchange reserves fall US$43.3b in Sept as central bank steps up yuan support
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves dropped $43.3 billion in September, reaching $3.514 trillion, as the central bank stepped up intervention to stabilize the yuan following a surprise devaluation. The reserves have fallen $93.9 billion in August, raising concerns about China's efforts to support the yuan amid fears of an economic slowdown and rising US interest rates. Analysts expect further declines in reserves. The yuan devaluation in August sparked global market turmoil, prompting policy makers to calm sentiment and ease concerns about a cooling economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 3.64 points to 1658.65, with a trading volume of 52.5 million lots worth RM25.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 99 to 56.

site_title: BOJ leaves policy unchanged despite signs of recession, focus on Kuroda
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its policy unchanged, despite signs of recession and weakening inflation, in its latest meeting. The central bank pledged to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen through aggressive asset purchases. Analysts expect the BOJ to ease policy further at its next meeting on October 30, citing concerns over its 2% inflation target and economic growth forecasts. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda may struggle to convince markets that the economy can recover without additional monetary support.

site_title: Singapore has sent formal request to Indonesia for names of errant firms: MFA
summary: Singapore has sent a formal request to Indonesia for the names of companies suspected of contributing to the haze in 2015. The request was made through the government-to-government channel, following a previous offer by Indonesia to provide the information. Singapore also reiterated its offer of assistance, including providing a team from the Singapore Civil Defence Force and equipment such as C-130 aircraft and a Chinook helicopter, to help Indonesia combat the haze.

site_title: Singapore to report monetary policy decision on Oct 14
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, will announce its semi-annual monetary policy decision on October 14. A majority of analysts expect the MAS to ease monetary policy due to rising recession risks and inflation concerns. This decision comes amid global economic uncertainty, with other countries facing challenges such as US tariffs, slowing China's GDP growth, and the UK's shrinking economy. The MAS's decision will likely have implications for the country's interest rates and economic outlook.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher as energy firms surge
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.24% on Wednesday, driven by a surge in energy firms as concerns about an oil glut eased. The Hang Seng Index reached 21,884.73, despite Chinese stock markets being closed for a public holiday. This upward trend follows a recent rally in other Asian markets, where traders have brushed off US President Trump's tariff threats.

images.alt_text: Energy firms helped fuel an early advance in Hong Kong stocks on Wednesday as easing concerns about an oil glut sent the price of the commodity soaring.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) edged slightly downwards on Wednesday, losing 2.56 points or 0.09% to 2,894.85 points, as 70.3 million shares worth S$77.2 million changed hands. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with gainers narrowly outnumbering losers 71 to 61. The market's performance is influenced by global economic developments, including US-EU trade talks and the ongoing rally in US stocks.

site_title: Singapore GDP will take hit from haze as countries issue travel warnings
summary: Singapore and Malaysia's economies may be affected by the ongoing haze caused by forest fires in Indonesia, with estimated losses ranging from 0.1% to 0.4% of Singapore's GDP. The haze is expected to prolong due to the strongest El Nino in two decades, potentially impacting tourism, retail spending, and the broader economy. Health costs may rise exponentially if the haze worsens, and the impact may also delay construction projects and slow factory output. The haze's effects on Indonesia itself, including its regional reputation, are also significant.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise to 2-mth highs as Samsung Elec soars; won edges down
summary: Seoul shares rose to a near two-month high on Wednesday, driven by Samsung Electronics' better-than-expected earnings guidance. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) increased 0.4% to 1,998.77 points, with Samsung Electronics surging 6% to its highest since July 31. The won edged down 0.1% against the dollar, while foreigners were net sellers, offloading 12.2 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Indonesia rupiah rises 2.5 per cent to near 7-week high
summary: Indonesia's rupiah surged 2.5% to a near seven-week high, reaching 13,900 per dollar. This marks its strongest level since August 21. Government bond prices also rose, with the 10-year yield dropping to 8.710%. Jakarta stocks gained 0.7% in the rally. The currency's increase is attributed to a combination of local economic gains and market sentiment.

site_title: China: Markets closed for National Day holiday
summary: China's stock, bond, foreign exchange, and commodity futures markets will be closed from October 1 to 7 for the National Day holiday, resuming trade on October 8.

images.alt_text: China's stock, bond, foreign exchange and commodity futures markets will be closed on October 1 to 7 for a national holiday.

site_title: LTA, Malaysia's Land Public Transport Commission launch market sensing exercise for KL-S'pore High Speed Rail
summary: Malaysia's Land Public Transport Commission (SPAD) and Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) have launched a market sensing exercise for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project. The exercise aims to gauge market interest and gather opinions from industry players on commercial and technical aspects. The RFI is expected to conclude by year-end, with feedback informing the subsequent formal tender process. The joint statement from Malaysian and Singaporean officials emphasizes the importance of industry views in refining and validating options for a successful project.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Land Public Transport Commission (SPAD) and Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) have jointly launched a market sensing exercise with a request for information (RFI) on the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR).

site_title: California adopts bill ensuring equal pay for women
summary: California Governor Jerry Brown signed the California Fair Pay Act, a bill ensuring equal pay for women, 66 years after the passage of the California Equal Pay Act. The bill prohibits paying employees less for substantially similar work and aims to close the persistent wage gap between men and women. The measure builds on existing legislation and was hailed as a major breakthrough for women, including actresses Geena Davis and Patricia Arquette, who advocated for wage equality.

site_title: SEC, Case push for key retailers to declare they do not purchase materials from firms linked to haze
summary: The Singapore Environment Council (SEC) and Consumers Association of Singapore (Case) are urging major retailers, including Dairy Farm International Holdings, Sheng Siong, and Ikea Singapore, to declare they do not purchase materials from companies linked to Indonesia's forest fires. The organizations will send declaration forms to the companies and expect responses within a week. This effort aims to promote environmentally friendly practices among retailers and encourage consumers to support brands with green procurement processes. The move is seen as a step towards reducing the impact of deforestation and haze.

site_title: Australia: Shares tread water after recent rally; NZ steady
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.2% on Wednesday, ending a brief rally, as banks and telecom stocks weighed down the market. Despite gains in resources and energy sectors, the S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,159.5 points, marking the first annual loss since 2011. The index had gained 5% over the last five sessions, but its early intraday gains were reversed. US stocks fell on Tuesday, while Asian stocks were firm due to a rebound in oil prices, with Europe and Asia markets also influenced by US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Malaysian banks race to pin down fleeing deposits
summary: Malaysian banks are experiencing a slowdown in deposit growth, with total deposits rising 4.8% in July, the lowest rate in over a decade. The slow growth is due to low interest rates of 3.1-4.0% per annum, making deposits less attractive. This, combined with a weaker economy, has led to banks operating with high loan-to-deposit ratios, potentially tightening liquidity. Analysts expect the sector-wide ratio to rise further, and banks may need to raise interest rates to attract deposits, potentially harming net interest margins.

site_title: SBF, Kadin push for businesses to follow sustainable agricultural practices
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (Kadin) are urging businesses to adopt sustainable agricultural practices to combat haze caused by forest fires in Sumatra and Kalimantan. They recommend certification to global industry standards such as RSPO, FSC, and SVLK for palm oil and pulp and paper production. The chambers also encourage businesses to buy sustainable products and adopt green procurement practices, citing the economic costs of haze, including lost productivity and health expenses. This move aims to promote responsible management of natural resources.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Olam
summary: Reports emerged about Noble Group and Olam's potential impact on share prices. Two senior US metals traders, Scott Evans and Jeff Romanek, left Noble Group amid a challenging operating environment. Noble is reducing copper exposure and focusing on aluminium and alumina. Olam expects a global coffee supply shortage due to declining stockpiles and new buyers, with prices dropping 23% this year.

site_title: Olam sees shrinking coffee supplies before Brazil's next harvest
summary: Global coffee supplies are expected to shrink before the next crop in Brazil due to eroded stockpiles and new buyers entering the market. According to Olam International Ltd, inventories will fall for at least six months, leading to a cumulative deficit of almost 10 million bags. Coffee prices fell 23% this year, and speculators are betting on lower prices, but supplies from the new crop in Brazil are expected to ease the global tightness around August 2016.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q3 profit likely up 79.8 per cent, beating expectations
summary: Samsung Electronics reported its July-September operating profit likely increased 79.8% from last year, beating expectations, marking its first quarterly profit growth in eight quarters. The company estimated a 7.3 trillion won profit, surpassing a Thomson Reuters poll estimate of 6.7 trillion won. Revenue is expected to have risen 7.5% to 51 trillion won. Samsung will disclose full results in late October.

site_title: Rio to cut Olympic costs by 10 per cent
summary: Rio de Janeiro organizers aim to cut 10% from the $2.7 billion Olympic budget to stay within financial limits amid Brazil's economic crisis. The cost-saving measures, which include downsizing and using temporary structures, are part of a broader strategy to be "efficient" rather than "modest." Despite concerns over the impact of the economic downturn, officials say preparations are on track and nearly all contracts have been fulfilled. The goal is to show the world how to host the Olympics without breaking the bank, with organizers confident they can deliver a successful event despite the challenges.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up after Sept CPI rises
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.5% to 8,435.42 points on October 7, 2015, after September's consumer price index unexpectedly accelerated for the first time in nine months due to higher food prices. The electronics subindex gained 0.6%, while the financials subindex rose 0.1%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.695 per US dollar. The decline in tourists allowed to visit Taiwan before the presidential election may have contributed to the decline in the transport and tourism sub-indices.

site_title: Givaudan opens S$100m production hub, perfumery school in Singapore
summary: Givaudan, a fragrance and flavor company, has opened a S$100 million production hub and perfumery school in Singapore, marking its largest global investment for the fragrance division. The Fragrance Creative Centre Perfumery School offers expertise in fragrance evaluation and consumer insights, serving as the region's central location for the firm's Fine Fragrance business in Asia. This move represents the first time Givaudan has set up a campus outside of France, highlighting its commitment to training and developing perfumers in Asia.

site_title: Former UN General Assembly head arrested for bribery
summary: Former UN General Assembly President John Ashe was arrested on Tuesday for taking $1.3 million in bribes from Chinese businessmen in exchange for backing a proposed UN conference center in Macau. Ashe allegedly accepted bribes from 2011 to 2014, including over $500,000, and used them to fund his personal expenses. The arrest is the first corruption scandal to hit the UN in its 70-year history, with US Attorney Preet Bharara calling it "a cancer of corruption" that has infected the global institution.

site_title: Asia: Stocks advance sixth day as Samsung jumps on profit report
summary: Asian stocks rose for the sixth consecutive day, driven by Samsung Electronics' strong quarterly profit report, which beat estimates. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.2% as Samsung's 3.8% rally provided the biggest boost. Japan's Topix index also rose 0.2% before a Bank of Japan decision on monetary policy. However, analysts expect little change in the BOJ's stimulus, and futures on the S&P 500 Index slipped 0.2% amid concerns over pharmaceutical pricing and earnings.

site_title: Japan's Abe set to keep allies in key posts as attention returns to economy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to retain close allies in key cabinet posts, including Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga and Finance Minister Taro Aso, in a cabinet reshuffle aimed at refocusing on the economy. Abe has also tapped veteran lawmakers for new portfolios, such as Motoo Hayashi for trade and industry. The move is seen as an attempt to boost his ratings after divisive security legislation, and Abe will promote Katsunobu Kato to a new post focused on promoting economic growth and women's participation.

site_title: Fantasy sports world battles 'insider trading' claims
summary: New York state Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has launched an inquiry into fantasy sports companies DraftKings and FanDuel over allegations of "insider trading". Schneiderman requested information from the companies, including names of staff with access to data that could be used to gain an advantage. The inquiry comes amid growing concerns over the need to regulate the multibillion-dollar fantasy sports industry. The move could potentially impact the companies' operations and highlight the need for better oversight in the sector.

site_title: Brazilian bank employees go on strike
summary: Brazilian bank employees went on strike on Tuesday, demanding a 16% pay rise and better working conditions. The strike, announced as indefinite, affected state and private bank outlets nationwide. Workers rejected a 5.5% pay offer from employers, following a similar strike last October that resulted in an 8.5% pay hike. The strike coinces with the banks' 18.5% profit increase from the previous year, with the five main banks earning 60.3 billion reais in profits.

site_title: UK high street prices fall harder, food prices down again: BRC
summary: UK shop prices fell 1.9% in September, the largest decline since August, according to the British Retail Consortium. Food prices dropped 0.5%, with supermarkets battling for market share. Non-food retailers on the high street are using seasonal promotions to drive sales growth. This marks the third consecutive month of price falls, underscoring the weak outlook for the UK economy.

site_title: Airbus says no longer in discussions with Bombardier
summary: Airbus Group has halted talks with Bombardier after exploring business opportunities with the Canadian manufacturer. Airbus had previously considered purchasing a majority stake in Bombardier's troubled CSeries jet, but the discussions are now no longer being pursued. The decision comes after Airbus confirmed that it had been exploring business opportunities with Bombardier.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO says recall to start in January, be completed end-2016
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller announced a recall for cars affected by diesel emissions rigging, set to begin in January and completed by the end of 2016. He denied involvement by a few employees, contradicting previous speculation about his predecessor Martin Winterkorn's knowledge. Mueller also stated the need for an "evolution" to revamp the company, rather than a "revolution," and pledged to closely examine every model and brand for its contribution to the company's issues.

site_title: Formula One: Ecclestone says F1 to be sold before year's end
summary: Formula One supremo Bernie Ecclestone stated that the Formula One circus could be sold by the end of the year. Ecclestone believes shareholders will have to sell some or all of their shares, indicating a potential change in ownership. This decision comes as the organization seeks new leadership, with a new owner expected to be found this year.

site_title: Obama 'confident' in TPP Pacific trade deal
summary: US President Barack Obama expressed confidence in the ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) Pacific free-trade deal, stating it would be good for American workers, businesses, farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers. Following a day of agreement by 12 countries on the deal, Obama emphasized his commitment to presenting the agreement to Congress only if he could be certain of its benefits. The agreement's ratification is crucial for the US, as it aims to strengthen economic ties with Pacific nations and promote trade growth.

site_title: Dollar slightly slower as IMF cuts global growth forecast
summary: The US dollar slightly declined against major currencies as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) reduced its global growth forecast to 2.6% this year and 2.8% in 2016, citing a slowdown in China and emerging markets. The US trade deficit widened in August, with exports slumping, further contributing to the dollar's decline. The IMF's downgrade suggests "cooler growth over the last quarter," according to economist Joe Manimbo.

site_title: Microsoft unveils Windows 10 smartphones, new laptop
summary: Microsoft unveiled its first Windows 10 smartphones, the Lumia 950 and 950 XL, along with a new laptop, the Surface Book. The smartphones feature innovative security tools and can be connected to other devices, while the Surface Book boasts a 13.5-inch detachable screen and up to 12 hours of battery life. The launch marks the latest step by CEO Satya Nadella to build on the successful release of Windows 10, which now runs on 110 million devices worldwide.

site_title: Noble's US metal traders leave in latest senior exits: sources
summary: Noble Group Ltd has seen two senior US metals traders, Scott Evans and Jeff Romanek, leave the company amid internal ructions and weak metals and oil prices. The departures are part of Noble's efforts to shore up its balance sheet and reduce capital-intensive operations, focusing on aluminum and alumina. The company's mining and metals segment swung to a loss in the first half of the year, while its shares have hit record lows and the yield on its bonds has tripled. This follows Glencore PLC's own struggles with costs and debts, sparking sector concerns.

images.alt_text: Noble Group Ltd's senior US metals traders Scott Evans and Jeff Romanek have left the company, four sources said on Tuesday, the latest in a string of high-profile departures as the Asian commodities trader battles weak metals and oil prices.

site_title: Cerberus leads buyers of distressed property debt in Europe
summary: Cerberus Capital Management LP led buyers of distressed European real estate debt, closing 8 deals worth 7.69 billion euros through the first 9 months of 2015. Sales of soured real estate debt and foreclosed assets dropped 23% to 44.6 billion euros. European banks are selling real estate loan books and properties to repair balance sheets damaged by the financial crisis. Cerberus has also made big bets on US real estate, while a venture between Deutsche Bank and Apollo Global Management was the second-biggest buyer.

site_title: AirAsia shares up almost 6 per cent after privatisation report
summary: AirAsia shares rose 5.6% on Wednesday after Reuters reported that the airline's co-founder Tony Fernandes is seeking to take the company private. This move is expected to be financed by banks and could be launched in the coming months. The news outperformed the benchmark index's 0.12% drop. An AirAsia spokeswoman declined to comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: Shares of AirAsia Bhd rose as much as 5.6 per cent on Wednesday after Reuters reported that the founders of Asia's largest budget airline are sounding out investors to take the company private.

site_title: Dubai set for first residential Reit amid softening prices
summary: Dubai's Emirates Reit plans to launch its first residential real estate investment trust (Reit) later this year or early 2016, capitalizing on falling property prices. Despite a 10% drop in selling prices, Dubai's rental market has remained strong, with rents declining only 1% in the year ending in August. The new trust aims to generate returns from rental income, with property prices expected to continue softening over the remainder of the year and into 2016.

site_title: US: Internet stocks sink after EU court ruling on data
summary: US internet stocks fell after the EU court ruled that a 15-year-old agreement on cross-Atlantic data transfers was invalid for privacy reasons, affecting Facebook, Twitter, and Amazon. Despite this, blue-chip stocks like DuPont rose due to its CEO's sudden departure. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 closed slightly higher, while the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.69%. The ruling could raise costs and operating difficulties for data-dependent companies, and investors reacted to this uncertainty.

site_title: There's no magic wand to boost US growth
summary: The US economy has been experiencing slow growth, averaging 2% annually, since World War II, resulting in lost income of hundreds of billions of dollars. A recent survey of 51 economists across the political spectrum found no consensus on how to boost growth, with diverse suggestions including ending patent protection for prescription drugs, mandating paid leave, paying more attention to foreign policy, streamlining government regulations, reducing federal budget deficits by taxing the rich, and shifting to a progressive consumption tax. The lack of consensus highlights the complexity and subjectivity of economic policy decisions.

site_title: Oil prices rebound sharply
summary: Global oil prices surged to one-month peaks, reaching US$51.71 per barrel for Brent North Sea crude and US$48.29 per barrel for West Texas Intermediate. The price rebound was driven by Syria tensions, rebounding equities, a weak dollar, and upbeat comments from Royal Dutch Shell CEO Ben van Beurden. Analysts attribute the price recovery to expected US shale oil output decline and a more balanced market. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) will meet on December 4, with its output target remaining unchanged at 30 million barrels per day.

site_title: Oxley CEO lifts stake in IHC, stirring talk over what's next
summary: Oxley Holdings CEO Ching Chiat Kwong has raised his stake in International Healthway Corp (IHC) to 21.08%, nearly matching IHC's CEO Fan Kow Hin's 23.37% stake. The move, made through a series of open market transactions, cost Oxley around S$3.94 million and added 47.56 million shares to Ching's portfolio. Speculation surrounds the next move of Oxley's top executives, with some market watchers suggesting they may seek a board seat to gain more influence over IHC's direction, which includes healthcare-related properties across the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Thailand turns to Mekong neighbours to diversify exports
summary: Thailand is diversifying its exports by strengthening ties with neighboring countries in the Mekong region, aiming to reverse a slump in exports. The country is investing $83 billion over seven years to build new railways, roads, and customs checkpoints to improve trade with Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam. With a growing population of 240 million, the CLMV region offers a significant market opportunity, and Thailand hopes to become a trade and logistics hub for the region, rivaling China and India.

site_title: Britain to spur home ownership, says PM Cameron with eye on his legacy
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron will unveil plans to spur home ownership, aiming to address criticism that his government is failing to help those priced out of the housing market. The move is seen as a bid to shape his legacy and appeal to young voters. Cameron will outline measures to increase the supply of homes and make buying more affordable, particularly for first-time buyers. The plans are expected to be a key part of his final five years in power.

site_title: Templeton bets on 'multi-decade' EM opportunity
summary: Franklin Templeton's Michael Hasenstab believes emerging markets, including the Mexican peso, Malaysian ringgit, and Indonesian rupiah, offer a "multi-decade" investment opportunity due to their low valuations. He's betting on an increase in US Treasury yields and a strengthening dollar against the euro, yen, and Australian currency. This stance contrasts with some hedge funds, which predict a bear market in emerging markets. Hasenstab, known for his contrarian bets, is doubling down on emerging markets despite a slowdown in China's growth rate and rising interest rates.

site_title: Scandal erupting in world of fantasy sports
summary: Fantasy sports companies DraftKings and FanDuel face allegations of insider trading after an employee at DraftKings released data on NFL players before the start of games, winning $350,000 at a rival site. The incident raises questions about data protection and the industry's ability to police itself. Industry analysts say the episode could imperil the industry unless real safeguards are put in place, and lawmakers are discussing potential regulation. The companies have temporarily barred employees from playing games at other sites and claim to have strong policies in place to prevent misuse of information.

site_title: Time ripe for Singapore to become Asian corporate bond trading hub
summary: Singapore is poised to become the Asian corporate bond trading hub due to its unique pan-Asian exchange, robust derivatives market, and favorable regulatory environment. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has already announced plans to launch an Asian corporate bond trading platform, which will be developed in collaboration with industry stakeholders. A research-quality database on Asian bonds is also proposed to facilitate value-adding research and improve financial market performance. This private-public-academic partnership approach aims to make Singapore a thought leader in fixed income markets and products, capitalizing on its reputation as a globalized city with a highly-educated workforce.

site_title: Singapore seen being able to fulfil minimum wage requirement
summary: Singapore is expected to comply with the Trans-Pacific Partnership's minimum wage requirement, despite not currently prescribing a national minimum wage. The country's Progressive Wage Model and Workfare Income Supplement initiatives can be viewed as a "price floor" for labor, meeting the TPP's minimum wage requirement. Singapore's government may argue that its wage policy framework is superior to the minimum wage, rather than implementing it. Observers doubt the government will introduce a minimum wage policy solely to comply with the TPP treaty obligations.

site_title: SGH apologises for virus outbreak
summary: Singapore General Hospital (SGH) has apologized for a hepatitis C virus outbreak in one of its renal wards, resulting in 22 patients infected and 4 deaths. The source of the virus is being investigated, with initial findings suggesting it may be related to "intravenous (IV) injectable agents." An independent review committee has been set up to determine if SGH took all necessary measures to prevent the outbreak. The Ministry of Health has expressed concern and disappointment, with the Health Minister announcing the review committee to provide added assurance on the internal findings.

site_title: Wall Street's recovery lifts local market
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 105 points or 3.8% to 2,897.41 on Tuesday, driven by blue chips. The STI's two-day gain was led by banks, with OCBC and Nomura reporting strong performances. CapitaLand and Q&M Dental also saw gains, with analysts citing undervalued shares and growth potential. Rabobank attributed the rally to the US Federal Reserve's potential hesitation to raise interest rates, but warned of potential risks.

site_title: Breaking down trade barriers
summary: US President Trump unveiled new tariff rates, including a 50% levy on Brazil, amidst global trade tensions. Meanwhile, Japan faces a succession crisis, fueling a 6,000% stock gain for an elevator empire. Alibaba risks a deepening US$100 billion rout as it navigates a turf war with rivals. China's Xi signals the possibility of ending deflationary price wars. Huawei seeks AI chip customers in the Middle East and South-east Asia, amid the ongoing trade uncertainty. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge towards fresh records despite ongoing tariff disputes.

site_title: Commodities slump set to continue
summary: Commodities prices are unlikely to rebound due to excess supplies, according to Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Citigroup. Goldman predicts crude oil and copper prices will remain low, while Morgan Stanley forecasts weaker currencies in producing countries will boost raw material output. Citigroup warns that a sluggish world economy makes it "hard to argue" that prices have already bottomed. The experts' warnings come amid the worst commodities slump in a generation.

site_title: Rich Singaporeans think life will improve over next 12 months
summary: A survey of Singapore-based millionaires found that 66% expect their disposable incomes to increase over the next 12 months. The majority believe they will have more disposable cash and better family lives, leading to increased spending on holidays and indulgences. The outlook is not influenced by China's recent yuan devaluation, and Chinese millionaires are equally confident in their financial prospects.

site_title: Trade deficit widens in August by biggest margin in five months
summary: The US trade deficit widened in August by 15.6% to $48.3 billion, the largest margin in five months, due to increased imports and limited sales abroad. Exports of goods dropped to their lowest level since June 2011. The strong US dollar, a record 12-year high, and weakening overseas economies contributed to the decline.

site_title: German factory orders in August fall amid China slowdown
summary: German factory orders unexpectedly fell 1.8% in August, exceeding a median estimate of a 0.5% increase. This decline was attributed to a China-led slowdown in emerging markets and an emissions scandal at Volkswagen. However, business confidence increased in September due to strengthening domestic demand, rising wages, and low inflation. Domestic factory orders declined 2.6% excluding big-ticket items, while the euro area saw a 0.2% increase in the benchmark DAX Index. Economists predict moderate economic growth of 0.5% in the coming quarters.

site_title: Sells outpace buys in S'pore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds sold more Singapore stocks than they bought in the three months to Sept 30, with net sells of S$741.8 million compared to net buys of S$650.2 million. The top-selling stock was Sunningdale Tech, while the top-buying stock was Ezra Holdings. The data, provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, highlights the market trends but notes that alternative investors and institutional money managers may also be trading without disclosure.

site_title: Welcoming different points of view
summary: Developing a diverse workforce has become crucial for businesses to tackle complex problems and avoid groupthink. Organisations that embrace diversity can attract better talent and enhance business performance. A good mix of talent with adaptability and the ability to think and work in different ways is essential for corporate success. Experts argue that this adaptability is key to responding to changing business needs, particularly in a globalised world with diverse stakeholders. By embracing diversity, companies can leverage different viewpoints and ideas to drive innovation and growth.

site_title: S'pore fund still haunted by risky investments during financial crisis
summary: A Singapore-listed mutual fund, Global Investments Ltd, continues to struggle with risky investments made during the 2009 financial crisis. The fund, which was managed by Babcock & Brown Ltd, owns RMBS and CLOs in Australia and Europe, resulting in a 38% discount to its net assets. Despite this, the fund has not posted a loss since 2009 and has continued to pay dividends. The fund's chairman, Boon Swan Foo, attributes the struggles to the difficult restructuring process, and the company is holding on to its assets in the expectation of getting good buyers at the right price.

site_title: TPP holds out some promise, but it's not over till it's over
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal, signed by the US, Japan, and 10 other countries, promises to boost free trade, despite its complexity and potential winners and losers. The deal aims to reduce tariffs, quotas, and other trade barriers, benefiting producers and lowering costs for consumers. However, it also poses challenges for governments, lawmakers, and employers, particularly in countries with inefficient industries. The agreement has boosted sentiment amid slowing global trade growth and weak productivity gains, but its impact remains uncertain.

site_title: Economic woes testing South-east Asia reserves, defences
summary: South-east Asia is experiencing economic woes due to speculative attacks on its currencies, despite having built up reserves to combat the 1997/98 Asian financial crisis. Indonesia and Malaysia, reliant on China and commodity exports, are particularly vulnerable. Foreign funds have sold billions of dollars in stocks, causing currencies to slide and investors to reassess risk profiles. Economists warn of a potential contagion effect, with falling currencies posing balance-sheet problems for companies with dollar debts.

site_title: TPP: a breakthrough, yes - but still far from a done deal
summary: US trade ministers have reached a breakthrough on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement, a landmark regional free-trade deal that could be the largest trade pact since the 1994 Uruguay Round. The 12-country deal, involving the US, Australia, and several Asian nations, aims to secure rules-setting and standards on trade, investment, data flows, and intellectual property. However, domestic politics, including US presidential and congressional elections, may still pose a challenge to ratification. The deal's success is uncertain, with some lawmakers expressing concerns about its impact on workers and jobs.

site_title: TPP applauded for attention to SMEs
summary: Singapore's Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement has been praised for its special provisions for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), aiming to boost growth and competitiveness. The agreement's Competitiveness and Business Facilitation chapter includes provisions to enhance SME participation in regional supply chains. Observers emphasize that SMEs must be well-versed in the agreement's terms to capitalize on new opportunities. Experts, such as the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises president Kurt Wee, highlight the importance of action plans and competition in overseas markets.

site_title: No simple solution to cap emissions
summary: Environmental lobbyists are pushing for measures to reduce emissions from the shipping industry, but a simple solution, such as a cap or levy, is unlikely to be implemented due to the industry's complexity. The Clean Shipping Coalition's president, John Maggs, criticized International Maritime Organization Secretary General Koji Sekimizu for dismissing potential measures to reduce emissions in a recent speech. The criticism highlights the challenges in finding effective solutions to address the shipping industry's significant carbon footprint, which is set to be a key topic at the upcoming UN Climate Change Conference in Paris.

site_title: Data management is a continual shared responsibility
summary: Businesses must acknowledge that data management is a shared responsibility, as incorrect or poor-quality data can lead to faulty output and regulatory and reputational risks. To effectively manage data, companies should identify and classify critical data elements, assess their value, and maintain their accuracy and consistency. A common misconception is that data management is solely the responsibility of the IT department, but rather it requires a culture of individual responsibility throughout the organization, supported by top management and standardized procedures.

site_title: Samsung seen tapping US$55b cash pile for share buyback
summary: Samsung Electronics may announce a share buyback as early as this month, potentially erasing this year's declines of 13% and boosting shares by up to 20%. The company, struggling with lukewarm sales of its new Galaxy smartphones, has $55 billion in cash and plans to remove over $1 billion of stock from the market. Analysts expect the buyback to be the company's second in eight years, helping to return value to shareholders and tighten the grip of the founding Lee family on the company.

site_title: Aviva Investors eyes growth in institutional, retail markets in Asia
summary: Aviva Investors plans to expand its presence in Asia's institutional and retail markets, aiming to register "outcome-oriented" funds in Singapore and Hong Kong. The funds will align with clients' long-term objectives for return and income. Aviva Investors, with £263 billion in assets under management globally, will bring its successful multi-strategy funds to the region. The firm's CEO, Kevin Talbot, says the funds will tap savers' appetite for reliable growth and income.

site_title: Airbus faces A380 test as SIA weighs lease renewal, says banker
summary: Airbus faces a double test of confidence in the A380 superjumbo, as Singapore Airlines ponders renewing its 10-year lease for the 544-seat plane, which expires in 2017, and the planemaker seeks to bolster new sales. Lease rates for the A380 could come under pressure if Singapore Airlines either returns the jet or renews the lease at lower rates, influencing the price of brand-new planes. Airbus aims to sell 25 A380s by the end of the year, but the market's untested nature and weak order book pose challenges.

site_title: AirAsia sounds out investors about taking firm private: sources
summary: AirAsia's founders are considering a management-led buyout to take the airline private, valuing the company at RM3.48 billion (US$796 million). The move comes after a critical research report questioned AirAsia's accounts, driving its shares to a seven-year low. CEO Tony Fernandes is seeking financing to secure the transaction, which could be launched over the next few months. Investors face challenges due to currency risk, with AirAsia's revenues in Malaysian ringgit and costs in US dollars.

site_title: India leads Asia's dash for coal as emissions blow east
summary: India has started production at its Magadh coal mine, aiming to double coal output by 2020 and become Asia's largest coal producer. The move is part of a pan-Asian dash to burn more coal, with other countries such as China, Indonesia, and Pakistan also increasing their coal production. Despite international efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, India has rejected absolute cuts, citing its low per capita emissions and need for energy growth to beat poverty. The country plans to invest in cleaner coal technology and plant trees to absorb carbon dioxide.

site_title: The bandana's back: Paris catwalk show brings back the 1970s
summary: The Paris Fashion Week saw a revival of 1970s-inspired bandanas, with Japanese brand Sacai updating the accessory for its Spring/Summer collection. Hermès showcased timeless, elegant designs, while Stella McCartney's show featured sporty, colourful outfits. The Alexander McQueen show took inspiration from the Victorian age, with intricate, embroidered numbers. These collections highlighted the return of pleats and bold colours, with Sacai credited for making old trends trendy again.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and ongoing trade tensions. In the US, stocks edged down from record highs amid tariff threats, while in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector issues. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. An Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

images.alt_text: We think Innovalues' 30 per cent retreat from its peak reached after Q2 2015 results opens up a buying window.

site_title: Opec sec-gen wants cooperation with non-members on surplus
summary: Opec Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri urged cooperation with non-Opec producers to address the global crude surplus, citing an overhang of 200 million barrels. Non-Opec countries, including Russia, have refused to cut output, but forecasters expect reduced supply growth due to low oil prices. Opec has invited non-Opec countries to a technical meeting in October to discuss the market. This move aims to tackle the global surplus and stabilize oil prices, which have nearly halved from a year ago.

site_title: Singapore leads region in per capita financial assets: Allianz
summary: Singapore holds the highest per capita financial assets in the region, with a gross of around 106,620 euros (S$170,610) per person, surpassing Japan, Taiwan, and India. The country's life and pension assets saw the strongest growth, at 9%, while its debt ratio climbed to 75.5%. Singapore retained its ninth position globally, with net financial assets per capita of 73,330 euros. The Allianz report found that 20.4% of the population had net financial assets between 6,100 and 36,700 euros, and 76.7% had low assets.

images.alt_text: Singapore posted the highest gross per capita financial assets in the region last year - beating Japan, Taiwan and India by quite a fair margin.

site_title: Money flees emerging markets with no respite in sight
summary: Emerging markets are experiencing a mass exodus of capital for the first time in 27 years, with investors fearing a prolonged economic slowdown. The Institute of International Finance reports that developing countries will record net capital outflows in 2015, the first time since 1988. Investors are concerned about China's slowing growth, declining exports, and high debt levels, leading to a significant underperformance of emerging equities and a widening price discount to developed peers. Many investors believe the crisis is more measured and slower-moving, and that corrections may take years to complete.

site_title: Transatlantic data pact struck down by EU's highest court
summary: The European Union's highest court has struck down the 15-year-old "Safe Harbor" pact, allowing US spies to access European citizens' private data, as it compromises EU citizens' right to challenge data use. The ruling, triggered by Austrian law student Max Schrems' complaint against Facebook, declares the pact invalid, forcing companies to find alternative mechanisms for data transfers to the US. This decision threatens internet companies with a legal limbo, with thousands of US businesses relying on Safe Harbor and now needing to put replacement measures in place.

site_title: Successful professionals take to angel investing
summary: Wealthy professionals are turning to angel investing as a way to generate high returns on their money, but many are not doing their due diligence, putting their investments at risk. Successful angel investors advise setting a diversified portfolio, researching the company's management, and looking for signs of a solid business plan and good business smarts. They also recommend avoiding investments in companies with complicated family dynamics or those that may need multiple rounds of financing. By taking a more informed approach, angel investors can minimize their risks and potentially reap significant rewards.

site_title: US firms hold US$2.1t in profits offshore to avoid taxes: Study
summary: The 500 largest US companies hold over $2.1 trillion in accumulated profits offshore to avoid US taxes, with nearly three-quarters operating tax haven subsidiaries in countries like Bermuda and Ireland. If repatriated, these firms would collectively owe an estimated $620 billion in US taxes. Technology giant Apple holds $181.1 billion offshore, while General Electric, Microsoft, and Pfizer have $119 billion, $108.3 billion, and $74 billion, respectively. The study calls for Congress to take action to prevent corporate tax evasion and restore fairness to the tax system.

site_title: A long road ahead for newly minted TPP
summary: The US Congress has not yet approved the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal, despite President Barack Obama completing international negotiations. The administration needs a majority of pro-trade lawmakers to pass the agreement, which faces opposition from carmakers, tobacco companies, and dairy farmers. The first steps towards congressional consideration will begin later this week, with a 90-day waiting period and a 60-day public review phase to follow. A poor reception during this phase could hinder Mr. Obama's efforts to rally support for the deal.

site_title: Despite optimism over historic TPP, doubts persist
summary: Singapore's ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement has raised concerns about the limited impact on the country in the short run. Despite its historic significance, economists and business leaders note that the deal still needs ratification in all 12 countries and requires smaller firms to adapt to its terms. This may hinder meaningful gains for Singapore companies, particularly in the short term.

site_title: Competition for land still strong despite tepid market
summary: Singapore's land market remains competitive despite a tepid market, with an average of nine bids per site from January to September 2015, up from 7.3 in 2014. Developers' caution is evident in higher margin buffers, but not outright pessimism, as they protect against falling home prices. Non-traditional developers are gaining ground, and more are forming consortiums to share risks. Traditional developers are struggling to restock their land banks, with some not winning any sites this year.

site_title: A$ gains after RBA holds rates steady
summary: The Australian dollar strengthened against other major currencies after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held interest rates steady, quelling speculation of further cuts. The RBA's relaxed message on growth threats eased global market nerves, despite a jobs report last week pushing back expectations for a US interest rate hike. The dollar was lower against the yen and euro, reflecting broader market uncertainty.

site_title: China property firm Country Garden plans Islamic bond in Malaysia
summary: China property firm Country Garden Holdings Company plans a RM1.5 billion (S$494 million) Islamic bond sale in Malaysia, marking its debut in the sukuk market. The move is seen as a way for Chinese companies to tap liquidity from Islamic investors, despite low borrowing costs in the onshore bond market. Country Garden's Malaysian subsidiary will issue the sukuk, which is expected to provide an alternative funding source for the company. This marks a growing trend of Chinese companies turning to sukuk as a funding option.

site_title: Investment treaties allow for claims against Indonesia for haze, says law firm
summary: A global law firm, Dechert LLP, has stated that investors under an investment treaty can claim against Indonesia for damage caused by haze, as the government had the ability to prevent it. Investment treaties allow investors to bring claims against a state that breaches treaty obligations, and remedies may include declaratory relief and monetary damages. Dechert cited a notable example of a successful investment treaty claim against India, where a private dispute was turned into a public one, resulting in a $4.5 million award. This approach may shed international light on regional problems like haze in Indonesia.

site_title: Alibaba could benefit from jump in China luxury spending
summary: Alibaba may benefit from China's luxury spending surge, as consumers are willing to pay up to 4,200 yuan (S$941) for a single item online, more than double the previous year's amount. This increase in luxury spending could provide a boost to e-commerce companies like Alibaba and JD.com, which are facing an economic slowdown in China.

site_title: US ship lost in hurricane was undergoing engine room work
summary: A US cargo ship, El Faro, sank off the Bahamas during Hurricane Joaquin, resulting in at least one confirmed death and presumed deaths of 31 others, mostly Americans. The ship was undergoing engine room work before it sank, but officials do not believe this contributed to the disaster. The 240-meter container ship was carrying 391 containers and 294 trailers when it lost propulsion, took on water, and sank in a 4,572-meter deep channel. An investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board is underway, with the Coast Guard and ship owner Tote Inc. taking part.

site_title: Govt ties up with industry players to beef up Singapore's cyber security
summary: The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) has partnered with Singtel, Check Point Software Technologies, and FireEye to enhance cyber-security capabilities. The Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) aim to boost Singapore's cyber security in a rapidly evolving landscape. The partnerships will focus on key areas, but specific details on the collaborations are not provided. This move is seen as a strategic effort to strengthen Singapore's cyber security infrastructure.

site_title: Luxury brands seen eyeing expansion in emerging cities
summary: Luxury brands are expanding into emerging cities, including Bangkok, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Ho Chi Minh City, Mexico City, Istanbul, Tel Aviv, and Lagos, according to a report by Wealthinsight. These cities, outside the BRIC grouping, are expected to drive luxury goods sales, with Istanbul having the highest number of ultra-high net worth individuals (UHNWIs) and Mexico City driven by its emerging middle class. The report highlights the importance of formulating expansion strategies to capture local demand and remain competitive in these markets.

site_title: IMF cuts world growth forecast
summary: The IMF has cut its global growth forecast for 2015 and 2016 to 3.1% and 3.6%, respectively, citing growing risks from China's slowdown and emerging markets. Wealthy countries, such as the US, are expected to recover, but the world economy is on track for its worst year since 2009. The slowdown in China is affecting other emerging economies and has led to a decline in commodity prices, impacting growth in countries like Brazil and sub-Saharan Africa.

site_title: Indonesia official says tough to set haze deadline with fires, weather
summary: Indonesia's disaster chief, Willem Rampangilei, rejected criticism that the country is not doing enough to combat the haze crisis, saying every possible resource is being deployed. The haze, caused by forest fires on Sumatra and Borneo, has sent pollution levels soaring in Malaysia and Singapore, with schools closed and major events cancelled. Indonesia has set a deadline to put out the fires, but faces challenges from unpredictable weather and farmers continuing to burn to clear land. The country has offered to punish plantation companies and deploy soldiers, but limited by a decentralized system of government that makes it harder to tackle corruption and coordinate efforts.

site_title: IMF says global economic growth remains elusive
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded its global economic growth forecast for 2015 to 3.1%, citing an elusive recovery in the world economy six years after the postwar recession. Advanced economies, such as the US and UK, are expected to see a slight pick-up in growth, while emerging markets and developing economies are projected to decline for the fifth consecutive year. The IMF warns of downside risks, particularly for emerging markets, due to declining commodity prices, reduced capital flows, and financial market volatility.

site_title: Noble Group appoints new head of internal audit: report
summary: NOBLE Group has appointed Frank Russo as its new head of internal audit, according to a Channel NewsAsia report. Russo previously held the position at GE Capital's energy, aviation, and insurance businesses and has also worked at Deloitte and Touche for over eight years. He started his new role on Monday and will be based in Stamford, Connecticut.

site_title: Shenzhen is China's hottest property market
summary: Shenzhen, China's booming property market, saw a 30% year-over-year increase in real estate prices in August, outpacing the 2.3% decline nationwide. The city's strong demand, fueled by limited land supply and luxury buyers, drives the boom. Despite a stock market rout, property demand remains strong, with only one plot of land sold in Shenzhen this year, compared to 120 in major cities. Analysts expect a slight easing of prices towards the end of the year, but substantial drops are unlikely due to seller resistance.

site_title: Banks in S'pore reviewing ethical lending practices
summary: Singapore's banking group reviews ethical lending practices amid haze caused by forest fires in Indonesia, a potential backlash against companies funding them. The Association of Banks in Singapore is working on guidelines to improve responsible lending, but details are yet to be announced. Only four major banks in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore embed environmental factors in their credit-decision process. The World Wildlife Fund says Singapore's air quality has soared to "hazardous" levels, while Indonesia's pollutant standards index reached 1,990, almost 20 times the level considered unhealthy.

site_title: US trade deficit widens as exports sag, imports from China surge
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $48.3 billion in August, the largest expansion in five months, as exports fell 2% to their lowest level since 2012 due to a strong dollar and weak foreign demand. Imports from China surged 3% due to the devaluation of the yuan, contributing to the widening deficit. The US economy's vulnerabilities to global economic trends and a strong dollar may prompt the Federal Reserve to delay interest rate hikes, as investors now expect the Fed to hold off until at least March.

site_title: Europe: Stocks finish higher
summary: Europe's main stock markets finished higher on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.43% to 6,326.16 points, and Paris' CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices gaining 0.95% and 0.90% respectively. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks. The US stock markets also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Islamic halal economy set to grow: experts
summary: The halal economy is expected to grow as the global Muslim population expands, with an estimated 1.8 billion consumers. The economy, which includes products and services compliant with Islamic sharia law, is projected to grow by 20% annually. Countries like Japan and Korea are adopting halal-friendly practices to attract Muslim tourists. The Organisation of Islamic Cooperation values the global halal sector at US$2.3 trillion, with the Muslim population expected to reach 2.2 billion by 2030, making it a "core market" for halal products. This growth is driven by the increasing demand for halal products and certification.

site_title: Q4 business optimism falls to second-lowest in nearly 3 years: study
summary: Business optimism in Q4 has fallen to its second-lowest level in nearly three years, according to a study by the Business Optimism Index. The index dropped to 0.14 percentage point from 14.60 in Q3 and 10.79 from a year ago. Expectations for sales and profits have also plunged into the contractionary zone. The decline is attributed to global economic uncertainty, with the SCCB stating that prevailing uncertainty continues to weigh on the Asean business community. This is the first time since Q1 this year that both expectations have fallen into the contractionary zone.

site_title: Paying heed to a demanding electorate
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) won an overwhelming mandate in the 2015 General Election, receiving 83 out of 89 seats and increasing its share of votes from 60.14% in 2011 to 69.86%. Contrary to predictions, the PAP's fortunes did not decline, and its victory was attributed to its remarkable economic development record, commitment to listening to the people, and nuanced policy approach. The opposition parties were criticized for lacking a coherent policy narrative and blaming foreigners for social and economic issues. The PAP's ability to deliver good governance and adapt to changing circumstances is expected to keep it in power.

site_title: EU ministers agree measures to curb multinationals' tax avoidance
summary: EU finance ministers agreed to automatically exchange information on deals with multinational companies from 2017 to curb tax avoidance. The move aims to discourage aggressive tax planning and ensure companies pay tax according to where they operate. The practice, known as rulings and advance price arrangements, allows companies to minimize tax bills by shifting profits to countries with lower taxes. The automatic exchange of information is seen as a step to reduce tax avoidance and increase transparency.

site_title: VW to place all investments under review amid scandal: labour boss
summary: Volkswagen's top labour representative, Bernd Osterloh, announced that all investments will be reviewed amid the diesel emissions scandal. The review will impact earnings and bonus payments for workers, but no job losses have been confirmed at the company's main factory. Osterloh emphasized the need to question non-economical investments, signaling a significant overhaul of the company's financial strategy.

site_title: MoneySmart.sg raises S$2.8m in Series A funding
summary: MoneySmart.sg, a Singapore-based personal finance portal, has raised S$2.8 million in Series A funding led by SPH Media Fund, Convergence Ventures, and OPT SEA. The startup aims to grow its team and expand into a new Asian market by mid-2016. Founded in 2009, MoneySmart.sg achieved break-even and profitability in 2014 and generates 80% of its revenue from cost per acquisition. The portal has 1.5 million page views a month and partners with major financial institutions, but has faced criticism about the integrity of its advertising.

site_title: Toyota unveils self-driving car
summary: Toyota unveiled a self-driving car, a modified Lexus GS, that can drive itself on highways using sophisticated sensors. The car navigates roads, merges lanes, and overtakes other vehicles. Toyota aims to make similar cars available within five years, in time for the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.

site_title: UK watchdogs publish rules on whistleblowing, bank staff references
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority published rules to standardize the sector's approach to whistleblowing, aiming to stamp out misconduct in the financial industry. The rules complement recent initiatives to reform senior management arrangements and remuneration. The FCA also published a consultation paper on a common approach to bank references. These efforts follow a series of reforms and come as part of a broader effort to promote a culture of transparency and accountability in the financial services industry.

site_title: UK brewer SABMiller rejects InBev takeover bid: report
summary: British brewing company SABMiller has rejected a £66.4 billion takeover bid from AB InBev, citing the offer price of £40 per share as too low. SABMiller's share price dropped 3.02% after the rejection. A potential deal would have combined AB InBev's Budweiser and Stella Artois with SABMiller's Foster's and Pilsner Urquell. The decision is seen as a blow to AB InBev's efforts to expand its global presence.

site_title: US: Shares reverse losses in early trade
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 19.97 points (0.12%) to 16,796.40, reversing early losses, after DuPont's 10.6% surge following CEO Ellen Kuhlman's retirement. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.08% and 0.14%, respectively, to 1,985.41 and 4,774.39. The gains were attributed to the DuPont announcement, which lifted investor confidence.

site_title: EU court strikes down transatlantic data deal in Facebook case
summary: The European Union's top court has ruled that a key transatlantic data sharing deal between the US and EU, known as the "Safe Harbour" agreement, is invalid due to insufficient protection of Europeans' personal data. The decision, made in a case brought by Austrian law student Max Schrems, affects companies such as Facebook, which transfer data from European users to US servers. The court's ruling gives European authorities the power to decide whether to suspend data transfers, and is seen as a major blow to US global surveillance practices.

site_title: Air France violence 'unacceptable', threatens France's image: Hollande
summary: French President Francois Hollande condemned a violent protest against Air France managers by striking workers, calling it "unacceptable" and threatening France's image. The protest, which included hundreds of workers storming a board meeting, was over plans to cut 2,900 jobs. Hollande urged responsible dialogue between management and union leaders, saying "social dialogue matters" and that violence can have consequences for the country's image.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore reported positive economic indicators, including the Trans-Pacific Partnership as a catalyst for Asia-Pacific growth and the country boasting the highest gross per capita financial assets in Asia. The Singapore Business Federation welcomed the OECD's recommendations to combat tax avoidance. Meanwhile, Aberdeen Asset Management cut charges for its Singapore funds ahead of the CPF board's revised caps. The Straits Times Index rose 1.6% to 2,897.41, following a two-day rebound.

site_title: Quality of Death Index: Singapore ranked 2nd in Asia, 12th globally
summary: Singapore ranks 2nd in Asia and 12th globally in the 2015 Quality of Death Index, behind Taiwan. The country has improved its palliative care strategy, with increased resources and registered specialists. However, Singapore needs to address community engagement and capacity issues, particularly with its aging population. The report also highlights the need for better funding, training, and knowledge among healthcare professionals to improve palliative care services.

site_title: UK house prices fall in September: Halifax
summary: UK house prices fell by 0.9% in September, according to Halifax, with year-on-year growth slowing to 8.6% from 9.0%. This contrasts with Nationwide's measure, which found prices rose more quickly in September. Economists had expected a 0.1% monthly increase, taking the annual increase to 9.0%. The drop in prices follows a surprise strong leap in August.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 14.92 points to 1,662.51. The index saw 2.13 billion lots valued at RM2.12 billion traded, with gains outnumbering losses 495 to 363.

site_title: AirAsia sounding out investors to take company private: sources
summary: AirAsia's founders, Tony Fernandes and Kamarudin Meranun, are exploring a management-led buyout to take the company private, seeking financing from banks. This comes after a 40% decline in the airline's market value due to a critical research report in June. The plan is a decade in the making, with Fernandes and Meranun owning 19% of the airline through their joint venture, Tune Air. The deal could be launched in the next few months, with obtaining financing seen as a key hurdle to its success.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down 0.19%
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended 0.19% lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 21,812.83 points. Early morning gains were pared by profit-taking, despite no major news events driving the market. Mainland China's stock markets were closed for a public holiday, which may have contributed to the Hong Kong decline.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher in line with Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index jumped 46.16 points or 1.6% to 2,897.41 on Tuesday, following Wall Street's recovery. The two-day rebound brought a 105-point gain or 3.8% to the index. Blue chips, particularly banks, drove the market's performance, with OCBC rising S$0.11 to S$9.06. Analysts at Nomura maintain a "buy" rating on OCBC, citing strong risk management and a balance sheet. CapitaLand also saw gains, with its shares rising S$0.07 to S$2.95, as analysts consider it undervalued at 0.67x price-to-book value.

site_title: Pimco says asset prices can weather Fed shift as ECB to BOJ ease
summary: Pimco's Joachim Fels predicts that asset prices worldwide can withstand a potential Federal Reserve interest-rate increase due to central banks in Europe, Japan, and China easing their monetary policies in the fourth quarter. Fels believes the ECB and BOJ's significant expansions of their programs would offset any Fed move, making it hard to believe asset prices would decline.

images.alt_text: Pacific Investment Management Co, home to the world's biggest actively run bond fund, says asset prices around the world will be able to withstand a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase.

site_title: Volkswagen says 8m cars in EU affected by cheat software: letter
summary: Volkswagen admitted to installing cheat software in 8 million diesel vehicles in the European Union, affecting 1.2, 1.6, and 2.0 liter engine variants. The affected vehicles, produced between 2009 and 2015, were used for emissions tests. The company claims the software was designed to meet EU emissions standards. A letter to German lawmakers revealed the extent of the issue, which has sparked concerns over the company's honesty and the impact on air quality. An investigation is underway, and Volkswagen faces potential fines and legal consequences.

site_title: China jumps to 4th most-used world payment currency: Swift
summary: China's yuan surpassed the Japanese Yen to become the fourth most-used world payment currency in August, according to SWIFT. Global yuan payments increased by 9.13% and reached a record high market share of 2.79%. The yuan has surpassed seven currencies in the past three years and is now only after the US dollar, euro, and sterling. More than 100 countries used the yuan for payments, with Singapore and the UK processing 24.4% and 21.6% of flows, respectively.

site_title: Neutrino scientists win Nobel Prize for Physics
summary: Japanese physicist Takaaki Kajita and Canadian Arthur B. McDonald won the 2015 Nobel Prize for Physics for their discovery that neutrinos have mass, significantly altering our understanding of the universe. This groundbreaking finding has been recognized as crucial to the study of the innermost workings of matter. The 8 million Swedish crown prize was awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip lower, led by Germany
summary: European shares fell on Tuesday, with Germany underperforming after reporting industrial orders unexpectedly dropped in August. Volkswagen's admission of 8 million vehicles fitted with software capable of cheating diesel emissions tests led to a 3% drop in shares. The FTSEurofirst 300 fell 0.5% and the DAX was down 0.7%. Hopes of asset sales and output cuts lifted copper prices, supporting Glencore's shares, while Bouygues Telecom rose 2.5% after aiming to improve profit margins.

site_title: Card payments boom across the world, led by Finland
summary: Card payments worldwide increased by 9% to 390 billion transactions in 2015, led by Finland, where individuals made an average of 450 non-cash payments in 2013. The US and Netherlands followed, with 390 and 380 non-cash transactions, respectively. Advancements in mobile banking, contactless cards, and blockchain technology are driving the growth. Meanwhile, cheque transactions declined 11% in 2013, and forecasted to drop below 5 billion by 2025.

site_title: India hopes to roll out goods and services tax in 2016: Modi
summary: India aims to roll out a goods and services tax (GST) in 2016, according to Prime Minister Narendra Modi. In a speech to Indian and German businesses, Modi emphasized business-friendly measures, including speeding up regulatory clearances and reducing licensing requirements. He also stated that his government will not resort to retrospective taxation. This comes as the GST has been blocked in parliament, with Modi's government looking to implement the tax reform in 2016.

images.alt_text: India hopes to roll out a new goods and services tax (GST) in 2016, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said on Tuesday in a speech to Indian and German businesses that played up the attractiveness of investing in Asia's third-largest economy.

site_title: Australia central bank holds rates steady for a 5th month
summary: Australia's central bank kept its cash rate at a record low 2.0% for a fifth consecutive month, defying expectations of a change. The Reserve Bank of Australia made the announcement following its monthly policy meeting, citing uncertainty over the impact of past rate cuts. Analysts had predicted no change, with 25 out of 25 polled by Reuters expecting the rate to remain steady. The decision reflects the bank's cautious approach to monetary policy amid economic uncertainty.

site_title: Alibaba, JD could benefit from doubling of China luxury spending
summary: Chinese luxury spending is expected to double, with consumers willing to pay up to 4,200 yuan (S$942.98) for a single item online, according to a KPMG survey. This boost in luxury spending could benefit e-commerce companies like Alibaba and JD.com, which are facing an economic slowdown in China. Alibaba has signed international brands like L'Oreal and Apple for its platforms, and is focusing on expanding international markets and location-based services. The company's growth has been impacted by a slowing Chinese economy, with 12 analysts cutting sales predictions in the past four weeks.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding may be witnessing a slowdown in online transaction growth, yet it can find consolation in China shoppers boosting their budgets for luxury items.

site_title: Patek Philippe is running an elite (free) watchmaking school in NYC
summary: Patek Philippe is launching a free, two-year watchmaking program in New York, training the next generation of specialized watchmakers. The program, which began in October 2015, offers 80 students a stipend and guaranteed employment upon graduation. With 300 applicants, the company aims to encourage smart young people to pursue watchmaking as a career path, addressing the industry's shortage of skilled labor. The program, led by director Laurent Junod, will teach students to work on quartz, mechanical, and automatic watches, with the goal of providing high-quality service to clients worldwide.

site_title: Singapore backs OECD proposals to combat tax avoidance
summary: Singapore supports the OECD's final recommendations to combat tax avoidance through base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS). The country is already in compliance with the principle that profits should be taxed where value is created. The OECD's recommendations target activities aimed at reducing tax liabilities, and Singapore welcomes the international approach to tackle this issue.

site_title: MoneySmart raises S$2.8m in Series A round
summary: MoneySmart, a Singapore-based personal finance portal, has raised S$2.8 million in a Series A round led by SPH Media Fund and joined by several investors. The funding will be used to grow the team and expand into a new Asian market by mid-2016. Founded in 2009, MoneySmart analyses and compares various financial products, achieving break-even and profitability by the end of 2014. The portal competes with other personal finance platforms in Singapore, including GET.com and iMoney.

site_title: Indonesia doing best it can to combat haze: disaster chief
summary: Indonesia's disaster chief, Willem Rampangilei, denied criticism that his country was not doing enough to combat forest fires causing haze in South-east Asia. The fires, fueled by El Nino conditions, have sent pollution levels soaring in Malaysia and Singapore, prompting calls for action from neighboring countries. Indonesia has deployed resources, including planes, helicopters, and troops, and is considering dumping fire retardant on smoldering peatlands. Despite offers of help from Singapore, Indonesia insists it can handle the situation, with over 1,200 hotspots still active as of Tuesday.

site_title: MOH appoints independent committee to look into Hep C outbreak at Singapore General Hospital
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has appointed an independent review committee to investigate an outbreak of Hepatitis C at Singapore General Hospital (SGH). The outbreak, which affected 22 patients with kidney disease, occurred between April and June. The committee, chaired by Prof Leo Yee Sin, will review SGH's findings to identify weaknesses in infection control and provide learning points for the healthcare system. The committee's work is expected to be completed in two months, with the findings to be shared with the public and the wider healthcare system.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end 1.0% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.0% on Tuesday, following Wall Street rallies and the signing of a Pacific Rim free-trade deal. The Nikkei-225 index reached 18,186.10, while the Topix index gained 0.81% to 1,475.84. The deal, involving 12 nations including Japan and the US, aims to create the world's largest free-trade area.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close higher, helped by Samsung Elec; won gains
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.6% to 1,990.65 points, driven by gains in Samsung Electronics, which jumped 3.2% ahead of its earnings guidance. Hyundai Motor Co. and Kia Motors Corp. fell 3.7% and 3.2%, respectively. The South Korean won strengthened 0.6% to 1,165.9 per dollar. The gains were capped by selling in automakers, but investors remain hopeful for Samsung's earnings guidance.

site_title: Asia: Shares rise on fading Fed rate views
summary: Asian shares rose to two-week highs on Tuesday, driven by fading expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike and a bounce in oil and commodity prices. Japan's Nikkei rallied 1.5%, while MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rose 0.9%. Speculation about the Bank of Japan expanding its stimulus program also boosted the dollar against the yen. The US jobs data, which led many investors to abandon expectations of a rate hike, further boosted riskier assets.

site_title: Creative Elite launches general offer for Jacks International
summary: Creative Elite Holdings has launched a general offer for health-food retailer Jacks International, acquiring 19.83 million shares at S$0.80 per share from Abacus Pacific.
