The offer price is a 90.5% premium over the last traded price of 42 Singapore cents. The offer includes 10.17 million shares of Jacks International at the same price.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: AmCham Singapore urges US Congress support for TPP
summary: AmCham Singapore has urged the US Congress to support the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) to boost trade volumes and foster stronger economic partnerships among 12 countries, including Singapore. The landmark agreement is expected to create job opportunities and growth for firms, particularly small and medium enterprises. The chamber's chairman, James Andrade, emphasized that the TPP will enable American companies to capitalize on the Asia-Pacific region's high growth rates and increase regulatory coherence, benefiting smaller firms seeking to establish operations in multiple locations. A successful TPP is seen as revolutionizing international trade in the region.

site_title: Gold holds near one-week high after Fed rate increase delay
summary: Gold prices held near a one-week high after the Federal Reserve delayed interest rate hikes, reducing bets on a US rate rise this year. The probability of a rate hike dropped to 10%, boosting gold and emerging markets. Analysts expect the Fed to wait until March to tighten monetary policy. Silver rose 0.2% and palladium fell 0.6% in the same period. Gold prices rose to $1,142.07, the highest since September 28, as investors await the release of the September FOMC meeting minutes for guidance on short-term gold price movements.

site_title: Goldman Sachs says Fed may delay rate increase well into 2016
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts the Federal Reserve may delay its interest-rate increase into 2016 or later due to a slowdown in US output and employment. The probability of a rate hike this year has dropped to 35.2% from 60% in August, with the chance of a move by the next meeting on Oct 27-28 declining to 10%. A weak employment report and stalled wage growth have made it difficult for the Fed to hike rates, with some investors betting on no hikes for the foreseeable future.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group says there's a chance the Federal Reserve will delay its planned interest-rate increase well into 2016, or even later.

site_title: Samsung seen tapping US$55b cash pile for share buyback
summary: Samsung Electronics may use its US$55 billion cash pile to buy back shares, potentially erasing this year's US$25 billion market decline. The move, analysts say, could boost shares by up to 20% and offer consolation to investors. A buyback would be Samsung's second in eight years, following a 2014 program. The company's sales of the S6 and Note 5 have been sluggish, prompting concerns over market share and projected sales. The share buyback could help return value to stockholders and alleviate market concerns.

site_title: Oil prices hold above US$46 ahead of US inventories report
summary: Oil prices remain above $46 a barrel ahead of a US report on commercial crude inventories, with Brent crude rising 13 cents to $49.38 a barrel. A decline in US drilling activity has supported prices, while reports of Russia's willingness to discuss the global supply glut have also contributed to the increase. The US Department of Energy is expected to release its weekly stockpiles report, which may show rising inventories and slowing demand. Analysts expect Iranian oil to be a key topic of any meeting, potentially leading to a one million barrel per day surplus of supply.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up; HTC drops after Q3 net loss
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.7% to 8,410.17 points, driven by gains in the electronics and financial subindices. However, HTC Corp lost 2.6% after posting a Q3 net loss of US$137.63 million. LCD panel makers were the top gainers, while the Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.291 to T$32.711 per US dollar.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise to near 1-mth high, helped by Samsung Elec; won up
summary: Seoul shares rose to a near one-month high, reaching 1,988.44 points, driven by a 3.6% gain in Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, the largest market heavyweight. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) gained 0.5% despite losses in automakers. Analysts expect Samsung's earnings guidance to be released on Wednesday, further boosting the market.

site_title: Glencore rallies fourth day in Hong Kong as debt concerns ease
summary: Glencore's Hong Kong shares rallied for a fourth day, rising 9.2% to HK$13.76 after analysts from Sanford C. Bernstein & Co stated that the company's debt doesn't pose an existential crisis. The stock's recovery comes amid speculation that last week's sell-off was overdone. Glencore's CEO Ivan Glasenberg avoided discussing the stock's performance, instead focusing on copper price recovery prospects. The copper market is expected to tighten and prices will rise as production is shut down.

site_title: Singapore boasts of highest gross per capita financial assets in Asia: Allianz
summary: Singapore has the highest gross per capita financial assets in Asia, with $170,000 at the end of 2014, according to the Allianz Global Wealth Report 2015. The city-state's gross financial assets grew 6.4% last year, driven by a 9% increase in life and pension assets. This surpasses other Asian countries such as Japan, Taiwan, and India. Singapore's mature economy is characterized by high financial assets, with the country's GDP growth expected to continue, despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Aberdeen cuts charges for all its Singapore funds ahead of CPF board's revised caps
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management Asia Limited has announced that it will subsidize operating expenses for its Singapore unit trusts by S$2-3 million annually, ahead of the CPF board's revised expense caps on CPFIS-included funds. The caps, set to take effect on Jan 1, 2016, will reduce the maximum permissible total expense ratio on higher risk equity funds from 1.95% to 1.75%. Aberdeen's move aims to mitigate the impact of the caps and signal its commitment to good fund performance.

site_title: CSA to work with industry players to boost Singapore's cyber security
summary: The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) has formed partnerships with Singtel, Check Point Software Technologies, and FireEye to enhance cyber-security capabilities and boost Singapore's cyber security. The partnerships aim to build local capabilities, develop industry talent, and create indigenous research and development. CSA will leverage Check Point's expertise to develop industry-leading security solutions, while improving information sharing with FireEye. Additionally, CSA has signed memoranda of understanding with other companies to introduce certification programs and train infocomm technology professionals for cyber-security operations.

site_title: Big US firms hold US$2.1 trillion overseas to avoid taxes: study
summary: The 500 largest US companies hold approximately $2.1 trillion in overseas profits, largely in tax havens, to avoid US taxes. If repatriated, these firms would collectively owe an estimated $620 billion in US taxes. Nearly three-quarters of these companies operate tax haven subsidiaries in countries such as Bermuda, Ireland, and Luxembourg, according to a study by the Center for Tax Justice and the US Public Interest Research Group Education Fund.

site_title: Australia: Shares reach a near 1-month high
summary: Australian shares rose for a second day, reaching a near 1-month high, driven by banks and miners. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 43.8 points to 5,194.3, with Commonwealth Bank and Westpac up 1.3% each. The benchmark has gained 6% since its two-year trough in September, but is still down 4% for the year. Investors await the Reserve Bank of Australia's monetary policy meeting, where rates are expected to remain at a record low 2.0%.

site_title: Australia: Shares come off 1-month high to close up 0.33%
summary: Australian shares closed 0.33% higher on Tuesday, rebounding from a near 1-month high, as banks and miners led gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 16.87 points to 5,167.4, but fell short of an intraday peak of 5,220. Technical analysts expect selling pressure around 5,200 points and 5,000 points as crucial support.

site_title: Indonesian rupiah rallies most since July 2014 as funds return
summary: Indonesia's rupiah surged 1.3% to 14,305 a dollar, its largest gain since July 2014, as investors returned to the nation's assets amid speculation the Federal Reserve will delay raising interest rates. The Jakarta Composite Index advanced 2.2%, following a 3.2% gain on Monday, and the currency has strengthened 2.3% this week, paring its loss this year to 13%. Analysts see a "multi-decade opportunity" in emerging markets, including Indonesia, following recent selloffs.

site_title: US dollar holds steady on improved risk appetite
summary: The US dollar held steady against major currencies as investors returned to equities, betting the Federal Reserve would delay hiking rates after disappointing US economic data. The dollar remained unchanged against the yen at 120.45, while the euro stood at 1.1194 yen. Improved risk appetite, fueled by expectations that the Fed would delay interest rate hikes and the Bank of Japan could offer further easing measures, boosted the dollar and pressured the yen. This trend is seen as a positive sign for risk appetite, easing risk aversion and setting the groundwork for the yen to weaken.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.39 points to 1658.98 on Tuesday, driven by gains. Volume reached 48.1 million lots worth RM15.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 175 to 48.

site_title: Pilot falls ill, dies on American flight from Phoenix to Boston
summary: A 57-year-old American Airlines pilot from Utah died on a flight from Phoenix to Boston after falling ill. The Airbus A320 touched down safely in Syracuse, New York, where the pilot was pronounced dead on board. The copilot, who remained calm, landed the plane and requested medical assistance. The flight continued with a replacement crew and landed in Boston in the early afternoon. The cause and nature of the pilot's illness remain unknown, with the Onondaga County medical examiner's office referring questions to the police.

site_title: Paul Singer embraces Start-up Nation in battle for Israel economy
summary: US billionaire Paul Singer and Israeli economist Eugene Kandel are launching Start-Up Nation Central to promote Israel's high-tech industry, countering a Palestinian-led boycott movement. Singer's $20 million investment aims to attract international investors and officials, while Kandel will draw from his experience guiding long-term economic strategy at the prime minister's office. The foundation's goal is to strengthen Israel's economy, break down barriers with hostile countries, and promote Israel's tech industry globally. This effort counters pro-Palestinian groups' boycotts, such as the BDS campaign, and aims to shift attention to Israel's contributions to humanity.

site_title: Philippine Sept inflation hits record low, rates seen steady this year
summary: The Philippine annual inflation rate slowed to a record low of 0.4% in September, its seventh consecutive month of decline, and is expected to remain steady this year. Core inflation also reached a record low of 1.4%. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) has kept its key interest rate at 4.0% and is unlikely to change it, despite economists predicting a possible interest rate hike in 2016. The country's economic growth rebounded to 5.6% in the second quarter, but is expected to miss its 7-8% target for the year.

site_title: Trans-Pacific Partnership is a catalyst for Asia-Pacific growth: SBF
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) views the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) as a catalyst for Asia-Pacific growth and good news for the Singapore business community. Signed by 12 countries, including the US and Japan, the TPP provides a broad set of rules to enhance free trade and investment, boosting regional economic integration and improving market access for Singapore's exports. The agreement is also seen as a pathway towards a Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP).

site_title: SE Asia economic woes test reserves, defences built after 1997/98 crisis
summary: Southeast Asia's economies, particularly Malaysia and Indonesia, are facing increased vulnerability to economic downturns due to the region's reliance on commodity exports to China. While the region has made progress in improving its economic defenses since the 1997/98 crisis, economists warn that some countries could still be severely tested by currency pressures and reserve depletion. Foreign funds have sold a net $9.7 billion of stocks in Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia this year, with the region's largest net outflows.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday after gains in US, Europe
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 32.50 points or 1.14% to 2883.75 on Tuesday, mirroring gains in the US and European markets. The surge was driven by investor sentiment boosted by a deal reached by the 12 members of the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership. 124.4 million shares worth S$77.1 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 127 to 31. Top traded stocks included Singtel, DBS, and Wilmar.

site_title: Indonesia rupiah up more than 2 per cent to hit 1-month high
summary: Indonesia's rupiah surged more than 2% to a one-month high of 14,140 per dollar, driven by dollar selling by foreign investors. This rise joins other emerging Asian currencies in increasing against the US dollar, as investors expect the US Federal Reserve to hold off on raising interest rates. The rupiah's strength is also attributed to Indonesia's NDFs advancing against the dollar, with foreign investors dumping the greenback around 14,600. This move is seen as a positive sign for the Indonesian economy.

site_title: Little room for further easing with RBI's take on real rates
summary: India's central bank governor Raghuram Rajan has set a target for real interest rates of 1.5-2%, limiting room for further easing in borrowing costs. The RBI cut benchmark borrowing costs last week, but economists predict no further reductions through March due to inflation concerns and the need to shield markets from US interest rate hikes. The RBI aims to boost savings to finance growth, but the real-rate goal may prevent it from lowering borrowing costs, according to nine out of 11 economists surveyed.

site_title: China: Markets closed for National Day holiday Oct 1-7
summary: China's stock, bond, foreign exchange, and commodity futures markets will be closed from October 1-7 for a national holiday, resuming trade on October 8.

site_title: Pacific trade agreement boosts Abe's drive to recharge Japan
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to push through structural changes to recharge the country's economy received a boost with the signing of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a Pacific trade pact that would create the world's largest regional trade zone. The deal, which has been five years in the making, aims to boost commerce among nations producing 40% of global economic output. The agreement is expected to widen Japan's market for exports of cars and auto parts, attract overseas investment, and expand exports through deregulation, key components of Abe's growth plans.

site_title: SMEs to benefit from TPP: Lim Hng Kiang
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang stated that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal is designed to benefit small and medium enterprises (SMEs), despite being more inclusive for large companies. The TPP aims to reduce tariff and non-tariff barriers, encourage investment, and address new trade challenges, transforming the region and providing SMEs with full access to its benefits. The agreement was concluded by Singapore and 11 other countries, including major trading partners.

site_title: Fraser's A$520m Sydney mixed-use project gets the go-ahead
summary: Fraser's AU$520 million mixed-use project, DUO, has received development approval in Sydney. The project, part of the AU$2 billion Central Park development, will feature 313 residential apartments, a 300-room hotel, and commercial spaces. DUO is set to be launched to the market in late November with registrations of interest currently being taken. The project's completion is seen as a significant milestone for the joint venture team, with the development of Central Park nearing its completion.

site_title: China economic slowdown under control, says Japan former FX head
summary: China's economy remains in a controlled slowdown, according to Tatsuo Yamasaki, Japan's former currency chief. Yamasaki believes China has ample financial resources to cut rates and avoid a hard landing. The real economy will be less affected by market volatility, and the country is undergoing a transformation from manufacturing to services. Yamasaki advises Japan to monitor Chinese consumer trends, which impact the Japanese economy. China's devaluation in August was part of efforts to increase currency flexibility and internationalize the yuan, with a goal of becoming an IMF reserve currency.

site_title: Asia set for more stock gains as US rate outlook fuels rebound
summary: Asia's stock market is expected to continue its rally as the US Federal Reserve is likely to hold off raising interest rates until 2016, boosting riskier assets. Futures on Japanese and Hong Kong indexes rose 1-1.2% in recent trading, while Australian shares climbed 1% and New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 Index jumped 0.8%. The dollar and yen maintained losses, with the yen steady at 120.43 per dollar. The rally has pushed global equity values above $60 trillion this month, driven by weaker-than-expected US labor market data and the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal.

site_title: Home prices sizzle in China's Silicon Valley even as economy slows
summary: China's property market in Shenzhen, a tech hub, continues to boom despite the country's slowing economy. Real estate prices rose by nearly 33% in August from the same month last year, outpacing the 2.3% year-on-year decline in the rest of the country. Strong demand from tech executives and a scarcity of land contribute to the surge. Analysts predict a slight easing of prices by year-end as buyers seek more affordable options, but expect home prices to remain high due to limited supply.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares surge by opening on TPP deal
summary: Tokyo shares surged by 1.95% on Tuesday, October 6, 2015, after the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership free trade deal was reached by 12 members. The Nikkei Stock Average jumped 350.68 points to 18,356.17, while the Topix index rose 25.11 points to 1,489.03. The overnight gains in overseas markets and the deal's broad support boosted investors' sentiment.

site_title: LMIRT considers exercising put option for Jakarta mall's acquisition
summary: LMIRT Management is considering exercising a put option for the acquisition of Lippo Mall Kemang in South Jakarta due to a delay in strata-title certificate issuance. The mall was acquired in December 2014, and unitholders approved the acquisition in November 2014. The put option's long stop date may also be extended. The decision aims to address the delay and ensure the trust's interests are protected.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Miyoshi, Q&M Dental, Soup Restaurant, Frasers Centrepoint
summary: Precision engineering firm Miyoshi signed a joint venture agreement with Core Power Group, with the potential to acquire up to 49% stake in the Fujian-based electric-car firm. Q&M Dental Group's indirect subsidiary acquired a 60% stake in a Chinese medical equipment company for S$1.69 million. Soup Restaurant's owner successfully appealed a court decision on a lease lawsuit, while Frasers Property Australia and Sekisui House Australia received approval for their AU$520 million DUO project in Sydney, featuring 313 residential apartments and a 300-room hotel.

site_title: Wake up to Brexit risks, UBS to Morgan Stanley tell investors
summary: Investors are being warned to monitor the UK's membership in the European Union amid signs of diminishing support for staying in the bloc. Opinion polls show a narrowing gap between those wanting to leave and those wanting to stay, with some banks, including UBS, Citigroup, and Morgan Stanley, raising their estimates of the probability of Brexit to as high as 30%. The UK's economic and political stability could be threatened by a vote for Brexit, and uncertainty over the outcome may prompt gilt traders to discount interest rate hikes from the Bank of England.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend global surge on policy outlook as won jumps
summary: Asian stocks continued their upward trend, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rising 0.9% and the S&P 500 Index futures gaining 0.2% for a fifth consecutive day. The won jumped 0.5% versus the dollar, bolstering equities in riskier markets. Central banks are expected to maintain accommodative policies, delaying rate hikes, and speculation about the Federal Reserve's decision has boosted asset prices. The Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal may also have a positive impact on stocks.

site_title: Riyadh to convert state housing fund into bank
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to convert its state-owned Real Estate Development Fund into a bank, offering financing in cooperation with the private sector. The fund, which has 40 branches and a size of 183 billion riyals, aims to provide housing loans to eligible people, expanding its operations beyond interest-free loans for new residential construction. The move is part of King Salman's efforts to address the country's affordable housing shortage, which has been a complaint among young Saudis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.44% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.44% on Tuesday, following a global advance as investors await the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Hang Seng Index gained 314.60 points to 22,169.10, extending gains from the previous day. The move is seen as a positive sign for the market, with traders brushing off recent Trump threats. The US-EU trade talks and China's public holiday also influenced the market.

site_title: More execs should have faced prosecution for 2008 crisis: Bernanke
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke stated that more corporate executives should have faced prosecution for their actions leading up to the 2008 financial crisis. Bernanke emphasized that individual actions, rather than firms, were responsible for the crisis. He noted that the Fed is not a law enforcement agency, and prosecution decisions should be made by the Department of Justice and other law enforcement agencies.

site_title: Australia hails TPP as 'gigantic foundation stone'
summary: Australia welcomed the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement, hailing it as a "gigantic foundation stone" for the country's future prosperity. The 12-nation pact, which includes Australia, the US, and several Asian nations, aims to eliminate 98% of tariffs on goods and services. The deal is expected to boost trade, create jobs, and increase living standards, particularly in the mining-driven economy. However, some groups, including cane-growers and Labor opposition, have expressed concerns about specific provisions and potential disadvantages. The agreement must still be signed and ratified by participating countries.

site_title: US: Wall St rises as investors eye rate hike delay, oil up
summary: US stocks rose for the fifth day in a row, with the S&P 500 gaining 5.6% as investors bet the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates this year. Rising oil prices boosted energy stocks, while a weaker-than-expected job growth report increased expectations that the Fed will hold interest rates steady. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.85% and the Nasdaq Composite added 1.56%. Energy stocks jumped 2.9% and industrial stocks rose 3%, with GE and DuPont leading the gains.

site_title: NZ business confidence falls in Q3: survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence fell to a four-year low in the third quarter, with 14% of firms expecting general business conditions to deteriorate, according to a private think tank. The survey points to annual growth of 2.5% and weak inflation, with 10% of businesses cutting prices over the last quarter. Economists expect a further rate cut by the end of the year, citing low inflation indicators. The reading also showed a decline in capacity utilization and a slowdown in the building sector.

site_title: Singapore haze prompts banks to debate rainforest loan standards
summary: Singapore's banking group has launched a review of ethical lending practices amid haze caused by forest fires in Indonesia. The Association of Banks in Singapore will work on measures to improve responsible lending without specific details. Only four major banks in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore embed environmental factors into their credit-decision process. The move aims to mirror efforts by regional companies to clean up their act, particularly in Europe and developed economies. The review comes as the Indonesian government investigates 100 companies for blazes on their land and the fires are expected to become the worst on record, surpassing a 1997 environmental disaster.

site_title: With free trade deal, Obama solidifies US pivot to Asia
summary: US President Barack Obama has finalized a free trade agreement with Asia-Pacific nations, solidifying his administration's "pivot" to the region. The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) brings together 12 countries representing 40% of the global economy, excluding China. The agreement is seen as a diplomatic success for Obama, who has faced criticism for his handling of the Middle East. The pact is intended to strengthen US relationships with partners and allies, and provide a counterbalance to China's growing economic influence.

site_title: Vietnam weathers, Indonesia suffers fallout from commodity rout
summary: Vietnam's economy is expected to benefit from its diversified exports, with a reduced dependence on commodities. In contrast, Indonesia and Malaysia's failure to diversify their exports poses a risk to Asia's 2016 outlook. Vietnam's GDP per capita is lower than Indonesia's, but its economy is projected to expand by over 6% in 2016, the fastest among major Southeast Asian economies. Indonesia's economy is expected to grow 5.4% and Malaysia's 4.9% in 2016. The commodity rout, combined with an intensifying El Nino weather pattern, is expected to drag on growth in 2016.

site_title: Historic Pacific trade deal faces skeptics in US Congress
summary: US lawmakers are skeptical about the historic Pacific trade deal, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), which aims to liberalize commerce in 40% of the world's economy. The deal, reached by 12 Pacific Rim countries, would cut trade barriers and set common standards, but critics fear it would cost manufacturing jobs and weaken environmental laws. US lawmakers must approve the deal, with some, including Senator Bernie Sanders, warning it would hurt consumers and jobs. The pact would reduce or eliminate tariffs on almost 18,000 categories of goods, but its fate remains uncertain.

site_title: Najib urges Indonesia to tackle fires; haze drifts to Thai sky
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has urged Indonesia to take decisive action against people and companies setting fires that cause haze, affecting southern Thailand. The haze crisis is exacerbated by dry conditions due to El Nino, with over 200 companies suspected of causing fires. Indonesia has declined offers of help and continues to brush off complaints, despite vowing to stop the burning. Schools in Malaysia and Singapore have closed, and health authorities warn people to avoid exercise on bad days, as the situation remains unresolved.

site_title: Tools for a new business landscape
summary: Two innovative companies have developed solutions to enhance business operations. Concorde Security's I-Man Facility Sprinter (IFS) provides remote surveillance and monitoring services for buildings, reducing costs and improving productivity. The IFS system uses advanced technology to react to alarms and suspicious activities, allowing businesses to cut costs and improve work-life balance for security guards. Meanwhile, LDR's Pocket Trips app enables companies to create location-based apps for outdoor training programs and tours, engaging employees and visitors in a more interactive way.

site_title: Singapore fund still haunted by risky credit crisis investments
summary: A Singapore-listed mutual fund, Global Investments Ltd, continues to struggle with risky investments made during the 2008 global financial crisis. The fund, which owns $46.5 million in Australian residential mortgage-backed securities and €30.3 million in European collateralized loan obligations, is trading at a 38% discount to its net assets. Chairman Boon Swan Foo admits it's been a "massive struggle" and the fund has had to change its board and clean up legacy assets. Despite this, the fund has not posted a loss since 2009 and has continued to pay dividends.

images.alt_text: Residential mortgage-backed securities and collateralised loan obligations didn't turn out to be very good investments during the global financial crisis.

site_title: SSMC goes green in energy usage and strategic approach
summary: Systems on Silicon Manufacturing Co (SSMC) has been recognized for its energy efficiency efforts, saving 23.9 million kWh per year. This translates to powering approximately 5,000 4-Room HDB flats for a year. The company attributes its energy efficiency to being the most cost-effective way to address energy cost, security, and climate change challenges.

site_title: Citi appoints new head of secured finance solutions
summary: CitiBank Singapore has appointed Sherry Leong as head of secured finance solutions, with over 20 years of experience in the mortgage business. Leong will lead and grow the business covering personal home loans and car loans, with a focus on customer servicing. Under her leadership, the bank's market share in the business has grown steadily. Citi introduced Citi Direct Car Loan last year, which has effectively cut out car dealers as traditional middlemen in car purchases. Leong's appointment aims to further grow the business and improve customer experience.

site_title: Global regulators finalise new capital rules for nine biggest insurance firms
summary: Global regulators have finalized new capital rules for the nine biggest insurance firms, aiming to prevent taxpayer bailouts in a crisis. The rules require these insurers to hold an additional buffer, with the first capital cushion being 75% of the national requirement and a second buffer averaging 10% of the basic requirement. The insurers, including AIG and MetLife, must meet their combined capital requirements from 2019. The move follows the massive public rescue of AIG during the 2007-2009 financial crisis, with the goal of preventing similar bailouts in the future.

site_title: BOJ expected to hold monetary policy steady
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to hold its monetary policy steady on October 7, as policymakers prefer to save options while hoping a tightening job market will offset economic pain from China's slowdown. The BOJ will face pressure to ease policy at a crucial meeting on October 30, when it may cut long-term economic projections due to sluggish exports and falling oil prices. This decision comes as China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

summary: Per Wimmer, a financier, is taking his love for adrenaline to new heights by planning to go to space.

site_title: Google in talks to invest in chat company Symphony: source
summary: Google, now a holding company Alphabet Inc, is in talks with messaging startup Symphony for a fundraising round, valued at about $650 million. Symphony's chat service allows financial firms and corporate customers to centralize their digital communications, rivaling Bloomberg LP and Thomson Reuters Corp. The service costs $15 per user per month for businesses with over 50 users, and offers free access for smaller businesses and individuals. The talks are ongoing, with Goldman Sachs leading a group of 14 banks in a $66 million investment in Symphony last October.

site_title: Modi, Merkel agree to fast-track business deals
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and German Chancellor Angela Merkel signed 18 agreements worth $3.2 billion, including deals on clean energy and investment in India's solar energy industry. The agreements were signed during Merkel's visit to New Delhi, where she and Modi discussed increasing trade and cooperation between the two countries. The agreements include fast-tracking approvals for German companies to operate in India and lending expertise in vocational education. The move aims to boost investment and trade between the two nations, with Germany being India's largest European trading partner.

site_title: Hamburg to seize empty commercial space for refugees
summary: Hamburg, Germany has passed a law allowing the city to requisition empty commercial properties to house asylum seekers. The law, adopted by the city's parliament, does not affect private apartments. The move comes as the city struggles to find alternative solutions to the record influx of migrants, with up to a million expected this year. The opposition has condemned the initiative, but it follows a similar measure adopted by Berlin.

site_title: Educating the next generation
summary: Singapore's School of Science and Technology (SST) has won the Best Energy Efficiency Practices for Public Sector Agencies (Schools) category of the EENP Awards 2015. The school emphasizes sustainability and environmental friendliness, incorporating eco-friendly design and practices into its operations. By implementing strict control policies, educating students and staff on energy conservation, and collaborating with external organizations, SST has reduced its energy consumption by an average of 20% annually, exceeding its 10% target. The school's efforts have been recognized with the BCA Green Mark Gold Plus Award and the School Green Audit (Lotus Award).

site_title: 12 Pacific rim nations seal deal for world's largest free trade area
summary: Twelve Pacific rim nations, including the US, Japan, and Canada, have sealed a deal to create the world's largest free trade area, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). The agreement aims to set rules for 21st-century trade and investment, press China to adhere to standards, and create jobs and drive sustainable growth. The pact, covering 40% of the global economy, includes duty-free trade on most goods and reduced tariffs on others. However, critics argue that the deal may harm workers and the environment in some countries, and its implementation will require ratification by each nation.

site_title: Share buybacks in third quarter triple from Q2
summary: Singapore-listed firms have spent almost two-thirds of their share buybacks in the third quarter, with $1.07 billion worth of shares purchased in July to September. This is triple the amount spent in Q2 and significantly higher than Q1. Analysts attribute the spike to the sharp drop in global stock markets, with companies buying back shares to signal confidence or boost financial ratios. The largest share buyback was by Global Logistic Properties, purchasing 101.6 million shares worth $224 million.

Productivity gains are seen as crucial to unlocking wealth creation, while de-dollarization and shifting safe havens are also on the horizon.

site_title: Services growth cools in September as orders slow
summary: US services industries experienced a slowdown in growth in September, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index declining to 56.9 from 59 the prior month. This marks the best readings in a decade, but a sign that consumers may be taking demand down to a more sustainable level amid global weakness. The median estimate of economists had forecast a reading of 57.5.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ascendas Reit will issue S$300 million worth of subordinated perpetual securities. Q&M Dental Group's indirect subsidiary plans to acquire a 60% stake in a Chinese medical equipment company for S$1.69 million. Ramba Energy will invest US$179.6 million in a 35% stake in a Lemang Production Sharing Contract. Soup Restaurant's owner successfully appealed against a court decision over a lease lawsuit with the company, winning the 69 sq m of shop space.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a healthcare glove manufacturer, has seen its share price increase to S$1.655 after a non-deal roadshow in Malaysia, where institutional funds expressed interest due to its dominance in the cleanroom-glove niche and above-average returns. In contrast, Citic Envirotech's share price fell 26% after its Q2 results, despite a relatively strong set of numbers, due to market concerns over the water treatment industry in China.

site_title: ICE Singapore gets European clearing nod, will go live on Nov 17
summary: ICE Singapore's clearing house has been recognized by the European Securities and Markets Authority as meeting the continent's standards, allowing it to provide clearing services to European companies. The unit will go live on November 17, along with its futures market. This equivalence decision will help ICE tap into European customers, who will no longer face capital requirements seen as prohibitively expensive. This is the latest in a series of countries granted equivalence status, including Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, and Singapore.

site_title: Creating better value for stakeholders
summary: The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) is hosting the 6th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2015 from Oct 12-16, 2015, with 85 companies having joined the statement of support initiative for excellence in corporate governance. The statement, endorsed by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) and the Singapore Accountancy Commission (SAC), emphasizes the importance of good corporate governance in enhancing shareholder value and maintaining the stability of the financial markets. Companies participating in the initiative include Neo Group, Midas Holdings, CapitaLand Mall Trust Management, StarHub, and Vard Holdings.

site_title: No orders from Emirates at Dubai Airshow
summary: Emirates airlines announced it will not make any significant orders at the upcoming Dubai Airshow, set to take place from November 8-12. The airline's president, Tim Clark, stated that the carrier is still receiving planes announced at the 2013 air show. Additionally, Emirates will not make a decision on purchasing Airbus A350 or Boeing 787 twin-aisle jets this year.

site_title: Ser Luck: Govt to look into foreign worker levy
summary: Singapore's newly-appointed Minister of State for the Manpower Ministry, Teo Ser Luck, has announced that the government will review the foreign worker levy due to growing concerns from businesses. The levy's high cost is a major worry, and Teo plans to discuss manpower policy responses with industry leaders to prioritize sector-specific solutions. This move comes as Singapore navigates economic headwinds, with global trade tensions and a slowing economy posing challenges to the country's growth.

site_title: Jack Ma canvas fetches HK$42.2m at Sotheby's auction in HK
summary: Jack Ma's oil on canvas painting, "Paradise," fetched HK$42.2 million at a Sotheby's auction in Hong Kong, 17 times the high estimate. The painting, created in 2014 and depicting planet Earth, will be sold for charity to promote environmental awareness. Ma, Alibaba founder, has no plans to pursue a career in art and views the sale as an honor. The sale was part of Sotheby's Modern and Contemporary Asian Evening Art Sale, which saw HK$596 million worth of art sold.

site_title: Online video providers eye more relevant search functions
summary: Online video providers are working to improve their search functions, with HBO's executive vice-president citing the need for more specific search capabilities. Currently, services like Netflix and Hulu have limited search functionality, while YouTube offers more advanced search features, including the ability to search for specific scenes within videos. However, delivering relevant results remains a challenge, with many services relying on recommendation systems instead of traditional search. Experts suggest that true video search should allow users to link directly to specific moments within videos, but this functionality is not yet available on major subscription video-on-demand sites.

site_title: Murata Electronics goes for low-hanging fruits first
summary: Murata Electronics Singapore implemented energy efficiency projects to reduce energy consumption and costs. The company started with simple measures such as shutting down air-conditioning and increasing room temperature, and later progressed to more advanced projects. The efforts led to a significant energy consumption cost downtrend and improved the company's competitive edge. The company's assistant general manager, Wee Boon Kuang, emphasizes the importance of energy efficiency in reducing waste, costs, and environmental impact, and encourages other companies to prioritize sustainable energy consumption.

site_title: VW began cheating on emissions tests in 2008: sources
summary: Volkswagen began installing software to cheat on emissions tests in 2008 after realizing the new diesel engine couldn't meet US pollution standards. The company decided to cheat rather than cancel production, which would have been costly. The deception will force Volkswagen to undertake costly repairs on 11 million affected vehicles and has tarnished Germany's image. The company has suspended three top managers and will disclose findings from its internal inquiry this week. Analysts warn the crisis could affect Volkswagen's financial health, credit rating, and ability to package car loans into securities, potentially forcing the company to sell assets.

site_title: 'Coup capital of the democratic world'
summary: Australia's Malcolm Turnbull becomes its 29th Prime Minister after defeating Tony Abbott in an internal party room ballot. This marks the fourth change of leader since 2010, with only one coming from a general election. The country's high turnover of leaders has led to it being dubbed the "coup capital of the democratic world." However, the changes are legitimate under the Westminster system, where the leader of the largest bloc in parliament becomes head of government, and their tenure depends on maintaining majority support. Turnbull's ascension is seen as a result of internal party deliberations.

site_title: Coca-Cola to shut Tuas plant; plans investment to move up value chain
summary: Coca-Cola Singapore Beverages will close its Tuas plant by February 2016, affecting around 200 employees. The company plans to invest over $100 million in Singapore over the next five years to focus on high-value added services like innovation and research. Employees will receive competitive severance packages and support services. The closure is part of Coca-Cola's strategy to better position itself for future growth, with operations to remain in Singapore.

site_title: Abbott on course to cut energy spending by 45%
summary: Abbott's Singapore plant aims to reduce its annual energy spending by 45% by the end of 2017, a 33% decrease from 2012. This initiative, launched in 2012, has saved the equivalent energy needed for 7,000 households in Singapore for a year. Abbott's efforts to improve energy efficiency have not only helped protect the environment but also strengthened the company's business. Steven Huang, utility & facility manager, has been named Outstanding Energy Manager of the Year at the EENP Awards 2015.

site_title: Woodlands Civic Centre lauded for new initiatives
summary: The Woodlands Civic Centre in Singapore has been recognised as an energy-efficient building at this year's EENP Awards, thanks to various new energy-efficient initiatives implemented by the Housing & Development Board (HDB) over the past three years. These initiatives have helped the complex achieve an energy consumption savings of over 40% and saved S$700,000 in utility bills annually. The HDB has also planned to install variable air volume boxes, temperature sensors, solar panels, and more efficient air filters to further enhance energy efficiency and sustainability.

site_title: S'pore firms improving energy efficiency
summary: Singaporean firms are improving energy efficiency to address energy costs, security, and global climate change. The country's growing economy and increasing population drive energy demand, prompting companies to adopt energy-efficient practices. The National Energy Efficiency Conference (NEEC) 2015 highlights the importance of strategic energy management for resilience. Energy Efficiency National Partnership (EENP) Awards recognize companies that have made significant energy efficiency improvements, with 218 companies joining the program since its launch in 2010. Experts emphasize the need for companies to adopt robust energy management systems and utilize data to improve energy efficiency.

site_title: South African coal miners strike as wage talks fail
summary: Over 30,000 South African coal miners began an indefinite strike on October 5, 2015, after wage negotiations with industry bosses failed. The National Union of Mineworkers is demanding a 14% wage increase, while the industry offers only about half of that. The strike affects mining houses Anglo American, Exxaro, and Glencore, including Glencore's Optimum Coal Mine, which is restructuring due to financial hardship. The strike will continue until the two parties can resolve their differences.

site_title: Nan Chiau High's 3-year strategic thrust
summary: Nan Chiau High School in Sengkang, Singapore, has been recognized as one of the top energy-efficient schools in the country, winning the Best Energy Efficiency Practices award at the EENP Awards 2015. The school's three-year strategic thrust aims to decrease its energy consumption by 0.3% each year. To achieve this, the school has implemented various initiatives, including energy-saving projects, environmental awareness programs, and green procurement practices. The school's efforts have resulted in significant energy savings and a more sustainable learning environment.

site_title: IMF calms market fears over China slowdown
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has calmed market fears over China's slowdown, stating that Beijing has adequate room for manoeuvre to implement policy stimulus if needed. The IMF acknowledged that China's transition to domestic demand-driven growth poses risks, particularly due to high debt levels, but noted that the current pace of slowdown is in line with forecasts. The organization emphasized the need for vigilance, particularly for the rest of the world, as China's slowdown could have spillover effects on other Asian countries.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund on Monday moved to calm growing anxiety over the slowdown in China's economy, saying that developments so far "provide some comfort" that the transition from export-led to domestic demand-driven growth "can be managed".

site_title: State giants look elsewhere as China's gas boom falters
summary: China's energy giants, PetroChina, China National Offshore Oil Corporation, and Sinopec, are forced to sell a glut of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to buyers abroad due to a slowdown in domestic demand. The cooling economy and high gas prices, which are among the world's highest, have led to a 3% decline in demand, threatening Beijing's targets of curbing pollution and emissions. The excess supply is expected to increase global gas prices and pressure Chinese policymakers to speed up reforms of the oil and gas sector.

site_title: Overseas investors fire warning at China Inc
summary: Institutional investors are increasingly speaking out against corporate governance in China, with recent shareholder votes in Hong Kong signaling a shift in tolerance for sloppy practices. China Merchants Bank's proposal to allow its chairman and non-executive directors to buy shares at a discount was rejected by almost 42% of shareholders, and a similar plan by Citic Securities was opposed by over a quarter of its shareholders. This growing unease may mark a turning point for Chinese companies, as foreign investors once held significant sway. Institutional investors are now using their limited powers to challenge corporate practices.

site_title: Glencore shares surge; analysts say worry about firm's survival unjustified
summary: Glencore shares surged 12% to a one-week high, reaching 106.85 pence, after analysts at Sanford C Bernstein & Co stated concerns about the company's solvency are unjustified. The company has secure access to funding, plans asset sales to cut debt, and released a statement saying its business is "robust." Analysts, including Citigroup, had recommended buying the shares, citing the company's ability to manage its leverage and recover from losses. Glencore's debt is expected to be manageable, with immediate access to $13 billion in cash liquidity.

site_title: World Bank trims Asia forecast but says no China hard landing
summary: The World Bank has trimmed its growth forecasts for developing economies in East Asia and the Pacific, but reassured that China's economy will not experience a hard landing. China's GDP is forecast to grow 6.9% this year, moderating to 6.7% in 2016 and 6.5% in 2017. The bank expects a moderate slowdown in China to be the main reason for the lower forecasts, while also warning of a risk that US interest rate increases could prompt regional currency falls.

site_title: Commodity prices poised to keep falling, and the end isn't yet in sight
summary: Commodity prices have declined 46% since 2011, causing industry consolidation and bankruptcies. Economic growth remains weak, and developed countries' demand for commodity-based products is decreasing due to financial excesses. The world is in an 8-year deleveraging cycle, potentially taking over 10 years to complete. New commodity production capacity has increased, but muted demand in North America and Europe has slowed economic growth in China. Hard-rock miners are compelled to produce at low prices to avoid losses, and Russia depends on energy exports to cover costs.

site_title: CAAS net surplus for FY14/15 drops to S$65.88m
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) reported a net surplus of S$65.88 million for the year ended March 31, 2015, down from S$89.9 million the previous year. Income declined due to lower air navigation service charges, while expenditure rose due to higher salaries and staff benefits. The decrease in net surplus was attributed to "financial costs having a significant effect on Singapore's air hub competitiveness." CAAS chairman Lee Hsien Yang attributed the adjustments in fees and charges to keep Changi Airport cost-competitive.

Kwong notes that Asia will both drive and gain from dollar asset diversification. site_title: Philippines to grow 5.8% in 2015: World Bank
summary: The Philippines is expected to experience 5.8% economic growth in 2015, according to a World Bank report. This growth is attributed to private domestic demand, record low inflation, and robust remittances. However, the country faces challenges such as slow public spending, stagnant agriculture growth, and cumbersome business regulations. The report projects improved growth in 2016, reaching 6.4%. The central bank has maintained a steady monetary policy, and inflation is expected to remain low.

site_title: Dow's Friday rally helps STI rebound 2%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 2.1% on Monday, driven by a US market rally on Friday, which was fueled by a weak jobs report. Trading volume remained low, with 1.1 billion units worth S$942 million, mostly concentrated in the 30 STI components. Program trading by computers and potential short-sellers caught in a short squeeze are possible explanations for the index's bounce.

site_title: UK govt plans to sell at least £2b of Lloyds shares to consumers early next year
summary: The UK government plans to sell at least £2 billion of Lloyds Banking Group shares to consumers early next year, with a 5% discount and a bonus share for holding the investment for over a year. The government aims to "fully exit" its Lloyds stake in the coming months.

site_title: Excellent time to join #FreeTheFed campaign
summary: The US Federal Reserve failed to raise interest rates in September, instead signaling slower rate changes. The decision was attributed to market volatility, a reason deemed "frightening" by economists. However, Fed Chair Janet Yellen later expressed her desire to raise rates, citing a potential 2% inflation target. As oil prices fade, headline inflation is expected to rise, potentially leading to a rate hike and freeing the Fed from market influence. This shift in market psychology and inflation outlook presents an opportunity to "Free the Fed."

site_title: OSIM edges up despite tea unit's HK media storm over pesticides
summary: OSIM International shares rose 1.23% to S$1.645 on Monday after a storm over pesticide residues in a batch of TWG Tea's "Chamomile Green Tea" sent to Taiwan was deemed a "storm in a teacup" by the market. TWG Tea explained that different markets have varying tests, and the batch had passed tests in Singapore. The company adheres to HACCP standards and tests teas multiple times before export. Shares closed higher after opening higher on Monday, with 2.19 million shares traded.

site_title: More people having trouble paying off unsecured debt
summary: Singapore sees a 10% increase in people struggling to pay unsecured debt, with 85,352 individuals missing two or more months of payments in June 2015. This represents a 32% jump from 2011. Economists warn that the weakening economy may worsen the debt situation, with interest rates, job market concerns, and a possible recession contributing to financial distress.

site_title: September PMI improves but outlook remains muted
summary: The Nikkei Singapore purchasing managers' index (PMI) rose to 51.4 in September, a seven-month high, indicating improved business conditions for private sector companies. Despite this, economists remain cautious due to external factors affecting the economy. The service sector showed resilience, while manufacturing weakness persisted. The improved PMI reading suggests a better operating environment, but concerns about external factors, such as global economic uncertainty, continue to dampen Singapore's economic performance.

site_title: Targeted ads offer hope with America's TV business in upheaval
summary: The US TV business is undergoing a shift as traditional viewing patterns challenge old advertising models. New digital mediums like Netflix and YouTube are disrupting the industry, leading to weaker TV ad revenue and shares suffering. However, this shift also presents opportunities for targeted advertising, with digital video ads projected to grow 21% annually. The TV industry is embracing digital technology, allowing for more detailed audience information and predicting behavior and buying habits. Set-top boxes are being upgraded to provide Internet-style targeting capabilities, and data brokers are supplying targeting services to the emerging industry of digital TV.

site_title: Why SMEs should step up in cyber security
summary: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are at risk of losing reputation and trust with clients due to inadequate cyber security measures. Despite the increasing sophistication of cyber threats, many SMEs prioritize other business issues, such as managing cash flow and manpower shortages. SMEs are often in denial about their vulnerability to cyber attacks, but failing to prepare for these threats can lead to significant financial losses and business failure. Investing in cyber security is crucial for SMEs to safeguard intellectual property, customer data, and financial information.

site_title: American Apparel files for bankruptcy
summary: American Apparel filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing huge debts, declining sales, and employee strife. The company, once a symbol of edgy made-in-America cool, will keep its manufacturing operations in Los Angeles and 130 US stores open through a debt-for-equity conversion deal with secured lenders. The restructuring will wipe out current shareholders, including ousted founder Dov Charney, and put creditors in control. The bankruptcy will also delay lawsuits against the company, allowing management to reorganize and implement a turnaround plan.

site_title: New education ministers pledge to build more and better learning pathways
summary: Singapore's new education ministers, Ng Chee Meng and Ong Ye Kung, have pledged to build more and better learning pathways for Singaporeans. They will oversee pre-schools, primary and secondary schools, and higher education, aiming to ensure students are well-prepared for the workforce. The ministers emphasized the importance of integrating and synergizing their work, building on the good work of their predecessor, and driving the national effort of SkillsFuture to equip students and workers with industry-relevant skills.

site_title: Thailand's military govt picks panel to write constitution after rejection of draft
summary: Thailand's military government has appointed a 21-member committee to draft the country's 20th constitution after a previous draft was rejected by the legislature, delaying promised elections until at least 2017. The new committee will have six months to write a new draft, requiring approval from the legislature and a referendum. The military-backed constitution was criticized for giving the military control over the executive and legislative branches in a "crisis" situation, and its rejection was seen as a victory for opponents. Elections are now expected to take place in 2017.

site_title: Apple Pay faces consumer indifference in inaugural year
summary: Apple Pay, launched in 2014, has failed to gain traction with consumers, accounting for only 1% of US retail transactions in 2015. Despite being called the "year of Apple Pay" by CEO Tim Cook, the service has been hindered by a lack of promotion and limited terminal availability, particularly on older iPhones. The service's availability is also limited to newer iPhone models, further contributing to its slow adoption.

site_title: Eurozone September business growth at four-month low: PMI
summary: The Eurozone's business activity grew at its weakest pace in four months in September, with a composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 53.6, down from 54.3 in August. Service firms raised prices for the first time in four years, but overall growth is expected to be modest, with a 0.4% third-quarter growth rate. This data is likely to disappoint policymakers, including the European Central Bank, which is reviewing its quantitative easing program. The UK's economy, which has been outpacing the eurozone, also showed a two-and-a-half-year low in service industry growth.

site_title: Short-sellers take on top HK property stock
summary: Evergrande Real Estate Group Ltd, the top-performing Hong Kong property stock, is also the most-shorted and lowest-rated among peers. Analysts and investors are concerned about the company's high debt load and potential liquidity issues, despite its recent buyback efforts and strong branding in China. The developer's shares have risen 51% this year, but fell 14% in September, and it plans to sell up to $4.47 billion in bonds this month. Experts warn it will take time for Evergrande to alleviate investor concerns about its balance sheet.

site_title: Air France-KLM to axe 2,900 jobs, cut long-haul flights
summary: Air France-KLM is set to unveil a restructuring plan on Monday, which is expected to lead to 3,000 job losses. The plan includes a 10% reduction in long-haul flights, a delay in Boeing 787 orders, and reducing its headcount. The airline aims to cut costs by 1.8 billion euros over two years. Unions have called a strike in response to the plan, which includes compulsory job cuts, a first for the carrier. The airline had previously sought to win pilots' agreement to fly more hours annually for the same salary.

site_title: Improving lives through technology
summary: The Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation (SiTF) Awards recognized innovative products and research in the information, communications, and media industry. The winners include Rotimatic, a robot that makes flatbread, and VEON@Hair Experience, a virtual hairstyling app. The awards showcased the diversity of winners, with backgrounds in technology, mechanical engineering, and university graduates. Rotimatic won Gold in the "Best Innovative Infocomm Product (Consumer)" category, while VEON@Hair Experience received the Silver award for "Best Innovative Research and Development".

site_title: Singapore office rents soften in Q3 on economic outlook: DTZ
summary: Singapore's average monthly gross rents in the central business district (CBD) declined by 4.1% quarter-over-quarter in Q3, marking the first decline from an uptrend since 2013. This follows headwinds in the external economic environment, including China's economic slowdown and subdued global growth. Office occupancy in the CBD also declined 0.9 percentage point to 95% in Q3, with rents expected to trend downwards in 2016 due to the large impending supply of office space.

site_title: Shining brightly beyond S'pore shores
summary: Singapore-based Sunray Woodcraft Construction, a leading commercial fit-out specialist, has expanded into key Asia-Pacific markets. Established in 1982, the company has grown from a small carpentry firm to a one-stop solution provider with a diverse portfolio of projects. Despite facing setbacks, including a 1999 fire that crippled its production arm, Sunray has successfully rebounded and expanded its services. The company has secured major projects in Singapore and abroad, including Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa, and has established a presence in China, India, Indonesia, and Malaysia.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to cut 400 marine jobs as oil slump hits ship sales
summary: Rolls-Royce to cut 400 marine jobs as oil slump hits ship sales, saving £40m a year with incremental benefits from 2016. The cutbacks follow the elimination of 600 factory posts in May and aim to simplify the marine unit's structure. The company's profit and revenue guidance for the marine unit remains unchanged, with the cuts part of a broader restructuring effort across the business.

site_title: Reducing costs to provide more affordable medicine
summary: Pharmaceutical company MSD International GmbH (Singapore branch) has won the Excellence in Energy Management award for its efforts to reduce energy costs. By implementing energy-efficient measures, such as using a 1500RT water chiller, MSD has saved approximately S$7 million annually. The company's energy-efficient initiatives have resulted in a 33% reduction in energy consumption and a corresponding reduction of 43,000 metric tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions. MSD's success in energy management has also generated business value through increased productivity and lower operating costs, benefiting patients by making medicine more accessible and affordable.

site_title: SRC wins award for its efforts
summary: Singapore Refining Company (SRC) won the Best Practices award for its efforts in improving energy efficiency, reducing costs, and lowering carbon emissions. The refinery, which processes 290,000 barrels of crude oil per day, implemented various initiatives such as energy blitzes, insulation improvements, and steam trap surveys to minimize energy consumption. SRC's energy team plans to continue sourcing energy-efficient technologies and aims to achieve a 10% reduction in energy consumption by 2020, further solidifying its position as a leader in strategic energy management.

site_title: Giving consumers a leg-up
summary: Two innovative businesses have received awards for their consumer-facing products. Rotimatic, a fully automatic flatbread-making robot, has won Gold for Best Innovative Infocomm Product (Consumer) by Zimplistic. In contrast, ShopBack, an e-commerce platform offering cashback to consumers, won Silver for Best Innovative Infocomm Product (Consumer) and Best Innovative Start-up (Growth Stage). Meanwhile, VEON@Hair Experience, a 3D hair-styling app, received Silver for Best Innovative Research & Development. These products showcase how technology can improve the consumer experience and are set to revolutionize various industries.

site_title: Najib walks the tightrope of fiscal prudence and economic activity
summary: Malaysia's government may miss its goal for a balanced budget by 2020 due to the country's reliance on oil exports, which have fallen by 50% since 2014. Prime Minister Najib Razak has indicated a one-per-cent GDP shortfall, reversing previous statements that the country would achieve a balanced budget in five years. Fiscal consolidation efforts are being aided by tax reforms and fuel subsidy changes, but economists warn that policymakers may backtrack on reforms, affecting the country's fiscal prudence and economic growth. The government's ability to strike a balance between spending and growth will be closely watched by international rating agencies.

images.alt_text: Squeezed by slumping oil prices, the Malaysian government has signalled that the country could miss its goal for a balanced budget by 2020, further derailing the crude-exporting nation's fiscal consolidation efforts.

site_title: SGX diversifies into indexing
summary: SGX has launched an index business, SGX Index Edge, to diversify beyond its domestic stock market. The new business will create and offer indices in Asia for issuers, asset managers, and investors. Revenue from the traditional securities business fell 8% in the year ended June 30, prompting diversification as a key priority. Simon Karaban will head Index Edge, and the business aims to bolster product offerings for investors. However, modest expectations are expected at the start, with SGX shares rising 2.2% after the announcement.

site_title: Dollar weaker as rate increase expectations pushed back
summary: The US dollar declined 0.5% against the euro and slipped against a basket of currencies after a weak US jobs report pushed back expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike to early 2016. The euro rose to US$1.1270, but its gains are likely to be muted due to the European Central Bank's need to ease monetary policy to counter inflation. The dollar index fell to 95.218, its lowest since September 21, while the euro-yen exchange rate moved away from its lowest since September 7.

site_title: New global proposals target corporate tax dodging
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has proposed significant changes to international corporate tax laws to combat avoidance, representing a "fundamental shift" in policy. The proposals aim to overhaul the current system, following public outcry over tax avoidance by companies like Starbucks and Google. Critics argue the proposals do not go far enough, while the OECD says they will help to "level the playing field" and ensure fairer taxation.

site_title: UK's Osborne borrows from Labour policies with eye on Tory leadership
summary: Finance Minister George Osborne, a potential future Conservative Party leader, has borrowed from Labour policies to appeal to workers and cement his "centrist" credentials. In a speech at the annual conference, Osborne said the Conservatives are the party of work and promised lower taxes and increased local government autonomy. He also unveiled plans to invest £5 billion in infrastructure by 2020 and recruited a former Labour cabinet minister to chair an independent commission. Osborne's move aims to address criticism over his austerity drive and strike at the heart of Labour's efforts to rally support for its new far-left leader, Jeremy Corbyn.

site_title: Washington gym takes fighters from streets into the ring
summary: A Washington gym, the Bald Eagle Recreation Center, provides a safe haven for aspiring boxers from a rough neighborhood. The gym, equipped with state-of-the-art facilities, is led by experienced coaches who serve as father figures. The center aims to redirect fighters from the streets into the ring, promoting a positive outlet for their energy and skills. By offering a supportive environment, the gym hopes to transform lives and build a sense of community in a neighborhood plagued by violence and crime.

site_title: Two Chinese financial giants to raise US$5b in IPOs
summary: Two Chinese financial giants, China Huarong Asset Management Co Ltd and China Reinsurance (Group), plan to raise a combined US$5 billion in initial public offerings (IPOs) in Hong Kong, a sign of improving market confidence. Huarong aims to raise US$3 billion, while China RE seeks to raise US$2 billion. The IPOs come after a period of volatility, but investors are cautiously optimistic about the prospects. The firms plan to use the funds to develop distressed asset businesses and expand financial services, indicating a potential boost to the Chinese economy.

site_title: Searching for value
summary: H-shares, a type of Chinese stock, are trading at a discount to A-shares, potentially offering a good entry point for long-term investors. This could be a strategic move for those looking to build positions in the Chinese market.

site_title: Miyoshi signs MOU on JV with China light electric car firm
summary: Singapore precision engineering firm Miyoshi has signed a memorandum of understanding with Fujian-based light electric car firm Core Power Group for a joint venture. The JV, subject to conditions, will see Miyoshi acquire up to 49% of Core Power, leveraging the latter's land and factory to produce environmentally friendly and affordable light electric vehicles. This move comes after Miyoshi's previous attempt to enter the light electric vehicle industry was put on hold due to supply chain disruptions and losses.

site_title: Banks, corporates making progress in sustainable development, says MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported progress in promoting sustainable development among financial institutions and listed corporations. MAS has been discussing guidelines with the Association of Banks in Singapore and supporting the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) plans to mandate sustainability reporting on a "comply or explain" basis, targeting implementation for 2017. The MAS also aims to develop guidance for investors to engage with companies on sustainability, social, and environmental considerations.

site_title: Most EU nations to block cultivation of 8 GMO crops
summary: Most EU nations, 19 out of 28, plan to block the cultivation of 8 genetically modified crops awaiting regulatory approval, citing a new right to opt-out on biotech foods. This marks the first use of a provision in EU legislation that lets individual governments adjust the geographical scope of GMO applications. The countries affected include Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Slovenia, and the UK, excluding Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.

site_title: Yoma would gain from selling Digicel Asian stake: analysts
summary: Analysts say Yoma Strategic could benefit from selling its Digicel Asian stake to Malaysian telco Axiata Group, which is planning to buy Digicel's 75% stake for $221 million. This sale would lift Yoma's stake value to around $20 million above its carrying value. Experts believe a sale would streamline the group's focus on core businesses and potentially yield a 1.1 US cents per share gain for Yoma. The company's stock has been muted due to the uncertain political climate in Myanmar, but is trading at an "attractive" 0.5 times RNAV.

site_title: IMF says China can manage slowdown, needs to communicate policy
summary: China can manage its economic slowdown, but needs to improve policy communication and prevent spillovers, according to the International Monetary Fund. The yuan's depreciation by around 3% in August was seen as in line with medium-term fundamentals. China must expand market forces and strengthen financial supervision to achieve sustainable growth. The slowdown's impact on other Asian countries is estimated to be 0.3% for each percentage point decline in China's growth. China is working to curb currency speculation and accelerate yuan convertibility on the capital account.

site_title: Beef isn't for dinner anymore as Americans devour cheaper pork
summary: US beef demand is slumping to its lowest in over four decades, with consumers opting for cheaper pork and chicken alternatives due to economic concerns. Cattle futures have fallen 12% in the last quarter, while hog futures are expected to rebound. This shift is driven by lower prices, with retail beef costs dropping 14% in September and pork prices down over 7% from a record high. As a result, US per-capita beef consumption is expected to decline to 53.9 pounds a person in 2015, the lowest since 1970.

site_title: Oil up as Russia mulls talks with Opec and rig count drops
summary: Russia has expressed willingness to meet with Opec and non-Opec oil producers to discuss oil markets, potentially supporting prices. Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent increasing 70 cents to $48.83 a barrel, amid a fifth weekly fall in US oil rigs and Russia's reluctance to cut output. Russia's oil output hit a post-Soviet monthly high in September, despite global prices hitting 6 1/2-year lows in August. A planned meeting between Russian and Saudi officials is set for the end of October, fueling expectations of possible production restraint.

site_title: Wild markets bring equity risk premium debate to the fore
summary: Equity risk premiums in Asian markets have surged in recent weeks due to market volatility, but the concept's computation and usage remain disputed among industry practitioners and academics. The figures range from 4% to nearly 8% and are influenced by factors such as fear, economic conditions, and commodity prices. Analysts debate the use of short-term versus long-term ERPs, with some arguing that only long-term figures are valid. The concept is considered essential for asset allocation decisions, but its interpretation should be done within a larger matrix of indicators and with caution.

site_title: Indonesia maritime bodies seek rupiah exemption
summary: Indonesia's shipowner and shipbuilder associations, Insa and Iperindo, are seeking an exemption from using the rupiah for their members due to the added burden it poses from the oil and gas downturn. The associations are also seeking clarity on the implementation of the rupiah requirement imposed by Bank Indonesia in July 2015, which allows for exemptions in certain sectors, including the oil and gas sector with international credit backing. The move aims to reduce hardship for the sectors that mostly transact in US dollars.

site_title: Asia: The epicentre of the digital banking shake-up
summary: Asia is the epicentre of the digital banking revolution, with customers increasingly using digital channels over traditional ones. The rise of digitally savvy customers with sophisticated expectations is driving change in the banking industry, with 46% of bankers surveyed expecting changing customer demands to have a significant impact on retail banking by 2020. Established players are investing heavily in digital strategies, with new-model lenders like Alibaba's Ant Financial and Tencent's WeBank set to launch in the region, offering innovative credit rating systems and streamlined customer experiences. The stakes are high, with 80% of consumers willing to shift their holdings to a bank with a compelling digital proposition.

site_title: Who's afraid of vacancies? Not billionaire Larry Friedland
summary: New York real estate billionaire Larry Friedland, 76, has maintained his business empire despite criticism for allowing commercial properties to remain vacant until he secures the desired rent. Friedland Properties, founded by him and his late brother in 1960, is valued at $3 billion and owns over 20 buildings on Madison Avenue, including luxury retailers like Ralph Lauren and Dolce & Gabbana. Friedland's strategy has been praised by some, who say it allows him to maintain control over the high-end retail strip, while others criticize it as "exorbitant rates" that force local businesses to leave.

site_title: Twitter names Jack Dorsey permanent CEO
summary: Twitter named Jack Dorsey as its permanent CEO on October 5, 2015, replacing former CEO Dick Costolo. Dorsey had served as interim CEO for three months. He will remain head of Square, potentially creating a conflict of interests. Twitter had previously stated the CEO job would be full-time, excluding Dorsey's role in Square.

site_title: São Paulo mayor battles resistance to ease gridlock
summary: São Paulo Mayor Fernando Haddad is implementing sweeping mobility reforms to ease gridlock in the megacity, including bike lanes, expanded pavements, and reduced speed limits. The measures have drawn criticism from motorists and opponents, but polls show relatively high levels of support, with 59% of residents in favor of bike lanes and 64% supporting car-free Sundays. Despite resistance, Haddad remains committed to his policies, citing statistics showing a 18.5% decline in traffic-related fatalities and faster traffic flow on highways with reduced speed limits.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on talk of later rate hike
summary: US stocks rose in early trading Monday, driven by relief that the Federal Reserve may hold off on a rate hike until December. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.73% to 16,592.30, while the S&P 500 gained 0.84% to 1,967.81, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.78% to 4,744.50. This follows a European rally after a weak US jobs report on Friday. The Fed's decision has sparked speculation that a rate hike may be delayed, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: 'Li Na factor' not enough for China to become tennis powerhouse: observers
summary: China's emergence as a tennis powerhouse is hindered by a cultural shift towards individual development, despite Li Na's Grand Slam wins. Experts say central planning is insufficient for the sport's growth, citing the need for a more individualized approach. The recent opening of a 15,000-seat stadium in Wuhan, China, demonstrates the sport's growth, but more must be done to support individual players and coaches. A cultural shift towards supporting individual development is necessary for China to become a dominant force in tennis.

site_title: Let the luxury wars begin - online
summary: Department stores and luxury brands are shifting their focus to online sales, competing with e-commerce platforms and Web distributors.
