This trend is driven by slowing growth in China, with luxury-goods makers such as LVMH and Hugo Boss increasing their e-commerce efforts. As a result, deals like Yoox's merger with Net-a-Porter are becoming more common, indicating a shift in the luxury retail landscape, with the Internet resembling the real world.

site_title: Macau cloud shouldn't darken my casino: Enrique Razon
summary: Philippine billionaire Enrique Razon Jr, CEO of Bloomberry Resorts Corp, says the company's casino losses are not comparable to Macau's, despite both being major players in the industry. Razon attributes Bloomberry's losses to the decline in Macau's revenue and credits the company's growing gaming revenue and expanding mass market. He expects the mass segment to account for 60% of Bloomberry's gaming revenue in 3-5 years, reversing the current ratio of VIP customers. Razon plans to invest in new gaming ventures, including a $1 billion casino in South Korea and a potential casino in Argentina.

images.alt_text: "We can't stick to a strategy just because we want to. We have to adapt to the market, whatever that takes," says Mr Razon.

site_title: Rare Tintin drawing fetches US$1m in Hong Kong
summary: A rare Tintin drawing by Belgian cartoonist Hergé, from the 1936 book "The Blue Lotus," sold for HK$9.6 million (US$1.7 million) at an auction in Hong Kong, setting a record for a Tintin piece. The monochrome illustration shows Tintin being pulled through a Shanghai street and is one of only a few original copies remaining in private hands. The sale indicates comic art is becoming collectible, with experts comparing it to paintings.

site_title: Pacific trade negotiators reach landmark deal, fight for approval to follow
summary: Pacific trade ministers have reached a landmark deal on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a trade liberalization pact affecting 40% of the world economy. The 12-country agreement sets common standards and cuts trade barriers, but faces approval challenges in Congress and other countries. A compromise was reached on biotech drug monopolies, granting them a period of protection short of the US's sought 12 years. The deal also addresses dairy farmer protections and sets minimum standards on workers' rights and environmental protection.

site_title: Global business growth at weakest pace this year in Sept: PMI
summary: Global business growth slowed to its weakest pace this year in September, according to a survey, with the JPMorgan Global All-Industry Output Index falling to 52.8 from 53.9 in August. Demand faltered, despite firms cutting prices for the first time since January. The global service sector PMI also declined, while manufacturing growth remained lackluster. The decline in output prices was the lowest in over three years. This slowdown in global economic growth suggests a waning trend at the end of the third quarter.

site_title: Banks should promote sustainable development: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has emphasized the role of financial institutions in promoting sustainable development. MAS has been discussing guidelines with the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) and collaborating with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to enhance disclosure on environmental and social aspects of businesses. The MAS supports SGX's plans to mandate sustainability reporting, with implementation targeted for 2017. Additionally, MAS plans to develop guidance for investors on sustainability and social-environmental considerations.

site_title: Glencore surges 72 per cent in Hong Kong amid unit sale talks
summary: Glencore shares surged 72% in Hong Kong amid talks of a potential sale of its agriculture business, with interest from Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, Japanese trading house Mitsui & Co, and a Canadian pension fund. The company is also planning to sell assets and pare debt, including a $2.5 billion stock sale. The agriculture unit, which generated $25.8 billion in revenue last year, could be valued at $10.5 billion. The surge in Glencore's trading volume was the highest among Hong Kong-listed stocks.

site_title: Indonesia: Stock index rises more than 3%
summary: Indonesia's main stock index rose 3.23% on Monday, outperforming regional markets, following disappointing US jobs data that reduced expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike this year. The Jakarta composite index ended at 4,343.7, while the rupiah strengthened 1% to 14,490 per dollar, reaching a 17-year high.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close sharply higher on Fed hike delay hopes
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed sharply higher on October 5, 2015, as investors reacted to the US Federal Reserve's delay in a quick interest rate hike. The FTSE 100 index rose 2.57%, while the CAC 40 index in the eurozone increased 3.54%. The DAX 30 index also gained 2.74%. The delayed interest rate hike boosted investor sentiment, driving stocks higher.

site_title: OECD reveals plan for tax clampdown on multinationals
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has unveiled a 15-point plan to combat tax avoidance by multinational corporations, aiming to close loopholes that cost countries over $100 billion annually. The plan, dubbed "Base Erosion and Profit Shifting" (BEPS), seeks to oblige companies to pay tax in the country where their main business activity is based, preventing them from exploiting differences in national tax rules and bilateral treaties. The plan is set to be submitted for approval by the Group of 20 top world economies and will then go to a G20 leaders' summit for endorsement, with the goal of preventing firms from "gaming" national tax systems.

site_title: Indonesia expands search for missing plane
summary: Indonesia's search for a missing plane carrying 10 people expanded on Monday, with rescue teams scouring the sea and land in a central island. The Aviastar plane vanished three days ago while en route to Makassar, and one team reported spotting the main body of the aircraft in a remote location. Confirmation of the sighting is pending, with the search agency chief set to visit the site by plane on Tuesday to verify the information. The search area has been expanded to include a gulf, with boats and planes scouring the waters.

site_title: Nobel medicine prize awarded for work on parasitic diseases
summary: The 2015 Nobel Prize in Medicine was awarded to William Campbell, Satoshi Omura, and Youyou Tu for their work on parasitic diseases. Campbell and Omura received half the prize for discovering avermectin, a drug effective against river blindness and lymphatic filariasis, while Tu received the other half for discovering artemisinin, a malaria treatment that significantly reduced mortality rates. The discoveries have provided powerful means to combat debilitating diseases affecting hundreds of millions of people annually, resulting in improved human health and reduced suffering.

site_title: 20% of paper products at NTUC FairPrice sourced from Asia Pulp & Paper
summary: NTUC FairPrice has confirmed that 20% of its paper products are sourced from Asia Pulp & Paper (APP) Group, through a licensed distributor in Singapore. The move comes amid concerns over haze pollution in Indonesia, with APP and five other companies named as possible contributors. NTUC FairPrice has expressed concern over APP's practices and will take "prompt and firm actions" if found responsible for unethical practices contributing to the haze. The supermarket chain has also approached APP to seek clarification on their practices.

site_title: HKEx says no change to listing rules that drove Alibaba IPO away
summary: The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEx) announced it will not change its listing rules that led to Alibaba's $25 billion IPO in New York instead of Hong Kong. The HKEx's listing committee had proposed weighted voting rights, but the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) opposed the plan citing concerns over investor protection. The SFC's board unanimously concluded that the proposal was not workable, leading the HKEx to abandon the plan.

site_title: US holiday shopping season forecast: consumers fight for deals
summary: US retailers anticipate a challenging holiday season, with forecasted slowest year-on-year growth since 2009. Consumers are increasingly seeking deals, with 87% of shoppers citing price as the primary factor in purchasing decisions. Retailers are responding by focusing on service, differentiated products, and minimizing promotions. Despite a recovering economy, stagnant wage growth and rising costs are crimping overall spending. Retailers are launching early holiday promotions, but it's unclear whether this will translate to increased sales.

site_title: A-Reit to issue S$300m perpetual bonds at 4.75%
summary: ASCENDAS Reit plans to issue S$300 million worth of subordinated perpetual securities with a 4.75% distribution rate. The net proceeds will be used to partially fund the acquisition of Australian logistics properties. The securities have been assigned an "A3" issuer rating and are expected to be rated Baa2 by Moody's Investors Service.

site_title: Alibaba's Ma canvas gets US$5.4m at Hong Kong auction
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma's oil on canvas painting, "Paradise," sold for HK$42.2 million (S$7.7 million) at a Sotheby's auction in Hong Kong, more than 17 times the high estimate. The painting, created in 2014, will go to charity to promote environmental awareness. Ma, China's second-richest man, had no plans to pursue a career in art, saying it was an honor to have his work sold for charity.

site_title: Dian Xiao Er owner wins appeal in lease lawsuit with Soup Restaurant
summary: YES F&B Group, the owner of Dian Xiao Er, has successfully appealed against a court decision in a lease lawsuit with Soup Restaurant. The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal with costs, reversing Soup Restaurant's 2015 win over 69 square meters of shop space at VivoCity mall.

site_title: Nordex buys Acciona's wind power business
summary: German wind turbine maker Nordex is acquiring Acciona's wind power business for 785 million euros in cash and shares, creating a global player in the wind energy market. The deal, expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2016, will reduce exposure to demand swings in individual markets. Nordex will pay 366.4 million euros in cash and issue 16.1 million new shares, while Acciona will increase its stake in Nordex to 29.9% and retain a 5.7% stake. The combined company will have an estimated 2.8 gigawatt order backlog in 2015.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Singapore saw a mixed bag of economic news, with the Nikkei Singapore PMI showing further improvement in business conditions, while office rents softened in the CBD by 4.1% in Q3. The Singapore Exchange launched a new index business, SGX Index Edge, to cater to the growing demand for index-linked investments in Asia. However, consumers' outstanding unsecured debt continued to rise in the first half of 2015. Stocks closed higher, with the Straits Times Index jumping 2.1% on Monday, driven by Wall Street's unexpected bounce.

images.alt_text: There has been further improvement in overall operating conditions faced by Singapore's private-sector companies, according to the Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI).

site_title: Share buybacks spike up in Q3
summary: Share buybacks in Q3 surged to S$1.07 billion, with a total of 713.8 million shares bought back, exceeding Q2 and Q1 totals. Global Logistic Properties spent the most, buying back 101.6 million shares for S$224 million, followed by Wilmar International and DBS Group. The spike in share buybacks may be linked to market volatility, including China's yuan devaluation in August. The year-to-date total now stands at S$1.73 billion.

site_title: ICE Singapore approved for European clearing while US blocked
summary: ICE Singapore's clearing house has been recognized by the European Securities and Markets Authority, allowing it to provide clearing services to European companies, starting November 17. In contrast, ICE's US and European units have yet to gain approval due to disagreements between regulators. This decision highlights the complexities of the industry and the regulatory challenges faced by companies, which could impact European Union banks and the competitiveness of clearinghouses.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 18.79 points to 1,647.59. The trading volume reached 1.91 billion lots, valued at RM1.86 billion, with 601 gainers and 236 losers.

site_title: Tiny Nauru throws gates open at Australian camp for asylum seekers
summary: Nauru unexpectedly opened its camp for 600 asylum seekers held by Australia, allowing them to move freely and process their applications this week. The move, which was a surprise to Australia, aims to reduce harsh conditions and criticism from the UN and human rights groups. Australia will provide police assistance to support Nauru's safety and security. The asylum seekers, who are not eligible to be settled in Australia, will receive settlement services funded by the Australian government.

site_title: Update: Glencore shares enjoy bounce-back after Hong Kong-led surge
summary: Glencore shares surged 20% in London and 25% in Hong Kong on Monday, driven by hopes for deal-making and outweighing concerns over a slump in metals prices. The company is in talks with a Saudi Arabian sovereign wealth fund and Chinese state-backed grain trader to sell a stake in its agricultural assets. Glencore's shares have recouped losses from the past week, with brokers citing the company's ability to withstand commodity price crunches. The company attributed the price movements to unknown reasons.

site_title: 10 companies declare their paper products from sustainable sources
summary: Ten companies in Singapore, including Canon and Fuji Xerox, have declared that their paper products come from sustainable sources, following the haze pollution in the region. Another seven third-party producers are expected to make similar declarations. The Singapore Environment Council and Consumers Association of Singapore are urging consumers to support only socially responsible firms to send a strong signal against environmentally irresponsible practices. The government has also sent notices to Indonesian companies suspected of contributing to the haze pollution, requiring them to inform the SEC of their activities if they source products from these companies.

images.alt_text: Ten firms with paper products sold in Singapore have declared that they only obtain wood, paper or pulp materials from socially responsible companies, with more likely to make similar declarations, as the haze continues to linger.

site_title: Nestle in talks to merge international ice cream ops with R&R: source
summary: Nestle is in talks to merge its international ice cream operations with R&R Ice Cream in a 3 billion euro (S$4.8 billion) deal. The proposed 50/50 joint venture would include R&R's global ice cream operations outside of Israel and the US, excluding Nestle's US brands. The deal could be announced as early as this week and is expected to result in PAI exiting the business in a few years. The venture would provide Nestle with a more focused portfolio, focusing on its higher-performing brands.

site_title: Swiss travellers help keep hotels booked despite strong franc
summary: Switzerland's hotels saw a 0.5% increase in overnight stays over the first eight months of the year, driven by domestic demand that rose 1.0%. Foreign visitors declined 1.6% to 14 million stays, with significant drops in German, Dutch, and Italian visitors. However, Asian visitors increased by 13%, led by Chinese, Gulf, Indian, South Korean, and US visitors, which offset the decline in foreign bookings. The strong Swiss franc, which soared against the euro this year, also contributed to the increase in domestic bookings.

site_title: Coca-Cola Singapore Beverages to shut Tuas plant; commits US$100m investment
summary: Coca-Cola Singapore Beverages (CCSB) will shut down its Tuas plant in February 2026, affecting 200 employees, and move operations to Malaysia. Despite the closure, CCSB has committed to a US$100 million investment in Singapore over the next five years. The company will retain 450 employees and continue to operate its sales force, sales and marketing, and other functions. The government and union have expressed confidence in the move, citing Singapore's strategic business location and expected creation of 2,400 jobs and S$2.1 billion in value added.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up 1.6%
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.62% up on Monday, driven by casino operators, despite Chinese markets being closed for a public holiday. The Hang Seng Index gained 348.41 points to end at 21,854.5. Weak US jobs data also contributed to the gain.

site_title: More losses for Taiwanese smartphone maker HTC
summary: Taiwanese smartphone maker HTC reported its second consecutive quarterly loss, with a net loss of TW$4.48 billion in the third quarter. The company's revenue was nearly halved from the same period last year, and it has cut over 2,000 jobs as part of its restructuring efforts. HTC's struggles in the competitive smartphone market are attributed to the rise of Samsung, Apple, and Chinese brands like Huawei. Analysts predict the company's turnaround will be challenging, with one expert stating HTC's biggest challenge is driving up sales in a market it can no longer dominate.

site_title: German private sector growth points to moderate Q3 expansion: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector experienced moderate growth in September, according to a survey by Markit, with the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 54.1. This is the 29th consecutive month of expansion, but slower than a month prior. The services sector also saw a slight decrease, but remained above the 50 mark and new orders rose at their strongest rate in a year. The growth is attributed to an influx of refugees and asylum seekers, leading to increased demand and hiring of new staff.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes 1.58% higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed 1.58% higher on Monday, driven by speculation that the US Federal Reserve will keep interest rates near zero, potentially forcing Japanese policymakers to increase stimulus. The Nikkei index rose to 18,005.49, while the Topix index gained 1.31%. The gains come as investors await updates on US-EU trade talks and economic downturn concerns.

site_title: Europe: Shares climb as Glencore, Arcelor lift mining stocks
summary: European shares rose 2.2% on Monday, driven by gains in mining stocks led by Glencore and ArcelorMittal. French economic data also lifted the Paris stock market, with the CAC gaining 2.7%. Lisbon's PSI-20 index rose 1.9% after Portugal's centre-right government won an election. However, German potash producer K+S slumped 20% after Potash Corp withdrew its bid. European markets remain below 2015 peaks, with overall sentiment remaining "neutral".

site_title: UK government plans US$3b Lloyds retail share sale in spring 2016
summary: The UK government plans to sell at least 2 billion pounds (S$4.35 billion) in Lloyds Banking Group shares to retail investors in spring 2016 as part of its plan to return the bank to full private ownership. The shares will be offered at a 5% discount to the market price with a bonus share incentive for investors holding their investment for over a year. The government has already recouped almost three-quarters of the taxpayer cash used in the rescue of the bank through sales to institutional investors, now owning nearly 12% of the lender.

site_title: Short sellers take on top Hong Kong property stock of 2015
summary: Short sellers have targeted Evergrande Real Estate Group, the top-performing Hong Kong property stock of 2015, due to concerns over its debt levels and sustainability. The company has bought back shares and increased its debt, leading analysts to bet that its shares won't maintain their growth. Evergrande's shares have fallen 14% in September, despite a 51% year-to-date gain, and its debt-to-equity leverage has reached a record high. Short sellers are betting on the company's shares to decline, with short interest surging to 29% of its free float.

site_title: Seoul: Shares pare early gains; won up as soft US jobs put rate hike on hold
summary: Seoul shares rose 0.4% to 1,978.25 points, bolstered by refinery and chemical shares, despite foreigners selling 10.8 billion won worth of shares. The won strengthened 0.7% to 1,172.4 per dollar after a weak US jobs report delayed expectations of a US interest rate hike. Refinery SK Innovation Co Ltd and S-Oil Corp gained 5.9% and 5.8% respectively.

site_title: Rolls-Royce cuts 400 marine jobs as oil hits offshore-ship sales
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings cuts 400 marine jobs as oil prices decline, impacting demand for offshore vessels. The job cuts will save 40 million pounds annually, with benefits from 2016 onwards. The move follows the elimination of 600 factory posts in May and is part of a restructuring effort to simplify and optimize the marine unit. The company remains unchanged on its profit and revenue guidance for the marine unit, with a workforce of 5,800.

site_title: Big Hong Kong IPOs pitched to investors as market confidence improves
summary: China Huarong Asset Management Co Ltd and China Reinsurance (Group) are pitching Hong Kong IPOs worth up to $5 billion to investors, signaling improving market confidence. The IPOs, worth $3 billion and $2 billion, respectively, are the largest by state-owned companies in Hong Kong. Huarong plans to use 60% of the proceeds to develop its distressed asset business and China RE will use 60% for share buybacks. The IPOs come as Hong Kong's benchmark stock index starts October on a positive tone, despite uncertainties about China's economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher in response to Wall Street's Friday bounce
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 58.1 points or 2.1% to 2,851.25 on Monday, driven by a Wall Street bounce on Friday. The market's low turnover was attributed to limited client business, with most brokers attributing the index's rise to programme trading by computers. The banks led the rally, while Singtel, Wilmar International, and Hongkong Land also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Eurozone business activity slows in September: data
summary: Eurozone business activity slowed more than initially thought in September, according to a revised business survey. The September Purchasing Managers Index fell to 53.6 points, down from the initial reading of 53.9 points. This marks a slowdown from the 54.3 points in August, which was the best performance in four years. The data adds to concerns over the Eurozone's economic outlook.

site_title: Most EU countries to ban cultivation of 8 GMOs using new rules
summary: More than half of the EU's 28 countries plan to prohibit the cultivation of eight genetically modified crops awaiting regulatory approval. Nineteen countries, including Austria, France, and the UK, invoked a new EU law to shield their territories from the crops. The law, passed in 2015, allows individual governments to opt out of GMO cultivation, giving them greater control over biotech food production. The countries' decision marks the first use of this right, which is seen as a response to concerns over the safety of biotech foods.

site_title: Australia a test case for Uber's bold global push
summary: Uber's global push is being tested in Australia, where the service is popular but largely illegal. Despite registering over 1 million users, Uber faces challenges from the taxi industry and local authorities. The company has made progress in some areas, such as Canberra introducing ride-sharing laws, but is facing lawsuits and crackdowns in other states. Uber is confident in its position and is appealing to the Australian public with its low prices, but the company is also working to address criticism and improve its policies.

site_title: 10 firms declare their paper products are from socially responsible firms
summary: Ten Singaporean companies selling paper products have declared they do not source wood, paper, and pulp from companies suspected of contributing to the 2015 haze pollution in Indonesia. The declaration is part of a joint statement by the Singapore Environment Council and the Consumers Association of Singapore. Companies such as Canon and Fuji Xerox have made the commitment, and the list will be updated regularly. Consumers are urged to support socially responsible firms involved in the sourcing of these materials.

site_title: Fed odds drop to 8% for October; El-Erian says December is 50-50
summary: The Federal Reserve's odds of raising interest rates in October have dropped to 8%, according to traders, following weaker-than-expected employment growth. Mohamed El-Erian believes the odds of a rate hike in December are 50%, contradicting the previous consensus. The US 10-year yields are below 2% due to the lack of consensus on when the Fed will shift policy. The employment report showed a slowdown in services growth and a surprise increase in jobs, which may keep the Fed from raising rates in October.

site_title: Gold retains sharp gains after sluggish US jobs data
summary: Gold retained gains after the US jobs data showed a slowdown in hiring, easing fears of a rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Spot gold remained at $1,136.60 an ounce, its biggest daily jump in nearly nine months. The metal rallied as the dollar fell, despite being down 4% this year. Analysts say the Fed is unlikely to raise rates soon, citing a weak global economy and volatility in financial markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise 2% to top 2-week highs
summary: Australian shares rose 2% on Monday, reaching their highest close since September 18, driven by strong job advertising figures boosting investor confidence in the economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index surged 98.48 points to 5,510.5, following a 2-year trough in September. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also rose 0.7%. The gains come as market strategists revise their year-end expectations, with the index seen ending 2015 roughly 1% above Monday's close.

site_title: JPMorgan says 'waves of protectionism' will cap China steel
summary: JPMorgan predicts China's steel exports will peak in 2015 due to a surge in protectionism worldwide. Net exports are expected to plateau at 90 million metric tons, with gross shipments reaching 105 million tons. This comes as China's steel demand shrinks 4% in 2015 and 2% in 2016, driven by domestic demand and economic growth slowdown. The protectionism wave has led to trade tensions globally, affecting countries like the US, India, and Africa.

site_title: Update: Oil extends gains in Asia
summary: Oil prices surged in Asia on Monday, driven by a decline in US drilling, which pointed to a slowdown in production. The US Labor Department reported a disappointing 142,000 jobs growth in September, sparking concerns about demand for oil. The news tempered optimism, however, as analysts expect the US central bank to delay its first interest rate hike due to the soft numbers. Oil prices rose 29 cents to $45.83 for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 23 cents to $48.36 for Brent crude.

site_title: Nissan's selfie-friendly car sends knobs, buttons out the window
summary: Nissan unveiled the Teatro for Dayz concept car at the Tokyo Motor Show, designed to appeal to a generation apathetic about autos. The car features a clear-white surface for displaying photos, movies, and games, as well as an on-board camera for taking and sharing selfies. The concept, powered by a battery, also includes voice controls and motion sensors. Nissan aims to build momentum in appealing to younger consumers with cars that will soon reach showrooms, following the introduction of the Lannia sedan in China.

site_title: Taiwan's September exports seen falling 11.6% year on year, CPI to weaken further: poll
summary: Taiwan's exports are expected to fall 11.6% year-over-year in September, marking the eighth consecutive month of contraction, and raising concerns about the island's export-driven economy. This decline is attributed to weak global demand for technology gadgets. Meanwhile, the consumer price index is forecast to weaken further, falling 0.48% in September. The central bank's recent interest rate cut aims to stimulate growth, but the economy's performance remains a concern.

site_title: Dollar steady against emerging market currencies
summary: The US dollar faced selling pressure against major currencies but strengthened against most of its Asia-Pacific peers due to concerns over emerging economies. Despite an expected delay in the Federal Reserve's rate hike, investors withdrew cash from emerging economies, causing the Singapore dollar, South Korean won, and Taiwan dollar to fall. However, the Thai baht rose 0.14% against the US dollar. Analysts expect the dollar to remain stable, citing a lack of encouraging factors to support regional currencies.

site_title: Singapore's new Acting Education Ministers stress a more diverse education system
summary: Singapore's new Acting Education Ministers, Ng Chee Meng and Ong Ye Kung, emphasized the government's commitment to building a more diverse education system to help students fulfill their potential. They vowed to nurture students holistically and drive the SkillsFuture initiative to support learners of all ages. The goal is to create a system where every school is good, every student is an engaged learner, and every teacher is a caring educator. The ministers aim to provide more opportunities for Singaporeans to develop and deepen their skills, leading to a more diverse and capable workforce.

site_title: Singapore's office rents soften in Q3 on economic outlook: DTZ
summary: Singapore's office rents declined 4.1% quarter-over-quarter in Q3, marking the first decline since 2013, according to DTZ Southeast Asia. This follows a subdued global economic environment and China's economic slowdown. Leasing incentives have increased as landlords compete for tenants, resulting in lower net effective rents. Office occupancy in the CBD declined 0.9 percentage-points to 95% in Q3, with Raffles Place's occupancy edging up due to newer developments. A large supply of office space is expected to put downward pressure on rents in 2016, with 2.6 million sq ft coming on board next year.

site_title: American Apparel files for bankruptcy
summary: American Apparel Inc filed for bankruptcy protection on October 5, 2015, listing assets and liabilities between $100 million and $500 million. The company reached a restructuring support agreement with 95% of its secured lenders, allowing it to become a stronger, more vibrant company.

site_title: South Korea central bank chief says 2015 growth will be near 2.8 per cent
summary: South Korea's central bank chief, Lee Ju-yeol, stated that the country's economic growth this year will likely reach 2.8%, near the previous forecast of 2.8%. The Bank of Korea is expected to revise its forecasts later this month. Finance Minister Choi Kyung-hwan acknowledged downside risks to the government's current GDP forecast of 3.1%.

site_title: China: Financial markets closed
summary: China's financial markets are closed on Monday for a public holiday, reopening on Thursday. Meanwhile, global stocks fell, with European markets dragged down by bank and healthcare stocks, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. In Asia, traders dismissed new Trump threats, and Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally tracking Wall Street gains
summary: Australian shares rallied 1.7% on Monday, driven by gains in US stocks and positive job advertising figures, boosting investor confidence in the economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index jumped 86.08 points to 5,138.1. The market is now moving towards positive territory for the first time since July, with key sectors including banks, resources, and energy-related shares experiencing significant gains. A monthly survey showed total job advertisements rose 3.9% in September, supporting the market's recovery.

site_title: US dollar steady against emerging market currencies; SGD falls 0.03% against USD
summary: The US dollar remained steady against emerging market currencies, including the Singapore dollar, which fell 0.03% against the US unit. Despite concerns over emerging economies, the dollar strengthened against most Asia-Pacific peers due to weak job growth and stagnant wages in the US. The Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates this month or in December, reducing pressure on emerging economies. The dollar edged up to 119.97 yen, while the euro rose to US$1.1235.

site_title: Hong Kong: Chinese stocks rise on stimulus, US rate outlook
summary: Chinese stocks in Hong Kong rose 2.6% to a two-week high on targeted government support and traders pushing back US interest rate estimates. Gaming companies surged after reports of potential economic stimulus, while automakers extended gains on a tax cut for passenger-vehicle purchases. The US jobs report showed weaker-than-expected employment gains, reducing the likelihood of a Fed interest rate hike in October or December. Chinese policy makers are increasing stimulus efforts to support the economy, which is expected to slow to 6.8% this year.

site_title: Embattled Uber faces global crackdown
summary: Uber faces a global crackdown by governments and protests from taxi drivers, despite the company's claims of driving forward into the future. The ride-sharing service is involved in several controversies, including rape allegations in New Delhi, office raids in Amsterdam, and executive trials in Paris. Despite this, Uber maintains a strong growth trajectory, present in 340 cities and taking 3 million trips daily. The company considers itself a player in the "sharing economy" and is leading a challenge to traditional taxi regulations.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as weak US jobs dampen prospects of near-term Fed hike
summary: Asian stocks rose early Monday following the release of weaker-than-expected US employment data, which fueled doubts about a near-term interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The data showed a 142,000 job gain in September, lower than expected, and a stall in hourly wage growth. This led to a delay in a potential rate hike, keeping risk assets globally buoyant. Asian markets, including the Nikkei and MSCI's Asia-Pacific index, rose 0.7-1.9% as safe-haven government bonds fell and the dollar weakened.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won rise to 2-week highs as weak US job data chills Fed rate view
summary: South Korean shares rose to a two-week high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) up 1.2% at 1,993.50 points. A weak US jobs report led investors to delay expectations of a US interest rate hike, supporting a risk-averse market. Refinery and chemical shares outperformed the market, driven by a surge in oil prices, while semiconductor chipmaker SK Hynix Inc saw its shares rise to a two-week high. The South Korean won also rose to 0.7% against the dollar, its highest level since September 18.

site_title: Air France to announce job cuts under new restructuring plan
summary: Air France-KLM is set to unveil a new restructuring plan on Monday, expected to lead to 3,000 job losses. Four unions have called a strike to coincide with the plan's launch, citing concerns over the impact on employees. The airline has assured that all flights will operate, albeit with some delays. The central company enterprise committee is scheduled to review the plan at 9:30am GMT on Monday.

site_title: Ascendas Reit opens books for Sing dollar perpetual
summary: Ascendas Reit has started bookbuilding for its Singapore dollar perpetual non-call 5, aiming to raise S$300-500 million. The trust, which will partially fund its Australia logistics property acquisition, has set a formal guidance of 5% and expects a Baa2 rating from Moody's. The deal will be led by Citigroup and ANZ, with proceeds used to fund the Australian acquisition and providing a 25-cent rebate to private banks. Pricing is expected as early as today.

site_title: Hong Kong former leader Donald Tsang charged over corruption
summary: Hong Kong's former leader Donald Tsang has been charged with misconduct, marking a high-profile corruption case. Tsang admitted to accepting luxury gifts during his term in office, but denied any conflict of interest. He has been under investigation since 2012.

site_title: UK firms see least certain outlook in two and a half years: Deloitte
summary: UK firms are more uncertain about their economic outlook than in two and a half years, according to a Deloitte survey. 73% of CFOs believe uncertainty is high, up from 55% in June, citing emerging market slowdown and potential interest rate rises. Higher interest rates are ranked as the biggest threat, followed by weakness in emerging markets and the euro zone economy. Despite this, Deloitte's chief economist sees positive prospects for the British economy, citing low inflation, rising pay, and cheap credit.

site_title: Nikkei Singapore PMI shows further improvement in business conditions
summary: Singapore's private-sector companies saw further improvement in business conditions, with the Nikkei Singapore PMI rising to 51.4 in September, up from 50.8 in August. Output increased solidly, with staffing numbers rising, while input costs rose at the fastest rate since February. Companies passed on these costs to clients in the form of higher selling prices. In contrast, the SIPMM PMI, which covers only the manufacturing sector, showed a reading of 48.6, contracting for the third month in a row.

site_title: Malaysian PM Najib urges Indonesia to act on smoke-belching fires
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak urged Indonesia to take action against companies responsible for raging forest and agricultural fires, which have caused widespread smog in the region. The fires, which flare annually during the dry season, have affected Malaysia, Indonesia, and Singapore, prompting health alerts, school closures, and economic losses. Najib blamed plantation companies for the problem, saying Indonesia must gather evidence and convict the companies. The issue has been ongoing for nearly 20 years, with no long-term solution in sight. Najib called for cooperation among the three countries to tackle the environmental disaster.

site_title: Lingering haze casts pall on businesses
summary: The prolonged haze in Singapore continues to disrupt businesses and events, with visitorship to outdoor attractions declining and events being cancelled. The 24-hour PSI remained in the unhealthy range, prompting organisers to cancel the Fina Swimming World Cup finals and expecting cancellations or diversion of traffic from overseas. Business costs are forecast to mount, with estimates suggesting a 5-10% drop in visitorship and a potential revenue loss of S$400 to S$500 per day from tourists avoiding the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.79 points to 1629.59. A total of 27.3 million lots were traded, worth RM9.5 million, with 125 gainers and 45 losers.

site_title: World Bank trims 2015, 2016 East Asia forecasts, cites China, US rate risks
summary: The World Bank has cut its 2015 and 2016 growth forecasts for developing East Asia and Pacific to 6.5% and 6.4% respectively, citing risks from a slowdown in China's economy and potential US interest rate increases. China's growth is expected to slow to 6.9% in 2015 and 6.7% in 2016, down from 7.3% in 2014. The outlook for other countries, including Indonesia and Malaysia, is also clouded by weakness in global commodity markets.

site_title: Japan's August wage growth slows, boding ill for consumption
summary: Japan's wage growth slowed in August, with real wages rising just 0.2% year-on-year, down from a 0.5% gain in July. Nominal wages also failed to keep pace with inflation, undermining household purchasing power. Total cash earnings rose 0.5% year-on-year, while summer bonuses stood 3.4% lower than last year. Tepid wage growth poses pressure on policymakers struggling to boost the economy, which faces recession fears.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 1.11% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.11% higher on Monday, driven by speculation that an economic downturn will prompt the Bank of Japan to increase stimulus. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 195.87 points to 17,921.00. This move comes ahead of policymakers meeting later this week.

site_title: Record 80% Singapore employers provided structured training in 2014: MOM
summary: In 2014, a record 80% of Singapore employers provided structured training to at least one employee, up from 70% in 2012, according to the Ministry of Manpower. Training expenditure averaged S$726 per trainee, with 96% of construction employers, 90% of financial services employers, and 84% of manufacturing employers participating. The majority of employers reported positive impacts of training on work efficiency, employee skills, and job responsibilities. Similar to 2012, increased training subsidies and better workload management were the top motivations for employers to send staff for training.

site_title: Consumers' outstanding unsecured debt continues to rise in H1 2015
summary: Consumers in Singapore have seen a 10% rise in missed unsecured debt payments in June 2015, with 85,352 individuals defaulting on two or more months of payments. The total overdue balance rose 7% to S$288.45 million. Meanwhile, average unsecured debt exposure has increased 16% to S$7,971 since 2011. Despite this, Credit Bureau Singapore notes that average debt exposure for credit cards and overdrafts is stabilizing, suggesting measures to help borrowers pay down debt may be having an effect.

site_title: Oil holds gains near US$45 as falling rigs signal US output cuts
summary: Oil prices held gains near $45 a barrel after data showed a 26-rig decline in the US, signaling output cuts. The US rig count has fallen to a five-year low, and Saudi Arabia cut pricing for November supplies to Asia and the US. Despite US crude stockpiles exceeding the five-year average, prices have held steady, with WTI for November delivery rising 22 cents to $45.76 a barrel. Analysts say the decline in US production and Saudi's pricing cut signal a potential rebound.

site_title: Ensuring a smooth journey
summary: Airlines face increasing competition and pressure to satisfy customers, with a study finding that interactions prior to flight can significantly impact perceived quality. Airlines are investing in enhancing touch points, such as online booking systems and self-service options, to improve customer experience. Singapore Airlines' new Customer Experience Management system and rigorous training programs for staff aim to drive loyalty and satisfaction. The study's findings also highlight the importance of ground staff and agents in determining perceived quality, with some airlines, such as AirAsia, seeing improvements in customer satisfaction.

site_title: SGX launches index services in Asia, seeks to build regional index business
summary: SGX launches SGX Index Edge, a comprehensive index business offering Asia-focused index solutions for product issuers. The new service aims to capitalize on rising demand for index-linked investments in Asia, providing transparency and attracting greater participation in SGX's markets. The company plans to offer thematic and strategy-based equity indices for the Singapore market, while also growing partnerships with global index providers. This move positions SGX as a pan-Asian index provider, with CEO Loh Boon Chye stating the company is well-positioned to become the choice for index-linked investment solutions.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a new index business, SGX Index Edge, that will offer comprehensive services aimed at addressing the rising demand for index-linked investment in Asia.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher on Monday, rising 36.23 points or 1.3% to 2,829.38. Around 67.7 million shares worth S$75.1 million traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 113 to 35. Top shares by value traded included Keppel Corp, DBS, UOB, CapitaLand, and SingTel.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ramba Energy, Sinocloud Group, Global Yellow Pages
summary: Ramba Energy has agreed to invest up to $179.6 million in Indonesia's Lemang Production Sharing Contract through a subsidiary. Mandal Energy, backed by KKR, will acquire a 35% stake in the contract. Sinocloud Group has cancelled a proposed acquisition of China Satellite Mobile Communications Group due to unsatisfied conditions. Global Yellow Pages has signed a deal to buy a company handling Wendy's retail master franchise in Australia and New Zealand for an undisclosed price.

site_title: TPP trade talks head into Monday
summary: US trade talks on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) have been extended to Monday as negotiations on dairy trade and biologic patent protections remain unresolved. Despite Japan's Economy Minister Akira Amari stating that a deal "in principle" was expected to be announced Sunday, plans for a press conference were cancelled. The 12-nation talks aim to create the world's largest free-trade zone, with the US administration pushing for 21st-century trade rules. The talks have been ongoing since Wednesday, with the US and Australia sharply divided on biologic patent protections.

images.alt_text: Earlier in the day, Japan's Economy Minister Akira Amari said he was expecting a deal "in principle" to be announced Sunday afternoon.

site_title: Mandala Energy to invest in 35% stake in Ramba's Lemang PSC
summary: Mandala Energy will invest up to US$179.6 million in a 35% stake in Ramba Energy's Lemang Production Sharing Contract in Indonesia's South Sumatra basin. The investment includes an upfront payment of US$26.25 million and contingent payments based on oil and gas reserves. This deal allows Ramba to realise value from its investment and leverage Mandala's technical and financial capabilities. The agreement is subject to Indonesian government approval, and it marks Mandala's first transaction in Indonesia, with the company backing from international investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co.

site_title: Australia job advertisements rise in September: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements rose 3.9% in September to 153,778 per week, the second consecutive month of gains. This increase, coupled with a 12.8% rise from last year, suggests employment growth is picking up momentum. Internet ads grew 4.0% while newspaper ads dipped 2.7%. ANZ's chief economist Warren Hogan attributes the trend to strengthening demand for labor in services industries, driven by the Australian dollar's depreciation and low interest rates. However, Hogan warns that this support will wane in 2016, leading to potential interest rate cuts.

site_title: America's beaten-down factory worker is getting squeezed again
summary: The US manufacturing sector has seen a decline in jobs, with factory employment falling 27,000 in August and September, the worst back-to-back months since 2009. This marks a reversal of the five-year surge in manufacturing jobs that began after the financial crisis. The decline is attributed to a company, Titan International Inc., which makes tires for tractors and other equipment, a sector that has seen reduced demand due to the decline of the US shale industry.

site_title: TPP deal eludes Pacific trade ministers as talks break up over biologics patents, dairy trade
summary: Trade ministers from 12 Pacific Rim countries failed to conclude a deal on a free-trade area after a meeting in Atlanta broke up over biologics patents and dairy trade. The talks, which began on Wednesday, were the second attempt this year to reach an agreement, with the US and Canada seeking longer patent protections and the US, Canada, and New Zealand disagreeing on dairy trade barriers. The ministers are set to meet one last time on Sunday, but a breakthrough seems unlikely, with Australian Trade Minister Andrew Robb warning that failure to strike a compromise could jeopardize the deal.

site_title: Portugal's ruling coalition defeats socialists in election
summary: Portugal's ruling coalition, led by Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho, has won the country's first general election since regaining economic sovereignty. The coalition secured 94 of the 230 parliamentary seats, while the Socialist opposition has 79 seats. The victory solidifies the coalition's position, with Coelho declaring it the winning political force.

site_title: Greece to unveil painful 2016 draft budget
summary: Greece is set to unveil a 2016 draft budget that aims to satisfy international creditors, projecting a recession next year before returning to growth in 2017. The budget, part of an 86 billion euro bailout, forecasts a 2.3% economic contraction this year and 0.5% in 2016. Public debt is expected to rise to 196% of GDP this year and peak at 201% in 2016. Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has agreed to implement spending cuts and economic reforms in exchange for the bailout, aiming to conclude the first review and recapitalize its banks by mid-November.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up; regulator says better Q4 on capital inflow
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.4% on Monday, marking the first increase in four months, as foreign capitals returned to domestic equities. The Financial Supervisory Commission expects a better fourth quarter due to increased capital inflows. Key performers included TSMC, which gained 0.8%, and Inotera Memories, which rose 4.7%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.825 per US dollar. Analysts predict a recovery in the tech industry in the first quarter of next year after clearing inventory by the end of the year.

site_title: France to consider phasing out diesel tax breaks: minister
summary: France is considering phasing out diesel tax breaks over the next five years to encourage cleaner car choices. Environment Minister Segolene Royal said the move aims to end the fuel's advantage over gasoline, tarnished by health warnings and the Volkswagen emissions scandal. Diesel's tax advantage is currently 0.15 euros per liter lower than gasoline. To offset the tax increase, tax breaks for buying cleaner-fuel vehicles will be introduced. This move aims to reduce diesel's share on French roads, which currently accounts for more than half of all cars.

site_title: Dollar weaker, Asian index futures rise as jobs dim rate outlook
summary: The US dollar weakened, while Asian index futures rose as investors became less optimistic about a Federal Reserve interest rate hike this year following disappointing US payrolls data. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index extended its decline into a third day, with traders pushing out bets on a first US rate hike since 2006 to March next year. Global stocks ended last week higher, with most Asian index futures signaling gains, while copper futures jumped and gold held onto its Friday surge. The prospect of a delay in US monetary tightening burnished gold's appeal, and the euro remained steady at US$1.120.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to cut 400 marine division jobs: FT
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings may announce 400 job cuts in its marine division, part of a plan to rebase costs and shift manufacturing from high-cost Scandinavian countries to Asia. The move aims to stabilize the marine business, which has been impacted by low oil prices. The job cuts are part of a long-term plan to boost profitability, with increased spending on technology expected after the business stabilizes.

site_title: Cameron refuses to rule out 'Brexit'
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron has refused to rule out campaigning for a British exit from the European Union if his renegotiation efforts fail, stating that if he doesn't get what he wants, he'll "rule nothing out." Cameron is pushing for changes to EU policies, including cutting benefits for EU migrants and allowing the UK to opt out of eurozone rules. He has promised a referendum on Britain's EU membership by the end of 2017, despite internal party divisions on the issue.

site_title: After five years of negotiations, Pacific trade talks near deal
summary: A dozen Pacific nations are close to a sweeping free trade pact after a breakthrough on pharmaceutical protections, which pitted the US against Australia. The US wants 12 years of exclusivity for new biotech drugs, while Australia insists on 5 years. A compromise sets a 5-year minimum and additional years for competing drugs, with some countries granting 8 years of exclusive rights. The deal aims to lower tariffs and set common standards for 12 economies, with the US pushing for market access and a counterweight to China.

site_title: Argentina rewards bond investors who braved crises with 135% return
summary: Argentina will pay off its $5.7 billion 10-year bonds, maturing next week, with a 135% return to investors who held the securities since the country's 2001 default. The bonds, which traded at 18 cents on the dollar in 2008, have seen yields surge past 50% in the 2008 financial crisis and again spiked in 2012 due to speculation about the government's debt policies. The payment marks a significant return for investors who braved the country's economic turmoil, surpassing the average 93% gain for emerging markets.

site_title: Australia inflation picks up in Sept, but still tame: TDMI
summary: Australia's private-sector inflation gauge rose 0.3% in September, exceeding the previous month's 0.1% increase. The annual pace ticked up to 1.9%, its highest since November 2014, but remains below the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2-3% target. Analysts expect the RBA to keep interest rates unchanged at its upcoming policy meeting, citing the benign inflation environment. The RBA has been happy with its current policy setting, with some analysts suggesting a terminal cash rate of 2%.

site_title: Rachel and Monica's new BFFs: New York teenagers
summary: The article discusses the enduring popularity of the TV show Friends among young people, particularly in New York. Released 21 years ago, Friends has become a cultural phenomenon, with over 19 million people liking it on Facebook. The show's absence of corrosive ambition and its focus on fun, relationships, and relaxation have resonated with teenagers, who appreciate the idealized lifestyle portrayed. The show's influence extends beyond its original run, with fans creating their own categories and memes, and its theme song even being performed at a high school concert.

site_title: Global regulators finalise new capital rule for big insurers
summary: Global regulators have finalized new capital rules for the world's nine largest insurance companies, requiring them to hold more capital to prevent taxpayer bailouts in a crisis. The rules follow the massive public rescue of insurer AIG during the 2007-2009 financial crisis. The insurers, including AIG and MetLife, will need to hold a combined capital cushion of at least 75% of their national requirements, with an additional 10% buffer, starting from 2019. The move aims to enhance global market stability and prevent future bailouts.

site_title: Technology rents catching up with banks as digital economy expands
summary: The gap between rent paid by technology companies and financial services businesses in cities like San Francisco and Hong Kong is narrowing. According to a report by Savills, technology companies now pay 56% of the equivalent rent per employee, up from 42% in 2008. This shift is driven by the growing demand for space suitable for technology workers and the increasing number of companies in the sector. Experts predict the gap will close over the next 10-20 years as technology rents continue to rise.

site_title: US a long way from 'macroprudential' safeguards
summary: US is far from implementing effective macroprudential safeguards, according to New York Fed president William Dudley, citing regulatory structure and crisis prediction difficulties. He warned against hastily implementing tools to protect the financial system and economy from broad risks. The US is a long way from successfully using macroprudential tools, which aim to regulate the broader financial sector beyond specific banks and firms.

site_title: Winter wonderland for MICE events
summary: Gangwon province in South Korea is emerging as a new MICE destination, thanks to its hosting of the 2018 Winter Olympics. The province has well-established corporate training facilities, including resorts, ski slopes, and entertainment venues, making it an ideal spot for corporate meetings and incentive tours. Gangwon's natural and cultural attractions, such as its national parks and UNESCO World Heritage Site, also draw visitors. With improvements to its winter sports facilities set to be completed after the Olympics, Gangwon is poised to attract more international business events and tourists.

site_title: The pastry wars of Milan
summary: A new cafe, Pasticceria Marchesi, opened in Milan's Via Monte Napoleone, owned by Prada and designed by Roberto Baciocchi. The cafe features 38 elevated tearoom displays and pricey pink Sacher tortes, attracting both local Milanese and tourists. The location coincides with fashion week, adding to the city's style circuit.

site_title: Dive in nickel prices plunges French islands into crisis
summary: Nickel prices have plunged 35% this year, reaching a six-and-a-half year low of less than US$10,000 a tonne, causing economic crisis in New Caledonia, a French territory in the Pacific that heavily relies on nickel mining. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in China's economic growth and stockpiles of over 450,000 tonnes. The crisis has affected major mining companies, including Glencore, which owns 49% of the Koniambo Nickel smelter, and has led to calls for a cut in government spending and diversification of the economy.

site_title: Engaging the public to rebuild trust
summary: Singapore's public transport operators experienced a 2-3% increase in customer satisfaction scores in the Q2 2015 period, according to the CSISG. This improvement was attributed to taxi services, public buses, and MRT trains. However, a major disruption in July 2015 may have negatively impacted commuter satisfaction. The Institute of Service Excellence suggests that rebuilding trust requires emphasizing competence, benevolence, and integrity in public transport operators' engagement with the public. Operators, such as SMRT, have committed to improving service excellence efforts.

site_title: S'pore firm develops IT solution for forwarders
summary: A Singaporean firm, Centrolene, has developed an IT solution called C-Suite to help freight forwarders transform themselves into global players. The industry, which plays a crucial role in Singapore's logistics and supply chain, faces increasing competition, new regulations, and customer demands. Freight forwarders are relying on IT to remain competitive, and Centrolene's C-Suite aims to address these challenges, enabling clients to expand their business globally.

site_title: Sake attracting younger, international fans
summary: Japanese sake breweries are expanding their product ranges to attract younger, international fans, particularly women and overseas consumers. Sake consumption, which peaked in 1975, has shown signs of revival, with about 600,000 kilolitres consumed annually since 2011. New products, such as sparkling sake and ones complementing Western food, are being developed to appeal to a broader audience. Sake exports have increased, valued at 11.5 billion yen in 2014, and breweries are creating new demand by developing products for female and younger customers, challenging the traditional view that sake is only for middle-aged men.

site_title: Volkswagen shows two sides of pushy culture
summary: Volkswagen's emissions scandal, involving 11.5 million vehicles, was a result of the company's pushy culture that prioritized performance and profit over ethics. A hard management style, promoted by top executives, led to a lack of delegation, pressure on engineers to find a low-cost solution, and a reluctance to listen to warnings of foul play. The scandal highlights the risks of a single-minded focus on growth and profitability, which can lead to reckless behavior and compromise a company's values. Volkswagen has vowed to change its ways, but the incident serves as a cautionary tale for companies to balance ambition with ethics and accountability.

site_title: Q3 property investment sales dive to lowest level since Global Crisis
summary: Singapore's Q3 property investment sales plummeted to S$2.86 billion, the lowest level since the Global Financial Crisis in 2009. The drop is attributed to weak global economic conditions, currency volatility, and property cooling measures. Despite a few major deals in the pipeline, such as Asia Square Tower 1 and CPF Building, the market remains cautious. Total investment sales for 2015 are forecasted to be between S$15 billion and S$18 billion, a scaleback from earlier projections.

site_title: Billionaire Kenneth Griffin goes on record-setting spending spree
summary: Billionaire Kenneth Griffin has spent nearly $300 million on a multicity real estate shopping spree over the last two years, setting new price records in three cities. He purchased two full floors of the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Chicago for $30 million, three full floors at 220 Central Park South in New York for $200 million, and a penthouse in Miami Beach for $60 million. Griffin's spending coincides with his divorce and does not appear to be related to his investment strategy.

site_title: Migrant breach briefly closes Channel Tunnel
summary: A group of over 100 migrants stormed the Channel Tunnel in France, breaching a third of the way through and halting traffic for over seven hours. The incident, which occurred on October 3, was described as unprecedented and aggressive, with migrants attacking Eurotunnel staff. Two police officers and four migrants sustained light injuries. The breach is part of a larger migration crisis in Europe, with thousands attempting to cross the Channel to reach England.

site_title: Boost for businesses
summary: Australia's new Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has been expected to bring a boost to businesses in Singapore, with no significant policy changes anticipated. Turnbull's experience as a businessman and his emphasis on pro-technologies, smart cities, and economic reform are seen as positives for the country. Businesses in Singapore can expect a more stable and constructive engagement with Australia, with the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership developing. While some potential policy changes may affect Singaporean companies, such as stricter regulators and local content requirements, overall, the business community is optimistic about Turnbull's ability to deliver a more productive and competitive economy for Australia.

site_title: Banking on the allure of Seoul's rich history and culture
summary: Seoul's luxury hotel scene is expanding with the opening of the Four Seasons Hotel Seoul in October. The 317-room hotel, located in the Gwanghwamun area, combines modern Korean motifs with contemporary design. Meanwhile, The Plaza hotel, part of Hanwha Hotels & Resorts, has joined Autograph Collection, Marriott International's exclusive portfolio, allowing it to leverage global sales and marketing channels. The Plaza, with its 410 rooms and nine banquet halls, has hosted high-profile events such as the G-20 Seoul Summit and the Seoul Nuclear Security Summit.

images.alt_text: Seoul is adding to its stock of excellent convention and accommodation facilities, with luxury hotel The Plaza joining Marriott International's Autograph Collection; one of The Plaza's nine banquet halls, and (above) a view from the hotel of Seoul's rich heritage

Seoul is adding to its stock of excellent convention and accommodation facilities, with luxury hotel The Plaza joining Marriott International's Autograph Collection; (above) one of The Plaza's nine banquet halls, and a view from the hotel of Seoul's rich heritage

site_title: Small on space, big on vibe
summary: Two hipster restaurants, Maggie Joan's and Humpback Seafood, have successfully created a trendy dining experience despite limited space. Maggie Joan's has a cramped but stylish bunker-like atmosphere, while Humpback offers a seafood experience with a lively happy hour. The food at both restaurants is hit-or-miss, with standout dishes like Maggie Joan's orange cake and Humpback's slow-cooked rainbow trout. Overall, the restaurants score high on "vibe" but may not be ideal for those seeking a more relaxed dining experience.

site_title: Investment lessons from August's mayhem
summary: The article discusses the lessons learned from the market turmoil in August 2015, which saw a 1.1% drop in the Standard & Poor's 500 Index, the worst average performance for September since 1927. Key takeaways include the normalcy of market volatility, the benefits of dollar-cost averaging, and the use of limit orders to limit losses. Investors who remained calm and dollar-cost-averaged their investments saw their 401(k) balances grow, with some even doubling their money, while those who panicked and sold their stocks during market dips lost out.

site_title: Tesla's chic is no match for BYD's China profits
summary: Tesla's stock price surged due to China's State Council's announcement that local governments must dedicate 30% of their fleet purchases to new energy vehicles. This prompted a 14% gain in Hong Kong-traded BYD shares, despite Tesla's more advanced technology. BYD's PEG ratio of 0.7 makes it undervalued compared to Tesla's 8.2, with investors attributing the disparity to BYD's poor past performance. However, China's electric vehicle sales surged 2.4 times in the first half, with BYD claiming a 43% market share, potentially overtaking Tesla in second-half volumes.

site_title: China economy to decline as global growth struggles
summary: China's manufacturing activity declined to a 6 1/2-year low in September, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) registering a value of 47. This marks the seventh consecutive month of contraction in manufacturing activity. The decline is attributed to a credit bubble that fueled China's growth in 2010, which has now led to a shift towards lower-quality investment projects. China's President Xi Jinping has attempted to address the issue by cracking down on the shadow banking industry, but efforts have been futile. Further decline is expected in the near term.

site_title: Bad economic news is good for stocks?
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average experienced a 258-point drop before closing with a net gain of 200, sparking debate over whether bad economic news is good for stocks. A recent jobs report was released, but investors remain uncertain about the impact of a potential interest rate hike, as the Fed's decision to keep rates steady amid China's volatility has added uncertainty. The market's volatility and weakness since the FOMC meeting on September 17 suggest that good economic news may not necessarily be good for stocks.

site_title: Incheon spares no effort amid competition
summary: Incheon, South Korea, is enhancing its infrastructure to cater to the demands of the Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions (MICE) industry, competing with other popular destinations. The city, known for its Chinatown and rich culture, is developing new activities to attract MICE clients. Incheon's efforts aim to showcase its unique attractions, such as its Chinese heritage and classic Korean dish jjajangmyeon, to increase its appeal as a MICE destination.

site_title: Encryption is the key to cloud security
summary: Cloud storage vendors are implementing encryption technology to increase consumer confidence in their products, providing a safer alternative to local storage devices. Despite frequent reports of data breaches, the actual amount of lost data in the cloud is minimal compared to local computers and storage devices. Cloud vendors can mitigate risks by educating consumers on best practices, investing in disaster recovery software, and providing business continuity management. By using encryption keys and extra backups, individuals and businesses can protect sensitive data and avoid embarrassing moments.

site_title: Bitcoin flounders in Australia as regulatory worries bite
summary: Bitcoin's mainstream appeal in Australia is fading due to regulatory concerns and the shutdown of 13 bitcoin exchanges by major banks. The cryptocurrency's untraceable nature makes it attractive for money laundering and selling illicit drugs, prompting authorities to crack down. Businesses are turning away from bitcoin, with some estimating it holds 7% of the currency's global value. The shutdown threatens bitcoin's long-term value and makes it harder for people to convert regular currencies into or out of bitcoin.

site_title: Aerospace firm's new frontier: competition
summary: ULA, a joint venture between Lockheed Martin and Boeing, is facing competition from SpaceX after the Air Force certified SpaceX to launch Pentagon payloads. ULA's reliance on Russian-made rocket engines has been restricted, with Congress banning their use for national security launches starting in 2019. ULA needs at least 14 RD-180 engines, but Congress has proposed allowing only four, which CEO Salvatore Bruno considers insufficient. The Air Force is working to loosen the restriction and introduce competition into the contract, aiming to reduce costs and bring down prices.

site_title: America's cappuccino having an identity crisis
summary: The cappuccino is experiencing an identity crisis due to disagreements over its definition. Traditionally, a cappuccino consists of a shot of espresso, steamed milk, and a meringue-like milk foam. However, modern variations, such as the flat white, blur the lines between the two. This confusion raises questions about what constitutes a cappuccino, threatening the drink's established identity.

site_title: EU urged to loosen deficit rules to cope with refugees
summary: The European Union is urged to relax its deficit rules due to increased spending caused by the record influx of refugees. European Parliament president Martin Schulz and Luxembourg's Finance Minister Pierre Gramegna have called for exemptions, citing the extraordinary burden on countries dealing with refugees. The EU's 3% deficit rule, which states budget deficits must not exceed 3% of gross domestic product, may need to be loosened to accommodate the costs of refugee crises, with Austria also requesting consideration for exemptions.

site_title: Russia ready to meet oil producers for talks on market situation
summary: Russia's Energy Minister Alexander Novak announced plans to meet Opec and non-Opec oil producers to discuss the global oil market situation. A separate meeting with Saudi officials is set for late October to discuss energy issues and other projects. This move comes amid market uncertainty due to tariffs, sanctions, and other factors.

site_title: Universities get top marks for keeping students happy
summary: Universities in Singapore have achieved high customer satisfaction scores, with public universities scoring 75.6 on the Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSIG) for the three months ended June 30, the highest score since the survey began in 2007. Nanyang Technological University and the National University of Singapore saw significant improvements, while SMU retained the top spot among local universities. The universities' focus on non-academic aspects of student life, such as career counselling and campus facilities, contributed to the high scores. Overall, public education institutions rose 1.6% to 74.1 from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: SMU has launched a two-year plan to freshen and liven up the campus, with new spaces created for co-curricular activities; (above) artist's impression of the co-curricular centre and amphitheatre on Campus Green

site_title: Getting a piece of the millennial pie
summary: Korea's tourism industry is adapting to the growing number of younger travelers, known as "Gen Y" international travelers. In response, lifestyle hotels are emerging, offering smart luxury or upscale select service at affordable prices. Major chains such as Best Western, Starwood, Accor, and InterContinental Hotel Group are opening new properties in Seoul and other cities, catering to millennials who value community, unique experiences, and good value. These hotels will feature stylish design, free Wi-Fi, social areas, and curated local travel guides, providing an engaging and empowering experience for younger travelers.

site_title: Analysts divided over reliability of China data as growth flags
summary: China's official growth figures, which forecast 7% growth, are being questioned by economists, who estimate real growth to be lower, around 4.5% or 6.3%. Analysts cite the political nature of economic statistics in China and the reliance on growth for legitimacy, as well as discrepancies between provincial and national growth rates. China's premier, Li Keqiang, has expressed doubts about the accuracy of GDP figures, and recent data, such as a 1% rise in electricity consumption, suggests a slower economy.

site_title: Shareholders' buying continues to rise as selling surges
summary: Shareholders in Singapore continued buying shares, with 30 companies making purchases worth S$14.76 million from Sept 28 to Oct 2. This outweighs the 2 firms that made disposals worth S$7.71 million during the same period. Buyback activity was also high, with 32 companies posting 125 repurchases worth S$147.6 million. Several significant trades included purchases by directors and executives of companies such as A-Sonic Aerospace, DBS Group, and Health Management International, while Low Keng Huat (Singapore) saw an on-market sale.

site_title: BT celebrates its 39th anniversary
summary: The Business Times (BT) celebrated its 39th anniversary in Singapore, marking another year of excellence in financial journalism. Staff members celebrated with a toast and received a set of newly issued Singapore dollar notes as a gift from the editors. This milestone comes after a series of notable partnerships and initiatives, including collaborations with organizations focused on corporate purpose, financial literacy, and sustainability. BT continues to grow and evolve, solidifying its position as Singapore's leading financial daily.

site_title: Self-storage business in Asia 'set to grow'
summary: A self-storage business in Asia is expected to grow due to rising incomes and limited land availability, particularly in Singapore. Extra Space Asia, a privately owned provider, operates 26 facilities across Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, with a projected increase in rentable square feet per capita in the region. The company aims to expand its presence in markets such as Japan, the Philippines, and Indonesia, with a goal of being the largest operator in each market. Despite market headwinds, the company is optimistic about its prospects, driven by customer-centric approaches and a focus on differentiating its services.

images.alt_text: "Prices have gone up 30 per cent in terms of valuation of the buildings, so it cost us 30 per cent less had we started the business today." - Extra Space Asia CEO Kenneth Worsdale (above)

site_title: Cyber security: not just for the tech-hearted
summary: A growing number of high-profile cyber attacks on companies in Singapore and globally have highlighted the need for robust cyber security measures. The government has established a Cyber Security Agency to oversee the nation's cyber security functions, while companies must also take proactive steps to manage cyber risk. A key step is undertaking a risk analysis exercise to identify and prioritize critical assets, followed by leadership and institutionalized processes for detecting and responding to security breaches. The government and companies must work together to address the evolving cyber threat landscape, with the CEO of the Cyber Security Agency warning that a major cyber attack is inevitable.

site_title: Mortgage exec who took rap for subprime crisis prepares appeal
summary: A former Countrywide Financial Corp executive, Rebecca Mairone, is appealing a 2013 ruling that found her liable for misrepresenting the quality of mortgages sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac during the 2008 financial crisis. The $1 million fine was imposed by US District Judge Jed Rakoff, who deemed her testimony "implausible." Mairone claims she did nothing wrong and is seeking to overturn the ruling. Her case highlights the lack of accountability for senior executives in the mortgage meltdown, which cost millions of people their homes and livelihoods.

site_title: New issues of emerging market bonds sliding
summary: Global investors' fear of a slowdown in China and other emerging markets has led to a decline in new bond issues from EM nations. Bond Radar estimates that new Asian, Latin American, and CEEMEA international bond issues fell to $55 billion in the third quarter of 2015, down from $95 billion the previous year. This decline reflects a pricking of an EM bond and equity bubble, exacerbated by a slide in Asian, Latin American, and African currencies, which has raised the burden of emerging market borrowers.

site_title: Why does this watch cost US$815,000?
summary: The Greubel Forsey Quadruple Tourbillon watch, priced at US$815,000, is a rare, exclusive timepiece produced by the Swiss company Greubel Forsey. Its engineering features four tourbillon cages, a technical innovation that enhances accuracy, and comprises 534 components, many of which are hand-finished. The watch's high production time and cost are due to the scarcity of skilled labor, with only 18 hand-finishing specialists among the 100 people employed by the company. The Quadruple Tourbillon is considered a landmark achievement in mechanical watches, and its price reflects the value of human capital and craftsmanship involved in its production.

site_title: Bouygues readies for Paris battle to emulate WeWork
summary: Bouygues SA, France's second-largest builder, is launching a shared office space initiative called Nextdoor, emulating WeWork's model. The first location in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris will be fully booked by the end of the month, with plans to open dozens of shared offices nationwide if successful. Companies can cut their office rental bills by up to 30%, generating around 2 million euros in annual revenue. Bouygues faces a "ferocious battle" with WeWork, which is raising a new round of capital at a US$10 billion valuation.

site_title: Logistics committed to delivering satisfaction
