Trading volume was 28.4 million shares worth S$42 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 75 to 47. Top shares by value traded included DBS, Singtel, and UOB.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to use Qualcomm chips for some Galaxy S7 phones
summary: Samsung Electronics will use Qualcomm's Snapdragon 820 chips for some Galaxy S7 phones sold in the US and China, while other markets will be powered by Samsung's Exynos processors. This marks a shift for Samsung, which previously used only Exynos processors for the Galaxy S6. The decision could be seen as a strategic move to diversify its supplier base and potentially alleviate supply chain risks. Samsung had previously mentioned the possibility of using Qualcomm chips in the future.

site_title: Ringgit leads losses in Asia as Malaysian budget woes add to China concern
summary: Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, led losses in Asia as concerns about the country's budget deficit and Prime Minister Najib Razak's alleged corruption hurt investor sentiment. The ringgit fell 0.9% to 4.4415 USD, with the country's benchmark index also retreating 0.5% on Friday. Malaysia's budget deficit is expected to be around 1% of GDP by 2020, despite current deficit of 3.2%. Allegations against Najib and a 49% drop in Brent crude have exacerbated the slowdown in China, contributing to the decline.

site_title: MOT will study third-party ride-booking apps, ensure level playing field: Khaw
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Transport (MOT) will study third-party ride-booking apps like GrabTaxi and Uber, aiming to create a level playing field for private-hire drivers and taxi drivers. Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan announced the move in response to concerns from taxi drivers, who feel UberX is unfair due to its drivers not requiring a vocational licence. The study will be led by Senior Minister of State Ng Chee Meng, who will consult with taxi drivers and the public to find a fair solution.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip on profit taking ahead of US payrolls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Friday, snapping a two-day gain, as investors took profits ahead of US non-farm payrolls data. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 25.6 points to 5,086.5. The benchmark rose 1.8% on Thursday, marking its first weekly gain in two weeks. Investors are awaiting the release of US payrolls data, which may indicate when US interest rates will rise, and are seeking a breather before the market moves.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks slightly higher, caution ahead of weekend
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.1% to 8,302.94, but gains were limited due to caution ahead of the weekend. The electronics subindex fell 0.1%, while financials subindex was mostly flat to lower. Notable movers included CTBC Financial up 0.9% and AU Optronics up 1.9%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.959 per US dollar.

site_title: US: Stocks end flat ahead of jobs report
summary: US stocks ended flat on Thursday ahead of the jobs report, with the Dow losing 0.08% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rising 0.20% and 0.15% respectively. Mixed economic data, including near-flat US manufacturing activity and a seven-year high in construction spending, influenced the session. Pharmaceutical stocks rallied, while General Motors and Ford rose after beating expectations on September auto sales. The jobs report, expected to show 205,000 jobs added and a 5.1% unemployment rate, will be released on Friday.

site_title: China: Markets closed on October 1-7
summary: China's stock, bond, foreign exchange, and commodity futures markets will be closed from October 1 to 7 for a national holiday, resuming trade on October 8. Meanwhile, global markets experienced volatility, with US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats and Europe's mining and healthcare sectors propelling shares higher. Asia's stocks rallied despite new Trump threats, and Singapore stocks reached a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Japan jobless rate edges up to 3.4% in August
summary: Japan's jobless rate rose to 3.4% in August, surpassing analysts' expectations, with a job offer ratio of 1.23, the highest in 23 years. Despite the slight increase, the labour market remained tight. Household spending rose 2.9% year-on-year, and a slowdown in China and weakness at home dented Japanese firms' confidence, fuelling speculation about the Bank of Japan expanding its asset-buying plan. This marks a faltering of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics growth strategy.

site_title: Asia: Stock futures drop as rally wavers ahead of payrolls data
summary: Asian stock futures declined ahead of US payrolls data, which will be scrutinized for signs the US recovery has been shaken. The dollar traded with bonds as traders await the report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's decision on raising interest rates. Global equities have fallen this week despite signs of a relief rally, with markets expecting a weak number to have a negative impact on the dollar. The S&P 500 index futures were little changed, while US oil rose above $45 a barrel.

site_title: Macau September gambling revenues fall 33%, 16th consecutive monthly decline
summary: Macau's September gambling revenues plummeted 33% year-on-year, marking the 16th consecutive monthly decline. The decline is attributed to wealthy VIP gamers staying away due to Beijing's crackdown on corruption and illicit money outflows. Revenues fell to 17.13 billion patacas, down from 25.56 billion patacas in the same period last year. Analysts had forecast a decline of around 32-34%.

site_title: Japan firms expect CPI to rise 1.2% a year from now: BOJ survey
summary: Japanese firms expect consumer prices to rise 1.2% annually in the next year, according to a Bank of Japan survey. This is a decrease from the previous survey's 1.4% projection. Firms also expect a 1.4% annual increase in three years and 1.5% in five years. The survey, known as "tankan," provides insight into the Japanese economy's growth prospects.

site_title: HKMA sells HK$3.9b to keep Hong Kong dollar in trading band on Oct 1
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) intervened in the currency market by selling HK$3.875 billion in Hong Kong dollars to maintain the local currency within its trading band of 7.75 to 7.85 against the US dollar. The move was made on October 1, as the Hong Kong dollar hit the strong end of its range. The injected funds will be settled on October 5, increasing the aggregate balance to HK$361.828 billion. This intervention is a necessary step to keep the currency peg intact, as the HKMA is obliged to intervene when the Hong Kong dollar reaches 7.75 or 7.85.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sarine Tech, BBR Holdings
summary: Sarine Technologies Ltd expects revenue for the quarter to be about half of those in Q3 2014, due to material announcements on Thursday evening. BBR Holdings won a S$116 million design-and-build contract for a mixed-use project at Yishun Avenue 4.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.89% lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.89% lower on October 2, 2015, as Wall Street remained flat ahead of a US jobs report. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 158.03 points to 17,564.39. Trading was quiet, with no significant market-moving news. The decline was attributed to general market conditions rather than any specific event.

site_title: Thailand rolls out red carpet for foreign bond issuers
summary: Thailand has announced plans to ease the approval process for foreign bond issuers, allowing them to access the baht market on a monthly basis starting from January. The move aims to boost the country's status as a regional funding hub and deepen its capital markets. Foreign issuers will now have more flexibility to sell bonds in Thailand, with a reduced nine-month window and a shortened issuance period of six months. This change is seen as a response to the need for more frequent and flexible market conditions.

site_title: Japan's household spending bounces back with 2.9% gain in August
summary: Japan's household spending increased by 2.9% in August, the first gain in three months, exceeding economists' expectations of a 0.3% gain. This boost is seen as a positive sign for the economy, potentially easing concerns of a recession. However, industrial production dropped, and economists predict a 1% decline in GDP in the third quarter due to weak exports and soft demand. The government may compile a stimulus package, according to some estimates, to support economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.57% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 1.57% higher on Friday, despite flat US markets ahead of a jobs report. The Hang Seng Index rose 327.77 points to 21,174.07. Chinese stock markets were closed for a public holiday.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened 1.57 per cent higher on Friday, despite flatness on Wall Street ahead of a US jobs report later in the day.

site_title: New Zealand commodity prices rise in September
summary: New Zealand's commodity prices rose 5.5% in September, reversing a five-month trend of falls, according to ANZ Bank's commodity price index. This increase was driven by gains in dairy and aluminium prices. On an annual basis, the index was 18.2% lower, compared to a 23.5% fall in the previous month.

site_title: South Korea's August seasonally adjusted current account surplus edges down
summary: South Korea's seasonally adjusted current account surplus decreased to US$8.41 billion in August, down from US$8.72 billion in July. Exports slipped 0.6% to US$45 billion, while imports rose 0.9% to US$35.97 billion, resulting in a goods account surplus of US$9.03 billion. The financial account recorded a net outflow of US$9.12 billion in August, compared to a net outflow of US$10.21 billion in July.

site_title: JPMorgan to pay most in US$1.86b swaps price-fixing settlement
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is set to pay US$595 million as part of a US$1.86 billion settlement with regulators over price-fixing in the credit-default swaps market. The settlement involves a dozen big banks, with Morgan Stanley, Barclays Plc, and Goldman Sachs Group Inc paying US$230 million, US$175 million, and US$164 million, respectively. The deal resolves claims that the banks conspired to limit competition and restrict access to the market.

site_title: India: Markets closed on Friday
summary: Financial markets in India were closed on Friday due to a public holiday. In contrast, global markets experienced volatility with stocks in Europe and the US down, despite US indices reaching fresh records. The focus is on US-EU trade talks and the ongoing rally in Singapore stocks. Meanwhile, traders in Asia are brushing off new Trump threats, and several companies, including Singtel and PSC, are under watch due to their upcoming events.

site_title: Oil ends lower after choppy session
summary: Oil prices ended lower on Thursday following a choppy session as traders awaited the US jobs report for September. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dipped 35 cents to $44.74 a barrel, while European benchmark Brent oil lost 68 cents to $47.69 a barrel. Despite a rally from US petroleum data showing lower oil production, analysts say the declines are not significant enough to address the supply glut. The market is expected to take cues from the US jobs report on Friday, which is expected to show 205,000 jobs added and an unemployment rate of 5.1%.

site_title: Wal-Mart reaches 'line in sand' moment in push to improve stores
summary: Wal-Mart, the US retail giant, has reached a critical "line in the sand" milestone in its efforts to transform its stores into cleaner, easier, and friendlier places to shop. As of October 1, 2015, the company's US operations head, Greg Foran, has been visiting stores to assess their progress in achieving key priorities, including reducing checkout lines and improving efficiency. Despite progress, some stores still lag behind, and Foran continues his surprise visits to identify areas for improvement. The company aims to bring costs lower and enhance customer service, but faces challenges from fiercer Amazon competition and a broader retail slowdown.

site_title: Williams says uncertainty alone shouldn't stop Fed rate increase
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams stated that despite global risks and uncertainties, domestic economic conditions remain positive, and he continues to advocate for a rate increase this year. The Fed has kept its main policy interest rate near-zero since 2008, and Williams expects the unemployment rate to fall below 5% this year. Despite a close decision at the previous meeting, Williams believes a rate increase is on the table at the next meeting in October, and the labor market continues to improve while inflation remains stagnant at 0.3%.

site_title: US auto sales stay strong in September; Volkswagen flat
summary: US auto sales continued to show strength in September, with most major automakers reporting double-digit year-over-year gains. General Motors, Ford, Toyota, and Fiat Chrysler all saw significant increases in sales, with lightweight vehicles accounting for 1.44 million sales, a 15.8% rise from last year. Volkswagen's sales remained flat, despite efforts to regain trust after the emissions scandal. SUVs and trucks saw strong demand, with sales up 15.8% for the year.

site_title: Corporate tax dodging is 'corruption': World Bank chief
summary: World Bank President Jim Yong Kim criticized corporate tax dodging as corrupt behavior, stating it hurts the poor. He called for more equitable taxation in developing countries to generate revenues that could surpass official development assistance. Kim argued that companies use complex strategies to avoid paying taxes, a form of corruption that undermines economic development.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler's US workers reject contract offer
summary: US workers at Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) rejected a proposed four-year contract, voting down the agreement by 65% in a ratification vote. The contract, which included pay raises and a profit-sharing plan, was seen as a template for UAW contracts with General Motors and Ford. The UAW, representing 40,000 FCA US employees, will seek further talks with the company after the failure. The rejection is a setback for Fiat Chrysler's restructuring plans and may impact contract talks with GM and Ford.

site_title: TPP trade talks extended
summary: Trade officials from 12 Pacific rim countries have extended negotiations on the world's largest free trade zone until Friday, despite unresolved issues such as US auto parts regulations and Canada's dairy market access. The US Trade Representative's planned press conference was cancelled, and talks will continue. The talks have been bogged down on these and other issues, but the extension indicates a desire to reach an agreement.

images.alt_text: The twelve Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) Ministers hold a press conference to discuss progress in the negotiations in Lahaina, Maui, Hawaii on July 31, 2015.

site_title: Update: TWG says pesticide issue 'overblown'
summary: TWG Tea, a luxury tea seller, has faced controversy over pesticide residues in its "Chamomile Green Tea" exported from India. The issue was sparked by a Taiwanese FDA report, but TWG Tea spokeswoman Maranda Barnes claims the issue is "overblown" and the product is safe for consumption. The company has exported 800 types of tea to Taiwan without issue, and is working with Taiwanese authorities to resolve the matter. Different testing standards and methods used by various countries and territories may be contributing to the confusion.

site_title: Sinarmas Land share buyback raises questions
summary: Sinarmas Land, a Singapore-listed real estate firm, has conducted a share buyback of S$88.5 million, acquiring 149.8 million shares, with the remaining shares to be purchased under a program. The buyback has raised questions about the identity of the seller, who is believed to have held warrants that could be converted into shares at a higher price, potentially resulting in a significant profit. The company has not disclosed the seller's identity, citing listing rules, but market observers are eagerly awaiting further information.

site_title: ANZ's CFO to take helm, flags more-disciplined Asia strategy
summary: ANZ Banking Group's incoming CEO, Shayne Elliott, will take the helm on January 1, replacing Mike Smith. Elliott, who has been CFO for three years, has signaled a more disciplined approach to Asia growth, following criticism of the bank's low returns. Elliott's leadership marks a shift in strategy, with a focus on more measured expansion in the region.

site_title: VW says probe into pollution scam to take months
summary: Volkswagen has begun a months-long investigation into its massive pollution cheating scandal, hiring US law firm Jones Day to conduct an independent probe. The company faces huge fines and potential litigation worldwide, with the EU seeking coordinated action by the end of November. In the US, VW could face up to $18 billion in fines, while Australia's competition watchdog could fine the company billions for each cheating device. The scandal has cost VW nearly 40% of its share price in 10 days and has led to the resignation of CEO Martin Winterkorn and the suspension of suspected managers.

site_title: Dollar little changed ahead of US jobs report
summary: The US dollar remained unchanged ahead of the September jobs report, which is expected to show 205,000 jobs added and a 5.1% unemployment rate. Analysts believe a strong jobs report with solid wage growth could boost the dollar, paving the way for a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. However, a weak report could make the Fed's decision more uncertain, negatively impacting the dollar.

site_title: Singapore's September PMI falls for third month in a row
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted for the third consecutive month in September, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 48.6, lower than expected. The decline was attributed to weak external demand, domestic constraints, and a stronger Singapore dollar eroding competitiveness. However, some economists note that the North American semiconductor industry may be bottoming out, and Singapore's manufacturing growth is expected to contract less severely in the fourth quarter. The chances of a technical recession in the third quarter are high, but economists caution against job losses.

site_title: Thai govt websites crash in 'symbolic act' by censorship critics
summary: Thai government websites temporarily crashed due to a "symbolic act" by those opposed to plans to introduce a single Internet gateway, dubbed the "Great Firewall of Thailand". The proposal, which critics say will enable the ruling junta to censor the web, was met with a petition signed by over 132,000 people. The Ministry of Information and Communication Technology's website crashed due to overcrowding, but access to other government sites was restored. The government maintains that the incident was not a cyber attack, but a protest against the proposal.

site_title: People-rating app sparks firestorm
summary: A new people-rating app, Peeple, has sparked outrage over its concept of allowing users to rate friends, family, and others with one to five stars without their consent. The app's creators, Julia Cordray and Nicole McCullough, defended the idea as a platform for praise and constructive feedback, but faced criticism on Twitter and other online venues, with some calling it a "nightmare" and a potential tool for bullies and stalkers. Despite the backlash, Peeple plans to launch in November as scheduled.

site_title: Walmart to cut hundreds of jobs at its Arkansas HQ
summary: Walmart plans to lay off hundreds of employees at its Arkansas headquarters, with fewer than 500 employees expected to lose their jobs. The cuts are part of the company's efforts to pare costs and follow a streamlining effort flagged by CEO Doug McMillon. The move comes as Walmart struggles to shore up its profit margins, weighed down by higher labor costs, lower pharmacy margins, and a stronger dollar. The layoffs are expected to be announced as early as this Friday.

site_title: China's manufacturing sector shrinks further in September
summary: China's manufacturing sector contracted further in September, with the Caixin/Markit PMI falling to a six-and-a-half year low of 47.2. The official PMI edged up to 49.8, indicating a slight improvement in output and new orders. Economists welcome the bounce, attributing it to easing monetary policies and potential support measures. However, the services sector PMI fell to 50.5, and input prices are still rising, raising concerns about the economy's overall health. Despite a slight improvement, the data suggests that China's economic slowdown remains significant, with economists predicting a third-quarter GDP growth below the official target of 7%.

site_title: US should not oppose Russian intervention in Syria
summary: The US should not oppose Russia's intervention in Syria, as it may create a strategic vacuum that Russia can fill, potentially destabilizing the region. Critics of President Obama's Syria policy argue that retaining more US troops or providing more military assistance would not have worked, citing failed efforts to arm moderate rebels. Instead, partnering with Russia could help defeat ISIS and protect Russian national interests, including the Alawite minority and Christian communities under threat in Syria. This approach aligns with the US experience of collaborating with Russia in the past, such as during the Cold War.

site_title: US teens add social media to toolbox for flirting: study
summary: US teens are increasingly using social media as tools for flirting, with 55% of those aged 13-17 having flirted or talked to someone in person to show interest. The study found that 31% had sent flirtatious messages, 10% had sent photos, and 7% had made videos for a potential partner. However, the use of social media can also lead to negative behaviors such as jealousy, meddling, and controlling behavior, with 35% of girls and 16% of boys blocking or unfriending someone who made them uncomfortable.

site_title: Euro manufacturers begin passing on oil price slump
summary: Eurozone manufacturers are passing on the latest oil-price slump to their customers, with factory-gate prices falling in September for the first time in six months. The European Central Bank is closely watching the impact on the economy, amid speculation that policy makers may need to expand their stimulus program to revive inflation. Despite a strengthening economic recovery, the manufacturing sector is expected to grow only at a modest pace, with companies stepping up output in response to rising new orders.

site_title: Cost of new cholesterol drugs in spotlight
summary: Two costly new cholesterol fighters, Praluent from Regeneron Pharmaceuticals and Sanofi, and Repatha from Amgen Inc, have been rejected by Express Scripts, the largest pharmacy benefit manager in the US, due to patients not meeting medical criteria. The injectable drugs, which can slash "bad" LDL cholesterol by over 60%, cost more than $14,000 a year and are meant for patients with hereditary high cholesterol and cardiovascular disease. Express Scripts predicts a sharp drop in rejected prescriptions as doctors prescribe them more narrowly.

site_title: Starwood Hotels plans to expand presence in Africa
summary: Starwood Hotels & Resorts plans to expand its presence in Africa by 50% over the next five years, aiming to operate over 50 hotels on the continent by 2020. The company has signed deals to run hotels in Mali, Kenya, Tanzania, Nigeria, Senegal, and Egypt, adding to its existing portfolio in these countries. This move comes despite short-term security and economic concerns, as the company sees positive growth prospects in the region.

site_title: DNB's 7.04% Ezra stake buy likely just a share pledge: analysts
summary: A $25 million stake buy in Ezra Holdings by DNB Bank is likely a share pledge, analysts say. Frontica Global Employment, a Norwegian company, sold 207 million shares on September 25, but then bought them back the same day, citing a forward agreement. This may be a loan of around $25 million, with Frontica providing collateral and agreeing to repurchase the stake in the future. The move does not signal a change of control and maintains the status quo for substantial shareholders.

site_title: Apps for fitness buffs
summary: Fitness-sharing platforms have emerged as a convenient alternative to traditional gym memberships, offering access to hundreds of classes per month for a flat fee starting from S$59. Companies like Passport Asia, GuavaPass, and KFit have launched in Singapore, allowing users to book classes in various locations, including Bangkok, Hong Kong, and Dubai. These platforms cater to a wide range of fitness enthusiasts, from yoga and pilates to pole dancing and trampoline fitness. While some studios are concerned about the long-term impact, users are benefiting from the increased variety and social aspect of fitness.

site_title: US retail Reit sells minority stakes in 5 malls to GIC
summary: Macerich Co, a US retail Reit, has agreed to sell minority stakes in eight US malls to Singapore's GIC and Heitman LLC for $2.3 billion. The deal allows Macerich to pay a special dividend, buy back shares, and cut debt. GIC will own 40% of five malls, while Heitman will have a 49% interest in three. The transactions, valued at $5.4 billion, are scheduled to close in phases starting in October. The deal comes after Macerich spurned a takeover offer from Simon Property Group Inc earlier this year.

site_title: Thai hotel group to acquire 10 properties in Europe in 3 years
summary: Bangkok-based Absolute Hotel Services (AHS) plans to acquire 10 properties in Europe over the next three years, aiming to capitalize on the region's tourism potential and the weak euro against the Thai baht. The company, which already operates 60 hotels worldwide, aims to expand its presence in Europe with its U Hotels & Resorts brand, and will also manage hotels for others. AHS expects to increase its total revenue by 10-12% next year, driven by its hotel expansion plan, which includes its first hotel in Turkey set to open in 2016.

site_title: Asia-Pacific corporate banks keep an eye on cost amid strength: report
summary: Asia-Pacific corporate banks maintained revenue growth in 2014, with a 3% increase to 396 billion euros, driven by corporate banking revenue rising on transaction banking and lending gains. However, global corporate and investment banking revenue was flat at 985 billion euros, reflecting cost pressures and overcapacity. The region's lower cost-to-income ratio, averaging 34%, is expected to decline as fintechs capture business and drive down margins. To offset this, banks may need to cut costs further to meet a realistic return on equity (ROE) range of 11-14% by 2016.

site_title: Microsoft, Google drop all patent litigation against each other
summary: Microsoft and Google have settled 18 patent infringement cases in the US and Germany, effectively ending all patent litigation against each other. The deal affects various technologies, including mobile phones, Wi-Fi, and Xbox game consoles. The agreement marks a significant development in the global smartphone wars, with the companies focusing on other areas. Financial terms of the deal remain undisclosed, leaving room for potential future lawsuits.

site_title: Daiichi Chuo files for bankruptcy protection
summary: Japanese shipping line Daiichi Chuo files for bankruptcy protection with 120 billion yen in liabilities, citing four straight years of losses due to over-expansion amid plunging freight rates. The company's shares will be delisted on October 30, and Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd will book a 25 billion yen charge. Despite Daiichi Chuo's struggles, the Japanese shipping market is expected to remain sound, with other top companies operating well.

site_title: Europe's biggest test
summary: The European Union faces a critical stress test, with the upcoming British referendum on EU membership being a crucial factor. The author believes that Britain's EU membership provides a balanced and meaningful integration project for the continent. Without Britain, the EU would lack a comparable strength in counterbalancing other countries, potentially destabilizing the project. The author argues that Britain's membership is essential for the EU's long-term success, despite the challenges posed by the refugee crisis and Greek turbulence.

site_title: Beam Suntory marks SG50 with donation
summary: Beam Suntory, the world's third largest premium spirits company, donated S$70,500 to the Business Times Budding Artists Fund to celebrate SG50. The donation was raised through an auction of three 50-year-old single malts, with a winning bid of S$141,100. The funds will support disadvantaged young people in developing their artistic talent. Beam Suntory's managing director, Jonathan Chow, expressed his honor in giving back to the future of Singapore while celebrating the country's 50th anniversary.

site_title: Zurich Life's agents to move to financial advisory firm Nexus
summary: Zurich Life Singapore will transfer its 160 financial adviser representatives and 10 support staff to Nexus Financial Services Pte Ltd, a new financial advisory firm, in a move to expand its product choice and quality advice. The transfer will not impact existing customers, and Zurich will maintain its independent distribution model, partnering with FA firms and banks. The new firm, led by Gary Harvey, aims to build a strong adviser network across multiple client segments, with initial focus on the mass affluent market before expanding into high net worth segments.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezra Holdings' stock price fell to S$0.116 on October 1 after Norwegian-based DNB Bank acquired 207 million shares at S$0.12 per share, resulting in a 7.04% stake. The acquisition may be part of a forward agreement or share pledge agreement for financing. Despite a dim industry outlook, analysts maintain a "hold" rating and S$0.16 fair value estimate, citing potential positive catalysts.

site_title: American bull in a china shop
summary: David Henry Hwang's comedy Chinglish, set to be staged by Pangdemonium, revolves around American businessman Daniel Cavanaugh's struggles with miscommunication in China. Daniel, hired to create proper English signs for a cultural centre, faces hilarity and confusion due to China's unique English language challenges. Examples include a "deformed man's toilet" sign and a misinterpretation of his company as "tiny and insignificant". The story highlights the comedic side of cultural differences in language and communication.

site_title: Horror is the Maine attraction in Portland
summary: The city of Portland in Maine, known as the horror capital of the world due to its association with horror writer Stephen King, is set to showcase its horror film talent to Singaporean audiences for the first time. The 6th annual "Damnationland" film event, featuring 10 short films by Maine filmmakers, will be screened as part of the SCUMSCOPE film festival in Singapore later this month. The event marks the first time "Damnationland" has traveled outside of America, highlighting the state's thriving horror film scene.

site_title: Mass-customised goods do have a future in Asia
summary: Mass customisation is gaining popularity in Asia, but its effectiveness varies across the region due to cultural differences. In high uncertainty avoidance markets like Japan and Taiwan, consumers prefer pre-packaged options and are less likely to share customised products on social media. However, in low uncertainty avoidance markets like Singapore and China, consumers are more accepting of customised products and are willing to share their creations online. Companies must tailor their approach to each market, using incentives and interactive platforms to boost product awareness and engagement. Despite cultural differences, mass customisation has a future in Asia, but companies must be mindful of these unique influences.

site_title: Integrated checkpoints command launched at Singapore's air checkpoints
summary: Singapore has launched the Integrated Checkpoints Command (ICC) at its air checkpoints, strengthening coordination among Home Team agencies. Senior Assistant Commissioner of Police Zuraidah Abdullah, now ICC's domain commander (air), oversees operations at Changi Airport and four other air checkpoints. The ICC aims to enhance coordination and provide clearer lines of responsibility among Home Team officers. This move is part of a phased implementation to unify command and control structures, ensuring safe and secure air checkpoints.

site_title: Sylvie Guillem's long goodbye
summary: Renowned French ballerina Sylvie Guillem, 50, has announced her final tour, "Life In Progress," featuring works created by three renowned choreographers: Akram Khan, Russell Maliphant, and Mats Ek. This showcase marks her farewell to the stage, following a career spanning ballet and contemporary dance. Guillem has chosen these choreographers for their unique styles, which align with her own inquisitive nature and desire to explore new artistic boundaries. Her final performance will take place in Taiwan, after which she plans to reflect and consider future creative endeavors.

site_title: Headwinds make markets more forgiving of a missed KL fiscal deficit target
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has acknowledged that the country may not meet its balanced budget target by 2020, citing economic headwinds. Analysts believe that the fiscal deficit will be trimmed to avoid criticism, given the challenging global economic environment. This news comes as other countries also face economic challenges, including a slowdown in China's GDP growth and a shrinking UK economy.

site_title: US manufacturing shrinks in Sept on weaker global demand
summary: US manufacturing contracted in September with the Institute for Supply Management's factory index falling to 50.2, the weakest since May 2013, due to weaker global demand and a stronger dollar. Export demand matched its weakest since July 2012, while US consumers' spending helped underpin manufacturing. Economists forecast a decline in demand, citing the dollar's appreciation, which is expected to hit US exports.

site_title: Gehry's Conde Nast cafeteria to stay
summary: Frank Gehry's 1997 cafeteria in 4 Times Square, a prominent contemporary architecture piece, will remain preserved as part of a conference center. The space, designed by Gehry, was initially intended for Condé Nast employees but will now serve as an amenity for potential new occupants. The cafeteria's unique glass partitions and naturalistic forms have been praised for their engineering and design, offering a glimpse into Gehry's early work in New York City. The space will be opened to the public for admirers of design and architectural history.

images.alt_text: The cafeteria space designed by Frank Gehry in the now-vacated former headquarters of Conde Nast, on the fourth floor of 4 Times Square in New York. Building owner Durst is meeting with potential operators of the space, which is off limits to the public.

site_title: Amazon setting up its own US network of delivery couriers
summary: Amazon is launching its own US network of delivery couriers through Amazon Flex, a programme that pays drivers $18 to $25 per hour for ferrying packages to customers. This move aims to bring instant gratification to online shopping. The company is also expanding its Prime Now delivery service, which requires drivers to make deliveries within one hour.

site_title: Bringing back the heyday of disco
summary: A musical adaptation of the 1977 film Saturday Night Fever has been touring the world, drawing in audiences with its nostalgic value and Bee Gees soundtrack. Despite lukewarm reviews, the show has remained popular due to its ability to transport viewers back in time. However, the musical has been criticized for its lack of convincing performances, particularly in the lead roles, and its reliance on campy elements such as the Filipino ensemble's accents and wigs. The show will run at Mastercard Theatres in Singapore until October 4.

site_title: US dollar seen ready for 25% gain with or without Fed liftoff
summary: The US dollar is expected to gain 25% over the next three years, driven by investors exiting "carry trades" and a reluctance from the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The dollar has strengthened against 15 of its 16 most-traded peers since September 17, and a gauge tracking 20 developing-nation currencies dropped 8.3% in the third quarter. Experts believe the dollar's gains will continue, with the Dollar Index reaching 120, as other central banks combat slowing growth and muted inflation.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

In Singapore, new restaurants and bars have opened, including Aura at the National Gallery, offering Italian cuisine and a sky lounge, and Gibson, a raw food bar with seafood dishes. Stand-up comedian Ronny Chieng is back with his new solo show "You Don't Know What You're Talking About." Meanwhile, Xu Zheng's film "Lost in Hong Kong" has broken box office records, selling over US$100 million worth of tickets in China. Italian restaurant The Italian Table offers a unique brunch experience with multiple courses, and the National Gallery is set to open its doors in November.

site_title: Weaker Japan manufacturing sentiment intensifies talk of monetary easing
summary: Japan's manufacturing sentiment worsened in September, according to the Bank of Japan's Tankan survey, sparking speculation of further monetary easing. This prospect, combined with China's potential manufacturing stabilization, led to Tokyo's Nikkei 225 average gaining 1.9% to 17,722.42. The news boosted Japanese stock prices, reversing some losses from earlier in the week. These developments come as global economic uncertainty persists, with ongoing trade tensions and economic slowdowns in major economies.

site_title: Singtel's Thai dispute sent for arbitration
summary: Thai state-owned telco TOT Public Company Ltd is claiming 70 billion baht (S$2.74 billion) from Singtel's Thai associate, Advanced Info Service Public Company Ltd (AIS), over alleged unlawful contract amendments dating back to 2001 and 2002. AIS refutes the claim and has submitted the matter for arbitration, stating that the amendments were made correctly and with consent. The dispute involves changes to revenue-sharing and concession fees, and is the latest in a long-standing dispute between the two companies.

site_title: Beauty of the indomitable human spirit
summary: The Martian, a 3D-thriller film directed by Ridley Scott, tells the story of astronaut Mark Watney (Matt Damon) who is stranded on Mars after a sandstorm and presumed dead. Using his ingenuity and training, Watney survives for four years until rescue, adapting to his situation and maintaining a positive attitude despite setbacks. The film, based on Andy Weir's novel, balances scientific accuracy with entertainment, showcasing the indomitable human spirit and its ability to overcome adversity. With a talented cast and visually stunning visuals, The Martian is a cinematic success.

site_title: Portable but never a commodity
summary: Portable Art Week, a group exhibition at iPreciation Gallery in Singapore, offers affordable art-buying opportunities for entry-level collectors, with prices ranging from S$1,000 to S$8,000. The event provides a platform for young and new collectors to engage with Singapore contemporary art, featuring diverse works by local artists such as April Ng, Boo Sze Yang, and Jeremy Sharma. The event aims to change perceptions of fine art as intimidating and expensive, and instead encourages collectors to view it as an alternative to year-end presents.

site_title: Asian voices and stories to feature at S'pore film fest
summary: Acclaimed Iranian filmmaker Mohsen Makhmalbaf will receive an honorary award at this year's Singapore International Film Festival. A retrospective of his films will also be screened, featuring over 20 features and 50 awards won since 1983. His latest film, The President, will be showcased alongside other award-winning films such as The Cyclist and Salam Cinema. Makhmalbaf's works continue to reflect his home country's socio-political climate, despite living in Paris.

images.alt_text: "The President" is a black comedy about a deposed dictator and his six-year-old grandson who are forced to flee after his regime is toppled

site_title: Fed should rethink the need for an interest-rate hike this year
summary: The US Federal Reserve may reconsider raising interest rates this year, following severe market corrections since its September meeting. Critics argue the Fed unnerved markets by referencing China's economic issues, which could lead to a global credit crunch. The IMF has warned that a rate hike could prompt a new credit crunch in emerging markets. A "hard landing" in China could have a significant impact on global growth, with major economies including Japan, Korea, and Hong Kong at risk.

site_title: Hackers step up attacks in South-east Asia amid tensions
summary: Hackers have increased attacks on government organisations and companies in South-east Asia, making the region one of the most targeted in the world. According to FireEye, organisations in the region were 45% more likely to be targeted due to disputes over territorial waters and trade talks. Thailand was twice as likely to see attacks, and telecommunications, technology, and financial services companies were the most targeted. Security breaches cost the global economy over $400 billion annually, with Asian countries being disproportionately affected.

site_title: Comair drops Boeing deliveries as US Ex-Im charter expires
summary: Comair, a South African airline, may drop $1.1 billion in Boeing deliveries due to lack of financing without US government assistance. The US Export-Import Bank's charter has expired, leaving Comair to find credit at a higher cost. Boeing is exploring conversions of its 737-800 passenger jet into freight haulers to meet demand from express parcel firms. The company aims to offer 1,000 single-aisle conversions over 20 years, with potential demand in the US and China.

site_title: Global M&A deal value in 2015 could surpass 2007 peak
summary: Global mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deal value for the first three quarters of 2015 is projected to surpass the 2007 peak, reaching US$2.87 trillion, according to a report by Mergermarket. Despite a rough summer, this year's deal values are 21% higher than the equivalent period in 2014 and only 12% lower than last year. The report suggests that privatisation could be a possible theme in the battered markets.

site_title: TPP trade talks make headway on car parts hurdle
summary: Negotiators for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) made progress on a hurdle for car parts, with Canada and Mexico signaling a willingness to open the North American market to more parts made in Asia. Japan pushed for a 32.5% local sourcing threshold, while officials from Mexico and Canada aimed for a 45% threshold. If agreed upon, this would allow for more parts sourced from outside the 12 countries to be sold in the US without tariffs. The deal is expected to be finalized before Friday, but other issues such as dairy trade and biologic drugs remain unresolved.

site_title: Disneyland of culinary experiences
summary: CulinaryOn, the largest cooking studio in Europe, has opened its doors in Singapore. Founded in Moscow by Alexander Blanc, the studio offers immersive culinary experiences, similar to a "Disneyland of culinary experiences." With a 7,000 sq ft space, it features multiple event areas, cooking stations, and a conference room, accommodating up to 200 people. The studio aims to replicate its Moscow success, with plans to open 20 locations worldwide in the next five years, targeting cities with a lack of extraordinary entertainment options.

images.alt_text: Says co-founder Alexander Blanc: "In Moscow, we employ eight full-time photographers because we know that's the magical part of the experience - making memories."

site_title: India's food safety crisis indicative of bureaucratic failures
summary: India's food safety crisis is indicative of bureaucratic failures, with the country's regulatory bodies lacking credibility and inadequate testing capacity. The Maggi instant noodles scandal has highlighted the issue, with the Indian government's ban on the product being overturned by a court, and Nestlé destroying over 35,000 tonnes of the product. The country's food safety standards are not at developed world standards, and the US FDA frequently rejects products shipped from India. To address the issue, effective appropriation of resources, institutional strengthening, and capacity building are needed, along with tighter coordination among agencies.

site_title: Singapore firms better on payments in Q3
summary: Singapore firms showed improved payment performance in the third quarter, with slow payments reaching its lowest in six quarters. Prompt payments also reached its best since the first quarter of last year. Slow payments dropped 3.61 percentage points compared to a year ago, while prompt payments rose to 51.05%, the highest since the first quarter of last year. The construction sector led the improvement, with payments delays declining by 8.3 percentage points.

site_title: New margin rules coming for uncleared OTC derivatives
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to impose new margin rules for uncleared over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives, starting with banks, to reduce systemic risk. The rules will apply to nearly all uncleared OTC derivatives, except for physically settled foreign exchange forwards and swaps. The MAS aims to reduce counterparty risk and is part of broader global reforms to make OTC derivatives trading safer. The rules will be introduced in phases, with a quantitative study to assess the impact, and comments are invited from interested parties by November 1.

site_title: Emerging-market capital flows forecast to turn negative in 2015
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) forecasts negative net capital flows to emerging markets in 2015, with outflows projected at $541 billion, the lowest since the 2008 financial crisis. This is due to internal concerns about economic prospects and policies in China, rather than external factors. Countries with large current-account deficits and poor macro policy frameworks, such as Brazil and Turkey, are most at risk. The IIF expects moderate pace of net capital outflows in 2016, driven by subdued emerging-market growth and US Federal Reserve policy tightening.

site_title: Fusing kathak and flamenco on a common stage at the Esplanade
summary: Dancers Akram Khan and Israel Galvan will perform "Torobaka" on Oct 16-17 at the Esplanade Theatre, blending kathak and flamenco on a common stage. The piece, which breaks traditional boundaries, will see the two artists investigating their respective dance traditions while leaning towards their primal instincts. Khan, a UK-based associate artist, and Galvan, a Spanish associate artist, aim to fuse tradition and vision into an unforgettable experience, with a four-piece band accompanying them.

site_title: A sizzling expression of seduction and intimacy
summary: Argentinean tango couple Pablo Sosa and Mariela Maldonado will perform "Tango Legends" in Singapore, showcasing the evolution of the dance from the 1940s. The show features a multi-piece performance, including pieces like "Inspiracion" and "La Mariposa," which highlight the dance's sensual and intimate nature. The couple, who have been dancing since the 1990s, aim to share the cultural heritage of tango with a new audience, with performances scheduled for October 9 and 10 at The Esplanade Concert Hall.

site_title: Firms await EU ruling on US data privacy
summary: The EU's top court will rule next week on the continued legality of the Safe Harbour framework agreement, which allows companies to transfer personal data from Europe to the US. The agreement's future could be disrupted, affecting thousands of companies and online transactions. A negative ruling could also mean that US intelligence services can access data, despite previous assurances. Companies are advised to establish alternative frameworks to ensure uninterrupted data transfers.

site_title: Stock rises put yen and euro under pressure
summary: Global stock markets rose, putting pressure on the yen, euro, and Swiss franc. The euro fell 0.25% to $1.1150, while the dollar gained 0.2% against the yen, reaching 120.15 yen. The Bank of Japan's tankan survey showed mixed signals, and the European Central Bank is expected to expand quantitative easing. China's economy, though still shaky, showed improvement, with inflation reports and manufacturing PMI data slightly better than expected. Economists expect the US dollar to strengthen in the medium term due to diverging monetary policies.

site_title: Sarine Tech expects Q3 revenues to halve y-o-y
summary: Sarine Technologies Ltd, a provider of precision technology products for diamonds and gems, expects Q3 revenues to halve year-over-year due to reduced demand and lower prices. The company expects an operating loss of around $1.5 million and has seen a liquidation sale of equipment, resulting in a decrease in new-equipment sales. Despite this, Sarine plans to reduce costs and launch new products, including the Meteor inclusion mapping system, which is expected to contribute to revenue growth in future years.

site_title: Manhattan home prices near million-dollar mark
summary: Manhattan home prices have reached a record high, with the median sales price for an apartment setting at $999,000 in the third quarter of 2015. This is due to a combination of high demand and limited listings, resulting in a 20% decrease in inventory and a record-low 73-day sales period. Despite this, the luxury market saw a 12% drop in average sales price, while buyers are pushing back on high-end prices, with some sellers asking for unrealistic prices.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Aspial Corp has acquired a 90% stake in World Class Global for S$14.41 million as part of a group restructuring. BBR Holdings' unit won a S$116 million design-and-build contract for a mixed-use project in Yishun Avenue 4. STATS ChipPAC has exercised early purchase options for US$200 million senior notes and US$611.152 million senior notes. These developments come amidst global market volatility, with oil prices rising over 2% and stocks in Europe and the US down due to bank and healthcare concerns, as well as US-EU tariff tensions.

site_title: UOB as it looked 80 years ago
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is celebrating its 80th anniversary by reviving its original headquarters, the Bonham Building, at its Main Branch in Raffles Place. The building, which served as UOB's headquarters from 1935 to 1970, has been recognized as a historic site by the National Heritage Board. The "dressed up" facade will remain in place until the end of the year, allowing staff and visitors to experience the bank's heritage.

site_title: Global recession? It's not happening yet, but it's a possibility
summary: The US economy is experiencing a steady recovery, but its resilience is being tested by the weakening of emerging market economies, particularly China, Brazil, and others. Economic growth in these countries has dropped by half, leading to a plunge in raw materials prices and a slowdown in global industries. Despite this, many economists believe the US recovery will survive due to strong consumer spending and low interest rates. However, a further slowdown in China could trigger a broader reaction, and governments lack the tools to combat a new slump, making a global recession a possibility, especially in the context of the US presidential election.

site_title: India's push for solar power hits obstacles
summary: India's solar power industry faces obstacles due to foreign investors offering unrealistically low rates. Companies like SkyPower Global from Toronto are undercutting local developers, including Azure Power and CLP India Pvt, in recent auctions. Local rivals claim they may not be able to match the capacity promised by foreign competitors, threatening to destabilize the industry. This could hinder India's push for solar power, which is a key part of its renewable energy goals.

site_title: As Twitter, Square interests converge, CEO Dorsey risks conflicts
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey is expected to become permanent CEO of both Twitter and Square, raising concerns about conflicts of interest, particularly in e-commerce, a key area for both companies. Dorsey has acknowledged the risk and recuses himself from decisions involving both companies, but lawyers say he would have a fiduciary duty to pursue both parties' best interests, which could pose problems. The move could impact Twitter's e-commerce strategy and potentially lead to conflicts with Square, which is expected to file for an IPO later this year.

site_title: Pritam Singh to be chairman of WP-run town council, taking over from Sylvia Lim
summary: Workers' Party MP Pritam Singh will take over as chairman of the Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC), succeeding party chairman Sylvia Lim. Lim and MP Png Eng Huat will serve as vice-chairmen. This change is part of the WP's organizational restructuring, with the party seeking to reorganize its leadership positions.

site_title: Fed rate hike may lead to a 'vicious cycle': IMF chief
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief, Christine Lagarde, expressed concern over the global economy, citing China's slowdown and a potential "vicious cycle" from a looming US interest rate hike. Lagarde stated that rising interest rates and China's economic slowdown contribute to uncertainty and higher market volatility. The IMF's warning comes as the global economy faces various challenges, including US and Chinese economic shifts.

site_title: Australian Sept home prices rise 0.9%
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.9% in September, with annual growth accelerating to 11%. Sydney's prices stagnated at 0.1%, while Melbourne rose 2.4% and Canberra increased by 1%. Perth and Darwin experienced declines, with Perth's price falling 3.9%. Tightening lending standards for property investment appear to be slowing growth, with credit advances for housing investment easing to 10.7% in August.

site_title: Headwinds expected to continue for HDB resale flats: consultants
summary: Resale prices of HDB flats in Singapore are expected to face headwinds despite a 0.3% drop in the resale price index, the smallest decline since 2013. The introduction of a higher income ceiling for new HDB flat applicants and the Mortgage Servicing Ratio (MSR) are expected to boost demand for Build-To-Order (BTO) flats and keep resale prices down. Consultants predict a 2% price fall for 2015, with some expecting a softer price drop of 2-3% for the full year.

site_title: Indonesia defends rail project after Japan angered
summary: Indonesia defended its chaotic bidding process for a $5 billion high-speed railway project after Japan was chosen over China, despite Tokyo's initial disappointment. The Indonesian government cited the Chinese bid's financial structure as the reason for the selection, as it did not require government financing or guarantees. The project is part of President Joko Widodo's infrastructure drive, with an Indonesian-Chinese consortium now negotiating the contract terms. The decision has been seen as a strategic move to balance influence between the two Asian giants.

site_title: Downtrend in private home prices picks up momentum
summary: Singapore's private home prices have dropped 1.3% in the third quarter, marking the largest quarterly decline since 2013. The overall private home price index has fallen 4.2% year-on-year, with non-landed homes in all three geographical regions experiencing price drops. Despite this, authorities are unlikely to roll back cooling measures, citing the looming economic risks, including the Chinese slowdown and US interest rate hike. Experts expect the market to remain soft, with price corrections to continue at a moderate pace, and a potential bigger price hit for suburbs in the coming quarters.

images.alt_text: The drop in private home prices gathered momentum in the third quarter.

site_title: Cash helping US fund managers, even as they look to spend it
summary: US stock mutual fund managers who held more cash in 2015 are now shopping for shares near 2015 lows. Those with higher cash reserves outperformed their peers and are preparing to buy beaten-down consumer companies. Fidelity Blue Chip Value Fund manager Sean Gavin and Monetta Fund manager Robert Bacarella are among those pulling out to invest in these companies, with Gavin holding 9% of his portfolio in cash and Bacarella holding 6%. This shift in strategy comes as managers look to capitalize on undervalued stocks.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on rise in Dow futures
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 10.96 points to 2,801.85 on October 1, 2015, in thin volume due to Hong Kong and China market closures for National Day. The gain was driven by a large Wall Street bounce and expectations of US gains, with Dow futures rising 130 points. China's PMI also rose to 49.8 in September from 49.7 in August. The three banks and Hongkong Land led the STI's rise, with 222 gains versus 152 falls in the market.

site_title: A noticeable shift in style
summary: A recent appraisal of 2014 Burgundies from Maison Joseph Faiveley highlights the quality of the negociant wines, dispelling the notion that they are inferior to "grower's" burgundies. The House of Faiveley owns several sought-after vineyards, including Musigny and Montrachet, and has been a generous host to wine experts. The appraisal praises the wines' style, noting a noticeable shift towards elegance and finesse, with notable examples including the Faiveley Bourgogne Blanc and Bourgogne Rouge. The assessment concludes that Faiveley's wines are deserving of recognition and appreciation.

site_title: British 'DIY group' turns architecture into art
summary: A British architectural collective, ASSEMBLE, has been shortlisted for the Turner Prize for its redevelopment plans of 10 Victorian houses in Liverpool. The group has blurred the lines between art and design, sparking a debate about the state of contemporary art in Britain. Their plans aim to transform the run-down Toxteth district into a unique and artistic space, challenging traditional notions of architecture and urban development.

site_title: Euro zone manufacturing growth dips in September: PMI
summary: Euro zone manufacturing growth slowed in September, with a PMI of 52.0, down from 52.3 in August. The sector's output index fell to 53.4, and growth in new orders from abroad also dipped. Despite this, factories cut prices, which could intensify deflation concerns. The European Central Bank's stimulus program may be enhanced due to the pressure from weak growth and inflation below zero. The PMI for Germany, Europe's largest economy, also fell to 52.3.

site_title: BBR unit wins S$116m contract for Yishun integrated development
summary: A unit of BBR Holdings secured a S$116 million design-and-build contract for a mixed-use development in Yishun Avenue 4, the first in Singapore to use prefabricated, prefinished volumetric construction (PPVC) technology. The project, consisting of Wisteria Mall and a residential component, will require the use of prefabricated bathrooms. The contract was awarded by a consortium that counts BBR as one of the main parties, following a 99-year leasehold plot tender in January.

site_title: Lax scrutiny, over-reliant directors behind improper financial statements: Acra
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) of Singapore has completed its first review of financial statements under an expanded surveillance programme, finding four instances of serious non-compliance among 49 listed companies. Insufficient scrutiny and over-reliance on management were identified as the root causes of non-compliance. The review found 54 instances of minor non-compliance and 74 areas of improvement, with two cases still unresolved. Acra described the state of financial reporting as "generally healthy" but with room for improvement, and will soon announce the surveillance programme's areas of focus for the fiscal 2015 financial statements.

site_title: Nicaragua canal project fraught with risks, warns consultancy
summary: Nicaragua's planned US$50 billion canal project, backed by China, is fraught with risks and uncertainties, according to an environmental consultancy. The 278 km canal project could cause more harm than good unless the government and its Chinese builder implement mitigation measures. The consultancy warned that the project's planned five-year timeline poses logistical, procurement, and workforce challenges. The report also criticized the lack of transparency from the project's builder, Hong Kong-based HK Nicaragua Canal Development Investment Co Ltd, and the potential displacement of 30,000 people. The project's completion deadline is now set for early next year.

site_title: Singapore economy in need of review: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that Singapore's economy requires a review, focusing on national security, economic and social policies, and infrastructure. He emphasized the need to create opportunities for workers, particularly in a "lean workforce," and to foster innovation and productivity. Lee also highlighted the importance of national security, citing threats from the Islamic State and tensions in the South China Sea. He appointed Coordinating Ministers for these areas, including Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean, Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, and Coordinating Minister Khaw Boon Wan.

site_title: VW says probe into pollution scam to take 'several months'
summary: Volkswagen has commissioned an independent US-based firm, Jones Day, to investigate the company's global pollution-cheating scandal. The probe, which has been ongoing since the company admitted to installing software in diesel engines to skew emission testing, is expected to take several months to complete. Volkswagen's supervisory board members believe the investigations will be finished before the company can implement any necessary changes. This move comes as the company faces widespread criticism and regulatory scrutiny over the emissions scandal.

site_title: Tale of a brilliant, fragile mind slowly crumbling
summary: Bobby Fischer, a brilliant but fragile chess prodigy, is portrayed in the film "Pawn Sacrifice" as a volatile and unpredictable individual. The 1972 world championship match between Fischer and Russian grandmaster Boris Spassky in Reykjavik is depicted as a clash of superpowers. Fischer's aggressive playing style and willingness to win rather than draw are highlighted, as he faces off against the determined Spassky. The film showcases Fischer's complex personality, balancing genius and instability, and his iconic match against Spassky remains a pivotal moment in chess history.

site_title: Stocks end higher on rise in Dow futures
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 10.96 points to 2,801.85, its second consecutive gain, driven by a large Wednesday bounce on Wall Street and expectations of US gains. China's official purchasing managers' index climbed to 49.8 in September, also supporting the STI. However, market turnover was low due to the closure of Hong Kong and China markets. Analysts, including OCBC Investment Research and Phillip Securities, expect the market to face headwinds, including a potential first rate hike and slowing US economic growth, leading to a gradual selloff.

site_title: US manufacturing sector growth eases in September: ISM
summary: The US manufacturing sector's growth eased in September, with the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) index falling to 50.2, the lowest level since May 2013. This marked a slowdown from the previous month's 51.1 and fell short of the expected 50.6. Key indicators, including new orders, prices paid, and employment, also showed declines, with the lowest levels since 2012 and 2013, respectively.

site_title: OUE to snap up extra 33.33 per cent stake in One Raffles Place owner for S$465m
summary: OUE Limited is acquiring the entire 33.33% stake in OUB Centre Limited (OUBC) for S$465.42 million. This deal will increase OUE's stake in OUBC to 83.33%, and subsequently its stake in One Raffles Place mixed-use development to 67.95%. OUBC is the registered owner of One Raffles Place, with UOB holding the remaining beneficial interest.

site_title: Singapore's PMI contracts again in September
summary: Singapore's manufacturing economy contracted for a third month in September, with the Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 48.6, down from 49.3 in August. The electronics sector PMI also contracted, falling from 49 in August to 48.5 in September. The main contributor to the contraction was a decline in new orders, export orders, and production output, while inventory and stockholdings of finished goods continued to expand.

site_title: Radio frequency 'harvesting' technology unveiled in London
summary: A new energy harvesting technology called "Freevolt" has been unveiled in London, capable of turning ambient radio frequency waves into usable electricity to charge low-power devices. Developed by Drayson Technologies and Imperial College London, the technology uses a multi-band antenna and rectifier to absorb energy from multiple radio frequency bands. The technology was demonstrated by former British science minister Paul Drayson, who showed it could power a loudspeaker using signals from mobile phones. Experts believe the technology has potential, but also raise concerns about its impact on mobile phone signals and availability of energy.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard board approves split into 2 companies
summary: Hewlett-Packard's board has approved the split of the company into two separate entities: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co and HP Inc. The split is expected to be completed on November 1. Hewlett Packard Enterprise will comprise corporate hardware and services, trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol "HPE", while HP Inc will focus on computers and printers. The move aims to simplify the company's operations and focus on core businesses.

site_title: Indonesia to unveil third batch of economic stimulus steps next week: cabinet secretary
summary: Indonesia plans to unveil its third batch of economic stimulus measures next week, aiming to attract investors and boost economic growth. The cabinet secretary announced that the new measures will include faster permit processing times, with applications in industrial zones to be acted on in no more than three hours. This is part of the government's ongoing efforts to revive economic growth.

site_title: Eurozone banks still face profitability squeeze, credit risk: Nouy
summary: Eurozone banks face a squeeze on profitability due to weak growth and volatile financial conditions, with many needing to review their business models to remain profitable. According to ECB head Daniele Nouy, rising asset prices and low interest rates contribute to the challenge, with a focus on non-performing exposures and real estate concentrations remaining a priority for banks. Significant credit risk remains a concern, particularly for banks in the euro area.

site_title: Uber campaigns against tough rules proposed in London
summary: Uber has launched a petition with over 116,000 signatures opposing proposed regulations in London that would require ride-sharing drivers to pass English language and map reading tests. The proposed rules, proposed by Transport for London, also include stricter insurance requirements and a minimum 5-minute gap between bookings and journey start. Uber claims the rules will harm riders, drivers, and London, and the company's British branch has stated it will not introduce rules that will be "bad for riders, drivers and London." The consultation on the proposals ends on December 23.

site_title: Porsche recalls close to 60,000 vehicles over leak
summary: Porsche is recalling nearly 60,000 Macan S and Macan Turbo vehicles due to potential engine leaks in a low-pressure fuel line. The recall affects 58,881 cars worldwide, including 21,835 in the US, 3,490 in Canada, and 3,641 in Germany. Owners will be contacted by local dealers to perform a one-hour repair. This comes as Volkswagen, Porsche's parent company, faces ongoing probes over its role in the global emissions scandal and booked its first quarterly loss in over 15 years.

site_title: Indians declare US$500m in black money in tax crackdown
summary: India's government announced that 600 tax evaders declared $574 million in black money, a fraction of the estimated $439 billion hidden abroad. The declaration, made within a three-month window, included assets in foreign bank accounts and property. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has pledged to crack down on black money, but experts doubt the government's ability to find the money offshore due to the phenomenon's deep-rooted nature. The government has introduced measures, including a 10-year jail term for evaders, to combat black money.

site_title: IMF urges US Fed to be cautious in hiking rates
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the US Federal Reserve to be cautious when considering a rate hike, warning that rapid tightening could lead to a reversal and loss of credibility. The IMF cited risks tied to labor market slack, inflation, and wages, as well as potential global financial instability. A rate rise could also drive the dollar higher, negatively impacting US exports, and force the Fed to reverse direction. The IMF advises the US and other G-20 economies to implement strong medium-term plans to address debt and economic imbalances.

site_title: US: Wall St slips as Apple shares fall
summary: US stocks fell in early trading on Thursday, led by a 2.1% decline in Apple shares, bringing the Dow Jones down. The decline erased opening gains for US stocks. Investors await US data, including non-farm payroll numbers due Friday, which may influence the timing of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The US stock market posted its worst quarter in four years, while the Shanghai stock market plummeted 25% in the last quarter.

site_title: Oil trade giant and Trafigura founder Dauphin dies
summary: Trafigura founder Claude Dauphin, a prominent oil trader, died at 64 after a battle with cancer in Bogota, Colombia. Dauphin founded Trafigura in 1993 and transformed it into a top global oil and commodities trader, with a turnover of $127 billion. He spent 20 years traveling the world, expanding the company's ties with Russia's Rosneft and making strategic partnerships. Dauphin was also involved in a 2006-7 dispute in Ivory Coast, where Trafigura faced allegations of toxic waste dumping, resulting in a $200 million settlement.

images.alt_text: Described by colleagues and rivals alike as a man of formidable drive, Mr Dauphin over the past decade took a very different approach to developing his company from that of Glencore.

site_title: Tsinghua deal to connect Western Digital to powerful China tech set
summary: Western Digital Corp has agreed to a $3.8 billion deal with Tsinghua Holdings Co, a unit of state-owned Tsinghua University, to acquire a 15% stake in the US data storage firm. The deal aims to connect Western Digital to a network of influential China tech players, as Beijing ramps up efforts to develop chip expertise. This follows Tsinghua's $23 billion acquisition of US chipmaker Micron Technology Inc, raising US security concerns. The deal may face similar challenges due to Tsinghua's Chinese government affiliation.

site_title: Glencore tells investors debt cutting on track
summary: Glencore, a commodities trading company, has told investors it is on track to cut its debt by selling assets, reducing capital expenditure, and raising new equity capital. The company aims to reduce its net debt to $20 billion from $30 billion. Glencore has also secured $50 billion in credit lines from banks and plans to sell a stake in its agricultural business by next year and complete a streaming deal by the end of the year. Barclays analysts believe Glencore is not at risk of imminent default and can retain its investment-grade credit rating.

site_title: PM Lee stresses urgency of leadership renewal
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stressed the urgency of leadership renewal, aiming to have a new team ready after the next elections. He entrusted younger ministers with major responsibilities and relied on older ministers for depth and breadth. Lee highlighted the need for economic review, focusing on creating opportunities and driving higher skills, innovation, and productivity in a challenging global environment.

site_title: Smooth operator
summary: Citroen has updated the C4 Picasso with a new 6-speed automatic transmission and Euro 6 turbodiesel engine, offering improved smoothness and efficiency. The new powertrain reduces nitrogen oxide emissions by up to 90% and CO2 emissions by 4% compared to the previous Euro 5 version. The C4 Picasso now boasts a 300 Newton-metres of torque and a low CO2 emission of 101 g/km. The vehicle's spacious interior and comfortable ride remain unchanged, making it an attractive option for those seeking a smooth drive and eco-friendly features.

site_title: Toshiba may lay off appliances, TV and PC workers: CEO
summary: Toshiba Corp may lay off staff in its underperforming home appliances, TV, and PC businesses as part of an overhaul following a $1.3 billion accounting scandal. CEO Masashi Muromachi plans to seek partnerships for its nuclear operations. The company has launched a new management team, approved by shareholders, to address the issues.

site_title: Opening that blocked artery
summary: A recent update by the American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology Foundation recommends that patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for a major heart attack have multiple blocked heart arteries treated during the same hospitalization, rather than just the culprit blockage, to reduce the risk of a second heart attack. Newer stents with thinner metallic struts and bioabsorbable polymer coatings can also help minimize damage to the arterial wall and promote healing. Pre-planning with a computed tomography (CT) scan prior to PCI can ensure choosing the right stent size and minimize complications.

site_title: Australian retailer David Jones chief in shock resignation
summary: David Jones' chief executive Ian Nairn has resigned after 14 months, citing personal reasons. Woolworths Holdings, the parent company, has appointed John Dixon, a Marks & Spencer veteran, to replace him. Dixon's appointment reflects Woolworths' long-term strategy to boost the David Jones business. Nairn's departure may allow Woolworths to focus on improving its food halls and expanding its food retail market share. Dixon will help settle into the new role over the next three months.

site_title: More rooftop recreation in Japanese commercial buildings
summary: Rooftop recreation is becoming increasingly popular in Japanese commercial buildings, with various green spaces and recreational facilities emerging. Vegetable gardens, parks, and running tracks are being incorporated into shopping centers and department stores, attracting customers and contributing to the environment. The trend is driven by regulations requiring greenery on new buildings and a desire to attract customers. Since 2000, about 413.8 hectares of rooftop gardens have been set up, and the trend is expected to continue, with commercial facilities using rooftop greening to contribute to their profits.

site_title: S&P downgrades Saudi Arabia on oil price slide
summary: Standard and Poor's downgraded Saudi Arabia's long-term credit rating to A+ due to a sharply rising deficit caused by low oil prices. The ratings agency maintained a negative outlook, warning that further downgrades could occur if Riyadh fails to reduce the general government deficit. The decision reflects the challenges of reversing the "marked deterioration" in the Saudi fiscal balance.

site_title: Japan still suffers butter deficit despite trade pact
summary: Japan's butter shortage persists despite a trade pact, with a chronic lack of dairy farmers and high import duties limiting supply. The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal agreed in October does not loosen curbs on butter imports, prompting industry officials and analysts to say Tokyo is wary of upsetting farmers. The shortage has been fueled by aging population and younger people moving away from rural areas, with consumers paying up to four times more than buyers abroad. The government may repeat emergency imports, benefiting key dairy exporters like New Zealand and the Netherlands.

site_title: ECB to say how much Greek banks need to survive
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to announce that Greece's battered banks require up to 14 billion euros in fresh capital to survive. The banks, including National Bank of Greece and Piraeus, face a capital gap of 4.5 billion euros under a baseline scenario, which could rise to 14 billion euros under a stress scenario. The ECB's announcement comes after years of economic decline in Greece and a recent bailout stand-off between the country's government and international lenders.

site_title: MAS proposes margin requirements for 'uncleared' OTC derivatives
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposed imposing margin requirements on nearly all over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives not cleared by a central counterparty, aiming to make trading safer. The exceptions include physically settled foreign-exchange forwards and swaps. The MAS plans to implement the requirements in phases, starting with banks, and invites comments by November 1. The move is part of broader global reforms to reduce counterparty risks.

site_title: UIC Q3 net profit rises 9% to S$65.3m
summary: UIC, a Singapore property company, reported a 9% increase in net profit to S$65.28 million for Q3 FY2015, driven by a 25% expansion in trading property sales. Revenue rose 6% to S$189.35 million, despite a 4% decline in hotel operations and a 2% drop in gross rental income from investment properties. The group expects CBD office demand to remain "subdued and steady."

site_title: BT-EE merger wins provisional British regulator clearance
summary: Britain's Competition and Markets Authority provisionally cleared BT's 12.5 billion pound deal to buy mobile operator EE, creating the country's leading broadband, fixed line, and mobile provider. The decision, made on October 28, 2015, does not expect the merger to significantly lessen competition in the UK market. Rivals, including Vodafone, expressed disappointment, citing concerns about BT's dominance in supplying backhaul services and wholesale lines.
